text:
ABDON, BONIFACIO (Bonifacio Abdon) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 14 May 1876. d. Manila 23 Apr 1944. Violinist, conductor, composer, teacher. Abdon was the son of Gregorio Abdon, a carpenter and goldsmith, and his first wife, Juliana, who died when the boy was only seven. He was married to Felisa Mariano, playwright Patricio Mariano’s sister. They had five children. He bought himself a fife, and to escape reprimands and whipping, ran away to Pandacan which was then famous for its artists and musicians and where his grandfather, Juan de Dios Abdon, lived. Abdon was sent to Mundong Bulag (Raymundo Fermin) who taught him solfeggio and later to the Ateneo Municipal to be a tiple in its choir. At age 13, he studied violin under LadislaoBonus, and later learned something about conducting and score reading under Maestros Morino and Cavalleri who were conducting for visiting Italian opera companies.

In 1902, Abdon was invited to direct the orchestra of YeyengFernandez’s zarzuela group. Later he joined the Orquesta Rizal of Carmelo. In 1910, he founded and organized the Orquesta Oriental. Two years later, the AsociacionMusicaldeFilipinas was formed, and he became its first musical director. He was also one of the founding members of the ManilaChamberMusicSociety which was set up in 1921. That year also marked the formation of the String Quartet in which he played first violin. He found time to hold violin lessons at his residence on Escaldo Street in Quiapo, which came to be known as the Escuela de Violin. In 1920, he became a violin instructor at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, and later at the Instituto de Mujeres and the Philippine Lyric Academy. Among his pupils were ErnestoVallejo, RamonTapales, Ramon Mendoza, and Antonio Lozano.

Abdon composed music for the Tagalog sarsuwela. In 1901, he finished his first score for the sarsuwela Ang Sampaguita (The Sampaguita). He also composed in 1908 the music for Patricio Mariano’s Deni, Ang Tulisan (The Bandit), Luha’t Dugo (Tears and Blood), and Ang Anak ng Dagat (The Child of the Sea); AurelioTolentino’s La Rosa (The Rose), La Boda Maldita (The Accursed Nuptials), Crimen Sobre Crimen (Crime Upon Crime), and Manila Cinematografica (Manila of the Cinema); and PantaleonLopez’s Delingkwente (Delinquent), as well as MaximinodelosReyes’s Ang Mag-anak (The Family) and Kundangan (If It Were Not For). Some of his songs, like “Bibingka” (Rice Cake) from Ang Anak ng Dagat, became so popular as they were mistaken for folksongs.

His most notable song was “Kundiman,” 1920, also known as the “Kundiman ni Abdon” (Abdon’s Kundiman), which he composed for visiting Russian Bogumil Sykora who wanted to play a native piece in the concert he was conducting for the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas. Other compositions include Misang Tagalog sa Balintawak (Tagalog Mass in Balintawak), composed ca 1910 for the Aglipayan Church, “Romanza” (Romance), “Ang Masamang Kaugalian” (Bad Manners), “Carnaval” (Carnival), “Huwag Lang Lugi sa Puhunan” (Just Break Even), “In Memoriam,” “Antipolo,” “Paghihinakit” (Hurting), “Awit ng Pulubi” (Beggar’s Song), and “IbongAdarna” (Adarna Bird). His cantata O! Dios sa Kalangitan! (Oh! God in Heaven!) used Tagalog pasyon melodies.

Abdon conducted concerts and operas for the Manila Chamber Music Society, among them: Verdi’s Requiem Mass in 1923, Tchaikovsky’s Piano Concerto in B-flat major in 1924, and Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9 in D minor in 1925; and, in cooperation with VictorinoCarrion’s Schola Cantorum, Verdi’s Aida and La Traviata, 1933, Il Travatore, 1934, and Donizetti’s Lucia di Lammermoor, 1935. Written byNicanor G. Tiongson

ABEJO, ROSALINA (Rosalina Abejo) b. Misamis Oriental 13 Jul 1922. d. 5 June 1991. Composer, conductor. Aunt of music educator Sr Mary Placid Abejo OSB and grandaunt of composer Joed Balsamo. She finished her associate in music in piano at St Scholastica’s College in 1949, and her master of music in composition at Philippine Women’s University in 1957. She took further studies at Labunski School of Composition in Ohio, the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, and Catholic University of America in Washington DC, 1963-64. She was dean of St Mary’s College School of Music, and secretary of the LeagueofFilipinoComposers, 1967-77.

She left the Religious of the Virgin Mary in 1976, and joined the International Sisters for Christian Community in the United States in 1979. She headed the music department of St Pius X Seminary in Kentucky.

She wrote many compositions in symphonic, chamber, and choral music genres. Some of her works are: Aeolian Piano Concerto, 1949; the cantata The Conversion of King Humabon (Ang Pagbabago ni Haring Humabon), 1967; the oratorio Pagtubos (Salvation), 1969; The Trilogy of Man Symphony, 1971; Overture 1081, 1974; and Pag-ibig sa Tinubuang Bayan (Love for the Native Land), 1979. Her chambermusic pieces include Maranaw Trail for two marimbas, piano, and percussions, 1971. She also composed operettas, masses, and hymns.

She received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award 1967; the Mother Battig Centennial Recognition, 1970; and the Tandang Sora Award, 1975. Written by Ramon Jocson, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

ABELARDO, NICANOR (Nicanor Santa Ana Abelardo) b. San Miguel de Mayumo, Bulacan 7 Feb 1893. d. Manila 21 Mar 1934. Composer, pianist, teacher. He was the eldest of the eight children of Valentin Abelardo, a photographer, and Placida Santa Ana, a church singer. He was a cousin of movie director and visual effects artist RichardAbelardo and cinematographer Bayani Abelardo, and nephew to Richard and Bayani’s father, scenic painter, JuanAbelardo. In 1917, he married Sixta Naguiat, a taquillera (movie-ticket seller). Their marriage bore six children, two of whom—Nicanor Jr and Cresencio—became musicians. His father taught him solfeggio and bandurria when he was five. At six, he could already play William Tell Overture on the guitar. In 1901, at age eight, Abelardo composed “Ang Unang Buko” (First Bud), a waltz dedicated to his grandmother. The following year, he was brought by his uncle, the painter Juan Abelardo, to Manila, where he studied in several primary schools. While working for his uncle, he learned to play the piano, and later studied voice under Italian maestro Enrico Capozzi who refused to be paid for teaching such a talented boy. Upon the recommendation of FranciscoBuencamino, he was hired to play at saloons and cabarets at age 13. After finishing the sixth grade in 1908, Abelardo left Manila and, barely 15, took on a teaching job in barrio schools in San Ildefonso and San Miguel, Bulacan. Soon, Abelardo was invited back to the city by his uncle Juan. To support himself and his young family, he worked as a pianist in pubs and theaters in Manila.

It was not until 1916, however, that he decided to study at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, taking courses under Guy F. Harrison and Robert Schofield. While in UP, he composed “UP Beloved,” a school hymn which won first prize in an open musical composition contest in 1917. The faculty of the Conservatory instantly noticed his musical ability and, in 1918, he was appointed as assistant instructor in solfeggio and harmony. He became a full-fledged instructor in 1919. He took formal lessons in voice culture under VictorinoCarrion, and piano under JoseEstella. He received his teacher’s certificate in science and composition in 1921. In 1922, he took up a postgraduate course at the Conservatory, which he completed in 1923. The following year, he became the head of the composition department of the Conservatory. Early in 1931, he was sent to the Chicago Musical College, where he took courses towards a master’s degree. He won the Le Violette scholarship, but came back in 1932 without a degree. He later finished his degree at the National University.

Upon his return to the Philippines, Abelardo resumed teaching at the Conservatory and ran a boarding school where his students associated with him. He busied himself writing various compositions. Among his students were AntoninoBuenaventura, AlfredoLozano, and LucinoT.Sacramento.

A prolific composer of artsong-kundiman, he redefined this genre and elevated it to artistic heights through his compositions like “NasaanKaIrog?” (Where Are You, My Love?), 1923; “KundimanngLuha” (Kundiman of Tears), 1924; “Magbalik Ka Hirang” (Come Back, My Love), 1925; “MutyangPasig” (Muse of Pasig), 1926; “Himutok” (Plaint), 1928; “Ikaw Rin” (It’s Up to You), 1929; and “Paghanga” (Admiration), 1939.

Abelardo also composed music for the sarsuwela. For Kawanggawa (Charity), 1918, he composed four songs with lyrics by Felix A. Roxas. For Servandodelos Angeles, he did Dakilang Punglo (Noble Bullet), 1926, which has the popular songs “Ang Puso Kong Nalulumbay” (My Sorrowful Heart) and “BituingMarikit” (Beautiful Star); and Tayo’y Pakasal Na (Let’s Get Married), 1930. He also composed for Basilio Lanuza’s Kapabayaan o Bunga ng Masamang Hilig (Negligence or Result of a Bad Habit), 1918, and Sumilang (Risen); and Danding Gabriel’s Ang Tala ng Universidad (The University’s Star). He also did the music for the sarsuwela Lucila, 1911; the operetta Akibat (Affiliation), 1913, and Ang Likha ni Pierrot o Batik ng Kabihasnan (Pierrot’s Creation or A Trace of Civilization), 1931, both by FlorentinoBallecer; Ang Mestiza (The Mestiza), 1922, by EngracioValmonte; and for the sarsuwela Makabagong Dalaga (Modern Lady) and Ang Batang Tulisan (The Young Bandit), 1934.

His other songs in different musical forms include “Kung Hindi Man” (Would It Not Be So), 1920, transcribed from an original love song for voice, violin, cello, and piano; “Ang Aking Bayan” (My Country), a patriotic song; “Bonifacio Song” and “Paraluman” (Muse), a waltz-song, both in 1922; “Pahimakas” (Farewell), a song for a dying person, 1925; “Himutok” (Lament), 1928; “May Isang Bulaklak na Ibig Lumitaw” (There’s a Flower Wishing to Bloom), 1929; “Kung Ako’y Umibig” (If I Were To Love) and “Naku … Kenkoy!” (Gosh … Kenkoy!), 1930.

His works include Mountain Suite and “Ave Maria,” a sacred song for tenor or soprano with violin obligato, and Cavatina for violin and piano, all in 1921; Concerto in B-flat minor, 1923, the first concerto ever written in the country which uses folk themes; “Stabat Mater,” for voice, piano, organ, with violin obligato, 1924; Sonata for violin and piano, Cinderella Overture, Panoramas, a suite for flute, violin, viola, celesta, and piano, and Sinfoniette for orchestra, all in 1931; Salve Regina Mater, 1932; Misa de Requiem, 1934, and many others. His 1931 works show influences from modern 20th century art music compositions and for these he is considered the “Father of Music Modernism” in the country.

Abelardo died in 1934 leaving more than 140 works, an unfinished symphony, an opera, and a concerto. For his mastery of compositional techniques and fluency in expressing musical ideas that are uniquely Filipino, he is often considered the greatest Filipino composer ever. The UP College of Music and the main theater of the Cultural Center of the Philippines are both named in recognition of his pioneering musical achievement and of his pride for local music. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

ABRAHAM, EDRU (Pedro Reyes Abraham Jr) b. Tuguegarao, Cagayan 21 Jun 1947. Composer, singer, arranger, actor, choreographer, dancer, writer, producer. He is the son of Boutros Brahim Fahkry (Pedro Abraham), a Lebanese, and Josefina Pagulayan Reyes. He is married to singer BeckyDemetillo with whom he has two children, Apollo and Astarte, both performing artists. He finished his speech and drama course in 1971 at the University of the Philippines (UP) where he also obtained his master of arts degree in art history in 1981. Abraham started his teaching career as an instructor at UP Los Baños Department of Speech, Theater Arts and Humanities in 1976. For most of his career, he taught at the Department of Arts Studies, UP College of Arts and Letters until his retirement in 2012. He continues to serve as professorial lecturer in the same department. As the Philippine representative to the ASEAN Cultural Exchange Program in 1983, he studied Indonesian dance, music, and theater in Padepokan Seni Bagong Kussudiarja in Jogyakarta, Indonesia. In 1986 and 1987, he took part in the International Human Rights Internship Program in the United Kingdom.

He performed with the UPConcertChorus as well as with the FilipinescasDanceCompany, which was founded by National Artist for dance, Leonor Orosa Goquingco. For Filipinescas, he performed in various capacities as singer, instrumentalist, dancer, and choreographer, and a member of this company from 1965-71. He directed numerous programs, as choreographer and director of the Himig ng Lahi (Song of the Race), which went on tour to the United States and Canada from 1979-81. The Himig ng Lahi is a story of the Filipino people in song, an ensemble founded and directed by National Artist for music Felipe Padilla de Leon. The Legend of May-i, a dance drama was also directed by Abraham in 1986. In UP, he was active in cultural research and served as resource person for many cultural tours. Abraham joined the UP Filipiniana Dance Troupe, in its 1982-83 Southeast Asian Tours.

Abraham has 100 instrumental pieces to his credit, as well as 100 song compositions, 20 of which have been professionally recorded. He performed several of his compositions in a concert titled Dalawang Makata, Dalawang Musikero, Isang Konsyerto (Two Poets, Two Musicians, One Concert) in Jan 1989. In August of that year, he scored the music for DulaangUP’s staging of Isang Dulang Panaginip (A Dream Play) by August Strindberg. He joined his fellow artists—singer Susan Fernandez-Magno, guitarist Lester Demetillo, and poets EdgardoB.Maranan and DomingoLandicho—in Alay Ani (Harvest Offering), a concert of songs and poetry. This presentation was eventually made part of Cultural Center of the Philippines’ outreach initiatives in 1990 with 25 performances countrywide. As musical director, he did Dulaang UP’s Gironiere, 1991, and has provided the songs for its production of Ang Alkalde ng Zalamea (The Governor of Zalamea), 1991, and the dances and chants for And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, 1992.

In 1989, he organized the ethnic music and dance ensemble called Kontemporaryong Gamelan Pilipino popularly known as Kontra-Gapi or KG, which is an all-original integrative performing group that combines songs, music, mime, and dance. In Abraham’s words, Kontra-Gapi means “breaking away from something narrow, limiting space or narrow musical parameters” and is “a political statement against the Filipino’s unnecessary confinement to Western music,” discovering “other types of music closer to our center of gravity and our sphere of influence.” In a span of four years, the group has given over 500 performances in different types of venues. Abraham toured with Kontra-Gapi to Asia, Australia. Europe and North America for concert performances, lectures and demonstrations, music and dance workshops, and for Philippine culture and national heritage consultations. The Kontra-Gapi was made the UP College of Arts and Letters resident ethnic music and dance ensemble in 1993. They had produced two cassette albums titled World Beat / World Music – Filipino and Gong at Ritmo, Lunggating Pilipino (Gong and Rhythm, Filipino Aspiration). Abraham also produced, composed, and arranged the cassette titled Edru Abraham at ang Kontemporaryong Gamelan Pilipino (Edru Abraham and the Contemporary Filipino Gamelan).

Abraham received the UP Gawad Chanselor in 1996, a plaque for exemplary achievement in the performing arts. He was also given the UP Outstanding Artist in the Performing Arts Award for International Achievement in 2000; named as Defender of Our Cultural Heritage in the Fookien Times yearly publication in 2005; and was officially declared “a favorite son in Tuguegarao, Cagayan” for Outstanding Achievement in Culture and Arts. He became a national committee member on culture in the UNESCO from 2004 to 2010. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Josephine Baradas

ABROGAR-QUINTO, NITA (Anita Velez Abrogar-Quinto) b. Cagayan de Oro 17 Jan 1951. d. Quezon City 26 Feb 2014. Piano soloist, collaborating pianist, and piano teacher. She was the daughter of Alipio Abrogar and Caridad Velez, who was the younger sister of Manuel “Maning” Velez, the composer of the art song balitaw “Sa Kabukiran.” She was married to Benjamin Abrogar with whom she had two children.

Nita grew up in a musical family. She started piano lessons with her mother at age four and gave her first public recital at age 12. She later enrolled in Lourdes College, Cagayan de Oro, where she studied piano under Mela Velez-Malferrari, a first cousin of her mother. She entered the UP College of Music in the late 1960s, studying under Regalado Jose, and earned a bachelor’s degree in music (piano) in 1971 and a master’s degree (piano) in 1973. Her studies were marked with outstanding achievements: private scholar of Gertrudis del Rosario and winner of the Beethoven Piano Competition. Under a British Council Scholarship, she pursued postgraduate studies in London, England and earned a certificate in advanced studies at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in 1975. Her mentors were James Gibb and Nelly Nen-Or, the latter famous for the Alexander Technique. For the graduation requirement in which she got the second highest honors throughout the British Isles in the licentiate diploma examinations, she was awarded a silver medal.

Her artistry as soloist is affirmed by a record of performances with leading local symphony orchestras conducted by Regalado Jose, Helen Quach, and Josefino Toledo. Quinto is most remembered for her performance of Nicanor Abelardo’s Piano Concerto in B-flat minor, which she revived during the one hundredth birth centenary of Abelardo in 1997 and which she played again, miraculously after fighting an advanced stage of cancer, in 2010 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), with the UP Orchestra conducted by Edna Marcil Martinez. She also played in many well-received solo piano recitals in various venues in the country and abroad. In 1999, she was featured in the CCP Filipino Artists Series.

For her gift as collaborative pianist, she was much sought after by chamber artists and solo musicians. Her commitment as an effective and eminent piano pedagogue is manifested in the number of piano students she had who became winners, soloists, collaborative artists in the local and international scene. Her outstanding students include Charisse Baldoria and Gabriel Allan Paguirigan.

She was chair of the UP College of Music Piano Department in 2005-07 and board member of the Piano Teachers’ Guild of the Philippines in 2004-06.

In recognition of her achievements, she received the Outstanding Graduate Award in college and was elected to the Phi Kappa Phi International Honor Society for Academic Excellence. Written by Mauricia Borromeo, with additional notes by Jose S. Buenconsejo

ABUCAY BAND ’91 Abucay, Bataan. The Abucay Band has existed since 1810. It has been under several recamaderos (owners of bands), the first of whom was known as Apeng Malixi, a resident of Abucay, Bataan. After several years, it was turned over to Tandang Bastian then to another owner Santos Delfin, also a resident of Abucay. The last recamadero to finance and maintain the band around the end of the 19th century was Idrong Pague. Some known conductors and directors of the band since then were Taburio from Orion, Bataan, Lucino Buenaventura of Baliuag, Bulacan, and Pedro Navarro of Ilocos Sur.

Beginning the 20th century, the band was no longer under any recamadero. Band members grouped themselves into an association (samahan) and elected amongst themselves the manager of the band called encargado. During this time, conductors were David Toribio of Hermosa, Bataan and Narciso Manlapaz of Abucay who was in active duty in the US Navy Band. Manlapaz then transferred the directorship to Mariano B. Danque Sr, a retired US Army musician. During the Japanese occupation, Mariano Danque evacuated to another province and the directorship passed on to Perfecto Adrid, a retired US Navy Band musician from Cavite who married a woman from Abucay. After the occupation, a son of Mariano Danque Sr took music courses at the UP Conservatory of Music and consequently graduated with bachelor of music degrees in conducting and composition. Mariano Danque Jr took over the directorship and led the band to new heights, gaining several awards and trophies from concert and parade competitions. The band became known for its performances in civic activities that were sponsored by the Abucay Society. They had given free concerts to the sick and disabled veterans at the Veterans Memorial Hospital and V. Luna Hospital. Written by Rodney D. S. Ambat

ACOYMO, RAMON (Ramon Gamer Acoymo) aka Montet Acoymo. b. Paco, Manila 30 Jan 1959. Singer, arranger, music and stage director, voice teacher. He is the son of Augusto Acoymo, an amateur violinist, from Iloilo City and Luz Gamer, a pianist from Roxas City, Capiz. He heard music from his parents at an early age and, beginning age five, intermittently studied piano. He enrolled in La Salle Greenhills Grade School and was a boy soprano soloist in the school choir in grades one and two. He continued engagement with music in his entire high school at La Salle Greenhills, and was a member of Kundirana, where he was a soloist and arranger. In this period, he won first prize in the Interscholastic High School Voice Competition held in Don Bosco High School in 1973. His involvement with Kundirana continued in his later life when he served as a creative director of the group in its international tours in 1983-90 and in 2005-09.

Acoymo entered the University of the Philippines (UP) and graduated with a biology degree, cum laude, in 1979. He became a soloist for the UP Concert Chorus in 1976 and joined the Philippine Madrigal Singers in 1976-81 and in 1992-93. While teaching biology in UP for a year in 1983-84, he enrolled in the voice degree program at UP College of Music and finished his music degree in 1988, magna cum laude. Beginning 1992, he got fellowships in the universities of Wyoming, Mississippi, and Cincinnati. At the University of Wyoming, he finished a master’s degree in vocal performance. At the University of Mississippi, he studied vocal pedagogy. At the University of Cincinnati, he took up music education and arts administration. He completed his doctorate degree in history and philosophy of education at UP in 2005.

As a solo tenor, Acoymo has performed in concerts at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), such as with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 1998 and in the Filipino Artist Series in 1999, in the Bamboo Organ Festival of 2006, in Concert Nights at the Old Walls in Intramuros and in Alice Tully Hall, Weill Hall, and Merkin Concert Hall in New York City from 1995 to 1998. He also did solo performances in Denver, 1993-94; New Jersey, 1982 and 1998; and in Bonn, Freiburg, and Heidelberg in Germany, 1998; Bangkok, Thailand, 2000, 2004, 2005, 2006; in Vietnam, 2004; and in Florence Italy, 2010.

In the world of opera, he appeared in the lead role of Lucrecia Kasilag’s Ang Pagong at ang Matsing (The Turtle and the Monkey) with Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 1984, as Tamino in the Manila Symphony Orchestra’s Mozart’s Magic Flute in 1998; in the title role in Stravinsky’s Oedipus Rex in UP in 1998; as Macduff in Verdi’s Macbeth of Repertory Philippines in 2003; as Sharpless in CCP’s Madame Butterfly with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 2005; as Monastatos in the Magic Flute at the University of Mississippi in 2005; as Canio in Leoncavallo’s Pagliacci in CCP in 2006; as Aeneas in Dido and Aeneas in PhilAm Life, 2007; and the title role of Handel’s Xerxes at CCP in 2009.

For UP, Acoymo has directed operas for the stage like Floyd’s Susannah, 2006; Donizetti’s L’Elisir d’Amore, 2006; and Pergolesi’s La Serva Padrona, 2006. He also directed Mozart’s Der Schauspieldirektor for CCP in 2006; Dido and Aeneas at Philamlife Auditorim, 2007; and Opera Portraits in Mahidol University in 2011. As music director of popular music theater, he did Repertory Philippines’ Pippin, 1988; Kismet, 1989; and Miong, 1990. He also directed the dance musical Bahaghari: A Celebration of the Philippine Spirit, in cooperation with the New Jersey State Arts Council in 1996. He published a rare album of art songs titled Art Songs for a New Millenium, which contains some of his compositions and arrangements of folk songs in 2004.

Acoymo has been teaching in UP College of Music since 1997. He has also been active in administrative duties on top of his creative career. He was dean of the College of Music from 2004 to 2010, and is the incumbent Chair of the Department of Voice, Music Theater, and Dance. For his artistic achievement, he won the US National Association of Teachers in Singing Voice Competition in 1993; and garnered the Best Male Classical Performer trophy in the Aliw Awards in 2006, 2007, and 2008, after which he was elevated to the Hall of Fame. His work with Kundirana had been partly responsible for its Aliw Awards in 1985 and 1986 as the Best Cultural Group in the Philippines. He was recognized with the University of the Philippines Artist Award in 2009. Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

ADONAY, MARCELO (Marcelo Quiteria Adonay) b. Pakil, Laguna 6 Feb 1848. d. Manila 8 Feb 1928. Composer, conductor, teacher. Adonay is the eldest of 11 children born to the peasant couple Mariano Adonay and Prudencia Quiteria. He married Maria Vasquez of Malolos, Bulacan in 1874. They had 13 children. Because of his family’s poverty, the young Adonay was entrusted to the care of the priests at San Agustin Church in Manila who soon discovered his innate musicality. Largely self-taught, Adonay mastered the organ, the violin, the contrabass, and the trumpet.

Eventually he was appointed maestro di capella (choirmaster) at San Agustin Church in Manila where he also directed the church orchestra, which included four of his brothers, until 1914. He taught music at several schools: San Sebastian, Santa Rosa, Santa Catalina, and La Compania de Jesus, and at the houses of rich families like that of Francisco Roxas. As conductor, Adonay is best remembered for the premiere performance in the Philippines of Beethoven’s Missa Solemnis in D major in 1887.

Together with other maestros and aficionados of the era, Adonay was a founding member of the first musicians’ union in the Philippines, the Union Artistica Musical, in 1885. He also taught solfeggio, harmony, and composition in the Centro de Bellas Artes in 1902, and became a member of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas in 1912.

By 1869, Adonay had already written two major works: “Benedictus, El Canto de Zacarias” (Benedictus, the Song of Zacarias) for voices and string quartet, and “Libera Me Domine” (Liberate Me, Oh Lord) for solo voices with contrabass accompaniment. Among his other major works are: “Gozos a La Santisima Virgen: a Nuestra Señora de la Consolacion” (Paean to the Most Holy Virgin Our Lady of Consolation), 1890; “O Vita Jesus” (Oh Jesus, Life), 1891, for voices and orchestra; “A San Pascual Bailon en Obando” (To San Pascual Bailon in Obando), 1894; “Responsarium,” 1894, usually sung during Christmas; “Benedictus,” 1895, scored for tenor solo with English horn and harp obligato, which shows Adonay’s penchant for unusual instrumental combinations; “Hossana,” 1899; Grand Mass and Te Deum for orchestra, 1903; Pequeña Misa Solemne (Short Solemn Mass) based on the Mass on a Gregorian Chant Motive by Dumont, 1904; “A Nuestra Señora de Antipolo” (To Our Lady of Antipolo), 1909; “A San Juan Bautista” (To Saint John the Baptist), 1916; “Via Crucis” (Way of the Cross) nos. 1-5, “Salve Regina,” “Villancico a Belen Pastores” (Carol of the Shepherds), “Rosario de Difunto” (Rosary for the Deceased), “Salve a Solo y Septimino” (Salve for Solo and Septet), and “La Procesion de Turumba en Pakil” (The Turumba Procession in Pakil). His secular works include “Rizal Glorified,” 1911, the last of a seven-part work on Rizal’s life by seven composers for symphony orchestra; “Himno Pakileño” (Pakil Hymn), 1921; “Meditacion Lugubre no. 2: A mi nieta Julita Maulawin” (Gloomy Meditation no. 2: for my niece, Julita Maulawin); “Meditacion Lugubre no. 3: A mi amigo Felipe San Gaspar” (Gloomy Meditation no. 3: for my friend, Felipe San Gaspar); and “Tocata en Do Mayor,” 1921, written at the request of Col Walter Loving.

An extensive research on the contributions of Adonay by a team of musicologists and historians headed by Elena Rivera Mirano led to the publication of The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay in two volumes, in 2009. Written by Julia Ann Hallazgo, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

AEGIS - This local band was formed in 1998 under Alpha Records. It is composed of six members: vocalists Juliet, Mercy, and Ken Sunot, keyboardist Stella Pabico, vocalist and lead guitarist Rey Abenoja, bass guitarist Rowena Adriano, and drummer Vilma Goloviogo. Named thus from the two initials of their former band, AG Soundtrippers, after the managers Abenoja-Galindo, the name was shortened by Alvin de Vera to AG’s, which also tapped into the significance of aegis (protection) as the band has lasted more than a decade where other bands have disbanded due to intrigue and politicking.

The band has released 10 albums in its career, including Halik (Kiss), 1999, Mahal na Mahal Kita (I Love You Very Much), 2000, Awit at Pag-Ibig (Songs and Love), 2001, Paskong-Pasko (Christmas All the Way), 2000, and Ating Balikan (Let’s Reminisce), 2002, all of which achieved gold and platinum status. They also produced a collection of remixed hits in Ating Sayawin (Let’s Dance To It), 2004. Their hallmark singles, unmistakable due to the rock opera sound of its female lead vocalists, include “Halik” and “Luha” (Tears). The band has had a huge following due to the lovelorn content of their songs whose appeal cuts across gender and class differences and captures the Filipino penchant for melodramatic expressions of romantic love.

In 2014, the Philippine Educational Theater Association produced Rak of Aegis, a musical based on popular Aegis songs, written by Liza Magtoto and directed by Maribel Legarda. The musical became a huge hit and has exceeded more than 200 performances. Written byLara T. Mendoza

AGANA-SANTOS, TESSIE (Teresita Agana-Santos) Singer. Her first music teacher was her mother, Martha Agana. She is married to Jose P. Santos. She studied music at the Centro Escolar University (CEU) under the tutelage of Nelia Manalo-Concordia and took postgraduate courses in CEU and Santa Isabel College of Music. After graduation, she became assistant to the dean of the CEU Conservatory of Music.

Santos made her professional debut as Violetta in the successful vernacular presentation of Verdi’s La Traviata. Later, she sang lead roles in LucinoT.Sacramento’s Pagmamahalan (Loving), a one-act opera; LucreciaR.Kasilag’s oratorio, Jose Aking Anak (Jose, My Son); JeffreyChing’s Masquerade, the Filipino version of Merry Wives of Windsor; Puccini’s La Boheme; and Bizet’s Carmen.

She has been conductor and music director of Opera Chorus of the Philippines Inc. since 1973, as well as other choralgroups. She has also directed stage productions, such as Rigoletto, Donizetti’s Princesa Urduja, Verdi’s Un Ballo in Maschera, and Menotti’s Amahl and the Night Visitors.

Santos received an award from the Kagawaran ng Pagtuturo ng Wikang Pambansang Pilipino for promoting the presentation of foreign operas in Filipino. In 2010, she appeared conducting the Philippine-Japan Ladies choir during a musical fellowship of the Philippine Normal University Bamboo and Rondalla Ensemble and the Philippine Society for Music Education. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Josephine Baradas.

AGUILAR, FREDDIE (Ferdinand Pascual Aguilar) b. Santo Tomas, Isabela, 5 Feb 1953. Singer and composer. Born to Gregorio Aguilar and Salud Pascual, he took up electrical engineering at the De Guzman Institute of Technology in the 1970s but did not finish the course. He has six children, the eldest of whom was with Marilyn Angelo and four with Josephine Ponce Queipo. He is currently married to his third wife, Jovie Gatdula Albao. His daughter, Meagan, also had a short-lived career as a musician.

In 1973, he started singing at a small bar in Ermita, Manila. Soon his pinched brown face, buri hat, and guitar perpetually slung from one shoulder became familiar to folk music audiences.

His fame was catapulted by his song, “Anak” (Child), which he entered into the first Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1978. Although the song did not win, it became a classic and has been recorded in Malay, Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, Spanish, Italian, English, French, German, and Dutch. Japan was his biggest fan, recording 53 different versions of the song in Japanese. Beyond “Anak,” his music continues to cross international borders.

Aguilar’s songs are rich in sociopolitical images and themes. Among them are “Bulag, Pipi at Bingi” (Blind, Mute, and Deaf), “Mahal Kita” (I Love You), “Magdalena,” “Mga Bata sa Negros” (The Children of Negros), “Katarungan” (Justice), “Olongapo,” “Trabaho” (Work), “Himig” (Melody), “Estudyante Blues” (Student Blues), and “Sariling Atin” (Our Very Own). He also wrote love ballads, like “Ipaglalaban Ko” (I Will Fight For It), “Kumusta Ka?” (How Are You?), and “Minamahal Kita” (I Love You). His rendition of Constancio de Guzman and Jose Corazon de Jesus’ “Bayan Ko” (My Country) was heard in protest and mass actions from 1983 to 1986.

His award-winning songs include: “Anak,” “Luzviminda,” and “Katarungan,” Catholic Radio Awards for Best Musical Composition in 1981, 1984, and 1986, respectively; “Mga Bata sa Negros,” Special Award from the Aliw Awards in 1985; and the Cecil Awards for Folk Vocal Performance of the Year for the song “Bayan Ko”, Best Folk Pop Vocal Performance for the song “Magdalena”, and Best Novelty Vocal or Instrumental Performance and Best Novelty Composition for the song “Sulat” (Letter), also in 1985. The story in his song “Sa Kuko ng Agila” (In the Claws of the Eagle) was made into a movie starring Joseph Estrada in 1989.

Among his award-winning long-playing albums are Anak which went gold, platinum, and double platinum in 1978, and awarded the First Millionaire’s Award in 1991; Freddie Aguilar, Greatest Hits, gold record award, 1982; Magdalena, gold and double platinum record awards, and Katarungan, gold record award, both in 1985; Bayan Ko, Di Ka Nag-iisa (My Country, You are Not Alone), 1986; Sariling Atin, gold and platinum record awards, 1989; Hala Bira (Go On, Hit It), gold and platinum record awards, 1990 and an Ampex Golden Reel Award from Redwood City, California in 1992. The following year, he released Kumusta Ka, the album that launched his own record label Aguilar Music Productions, Inc., (AMP). This song garnered gold and platinum awards, a double platinum, and multi-platinum record awards. The success of his record label AMP extended to Aguilar Music Publishing.

Freddie Aguilar’s music has reaped accolades year after year across several genres. Early in his career, he won the Japan’s Polydor Award in 1978; the Ulo ng Apo Award, 1979; and the prestigious Catholic Mass Media Grand Award in 1981. In 1982, he was Best Asian Artist in Hawaii’s World Music Festival and Manila’s coveted Cecil Awards awarded him the Best Rock, Best Folk Vocals, Best Folk Pop Performance and Best Folk Pop Composition, Best Folk-Rock, and Best Novelty Composition. The Aliw Awards presented him Best Solo International Road Show and Entertainer of the Year in 1986. He got recognition from the Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino Awit Awards in 1993 and a Lifetime Achievement Award from NU Rock Awards in 1994. In 1995, he bagged the Best Alternative Recording, and as producer of his daughter Maegan’s Sige Lang Sige (Go Ahead) debut album. Katha Music Awards presented him with Best Rock Vocal Perfomance and Best Country Song for a duet he wrote in 1996 for Nora Aunor. In 1997, Freddie accepted the Lifetime Achievement Award in MetroPop and in 1998 was Katha’s Best Contemporary Blues Song Producer. His other awards include: Pinoy Musika Awards Kakayahang Pinoy, 2001; Hall of Fame Tinig Awards, 2003; the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award for Music, 2005; and the Asap Platinum Circle Awards of Elite Platinum Artist, 2006. South Korea KBS gave Freddie the Best of Asia Award in 2008. In 2011, Freddie received the Dangal ng OPM and Spirit of EDSA Foundation Award. And in 2013, he received another Lifetime Achievement Award from the Philippine Movie Press Club. Written by Collie de los Reyes, updated by Josephine Queipo

AHADAS, UWANG b. Lamitan, Basilan 15 Feb 1945. Yakan musician. Near-blind since five years old, Uwang Ahadas grew up in a social environment where music is learned intimately and gradually by imitation, particularly in a context where it is best acquired, his family. In the village of Bohe Bessey where Ahadas was born to an imam, instrumental music played in ensemble is important because it fulfills many social functions, one of which can be understood to be fostering social cooperation among villagers that is needed in agricultural labor.

For Yakan people, a common instrument is the kwintangan kayu, an instrument made of five wooden logs hung horizontally, from the shortest to the longest, with the shortest being nearest the ground. It is associated with agricultural activity. It is hung from a beam tied to a tree and played after the planting of rice in the fields as a way of wooing the rice plant (de Leon). Elsewhere in Basilan, kwintangan kayu is played by in a group, with one playing an active rhythmic pattern (a “melody”) on all five logs, while one, two, or three sticks on the middle log constitutes the steady or drone ostinato. The performative of playing together unmistakably symbolizes social cooperation, a value indispensable in agriculture which cannot be done alone.

This ethos of bridging work and play was the setting for Uwang’s early exposure to music. While he and his siblings helped their parents in their work, they learned to play other Yakan instruments in the process. He learned the gabbang (a bamboo xylophone), which also has many performers playing different musical parts. Eventually, he joined ensembles, playing the more popular shared instruments in the region, which are the kwintangan and the most universal of all indigenous Filipino instruments, the agung. In Yakan culture, kwintangan is a woman’s instrument, the agung, a man’s. When Uwang reached the age of 20, he had already mastered these fundamental Yakan musical instruments.

Aside from performing, Uwang is an exemplary teacher of Yakan music. True to the traditional culture that he knew, his children have been the first recipients of his art. In addition, Uwang’s accomplishment as possessing an exceptional technical and artistic mastery of Yakan music had spread beyond his town of Basilan. At present, he is constantly invited to grace civic events. Filled with a vision, he hopes his knowledge of traditional arts will outlive him.

Uwang’s teaching style bears essentially the mark of traditional transmission via hands-on imitation. He demonstrates passages, teaching these by example to his students. A caring artist, he is keen in giving his students his full attention. However, worried about the future of his art, his younger brother, Rohas, had thought of documenting his brother’s pedagogy by creating a notation system that will simplify the transmission of his music knowledge.

Uwang Ahadas was awarded the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2000. Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

Sources:

de la Paz n.d.; de Leon Jr. 2011; Maceda 1998.

ALBERT, JOEY (Ma. Josefina Albert-Pacis) b. 18 Mar 1960. Singer, songwriter, movie actor, television host. The youngest child in the brood of four of Angel Ma. and Leticia Albert. Albert finished her elementary education at St Theresa’s College Manila, and high school and college at Our Lady of Assumption, major in communication arts. She plays the piano and guitar. She married Vicente Pacis III with whom she has two children, Trixie and Margarita. In 1982, she won the “Dream Girl Filipina” contest on a TV show and this paved the way for her singing career. She was the executive producer and host of Bahay Kalinga (House of Care), an award-winning public service program aired over ABS-CBN 2.

She held numerous successful concerts at the ULTRA, Folk Arts Theater, Greenhills Theater, Araneta Coliseum, and Manila Hotel, and performed in countries such as as Malaysia, Hong Kong, Singapore, the United States, and Oman. She also appeared in a few movies with the comic trio of Tito, Vic and Joey, and Dolphy. She also holds the distinction of being the first Filipino artist to have an album recorded on compact disc. Her family migrated to Vancouver, Canada in 1994, and in the following year, she was diagnosed with cancer. Albert continued her singing career despite her illness.

Albert has recorded 10 albums, containing such hit songs as “Tell Me,” “A Million Miles Away,” “Over and Over Again,” “Memories,” “Points of View,” “Yakapin Mo Ako” (Embrace Me), “I Remember the Boy,” “Ikaw Lang ang Mamahalin” (You’re the Only One I’ll Love), “Without You,” “Kumukutikutitap” (Twinkle, Twinkle), and “Maybe Next Year.” The albums are titled: Joey Albert, 1990; Brief Encounters and The Best of Joey Albert, 1992; A Christmas with Joey Albert, 1993; Sa ’Yo Lamang (Only Yours), 1995; Joey Albert, 1996; OPM Timeless Collection Gold Series 2: Joey Albert, 1997; Joey Albert Greatest Hits and Inspirations, 1998; Ikaw Lang ang Mamahalin (I Shall Love Only You), 1999; Lookin’ Back, 2000; The Story of Joey Albert: The Ultimate OPM Collection and The Story of Joey Albert: The Ultimate OPM Video Collection, 2001; Carmen Valdez Sandalwood featuring Joey Albert, 2004; and Joey Albert 2009 Album, 2009, Viva Records.

Albert started winning recognition in the music industry in 1983, when she was named one of the Top 10 Entertainers at the Tinig Awards. She was chosen Best Female Vocal Performer at the Cecil Awards in 1985 and Best Female Performer at the Awit Awards in 1990. “Ikaw Lang ang Mamahalin,” a song she composed with Louie Ocampo, was awarded Best Song of the Year by the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1989. Her self-styled album garnered gold and platinum record awards in 1992. She received the Awit Award for Best Christmas Recording for “Be Like the Children on Christmas” in 1994; Best Movie Theme Song Award for “Sa ’Yo Lamang” in the Manila Film Festival in 1995; and as songwriter together with Louie Ocampo and Janice de Belen in the Awit Awards for Best Ballad “It’s Over Now” in 2008. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Josephine Baradas

ALCASID, OGIE (Herminio Jose Lualhati Alcasid Jr.) b. Manila 27 Aug 1967. Singer, songwriter, actor, comedian, television host. He is the youngest of four children of Herminio Martirez Alcasid Sr and Herminia Lualhati. He has two children from a previous marriage with Australian beauty queen Michelle Van Eimeren, and is currently married to singer Regine Velasquez, with whom he has a son. He completed his elementary and high school education in De La Salle Greenhills. His membership in the La Salle Glee Club in grade school and the Kundirana in high school played an influential role in building the foundation for his musical career. He was admitted to University of the Philippines (UP) in Los Baños in 1985 and transferred one year after to UP Diliman where he graduated with a degree in broadcast communication in 1993. While a student in Diliman, he was a member of a singing group called Sparkle managed by Nonong Pedero.

In 1988, he embarked on a solo career. His first hit was in 1989, when he sang and wrote the lyrics of “Nandito Ako” (I Am Here) to a melody of Aaron Paul. By the time he held his first major concert, Radioactive, at the Folk Arts Theater, his other songs had already become hits: “Peksman” (Cross My Heart), “Ako’y Iyong-Iyo” (I Am All Yours), “Mahal Kita, Walang Iba” (I Love You and No One Else), and “Sa Kanya” (To Her). By this time, he had also written new hits like “Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang” (Why Have You Come Only Now), “Pangako” (Promise), and “Dahil Mahal Kita” (Because I Love You). A new rush of inspiration came to him in 2000 when he created “Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw” (I Need You) and “Kung Mawawala Ka” (If You Leave), and thereafter, “Kailangan Kita” (I Need You), “Pangarap Ko ay Ibigin Ka” (My Dream is To Love You), “Ikaw Sana” (I Hope It’s You), “Huwag Ka Lang Mawawala” (Just Don’t Go Away), “Ikaw Lamang” (Only You), and “Ikaw ang Aking Pangarap” (You’re My Dream), which he wrote for Martin Nievera. In 2009, he wrote “Kaya Natin Ito” (We Can Do This) for the victims of typhoon Ondoy which brought all the pop music artists together. In 2014, he wrote “Ang Pilipinas ay Babangon” (The Philippines Will Rise) for the victims of Typhoon Yolanda. This was performed by the directors, board members, and junior ambassadors of the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit (OPM) at its premiere in Cebu on 25 Feb 2014 for the Anniversary of the EDSA Revolution. Ogie has written the melody and lyrics to more than 67 songs, but finds the most fulfillment in writing inspirational and Christian songs.

He concentrated on doing comedy movies beginning 1991. He became part of the love triangle with Manilyn Reynes and Janno Gibbs. His comedic partnership with Janno, propelled as a tandem called Small Brothers, which began as a title to their concert and went on to become the title of a television program in 1994. He was a mainstay of GMA7’s gag show Bubble Gang for 18 years and Sunday lunchtime shows SOP and Party Pilipinas. His move to TV5 in Jul 2013 expanded his career from just being an actor and artist to heading the music department to create the content for music-related programs. He also appeared in TV5’s gag show Tropa Mo Ako Unli (Part of Your Gang Unlimited) and a romantic comedy series Confessions of a Torpe (Confessions of a Shy Guy).

As of 2012, he had received awards for 12 gold records, three platinum records, and three double platinum records. His first came in 1989 with the Song of the Year from DWTM 89.9, which paved the way for his career. He received the following recognition from Awit Awards: Best Revival Song, “Pagkakataon” (Chance), 1991; Best Performance by a Male Recording Artist, 1993 for “Mahal Kita, Walang Iba,” 1994, for “Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang”, and 2002 for “Ikaw Sana”; Best Produced Record of the Year, 1995, for “Bakit Ka Lumayo” (Why Did You Go Away); Best Inspirational/Religious Recording, 1996, for “Siya ang Bida” (He’s the Man), and 2014, for “Nathaniel (Gift of God)”; Best Ballad Recording and Song of the Year, 2000, for “Kung Mawawala Ka,” and 2001, for “Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw” (I Need You); Album of the Year, A Better Man, 2002; Best Performance by a Duet (with Karylle), “Kung Mawawala Ka,” 2003; Best Movie Theme Song, 1994 for “Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang,” 2001 for “Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw,” 2004 for “Pangarap Ko’y Ibigin Ka” (My Dream is To Love You), 2008 for “Paano Kita Iibigin” (How Will I Love You), 2009 for “Ikaw ang Aking Pangarap”; Best World Recording, 2013, for “Pinoy Krismas” (Filipino Christmas); and Best Christmas Recording, 2014, for “Hele ni Inay” (Mother’s Lullaby). His other awards include: Catholic Mass Media Awards, Best Original Pilipino Music, 1994; Star Awards and FAMAS, Best Movie Theme Song, 2003; Manila Film Festival, Best Movie Theme Song, 2003; Golden Screen Award for Best Original Song, 2004; and the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Award in 1990, 2004, 2005, and 2006 for Most Popular Male Recording Artist/Male Singer/Entertainer. Because of this success, he was elected president of OPM and became a member of the Board of Trustees of PhilPop Foundation in 2011. Written by Katherine V. Molina

ALDABA, DALISAY (Dalisay Julian Aldaba) b. Hagonoy, Bulacan 9 Sep 1912. d. Manila 14 Mar 2006. Singer, teacher, artistic director, cultural diplomat. Born to Amado Aldaba and Estefania Julian, she had her early education in Malolos, Bulacan. She graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music with a degree in voice teaching in 1936 and a bachelor’s degree in voice from the same university in 1941. As an Oliver Ditson scholar, she obtained a master’s degree in voice (music literature) from the University of Michigan in 1947.

From 1936 to 1945, Aldaba was the director of the opera workshop and head of the Voice Department at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) and associate professor in voice at the UP. In 1947, she won wide acclaim for her singing debut with the New York City Opera Company in the title role of CioCio San in Puccini’s Madame Butterfly and for subsequent performances in the United States (US) and Europe. Until 1967, she performed in operas in the Philippines, Asia, US, Italy, France, Spain, and England. She played various lead roles as member of the New York City Opera Company, La Scala Opera Company, Baltimore Opera Company, and Philadelphia Civic Grand Opera Company. Aside from Madame Butterfly, she also appeared as Manon in Manon, Gilda in Rigoletto, Susel in L’Mico Fritz, and Susanah in Marriage of Figaro. She was also the lone Asian member of the One World Ensemble quartet.

On 22 Dec 1969, Aldaba founded the Opera Guild of the Philippines to develop and promote greater public interest in the opera. The Guild has trained Filipino talents and staged both foreign and Filipino operas. From 1973 to 1983, she invited international artists to perform with the Filipino cast in her productions of such operas as Tosca, Serrata Pucciana, The Magic Flute, and Madame Butterfly. The latter, staged and directed by her in 1973, was the biggest and longest running production of the Guild at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

Aldaba has also served as cultural attache at the Philippine Mission to the United Nations in New York City and the Philippine Embassy in Tokyo. She was also the lone Filipino delegate to the UNESCO International Music Council Conference on the Opera in Moscow and Bulgaria.

The Manila Music Lovers Society chose her as Opera Singer of the Year in 1947. In 1976, Aldaba received an Award of Merit from the UP College of Music for her outstanding contributions in the music field. In 1993, she received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining “for her lifelong excellence as a performing artist in the art of opera, and for her invaluable contribution to the development of opera in the Philippines.” In 2006, the recital hall at the back of the UP Theater (Villamor Hall) with a 211 seating capacity was named Dalisay J. Aldaba Hall. Written byRaj Mansukhani, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

ALEGRE, JUAN BAUTISTA (Juan Bautista Hernaez Alegre) aka Johnny Alegre. b. Pasay 4 Jun 1955. Jazz guitarist, composer, creative writer, record producer. He is the son of Narciso Alegre of Teruel, Spain, and Teodora Hernaez of Sampaloc, Manila. His father was a businessman and agriculturist who had played the cello at the Real Colegio de las Escuelas Pias de Sarria in Barcelona during his student days. His paternal grandfather, Sen Juan B. Alegre, served at the 6th and 7th Philippine Legislatures during the Commonwealth Period. His paternal grandmother, Aimee Sargent, belonged to a family who descended from the earliest American settlers of New England.

Alegre attended the Holy Trinity Academy in Balic-Balic and later, the Don Bosco Technical Institute in Mandaluyong, where he finished his primary and secondary education in 1970 and 1974, respectively. He grew up in the cosmopolitan district of Malate where he honed his guitar playing as he experimented on jazz-rock, blues, ballads, electronics, and other influences. Aside from playing with his band, he also immersed himself in literary creations. In 1974, he won the second place in the one-act play category of the Don Carlos Palanca Awards for Literature. In the late 1970s, he studied composition under Francisco Feliciano at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, and was among the pioneers of the UP Jazz Ensemble. As a composition student, he participated in workshops under respected scholars such as Chou Wen-chung, Ike Isaacs, and Erhard Karkoshka. He also studied jazz performance under Joseph Howard and Fred Robles.

In 2002, Alegre formed the Johnny Alegre Affinity, a jazz group made up of Colby de la Calzada, Koko Bermejo, Elhmir Saison, Tots Tolentino, and himself. The group ventured into performing and recording their original compositions. Their pioneering recorded work written by Alegre, Stones of Intramuros, 2002, was noticed by the UK-based jazz record company, Candid Records. The album Johnny Alegre Affinity, released in the Philippines in 2005, was re-released in England by Candid Records for global distribution as Jazzhound. In 2008, Candid Records released Eastern Skies, an album of original compositions written by Alegre and his band in 2006 and 2007. The entire collection was set to symphonic instrumentation and was recorded by the Global Studio Orchestra under the direction of Gerard Salonga.

Another foreign recording company, the American MCA Music (Universal Music Group) released Johnny Alegre 3 in 2009, which featured Alegre together with two noted American jazz musicians, Billy Hart and Ron McClure. The album, Humanfolk, released by MCA Music in 2011, highlighted Alegre’s world music compositions which combined multiple musical idioms: jazz, rock, folk, electronic, and indigenous music, in a contemporary setting. The album featured the collaboration of Alegre with American-based percussionists Susie Ibarra and Roberto Juan, together with Filipino musicians Cynthia Alexander, Malek Lopez, and Abby Clutario. Alegre’s song, “Para Sa Tao” (For the People), which is part of the album Humanfolk, was bestowed an Awit Award by the Philippine Association of the Recording Industry (PARI) as Best World Music Recording in 2012. In 2014, MCA Music released Stories, an anthology of his groundbreaking and influential Candid Record recordings with Affinity, in 2014.

In 1982, Alegre was recognized as the Foremost Exponent of Jazz at the 1st Cebu Jazz Festival by the Philippine Ministry of Tourism. In 2013, he was conferred the Icon Award by the 8th Philippine International Jazz and Arts Festival, as well as the Best Performer Award by the Kansai Music Conference in Japan. His latest accolade is an Aliw Award as Best Instrumentalist in 2014. Alegre is recognized as among the world’s best jazz guitarists, which is attested to by the inclusion of his name in the book, The Great Jazz Guitarists: The Ultimate Guide. Written by Arwin Q. Tan

ALEJANDRO, HAJJI (Angelito Toledo Alejandro) b. Manila 26 Dec 1954. Singer. Born to Edgardo Alejandro and Aida Toledo, he was a management graduate of the Ateneo de Manila University in 1976. His eldest daughter, Rachel Alejandro, is one of the most talented female singers in the country today.

Alejandro formed his own singing group in high school and started singing professionally in 1973 with the Circus Band. In 1976, he launched his solo career with the single “Tag-araw, Tag-ulan” (Summer Season, Rainy Season), an adaptation of the Bee Gees’ “Charade,” flipsided by “Panakip-butas” (Second Choice). Both songs hit the top of the music charts, and the single became a gold record. It was the beginning of a succession of hits such as “Nakapagtataka” (It’s Surprising), “KayGandangAtingMusika” (How Beautiful is Our Music), and “Ang Lahat ng Ito’y Para sa Iyo” (All This For You). Within a decade, Alejandro came out with seven albums, two of which, Hajji and Strictly OPM, received gold record awards.

Alejandro’s musical talent and personal charm made him the favorite of young female audiences everywhere, especially the collegiate crowd. In 1977, he held a series of campus tours in the capital’s major colleges and universities, capped by a successful solo concert at the Folk Arts Theater. He later developed into an all-around artist capable of holding the attention of mature and sophisticated audiences as proven by his well-attended shows in Manila’s plush hotels and nightclubs. He also took on lead roles on stage, in Batibot and Kapinangan, original ethnic musicals at the MetropolitanTheater, adaptations of Broadway musicals at the Metropolitan Theater such as The Wiz and The Fantastiks, and in the rock opera ballet TalesoftheManuvu, in 1977.

In 1987, Alejandro left for the United States where he lived for five years. When he returned in 1992, he resumed his musical career. BMG Pilipinas produced his comeback album, Pagbabalik (Return), and his Christmas album, Ang Aking Pamasko (My Christmas Gift), both in 1992. In 1999, to celebrate his anniversary in the industry, he released 25: The Silver Anniversary Album of Hajji Alejandro. He has released a performance video titled The Greatest Hits Live in 2003 with contemporaries Rico J. Puno and Rey Valera. Alejandro also ventured into television playing a character in the series on GMA Network, Love to Love, 2004.

Alejandro was the interpreter of RyanCayabyab’s prizewinning song, “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika,” which won the grand prize in the 1st Metro Manila Music Festival and the 1st International Seoul Song Festival in Korea, both in 1978. The song “Inaanak” (Godchild), a cut from his 1992 Christmas album, received the 1993 Awit Awards for Best Christmas Song. “Babalik-balikan” (Keep Coming Back), his duet with daughter Rachel, also received the 1993 Awit Award for Best Recording by a Duet.Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

AMBAT, RODNEY (Rodney de los Santos Ambat) b. Amadeo, Cavite 18 Feb 1972. Trombonist, conductor. His parents are Edgardo Ambat and Olivia de los Santos. He earned a diploma in creative performing musical arts in band conducting, 1994; bachelor of music in orchestra conducting, 1996, and trombone, 1999; and a master of music in trombone, 2004—all from the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. He is married to Sharelyn S. Ambat, a dentist. A prize-winner of the 1995 National Music Competitions for Young Artists, trombone, category C, he furthered his training in trombone with Ron Nethercutt.

Ambat has conducted the Philippine Youth Symphonic Band, 1993-94, and initiated the formation of the UP Symphonic Band in 1998 and has conducted this group from 2002 until the present. He conducted the Manila Youth Symphony Orchestra in his graduation recital in 1996 and has assisted piano recitalists and graduating composition majors at the UP College of Music. He served as administrative officer and assistant conductor of the Crosswave Symphony Orchestra with Josefino Toledo.

He became the first conductor of the UP Orchestra, which was launched in a concert in Jan 2005 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Since then, he has conducted the UP Orchestra. Among the works he conducted were Handel’s Messiah, Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9, Tchaikovsky’s Symphony No. 4, Pergolesi’s La Serva Padrona, Purcell’s Dido and Aeneas, and Carlisle Floyd’s Susannah. In celebration of the UP Centennial Anniversary in 2008, he conducted the UP Orchestra in a series of concerts the whole year. He also conducted the said orchestra during the 300th year anniversary of Naga City.

As an instrumentalist, he served as principal trombone of the Philippine Youth Orchestra, 1992-95; Manila Youth Symphony Orchestra, 1994-98; and the UP Chamber Orchestra, the UP Jazz Ensemble, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, the Manila Philharmonic Orchestra, and San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra, 2004-06. He has collaborated with different groups, local as well as foreign artists, in several performances including television appearances. He was also the leader-representative of the Ambassador Brass Quintet and a long time trombone player of PUT3SKA Band, which made a mark in the commercial music scene during the 1990s.

He attended several workshops and master classes conducted by Helen Quach; Brazz Brothers workshop; Per Gade; the Principals Brass Sextet; the Apollo Brass Sextet; Eddie Henderson on Jazz Improvisation; and the Second ASEAN Youth Symphonic Band Workshop held in Petchaburi, Thailand as a tuba player. A member of the International Trombone Association, he is the current chair of the Department of Conducting and Choral ensemble of the UP College of Music and the current director of the UP Symphonic Band, a post he held since 2010. Written byAntonio C. Hila

ANAK ZAPOTE BAND Bacoor, Cavite. The Band was organized in 1925 by Hilarion Rubio (later, a professor of composition in the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music) and Felipe Dominguez after the disintegration of the old “Bagong Silang” Band in Bacoor. Dominguez recruited young boys and Rubio taught them note reading and playing of instruments. Since the beginning, the band never had a solo owner. It gained status and support from donations and contributions from the townspeople. The first persons who volunteered to supply instruments were Ignacio Alagar, Damaso Redondo, Evaristo Concepcion, and Marcelo Miranda. The bulk of the Band’s library was donated by Silvino Evangelista, a US Navy musician. Expenses for uniforms and other equipments were shouldered by the parents of the members and avid listeners of the band.

Under Rubio’s leadership, the band participated in band competitions. Some of the music played as contest pieces in the competitions were Il Guarany, Mignon, Second Hungarian Rhapsody, 1812 Overture, and Willam Tell Overture. They obtained more prizes in military and fancy drill exhibitions led by their military instructor, Capt Candido S. Burgos.

The band also helped graduating composers in performing their works in UP Conservatory of Music. Felipe Padilla de Leon Sr conducted the band in Villamor Hall (now Supreme Court) when he graduated in composition and conducting. Col Jose M. Campana did the same with the band, which was beneficial to the band members who got trained in the process. They found themselves in the services of the US Navy Bands, Philippine Armed Forces Bands, and other professional groups. Notable members of the band were clarinettist Carlos Samonte and French horn player Sgt Quirino Enriquez. The Band also produced two conductors who assisted Rubio. They were saxophonist Benedicto Mascardo and trumpetist Magligtas Bartolome. Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

ANGONO NATIONAL SYMPHONIC BAND aka Banda Angono Numero Uno, Angono Municipal Band, Angono Municipal Symphonic Band. The group had a humble informal beginning at the turn of the 20th century as a banda de voca (literally, “band of the mouth”), in which a group of young boys played band instruments made from locally available materials such as bamboo, sardine tin cans, and bilao (flat, round basket) that served as tambol (drum). Under the leadership of Elpidio San Pedro, however, it was formally organized upon the acquisition of standard instruments from the defunct Arevalo Band in 1918. Elpidio San Pedro was a fisherman, trader, and musician and father of National Artist for Music Lucio San Pedro. With the instruments, the elder San Pedro gathered 15 persons who comprised the core of a band that was named The Banda Angono Numero Uno. Beginning in 1933, the band was renamed as the Angono Municipal Band, then as the Angono Municipal Symphonic Band. It is now known as Angono National Symphonic Band (ANSB).

Under the tutelage and leadership of Lucio D. San Pedro, ANSB earned much praise for its accomplishments and achievements. It won championships in national band competitions such as the National Band Contest in 1960 and the San Miguel Corporation’s Balik-Banda Competition in 1979. Since Lucio San Pedro was a composer, the band did not only perform works of non-Filipino composers, but valuable original band music by San Pedro for many decades. Lucio D. San Pedro’s nephew, Manuel S.P. Bautista, then the late Agripino V. Diestro, succeeded him. Presently the band is under the leadership of San Pedro’s grandson, Gabrielle S.P. Rojas.

The ANSB has continuously mounted regular concerts in the town, while fulfilling its religious functions in lenten ceremonies, fiestas, and the simbang gabi (nine dawn Masses before Christmas) concerts, and other civic activities. In addition, the band has been regularly featured in notable concert series outside Angono, such as Concert at the Park in Luneta (now Rizal Park) and Puerta Real Evenings in Intramuros, Manila. It has been invited to perform in numerous events such as Araw ng Maynila on Jun 24, Independence Day on Jun 12, Rizal Day on Dec 30, and New Year’s Eve in December. In addition, the group has done outreach concerts in Subic Bay and Clark Air Base, in the Manila Peninsula and the Manila Hotel, as well as in parks of gated subdivisions in Metro Manila. Other venues where the group had frequent concerts are the Cultural Center of the Philippines where they did a collaboration with the Ballet Philippines’ production of Jose Rizal’s Junto al Pasig (On the Banks of the Pasig), featuring the music of San Pedro, Metropolitan Manila Theater, Meralco Theater, and Philamlife Auditorium. Socio-civic groups and organizations in Manila have sponsored the special concerts held in the said venues. In May 1997, the band was featured in a special concert in Hong Kong at the International Convention Center in connection with the Glaxo Philippines fellowship dinner.

ANSB has contributed to the community by serving as a training center for promising music students, and especially for the less privileged but deserving talents. Written byAlberto de los Santos, with notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

Julio Esteban Anguita (Julio Anguita Esteban) was a pianist, piano teacher, composer, and film scorer. Of Spanish parentage, he was born in Shanghai, China on 18 Mar 1906, but was raised in Spain. He died in Palma de Mallorca, Spain on 3 Dec 1987. Although he was known as Mr. Anguita, his real surname was Esteban, Anguita being his mother’s surname.

Anguita started playing the piano at age seven and studied music in Barcelona, Spain. By the time he was 18, he graduated with honors at the Circulo Filarmonico de Barcelona. In a year’s time, at age 19, he was hailed in Barcelona as well as other key cities and suburbs in Spain as a concert artist and soloist.

He arrived in Manila on 14 Jan 1925 and became a staff pianist at the radio station KZRH, now DZRH. Later he became a piano instructor in the music department of the Colegio de San Juan de Letran. He pursued further education in music and obtained a bachelor of music degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music in 1933, after which he went back to Barcelona to finish his masteral degree in music at Escuela Municipal de Musica.

He taught music at the UP Conservatory of Music for more than two decades. In between his teaching career, Anguita teamed up with violin virtuoso ErnestoVallejo to perform in concert tours in the Visayas and southern China. Around this time, he began to compose music for the movies, like Parlatone Hispano-Filipino’s Bahay Kubo (Nipa Hut), 1938. In addition, from 1928 to 1952, he appeared intermittently as piano soloist in concerts by the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) and, in 1949 and 1952, guest conducted the same orchestra.

During the Japanese Occupation, he transferred to the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) Conservatory of Music to head its piano department. With the resurgence of theater activities during World War II, Anguita and Vallejo again teamed up in a series of musical performances at the Times Theater.

After World War II, he resumed his position in the UP Conservatory of Music. Later he transferred to the University of Santo Tomas (UST) as the second director of its conservatory from 1947 to 1957.

Concomitantly, he was also a musical consultant for Lebran Productions where he did over 50 musical scores of local films like He Promised to Return, 1949; The Spell, His Darkest Hour,and The Pirates Go to Town, all in 1950; Romeo at Julieta (Romeo and Juliet), Babae, Babae at Babae pa! (Women, Women, and More Women!), Sigfredo, and Tatlong Patak ng Luha (Three Teardrops), all in 1951; Kalbaryo ni Hesus (The Calvary of Jesus), 1952; and Malapit sa Diyos (Close to God), 1953.

He conducted operas and ballets in Europe, Asia, and the United States, and composed the United Nations Hymn in the Philippines and the UST Hymn. As chair of the curriculum committee of the then Bureau of Education of the Philippines, he introduced the bachelor and master degrees in music in private schools based on the standards of American conservatories.

He later settled in the United States where he taught piano pedagogy, piano, and piano literature at the Peabody Conservatory of Music in Baltimore, Maryland.

He published two books, namely The Technical Exercises with Liszt and Chopin Etudes, Op. 18, and wrote numerous articles for professional publications.

Anguita won the 1950 Maria Clara Awards for best musical direction for his work in The Spell. The same award was bestowed on him by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for his work in Kalbaryo ni Hesus in 1952.   Written by M. Globio and M. Ojeda, updated by Josephine Baradas

APO HIKING SOCIETY (Apolinario Mabini Hiking Society) Organized in 1969, this singing group is composed of singers, humorists, and songwriters Danny(Daniel) Javier b. Manila, 1947; Jim(JaimeRamon)Paredes b. Manila, 1951; and Boboy (Jose) Garrovillo Jr b. Dipolog City, 1951. They graduated with liberal arts degrees from the Ateneo de Manila University in 1973. Popular as campus entertainers, the APO originally included Butch Dans, Lito de Joya, Gus Cosio, Renato Garcia, Chito Kintanar, Sonny Santiago, and Kenny Barton. Trimmed down to three, the APO turned professional in 1974. They have since developed into prime exponents of original Filipino music, including protestsongs, ballads, and novelty numbers. Their compositions, mostly in colloquial Filipino, are known for their distinctive urban sound and sense of humor.

They have performed many times in different parts of the world, including the United States, Saudi Arabia, Italy, and Canada, mainly to entertain overseas Filipinos. In 1987, they performed at Carnegie Hall in New York. In 1985 and 1986, amid threats of censorship, they staged three major solo concerts, Eto nAPO sila, Eto na namAnPO sila, and Nanalo nAPO sila (“Posila” is Cebuano for “shoot him,” the words shouted by former Sen Benigno S. Aquino Jr’s assassin). They have also hosted several television shows, the latest being Sa Linggo nAPO Sila (The APO on a Sunday), 1990-95, a noontime musical variety show on ABS-CBN. This was later aired on a daily basis thereby changing the show’s title to ‘Sang Linggo nAPO Sila (The APO All Week) from 1995-98.

The group celebrated its 20th anniversary via a concert titled Dalawampu nAPO sila (APO Turns Twenty) in 1989. After a long break, they later performed in reunion concerts titled Apo of the Philippines, 2008, at the Araneta Coliseum, and APO Kayang-Kaya Pa (APO Can Still Do It), 2009, at the SM North Edsa Skydome. I Do Bidoo Bidoo, a musical film which used some of APO’s most beloved songs, was released in 2012. It was written and directed by Chris Martinez, and starred Ogie Alcasid, Gary Valenciano, Zsa Zsa Padilla, and Eugene Domingo.

The Apo’s early hit songs include “Mahirap Magmahal ng Syota ng Iba” (It’s Difficult to Love Someone Else’s Girl), 1976; “PumapatakangUlan” (Rain is Falling), 1978; and “Salawikain” (Folk Saying), 1981. In 1985, they came out with “AmericanJunk,” which protested the dominance of the American Top 40 song hits on Philippine radio and heralded the trio’s politicization. During the wave of anti-dictatorship protests in the mid-1980s, APO produced songs with social and political themes like “Hindi Ka Nag-iisa” (You Are Not Alone), 1986; “Tuloy ang Ikot ng Mundo” (The World Will Keep on Turning) and “Sasaya ang Pilipinas” (The Philippines Will Be Happy), both in 1987; and “Piece of the Peace,” 1988. After the popular uprising which overthrew the Marcos government in Feb 1986, Paredes composed “Handogng Pilipinosa Mundo” (Filipinos’ Gift to the World), which was sung by 15 Filipino singers.

The APO received awards such as second place, Metro Manila Popular Music Festival, 1979. They received the following recognition from Awit Awards: Best Performance by a Duo or Group Recording Artists for “Awit ng Barkada” (The Gang’s Song), 1990; Best Novelty Recording for “Tamad” (Lazy), 1989, “Kayod, Kayod, Kayod” (Work, Work, Work), 1997, and “Telephone Pal,” 2000; Best Folk-Pop Recording for “Dito sa Kanto” (In This Street Corner), 2000; and Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino, 1994. They garnered platinum record awards for their albums Ten Years Together, 1980; Mga Kuwentong Apo (The Tales of Apo), 1988; and Songbuk ng Apo (Apo’s Songbook), 1991. They also received the Lifetime Achievement Award, 1st Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) Star Awards for Music, 2009, and were also inducted to the Walk of Fame in Eastwood City in the same year.

In 2010, APO Hiking Society formally retired from singing as a group. Individually, they are active in promoting such causes as original Pilipino music (OPM), ecology, peace, tourism, and public health. Garrovillo regularly acts in TV soaps and movies, while Paredes remains to be a political activist. Written byJulie Anne Hallazgo, updated by James C. Diaz

ARACAMA, JANET (Janet Escalante Sabas-Aracama) aka Jai Sabas-Aracama b. Manila 13 Aug 1959. Choral conductor, mezzo soprano, educator. Her parents were Leon Borja Sabas of Aparri, Cagayan Valley and Luz Escalante of Gonzaga, Cagayan Valley. She is married to Felix Gregorio Aracama with whom she has two children. She finished elementary and high school at St. Theresa’s College in Quezon City. While she was in high school, she became a dancer of Felicitas Layag-Radaic’s Dance Theater Philippines, and at 15, she became one of the Philippine representatives to the 1975 Aberdeen International Youth Festival for the Performing Arts in Aberdeen, Scotland.

She finished her bachelor’s and master’s degrees in music at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, major in choral conducting. Aside from being trained in conducting by Reynaldo Paguio, she also studied voice under Josie Bailen, Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, and Elmo Makil. Since 1986, she has been a member of the faculty of the UP College of Music, teaching conducting and voice. She served as chairman of the Conducting Department in 2002-05, and at present is an associate professor at the UP College of Music. She also serves as vocal coach to many Filipino theater, film, and popular artists.

Aracama became an alto soloist and assistant conductor of the UP Concert Chorus during her student days from 1976 to 1986. Upon the demise of Reynaldo Paguio in 1999, she was elected and appointed as the new artistic director and conductor of the official chorus of the university. Under her leadership, the UP Concert Chorus won in international choral competitions in Germany, Italy, Switzerland, Hungary, and Spain. In 2012, the choir received the Ani ng Dangal Award from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Aliw Awards. Aracama also served as music director of Greenhills Christian Fellowship Exalting Ministry from 2006 to 2009.

As a vocal soloist, Aracama performed roles in the Philippine productions of operas, Broadway musicals, and sarsuwela. In 1979, Aracama was one of three Filipino singers chosen to sing with the San Francisco Met Opera Chorus production of Tosca, featuring Placido Domingo and Eva Marton at the Cultural Center of the Philippines with Kurt Adler as conductor. In 1982, she was adjudged as the best alto soloist in a vocal competition performing Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, sponsored by the Manila Symphony Society. Other productions where she sang as soloist were The Mikado, 1982; South Pacific, 1990; Candide, 199; Once on this Island, 1993; Madame Butterfly, 1994; Rendezvous in Venice, 1996; Bayan Ko Isang Paa Na Lamang (My Countrymen, We’re One Step Away), 2001; and Himala (Miracle), 2003.

She has also performed as guest soloist of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and the Las Piñas Bamboo Organ Festival. Her vocal versatility allows her to cross over from classical singing to contemporary gospel, soul, and jazz styles. Written byArwin Q. Tan

ARCE, NOEL (Noel Pichay Arce) b. Quezon City 7 Jan 1964. Pianist. He is the son of Manuel Arce and Remedios Pichay. He attended the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) and the University of the Philippines College of Music where he graduated cum laude in 1986 with a bachelor of music degree. He trained under Evelyn Crochet, Jose Ma. Contreras, ErnestinaCrisologo, Juan Ramos, and Estelita Topacio. He obtained his master’s degree in piano in 1992 from the University of Kansas under the tutelage of Portuguese pianist Sequeira Costa.

Arce appeared as soloist with the PhilippineYouthOrchestra playing Schumann’s Piano Concerto at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines(CCP) in 1983 and Chopin’s Piano Concerto in E minor in eight concerts held in other cities throughout the country in 1984. He was also a soloist for the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra’s Final Concert Season held at the Metropolitan Theater and the PCIBank FranciscoSantiago Hall in 1985.

He received the MARIA scholarship as an outstanding student of the PHSA in 1981. Upon graduating from the UP, he was given the Carlo Zechi Award for Piano Excellence. His other awards include: the Rosina Lhevinne Memorial Award for Public Performance; Outstanding Student Artist Award by the UP President’s Committee on Culture and the Arts; and second prize in the 1986 piano concerto competition of the PianoTeachersGuildofthePhilippines. He also won the Voya Toncitch Award which is given every four years at an audition/competition held for the purpose.

He was one of the four musicians chosen to represent the country at the Second Jakarta International Festival of the Performing Arts in 1992. He was also featured in CCP Filipino Artists Series in 1991 and Piano Series in 1992 where he gave a highly successful solo recital. Written byRosalinda Galang and Elmer L. Gatchalian

ARELLANO, GALIA (Justina Fernandez Galos de Arellano) aka Tinay Arellano. b. Quiapo, Manila 26 Sep 1900 d. Manila 7 Sep 1943. Singer, teacher. She is the daughter of Francisco Galos, municipal president of Ormoc, Leyte, and Eustaquia Fernandez. In 1923, she married Manuel Arellano and at his behest studied voice under teachers such as Vladimir Ellin, a Russian resident of Manila, and Mary Jordan. She then became a faculty member of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music whose then director, AlexanderLippay, recommended that she be sent to Italy to study.

Before she left, Arellano gave concerts under the sponsorship of the Asociacion MusicaldeFilipinas, either in galas or benefit shows.
