In the programs, her name appeared prominently, together with mezzo-soprano Teodorica Mariano, tenor VictorinoCarrion, JoseMossesgeldSantiago-Font, Mamerto Manahan, and others under the baton of BonifacioAbdon.

Eight months after arriving in Italy, she made her maiden appearance in the title role in Aida in the Carlo Felice Theater in Genoa with Lindi, Giani, Borgioli, Nava and others under the baton of Gaitano Navagnoli, one of the leading conductors of the time. She had already played this role on the occasion of the feast day of the Santissimo Rosario on Lavezares Street in Binondo, on 17 Oct 1927. Six months after, she played the title role in Madame Butterfly at the Teatro Nazionale in Milan, and for the next eight years, she sang in leading music centers in Europe and the Americas.

Upon returning in Oct 1936, Arellano made her first appearance in Manila at the MetropolitanTheatre under the sponsorship of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas. This was followed by numerous performances. In 1937 she taught voice culture in her apartment, then in the school of Victorina Lobregat in Malate, and for a time at St Theresa’s College. The Japanese Occupation did not deter her from teaching voice, and she opened a voice clinic. She was in her studio when fire broke out, and she suffered burns, from which she died the following day. Written by Espiridion Arsenio Manuel
AREVALO, TITO (See FILM volume.)

ARMOVIT, MARY ANNE (Maria Antonia Tagorda Rivas-Armovit) b. Vigan, Ilocos Sur 17 Jan 1932. Pianist. She is the daughter of Marino Rivas and Hermes Tagorda. She is married to Raymundo Armovit with whom she has five children. She earned her music degree at the St Scholastica’s College, took piano studies with Pilar Buencamino-Larracas, Marieta Cruz, ManuelP.Maramba,OSB, JoseContreras, Genevieve Joy, and Marieta Cruz; and finished a summer course in music education at the University of Oregon, USA. She became a scholar of the French government at the Conservatoire National Superieur de Musique de Paris, where she had master classes in piano ensemble together with pianist DellaBesa.

Armovit taught piano at Philippine Women’s University and University of the East. She also taught at the Victoria School Foundation.

From 1975, Armovit and Besa performed as duo pianists at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines, Philamlife Theater, Concert at the Park, PCI Bank FranciscoSantiago Hall, Paco Park Presents, and in other venues in major cities of the Philippines. She also performed in Honolulu, Hawaii.

In 2007 she received the Duo Artist Award from St Scholastica’s College for the school’s centennial celebration. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

ARRIETA, ROWENA (Rowena Arrieta Policarpio) b. Manila 8 Oct 1962. Pianist. She is the daughter of Osmundo Arrieta and Luz Sanchez. She is married to Jonathan Policarpio with whom she has two children. She received her elementary and secondary schooling at the Jose Abad Santos Memorial School, the University of the Philippines Integrated School, and the Philippine High School for the Arts as a full scholar.

At age two, she started playing the piano by ear, learned notes at the age of four, and wrote her first composition for piano at five. She had her first musical training under Leonila Celino, ReynaldoReyes, RegaladoJose, and Carmencita Arambulo. In 1979, she became the first Filipino scholar at the Moscow State Conservatory, Moscow, and came under the tutelage of Yevgeny Malinin, a National Artist of the Russian Federation. In 1985, she graduated with the highest honors, earning both a master’s and a bachelor’s degree in Russian language pedagogy. She had professional studies in music in 1989 under Solomon Mikowskyat the Manhattan School of Music in New York where she was a recipient of the Elva Van Gelder Memorial Scholarship. She also attended the Seventh Semaines Musicales of Tours, France conducted by the best Soviet artists and pedagogues.

Arrieta has performed in solo recitals and as a soloist with orchestra in the United States, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Australia, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, and the Philippines. Also, she has been a soloist for major orchestras including Orquesta de Radio Television España, Valencia Symphony Orchestra, Moscow Radio-TV Orchestra, Manhattan Philharmonia, California Symphony Orchestra, Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra.

Arrieta was the first prize winner in the 1976 National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA), 1976. She won in the organ competition in Manila, 1976, and reaped the following distinctions: the University of the Philippines Award for Academic Excellence in Music, 1977; Gold Medal Award on Performance, Manila, 1978; and Presidential Award on Performance, Manila, 1979. At 18 she was the first Filipino to become a laureate in the 1982 Tchaikovsky International Piano Competition in Moscow where she won the fifth prize and the special prize for being the youngest and most promising contestant among the group of 79 seasoned pianists from all over the world.

She has since won the grand prize in the 1986 Jose Iturbi International Competition in Spain and in the 1986 Frinna Awerbuch International Competition of the Piano Teachers Congress of New York. She was the winner of the Annual Concerto Competition, Manhattan School of Music, 1987. She was the recipient of the Ten Outstanding Women in National Service, Manila, 1989; and Teodora Alonso Award, New York, USA, 1990. She was included in the National Piano Honor Roll of the Piano Teachers Guild of America in 1991. In 2009, she garnered the “Hall of Fame” award of the Piano Teachers Guild of America. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

ASENIERO, FRANCISCO (Francisco Carlson Aseniero Jr) b. Sampaloc, Manila 23 Jul 1946. Singer. The son of FranciscoAseniero Sr and Ingeborg Carlson, he is married to Nanette Nacorda. Aseniero studied voice under Aurelio Estanislao at the University of the Philippines, where he also completed his bachelor of arts in economics and master of arts in business administration. He later trained at the Hochschule für Musik in Berlin, Germany, and under Hannah Ludwig of the Hochschule Mozarteum in Salzburg, Austria and John Lester of the United States.

Aseniero has sung such roles as the Duke of Mantua in Rigoletto, Lt Pinkerton in Madame Butterfly, Rodolfo in La Boheme, Faust in Faust and Mephistofeles, Don Jose in Carmen, Nadir in Les Pecheures des Perles, Hoffman in Les Contes D’Hoffman, Tamino in Die Zauberfloete, Narciso in Il turco in Italia, and Alfredo in La Traviata. He also appeared in various musicals where he played the following roles: Lun Tha in The King and I, the Caliph in Kismet, Freddie in My Fair Lady, Camille in The Merry Widow, Charlie in Brigadoon, the Red Shadow in Desert Song, and the Prince in Student Prince. He was also in TeatroPilipino’s production of Ana Maria and has often performed with the Metro ManilaSymphonyOrchestra at the Concert at the Park series.

In concert and oratorio singing, he was Evangelist in Bach’s The Passion According to St John and tenor soloist in Johannes’ Passion, Mozart’s Requiem and Magnificat, Anton Bruckner’s TeDeum, Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, Zimmerman’s Misa Profana, Mendelssohn’s Elijah, Handel’s Samson and The Messiah, Verdi’s Requiem, Rossini’s Le Petite Messe Solenelle, and Puccini’s Missa di Gloria.

He has also given concerts in New York, Baltimore, Chicago, and San Francisco in the United States; Seoul, South Korea; Beijing, Xiamen, and Quangzho in the People’s Republic of China; Charles, Rouen, Troyes, and Fécamp in France; Düsseldorf, Berlin, Krefeld, Mönchen-Gladbach, Giessen, and other cities in Germany; Switzerland; Hong Kong; and Manila. A recent concert was at the Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall in New York in 2001.

With his background in economics and business administration and between his singing engagements, Aseniero is a businessman and has served as director of the National Economic Development Authority (NEDA) economic information staff. He is also the president of APO Production Unit, Inc. Ten Pillar Corporation (USA), and Asephil Inc.Written byRamon Jocson, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

ASIN The folk pop music group Asin is composed of Fred “Pendong” Aban, bass guitarist; Mike “Nonoy” Pillara Jr, acoustic guitarist; Lolita Carbon, rhythm guitarist, lead vocalist; and Cesar “Saro” Bañares, lead guitarist.

The group started with Pillara and Bañares who began doing the folkhouse circuit in 1977. They were then known as Salt of the Earth. Later Aban and Carbon joined the group. They were playing together in a folkhouse in Taft, Manila when they were discovered by Tony Ocampo, general manager of Vicor Records. They initially recorded two singles for the recording company: “Masdan Mo ang Kapaligiran” (Look at the Environment) and “Sayang Ka” (You’re Such a Waste). It was followed by a long-playing album, Asin (Salt), which was released in 1978. The said album introduced to the listening public the repertoire of Asin songs that are based on the dramatic and ingenious integration of Filipino indigenous music and pop instruments. The group was first managed by Joseph Olaguer, who was succeeded by Dindo Pillora, and later by Ed Formoso. Nonoy Pillora broke his ties with the group in 1986 to concentrate on his painting. Only the trio of Aban, Bañares and Carbon was left. The group officially disbanded in 1991 after the members decided to pursue separate singing careers.

Aban concentrated on his group called Grupong Pendong. Lolita Carbon went on to release a cassette featuring the music of her Nene Band. Bañares continued singing in folkhouses in Marvela, Davao until he was murdered in Apr 1993. Asin had a tour in Canada in Sep 2005 titled Konsyerto Para sa Kapayapaan (Concert for Peace). The following month, they had farewell concert in Toronto. An open-air and free reunion concert in 2010 was held in Koronadal City as part of South Cotabato’s 11th T’nalak Festival.

The directions of the group’s growth are reflected in such works as “Ludima,” “Lagablab sa Katimugan” (Blaze in the South), “Mahal Kong Panaginip” (Cherished Dream), and “Para sa Inyo” (For You). In their earlier album, Mga Awit ng Bayan Kong Pilipinas (Songs of My Country, the Philippines), 1984, Asin used bamboo flutes, the kudyapi, hagalong, kulintang, and dabakan, while exhibiting traces of the influence of Western pop musicians like the Beatles from the 1960s. The album’s major cuts include “Cebuanong Daku” (Big Cebuano), “Ang Sigaw ng Puso ni Awid” (The Cry of Awid’s Heart), and “Siga” (Toughie). The rest of Asin’s hits include cuts from their 1983 album Himig ng Lahi (Song of the Race), and their old pieces, dating back to 1978, “Mga Limot na Bayani” (Forgotten Heroes), “Pagbabalik” (Homecoming), “ltanong mo sa mga Bata” (Ask the Children), and “Ang Bayan kong Sinilangan” (The Land of my Birth).

Aside from the albums mentioned above, the group, composed of Aban, Bañares and Carbon, produced other long-playing albums, namely, Himig Kayumanggi (Song of the Brown Race), 1983, Sinta (Beloved), 1988 , and Mga Ginintuang Awitin ng Asin (The Golden Songs of Asin), 1984. Other albums followed: Masdan Mo ang Kapaligiran Special Collector’s Edition, 1994; The Best of Lolita Carbon, 1996; Pag-ibig, Pagbabago, Pagpapatuloy (Love, Change, Continuity), 2001; and Ang Bayan Kong Sinilangan: Paglalakbay sa mga Awitin ng ASIN (Land of My Birth: Journey Through the Songs of ASIN), a three-CD compilation of ASIN’s top hits, 2005.

The group was a two-time winner of the Best Folk Group award from the Aliw Awards in 1978 and 1979. They also received the Cecil Awards’ Best Song of the Year for the song “Orasyon” (Angelus), Best Ethnic Music for the song “Mahiwagang Tao” (Strange Man), and Best Vocal Arrangement for the song “Lupa” (Earth). They also won the Best Vocal Arrangement award for the song “Sinisinta Kita” (You are My Darling) from the Awit Awards in 1989. In 2005, Asin, represented by Carbon and Aban, was the only Filipino artist group awarded as one of the 2004 Environmental Champions by the DENR-World Bank Publication–Environmental Monitor 2004, given in June 2005. The song “Dalawang Dekada ng ASIN” (Two Decades of ASIN), a classical arrangement of all of ASIN’s top hit songs, won Best Musical Arrangement in the 2002 Awit Awards. Carbon continues to perform in music bars and local TV shows after having formed a new trio called Tres Marias with fellow singers Bayang Barrios and Cooky Chua. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Connie Ladrido

Sources:

Bernales 2005; Estabillo 2000; Lolita Carbon website 2013; South Cotabato News 2010.

ASOCIACION MUSICAL DE FILIPINAS Spearheaded by Jovita Fuentes in 1919, it had among its members Natividad Ocampo Arellano, Victorina Lobregat, Adelina Gurrea, Bonifacio Abdon, Mamerto Roxas, and Juan Arellano. The Asociacion aimed to promote good music by encouraging the production and performance of original Filipino compositions, as well as inviting foreign artists and providing financial assistance to needy musicians. The first elected officers were Arellano, president; Lobregat, vice-president; and Fuentes, treasurer.

During its lifetime, the Asociacion staged numerous concerts that featured famous arias from Italian operas and foreign art songs performed alongside original works by such Filipino composers as Nicanor Abelardo, Bonifacio Abdon, Francisco Santiago, Jose Estella, Juan S. Hernandez, and Antonio J. Molina. Foreign artists were also invited to perform, such as violinists Mischa Elman and Jan Kubelik, and pianist Alexander Sclarevsky. Fuentes also included folk songs in the Asociacion’s concert repertoire, and it was during one of those concerts that she first sang in public the Visayan “Walay Angay” (Not Suited) and “ Ay Kalisud” (Ah, Misery). The Asociacion also had its own choral group, Orfeon, which debuted onstage with a performance of Bonifacio Abdon’s “Kundiman.” Among those who had been provided with financial assistance by the Asociacion were Ernesto Vallejo, Galia Arellano, Fuentes, Isang Tapales, and Jose Maceda who all pursued further studies abroad.

In 1927 to 1931, the Asociacion supported the symphonic concerts of Alexander Lippay, the Austro-Hungarian composer who led the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music from 1925 to 1930. Members of the executive committee of the 1926-27 first symphonic offering were: Jose C. Abreu as president, Alfonso Fresnido as vice-president, Ramon Valdes Pica as secretary, Julio Esteban Anguita as vice-secretary, Anita Vaca as treasurer, Victorina Lobregat as vice-treasurer, with members Ramon Genato, Martin Hackhofer, Dolores Heras, Manuel V. del Rosario, and Mrs. Thomas Cary Welch. In a Jan 1932 program of the Manila Symphony Society, the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas was given a special recognition with a list of its board of directors led by Rosario A. de Roensch, Carmen R. de Mandelbaum, Rosario Valdes Pica, A.V.H. Hartendorp, Julio Nakpil, Teresa Legarda, Mrs. A. von Arend, Victorina Lobregat, Carmen Bastida, Anita Vaca and Mrs. H.G. Hornbostel. It was also in 1932 when the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas help found the Manila Symphony Society (MSS) under the guidance of conductor Alexander Lippay. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Ma. Edelyquinn Sy-Beltran

ASOSASYON NG MUSIKONG PILIPINO (AMP) AMP is a musicians’ guild whose principal endeavor is to promote the professionalization of session musicians. It also aims to preserve and promote Filipino music cultural heritage in the realm of Afro-American jazz. Conceived by Amelita Ramos and John Lesaca in the early 1990s, the AMP has since aspired to confront the challenging issues being faced and experienced by active Filipino working musicians. At present, music director, composer, and saxophone player Mel Villena manages the organization, whose current active members include Jun Austria (drums), Joey Quirino (keyboard), Tots Tolentino (tenor sax/flute), Michael Guevara (tenor sax/flute/clarinet), Nestor Gonzaga (trumpet), Ronnie Marqueses (trombone), Oscar Hernandez (trombone), Vanessa Celestual (trombone), Noel Santiago (guitar), Romy San Jose (trumpet), Simon Tan (bass), Romy Francisco (trumpet), Cocoy de Pano (trumpet), George Abundo (trumpet), Joey de Guzman (alto sax/clarinet/flute), Panggo Sarreal (tenor sax/clarinet), Roxy Modesto (baritone sax/clarinet/bass clarinet), Jojo Luz (percussions), Ulyssis Avante (percussions), and Myra Ruaro (Skarlet vocalist).

Part of the objectives of the organization is to hone continuously the skill, musicianship, and musicality not only of the members of the guild, but of amateur and university student musicians as well. With most of the members’ keen attachment to jazz playing, this objective led to the establishment of the AMP Big Band, with all the members mentioned above as the instrumentalists and Mel Villena as music director. This has become a setting for the musicians to practice their ensemble playing and improvisational skills. As they are able to play music apart from what they perform as session musicians, they have institutionalized themselves as a performance unit, playing in both public and private gigs alike.

The AMP Big Band began performing at Ten 02 (later renamed Skarlet Jazz Kitchen), Myra Ruaro’s jazz bar and restaurant in Timog Ave, Quezon City in 2009. When it closed down in 2012, the band continued rehearsing and performing at Tierry Garcia’s Balete@Kamias located at Kamias Road in Quezon City. Until the present, this house-turned-into-restaurant has become a venue for jazz music enthusiasts and musicians, student or professional, and for event clients. The gigs have brought AMP their corporate and private event performances and concerts. Most notable are their shows in the ABS-CBN network’s singing game show, The Singing Bee; their collaborative performances with international jazz artists such as Makoto Ozone; and their frequent presence in the entertainment program of Malacanang’s state luncheons and dinners. They have also performed for world leaders such as Pres Barack Obama. Written by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

ASPIRAS, CARMENCITA (Carmencita Sipin-Aspiras) aka Carmencita Sipin. b. Manila 27 Apr 1939. Pianist, teacher. Her parents are Telesporo Sipin of Santiago, Ilocos Sur and Carmen Olier of San Jacinto, Pangasinan. She is married to Armando Aspiras, with whom she has a daughter, Gia Aspiras Wunderlich.

She learned piano playing when she was five years old from her mother, an amateur pianist. She practiced on an upright piano that was given by her father as a wedding gift to her mother. A year after, she began piano lessons with Hermogenes de Guzman, a graduate of the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music. After four years, the family resided in Manila and she enrolled at the UP Conservatory of Music as a pupil of Juan Bañez. At age 11, she was chosen as a soloist in Mozart’s Concerto in D Minor KV 466 at UP Conservatory’s Christmas Concert. Bañez took her along when he moved to the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) School of Music when she was 14. At 17, she earned the artist’s diploma course in PWU. She played three piano concertos of contrasting styles in her graduation recital with Luis Valencia conducting the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra. Lucrecia R. Kasilag was her mentor after Bañez migrated to the United States.

A namesake, Carmencita Lozada, a violin student of Luis Valencia in the same school, became a duo partner. They played not only in school programs but in formal concerts as well. They both enrolled at the Vienna Academy of Music in 1959 on scholarship grants from the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines. Bruno Seidlhofer took Sipin as a student after passing the audition. She took summer courses at the Mozarteum in Salzburg, Austria and at the Internationale Academie d’Ete in Nice, France under the legendary Brazilian Magda Tagliaferro, a protege of Alfred Cortot. It was Tagliaferro from whom she learned the unhurried and elegant approach to piano playing.

Sipin successfully passed the rigorous Reifepruefung (maturity test) of the Konzertfach (concertist course) after six years of study at the Vienna Academy of Music, the last three of which she had Grete Hinterhofer as her mentor. She took private lessons in the next two years with the severe Richard Hauser. She had her Vienna debut at the Brahms Hall of the historic Musikverein in 1963, which elicited critical acclaim from Vienna’s Kurier: “Sipin interpreted her varied program with a wide range of tonal colors, sense of style and excitement.” She received another rave review for her 1964 performance in Stuttgart, Germany from the Stuttgart Rheinische Volksblatt: “...such a pianist of extraordinary capabilities and refinement of taste.” After a performance at a Festival in Karlsruhe, Germany, the Badische Volksblatt wrote in 1966: “The highlight of the evening was the playing of the young Filipino pianist Carmencita... with virtuosity, temperament and astounding technical facility.”

In Manila where she continued to perform and teach, Adelaida Katigbak of Manila Times wrote in 1975: “Her rendition of the Beethoven Concerto No. 4 was... marked by an overall refinement, which reflected a cultivated musical background.” Earlier in 1971, Vilma S. Felipe wrote: “To listen to her is so refreshing to the thirsty soul.” Of her more recent performance (2011), Antonio C. Hila hailed her “the grand dame of elegant pianism.”

She was the featured soloist in the Schumann Concerto of the CCP Philharmonic in 1972 (Philamlife Auditorium, Luis Valencia conducting). She was also the soloist in Chopin’s Concerto in F Minor, op. 21 during the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra Anniversary Concert of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1974. She was the soloist in Mozart D Minor KV 466 with visiting Dutch conductor Antonia Brico in 1975. Moreover, she was soloist in the Philippine premiere of Sir Michael Tippett’s Piano Concerto with the composer conducting in 1984. She was featured soloist in Beethoven Concerto No. 4, op. 58 and, again, Chopin’s F Minor, op. 21 in the Metro Manila Concert Orchestra conducted by Josefino Toledo at Santiago Hall in 2008.

Carmencita continues to perform and teach. Her memoir, At the Piano and Beyond, an autobiographical sketch that illuminates the lessons she learned along with experiences that influenced her musical mindset, was launched at the Ayala Museum in 2015. Written byAntonio C. Hila

ASUNCION, SAMMY (Samuel Villaseñor Asuncion) b. Malaybalay, Bukidnon 6 Dec 1953. Guitarist and multi-instrumentalist, vocalist, arranger, composer, musical director, album producer, film scorer. He is the son of Concordia Villaseñor, a high school principal, and Leandro Asuncion, a school district supervisor. He is primarily known for his work with the bands Spy, Pinikpikan, and Kalayo. Asuncion’s father was a musician who played the violin and piccolo. It was from him that Asuncion received his first formal instruction in music. Asuncion actively performed in grade school and high school, playing guitar and singing in various school activities and convocations. In college, he formed a blues band, which did covers of Jimi Hendrix and Santana.

After getting his degree in business management from Ateneo de Cagayan or Xavier University, he left Bukidnon in 1976 to explore the Manila music scene. He then formed the band Southern Blues, playing blues and rock-and-roll in the Manila bars that were popular during that time, such as Hobbit House, Bodega Mabini, Kola House in Kalaw, and My Father’s Moustache along M.H. del Pilar St. In 1982, he teamed up with Lolita Carbon and Popong Landero, and they toured all over the Philippines as the trio Lolita and the Sulabama.

In Jan 1983, Asuncion left Manila and moved to Paris, France, where he had gigs, playing as a solo act in cafes and bars. This eventually led him to collaborate with international musicians, resulting in the group High Hats composed of musicians from Cape Cod and Massachusetts, and the band On The Spot, which he established with French mulatto musical artists.

Around this time, Asuncion would often fly back to Manila for short breaks. One such visit gave birth to Eurasia, dubbed as the “first local reggae band” in the Philippines. Asuncion did guitar and vocal duties alongside Rico Velez on bass, Pete Canzon on saxophone, and Rene Tengasantos on drums. When Asuncion returned to Europe, Eurasia reshuffled its lineup and eventually became Cocojam.

In 1990, Asuncion formed the seminal band Spy with Viennese drummer Fritz Barth and Parisian bassist Maurice Cassanove. Spy played in concerts in France and did a musical tour in Germany, before finally making Manila their permanent home base. They went on to produce five albums: Spy by Spy, Come on Home, Reggae Man, Global Unity, and Cosmic Blah Blah. As of 2014, Spy’s new roster of members are Reli de Vera on drums and Louie Talan on bass. Talan also does bass duties for Asuncion’s other bands, such as Pinikpikan.

Originally starting as a drum circle in 1989, Pinikpikan eventually evolved into a world music performing group with a full-band setup when Asuncion stepped in. The band played regular gigs in various folkhouses and art spaces, such as 70s Bistro, Penguin, and Verve Room. It also played in major art and music festivals in Baguio, Cebu, and Davao, and represented the Philippines in Cambodia and Singapore.

Under Asuncion’s tutelage, Pinikpikan garnered five recognitions from the Katha Music Awards in 2000 for their album Atas (Duty), 1999, and bagged the prize in the categories Album of the Year, Best World Song, Best World Performance, Best World Album, and Best Instrumental Performance. In 2008, Pinikpikan adopted a new name, Kalayo, which means “fire” in Hiligaynon.

The year 2012 saw Asuncion returning to his blues roots, playing guitar for the group Kat Magic Express, which bagged the prize in the First Philippine Blues Competition (PBC) conducted by the Philippine Blues Society. In 2014, Asuncion’s new band Glass Cherry Breakers emerged victorious in the 3rd Philippine Blues Competition and was selected to represent the Philippines in the 31st International Blues Challenge in Memphis, Tennessee, in Jan 2015. Its members include Maegan Aguilar on vocals, Louie Talan on bass, Niki Cabardo on keyboards, and Boyet Aquino on drums.

As of 2015, Asuncion teaches music at the secondary and tertiary levels at the European International School in Parañaque. Written byFrancesca Casauay

Sources:

Asuncion 2014; Bello 2008; Caruncho 2013; Colvin 2015; Gargantiel 2012; Hilario 1997; Spy Facebook Page 2014.
AUNOR, NORA (See FILM volume.)

Ariston Avelino(Ariston Tejoro Avelino), also known asAris, was a composer, film scorer, conductor, and pianist. He was bornin Tondo, Manila on 7 September 1911. He died in Tagaytay City on 18 February 1980.His father, Juan Avelino, was a music teacher; his mother, Nicolasa Tejoro, sang in school choruses; his sister Dolores played the piano. He married movie actor Lirio Lakindanum. He played the piano by ear, and later learned to read notes. He taught himself to play the clarinet and saxophone. During his high school days at the Manila East (now Mapa High) School, he played in the school orchestra as pianist. After graduating from high school in 1929, Avelino could not afford to go on to college, so he worked and joined Serafin Payawal’s Orchestra, which played dance music at the Bayview Hotel.

He was also the pianist of the Modern Theater in Sampaloc and of the Starr Phonograph Company which released top hit records of the day. Later he joined the KZRM Orchestra as pianist under Johnny Harris. After Harris’ resignation, he became its conductor and subsequently program director.

During the Japanese Occupation, he played for community programs and stage shows. After World War II, he returned to radio work and at the same time organized an orchestra. He also had a stint as conductor of the Manila Polo Club Orchestra. In 1949 he resigned from radio but continued conducting the orchestra for the Camay Theatre of the Air for two more years. Avelino’s talent in composing music was enhanced when he attended Miklos Rosza’s lectures on motion picture scoring at the University of California during his trip to the United States in 1951-52.

It was while Avelino was at KZRM that he first composed for motion pictures. His first assignment, Dalaga, Isang Ngiti Mo Lamang (Lady, Just a Smile From You), 1940, was followed by many others, including the scores for Padre Burgos (Father Burgos), 1949; Sisa , 1951; HanggangsaDulongDaigdig (To the Ends of the Earth), 1958; and Habang Buhay (While There is Life), 1953.

In 1953, he won an award from the Filipino AcademyofMovie Arts andSciences (FAMAS) for musical direction for his work on the movie Habang Buhay. His scores for Desperado (Desperate), 1956, and Condenado (Condemned), 1958, were nominated for Best Musical Score in 1957 and 1959 respectively. From 1955 to 1972, he composed 89 movie songs, with years 1965 and 1966 being his most productive period. Aside from film scoring, Avelino composed jazzy popular tunes, lyrical ballads, and kundiman. He received a special citation from the KapisananngmgaBrodkastersaPilipinas (KBP) for his achievements. Written by J. Dalisay, updated by Josephine Baradas

AVES, BOB (Roberto Yulo Aves) b. Bacolod City 18 Jun 1954. d. 15 Jan 2019. Guitarist, composer, arranger. He was the son of Jose Castro Aves and Anunciacion Torres Yulo. He was married to singer-composer Grace Nono . He started tinkering with the piano before picking up the guitar at age twelve. In 1969, he listened to rock-guitarists Jimi Hendrix and John Mclaughlin and then to trumpeter Miles Davis, all of whom became early influences. He attended the University of the Philippines College of Music from 1974 to 1976, then moved to Boston, USA where he studied at the Berklee College of Music majoring in composition. He graduated with a bachelor degree from Berklee in 1979. He was considered a star student in arranging by Herb Pomeroy. He also studied privately with Hugo Norden of Boston Conservatory.

Back in Manila in 1980, he started his career as a guitarist and bandleader of various groups in the pop-rock and smooth-jazz genres, as an arranger for numerous big names in the local music scene, and as a composer of jingles for the advertising industry. After accumulating modest revenues, Aves established a home recording studio and embarked on a long journey of producing local artists in a multitude of genres. His first solo album in 1989, Welcome, under Aguilar Music, was his initial foray into World Music.

He co-produced a twin album with singer-ethnomusicologist Grace Nono, Tao Music (Human Music), 1991, which garnered positive reviews for the original arrangement of the traditional song “Salidomay,” and Opo (Respecful Yes), 1994, both under the international BMG Record label. In 1997, he married Grace Nono at rites held in Mount Makiling, Laguna. Eventually, the partnership would lead to a slew of collaborative albums such as Isang Buhay (One Life), 1997, and Hulagpos (Breaking Free), 1998. Inspired by indigenous Philippine music patterns like sinulog, binalig, and tangunggo, he learned to play the kudlong (indigenous lute) and octavina (16-fret guitar with short neck), and improvised on compositions influenced by Spanish folk and American jazz traditions. These improvisations culminated in a landmark album called, Inner Country, 2000, also under BMG records. Two follow-up albums, Translating the Gongs, 2006, and Out of Tradition, 2013, established Aves’ name in the world music genre.

His selected compositions for dance and theater productions include those for Agnes Locsin ’s: Sayao sa Pamlang, Pangalay, Sagayan, Kzuduratan, Kuntao, and Bamboo Holders; Indios Bravos for Dwight Rodrigazo ’s Airdance; and Alden Lugnasin ’s Ulaging, for Ballet Philippines . His film feature scores were done for Ramona Diaz’s Imelda, winner of the Sundance Film Festival, 2004; Sari Dalena ’s Memories of a Forgotten War, 2001, and Rigodon, 2005; Will Fredo’s Compound, 2006, and In Nomine Matris (In the Name of the Mother), 2012. Aves did selected audiovisual scores for the Philippine Pavilion World Exposition in Seville, Spain in 1992; Lisbon, Portugal in 1998; and Zaragoza, Spain in 2008.

Aves received the Katha Award for Best Instrumental Album for Inner Country in 2000 and for Best Alternative Album for Bo Razon’s Biyahero (Traveller) in 1998, for Jong Cuenco’s Imagine in 1999, for Wency Cornejo’s Himig (Music) in 2000, and for Lloyd Umali’s Babalikang Muli (To Return Once More) in 2000. Aves won the NU107 Album of the Year award in 1998 for The Jerks. He also received the 1996 Catholic Mass Media and Katha Awards for Album of the Year for Opo (Yes); the 1998 Katha Award for Producer of the Year for Isang Buhay; the 1998 Katha Award for Best World Music Album for Hulagpos; and the 2002 Catholic Mass Media Award Album of the Year for Diwa (Soul). All these albums were done in collaboration with Grace Nono. Written by Richie Quirino

AYALA, JOEY (Jose Iñigo Homer Lacambra Ayala) b. Camp Philipps, Bukidnon 1 Jun 1956. Singer-songwriter, composer, poet. He is the eldest of six children of fictionist, poet, painter, and agriculturist Jose V. Ayala Jr and fictionist, poet, painter, publisher-editor Tita Lacambra. Ayala is married to Jessie Soroñgon with whom he has two sons. He finished his elementary and high school at the Ateneo de Manila and got his Economics degree from the Ateneo de Davao in 1983.

While in high school he wrote songs in English and contributed articles, stories, and poems to Jingle Magazine and other nationwide publications. After the family moved to Davao in 1973, he began to write in Filipino. In 1986, Ayala performed in Canada at the Vancouver Folk Music Festival and in the British Columbia Gulf Islands, and in the Bay Area in San Francisco, California, USA. In 1987, he formed Bagong Lumad, becoming its bandleader and main songwriter. He has given concerts and tours with the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in various venues and different regions of the Philippines, and has reached audiences in Japan, India, London, Paris, Hawaii, and Vietnam. In 1988, he founded Bagong Lumad Artists Foundation Inc (BLAFI).

In 1977, Ayala supplied the rhythms and melodies to the rock opera Sa Bundok ng Apo (On Mount Apo), with playwright-librettist Al Santos and choreographer Agnes Locsin. In 1978, he demonstrated his diverse talents as scriptwriter, composer, musical director, and performer in the production of Lansangan (Streets), an audiovisual concert. He was also musical director, composer, and performer in the following ethno-and-punk-rock musicals: May-i, May-i, 1979, Nukleyar I, 1983, and II, 1985, all produced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA); Sampung Dekada (Ten Decades), 1983, a documentary-drama on the founding of the Augustinian order; Sinalimba, 1987, a “neo-ethnic” opera; Ang Misyonaryo: Bulawanong Tipugas (The Missionary: A Divine Planter), 1987; Kuwentong Dabaw (Davao Stories), 1988; Saging sa Kasing-kasing (Fruit of the Heart), 1988; Gabriela, 1989; and Mga Awit ng Tanod-lupa (Songs of the Earth Guardian), 1990. In 1992, he collaborated once more with librettist Al Santos and choreographer Agnes Locsin to produce the much acclaimed neo-ethnic modern ballet Encantada (Enchantress) for Ballet Philippines. Encantada was toured extensively abroad and was restaged at the CCP in 2011 and in Davao in 2012.

In 1982, he came out with his first recorded album, Panganay ng Umaga (Morning’s Firstborn), which was released again in 1989 with funding from CIDA, a Canadian development agency. Panganay… gave the public a taste of the raw music and haunting lyrics characteristic of Ayala’s work. With his band, he made his second independently produced cassette, Magkabilaan (Dualities), in 1987, which included Ayala’s much-beloved “Walang Hanggang Paalam” (Endless Farewell). This was followed by Mga Awit ng Tanod-lupa, 1990, which was supported by the Department of Environment and Natural Resources because of its ecological message. In 1991, his three albums were re-issued by WEA (now Universal Records), marking the entry of his alternative music into the mainstream of the music industry. This was followed by his fourth album Lumad sa S’yudad (A Native in the City) released by Universal Records in 1992; his fifth, Lupa’t Langit (Heaven and Earth), released by Star Records in 1997; his sixth, 16 Love Songs, released independently in 2003; and his seventh, Awit ng Magdaragat (Song of the Seafarer), produced with the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources in 2005. The last was staged as a community theater piece on an island in the Visayas and as the ballet Awit ng Magdaragat at the University of the Philippines College of Music in 2013.

An album of selected songs and the newly composed “Narito” (Here), done in collaboration with his sister-artist Cynthia Alexander, Ayala’s take on prosperity-consciousness and “ikot-nomiks,” was self-produced in 2009 for the Sining Bayan Art of Nation Building Fieldbook published by BLAFI, University of the Philippines National College of Public Administration and Governance, and the United Nations Development Program.

In 2011, Ayala initiated the Palay Bigas Kanin album and Core Book Project during his chairmanship of the Music Committee of the NCCA. In 2013, Ayala’s “Reinvented Lupang Hinirang” went viral on YouTube, presenting “ang magmahal nang dahil sa’yo” as his recommended edit to the Philippine National Anthem.

Ayala was chosen by the Philippine Jaycees as one of the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) in 1989, and recipient of the Gerry Roxas Leadership Medal. He also received the Gawad Tanglaw ng Lahi from the Ateneo de Manila University in 1991; a special citation from the Concerned Women of the Philippines, 1992; Gawad ng Pagkilala from the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino, 1993; Special MAGIS Award for Outstanding Alumni, 1996; Special Philippine Centennial Citation by the City of Davao, 1998; Datu Bago Award by the City of Davao, 2000; Fr Neri Satur Award for Environmental Heroism awarded by the NCCA, 2009; and numerous awards from the music industry and various artist organizations. He is listed in volume 1 of Adarna Books’ 101 Filipino Icons, published in 2007. He won a Palanca Award for his short story in English, “Perfect Sunday” in 1983. Written byMilagros Carunungan, updated by Pauline Bautista

BAES, JONAS (Jonas Baes) b. Los Baños, Laguna 4 Mar 1961. Composer, ethnomusicologist. His early musical exposure was through his father who conducted the University of the Philippines (UP) Los Baños ROTC band. In his teens, from 1977 to 1983, he joined an underground rock band called Tulisanes (Bandits). He enrolled at UP College of Music, major in composition, in 1977, and finished a bachelor’s degree in 1982. From 1992 to 1994, he did postgraduate studies Aufbaustudium at the Staatliche Hochschule für Musik in Freiburg, Germany. From the bachelor’s degree program in UP, he absorbed the avant-garde works of Jose Maceda and Ramon Santos and learned traditional Southeast Asian music such as Kalinga, Maguindanaon, and Javanese gamelan music. Musical processes of these traditions are reflected in his own compositions. In Germany, Jonas studied under Mathias Spahlinger. He later enrolled in the PhD Philippine Studies program of UP Diliman and finished the degree in 2004 with a dissertation on the politics of appropriating indigenous Philippine music.

Baes’s music is committed to an alternative concept of art music or “new music.” He sees composition as a radical, interactive, collaborative process, with flexible instrumentation. This is evident in all his compositions, including a penchant for works in which audiences participate by manipulating non-conventional sound sources. Pangtawag (Music for Calling People) was performed in a procession around UP Diliman campus in 1981 and employed 50 to 100 voices, sound sources such as scrapers and leaves. In 1982, he composed Kalipay (Happiness), a meditative work for 100 bamboo instruments, 100 voices, with an audience who plugged and unplugged their ears. He composed the work Daluy (Flow), 1994, a set of five pieces for five percussionists/animators playing bamboo instruments, together with the audience striking pebbles and chanting messages on vital social issues.

Baes’s view of the necessary relationship between music and politics has led him to compose music that advocates for the representation and rights of marginalized groups. His research from 1982 to 1987 among the Iraya Mangyan inspired him to compose Yayeyunan (Melody), 1985, which is for five women’s voices and 20 bamboo instruments. In 1983, he composed Basbasan (Blessing) for 20 bean-pod rattles and 20 men’s voices. This was his contribution to a memorial concert honoring the assassination of the returning political exile Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino. During this period, Baes composed and recorded protest songs against the dictatorship. His championing of the Filipino masses is reflected in his piece Huntahang-Bayan (People’s Forum), 1992-93, in which animators and the public discuss social issues through chanting. His song “Oyayi” (Lullaby) 1993, for female voice and pebbles played by the audience has been performed for various feminist advocacy gatherings. He composed Ibo/Ibon (Woman/Bird) for dance, with four animators and iron nail chimes distributed among the audience. The concept of distribution, dialogue, exchange, and dialectic is an aspect of his vision for music interaction and this is seen in his work Banwa (Nation), 1997, which was inspired by Benedict Anderson’s idea of “imagined community” and written for four bamboo scrapers, and other bamboo instruments, 100 bird whistle flutes played by the audience. In the piece Wala (Nothing), 1997, seven or hundreds of voices play on the opposition and integration of forces. His work Balawang-Paikutan (Swidden Stamping Poles), 1999, for five dancers, animators, voices, and audience is an allegorical ritual about the death of ancestral lands. His recent works include Patangis-Buwaya... And the Crocodile Wept, 2003, a ritual improvisation for four bass recorders and four indigenous instruments; Aguyoy (Gentle Wind), 2005, for hollow woodblock, three buray-dipay, small and large rasps, or tagutok, sticks or tree branches or dried leaves; Lisan (Leaving), 2007, a soundfilm with Jerrold Tarog, on the plight of the Iraya Mangyan; N/REPA, the Mimesis of Spirits, 2009, for indigenous flute with wind instruments and audience playing bird-whistles, iron nail chimes, and pair of pebbles; InAYTA (In Ayta Style), music for sound installation, 2010; Dinanggaan (Spirit Invocation), 2011, for flute, alto saxophone, tam-tam; Gandhing-Ni-Napi (Napi’s Lament), 2011, for suspended Maguindanaon gandingan, five trombones, five tam-tams, and audience, again plugging and unplugging their ears and playing iron-nail chimes; Babandir (hanging gong with narrow rim), 2012, for diverse percussion instruments; and Gita’a (Dissolution) for broken guitar and audience using crumpled plastic cups and empty water bottles, 2013.

As a scholar, Baes has published in international journals such as Ethnomusicology, 1987, the International Review of the Aesthetics and Sociology of Music, 1989, Perfect Beat, 1998, and the Journal of Intercultural Studies, 2001. He received the UP Diliman Gawad Chancellor for his research works on Philippine music in 2003. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

BALSAMO, JOED (Jude Edgard Caballero Balsamo) aka Jed Balsamo. b. Cagayan de Oro 23 Oct 1977. Composer, pianist, educator. He was born to Edgardo David Balsamo, a music aficionado who played by ear, and Josefina Abrogueña Caballero who taught him music at a young age. His great granduncle Tranquilino Caballero was a composer of sarsuwela from Mangaldan, Pangasinan. His grandaunt was composer Sr Maria Rosalina Abejo, SFCC, from Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. Music educator Sr Mary Placid Abejo, OSB, of St Scholastica’s College School of Music, is his aunt.

During summers at a young age, he took piano lessons with Mela Malferarri and Gloria Delgado. Later, he played the organ for church, which he continued until high school. At age nine, he wrote a“Kordero ng Dios”(Lamb of God) which was later incorporated into hisMisa Gingoogin 1997.While in Xavier University High School, he composed the original music for the productions May Katwiran ang Katwiran (There’s Reason for a Reason)andDamaso.He enrolled at St Scholastica’s College, where he finished a degree in piano, cum laude,and in composition, cum laude, with distinction. He studied under Alice Araneta-Lim, Mauricia Borromeo, Najib Ismail, Jonas Baes, Lucio San Pedro, and Ramon Santos. He wrote his first sung-through children’s musicalMammolina while in college.

Balsamo has received commissions from local and international organizations, which featured his music in festivals, concerts, theater, film, and dance productions. The Inter-Cultural Society of London commissioned him the Piano Trio No. 2, which received critical acclaimat its world premiere in London, Jul 2013. At the39th Bamboo Organ Festival in Feb 2014, he composedTago-Tago (Hide and Seek), which was interpreted by the Las Piñas Boys Choir. In Aug 2014, he released online the original soundtrack ofSandosenang Sapatos (A Dozen Shoes), which heco-composed with Noel Cabangon. This piece was also the official Philippine entry to the 6th Theater Olympics in Beijing. For Ballet Philippines (BP), he composedCrisostomo Ibarra. In 2015, he composed the music for Gantimpala Theater Foundation’s Kanser@35, The Musical. He was also commissioned to arrange and direct the music for APEC 2015 events.

His first song cycle for countertenor titledInahan (Motherly), with text written by Jay Rey Alovera, was based on remembered themes from a very young age which he also used in scoring the Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival full-length film entry Concerto, 2008, and earned him a nomination for Best Music at the 6th Golden Screen Awards and 32nd Gawad Urian. In the field of music and dance theater, he won the Gawad Buhay for Outstanding Musical Direction of BP’s Rama Hari in 2013. In 2016, he received the Outstanding Original Musical Composition andMusic Direction at the 8thPHILSTAGE Gawad Buhay! Awards for Tanghalang Pilipino’s Mabining Mandirigma (Gentle Warrior). In classical music, he received a “Special Mention” under Category C for his composition Andar 2.0, CB. 5a No. 4 (MMXV) in the 2nd Maurice Ravel International Composition Competition, Northern Italy. As pianist, he won second prize at the 2001 National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA), Category C, as well as Best Performance of a Filipino piece and third prize at the University of the Philippines Millennium Piano Competition in Jul 2000.

Balsamois currently a full time faculty at the Centro Escolar University Conservatory of Music, the resident music director for BP, and is a member of the Asian Composers’ League Philippines, Philippine Choral Directors Association, and of the Executive Music Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, 2011-16.Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

BAMBOO (Francisco Gaudencio Lope Bernardo Mañalac) aka Bamboo Mañalac. b. Manila 19 Jan 1978. Musician, singer, songwriter. Bamboo established his fame primarily as the lead vocalist of the popular alternative or indie rock band Rivermaya that consisted of Nathan Azarcon (bass), Rico Blanco (keyboards), Perfecto de Castro (guitars), and Mark Escueta (drums) in the 1990s. He later became the front man of his own band, Bamboo, which he founded in 2002 along with Ira Cruz, Nathan Azarcon, and Vic Mercado. The group disbanded in 2011.

In the wake of a series of hits by Rivermaya and subsequently by Bamboo, Mañalac distinguished himself for his unique vocal tone and performance style. He was awarded the vocalist of the year in the 2004 NU Rock Awards and was cited in the MTV Style Awards rock category. Bamboo is recognized as the “Prince or King of Rock” in the Philippines. His hit single, “Tatsulok” (Triangle), 2008, provided a biting critique on power abuse and poverty in Philippine society. Currently pursuing a solo career, Mañalac describes himself as a more “happy and fulfilled” individual, creating his own music and being content with ABS-CBN managing his career. His single “Questions” and a maiden album No Water, No Moon were released in 2011. He was also one of the judges in the hit TV show The Voice Philippines in 2013. Written by Lara T. Mendoza

BANDA 88 Santa Maria, Bulacan. Banda 88 of Santa Maria was established by the Spanish governor of Bulacan Antonio Rodriguez in 1888. Its band membership has been sustained for over a hundred years because its members have always been closely related to each other by lineage or friendships. The band has been maintained by families that continuously transmitted the skills and knowledge of music to their children.

Numerous engagements and commitments have been given by the band to the province of Bulacan. Banda 88 won the San Miguel Corporations Balik Banda Competition provincial level held in Santa Maria, Bulacan in 1978. They were led by Ricardo Quiambao who conducted Lucio San Pedro’s Lahing Kayumanggi Overture (Brown Race Overture) as their contest piece. This achievement earned them the right to represent the province of Bulacan in the finals of Balik Banda that was held at Quirino Grandstand, Luneta on 12 Jun 1978 as part of the celebration of Philippine Independence Day. They were also the champion of the Certamen Band Competition held in Muntinlupa, City in 2004 with their contest piece Capriccio Italien Overture by Tchaikovsky. This was conducted by their present director Arnel Jacinto who happens to be a member and double bass player of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. They were also back-to-back champion in the Antipolo City annual band competition in Dec 2004 and in 2005. This competition was part of the yearly celebration of the feast of their patron saint, the Immaculate Concepcion. Banda 88 continues to celebrate up to this day the richness of band music for the people of Bulacan.Written by Rodney D. S. Ambat

BANDA CABIAO 11 Cabiao, Nueva Ecija. Banda Cabiao was originally organized during the later part of the Spanish era. It is said that the band rules were so strict at that time that a member who failed to rehearse without sufficient excuse would be put in prison by the guardia civil (local police). At the start of the revolution in 1896, Gen Mariano Llanera invaded Factoria, now San Isidro, Nueva Ecija. Some of his men were band members, one of whom was Juan Lapuz, a bass drum player. It was at this time that Banda Cabiao members went in disarray and only 11 members remained, including Lapuz himself. He bravely continued to lead the band, which he initially named Juan de la Cruz Cabiao Band. Eventually, it became known as the Banda Cabiao 11 to commemorate the 11 men who remained in the original Banda Cabiao. Up to the present time, the band has been continuously managed by the Lapuz family in Cabiao. Today, it is directed by Camilo Lapuz, a trombone teacher who once taught at the University of the Philippines College of Music.

Other members who went on strike during the revolution formed their own band and named it Banda Cabiao 96. This name commemorated the gallantry and heroism of the pioneer members of the band. This band led the parade in Nueva Ecija during the revolution that caused the downfall of the Spanish government. The leadership and supervision of this band was inherited by Dominador Nogoy who guided the band in winning the Plaza Miranda Certamen Band Competition in 4 Jul 1952 and the National Band Contest at the Quirino Grandstand, Rizal Park in 1961. Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

BANDA DOS BATA Taytay, Rizal. Banda Dos Bata was founded as an organization in the year 1905 under the management of Jose Tamayo. This band was formerly associated with Banda Taytay, founded 1875, until the latter disbanded in the 1900s, forming two separate bands in Taytay, Rizal. The Banda Uno also known as “Banda Matanda” retains its name up to the present day, being the oldest band in the town. It consists mostly of non-Catholic and Protestant members, while the Banda Dos Bata or “Banda Makapare” was formerly under the supervision of the local parochial church. Composed of a group of relatives and friends, the management of Banda Dos was passed on to the younger generation of members. Among the members of the band who took the responsibility of training and instructing their youthful relatives were Pedro Cruz, Crispin Velasco, and German Tamayo. At its establishment in 1905, funding made the development of Banda Dos possible through the initiative of the former parish priest of Taytay, Fr Valentin Tanyag. He was responsible for providing and re-supplying the band with musical instruments which he bought from the disbanded Meralco Brass Band. In the 1950s, MSgt Felix de Leon, a former member of the Philippine Constabulary Band, became the maestro of Banda Dos Bata.

In 1953, a huge band organization in the country known as the Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas (PASAMBAP) was established under the leadership of Felipe Padilla de Leon Sr. This organization aimed to unite local bands and to promote good band music, seeking to eliminate the “show off” competition called tambakan. The Banda Dos Bata was one of the 77 band members of the PASAMBAP that has been actively participating in the group’s various activities such as National Concert Exhibition in 1954 and National Band contest in 1956 (de Leon 1966, 45). In 1957, Alfredo Villanueva Sr became the conductor of the Banda Dos Bata. The band garnered highest recognition by winning the National Championship under the baton of Felix De Leon in 1958 and in the National Balik Banda Championship under the baton of Alfredo Villanueva Sr in 1980. The latter event was organized by the San Miguel Corporation beginning in 1978, in cooperation with PASAMBAP as a program to revive and revitalize band music (Hila 1994, 137). In 1982, the late second-generation member of Banda Dos, Alfredo Villanueva Sr, was appointed vice-president for Promotions in the PASAMBAP administration. In this position, while leading the numerous community band members of PASAMBAP scattered in different regions throughout Philippines, Villanueva Sr helped Banda Dos members manage a wide variety of band activities. These included annual band festivals, seminars, workshops, and clinics that focused on band conducting and band management. Villanueva Sr’s notable contributions to the improvement of band management in the country gave him prominence and made him a model and inspiration to the younger musicians of Banda Dos.

Recognizing band music as a legitimate form of artistic expression and wishing to bring band music to wide national attention, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) organized and sponsored the series of Serenata ng mga Banda which began in 1987. Banda Dos has been one of the active participants in this annual event, particularly in the year 1984, 1986, and 1991 (Hila 1994, 138). Many prominent musicians in the country have formed a connection with the Banda Dos as guest conductor (kumbidado) of the band, including the National Artist Lucio San Pedro in the 1960s (Rubio 1966), Francisco Feliciano, and well renowned musician Gerard Salonga, founder of Filharmonika. During the early 1990s, the management of the Banda Dos was completely entrusted to third-generation members. The maestros of the band who followed were Alfredo Villanueva Jr, Edgardo Villanueva, Nephtalie Villanueva, Peping Calderon, Jose Dunca, Vicente Bernardino Jr and Benjie Velasco. In 2005, under the management of Edgardo Villanueva, the Banda Dos was registered in the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC Philippines), under its current name “Banda Taytay Dos Incorporated.”

Today, Banda Dos consists of approximately 60 members coming from various places in Rizal such as Taytay, Antipolo, Angono, Jala-Jala, and Cainta. It continues to function as a local community band in Taytay, Rizal that renders service to the community in the observance of family-based and community traditions. It continues to be managed and supported by several dedicated families and community members in Taytay who have kept the musical tradition alive since its establishment in 1905. Written by Benedict Caliwara

BANDA KAWAYAN PILIPINAS (BKP, formerly called PUP Banda Kawayan). BKP is a bamboo music ensemble based in the Polytechnic University of the Philippines (PUP) in Santa Mesa, Manila until 2013 after which it was registered in the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The group had its first performance on 19 Dec 1973 in the Christmas party of the Philippine College of Commerce (PCC), which later became PUP. This was organized by the then principal of the school, Gloria R. Talastas, and by then professor of the same institution, Siegfredo B. Calabig, who has been its composer, arranger, trainer, and instrument maker. Instruments of the BKP are made of indigenous materials, mainly bamboo and narra. The ensemble consists of marimba, lira gabbang, bumbong, panpipes, and angklung. Other instruments, also made by Calabig, are the kalagong, kalatok, and kalavien, so named to carry the first two syllables of the instrument maker’s surname, “kala.” The group is now under the artistic direction of Rossini Calabig, the eldest son of Siegfred. Rossini has also assisted his father in the construction of instruments. Rossini’s cousin, Jaime Calabig, acts as the deputy musical director.

In 2014, in its desire to expand membership and pursue its mission and vision, the group was registered as a private, nonstock, nonprofit cultural organization with the SEC under the name Banda Kawayan Pilipinas. The group, no longer part of PUP, has 50 active members, comprising of high school and college students and young professionals. Senior members have assisted in the training of new members, some of whom join the group as early as at the age of 11. Junior members are taught the rudiments of playing the bamboo instruments, fundamental musical pieces, and basic choreography during their first year. They are gradually integrated through the years into the senior group. BKP’s repertoire is wide and consists of all-time local and international favorites that cater to all music enthusiasts. Their musical performance is spiced up with creative and lively choreography.

In its more than four decades of existence, the group has performed for state functions at Malacañan Palace, events organized by Department of Tourism (DOT), program of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), and in other public and private performances all over the country and abroad. The group’s first international performance was in 1988 at the World Exposition ‘88 and Australian Centennial held in Brisbane, Australia. The group was chosen to represent the country in the International Bamboo Festival in Oita and Beppu, Japan in 1998. They were also selected as the Best Performing Group in Busan International Trade Fair in South Korea in 2006 and in Kyonggi, South Korea International Travel Exposition. In the 14th Busan International Travel Fair, South Korea in 2011, they were given the recognition of the Best Folkloric Performance. BKP’s musical instruments and style have also brought them on concert tours in Europe, North America, Australia, Middle East and other Asian countries, to promote tourism and serve as the country’s ambassador of goodwill.

Some former members of BKP have become solo artists. These are Ely Aguilar, a freelance drummer and recording artist in Australia; Johann Calabig, a freelance drummer and recording artist in the United Kingdom; and Arnulfo Escobedo Jr, a vocalist and pianist of Milk and Money. In addition, BKP members have also organized and trained similar bamboo ensembles, namely, Banda Kawayan PUP in Lopez, Quezon and in Mariveles, Bataan; FEU Bamboo Band under Norberto Cads and Jemellette Tambot; Don Bosco School Laguna, Pampanga, and Cebu under Haydn Calabig, Frances Calabig, and Vernadette Pareno; Bamboo Ensemble, Filipino Community in Alberta, Canada under Herald and Heddy Casana; Bamboo Band in Honolulu, Hawaii under Rossini and Jaime Calabig; PUP Banda Kawayan, Calauan, Laguna under Benjie Andres; and the Bamboo Ensemble of South Cotabato under Bruce Espinas and Gian Gonzales. Written by Pacita Narzo

BANDA MALAYA / BANDA UNOTaytay, Rizal. Banda Uno of Taytay was founded in 1875 by Ambrocio Manuel who also served as gobernadorcillo or town mayor of Taytay during that time. It was first named Banda Taytay, then Banda Makabayan until it was again renamed as Banda Malaya, the name by which it is known today. During the revolution of 1896, its members went their separate ways. After the revolution, some of the members organized themselves under the leadership of Celedonio Medina. Since then, the band has played under different directors, among whom were Jose Tamayo, Eugenio de Leon, Felipe Marin, Justino Bedana, Felix Bascon, Francisco Gregorio, Santiago Alejo, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Eliseo Pajaro, Daniel Naval, Felino de Leon,. Lucio D. San Pedro, Lt Col Eliseo Javier, Lt Col Pedro Tolentino Jr, Leopoldo Medina, and Leopoldo Lopez. To this day, Banda Uno of Taytay has continued to nurture the youth of Taytay who are taught band music. This thrust is considered the legacy of Daniel Naval, who is acknowledged as the Father of Banda Malaya.

The band garnered the First Prize in the 1919 Certamen Band Competition in Makati, Rizal, playing as its contest piece the overture to Il Guarani by Antonio Carlos Gomes. They also won first prize and the Magsaysay trophy award in the 1956 National Certamen Band Competition held at the Jose Rizal Stadium under the baton of Lucio San Pedro, playing Mozart’s Magic Flute Overture as contest piece. They represented the province of Rizal at the first Balik Banda Competition in 12 Jun 1978 held at the Quirino Grandstand, Luneta for the 80th anniversary celebration of the Philippine Independence Day. This competition was sponsored by San Miguel Brewery Corporation and featured the bands from Rizal, Laguna, Cavite, Quezon, Marinduque, Mindoro Oriental, Mindoro Occidental, and Palawan. Banda Malaya No. 1 won second prize in the said competition, further inspiring the youth of Taytay, Rizal to participate in the band’s activities. Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

BANDA MATANDA Malabon, General Trias, Cavite. In 1888, Don Catalino Arnaldo, a prosperous resident of San Francisco de Malabon Grande now known as General Trias Cavite, formed the Banda San Francisco de Malabon Grande. He bought the instruments and, with the help of his friends “Onofre” and “Jorge,” took care of teaching music to the town’s residents who had the musical inclination for it. Some of the original members were Ambrocio Clanor, Meliton Aroy, Salyo Batulan, Eustaquio Closas, Policarpio Culabutan, Clado Guinchoma, Anastacio Mota, Joaquin Pabalan, Antonio Poblete, Lucio Poblete, Raymundo Presa, and Candido de los Santos. During the Spanish-American war in 1898, a Filipino revolutionary named Julian Felipe migrated to San Francisco de Malabon Grande and stayed at the house of Gen Mariano Trias, a member of the secret revolutionary organization called Katipunan. Julian Felipe was a pianist and composer and he was introduced to Gen Emilio Aguinaldo in a meeting of the Katipunan. He was instructed to compose a march that would be the counterpart of the Spanish Royal March. Felipe did and after it was approved, he immediately arranged and taught it to the Banda San Francisco de Malabon Grande. The music was variously called Himno Nacional Filipino, Marcha Filipina Magdalo, Marcha Magdalo, and Aguinaldo March. On 12 Jun 1898, Aguinaldo declared Philippine independence from Spain and unfurled the revolutionary flag before the public in Kawit, Cavite. It was then that the Banda San Francisco de Malabon Grande played for the first time the march that became the Philippine National Anthem.

When Don Catalino Arnaldo died, the leadership was passed on to his son Emilio Arnaldo, then subsequently to Crispulo Arnaldo with the help of Engracio Clamor and Hilario Clanor. In 1921, a brewing conflict between Clamor and Clanor resulted in a split, despite the mediation of Crispulo Arnaldo.

Engracio Clamor founded a band called Banda Beteranos, now known as the Banda Kabataan. Hilario Clanor continued to lead the Banda San Francisco de Malabon Grande, now known as the Banda Matanda. The latter band became popular and played in the provinces of Cavite, Rizal, Bulacan, Nueva Ecija, Bataan, Laguna, Batangas, and Manila.

In 1931, Delfin Asercion, a retired US Navy, took over the supervision of the band from Hilario Clanor. Delfin later passed it on to fellow US Navy, Manuel Asercion. Some members of the band, namely, Diosdado Nocon Rios, Danilo Sotto, Diosdado Palompo and David Poblete proceeded to study at the Conservatory of Music of the University of the Philippines (UP) to help in further development of the band. Other members followed, including Eliseo Clamor who later not only taught at the UP College of Music but also became Director of the UP ROTC Band. Another notable member of the band was Agapito Afortunado who was a clarinet lecturer in UP and at the same time a member of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. Because of the band’s tradition of excellence in music, many of the members joined the US Navy and US Army Bands, Armed Forces of the Philippines Bands, Dance Bands and Symphony Orchestra. Other members like Isidro and Merofe Leano founded their own dance orchestra named Roy Leano Fil-American Orchestra in San Francisco, California. Many of them also became members of the US Navy concert and ceremonial band in Washington DC, including Rodrigo Mugol, Oscar Mugol, Rogelio Palompo, Wally Mugol, Diosdado Buan, and Norberto Clanor. Notable members from Gen Trias include Albert Asercion, a clarinet player, who became the first Filipino instructor at the US Navy School of Music in Norfolk, Virginia; Diosdado Palompo who became the Band Master of Subic Bay US Navy Band; and David Poblete who became Assistant Band Master of the 7th Fleet US Navy Band. In 1964, the Banda Matanda Foundation was formed under the leadership of Crispulo Arnaldo and Delfin Asercion with Merofe Leano as its first President.From 1888 up to the present time, Banda Matanda has displayed a strong sense of culture and excellence in band music. Written by Rodney D. S. Ambat

BANDA MORRIZ aka Banda Morong Rizal, Morriz Wind Orchestra. Founded in 1890, Banda Morriz is the first brass band on record in Morong, Rizal. It was organized by Aniceto Tupas, also known as Kapitan Titoy, a gobernadorcillo or town mayor of Distrito de Morong. The ownership changed hands in 1935 when Maximiano Feliciano Sr bought it. Since then, the band became popularly known as Banda Morriz, its name derived from the first syllables of its origin, Morong, Rizal.

In 1956, Maximiano Feliciano died. His wife Julia Feliciano took over its management with the help of her eldest sons Junior and Roberto, who were at that time young members of the band. It was in 1956 when Amando San Jose of Banda Ocho of Cardona, Rizal took pains in training the band. In his first stint as conductor, San Jose greatly improved the quality of the band’s performance for the ensuing three decades. Starting in 1983, San Jose gradually relinquished the directorship to Arnel Feliciano, who was then studying at the University of the Philippines College of Music. Arnel is a third generation member of the Feliciano family whose patriarch is Maximiano, the founder of the band. Arnel’s uncle, National Artist for Music Francisco Feliciano, assisted him in maintaining the standards of playing in Banda Morriz. In addition, Arnel was able to expand the repertoire of the band, owing to his professional experience as a member of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, a faculty member of the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music, and the assistant conductor of the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra.

Banda Morriz has performed in notable concerts outside of Morong, such as Alay sa Sambayanan at the University of the Philippines, Musika Manila in the Serenata ng mga Banda at Rizal Park, Pagdiriwang at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, in DWWW Radio Station’s Musika at Kultura, the second UST Band Festival at Philamlife Auditorium, Manila, and at the 35th Bamboo Organ Festival at Las Piñas City. Furthermore, the group was one of the active participants in the celebration of the Philippine Centennial in 1998 and in World Folklore Festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in the same year. From 2008 to 2013, it was the official marching band of SM Mall of Asia. They have been featured in various serenatas and parades held in the different cities, towns, and provinces in Luzon and the Visayas. In addition, Banda Morriz is the only community-based band in the Philippines which participated in the 2008 Chiayi International Band Festival in Taiwan. The management of the band decided to change its name to Morriz Wind Orchestra, following their international exposure.

Under Arnel Feliciano’s leadership, Banda Morriz was recognized as first prize winner in the Araw ng Taytay Band Competition; first prize winner in Antipolo Rizal’s Banda Bongga Competition; Best Band in Concert, Best Soloist and Best Conductor in Pililia Town Fiesta Competition; and first prize winner in Antipolo Town Fiesta Band Competition. They also joined the 2013 Hong Kong International Youth Marching Band Competition and emerged champion in three categories: Parade-International, Parade-Open Category, and Wind Ensemble. Currently, the band is under the tutelage of Edmel Tanawan who is Arnel Feliciano’s mentee.Written byCrisancti L. Macazo

BANDA PEÑARANDA Nueva Ecija. The band was founded in 1870 by a town musician named Pedro Mercado, becoming its first recamadero (owner) and encargado (manager). They started out as a handful of players but gradually increased its membership to serve the town of Peñaranda, Nueva Ecija. Due to financial difficulties, the band declined but the arrival of Fr Teodoro Parada, the town’s parish priest fondly known as Pari Kalabasa who was a music lover, reactivated the band. He hired a certain musician known as Maestrong Pepe to teach and conduct the band. Under his tutorship, together with Fr Parada’s financial support, the band made tremendous progress.

In 1888, Apolinar Bernabe, a native of Zamboanga who was a prolific composer and expert cornet player who married a Penaranda woman, became the band’s maestro or bandleader. Under his leadership, the band was very much in demand. Then came a time when the band split into two: “Banda Kabataan” (hulo) composed of young players and “Banda Pagkakaisa” (liwasan) composed of senior members. The intense rivalry between them resulted in improved playing thus gaining their popularity in many places in Luzon, especially during fiestas and other occasions. However, the constant feuding also had a divisive effect in the town of Peñaranda itself. Realizing this problem, Felipe Padilla de Leon, then a student at the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music, united the two groups. On Rizal Day 30 Dec 1935, the Peñaranda Band played as a unified group and gave a concert at the town plaza under the baton of the young de Leon. From then on, de Leon became the band’s conductor until the outbreak of World War II.

After the war, Felipe Padila de Leon became occupied with his teaching duties and other activities in Manila. He entrusted the band to Felicisimo Padilla, one of the more senior and experienced members of the band. Through his untiring efforts, Padilla became instrumental in sustaining the band’s mission of making music in public ceremonies.Written by Rodney D. S. Ambat
BANDA UNO (See BANDA MALAYA.)

BANDA ZAMORA Pandacan, Manila. Banda Zamora was founded in May 1928 by Santos Darramidan, a retired member of the Philippine Constabulary band, which was then under the baton of Col Walter H. Loving. The founder undertook the responsibility of recruiting and training its members until his death in May 1955. His daughter, Eufronia Darramidan, took over the supervision and Illuminado Macarasig, former student of Darramidan and also a member of the Philippine Constabulary Band, served as bandmaster. Macarasig left for abroad and the management recruited Alfredo M. Serapio who took over the musical training of its members. The new bandmaster doubled his efforts and, under his leadership, the band gained more members and popularity in different parts of the country.

When Eufronia Darramidan died on 2 Nov 1971, the management was passed on to her nephew and niece, Ernesto Baluyot and Adoracion Baluyot-Briones with husband Ponciano Briones. Alfredo Serapio continued to train band members and received asistes (engagements) in different parts of the country. The band also participated in innumerable concerts and parades where it has often triumphed.

Banda Zamora members perceive themselves to be good and keen musiko (musician). Some of the band members have gone to other countries as musicians, while others are employed in the army or in clubs in the country. Many of the former members of the band have become professionals such medical doctors, lawyers, engineers, chemists, dentists, and businessmen. These graduates used their knowledge of music learned from Banda Zamora to finish tertiary-level education through tuition scholarships in university bands.Written by Rodney D. S. Ambat

BANYUHAY A Filipino folk rock band comprised of brothers Heber, Levi, and Jesse Bartolome. The trio was originally formed in 1975 so that the siblings could participate in the Battle of the Bands contest. The group pioneered in socially relevant songs, with lyrics written in the vernacular and which tackled pressing social issues during the Martial Law era. The term “banyuhay” is short for “bagong anyo ng buhay,” meaning “new form of life” or “metamorphosis.” The group was widely recognized as one of the bands that shifted the attention from foreign to local artists in the Philippine music industry. Heber is credited as songwriter, rhythm guitarist, and vocalist, with Levi on lead guitar, and Jesse on bass and backup vocals.

In 1976, Banyuhay released their first single “Buhay Pinoy” (Filipino Life) under Dyna Records. Their song “Tayo’y Mga Pinoy” (We Are Filipinos) became a finalist in the first Metro Manila Pop Music Festival in 1978. They released their debut album under the same title, within the same year.

From 1979 to 1981, the band enjoyed regular shows and gigs in various venues, but they also experienced “sabotaged” performances and had their singles banned from the airwaves due to the political nature of their songs. The group took a break in 1982 so Heber could focus on his painting and teaching career, and they returned to the scene three years later with the independently released Kalamansi sa Sugat (Calamansi on the Wound), 1985, which was later distributed by Alpha Records. Popular hits from this album include “Karaniwang Tao” (Ordinary Person), “Almusal” (Breakfast), “Ako’y Mang-aawit ng Aking Panahon” (I am a Singer of My Times), and “Inutil na Gising” (Awake But Useless).

The year 1986 was considered the peak of their career, with concerts booked all over the Philippines. The long-playing albums they released afterwards were the independently produced Katotohanan Lamang (Only the Truth), 1988; Kung Walang Pag-ibig (If Love is Gone), 1989; and Tatlong Kahig Isang Tuka (Three Scratches, One Peck), 1992 under BMG Records. During their career, Banyuhay released a total of five albums and had numerous guestings in various local concerts such as Pinoy Naman (Filipino Now). This 1993 concert featured the best of local pop music artists like Mike Hanopol, Hotdog, Francis M., and Edru Abraham & Kontragapi at the Folk Arts Theater. Banyuhay has received recognition from the Catholic Mass Media Awards, Awit Awards, KBP Musicfest, and the Metro Manila Pop Music Festival.Written by Francesca Casauay

BARTOLOME, HEBER (Heber Gonzales Bartolome) b. Cabanatuan City, Nueva Ecija 9 Nov 1948. Folk musician, singer, songwriter, teacher, painter. Bartolome was born to parents who were active in the arts scene. His father, Deogracias Bartolome, was a pastor, string instrument maker, and rondalla band leader. His mother, Angelina Gonzalez, was a sarsuwela singer. He attended the bachelor of fine arts program in the University of the Philippines (UP), during which time he was also a member of the UP Concert Chorus and the UP ROTC Band. After graduating in 1973, his paintings and artworks were selected for local and international exhibitions and likewise became a source of inspiration for poets across the globe. In 1975, he finished his master’s degree in Philippine Literature at UP and, from 1981 to 1984, served as a professor of Filipino literature at the De La Salle University in Taft Avenue, Manila.

Bartolome started writing Pinoy rock songs in 1974. As a songwriter, he wrote primarily in the native tongue and his songs explored issues on nationalism, politics, and social justice. He is also widely recognized as the front man of the protest band Banyuhay, whose sound is characterized by a unique blend of Philippine indigenous rhythms, folk and religious music, and rock and blues, and which he co-founded with his two brothers, Jesse and Levi Bartolome in 1975.

In 1977, he wrote “Nena,” a song about a woman forced into a life of prostitution because of poverty, which instantly became a chart-topper. The following year, he wrote “Tayo’y Mga Pinoy” (We Filipinos), a song encouraging Filipinos to break away from colonial mentality and embrace their own identity. This song was a finalist in the Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1978.

In 1992, he released a compilation of his greatest hits, titled Mga Awit ni Heber (Heber’s Songs), under BMG Records. Throughout the years, he has had a string of local and international performances, with shows throughout the Philippines and in various parts of Europe such as Germany, Belgium, Spain, and France, among others.

Aside from creative work, Heber is also an avid lobbyist for composers’ rights and was a former member and trustee of the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (FILSCAP). He served as the organization’s president in 1991.Written by Francesca Casauay
BARROZO, TERESA (See FILM volume.)

BATTIG, BAPTISTA (Helene Battig) b. Breslau, Silesia (now in Germany) 9 Aug 1870. d. Manila 26 Jan 1942. Pianist, teacher. Helene Battig, better known as Sr BaptistaBattig, OSB entered the convent in Saint Ottilien, Germany in 1902, and made her profession of vows as a Benedictine nun in 1907. Her teacher, Ludwig Deppe of Berlin, had been a pupil of Hungarian composer and pianist Franz Liszt.

Sr Baptista left Germany for Manila in 1907 in response to a request for a music teacher from the missionary Benedictine nuns. She gave piano lessons, and on 9 Jun 1910, she performed in public with three other musicians to raise funds for a bigger school.
