She earned her masters in education at the University of Santo Tomas in 1937. She became a naturalized Filipino citizen in 1938.

Sr Baptista founded the St Scholastica School of Music in 1907 and pioneered in formal music education in the Philippines. She standardized the piano course and curriculum in the school. She taught her pupils the Deppe technique of piano playing, which covers such aspects as the correct position of the hands and wrists, the production of singing tones, the use of the pedal, and interpretation.

Among her students were LucreciaR.Kasilag, Pilar Blanco-Sala, Dolores Heras, Lourdes Villanueva-Cruz, Concepcion Virtuoso-Paguia, Paz Gloria-Canave, Estrella Wijangco-Ackerman, and Sr Cecile Donato.

She died of pneumonia in 1942. The Sr Baptista Battig Music Foundation, an organization of music graduates of the St Scholastica’s College, was named in her honor.Written by Edgardo B. Maranan

BAUTISTA,CELY(Maria Cecilia PimentelBautista) b. Pasay City 4 May 1939 d. 27 Sep 2018. Singer and radio, stage, and film actress. Eddie San Jose was her life partner with whom she had a son named Eduardo "Edrick" Eloriaga. She was seven years old when Pete Ancheta discovered her and signed her up as part of the dance duo Wonder Kids that regularly performed in the provinces and at the US Military Bases. At 10, as Celia Pimentel, she danced on stage with the young Dolphy, then known as Golay, as one of her regular partners. On 6 Jan 1954, Eddie San Jose introduced her asCelyBautista, the singer, in the radio program Star Time. Afterwards, musical director Danny Holmsen asked her to sing the theme for the movie Por Bida Gid (Oh My Goodness), which starred Anita Linda. Since then, she recorded themes for films for all film outfits one after the other and acted as voice double for actresses who could act but not sing. Her rendition of Tito Arevalo’s “Irog, Ako ay Mahalin” (Love Me, Darling) from Pedro Penduko and “Hinahanap Kita” (I’ve Been Searching for You) from Bandilang Pula (Red Emblem), both under Premiere Productions, identified her as a singer of the traditional danza and kundiman. She was paired with Ruben Tagalog, unofficially dubbed as the “King of Kundiman,” in the latter’s popular weekly radio show over DZFM during the 1950s, Harana ni Ruben Tagalog (Ruben Tagalog’s Serenade). The two of them waxed a number of well-loved duets like “Pandora” and “Si Eva at si Adan” (Eve and Adam). As a pair, they did two long-playing albums under Villar Records in the mid-1960s, Ruben at Cely (Ruben and Cely) and Mahal Ko Sa Buhay (Love of My Life).

In 1964, Mico Records released her long-playing album The Best of Cely Bautista that featured 12 movie themes by Danny Holmsen with lyrics by Ading Fernando. Included in the album are the songs “Tapat na Pag-ibig” (Faithful Love) from Sampaguita Pictures’ Anak sa Panalangin (A Child Out of Prayer) and “Pangakong Puso” (Heart’s Promise). That same year, her first album Alay Ko sa Iyo (My Gift to You) under Villar Records came out. She did 11 more albums for the said outfit, the last being Walang Kapantay (Nobody Comes Close) whose title song, a composition by Eddie Sangcap and Manuel P. Villar, became a big hit in 1975. Also included in the said album are her original hits “Mahiwaga” (Mysterious) by Ador Torres and Manuel P. Villar, “Di ba’t Ako’y Tao ring may Damdamin” (Am I Not Also a Human Being With Feelings) by Francisco Nieto, and “Tanong ng Puso” (Heart’s Query) by Ben Torres.

She received the Awit Awards for Best Female Singer in the vernacular category in 1969. As one of the Mabuhay Singers, of which she hadbeen a member since 1960, she sang regularly in the weekly radio program Harana ng Puso (Serenade of the Heart) aired every Sunday night over DWBR 104.3 FM of the Philippine Broadcasting Service. Villar Records has released compilations of her best songs, the three-volume The Best of Cely Bautista, under its Heritage Series. A fourth volume, 24 Best of Cely Bautista, was released by Aquarius Records. Written by Michael M. Coroza

BAUTISTA, CHRISTIAN (Christian Joseph Morata Bautista) b. Manila 19 Oct 1981. Singer, songwriter, actor. He was born to parents Ebert Rene Bautista and Josefa Rizalina Morata. He grew up in Imus, Cavite. He joined a church choir when he was seven, studied grade and high schools in Ateneo de Manila before earning a bachelor of science degree in Architectural Landscaping from the University of the Philippines Diliman. During high school, he formed an a cappella group and got the attention of singer and talent manager Carlo Orosa in one birthday performance. His works include roles in theater, a TV series (in the Philippines and Indonesia), recording contracts in the Philippines, and in several Southeast Asian countries.

In 2003, Bautista joined Search for a Star in a Million (or SIAM) while auditioning for a possible contract with Warner Philippines and this enabled him to release his first solo album with Warner instead of Star Records, as was the practice with other contestants of SIAM. He was one of the finalists of this popular contest, eventually bowing to Erik Santos in the final result.

Bautista was launched to local stardom with his first (self-titled) album, Christian Bautista, 2004, which contains the hit single, “The Way You Look At Me,” composed by Andrew Fromm and Keith Follese. The single became popular not only in Indonesia, but in Thailand, Malaysia, and Singapore as well.

His second release in 2005, Completely, also marketed and sold in Indonesia and Singapore, reached platinum status in the Philippines and Indonesia. In the same year, Bautista became the first Filipino artist to guest in Indonesian Idol, Indonesia’s version of American Idol. His popularity in the country led to a record deal with Warner and his own TV musical special titled Completely: Christian Bautista, where he performed with two of Indonesia’s pop artists, Krisdayanti and Titi DJ.

Five more albums followed in years 2008-12 that included collaborations with other artists such as Jose Mari Chan, Regine Velasquez, and Sarah Geronimo. His 2009 album of Chan’s hits, Romance Revisited: The Songs of Jose Mari Chan, achieved gold status.

Bautista played the role of Lorenzo in ABS-CBN’s soap opera, Kampanerang Kuba, 2005, where he was paired with Anne Curtis. He was also cast in Regal Films’ Mano Po 5: Gua Ai Di, 2006. He also became one of the leads of The Kitchen Musical, a musical series on TV which was aired in Singapore, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Philippines, and China.

Over a span of 10 years (2002-13), Bautista sang and acted in several theater productions, most notably in Spolarium, and The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe. Other theater credits include roles in Joseph the Dreamer, West Side Story (2008, as Tony), Rama Hari (2012), and Cinderella (2013). In 2013, after 10 years of working for ABS-CBN, Bautista transferred to GMA Network where he appeared in musical variety shows like Party Pilipinas and Sunday All Stars, and in various drama series such as With A Smile, Strawberry Lane, and My Mother’s Secret. He hosted the reality boy band search To The Top and was most recently seen as one of the judges in Lip Sync Battle Philippines and Superstar Duets.Written by Lara T. Mendoza

BESA, DELLA (Della Lucero Gamboa-Besa) b. Bacolod City 21 Apr 1936. d. Makati City 25 Feb 2015. Pianist. She was the daughter of Aguinaldo Gamboa and Alicia Lucero, the granddaughter of Santiago Estrella Lucero. She finished high school at St Scholastica’s College in 1951. Essayist and critic Doreen G. Fernandez was her sister. She was married to Benjamin A. Besa, an architect. They had seven children, one of whom, Juan Angelo, is a writer and professional musician. She graduated with the degrees of bachelor of arts in mathematics from St Scholastica’s College and bachelor of music in 1955, major in piano, from the Centro Escolar University. She earned masteral credits in music education at the De La Salle University, and continued her postgraduate studies in piano with Benjamin Tupas, Marieta Cruz, Gerd Kaemper, Manuel P. Maramba, OSB, and Jose Contreras. She was a French Government scholar in piano ensemble at the Conservatoire National Superieure de Musique de Paris where she trained under Genevieve Joy.

Her involvement with duo piano playing spans more than 20 years in partnerships with Anamaria Gregorio de Guzman and Mary Anne Rivas Armovit. Her performances in duo-piano and with flutist Antonio Maigue have taken her to the major concert halls and parks in Metro Manila and the provinces; and abroad to China and the United States.

From 1983 to 1986, she served as assistant dean of the St Scholastica’s School of Music until she joined the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) as director for musical arts. She was later appointed associate artistic director for the peforming arts. Besa served as treasurer of the Piano Teachers’ Guild of the Philippines (PTGP) in 1988, 1990, and 1991; and as an artistic director of the International Bamboo Organ Festival of Las Piñas until 2008.

An alumna of St Scholastica’s College, Besa received the Outstanding Music Centennial and Duo Artist awards. The duo-pianists Besa and De Guzman appeared in the CCP’s 40th Anniversary in 2009; in a fund-raising concert for the renovation of the Home for the Blind at Kinasang-an, Pardo, Cebu in 2010; in PTGP’s Forte @40 at the CCP Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, featuring over 300 pianists in 2012; and in Music Circle at the Scholastica’s College Music Board Room, which was sponsored by the St Scholastica’s Music Alumni Association in 2014.Writen by Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Ma. Josephine Baradas

D’ BIG THREE SULLIVANS D’ Big Three Sullivans was the musical-comedy trio famous in the 1960s and 1970s for their novelty songs and on-stage antics. In 1950s, Mar Lopez, who eventually became the group’s founder, was continually forming and performing in music comedy duets and trios. The most successful of these incarnations would be the “Top Three” featuring Apeng Daldal aka Seraphin Gabriel, Bebeng Dahilan aka Bebeng Samson, and Mar Reklamo aka Mar Lopez. It was entertainment impresario, Lou Salvador, who provided the group with their funny aliases.

In 1962, Boy Sullivan, one-time professional boxer and singer-comic co-performer with Mar Lopez, was convicted of murder and meted a punishment of 8-20 years imprisonment in the Muntinlupa Penitentiary. Mar Lopez decided to pay frequent visits to his friend, Sullivan, and they ended up performing for the prisoners. Word of their entertainment abilities spread throughout the prison facility, prompting the authorities to recognize the goodwill potential of the duo and to arrange for them to sing for other prisoners. Incarcerated only four years, Boy Sullivan was released from prison for good behavior. Mar Lopez then officially formed D’ Big Three Sullivans naming it after Boy (guitar/vocals) and adding Ding Arraza (guitar/vocals) to the group.

1966 was the year they produced their first hit, “Aswang” (Vampire) under Los Compadres Records. Entertainment promoters took notice of their popularity and performance bookings grew, leading to performance contracts abroad. They toured Japan for about a year, performing in the provinces of Okinawa, Kagoshima, and Hokkaido.

Later, D’ Big Three Sullivans joined the Philippine Constabulary’s Special Services in Camp Crame in the 1970s. This office opened doors for them to perform for audiences all over the Philippines, giving goodwill performances for servicemen and civilians alike. It was at this time that their song “May Pulis sa Ilalim ng Tulay” (There’s a Policeman Under the Bridge), inspired by the melody of a Japanese folk song, became a big hit. Two other versions of this song are “May Puno sa Ilalim ng Dagat” (There’s a Tree Under the Sea) and “May Tao sa Ilalim ng Kubo” (There’s Someone Under the Hut).

The trio was also a mainstay of the Hatid Saya program, a government program which exported local entertainers to perform for Filipino communities abroad, such as Filipino contract workers in the Middle East and immigrant Filipinos in the United States and Canada. All told, the trio has visited and performed in 36 countries including China and Australia.

D’ Big Three Sullivans produced several novelty hits, a sampling of which includes “Inday Palayasin Kita” (Inday, I’ll Send You Away), “Kaning Baboy” (Pig Slop), “Nagbomba si Candida” (Candida Goes Nude), “War Kami ng Misis Ko” (Me and My Wife Have a Fight), “Karanasan” (Experience), “Ang Gusto Ko’y Hot Pandesal” (I Like Hot Buns), “Manugang At Biyenan” (Son-in-Law and Mother-in-Law), “Awit ng Palaka” (Frog’s Song), and “Para Kang si Tarzan” (You’re Like Tarzan).

Another spin-off from the D’ Big Three Sullivans is Tatlong Pinoy, a comedy singing trio established in 1979 featuring Ilokano, Visayan, and Tagalog songs. Written by Jose Valenciano

BOHOL, ANTONIO AND JOSEFINABACALSO Cebuano balitaw performers, popularly known as the husband and wife team of Tonyo and Pasing. Tonyo and Pasing were the most popular practitioners of the balitaw after the famous pre-World War II pair of Indiong (Pedro Alfafara) and Colasing (Nicolasa Caniban).

Tonyo was from Banao, Cebu, while Pasing was from the Pardo district in Cebu City. It is said that it was Pasing’s parents, Mariano Bacalso and Gregoria Sabandeja, who inspired and trained the couple in the balitaw. Tonyo was a stage actor and playwright while Pasing played roles in Cebuano radio plays. As balitaw performers, they popularized the art through the medium of radio and stage performances. They also starred as balitaw dancers in the Cebuano movie, Garbosa (Vain Woman), 1956. Radio programs that featured the couple included Visayan Troubadours directed by Ben Zubiri, Mga Haranista (The Serenaders), Asan Ka Inday? (Where Are You Miss?), and the popular Balitaw Hour, aired over Cebu radio station DYRC from February 1948 to June 1950. They continued to be featured on radio programs until the 1970s.

In 1989, the couple left the Philippines to join a daughter in Australia where they performed before Filipino communities. They subsequently returned to the Philippines. Josefina Bacalso-Bohol died on 1 Jun 1991 and so did Antonio Bohol whose date of death is unknown.Written by Erlinda Alburo

BOLIPATA, ALFONSO (Alfonso Corpus Bolipata) aka Coke Bolipata. b. Manila 3 Sep 1964. Violinist and artistic director. He is the son of Ricardo Bolipata and Elenita Corpus, daughter of violinist Ramon Corpus. He is the youngest of the famed Bolipata Trio which is composed of his two other brothers— Ramon, a cellist, and Jaime, a pianist-composer. At eight, he started violin lessons with Oscar C. Yatco, then continued his studies under Basilio C. Manalo. Later, he studied under Jascha Brodsky at the New School of Music in Philadelphia, James Buswell at Indiana University, Felix Galimir in New York, and Dorothy DeLay at the Julliard School. During his student days at Indiana, he performed the Kodaly Duo Sonata with Hungarian cellist Janos Starker. He became concertmaster of the Indiana University Orchestra, and received critical claim for his flawless playing of the solo passages in Strauss’ Le Petit Bourgeois Gentil Homme.

He was the only Filipino who participated in the premiere season of the Miami-based New World Symphony (NWS) in 1988. He became the soloist of NWS during the 1991 performance of Leonard Berstein’s Serenade for solo violin, chamber orchestra, and percussion. He also appeared as soloist with the Central Philharmonic Orchestra in Beijing, China in 1990, playing Chausson’s Poeme under the baton of guest conductor Francisco F. Feliciano. Previously he was also a soloist of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 1979, the Philippine Youth Orchestra in 1980, and the Young Artists Chamber Orchestra from 1984 to 1985.

In 1993, Bolipata founded the arts school which was named Casa San Miguel or Creative Alternatives for Social Action in Barangay San Antonio, San Miguel, Zambales. This facility is a 15-hectare ancestral farmland built in 1921 by Ramon L. Corpus, his grandfather. The Casa San Miguel was turned into a community-based arts center that promotes classical arts and music to the rural people of Zambales, i.e., to children of farmers, fishermen, tricycle drivers, and other people interested in arts, and educates them to become highly skilled artists. The children meet every weekend to do lessons in the violin, viola, cello; to draw and paint; to make puppets for shadow play vignettes; and to act, direct or dance.

To promote the artists and bring culture to the countryside, Bolipata organized the yearly musical event called the Pundaquit Festival in Brgy Pundaquit since Mar 1994. The closing concert of that inaugural concert in 1994 was held in the newly built Ramon Corpus Hall, which was designed by Bolipata. This is considered one of the cultural centers in Central Luzon. Featured in the Festival’s 11th season in 2003 were Alfonso Bolipata, Ramon Corpus String Quartet, Jourdann Petalver, Pundaquit Senior and Junior Virtuosi which is the resident string ensemble of Casa San Miguel Foundation, Pundaquit Chamber Players, Anino Shadowplay of Zambales, and Dulaang San Antonio. The first concert of the Symphony-by-the-Bay Community Orchestra was inaugurated in that festival.

Bolipata continued his violin performances in several chamber ensembles such as Sharing the Radiance of Love, a benefit concert of the Radiance School Inc. in 2003 and the Ensembles of Eight in the centennial celebration of Insular Life in 2010. He has also mentored children in a program of the Center of Excellence in Public Elementary Education (CENTEX) in Tondo, Manila, which was established in 1998 in partnership with Ayala Foundation’s Education project, Department of Education, Manila City local government, and Batangas provincial government.

Bolipata won first prize in the 1978 National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA). He also received the following awards: Katha Music Award for Best Instrumental Album Pelikula at Pundaquit (Film and Pundaquit), in 1996; National Book Award for Design titled Water in the Ring of Fire: Folktales from the Asia-Pacific in 1997, a children’s book commissioned by APEC, and a compilation of creation myths from its 18 member countries; the NCCA Alab ng Haraya Award in 1997; Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award in 2000; 2001 Aliw Award as Best Instrumentalist for his performance of Prokofiev’s Violin Concerto with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra; and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan in music, 2002.

Bolipata was the lead character in the movie Boses (Voices) in 2008, playing a violinist teaching a young virtuoso. The film was about child abuse and music therapy, shot in Casa San Miguel, Zambales, with music by Coke Bolipata and Jourdann O. Petalver, produced and directed by Ellen Ongkeko-Marfil for the Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival.Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated Josephine Baradas

BOLIPATA, JAIME (Jaime Corpus Bolipata) aka Jed Bolipata. b. Manila 4 Oct 1959. Pianist, composer, and filmmaker. He is the son of Ricardo Bolipata and Elenita Corpus. He and his brothers, Ramon, a cellist, and Alfonso, a violinist, comprise the famous Bolipata Trio. His grandfather is violinist Ramon Corpus.

He began his musical career as a student of Stella Brimo, and after high school at the Ateneo de Manila, he became a scholar at the Juilliard School of Music, earning his bachelor’s degree in 1981 as well as his master’s degree under a Gina Bachauer Memorial Scholarship. He studied chamber music under Felix Galimir, a prominent figure in international chamber music circles. He has performed all over the United States, including at the Kennedy Center in Washington, New York Carnegie Recital Hall, Isabella Gardner Museum in Boston, and Pensacola Chamber Music Festival in Florida, and taught at the Governor’s School for the Arts in Radford, Virginia.

Bolipata made his debut at the New York Carnegie Recital Hall in 1981 as the first Filipino musician to win in the Artists International Annual Auditions. Since then, he has had solo recitals, played with several American orchestras, joined chamber music performances with other American artists, and been featured in WNCN’s Imperial Bosendofer series and WQXR’s “The Listening Room” in New York. At one time, he was asked by James Buswell to collaborate with him in some Beethoven works.

During his visits to the Philippines, Bolipata performed as soloist with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and the Young Artists Chamber Music Orchestra, and played solo repertoire at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), Paco Park, Abelardo Hall Auditorium of the University of the Philippines, the University of Santo Tomas, and Yamaha School of Music.

In 1985, the Bolipata brothers performed Mendelssohn’s Piano Trio No.1 in D minor, Schumann’s Adagio and Allegro, Abelardo’s Cavatina, Paganini’s Moses Variations, and a piano solo by Chopin, the Ballade No. 4 in F Minor at the CCP Main Theater for their first major concert as a trip. Bolipata was the featured soloist together with his two brothers in the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra Series IV concert at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990. Jed was also one of the 40 chamber musicians who participated in the Laurel Festival of the Arts, a celebration of chamber music in 1990. He has performed with the Monmouth Symphony, Berkshire Symphony, Honolulu Academy of Arts, Hope College in Holland, and Western Michigan University in Kalamazoo.

He composed some pieces for the piano, including the piano trio, For Peace, which he performed for the first time in Manila with his brothers in 1985. The piece was conceived as a personal expression against violence. One of his ballets has been produced in Virginia, USA.

After several years of concertizing internationally as a soloist and chamber musician, Bolipata decided to pursue writing and photography since 1993. His short film titled The Seventh Circle was premiered at the Clermont-Ferrand Film Festival in 2000. His solo photography show was exhibited at the Berlin’s Wallywoods Gallery titled the New York Underground in 2007.

Before he left for the United States in 1977, Bolipata had already won in several local competitions, including the Young Artists Competitions of the Manila Symphony Orchestra, the 1972 National Music Competitions for Young Artists, and the Bach Competition of the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music. In the United States, he won in the Young Musicians Competition sponsored by the Jewish Congress in New York, and in the yearly tilt of the Young Concert Artists. He also received the Baldwin and Clairmont Piano Prizes in 1983.Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Josephine Baradas

BOLIPATA, RAMON (Ramon Corpus Bolipata) aka Chino Bolipata. b. Manila 22 Dec 1960. Cellist. He is the son of Ricardo Bolipata and Elenita Corpus. He and his brothers, violinist Alfonso and pianist-composer Jaime, comprise the Bolipata Trio. His grandfather Ramon Corpus was a noted violinist and composer. He finished his grade school at the Ateneo de Manila and his first year high school at the University of Santo Tomas. In 1976, he left for the United States to study at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia.

Bolipata began his career at the age of 11 as a student of Herminia Atienza-Ilano. In 1972, he won a prize in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) and subsequently became the soloist of the newly organized Philippine Youth Orchestra in its first public concert. In 1981, when he was a student at Curtis, he toured Europe, playing in 16 cities as soloist and chamber music cellist of Concerts of Curtis, a series showcasing the best talents of the school. He has participated in numerous summer music festivals like the Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont, the Piatigorsky Seminar in Los Angeles, the Yale Summer Festival in Norfolk, and the Spoleto Festivals in Italy and in the United States. He also played as principal cellist of the New York String Orchestra and the Brandenburg Ensemble under Alexander Schneider for several seasons.

In the Philippines, he has performed in several concerts with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, the Young Artists Chamber Orchestra, the Manila Symphony Orchestra, and the Manila Chamber Orchestra. While at Curtis, Bolipata won many prizes. He won in the Philadelphia Orchestra Senior Auditions, which earned him the privilege of performing Tchaikovsky’s Rococo Variations with the orchestra. He was given the honor of performing at Giancarlo Menotti’s 60th birthday gala at the Brooklyn Academy, and at Samuel Barber’s funeral ceremony. In 1982, the Ridge Quartet which he founded with three other Curtis alumni won first prize in both Coleman and Fischoff music tilts held in the United States in 1982, and was voted Quartet of the Year by the California Consortium in 1986. The Ridge String Quartet was composed of cellist Ramon Bolipata, violinists Robert Reinhart and Krista Bennion, and violist Ah Ling Neu.

In 1985, the Bolipata Trio performed at the Philamlife Theater for the benefit of the construction of a Youth Center in San Antonio, Zambales, their grandfather’s hometown. He also played solo in Schumann’s Violoncello Concerto in A minor at the Francisco Santiago Hall in 1987. At the fourth chamber concert in the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1988, the Bolipata brothers played the Trio in B-flat Major by Ravel and Trio in F minor by Dvorak. Another benefit concert was performed by the Bolipata brothers for the Metropolitan Theater at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990. In the same year, they interpreted Stranvinsky’s suite and sonatas by Franck, Schubert, and Brahms at the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ Filipino Artists Series. Chino Bolipata had a comeback concert in 1994 at the Concert at the Park accompanied by pianist Carmencita Castro-Bautista. In the program was Abelardo’s Romanza.Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Josephine Baradas

BONUS, LADISLAO (Ladislao Mariano Bonus) b. Pandacan, Manila 27 Jun 1854. d. Pandacan, Manila 28 Mar 1908. Conductor, contrabass player, teacher, composer. LadislaoBonus was born to poor parents, Pedro Bonus and Maria Mariano. He married Rosalia Guazon with whom he had eight children. Due to poverty, he had no formal regular music education except for a few lessons from Gregorio de Luna. Bonus studied by himself and learned to play the contrabass, flute, cello, guitar, violin, and other instruments. He became an expert contrabass player and found a job as such in orchestras hired by foreign opera companies.

The musical atmosphere of Pandacan, then known as the “Venice of the Philippines,” stimulated his talents. Bonus learned opera production through observation of visiting opera company performances. In 1887, he established an all-Filipino opera company. It debuted in the same year with Donizetti’s Lucrezia Borgia, and presented other operas such as Linda di Chamounix, La Traviata, Lucia di Lammermoor, and Fra Diavolo. Next to the opera company, another musical group in Pandacan which he directed won general admiration—the Orquesta Feminina de Pandacan founded in 1890 by Raymundo Fermin. He also conducted the Marikina Orchestra owned by the landowner Jose Tuason, the celebrated Pasig Band of Rizal, and the Arevalo Band of Quiapo, Manila. In 1903, the Arevalo Band, then at the height of its fame, was sent to the Regional Exposition in Hanoi, Vietnam, and won first prize in the international band competition.

Bonus was also a composer. Three of his popular compositions were the “Triumphal March,” dedicated to the First Philippine Assembly; “Pasodoble Hanoi,” dedicated to the Hanoi International Exposition; and “Los Diputados” (The Representatives), dedicated to the members of the Philippine Assembly. He also composed the music of two sarsuwela, Unang Pag-ibig (First Love) and Buhay ng Lasing (A Drunkard’s Life). “Recuerdos a la Patria” (Memories of My Land) was composed as a result of JoseRizal’s request for him to compose the music for “Canto de Maria Clara” (Song of Maria Clara), a poem that appeared in one of the chapters of Rizal’s novel NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not). Bonus’ major work was the first Filipino opera SangdugongPanaguinip(Dreamed Alliance), 1902, based on the libretto written in Spanish by PedroPaterno and translated into Tagalog by RomanReyes. For this he has been called the “Father of Filipino Opera.” His birthplace along San Luis Street in Pandacan was marked on 21 Nov 2014.Written by Ma. Lourdes Maniquis

BORROMEO, LOU (Luis Francisco Borromeo)b. Cebu City 10 Oct 1879. d. Manila 1945. Pianist, composer, and bodabil impresario. Borromeo was one of the 16 children of Juan Borromeo and Paulina Veloso. He studied piano with his father, and attended the Seminario-Colegio de San Carlos in Cebu City and University of Santo Tomas in Manila, where he studied pharmacy. He married Clemencia Atillo in 1905. After her early death, Borromeo left for the United States in Sep 1914.

In San Francisco, Borromeo’s piano skills caught the attention of impresario Eugene D’Avigneau, who featured Borromeo alongside two American-born Chinese entertainers in the trio “D’Avigneau’s Celestials.” In 1916, this group began touring the United States and Canada on the Keith vaudeville circuit. Between 1920 and 1921, Borromeo also published four songs with American publishers, the first of which, “My Beautiful Philippines,” was made into a piano roll (Walsh 2013, 250). Borromeo returned to the Philippines in Apr 1921 upon hearing news of a parent’s illness.

Borromeo intended to return to the United States with a large Filipino vaudeville troupe but decided instead to remain in Manila. In Sep 1921, he performed the first of his “vod-a-vil” shows and began a four-year residency of popular weekly performances at Manila’s Olympic Stadium. Throughout the 1920s he also appeared occasionally in other Manila venues and took his troupe on yearly tours of the Visayas, Mindanao, and Sulu.

Borromeo was widely celebrated for discovering, developing, and promoting local Filipino talent. His shows featured dozens of famous performers, such as Catalina “Katy” de la Cruz, Dionisia “Toy Toy” Castro/Moncado, Canuto “Canuplin” Francia, and Honorata “Atang” de la Rama. While both vaudeville and jazz were well-established in the Philippines before 1921, Borromeo’s “vod-a-vil” was important in featuring a mix of local genres and American popular songs. His blend of Spanish, English, and Tagalog songs, dances, topical comedic routines, and everything from juggling to boxing tricks influenced the rise of other Filipino vaudeville troupes.

While rheumatism began hampering his ability to perform in the 1930s, Borromeo continued composing, creating over 40 musical pieces in a wide range of styles, including sacred pieces, tangos, fox-trots, and patriotic anthems. He worked with lyricists such as Manuel Bernabe, Flavio Zaragoza Cano, Jose Hernandez Gavira, and Amado V. Hernandez.

During an early tour in Iloilo in 1921, Borromeo met Angelina Villalobos, who became his second wife. They had five children and remained in Manila through World War II. Borromeo died in Manila of an undetermined illness in 1945 and is buried in the Borromeo-Veloso family tomb at the Basilica Minore del Santo Niño de Cebu.Written by Frederick J. Schenker

Sources:

Keppy 2013, Walsh 2013.

BORROMEO, MAURICIA (Mauricia Danguilan Borromeo) b. Solano, Nueva Vizcaya 23 Jul 1939. Music educator, collaborating pianist. She is the eldest among six children of the Dr. Vidal B. Borromeo and Fermina Ludan Danguilan. Her growing-up years in Solano consisted of nonstop piano lessons with the Franciscan nuns, and collaborative music activities in school and church which eventually led to her acceptance in 1955 as entrance scholar (then a privilege of high school valedictorians) at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. She obtained from UP a bachelor’s degree in piano, 1960; and master of music in piano, 1971; and, from the University of Michigan Ann Arbor, the master of music in music education in 1973. In Michigan, she was twice awarded the prestigious Levi Barbour Scholarship for Oriental women and was elected to the Pi Kappa Lambda, the USA National Music Honor Society. The second scholarship enabled her to expand her studies in ethnomusicology and in applied collaborative and off-campus piano pedagogy courses. Having successfully earned a piano teacher’s state and federal certification in the United States, she was an active member of the Ann Arbor Piano Teachers’ Guild until her return to the Philippines in 1986.

Reappointed to the UP College of Music faculty in 1986, she taught undergraduate music theory and literature, piano performance, and graduate music education courses, while serving as resource speaker and/or coordinator of music education and piano pedagogy workshops in the country and as collaborating pianist in concerts locally and abroad.

She has authored several articles on Philippine music and music education in the Compendium of the Humanities: Musical Arts, National Research Council of the Philippines, 1988; CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994; and Philippine Literature: Folk Songs compiled by Damiana Eugenio, 1997. Through the years, she has served as adjudicator in the regional competitions of the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) and mentored several winners in the piano categories of NAMCYA.

She was dean of the UP College of Music, 2000-04; chair of the Humanities Division of the National Research Council of the Philippines (NRCP) in 2004-09; president of the Piano Teachers’ Guild of the Philippines in 1994-96; and vice-head of the Committee on Music, National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) in 2004-10. At present, Borromeo serves as vice-president for planning implementation of the Philippine Society for Music Education; member of the Advisory Council of the Philippine High School for the Arts, member of the Music Committee, National Commission for Culture and the Arts; and part-time piano faculty at St Scholastica’s College and at the UP College of Music Extension program, where she had mentored pianist Lorenzo “Enzo” Medel.

She was a recipient of the 2010 Achievement Award (Humanities Division) given by the NRCP in recognition of her pioneering ethnomusicological research on Gaddang Folk Songs of her native province of Nueva Vizcaya.

BOSCH-JIMENEZ, REMEDIOS (Remedios Cruz Bosch-Jimenez) b. Malabon, Rizal 28 Jun 1917. d. Makati, Metro Manila 24 Aug 1992. Singer. She was born to Jose Bosch and Maria Cruz. She was married to Alfredo Jimenez. They had six children.

While teaching at the Centro Escolar University she took voice lessons with MercedesMatias-Santiago who immediately discovered her potential for the grand opera. In 4 May 1949, she debuted to wide acclaim in the opera stage as Santuzza in Mascagni’s Cavalleria Rusticana at the University of Santo Tomas Auditorium. Her initial success was followed by another when she landed the role of Leonora in the 1952 Manila Opera Company’s production of Il Travatore where she starred with Italian tenor Arrigo Pola. She played Violetta in La Traviata and Josephine Bracken in EliseoM.Pajaro’s BinhingKalayaan (Seeds of Freedom).

She was a soloist in a concert with the National Symphony Orchestra under the world-renowned conductor Fritz Mahler. Bosch-Jimenez also worked with famous conductors like Federico Elizalde, RamonTapales, HerbertZipper, LuisValencia, BernardinoF.Custodio, EliseoM.Pajaro, AntoninoBuenaventura, RedentorRomero, JulioEstebanAnguita, Tsai Chi-Kun, LucioD.SanPedro, and RegaladoJose. She has given countless performances in the United States, Europe, and Asia. She has also done numerous concerts for charities and civic clubs, thus earning her the title “Diva with a Heart.” Her performance in Cavalleria Rusticana earned for her the title Singer of the Year from the Manila Music Lovers Society in 1949. The same group cited her as the Opera Singer of the Year for her brilliant performance as the tragic Leonora in Il Travatore.Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

BUENAVENTURA, ALFREDO(Alfredo Santos Buenaventura) b. Santa Maria, Bulacan 14 Oct 1929.Composer, conductor, teacher. He is the fourth of the 13 children born to Vitallado Buenaventura, who played theviolin, and Felisa Santos, who was fond of singing.He is married to Amelia Encarnacion.They have three children. As a child, he joined six other brothers in the townband. He began elementary schooling in his hometown but was sent to the Colegio de San Juan de Letran in Manila when he reached third grade. While studying there, he qualified for thetiples choir at the pre-World War II Santo Domingo Church, and as a chorister, was subsequently trained inpiano, solfeggio, and the Gregorian chant. At the Colegio de San Juan de Letran, he graduated as salutatorian of the grade school department two years ahead of time. At about the same time, he won his first musical award when he bested all his fellow tiples in a solfeggio contest. When World War II broke out, he returned to his hometown where he served as church organist and band conductor and arranger when he was hardly 13 years old. When the war ended he went back to Letran for his high school diploma in 1949, then entered the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he simultaneously pursued courses in liberal arts and music. He earned an associate in arts degree from the UST in 1951, and a bachelor of music degree, major in composition and conducting, from Centro Escolar University(CEU) in 1958. In 1961, he acquired a sacred music certificate, with further specialization in organ, from the Gregorian Institute in Manila. In 1989, he was conferred an honorary doctor of music degree by the Philippine Women’s University (PWU).

Buenaventura’s works are inspired by Philippine history and folklore. His musical idioms, in particular, have utilized folk songs. He also employed Filipino indigenous instruments in his compositions. He has composed large works for the symphony orchestra. Among these are Kayumanggi (Brown Race), 1971; Bagong Pilipinas (New Philippines), 1973. One of his concertos, Celebration for Piano and Orchestra, 1976, was performed at the Carnegie Hall in New York by the American Symphony Orchestra with Carol Rosenberger as soloist. In 1978, he composed his symphonic poem Dulambuhay (Drama of Life) for San Miguel Corporation, and Sandigan (Haven) for Las Piñas Bamboo Organ. They were followed by other symphonic poems such as the Gintong Alaala (Golden Memory), 1980; and Rizal, the Great Malayan Antagonist, 1988. His Lakambini (Muse) for violin and orchestra, composed in 1982 for CCP, has been recorded for the international market by violinist Carmencita Lozada and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. In 2014, he composed Maharlika (Noble) for violin and orchestra for Metro Manila Community Orchestra.

He also composed music for the symphonic band. His major compositions for this medium are Overture in C, 1958; Bathaluman Concert Overture, 1965; Oriental Fugue, 1959; Prelude and Fugue, 1960; Dugong Kayumanggi (Brown Blood), 1981; Dakilang Lahi (Great Race) concert overture for brass band, 1985; and Fantasy for Bb clarinet and symphonic band, 2015.

Aside from his compositions for the orchestra, Buenaventura also composed music for the theater. Among these are operas such as Maria Makiling, 1961; Hinilawod in 1972; and musicals such as Ginintuang Alaala (Golden Memory), 1980; and Banahaw and Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), 1985.

Buenaventura’s body of work also includes sacred music compositions, usually commissioned songs for grand liturgical celebrations and festivities. Among these were “Philippines for Christ,” 1964, commissioned by Cardinal Rosales in Cebu City; “Salamat, O Birheng Mahal” (Thank You, Beloved Virgin), 1978, performed at Santo Domingo Church; Marian Songs for the 1985 Marian Year; “Luwalhati” (Glory), a choral piece for Manila Cathedral; Concert Mass for the Holy Redeemer Parish, 1987; “Hymns for the Sixteenth Centenary of St Augustine,” 1988; and “Recoletos Mass,” 1989.

He has also done commissioned works for some schools. For St Scholastica’s College, he did the cantata A las Flores de Hiedelberg (The Flowers of Heidelberg) in 1962. He composed “Ang Ating Watawat” (Our Flag) 1965, performed at the Centro Escolar University; Three Psalms, undated, for Santa Isabel College Diamond Jubilee; the Central Colleges of the Philippines Hymn, 1985; Jose Fabella Memorial School of Midwifery Hymn, 1986; and “Purihin si Yahweh” (Praised be Yahweh) for St Paul University, Manila, 1987. He also wrote songs for the Filipino communities. Among these are “Pigilin ang Pagwawasak” (Stop the Destruction); “Sa Iyong Pagsilang” (In your Birth); and marches such as “Maharlika” (Noble), Bataan Banda 31 Anniversary March, “PACMAN: Pambansang Kamao,” “Tanglaw” (Light), and others. He also wrote compositions for competitions, an important piece of which was “Panaghoy” (Lament), a violin contest piece for NAMCYA in 1990.

Buenaventura also did a lot of arrangements for the rondalla. Recordings of some his arrangements were performed by Villa Escudero Rondalla and PNU Rondalla and were released by CCP and NCCA.

As a conductor, Buenaventura has guest conducted professional orchestras as the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, the Manila Symphony Orchestra, and the Metro Manila Symphony Orchestra and local brass bands. He even conducted the Ateneo University College Glee CLub, and, in another context, the rondalla.

A noted academician, he served as a former CEU Conservatory of Music dean and taught at the University of the Philippines (UP), PWU, St Paul College, Manila, Ateneo de Manila University, St Scholastica’s College, FEATI University, Araneta University, La Concordia College, and International School Manila. At present, he is a faculty member of St Paul University Manila, Philippine Normal University, Santa Isabel College, and New Era University.

While enjoying his musical career, Buenaventura has also served as an active member of several civic, professional, religious, and business organizations such as the Rotary Club, Movement for the Refinement of Music in the Philippines, Knights of Columbus, League of Filipino Composers, Asian Composers’ League, Southeast Asian Band Directors Association, Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (FILSCAP), and Samahan sa Kultura at Sining. He has also served as the first official organist of the Manila Cathedral, 1961. At present, he is the vice-president of the National Band Association. As a member of the League of Filipino Composers since 1960, he won first place in the Bonifacio Centennial Competition Contest in 1963 with his entry “Huling Hibik ng Pilipinas” (The Last Cry of the Philippines), a kundiman inspired by the poem of Andres Bonifacio. He holds the distinction of having won the Republic Cultural Heritage Award twice: in 1964, for his opera Maria Makiling, and in 1972, for his Kayumanggi (Brown) Symphony. He received the Hiyas ng Bulacan Award in 1976; the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila in 1985; The Outstanding Filipino Award (TOFIL), 1995; and the Presidential Exemplary Service Award from the Rotary International, 1992.Written by Julie Ann Hallazgo, updated by Josie Antonio

BUENAVENTURA, ANTONINO (Antonino Ramirez Buenaventura) b. Baliuag, Bulacan 4 May 1904. d. 25 Jan 1996. National Artist for music. Composer, conductor, teacher. He was born to Leocadia Ramirez and Lucino Buenaventura, chief musician of the Spanish artillery band in Intramuros. He was the younger brother of Feliciano Buenaventura. He was married to Rizalina Exconde, a violin prodigy and violinist of the University of the Philippines Ladies String Quartet with whom he had four children. Daughter Lourdes Buenaventura-Salipsip is a pianist and two grandchildren Regina and Michael Buenaventura are violinist and cellist, respectively.

As a young boy, he learned the rudiments of solfeggio from a music teacher in his hometown. He became proficient at playing the clarinet, conducted the Banda Buenaventura which his father founded, and composed music. At 19, he entered University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, and earned a teacher’s diploma, major in science and composition in 1932. Among his mentors at UP were NicanorS.Abelardo, FranciscoSantiago, and Jeno von Takacs. When Abelardo died in 1934, Buenaventura took over his classes.

During his student days, Buenaventura was president of the Music Senior Organization and led the UP ROTC Band. He organized the first student string quartet and student symphony orchestra, which became the nucleus of the UP Junior Symphony Orchestra. As a member of the Presidents’ Advisory Committee on Folk Songs and Dances created by UP president JorgeBocobo in 1935, he traveled across the country with FranciscaReyes and Ramon Tolentino to collect folkdances and music.

In 1939, Buenaventura was music instructor and band conductor at the Philippine Military Academy. When World War II broke out, he and his wife founded the San Pablo Music Academy in Laguna. In 1945, he was assigned to reorganize the Philippine Constabulary Band, whose founder, ColWalterLoving, had died during the Battle of Manila. Gathering together 98 original members, he revived the band, which became the PhilippineArmyBand in 1946, and conducted it for the next 16 years. In 1948, he had a short stint as RamonTapales’s co-conductor of the Municipal Symphony Orchestra of Manila during its tour of Hong Kong, Yokohama, Guam, and Hawaii.

After retiring from military service, Buenaventura served as music director of the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music in 1961 and the University of the East (UE) School of Music and Arts, which he helped establish in 1964.

On several occasions, he represented the Philippines in international conferences as head or representative of music organizations. Among these were: the International Council of Music Conference in Rome, 1962, and Hamburg, 1964, in his capacity as president of the National Music Council; the Festival of the Asian Composers League in Kyoto, Japan, 1974, as vice-chairman of the LeagueofFilipinoComposers; and the General Assembly of the International Society for Music Education in Switzerland, 1976. He was also overall coordinator of the Second Southeast Asian Bandmasters Association held in Manila in 1977 and member of the Philippine delegation to the 40th anniversary of the All-Nippon Bandmaster Association in Tokyo, 1978.

Writing in the neoclassic and neoromantic vein, Buenaventura uses indigenous and folk materials in his compositions. Among his works based on Philippine folk melodies are: Menuet (based on an Igorot theme), 1936, for chamber orchestra; Rhapsodietta (based on a Manobo theme), 1937, for piano and orchestra; Greetings, 1938, a fantasy for band, based on the kumintang; MindanaoSketches, 1947, with two movements based on Manobo ritual: “Offering to the Gods” and “A Village Festival Dance;” Divertimento (based on an Igorot theme), 1959, for piano and orchestra; and Variations and Fugue on a Mountain Tune, 1972, for full orchestra. One of his most popular compositions is “PandanggosaIlaw” (Fandango of Lights), 1936, which was originally meant to accompany a dance choreographed by Francisca Reyes-Tolentino, and later transformed into a song by lyricist LeviCelerio. Other notable works are Echoes from the Philippines, performed by the PC Band under Loving at the Golden Gate Exposition in California, USA in 1939; BytheHillside, 1941, his most widely performed symphonic work; and “Awit sa Tagumpay ng Bayan” (Song for the Nation’s Triumph), 1986, a song commemorating the Feb 1986 uprising in the Philippines.

Mindanao Sketches was recorded by the London Philharmonic Orchestra and Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Redentor Romero, in the album titled The Best of Philippine Classics, 1983. In Jan 2013, By the Hillside was recorded by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra under the baton of Olivier Ochanine under the auspices of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

He also wrote a textbook titled Sing and Be Happy, 1966, for grades V and VI music classes in public schools. He has composed a number of school hymns and university marches.

His long list of honors and citations include: Band Conductor of the Year, Manila Music Lovers Society, 1951; Republic Cultural Heritage Award for Music, 1961; Outstanding Alumnus, UP Alumni Association Award, 1966; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award, 1971; Pro Mundi Beneficial Medal and Diploma Award, Academia Brazileira de Ciencias Humanas, 1975; Award of Merit for Outstanding Contribution to Philippine Music, Philippine Army, 1976; and Director Emeritus Award, UE, 1981. He is also listed in the Who’s Who in the World, 1974, and the Dictionary of International Biographies, 1975. He was proclaimed National Artist for music in 1988. He received a doctorate in music honoris causa from the University of the Philippines in 1991; and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the city of Manila in 1996.Written by Julie Ann Hallazgo, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

BUENAVENTURA BAND Baliuag, Bulacan. The Buenaventura Band was already organized long before the advent of the Americans. According to reliable sources, the band took active part in the revolution of 1896. Led by Lucino Buenaventura, it formed part of the army contingent that was sent to the battle of Malabon. It is believed that it was during this time that Buenaventura composed his stirring military march titled “Katagalugan.”

During the turn of the century when Lucino Buenaventura of Lucban, Quezon (then Tayabas) married Leocadia Ramirez of Baliuag, Bulacan, the band developed into one of the best musical organizations of the province. When he died in 1923, his son Feliciano Buenaventura took over the leadership of the band. Feliciano, eventually known as “Maestrong Anong,” obtained his licentiate in music from Quin’s Conservatory of Music, Boston, Massachusetts.

Some of the band’s achievements included the following: first prize, musical contest, Gagalangin, Tondo, Manila, 1921; first prize, band contest, Cabanatuan, Nueva Ecija, 1922; first prize, musical contest, Bustos, Bulacan, 1924; and first prize, first interprovincial band contest held in the Manila Stadium, 1928. With Anong’s younger brother, Col Antonino Buenaventura, as consultant, chief of band and music of the Philippine Army, the band continued to gain more popularity. The band consequently earned a name for Baliuag as famous for trained musicians. Many musicians from Baliaug are now members of bands in the Armed Forces of the Philippines and top university bands.

Since the death of Feliciano Buenaventura in 25 Apr 1976, his son Primitivo Buenaventura took over the leadership. Written by Rodney D. S. Ambat

BUENCAMINO, FRANCISCO (Francisco Beltran Buencamino) aka Francisco Buencamino Sr.b. San Miguel de Mayumo, Bulacan 5 Nov 1883. d. 16 Oct 1952. Composer. He was the sixth of 10 children of Fortunato Buencamino, a church organist and bandmaster, and Luisa Beltran, a singer. He was married to Pilar Luceño. They had two children, both of whom also took up music. His son, Francisco Jr, was a successful film scorer. Pianist CecileLicad is his grand niece while composers WillyCruz, LorrieIlustre, and Nonong Buencamino , and actor NonieBuencamino are his grand nephews. He first learned music from his father, and at age 12, he could play the organ. At 14, he was sent to study at the Liceo de Manila, where he took up courses in composition and harmony under MarceloAdonay and pianoforte under a Spanish music teacher. However, he did not finish his education, for he had taken an interest in the sarsuwela.

In the early 1900s, Buencamino taught music at the Ateneo de Manila and at the Centro Escolar de Señoritas. While at the Centro, he founded the Conservatory of Music, heading it until 1938. At the same time he was handling music lessons at the Liceo de Manila. In 1930, he founded the Buencamino Music Academy, which was authorized by the Department of Public Instruction to grant music degrees. Some of his pupils were NicanorS.Abelardo, ErnestinaCrisologo, Estela Velasco, Beatrice Alba, and Amelia Hilado. In the 1940s, he started working as musical director, also composing music for films produced by Sampaguita Pictures, LVN, and Excelsior.

Buencamino was also a musical director for sarsuwela productions together with BonifacioAbdon, and for a time acted frequently onstage. Apart from this, he collaborated on the plays written and produced by AurelioTolentino. Buencamino established Philippine Music Publishers, which undertook the printing of his more important compositions, but this venture was not successful.

Among the sarsuwela he wrote were: Marcela, 1904; Si Tio Selo (Uncle Selo), 1904; Yayang, 1905; and Pangakong Hindi Natupad (Broken Promise), 1905. In 1908, when the popularity of the sarsuwela started to wane because of American repression and the entry of the silent movies, Buencamino turned to composing kundiman. One early composition was “En el bello Oriente” (In the Beautiful Orient), 1909, which uses JoseRizal’s lyrics. His famous kundiman, “Ang Una Kong Pag-ibig” (My First Love), was inspired by his wife.

In 1938, he composed Daughters of Bathala, an epic poem which won a prize from the Far Eastern University (FEU) during one of the annual carnivals. In 1943, he began work on Mayon Concerto which is considered his magnum opus. It was finished in Nov 1948 and had a full rendition in Feb 1950 at the graduation recital of Rosario Buencamino at Holy Ghost College. Another composition based on a balitaw tune, Ang Larawan (The Portrait), 1943, is also one of his most acclaimed works. A version of this composition is PizzicatoCaprice, 1948, for string orchestra. Many of his other compositions were lost during the Japanese Occupation, when he had to evacuate his family to Novaliches, Rizal.

Among the movies he was involved in as musical director and/or composer were: Mabangong Bulaklak (Fragrant Flower), Lihim (Secret), Rosalinda, Ang Ibong Adarna (The Adarna Bird), Don Juan Teñoso, MutyangPasig (Muse of Pasig), Prinsesa ng Kumintang (Kumintang Princess), Walang Tahanan (Homeless), Magsasampaguita (Sampaguita Vendor), Arimunding-munding, and Alitaptap (Firefly).

In 1952, Buencamino was given a posthumous Outstanding Composer Award by the Manila Music Lovers Society. Written by Antonio C. Hila and Espiridion Arsenio Manuel

BUENCONSEJO, JOSE S. (Jose Semblante Buenconsejo) b. Cebu City 14 Sep 1961. Musicologist, music educator, administrator. He is the fifth among the six children of Nicanor Arias Buenconsejo of Dalaguete, Cebu and Magdalena Semblante of Consolacion, Cebu. Nicanor Buenconsejo, son of former Dalaguete mayor Hilarion, was a church organist, band musician, teacher of Spanish, and a government employee; while Magdalena Semblante was a church singer and leader, and a public school teacher. Jose’s early musical involvements include being a church organist and choir director during his high school years. In the 1978 National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA), he served as the accompanist of the winning University of the Visayas Children’s Choir. Not long after, he entered the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music as a piano student. While in college, from 1983 to 1988, he worked as a researcher-librarian, orchestra manager, and assistant to the music director of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. He also worked as a research assistant at the UP Ethnomusicological Archives from 1988 to 1990.

In 1988, Buenconsejo obtained his bachelor of music degree in musicology from the UP College of Music, under the tutelage of Jose Maceda and Corazon Dioquino. He went on to the University of Hawaii at Manoa in 1990 for his master of arts in music degree which he finished in 1993. He completed his doctorate degree in music from the University of Pennsylvania in 1999. His dissertation, later awarded the outstanding dissertation in music (Current Research in Ethnomusicology Series) by Routledge, was later revised and published as a book by the same press in 2002 with the title Songs and Gifts at the Frontier: Person and Exchange in the Agusan Manobo Possession Ritual. This book won the International Book Award from UP in 2003. He held a postdoctoral fellowship in the University of Hongkong from 2004 to 2007.

As a musicologist, he has published research articles like “Friendship and the Fear of Poison: A Particular History of Alterations in the Agusan Manobo Ritual” in The Journal of History, 2005; “On the Relationships Between Words and Melody in Pulangihon-Bukidnon Uwaging” in Humanities Diliman, 2006; “Spirit of the Act: On Indicating Presences in the Agusan Manobo Ritual Language” in the book (Re)making Society: The Politics of Language, Discourse and Identity in the Philippines, 2007; and “Orientalism in the Narrative, Music and Myth of the Amok in the 1937 film Zamboanga” in Plaridel: A Philippine Journal of Communication, Media, and Society, 2013. His full-length video documentary titled The River of Exchange was premiered at the UPCMu in 2008, and shown at the National Museum of the Philippines and at the International Gong Festival in Vietnam in 2009, at the 1st International Council for Traditional Music (ICTM) Symposium on the “Performing Arts of Southeast Asia” in Singapore in 2010, and at the Council on Southeast Asian Studies at Yale University in 2012. Buenconsejo’s current research projects include the source study of early Philippine music compositions, the restoration and preservation of rare Philippine music manuscripts in the UP College of Music library, Filipino composers of the 19th and 20th centuries, and the music of extant Filipino films.

Buenconsejo holds several research-oriented posts such as chair of the Humanities Division of the National Research Council of the Philippines; member of the technical committee in Music of the Commission on Higher Education; editor-in-chief of the Humanities Diliman, which received the recognition for being the only scopus-indexed UP Diliman journal during his term; editor-in-chief of Musika Journal Vol. 7; liaison officer for the Philippines of the International Council for Traditional Music; and organizer and convenor of several international conferences in UP Diliman. He is currently serving his second term as the dean of the UP College of Music, which he first held in August 2010.Written by Arwin Q. Tan

BUTOCAN, AGA MAYO b. Simuay Seashore, Sultan Kudarat, Maguindanao, South Cotabato (presently Sultan Mastura, Maguindanao) 24 Jul 1945. Maguindanao kulintang master and teacher. Her parents are Mayo Mamendeg and Madaya Abu. As is usual in oral cultures, Aga Mayo learned music by imitation at an early age. After graduating from Cotabato Public High School in 1962, she enrolled in the bachelor of science in education program of Arellano University, which she finished in 1968. Upon graduation, Jose Maceda took her to teach at the Department of Asian Music (now called Department of Musicology) of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. This was an important milestone in the teaching of music at the tertiary level in the country. Through Maceda and Butocan, kulintangan music has since then been studied as a translocal tradition by non-Maguindanao in a formal educational setting. Butocan’s teaching stint in UP was later emulated by the University of Washington Seattle, which graduated other Muslim musicians like Usopay Cadar and Danongan Kalanduyan who spread the tradition in a transnational context. Butocan continues to teach in the UP College of Music, but has also taught the instrument at St Scholastica’s College, Manila, 1986; Philippine Women’s University, 1982-85; Philippine High School for the Arts, 1985-90; University of Santo Tomas, Manila, 1985-93; St Paul College Manila, 1987; De La Salle Zobel, Alabang, Muntinlupa, 1996; and the Asian Institute for Liturgical Music, Quezon City, beginning 1986.

Aga Mayo Butocan is credited with formulating and developing a prescriptive notation system for kulintang music, which she has devised in order to aid in the transmission of the oral nature of kulintang music. This has engendered controversies in the academe because traditional learning of the instrument is done through imitation and copying as exemplified by her own experience. The notation system, developed during the time of Jose Maceda as chair of the Department of Music Research (now Department of Musicology), proved to be helpful and beneficial to those who have been trained in Western music. Felicidad Prudente and Kristina Benitez later helped Butocan publish her kulintang method booklet titled Palabunibunyan: A Repertoire of Musical Pieces for the Maguindanaon Kulintangan, Philippine Women’s University, 1987. Aside from being a pedagogue, Butocan performs actively as a kulintang artist in concerts, lectures, and symposiums, thus bringing her music to different areas both locally and abroad. Written by Janine Josephine Arianne A. Liao

CABAHUG, NOLYN (Nolyn Argamaso Cabahug) b. Jaro, Iloilo City 19 Mar 1956. d. Quezon City 2 Nov 2015. Singer. His parents were Salustiano Cabahug and Lily Argamaso. He was married to Meriam Ortega with whom he had two children: Marian, a quasi-dramatic soprano, and Eziel. He attended the West Negros College for his high school education and his bachelor of arts degree in English. He enrolled for a bachelor of music degree in voice at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music under the scholarship of the UPConcertChorus. He also took voice lessons with soprano IsangTapales.

Cabahug started as a member of the Manila Metropolitan Theater Concert Chorus in 1979. Cabahug was tenor/soloist of the UP Concert Chorus when it toured the United States, Canada, and Europe in 1981 and 1983, as well as in Germany and the Netherlands where it won the International Competitions, and in Australia where it represented the Philippines in the 1985 International Festival.

He has appeared in full-scale operas staged at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) and the Metropolitan Theater, among them, Tosca, Mefistofeles, Dialogues of the Carmélites, and LaLobaNegra (The Black She-wolf). He sang the role of Crisostomo Ibarra in the 1987 restaging of FelipePadilladeLeon’s NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not). A compact version of this opera was toured in key cities of the United States in 1988, with Cabahug reprising the role of Ibarra. In RolandoTinio’s Filipino adaptation of La Traviata, 1990, he sang the role of Alfredo Belmonte with soprano Donna Maria Zapola as his Violetta. He also performed as Nanki-poo in Mikado, also staged in 1990 at the Metropolitan Theater. He has sung in oratorios like The Messiah and Elijah, masses by Mozart, Puccini, Verdi, and Kodaly, and Carl Orff’s Carmina Burana and Stravinsky’s Les Noces. He starred in musical shows like Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) and Aliwang Pinoy Atbp. (Filipino Entertainment and Others), and the drama Ambon sa Madaling-araw (Early Morning Drizzle). In 1994, he was included in the lead cast of the musical Oh, Singapore alongside British actors at the Edinburgh International Festival of the Arts. The following year, he performed in a concert for the South East Asian Nations Festival held in London.

Cabahug had given concerts for the CCP Filipino Artists Series in 1991, Concert at the Park, Paco Park Presents, Puerta Real Evenings, the Manila Peninsula Hotel, and PCI Bank’s ManilaChamberOrchestra Concert Season. He also had numerous performances at the Malacañan Palace from the incumbency of Pres Corazon Aquino to the term of Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo. He also became the choirmaster and vocal coach of the Bank of the Philippine Islands’ Music Matrix, the United Coconut Planters Bank Chorale, the International Baptist Church Chorale, and the Makati Gospel Church Men’s Choir.

In 1991, Cabahug received the Operatic Singer of the Year citation from the National Press Club. The Negros Occidental Centennial Medal of Honor was conferred on him in the same year in recognition of his achievements in the performing arts. He was also a recipient of the Outstanding Citizen Award from Ilog, Negros Occidental. He was the recipient of Best Male Classical Performer given by Aliw Award in 2003 and 2005. He was also given the Bacolod City Outstanding Citizen Award in 2014. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo
CABALLERO, FEDERICO (See LITERATURE volume.)

CABANGON, NOEL (Noel Genetiano Cabangon) b. Rosario, La Union 25 Dec 1963. Musician and singer-songwriter. He is the son of Jose Cabangon and Adela Genetiano. He is married to Ma. Gloriosa Santos aka Beng Santos, theater artist and cultural administrator, with whom he has a son. He learned the guitar at 10 and entered in local singing contests. He began his career as a folk singer in 1982.

Cabangon is the voice behind the popular song “Kanlungan” (Life’s Chance) or “Pana-Panahon” (In One Own’s Time) as it is more popularly known. He has released four albums under the Jesuit Music Ministry (JMM) label of the Jesuit Communications Foundation (Jescom): Pasakalye (Prologue), 2001, H’wag Mangamba (Don’t Panic), 2002, Medjas (Slightly Jazz), 2003, and Noel, 2003, and another under Ballyhoo Records, Himig Nating Pag-Ibig (Ou Love Hymn), 2006. His music video, “Kayod Kabayo, Kayod Barya” (Work Like a Horse For a Few Cents) from Pasakalye, portrays the hardships of street vendors and common Filipinos. It won Best Music Video in the 2002 Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA). Selections from Medjas garnered several nominations in the Best Christmas Song category. The single “Tinamaan Mo” (You Hit It) was recognized as the Best Jazz Recording in the 17th Awit Awards by the Philippine Association of the Recording Industry (PARI).

Actively promoting alternative Filipino music, he formed a folk group, Buklod, in 1987 with Rom Dongeto and Rene Boncocan. They yielded three albums tackling socio-political-cultural issues. Bukid at Buhay (Farm and Life) speaks of the lives, struggles and aspirations of the Filipino peasants. Tatsulok (Triangle) deals with human rights. And Sa Kandungan ng Kalikasan (Nature’s Cradle) advocates for the environment.

Buklod toured European cities from 1989 until it was disbanded in 1994. Subsequently, Cabangon held concerts with artists such as Bayang Barrios and some Filipino farmers in 2000, performing for Filipino migrants in Denmark, Belgium, and Switzerland.

In 2002, Noel performed with artists from Africa and South America, advocating for the debt cancellation of the Southern countries at the World Social Forum in Porto Alegre, Brazil. At the same forum in Mumbai, India, 2004, he sang and attended a workshop on the relevance of music on the theme “Another World is Possible.” He collaborated with several artists from other countries that led to the album Arts in Resistance.

Cabangon wrote several songs such as “Hanap-hanap Ka” (Yearning For You) for Calvin Millado, “Ang Diwa ng Pasko” (The Meaning of Christmas) for GMA Network’s Christmas Collection interpreted by Janno Gibbs, and “Kita’y Maghihintay” (Let’s Wait) and “Nasa Langit” (In Heaven) for Agot Isidro.

His entry to the Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1999, “Dito sa Kanto” (At the Street Corner) was interpreted by the APO Hiking Society. His song “Ikaw ay Bayani” (You’re a Hero) in 2000 made it to the top 10 in ABS-CBN’s songwriting competition, Himig Handog sa Bayaning Pilipino (Gift of Song for the Filipino Hero).

Cabangon has also written several songs for other artists such as Cesar Montano, Randy Santiago, Dingdong Avanzado, and Nikki Gil. He composed the theme song of Pahina (Pages), an educational television program of the ABS-CBN Foundation. His song “Kayod Kabayo, Kayod Barya” was used as a soundtrack for the movie Ang Tanging Ina (The One and Only Mother). Cabangon also wrote and performed songs for GMA Network’s public affairs program, Debate With Mare and Pare (Debate With Female and Male Pals).

His song “Alaala Ka, Infanta” (You’re In Our Thoughts, Infanta) was a special tribute for the communities of Infanta, Real and Nakar, in Quezon province, which was ravaged by three big typhoons in December 2004. The song was performed at a concert in Infanta during the Earth Day celebration in 2005.

As a music director, Cabangon is an active artist-teacher-member of the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), having written several songs and musically directed plays such as Ang Tiririt ng Ibong Adarna (The Song of the Adarna Bird), Summer Dreaming, Don Guillermo, Romeo at Julieta: Isang Komedi (Romeo and Juliet: A Comedy), in collaboration with the Black Tent Theater of Japan, Dream Weavers, Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Grandma Basyang’s Stories), and Walang Himala (No Miracle). He also joined the cast of 1896, playing Jose Rizal. He also acted as Jesus Christ in the rock opera Jesus Christ Superstar at the Music Museum in June 2000.

Cabangon is a member of KATHA, FILSCAP, and Haribon Foundation. He campaigns for Greenpeace International, Jubilee South, Freedom from Debt Coalition (FDC), and for Global Call to Action Against Poverty (GCAP). Written by Lara T. Mendoza

CALALANG, FIDEL (Fidel Gener Calalang Jr) b. Manila 2 Feb 1963. He is the son of Fidel R. Calalang Sr and Maria Gener, both medical practitioners. He obtained his bachelor of music in piano, 1987, and master of arts in conducting, 2008, from the University of Sto. Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music. He studied piano under Erlinda Fule and Nilda Redoblado and took voice lessons with Gloria Colonel, Kathy Sternberg, Emmanuel Gregorio, and George Hernandez. At present, he teaches at the UST Conservatory of Music and is the coordinator of the Conducting Department and Advisor for international post-graduate students in conducting in the graduate school.

In early 1980s, he was an active chorister and sung with University of the Philippines Saringhimig and Camerata Singers who went on world tour in 1983 and 1984. In 1993, he founded the UST Singers and led it to several world tours between 1993 and 2013. The choir bagged many top prizes, including winning the choir of the world award twice in 2005 and 2011. He also founded the Coro Tomasino, 1985; the Maryknoll College Glee Club, 1987; and Kamerchor, 1991. He has conducted the Lyceum Institute of Technology Singers, 2006-08; Lyceum of the Philippines University Chorale, 2009; and First Church of God in Valenzuela City since 2006.

He is the recipient of several awards such as Dangal ng UST Outstanding Artist of the Year, 2000; Gawad Parangal sa Kaunlaran for Arts and Culture, 2002; and Dangal ng UST Gawad Lorenzo Ruiz, Benavidez Outstanding Achievement Award for International Excellence as Conductor, Outstanding Alumni of UST, all of which he received during the celebration of the quadricentennial foundation of UST in 2011.

Among the solo prizes he obtained are: third prize for a composition for solo instrument from the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and League of Filipino Composers (LFC) and second prize in the UST Mozart Competition, 1981; honorable mention in CCP-LFC Art Song Cycle Competition, 1983; first prize in the 1st International Choral Competition in Ojal, California, USA, second prize for his composition for solo instrument from the CCP and LFC, and finalist status in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (Voice Category C), all in 1987; first prize in Tonen International Choral Competition and Best Conductor in Monster, The Netherlands, 2002; and a prize in the Mga Awiting Bayan Para sa Korong Pilipino, 2007.

As conductor, he led the UST Singers in performances at the CCP, the Philamlife Theater, Meralco Theater, Francisco Santiago Hall, and in command performances for several head of states, including for Their Eminences Pope John Paul II and Pope Benedict XVI. He also led the UST Singers in performances telecast in radio and television stations in the Philippines and abroad.

He also composed and arranged for choir. Among his compositions are “Lux Aeterna,” 2002, “Pater Noster” (first prize, International Choral Competition, Ojal, California), and “Miserere Mei,” 2013. He was commissioned to write choral contest pieces such as “Circle of Life,” “Take on Me,” “Jubilate Deo,” and “Salamat, O Panginoon” (Thank You, Oh Lord).

He has attended national and international choral festivals, given lectures on choral music both locally and internationally, and sat as juror in many local as well as international choral competitions. Written by Antonio C. Hila

CANON, FERNANDO (Fernando Salvador Canon Faustino) b. Biñan, Laguna 6 Aug 1860. d. 18 Jul 1938. Music essayist and guitarist. He was the son of smith and watchmaker, Fernando Guevara Canon Faustino and landowner Blasa Alumna Salvador. He was a close friend of Jose Rizal, having been his townmate and later classmate at Ateneo Municipal where Canon graduated with a bacchiler en artes (bachelor of arts) in 1876.

Like the children of wealthy families during his time, Fernando studied in Madrid beginning 1877 and later became part of the group of Filipino ilustrado (educated) propagandists in Spain. He contributed a few articles in the newspaper La Solidaridad which was published by a printing press believed to have been supported by the Barcelona banker Ramon Battle y Serra whose daughter Teresa Battle became Fernando’s wife in 1887. It was in 1888, during Fernando’s return to Manila with his wife Teresa, supposedly on a “honeymoon” to avoid suspicion of the authorities, that 20 copies of the first edition of Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere were smuggled into the country.

After seven months in the Philippines in 1888, Canon and his wife returned to Barcelona where Canon got his degree in electrical engineering. Canon furthered his studies in Munich, in Belgium, Italy, Switzerland, and in Paris, where he met Rizal sometime in 1892, together with Antonio Luna (Jose 1972, 97). This was the last time Canon met Rizal, for Canon was in Barcelona when Rizal was executed in Dec 1896.

In 1898, Canon, together with his friend Antonio Luna, joined Aguinaldo’s Philippine revolutionary army and served as an engineer in Malolos before the capital was captured by the Americans. Canon then was assigned to Nueva Vizcaya as comandante politico-militar but was captured by the Americans. Thereafter he was released from prison, returned to Spain, and worked as instructor in polytechnics in Barcelona. In 1906, his wife Teresa immortalized the friendship of her husband Canon with Rizal in piano variations based on the theme of the Marcha Nacional Filipino.

Canon returned to the Philippines beginning 1908 and accepted a position in the Bureau of Public Works and at the same time taught at the Liceo de Manila and Escuela de Ingeniera y Arquitectura de Manila.

In 1910 and in 1914, Canon contributed essays on Philippine music, the first on “Kuriapi” (two-stringed Southeast Asian lute) and the second on “Cundiman,” both of which appeared in Cultura Filipina. These articles are literary, but they are significant for having been written in a time when culture was used as a weapon in asserting a sovereign Filipino nation in the midst of American colonial occupation. Canon wrote poetry, a skill he shared with Rizal and which he acquired since his early education in Ateneo. He penned a sonnet titled “A las Dalagas Malolenses” (To the Young Women of Malolos), published under his pen name “Kuitib” in the 15 Mar 1889 issue of La Solidaridad, which was dedicated to the 20 ladies who petitioned Gov Valeriano Weyler for a school. His poems “Flor Ideal” (Ideal Flower) and “Rizal Artista” (Rizal the Artist) were anthologized in Eduardo de la Camara’s Parnaso Filipino, published in Barcelona in the 1920s.

Canon was appointed secretary of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music in 1916. He taught guitar, an instrument that he and Epifanio de los Santos played and became famous for. Canon was the teacher of Jose Ma. Pellicer who was the guitar instructor of Lester Demetillo in UP College of Music. Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

George Canseco (George Masangkay Canseco) was a music composer and film scorer. He was born in Manila on 23 April 1934. He died on 19 November 2004. Born to Jose Canseco, a doctor, and Seferina Masangkay, he studied at the Naic Elementary School and Jose Abad Santos High School. He took liberal arts at the University of the East, but did not finish his course. A journalist by profession, he was at one time or another part-time scriptwriter for the Manila Broadcasting Co, news director at Eagle Broadcasting, senior desk editor of the Associated Press, and desk editor of Philippine Herald. When martial law was declared in 1972, he turned to music writing. He had been president of the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers or FILSCAP since 1973.

 

Canseco’s first composition was “I Will Never Be Yours” followed by “You’re All I Love.” He translated the latter into Tagalog in 1970, when Eddie Rodriguez asked him to write a theme song for the movie Kapantay ay Langit (As High as the Sky). It became a big hit, bringing Canseco instant popularity. Since then, he has composed one hit after another. Among them are “Rain,” “Kailangan Kita” (I Need You), “Ngayon at Kailanman” (Now and Forever), “Kung Ako’y liwan Mo” (If You Leave Me), “Kastilyong Buhangin” (Sand Castle), “Ako ang Nagwagi, Ako ang Nasawi” (I Was the One Who Won, I Was the One Who Lost), “Dito Ba?” (Is it Here?), and “Langis at Tubig” (Oil and Water), interpreted by popular singers like Pilita Corrales, Basil Valdez, Dulce, Leah Navarro, Kuh Ledesma, and Sharon Cuneta. Apart from composing movie theme songs, he had also been musical director for many films, such as Burlesk Queen, Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak (When the Crow Turns White, When the Heron Turns Black), Atsay (Maid), and Miss X.

 

Since 1969, Canseco had won numerous awards for best composer, best theme song, song of the year, best musical director, and best musical scoring from several award-giving bodies. He won the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) Best Theme Song award for “Kapantay ay Langit,” 1971, and “Imortal” (Immortal), 1989. He also won the Best Theme Song award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for the following songs: “Huwag, Bayaw” (No, Brother-in-law), 1979; “Langis at Tubig,” 1980; “Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan” (How Often is Once), 1982; “Paano Ba ang Mangarap” (How is it to Dream), 1983; “Dapat Ka Bang Mahalin?” (Are You Worthy to be Loved?), 1984; and “Hihintayin Kita sa Langit” (I Will Wait For You in Heaven), 1991. He was elevated to the FAMAS Hall of Fame in 1989. “Hiram” (Borrowed), used as the theme song of the movie Palimos ng Pag-ibig (Begging For Love), won the PMPC Star Awards for Movie Theme Song of the Year in 1987, while the following songs received the Best Original Song award from the Film Academy of the Philippines: “Sinasamba Kita” (I Adore You), 1982; “Misis Mo, Misis Ko” (Your Wife, My Wife), 1988; “Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas” (How Can You Escape Tomorrow), 1988; “Hihintayin Kita sa Langit,” 1991; and “Paano ang Ngayon Kung Wala ang Kahapon” (How Will Today Be Without Yesterday), 1995.
