He was chosen best musical director by the MMFF for Bato-Bato sa Langit (Throwing Stones to the Air), 1975; Burlesk Queen, 1977; Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak, 1978; Atsay, 1979; and Imortal, 1989; by the FAMAS for Pagputi ng Uwak, Pag-itim ng Tagak, 1978, Huwag, Bayaw, 1979, Miss X, 1980, Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan, 1982, and Palimos ng Pag-ibig, 1988; by the FAP Awards for Paano Tatakasan ang Bukas (How to Escape the Past), 1988; and by the PMPC Star Awards for Magdusa Ka! (Suffer!), 1987. Among his award-winning songs are “Sinasamba Kita,” 1982, and “Langis at Tubig,” 1983, both chosen by the Cecil Awards as best song written for motion picture, TV or radio; “Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan,” Cecil Awards’ Song of the Year, 1984; and “True Love Came Too Late,” Awit Awards Song of the Year, 1970. Dulce’s rendition of his composition, “Ako ang Nasawi, Ako ang Nagwagi,” won the grand prize for the Philippines at the World Song Festival in Hong Kong in 1979; the same year, “Ngayon” (Now) sung by Basil Valdez, received the Artistic Achievement Award at the Pacific Song Contests in Sydney, Australia and the grand prize in the Likha Awit Pambata Songwriting Contest. Ogie Alcasid’s album in 2010 was in his honor, Ngayon at Kailanman: A Tribute to George Canseco, Universal Records. It includes pop classics composed by Canseco such as “Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan” (To the End of Eternity), “Yakap” (Embrace), “Paano Kita Pasasalamatan” (How Can I Thank You), “Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo” (If You Leave me), “Kaibigan” (Friend), “Kapantay ay Langit,” and “Kastilyong Buhangin.”  Written by T. Galvez, updated by Connie Ladrido

CANSECO, JOSE (Jose Rivera Canseco Jr) b. Intramuros, Manila 1 Jun 1839. d. 12 Jun 1902. Composer, band conductor. He is the son of Jose Canseco Sr, a sea captain, and Cecilia Rivera. He was married twice. By his first wife, Engracia San Juan, he had two children. After Engracia died, he married Francisca Espiritu, with whom he had nine children. He was a tiple (soprano voice) in SanAgustinChurch. After a short period of service with the Spanish Army Regiment No 8 Band, he became a tenor in the ManilaCathedral under the directorship of Blas Echegoyen. In 1882, he served as conductor of the orchestra organized by Pedro Gruet. Four years later, he helped organize an orchestra and an opera company of local singers in Pandacan. With him as stage director, the all-Filipino cast successfully staged parts of La Traviata and Rigoletto and whole operas like Lucrezia Borgia and Linda di Chamounix in the cockpit of Pandacan. Canseco also became director of the Narvacan Band and, after passing rigid government examinations, was appointed band conductor of Regiment No 71 of the Spanish Army.

After the 1896 Revolution, Canseco devoted his time to teaching music. He taught piano and solfeggio in the Liceo de Manila and the Colegio Porvenir, and harmony and composition at home. His pupils included Felipe Marin, LeonIgnacio, Julio Paz, Silvestre Tapales, Santiago Cruz, and Alfredo Roa.

Among Canseco’s works are religious compositions such as “Salve a la Santisima Virgen” (Hail to the Most Holy Virgin), “Letania a la Santisima Virgen” (Litany to the Most Holy Virgin), “Liberame” (Free Me), “Plegaria a la Dolorosa” (Prayer to the Sorrowful Mother), “Salve [Regina] a tres voices,” and two hymns to Nuestra Señora de Guia, the patron saint of Ermita. His secular pieces include “La Despedida” (Farewell), a song with words by Lorenzo Guerrero; “La Ausencia” (The Absence); “Flor de Maria” (Flowers of Mary) in three parts; “La Huerfana” (The Orphan); “Josefina,” a polonaise; and the paso dobles “Valeroso” and “Themis y Marta” (Themis and Marta). He also wrote musical scores for a Spanish zarzuela, La Muerte de Lucrezia (The Death of Lucrezia), and several marches. All these compositions are now lost, except “Salve [Regina] a tres voices,” which is preserved in a church musician’s collection in Cebu. He also collected more than 70 native folksongs and airs from the north and south, which were never located.

In 1882, Canseco’s composition, “Santa Teresa Doctora, Sed mi Protectora” (Saint Theresa, Doctor, Be My Protector), was awarded the gold medal in the Santa Teresa centennial celebration contest. He also received a gold medal in the St Louis Exposition of 1904 for a musical apparatus he devised while he was posted in Zamboanga as band conductor of a Spanish regiment. Originally called the “miratonos” by Canseco (later renamed “tonopsis mechanica” by a Jesuit priest), the device facilitated musical transcription and harmonization for students and musicians. Written by Espiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo
CARLUEN, ALEJO (See THEATER volume.)
CARPENA, MARIA (See THEATER volume.)

CARPIO, MARK ANTHONY (Mark Anthony Austria Carpio) b. Manila 22 Aug 1968. Choral conductor, pianist, educator. He is the son of Manuel Carpio of Angat, Bulacan and Celerina Austria of Norzagaray, Bulacan. He finished elementary and high school at the Notre Dame of Greater Manila in Caloocan City. In high school, he became a piano scholar of the Lucia Francisco Music Circle and played the flute in the school band. He went on to finish his bachelor of music degree in piano at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, cum laude, and was, for a time, a scholar of the Jovita Fuentes Musicultural Society and the Music Promotions Foundation. From 1992 to 1996, he taught piano at the UP College of Music. Afterwards, he taught at the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music (AILM) from 1997 to 2001 and at the De La Salle University-College of St Benilde School of Design and Arts from 2001 to 2002. In 2003, he started teaching conducting at the UP College of Music.

Carpio became a member of the Philippine Madrigal Singers (aka UP Madrigal Singers) and was eventually chosen in 1991 to be its choirmaster by the unanimous vote of the choir’s Artistic Council, succeeding National Artist for music, Andrea O. Veneracion, the founder of the group. Under his leadership, Carpio catapulted the Philippine Madrigal Singers to win the European Grand Prix of Choral Singing for the second time in 2007 (the first time was in 1997 under Veneracion). The European Grand Prix of Choral Singing is regarded as the toughest choral competition in the world, as only grand prize winners of six European choral competitions are eligible to compete in it, namely: Arezzo, Italy; Varna, Bulgaria; Tours, France; Debrecen, Hungary; Tolosa, Spain; and Maribor, Slovenia. It was the first time in the history of the European Grand Prix that a choir won twice. In 2004, Carpio also led the choir to win the first prizes in both the Habanera and the Polyphonic categories of the 50th Certamen Internacional de Habaneras y Polifonia in Torrevieja, Spain. Since 2007, the Philippine Madrigal Singers has been awarded numerous accolades, among which are the UNESCO Artists for Peace in Paris, France, 2009; the Guidoneum Award from the Fondazione Guido d’Arezzo, 2010; and the Brand Laureate Premier Award as the World’s Best Choral Ensemble in Malaysia, 2012.

Carpio has given lectures and workshops at various international and local choral symposia and festivals. Aside from the yearly Madz et al Festival and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Annual Hands-on Choral Workshop, he has been a choral clinician in Singapore, Malaysia, and Taiwan, 2009; Indonesia and Lithuania, 2010; Canada, 2011; and Colombia, 2013. He continues to propagate the appreciation and development of choral arts in the country by continuing the Sing Philippines Choral Outreach Workshop, a program started by his predecessor, Andrea Veneracion. Written by Arwin Q. Tan

CARRION, BALBINO (Balbino Bautista Carrion) b. Imus, Cavite 31 Mar 1840. d. 21 Mar 1919. Singer. He was born to Gavino Carrion and Juana Bautista, and married to Basilia Jose with whom he had seven children, one of whom, Victorino, was also a singer and music teacher. While a young boy, he went to Manila and was a sacristan (altar boy) in Santa Cruz Church. The curate Jose Guevara, a secular priest of liberal ideas, took care of his education. When Guevara was transferred to the Quiapo Church, Carrion went with him. He became the cantor of the Quiapo Church choir, under the baton of NatalioMata, and achieved renown for the high pitch and quality of his voice. He also sang in novenas, rosario (rosary), or misa cantadas (high masses), celebrated in Manila churches and neighboring provinces, and with the Manila Cathedral choir under the direction of Blas Echegoyen.

Carrion used to perform minor parts in operas produced by visiting foreign companies, until he joined the Chananay dramatic troupe and played the role of Manrico in Il Trovatore. Together with the group, he toured the provinces, appearing in plays or singing in churches during town fiestas. His voice never faltered, and he continued to serve at the Quiapo Church until his old age. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang

CARRION, VICTORINO (Victorino Jose Carrion) b. Quiapo, Manila 6 Mar 1872. d. Quiapo 9 May 1935. Singer, teacher. He is the fifth of 11 children of BalbinoCarrion, tenor and cantor of Quiapo church, and of Basilia Jose, a gilder. He was born on Callejon Templanza, near the church where he sang from boyhood until his death. He married Agatona Trinidad in 1896. They had six children. Carrion studied for free at the Ateneo Municipal. He sang as tiple (soprano voice) at the Ateneo masses. He learned to play the guitar from beggars, and later the mandolin and the bandurria. After singing as tiple in the Quiapo choir, he was taught solfeggio by its director NatalioMata, and later the piano by ManuelMata, the church organist.

Carrion made his theatrical debut singing the last scene in Lucia di Lammermoor with NemesioRatiaJr at the Teatro Cervantes. Soon, he appeared with Ratia in the Spanish zarzuela, Una vieja (An Old Woman), and in others with YeyengFernandez and JoseCarvajal. He played Tenyong in WalangSugat (No Wounds) at the TeatroZorrilla in 1902. He joined the GranCompañiadelaZarzuelaTagala of SeverinoReyes, with which he toured for three years, just as his father had done with the Chananay troupe. It was during this time that he achieved prominence as a sarsuwela performer, sharing stellar billing with MariaCarpena or Estanislawa San Miguel, both of whom he had partnered in sarsuwela like Minda Mora, AngKalupi (The Wallet), Filipinas para los Filipinos (Philippines for the Filipinos), Filotea, Lukso ng Dugo (Leap of Blood), and La venta de Filipinas al Japon (The Sale of the Philippines to Japan). He last sang in 1919 in PatricioMariano’s Deni.

After performing on the sarsuwela stage, his interest shifted to the opera. In 1909, upon Sylvia Lanzi’s invitation, he sang with her in the opera Cavalleria Rusticana. Up to 1912, he was active in the opera scene, essaying such coveted roles as Manrico in Il Trovatore, Turridu in Cavalleria Rusticana, and a part in Gounod’s Faust.

In 1905, he opened the Escuela de Canto, a singing school, where the ordinary student paid six pesos a month; the middle class, 12; the well-to-do, 24; and the talented poor, nothing. Although he continued performing in well-known operas, he provided his students opportunities to perform. In 1923, his students debuted in Verdi’s Requiem at the ManilaGrandOperaHouse, among whom were JoseMossesgeldSantiago-Font, MercedesMatias, NeliaManalo, Jose Barredo, and others. His school, later named Schola Cantorum, figured prominently in musiceducation of the period, and was featured in opera productions like La Traviata, Aida, Lucia di Lammermoor, and Il Trovatore under the ManilaChamberMusicSociety. Carrion later acted as musical director for operas.

When he died, he left behind a music library, a composition with his own lyrics entitled “Despedida a Jesus Nazareno” (Farewell to Jesus of Nazareth) sung during novenas from 1 to 9 Jan, and a solid achievement as artist and teacher. The modest cross that marks his grave at the La Loma Cemetery was a gift from his pupils. Written by Espiridion Arsenio Manuel and Elmer L. Gatchalian
CARVAJAL, JOSE (See THEATER volume.)

Ryan Cayabyab (Raymundo Cipriano Pujante Cayabyab) is a music composer, conductor, musical director, film scorer, television host, and teacher. He is a National Artist for music. He was born in Manila on 4 May 1954. He is the son of Alberto Cayabyab and Celerina Pujante, a soprano and instructor at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. He is married to Emelina Punsalan with whom he has two children. Daughter Cristina Maria is also a singer and a music composer and arranger.

He first studied accounting at the UP but soon left school to augment his income working as an accompanist for the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) Chorale which was a special project of his uncle, an official of that government agency. He finished his bachelor of music major in composition at the UP College of Music in 1983. He was a faculty member of the UP College of Music Department of Composition and Theory from 1981 to 2003.

His friendship with composers Nonong Pedero and Jose Mari Chan led to an introduction to pop singer Cocoy Laurel, who hired him as musical director/accompanist for his stage and TV performances from 1972 to 1974. He did musical scores and directions for a number of established pop groups and solo performers from 1971 to 1978. A series of successes as musical director for noted pop performers like Celeste Legaspi, Kuh Ledesma, Basil Valdez, and Pilita Corrales soon followed at venues abroad like the Carnegie Hall and the Avery Fisher Hall of the Lincoln Center, both in New York; Kennedy Center in Washington DC; the Shrine Auditorium, Los Angeles; and the Circus Maximus of Caesars Palace, Las Vegas. He has also worked in the same shows with American performers like Sammy Davis Jr, Frank Sinatra, and Diane Schuur.

He set up the Ryan Cayabyab Music Studio in Makati, 1989, and Quezon City, 1992, as a means to alternative music education. The studio later moved to Robinsons Galleria in 2006, with the name The Music School of Ryan Cayabyab. He founded and managed groups like Smokey Mountain and 14 K in the early 1990s, Kayain 2000, and is at present the music director of The Ryan Cayabyab Singers that began in 2006.

As a requirement for his graduation, he presented his composition Misa (Mass), premiered by the UP Concert Chorus at the UP Abelardo Hall in 1983. At this time, he introduced his rearrangement of Nicanor S. Abelardo’s kundiman "Mutya ng Pasig" (Muse of Pasig) in a concert by Kuh Ledesma, followed by the recordings of Celeste Legaspi of Francisco Santiago and Abelardo’s kundiman arranged for piano and voice in a modern manner. These controversial arrangements drew mixed reactions from both the pop music and the serious music worlds. He has also set to music the words of St John of the Cross in a commissioned work titled “O, Noche Oscura” (Oh, Dark Night), a choral piece premiered by the Philippine Madrigal Singers in 1990. A series of two-piano pieces was begun with Pahilaga (Northbound), based on the folk songs of the north, which were performed by Raul Sunico and Rene Dalandan in their concert tours in the United States. Pahilaga was first composed for a violin, cello, and piano trio. He has composed Gloria, a choral work premiered by the UP Concert Chorus. Te Deum was his next major choral work incorporating kulintang and balimbing with piano. His work titled Ilocandia for solo flute and orchestra is a popular orchestral piece especially for outreach performances by the country’s premiere orchestra, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. It has been recently transcribed for flute and two pianos. His other orchestral work is a short character piece titled Pepe en Pilar (Pepe and Pilar). The motif of this piece is taken from the popular children’s folk song “Penpen de Sarapen.”

He was also the musical director for the stage performances for the three state visits to Morocco which earned the accolade of the King. In 1979, he was musical director of the show, Manila, Manila: As Time Goes By, for the grand reopening of the Manila Hotel. He also wrote the score of the hit musical Katy! The Musical, 1988, with libretto by Jose Javier Reyes, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1991, with libretto by Paul Dumol and Jovy Miroy. He also wrote music for ballets, like Rama, Hari (King Rama), 1980, with libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera and choreography by Alice Reyes, and Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass), 1984, with choreography by Basilio. His other musical theater credits include: Noli Me Tangere: The Musical (Touch Me Not: The Musical) and Alikabok (Dust), 1995; Ang Larawan (The Portrait) and Ilustrado, 1997; and Lorenzo, 2013.

Among his award-winning scores for the movies are: Karnal (Carnal), 1983, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) and Gawad Urian; Misis Mo, Misis Ko (Your Wife, My Wife), 1988, Urian; Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait For You in Heaven), 1991, FAMAS; Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You’re the Only One I Have Loved), 1992, Urian, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), and PMPC Star Awards; Kung Mawawala Ka Pa (If You Disappear), 1994, Metro Manila Film Festival, FAMAS; and Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (Call Me Joy), 1998, FAP. Other film credits as musical scorer include Ophelia at Paris (Ophelia and Paris), 1973; Magandang Gabi sa Inyong Lahat (Good Evening to All of You), 1975; Paraisong Parisukat (Square Paradise), the theme song of which won the FAMAS in 1977; Agila (Eagle), 1980; Kailangan Kita (I Need You) and Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1993; Abot-Kamay ang Pangarap (Elena’s Redemption), 1996; Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Selya’s Life), Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin, and Anak ng Bulkan (Son of the Volcano), 1997; Kahapon, May Dalawang Bata (Yesterday, There Were Two Children), 1999; Deathrow, 2000; Azucena, 2000; and Mga Kuwentong Barbero (Barber’s Tales), 2013. Ang Larawan, the musical adaptation of Nick Joaquin's A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino with music by Cayabyab and libretto by Rolando Tinio, was turned into a movie in 2017, directed by Loy Arcenas. It won Best Musical Score, among many other awards, in the 2017 Metro Manila Film Festival, Movie Musical Scorer of the Year in the 2018 PMPC Star Awards, and Best Music in the 2018 FAP as well as in the 2018 Asia-Pacific Film Festival. 

In 1978, his song, “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful is Our Music), won the grand prize in the first Metro Manila Popular Music Festival or Metropop as well as in the Seoul International Song Festival in Korea. In 1978, he received the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) award. His other citations and awards are: the Cecil Award for Producer of the Year and a Special Album Award for Outstanding Contribution in Serious Music for his production of the album, Misa, 1984; and the Awit Awards for Best Composer, Best Record Producer, and Best Arranger in 1990. His TV show, Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music With Ryan), received the Catholic Mass Media Award in 1988, 1989, and 1990, and was also adjudged as one of the 10 best TV programs in 1987 and 1992 by the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon. The same awardgiving body gave Cayabyab a special citation for his significant contribution to Philippine music.

In 1992, his song “Mama,” garnered the Best Song award in the Voice of Asia Song Festival held in Alma Ata, Tajikhstan in the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. His composition, “Bagong Tunog” (New Sound), a jingle for a soft drink commercial, received a bronze medal for Best Jingle in the New York Film and TV Festival and the Jingle of Year award in the 1991 Philippine Advertising Congress. He led the group Smokey Mountain to win the grand prize in the 1992 Tokyo Music Festival for the song “Paraiso” (Paradise).

From 2000 to 2006, he was the executive and artistic director of the San Miguel Foundation for the Performing Arts where the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra and San Miguel Master Chorale are formed. Throughout these years with the foundation, he has arranged the music and produced the following albums: Great Filipino Love Songs, 2004; Great Original Pilipino Music, 2004; The Sacred Works of Ryan Cayabyab, 2004; Pasko I and Pasko II, 2005; and Spoliarium The Opera, Basil Valdez: Filipino Classics (With the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra), and Dancing in the Rain, all in 2006.

Cayabyab has received local and international recognitions: Lifetime Achievement Award from Awit Awards, 1996; Professional Award in Music from the University of the Philippines, 1998; CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts, 1999; second prize for music and dance at the 2001 Onassis Cultural Competitions, 2001; Gawad CCP sa Sining for Music, 2004; and the Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice Award from Pope Francis and the Vatican, 2013. He was conferred the National Artist Award for music in 2018. 

Cayabyab is recognized by many sectors for his ability to bridge the gap between Filipino pop and classical music. Some of the albums he has produced include Routes to Roots, 1977; ONE (A One-Man A Cappella Album), 1981; ONE Christmas, 1991; The Silver Album, 1997; and ONE MORE, 2001.   Written by Felizidad Z. Reyes, updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

Levi Celerio (Levi Celerio Cruz) was a musician, lyricist, and poet. He is a National Artist for music and literature. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 30 Apr 1910. He died in Quezon City on 2 Apr 2002. He was the son of Cornelio Cruz, a native of Baliuag, Bulacan and Juliana Celerio of San Pablo, Laguna. He grew up in the slums of Tondo and went to the public elementary school there. At age 11, he started taking violin lessons from a Philippine Constabulary (PC) musician and became a member of the PC Band while attending classes at Torres High School. He finished two semesters of violin at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music. Alexander Lippay, then director of the Conservatory, recommended him for a scholarship at the Academy of Music of Manila and also made it possible for him to become the youngest member of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. However, a fall from a tree, which resulted in a broken wrist, ended Celerio’s dream of becoming a violinist. He worked for some time as a komiks illustrator.

In the mid-1930s, Celerio was asked to write the theme song of Filippine Films’s Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden) which starred Rogelio de la Rosa and Rosa del Rosario. He soon became the most sought after lyricist in the country. He was not only a master of the Tagalog language; he could finish a song’s lyrics in an average of 20 minutes. He wrote the lyrics of almost all of Santiago Suarez’s balitaw and harana, like “Caprichosa” (Capricious Woman), “Ang Tapis ni Inday” (Inday’s Overskirt), “Dungawin Mo, Hirang” (Look Out of the Window, My Love), and “Umaga na Neneng” (It’s Morning, Neneng). He was the lyricist of Lucio San Pedro’s "Sa Ugoy ng Duyan" (As the Cradle Rocks), as well as Tony Maiquez’s "Sapagkat Kami ay Tao Lamang" (For We are Only Human) which was made into a movie in 1963 and won the Best Theme Song award in the 1963 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). He also wrote the lyrics of standard Tagalog songs such as Restie Umali’s "Saan Ka Man Naroroon" (Wherever You Are), Leopoldo Silos’s “Lagi Kitang Naaalala” (You Are Always in My Mind), and Ernani Cuenco’s “Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal” (How Much Do I Love You). He set lyrics to novelty songs like Juan Silos Jr’s “Waray-waray,” “Alembong” (Flirt), “Ikaw Kasi” (You’re to Blame), “No Money, No Honey,” and “Basta’t Mahal Kita” (So Long As I Love You), Santiago Suarez’s “Nabasag ang Banga” (The Jar Was Broken), Tony Maiquez’s "Pitong Gatang" (Seven Gantas), and Ernani Cuenco’s “Kalesa” (Horse-driven Carriage). He started the trend of putting lyrics to folk melodies like “Pandangguhan,” “Cariñosa,” "Subli,” and “Maglalatik.” The most memorable song he wrote the lyrics for is “Maligayang Pasko at Manigong Bagong Taon” (Merry Christmas and a Prosperous New Year), also known as "Ang Pasko ay Sumapit" (Christmas is Here).

Celerio landed in the Guiness Book of World Records for being the only man who could play music on a leaf. He also published two books: Filipino Palindromes and Take it From Levi, a collection of love poems.

Celerio was conferred a doctorate in humanities, honoris causa, by the UP in 1991. Acknowledged as the dean of Filipino lyricists, he has received numerous citations and awards of recognition, like those from the Popular Music Foundation of the Philippines, 1983; the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), 1989; Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, 1991; Natatanging Gawad Urian from the Manunuring Pelikulang Pilipino, 1993; and the FILSCAP Filipino Artist Award from KATHA Music Awards, 1997. Celerio was named National Artist for music and literature in 1997.  Written by Michael M. Coroza, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

Josefino Cenizal (Josefino Yamzon Cenizal), also known as Pepe Cenizal, was a music composer, musical director, pop music pianist, and a film actor. He was born in Tanza, Cavite on 14 Sep 1919. He died in Tanza, Cavite on 27 Mar 2015. He was the son of Julio Cenizal and Rosario Yamzon. He was married to film actor and singer Olivia Cenizal (Gloria Maigue). His mother played the violin, and she was his first music teacher. Cenizal played the banjo as his first instrument. At age eight in 1927, his mother enrolled him at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music under Francisco Santiago. He studied voice under Emilia S. Reysio-Cruz and Jose Mossesgeld Santiago-Font. He took up law at UP, while studying music at the UP Conservatory of Music. Eventually, he decided to give up law and concentrate on music. He played the banjo in the Ilaya and Ideal Orchestras, sang and playedpianoover the radio, and when he was 17, became the youngest orchestra leader of the US Army and Navy Club.

Cenizal first entered the movies as an actor, doing several pictures under Parlatone as supporting player and later as leading man. Then, the first picture he worked on as musical director was Susi ng Kalangitan (Key to Heaven), 1937. The song “Agam-Agam” (Doubts), a tango piece with Salvador R. Barros as lyricist, was composed for this film where Cenizal himself appeared. Later, he also worked for X’Otic Films, Lebran Film Productions, Nolasco Bros. Pictures, LVN Pictures, and Premiere Productions. He directed and starred in San Francisco del Monte Pictures’s Rosa Birhen (Rose Virgin), 1940, where opera singer and actress Raymonda Guidote was his leading lady.

Until the 1960s, most of his work was for the movies, many of them romantic ballads and modern jazz. The theme songs he composed for movies were “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut), 1938; “Bakit Mo Nilimot” (Why Did You Forget), 1938; “Forbidden Women,” 1948; “Kumander Sundang” (Commander Sundang), 1949; “Ang Lumang Bahay sa Gulod” (The Old House on the Hilltop), 1949; “Satur,” 1951; “Gamugamong Naging Lawin” (The Firefly That Became a Hawk), 1951; “Pangakong Puso” (Promise of Heart), 1955; “Wala Kang Kapantay” (You Have No Equal), 1960; “Krusaldo” and “Milagrosang Kamay” (Miraculous Hand), 1961; “Prinsesang Mandirigma” (Warrior Princess), 1962; “Adonis Abril” (Adonis April), 1963; and “Ilusyon” (Illusion), 2005. His best-loved compositions are “Hindi Kita Malimot” (I Cannot Forget You), which was used in a Sampaguita Pictures’s movie of the same title starring Carmen Rosales and Leopoldo Salcedo. The song was played on radio for many decades and is now considered a classic. He also composed balitaw like “Ang Paglaba” (Washing Clothes), “Masaganang Kabukiran” (Bountiful Farm), and “Amihang Bukid” (Country Breeze).

Cenizal worked with his best friend Levi Celerio whenever Cenizal needed a lyricist. They produced songs like “Araw ng Pasko” (Christmas Day) and “Paskong Walang Ikaw” (Christmas Without You). He also wrote the novelty song “Ayoko na sa ’Yo” (I Don’t Like You Anymore,) and “I’m Proud to be a Rotarian” in the 1970s. Among his other compositions in the 1970s were “Ang Pag-ibig Ko’y Ingatan Mo” (Take Care of My Love), “Ipagdiwang ang Araw ng Pasko” (Celebrate Christmas Day), “Low Waist: Cha-Cha,” “Simbang Gabi at Bagong Taon” (Dawn Mass and New Year).

In 1989, he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila, and in 2010, the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, the Dangal ng FILSCAP Award.  Written by Rolando B. Tolentino, updated by Josephine Baradas

CERA, DIEGO (Fr Diego Cera de la Virgen del Carmen) b. Graus, Aragon, Spain 26 Jul 1762. d. Quiapo, Manila 24 Jun 1832. Spanish Augustinian Recollect missionary, organist, and organ builder. Born to Joaquin Cera and Francisca Badia. Ordained priest in the Augustinian Recollect Order on 30 January 1787 in Barcelona. He is remembered as the builder of the bamboo organ at the Parish of St Joseph in Las Piñas, Metro Manila.

In 1790, three years after his ordination in Barcelona, he left Spain for Mexico with other Augustinian Recollect missionaries. He arrived in Manila on 5 June 1792. In his first year in Manila, Fr Cera constructed a piano that was regarded by then Gov-Gen Don Rafael Maria de Aguilar y Ponce de Leon and the Recollect provincial, Fr Jose de Santa Orosia, as a worthy gift to Queen Maria Luisa of Parma, the wife of King Charles IV of Spain. It was believed that no piano constructed in Spain or England at that time could match it. In 1798, Fr Cera completed a pipe organ for the San Nicolas Church of the Recollects in Intramuros, Manila. This organ had 33 stops, one of which was made of bamboo. The San Nicolas pipe organ was probably Fr Cera’s first experimentation on the durability and performance of this type of material. It was damaged in 1898 during the siege of Manila. Although restoration work was done in the early 20th century, this pipe organ and the San Nicolas Church were totally destroyed in World War II that ended in 1945. Aside from the San Nicolas pipe organ, Fr Cera also constructed the organ at the Manila Cathedral which is believed to have begun in 1802. The Manila Cathedral pipe organ suffered extensive damages during the earthquakes of 9 Nov 1828 and 16 Sep 1852. It was totally destroyed in the earthquake of 3 Jun 1863.

Fr Cera’s first assignment was in Mabalacat Parish, Pampanga in Jun 1794. On 26 Dec 1795, he left Mabalacat to assume the position of parish priest of the newly organized Recollect parish of Las Piñas, amidst the opposition of the local secular clergy. The secular priests were favored by Gov-Gen Jose Basco y Vargas to serve as parish priests of Cavite Viejo and Parañaque, to which Las Piñas belonged. Nevertheless, Fr Cera began his work as the spiritual director of Las Piñas in late 1795 until his death in 1832. His first chapel was built of bamboo and nipa in 1796, located near the seashore. It is worthy to mention that this small chapel already featured a small chorus and a small orchestra of string instruments for the accompaniment of religious services. In 1797, the site of the present church was purchased by Fr Cera at the price of 150 pesos. On this site the stone church of St Joseph was eventually constructed. In 1816, three years before the completion of the stone church, Fr Cera began assembling the now famous bamboo organ. This has a striking resemblance to the old organ built by Fr Martin Peruga in 1653 in the Cathedral of San Vicente, approximately 25 kilometers north of Graus. By 1824, the bamboo organ was completely constructed, the pipes of which were 85% made of bamboo and the rest, of metal. Fr Cera is recorded in world history as the maker of the first pipe organ made of bamboo.

Other than his duties as parish priest in Las Piñas, he was also appointed prior of Taytay in Palawan, 1805; in Baclayon, Bohol, 1815; and in Tandag, 1825. These assignments did not require residency. His last appointment was president prior of San Sebastian Convent in Manila in 1832. On 15 May 15 1832, thirteen days after his appointment, Fr Cera fell ill and resigned from his positions. He passed away at the San Sebastian Convent in Manila on 24 Jun 1832. Written by Arwin Q. Tan

Source:

Samson-Lauterwald 2006.

CHAN, JOSE MARI (Jose Mari Lim Chan) b. Iloilo City 11 Mar 1945. Singer, composer. He is the son of Antonio Chan and Florence Lim. He finished economics at the Ateneo de Manila University in 1967. He married Mary Ann Ansaldo with whom he has five children. He is a sugar trader by occupation.

Chan is one of the country’s foremost pop music songwriters. His songs were first heard in the TV teen show he hosted for ABS-CBN 2 in 1966. His first single, “Afterglow,” 1967, was a big success, a significant achievement in the Philippine pop music industry, which was dominated by foreign music at that time. His first long-playing album, released in 1969, contained another hit, which happens to be the title of the album itself, “Deep in My Heart.” His second album, Can We Just Stop and Talk a While, with the carrier single of the same title was the country’s entry in the Yamaha World Popular Song Festival held in Tokyo, Japan in 1973.

From 1970 to 1974, Chan earned a string of nominations from the Filipino AcademyofMovieArtsandSciences(FAMAS) for his original themes and scores for about 26 movies. Between 1974 to 1976, Channel 2 produced five multi-awarded TV specials that exclusively featured his music. While living in the United States from 1975 to 1986, he continued to write songs for local artists, some of which became gold records and were recorded by foreign singers. He is the first Filipino artist to be released on laser videodiscs. Following his arrival from the United States in 1986, WEA Records signed him up for the company and produced his album A Golden Collection, 1987, which eventually earned success in Indonesia by 1992. His 1989 album, ConstantChange, received a Diamond Record Award in sales, and was named Album of the Year by the 1990 Awit Awards. It contained the single, “Beautiful Girl,” named Best Produced Record of the Year. Released throughout Southeast Asia, the album enjoyed high record sales in Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Hongkong, and Japan.

His other albums include Afterthoughts, 1974; Here and Now, 1975; Deep In My Heart: The Original Release, 1989 and 1993 for the CD version; Thank You, Love, 1994; Strictly Commercial: The Jingles Collection, 1997; Souvenirs, 1998; Love Letters and Other Souvenirs, 2007; Deep In My Heart: The First Album, 2010; The Manhattan Connection, 2011; and Going Home to Christmas, 2012. Chan’s compositions were also recorded by other artists locally and internationally. He self-published Words and Music Vols. 1 and 2 in 2003 and eventually he established his own music publishing company called Signature Music Inc. in 2008.

He had performances in numerous cities around the globe such as the Carnegie Hall in New York, The Bellagio in Las Vegas, The Show Boat Casino in Atlantic City, The Silver Legacy in Reno Nevada, and other places in the United States; and in Canada, Europe, Asia, New Zealand, and Australia.

Over the last 40 years, he has won several awards, among them are: Best Musical Composition Award from the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1989 for “Please Be Careful with My Heart”; Awit Awards Best Christmas Recording and Best Album Package in 1991 for his triple platinum album, Christmas in Our Hearts, which has also received the Diamond Record Award and Double Diamond Record Award, certified by the Philippine Association of the Recording Industry (PARI). Two cuts in the 1994 album Christmas Past were recognized by Awit Awards, one is “Give Me the Old Big Bang” which was recognized as Best Jazz Recording with Vocals; and the other, “Christmas Past” with Louie Ocampo which won Best Christmas Recording. In 1997, he received the Awit Awards Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino. He won his second Album of the Year Award from Awit Awards in 2003 for the album, A Heart’s Journey. His international fame grew even more when Indonesia released his album The Ultimate Platinum Collection in 2004. As a professional music writer, he was also commissioned to compose the official song for the 2005 Southeast Asian Games, with text by Rene Nieva. Other awards given to him include the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) in 1974; Elite Platinum Award given by ABS-CBN, 2005; MYX Magna Award given by MYX Music Awards, 2010; and Dangal ng OPM given by Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit, 2011. Written byEdna Marcil M. Martinez,updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

CHING, JEFFREY b. Manila 4 Nov 1965. Composer. His parents are Alfredo Ching and Encarnacion Tong. He is married to mezzo-soprano Andión Fernandez, with whom he has two children, Jeffrey Jr and Clara. He attended Xavier School for his elementary and secondary education. He studied the piano, violin, and viola, and from around age 10 to 16, was entirely self-taught in harmony, counterpoint, and orchestration. He obtained two bachelor of arts degrees, one in music and the other in sinology, at Harvard University in 1981, where he won two John Harvard scholarships and the Detur Prize, and graduated with a double magna cum laude. He finished his bachelor of arts in philosophy at Clare College, Cambridge University in 1985, and his master of arts in philosophy and master of music in composition at the University of London in 1986 and 1989, respectively. From 1987 to 1991, he was a lecturer in music at the University of London. In 2004, Ching became a British citizen, but now resides most of the year in Berlin with his family.

Ching has more than 300 compositions to his name in different forms. His works for theater include Rendezvous in Venice, 1978, an opera buffa in two acts; two full-length ballets, La Gitana, 1982, and Camille, 1983; Rizal, 1992, a dramatic cantata with words by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco; Das Weisendkind (The Orphan), 2006-07, a multicultural music-theater in two acts which was awarded by the Theater Erfurt Audience Prize as the best opera production of its 2009-10 season; and Before Brabant, 2014, a chamber opera commissioned by the Hong Kong Arts Festival, and inspired by Robert Copland’s The Knyght of the Swanne, written in 1512.

Other works include Maria Clara, 1989, a symphonic fantasy; two a capella symphonies for voices, Autumn Sonnets, 1987, and A Shelley Ode, 1993; several orchestral overtures, including Kyrie, 1984, and Gloria, 1985, for chorus and orchestra; Musick fore Feastynge, 1993; over 70 songs for solo voice and piano, 20 of which comprise the song cycle, The Poet Pleads With the Elemental Powers (poems by Yeats), 1991; Ayres for Fallen Kings, 2009; qi-cento, 2012; 10 piano sonatas, 1982-93; Ricercar for piano solo, 1988; ‘Superklavier’ Sonata, 1992 (revised, 1998-2012); works for piano ensemble, such as Toccata for Contrappuntistica No 1 for four pianos, 1989; duos, trios, quartets, and quintets for different combinations of instruments, like Divertimento, 1989, and Alea Iacta Est, 1991; various works for chamber ensemble such as Grand Morceau Symphonique for six bassoons, 1987, and Variations and Double Fugue, An Unmusical Offering, and Essay on Bach, all in 1989; Notasparauna Cartografia de Filipinas, for piano and lap-gong, 2007; Souvenir des Tang, 1997/2009; Spohr’s Last Thoughts, 2009; Souvenir des Song, 2010; works for solo voice and chamber instruments such as Kunstkabinett, 2008, Kundimanni Schumann, 2009, Bombyx Mandarina/ Bombyx Mori, 2010, Broken Madrigals, 2011, Raven Mantra, 2012, Wesendonck Sonata, 2012, Celestial-Infernal Grand Nuptial Rite, 2014, and A Chamber Requiem, 2014; and works for solo voices and orchestra such as Berceuse, 1989, L’amour Parisien, 1991, and La Tomba di Rossini, 1992, Concerto da Camera, 2009, HorologiaSinica, 2011, and Diese So-Geliebte, 2013.

In 1990, his ballet La Gitana was performed by the Central Ballet of China in Beijing. In 1990, 1993, and 1997, he led delegations of Filipino musicians on widely acclaimed concert tours of China.

Ching wrote his first Symphony in C in 1987, followed by Symphony No 2 “The Imp of the Perverse” in 1995. He was commissioned by the Philippine government to write an orchestral work in celebration of the centennial of Philippine independence from Spain in 1998, together with four other major Filipino composers who each wrote a large work for orchestra. Ching’s contribution was his Symphony No 3 (Rituals), highlighting his widening ethnographic interests in which he fused Balinese, Chinese and Spanish elements in a work for three orchestras and a male chanter. After this compositional turning point, Ching continued to broaden his works through a more in-depth study of Eastern cultures and incorporated them as integral components of his succeeding compositions, blurring the established boundaries of East and West. In 2006, he wrote his Symphony No 4 (Souvenir des Ming) and Symphony No 5 (Kunstkammer).

His musical works have been highlighted in radio portraits on Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg (rbb) and Deutschlandfunk (DLF), and in Neue Zeitschriftfür Musik. In Nov 2013, a unique technological achievement allowed for the concert goers and radio listeners of Dessau and Magdeburg to hear the two halves of his ‘incantation’ Diese So-Geliebte as a complete score. They were played separately in Dessau and Magdeburg, and were simultaneously broadcast live by Deutschlandradio Kultur and MDR Figaro.

Ching was recognized as one of the five Outstanding Young Citizens of the Year by the President of the Philippines in 1998. He has also received the Jose Rizal Award for Excellence in the category of art, literature, and culture in 2003. Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

CITIZENS BRIGADE BAND OF DASMARIÑAS (CBBD) Dasmariñas City, Cavite. The band was established in 1989 under the Citizens’ Brigade of Dasmariñas, a nonpolitical, nonprofit organization that also supports the Dasmariñas Public Library, the Citizens Band and Music Workshop, a Livelihood Program, the Midgets Basketball Tournament, the Dasmariñas Public Market, and a Credit Cooperative. The CBBD is an example of a modern Filipino brass band. It has adopted the new tradition of Band in Parade of wearing flashy uniforms and displaying great skill and discipline as a marching band. Band membership is open to everyone, but especially to the residents of the city and its neighboring towns who have the passion and love for music.

Young musicians are trained for free in the CBBD’s annual summer music workshop. At the workshop, CBBD members teach the participants how to read music notations and symbols, and how to play an instrument. Then they are subjected to rigorous marching drills to perfect their movements. To build their stamina during long competitions, they practice at the hottest time of the day. Trained by the band’s late drum major Victor Sapida, each step and turn must be snappy and precise as in a military drill. For the competitions, each member must wear the complete uniform with hair well groomed and beard and mustache shaved. The band is well known for its elaborate and colorful costumes, which include Scottish kilts, Russian soldier uniform, and anime-inspired attire.

The CBBD provides an alternative venue for expression and recreation among the youth, sparing them from the influence of drugs and criminality. Aside from earning money from band commitments, the youth also assist other bands in organizing out of town band exhibitions. Among the towns they visited were Vigan, Laoag, La Union, Baguio, Bataan, Pampanga, Laguna, Batangas, and Romblon.

Year after year, the CBBD has been the grandslam winner in different town fiesta competitions, in Amadeo and Silang in Cavite, Pasay City, Las Piñas City, and others which were previously dominated by bands from Bacoor, Cavite. The band’s biggest award came from the First Manila Band Competition on 24 Jun 2000, a project of then Manila Mayor Lito Atienza held in celebration of Araw ng Maynila at the Quirino Grandstand. They won trophies for Best Marching Band, Best Drum Major, and Best Uniform, and were given a sum of 250,000 pesos in prizes. The CBBD has become one of the most important institutions in the city, promoting music education, discipline, good health, camaraderie, and unity among the youth. Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

THE COMPANY This is a vocal harmony group that arranges and performs a vast range of music genres including traditional choral music, pop, mainstream jazz, smooth jazz, dance, rhythm and blues (R&B), contemporary a cappella, novelty, folk, gospel, electronica, Christmas, world music, swing, bebop, musical theater, rap, and Brazilian samba. Formed in 1985, the first members of The CompanY were mostly alumni of the Ateneo College Glee Club. There were 12: Moy Ortiz, Annie Quintos, Kathleen Ng, Kelly Reyes, Tom Calisterio, Max Aviola, Bob Acot, Manny Eulalia, Joji Innocentes, Reggie Reyes, Carol Menguito, and Malou Diaz. Before collectively becoming concert and recording artists themselves, the group sang as back up vocalists for the country’s pop singers of the 1980s. Besides performing in the group, each member has continued to pursue other artistic professions: as songwriters, vocal and instrumental arrangers, concert and record producers, choreographers, stage directors, scriptwriters, voice teachers, stage actors, and workshop masters.

The CompanY has released albums under Ivory Records (1991-97), BMG Records Pilipinas (1996, 1998, 1999, 2006), and Viva Records (2001-14), completing a total of 24 albums. Moy Ortiz leads as the artistic and musical director, record producer, concert producer, songwriter, arranger, and scriptwriter for the group. Other composers that have collaborated with the group are Edith Gallardo, Trina Belamide, Babsie Molina, and Luigi de Dios.

Some of their popular hits are “Everlasting Love,” “Now That I Have You,” “Muntik na Kitang Minahal” (I Almost Loved You), and their renditions of “Suwerte-Suwerte Lang” (It’s Just Luck), “Minsan Pa” (Once More), and “Special Memory.” The group has undergone a number of personnel changes throughout the years. In 2015, The CompanY is composed of Sweet Plantado (soprano), Annie Quintos (soprano/alto), Cecile Bautista (alto), OJ Mariano (tenor), and Moy Ortiz (tenor 2/bass). Previous members include Meus Bartolome, Tetet Tolentino, Andre Castillo, Reuben Laurente, Mary Ann Morales, Febe Magbanua, and Jay Marquez.

The CompanY has received 56 music industry awards such as Album of the Year from Awit Awards for Six by 6, 1992; Catholic Mass Media Awards for Harmony, 1995; and Katha Awards for Harmony, 1996. Recognition was also given to them for Best Performance by a Group by Awit Awards, the Guillermo Mendoza Awards, and the Parangal Youth Awards, all in 1991; the International Guam Music Festival Award, 1993; Katha Music Awards, 1995 and 1996; and Star Awards for Music, 2012 and 2013.Written byCristina Maria P. Cayabyab

CONTRERAS, JOSE (Jose Bermejo Contreras) b. Roxas City 25 Nov 1937. d. 7 Jun 1994. Pianist, teacher. He was born to JoseContreras Sr and Maria Bermejo. He received his first musical training in Roxas City. Then, he studied at the Colegio del Sagrado Corazon de Jesus in Iloilo City, finishing his bachelor of music degree in piano, magna cum laude, at the age of 17. In Manila, he earned his artist’s diploma in 1957 under a LuciaFrancisco scholarship, with RegaladoJose as his mentor. He then won in a piano competition sponsored by the Italian government, and was sent to Rome for further studies. As a scholar, he attended the master classes of Carlo Zecchi and Renzo Silvestri at the Accademia Nazionale di Santa Cecilia in Rome and at the Mozarteum in Salzburg, as well as the master classes of Zecchi and Nikita Magaloff. During the first six years of his stay in Europe, Contreras won twice in the Viotti International Piano Competition, fourth place in 1960 and second place in 1962 in the Alfredo Casella International Piano Competition, and second place in 1963 in the Ferruccio Busoni International Piano Competition. From then on, he became a familiar name in the concert halls on the continent.

In 1966, he earned his master of music degree with the highest average at the Juilliard School of Music in New York under Rosina Lhevine. He was also a grantee of the MusicPromotionFoundationofthePhilippines in 1958-66.

Returning to Europe from New York, Contreras resumed his concertizing, as soloist with the Orchestra dell’ Accademia di Santa Cecilia at the Auditorium in Via Conciliazione and at the Basilica di Massenzio, as well as with the orchestras of Teatro San Carlos in Naples; AIDEM Orchestra of Florence; Symphony Ochestra of Verona; Comunale Orchestra of Bologna; Sicilian Symphony Orchestra of Palermo; Wiener Kammerorchester of Vienna; Italian Radio Orchestras of Rome, Naples, Milano, and Torino; Irish Radio and Television Orchestra of Dublin; Romanian Radio and Television Orchestra of Bucharest; the Philharmonia Orchestra of Sofia in Bulgaria, Bratislava in Czechoslovakia, and Zagreb in Yugoslavia. He has also given recitals at the Sala di Via dei Greci as well as in other parts of Italy, in Austria, Ireland, Switzerland, France, and Greece. He has also performed at the Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center, New York. He taught piano and piano literature at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music from 1983 to 1989. His students at UP included Noel Arce, Mark Carpio, Jonathan Velasco, Artemio Panganiban III, and Allier Manahan. Before his sudden death in 1994, he was artist-in-residence of the St Scholastica’s College Music Department.Written byA.C. de los Reyes,updated by Yvette Andaya

CORNEJO, RODOLFO S. (Rodolfo Soldevilla Cornejo) b. Manila 15 May 1909 d. Manila 11 Aug 1991. Composer, pianist, conductor. He was the son of Miguel Cornejo Sr and Crisanta Soldevilla. In 1949, Cornejo married Nieves Guerrero, a lyric soprano. They had five children. At age six, Cornejo started piano lessons with Gelacio Reyes. At eight, he had his first recital and became the organist of the Pasay Catholic Church. He wrote his first composition, “Glissando Waltz,” at age 10. At 13, he wrote and published a military march, “Salute,” dedicated to Leonard Wood. By the time he turned sixteen, 26 of his works had been listed by the United Publishing Co. While finishing his high school, he was already enrolled at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music where he studied with Francisco Santiago, Nicanor Abelardo, and Alexander Lippay. In 1930, barely three years after completing high school, he obtained teacher’s diplomas in piano, and science and composition. He taught for a year at UP, then left for the United States. He won 400 dollars in a piano contest even before he could enroll at the Chicago Musical College of Roosevelt University where he acquired a bachelor’s degree in piano and theory in 1932.

Winning the Wesley Le Violette scholarship in composition at the same school, he went on to complete his master’s degree in 1933. He studied with Rudolf Ganz and Glenn Dillard Gunn. Cornejo returned to the Philippines in 1934. He then founded and directed the Manila Conservatory of Music. In 1939, he left for the United States to pursue doctorate studies in composition. While he was on the faculty of the Chicago Musical College, he studied with Leonard Rogers and Howard Hanson at the Eastman School of Music of the University of Rochester in New York, and with Victorio Giannini at Julliard. He earned his doctorate degree in 1947 from Neotarian College in Kansas City, USA. During his US sojourns, Cornejo was a soloist with the New York City Symphony Orchestra, National Orchestra Association, Rochester Civic Orchestra, CBS Orchestra, and CMC Orchestra. During World War II, he played at concerts for the Allied Armed Forces. In 1941, he became researcher and official composer of the Philippine government-in-exile. In 1954, he received an honorary doctorate in music from the Chicago Musical College. Back in the Philippines, Cornejo became director of Cosmopolitan Colleges Conservatory of Music from 1948 to 1949. He concertized and wrote the scores for 27 films during his 10 years as musical director for Sampaguita Pictures. A founding member of the League of Filipino Composers, he served as presidential technical adviser on cultural matters from 1958 to 1960 and protocol officer of Manila from 1967 to 1975.

He has over 300 compositions that range from classical to popular. Among his major works are The Seasons-Song Cycle, 1932; A la Juventud Filipina (To the Filipino Youth), 1935; Philippine Symphony No 1, 1939, No 2, 1942, and No 3, 1947, all for piano solo; Oriental Fantasy, 1944; and Philippine Fantasy with Marimba Solo, 1962. He also wrote the music for the ballets Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1970, and Baile de Ayer (Dance of Yesteryears), 1974; the cantata Christ the Redeemer for soloists, narrator, mixed chorus, and orchestra, which premiered at the Philamlife Auditorium in 1977; and the musical A Glimpse of Philippine Life and Culture which premiered at the Seattle Opera House in 1978.

He is listed in the International Who’s Who in Music. On his birth centenary in 2009, the Philippine Postal Corporation issued stamps showing Cornejo’s portrait with a music sheet in the background. On his 102nd birth anniversary in May 2011, a tribute concert titled Pamana (Legacy) was held in his honor at the UP Abelardo Hall. Members of the UP Alumni Music Association performed his works consisting of his Third Piano Concerto, his piano, song, ballet, and marimba pieces. Written byJulie Anne Hallazgo,updated by Connie Ladrido

CORRALES, PILITA (Pilar Garrido Corrales) b. Manila 22 Aug 1939. Singer. Born to Jose Corrales, plant manager of a brewery, and Maria Garrido. Corrales has two children: Ramon Christopher and Jackielou Blanco, both of whom also entered show business. She grew up in Cebu and attended the Colegio de la Inmaculada Concepcion. Later she studied at St Theresa’s College in Baguio and enrolled in a finishing school in Madrid, Spain.

When she returned from Spain, Corrales embarked on a career in entertainment. For a year and a half, she ran the program La Taverna over DZPI, where she sang Spanish songs and played the guitar. She also appeared in stage shows at the ManilaGrandOperaHouse and sang professionally in the Philippines and abroad. She has performed with internationally known artists: as the front act in the concerts of Sammy Davis Jr in Las Vegas and the Philippines, and of the Beatles at the Rizal Memorial Stadium in 1966, and as guest in the live shows of Bob Hope, Pat Boone, Frank Sinatra, and Julie Andrews.

In the movies, her first lead role was in Miss Wawaw, 1968. In the next two years, she starred in 11 movies, many of them musicals, under SampaguitaPictures and LeaProductions. Many decades later, she did supporting roles in movies such as I Will Survive, 2004, a comedy-drama musical, and Bride for Rent, 2014, romantic comedy.

Corrales has recorded for VillarRecords, Dyna Records, and Vicor Records, and has four gold records to her name: KapantayayLangit (As High as the Sky), Pipit, Sampaguita Movie Songs, and Philippine Love Songs Vols. I and II.

She was active in television with her shows Ang Bagong Kampeon (The New Champion) on RPN 9, an amateur singing contest which she co-hosted with Bert Marcelo; Tanghalan ng Kampeon (Stage of the Champion) on GMA 7, the same contest also with Bert Marcelo; Mag-asawa’y di Biro (Marriage is No Joke) on RPN 9, a situational comedy or sit-com; Awitawanan (Songs and Laughter) on IBC 13, a musical comedy show which she co-hosted with the Reycard Duet; Lagot Ka… Isusumbong Kita (You’re Busted… I Will Tell On You) on GMA 7, also a sit-com; and My Driver Sweet Lover, on TV5, a light drama series. Her most recent TV show was The X Factor Philippines, on ABS-CBN, a reality-TV music game show, where she was one of the judges along with Martin Nievera and Charice Pempengco.

Corrales has continued to perform in concerts and shows such as The New Minstrel Divos, Feb 2015, Fernbrook, Las Piñas, and Harana sa Dapithapon (Serenade at Dusk), Jul 2015, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Main Theater lobby. She has also been visible in performing for causes such as Voices for Visayas, in 15 Jan 2014, a fund-raising concert for the victims of typhoon Yolanda, held at the Newport Performing Arts Theater, Resorts World Manila; and Duets: A Million Thanks, in 13 Nov 2014, a dinner concert with special guest artists, held at the Fiesta Pavillion, Manila Hotel.

She won the Citizen’s Award for Television as Best TV Female Performer in 1965. Her television show, Your Evening with Pilita, was adjudged Best Musical TV Show by the Citizen’s Council for Mass Media (CCMM) in 1965, 1966, 1968, and 1969. In 1990 she received a Merit award from the FilipinoAcademy ofMovie Arts and Sciences(FAMAS), and in 1991, the PhilippineAssociation ofthe Record Industry (PARI) Lifetime Achievement Award, particularly for bringing Filipino musical artistry to audiences abroad. In 1997, “Matud Nila” (So They Say), her duet with Elmo Makil, won the Awit Awards Best Traditional Recording, while “Usahay,” another duet with Chad Borja, won Best Regional Recording in 2015. Written byErlinda Alburo,with notes from James C. Diaz

COYIUTO, CRISTINE (Cristine Lim Coyiuto) b. Davao City 21 Jan 1954. Daughter of Tomas and Marcelina Lim, Cristine is married to James Coyiuto and has a daughter, Caitlin Alisa, a flautist. She started learning the piano from her mother at age three and, a year later, had teacher Nelly Castro Domingo. She gave her first solo piano recital at age nine and continued her study with Benjamin Tupas and Rosario Picazo. She earned her bachelor of music in music education, cum laude, in 1973; and piano performance, magna cum laude, in 1974 from the Santa Isabel College.

She won first prize in the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) Young Artists’ Competition in 1973 and played her winning rendition of Chopin’s Piano Concerto in E minor with Regalado Jose conducting the MSO.

Coyiuto received her master of music degree in 1977 from the Juilliard School, where she was awarded a teaching fellowship. At Juilliard, she studied piano with Jacob Lateiner, and chamber music with William Lincer and Samuel Sanders. She furthered her studies with Philippe Entremont as a lauréate at the Académie International de Musique “Maurice Ravel” in France in 1976 and with Nikita Magaloff at the Genève Conservatoire in Switzerland in 1983. She was also awarded several Canada Council grants to study with Ruth Slenczynska in Illinois in 1980; Fou Ts’ong in London, England in 1983 and 1984; and Gaby Casadesus in Paris, France in 1984.

As a winner of the 1979 Canadian Broadcasting Corporation National Audition, she was featured in the First Young Artists’ Recital Series, which was broadcast live across Canada on CBC. She had subsequent performance tours in London and Paris in 1983. She gave a piano recital at the Okanagan Music Festival premiering new works by noted Canadian composers Sylvia Rickard, Jean Ethridge, Roger Knox, and David Gordon Duke. She also commissioned a new work by Jean Coulthard titled “Image Astrale” for solo piano in 1981. In 1983, Coyiuto opened the Filipino-Russian Festival Concerts performing Prokofiev Concerto No 3 and Rachmaninov Concerto No 2 with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, under the baton of Francisco Feliciano. Her playing earned a critical rave from Vilma Felipe-Santiago of Bulletin Today.

She has performed chamber music with violist Robert Verebes of the Bartok String Quartet, violinist Gil Morgenstern, flutists Robert Aitken and Yuko Enomoto, soprano Lani Misenas, cellist Ann Alton, and violinist Michael Emery. Jess Q. Cruz, Rosalinda L. Orosa, and Celine V. Pil hailed her “Poetess of the Piano,” “The Pianists’ Pianist,” and “The Clara Schumann of the Philippines,” respectively.

She was given the Outstanding Pianist Award by the Santa Isabel College Music Department in celebration of its Diamond Jubilee on 26 Jan 2006 held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo.

In 2007, Coyiuto appeared with her daughter and their collaborative playing earned them a critical rave from music critic Antonio C. Hila. She has given recitals at the CCP, 2003, 2005, and 2006-07; Francisco Santiago Hall, 2008-10; Luce Auditorium in Silliman University, 2003, 2007, 2009, and 2012-13; and Audi Showroom, 2009 and 2012.

She was the soloist of the Manila Symphony Orchestra in 2007 with Helen Quach as conductor, performing the Grieg and Schumann Piano Concertos at the CCP, St Scholastica’s College, La Salle Auditorium in Bacolod, Silliman University in Dumaguete City, and in Meralco Theater, Manila. Abroad, she has given recitals in the United States, Canada, United Kingdom, France, Switzerland, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong in 1980 and 1984; and appeared as a soloist with the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra, Vancouver Chamber Orchestra, New Westminster Orchestra, Orchestre du Capitole de Toulouse, Singapore Symphony Orchestra, Braddell Heights Symphony Orchestra, Lake Placid Sinfonietta, Manila Chamber Orchestra, Manila Symphony Orchestra, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 1983 and 2004; and Metro Manila Concert Orchestra in 2005, 2009, and 2011-13.

She has been heard on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Singapore Broadcasting, CFRO Vancouver, Radio Hong Kong, Radio Taiwan and DZFE Manila. Written byAntonio C. Hila

CRISOLOGO, ERNESTINA (Ernestina Lim Crisologo-Jose) b. Manila 19 Nov 1928. d. 3 Feb 2013. Pianist, marimbist, teacher. She was the only concert pianist and marimbist the country has ever had to this date. Her first teacher in piano was her mother, Adela Lim, wife of the noted orchestra leader, Serafin Payawal, who taught her the rudiments of piano playing at age three. She married Eduardo Jose, a lawyer, with whom she had two children, Eduardo Jr and Carolina. At age five, Ernestina was already being taught by Francisco Buencamino who was her mentor for five years. She started learning marimba at age eight and eventually had a degree under the tutelage of Philip Kraus. In 1929, at age 10, she won a national piano competition held at the Avenue Theater. And at age 12, she had her piano debut recital presented by A. Lozano.

She studied with Bernardino F. Custodio, and earned her teacher’s diploma in piano from Centro Escolar University (CEU) in 1946. She went to the Juilliard School of Music in New York for her bachelor of music and master of music degrees in piano, from 1947 to 1950. She was a scholar all throughout her stay in Juilliard, competing for it every year. She was also the first Filipina to receive a scholarship grant and the first Filipino to be conferred a post-graduate degree from that institution. She studied with Olga Samaroff Stokowski, Katherine Bacon, Arthur Newstead, and Leonid Hambro. She also went to France for master classes under Robert Casadesus. She studied marimba with Maurice Goldenberg, Philip Kraus, Yoichi Hiraoka, and Vida Scenoweth. She was the first Filipina pianist to perform at Carnegie Hall in New York in 1949, playing Schumann’s Piano Concerto in A minor with Richard Horn conducting the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. Since then she has concertized in Europe, the United States, and the Philippines.

Crisologo has introduced concertos which were hitherto unheard of, such as Piano Concerto in B major by Henry Holden Huss performed at the University of Santo Tomas Gymnasium in 1946 during her graduation recital, with Bernardino F. Custodio conducting the Manila Symphony Orchestra; Gershwin’s Rhapsody in Blue in the same venue in the same year, with the same conductor and orchestra; Ravel’s Concerto for the Left Hand, in the same venue in 1950, with Luis Valencia conducting the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra; and Rodolfo S. Cornejo’s Philippine Fantasy with marimba solo which she premiered in 1963 at the Philamlife Auditorium. In 2000, she held a performance for charity at the Philamlife Theater titled Play it Again, Ma’am which became sentimental because it fulfilled her mother’s dying wish that she perform back on stage.

She was on the faculty of Centro Escolar University, 1952-57; St Paul College, 1959-90; Santa Isabel College in the 1960s; and the Philippine High School for the Arts, 1979-83. She also served as consultant for Tourism and Cultural Affairs of the Manila City Hall as well as Quezon City Hall at the latter part of 1990.

Crisologo was given the award Pianist of the Year by the Manila Music Lovers Society in 1951; Golden Jubilee Award Medal from CEU in 1958. She received the Lifetime Achievement Award: A Salute to Women in the Arts and Heritage Preservation during the term of office of former Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo; and several certificates of appreciation from different associations/organizations.Written byCollie de los Reyes,updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

CRUZ, JOVIANNEY EMMANUEL (Jovianney Emmanuel Villanueva Cruz) aka John-Em Cruz. b. Manila 8 Aug 1966. Pianist. He is the youngest of 10 children of Delfin Rivera Cruz and Lourdes Villanueva. He began his piano studies at age three with his mother and continued them with other distinguished teachers in Manila, such as BenjaminTupas, Ernesto Lejano, ReynaldoReyes, and ManuelP.Maramba,OSB. At age six, he was invited to perform at the MalacañanPalace, and at age 10, he made his orchestra debut with the PhilippineYouthOrchestra after winning first prize in the National Music CompetitionsforYoungArtists. The Young Artists Foundation of the Philippines granted him a scholarship for piano studies abroad, first at the Chetham’s School of Music in Manchester, England, and at the Manhattan School of Music in New York where he was a pupil of the eminent piano pedagogue Solomon Mikowsky.

At the Manhattan School of Music, Cruz was a winner of both the Preparatory and College Divisions Concerto Competitions and a recipient of the Stanley Thomas Johnson Foundation, the Elva Van Gelder, and the Anne-Marie McDermott Memorial Scholarships. He took master classes under world-renowned pianists such as John Browning, Gary Graffman, Jan Gorbaty, Alexander Jenner, Lev Vlasenko, and Byron Janis, among others. He received his bachelor and master of music degrees in piano performance, and was awarded the Harold Bauer Award, the most coveted recognition given to a pianist with the highest honors at the Manhattan School of Music.

He has performed as soloist with the Manila


SymphonyOrchestra, Manhattan Philharmonia, Queens Symphony, Bergen Philharmonic, Maracaibo Symphony, Orquesta Municipal de Valencia, Philarmonic Orchestra of the State of Oradea, and several times with the Philippines


PhilharmonicOrchestra. He has collaborated with conductors such as Piero Gamba, Romica Rimbu, David Gilbert, Eduardo Rahn, Manule Galduf, Arthur Cohn, Pedro Calderon, and David Katz. As a chamber musician, Cruz has worked with the UP String Quartet, MSM String Quartet, Atheneaum String Quartet, and Takacs String Quartet. He has performed in the Canary Islands, England, Germany, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Singapore, Switzerland, Venezuela, and throughout Spain, the United States, and the Philippines. Cruz also performed for fund-raising concerts. Some of the recipients are: Cultural Center of the Philippines’ Young Artists Fund, Down Syndrome’s Association of the Philippines, Southeast Asian Institue for the Deaf, CRIBS Philippines, Inc., and Gawad Kalinga Smokey Mountain.

Cruz served as a member of the Piano Faculty at the University of the Philippines College of Music, as associate professor from 1991 to 2007, and as professorial lecturer from 2007 to 2011. He also did consultancies for the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), St Paul’s University Manila, Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila (PLM), and Sekolah Musik Yayasan Pendidikan Musik, in Jakarta, Indonesia. He is the founder, chairman, and artistic director of the Camerata dell’Arte Foundation, a creative body whose goal is to aid in making the Philippines the cultural center of Asia by establishing a privately run Endowment Fund for the Arts. He also organized the OPUSFEST 2006: The International Piano Festival Philippines; The Ultimate Pianist Competion, 2006 and 2008; OPUSFEST: The International Piano and Chamber Music Festival Philippines 2008; OPUSFEST CEBU 2010: The International Piano Festival; and Outlook Pointe Foundation’s Sulong Sining Trilogy, 2010-12, in Insular Life Theater.

Cruz was a prizewinner in the Jose Iturbi, Pilar Bayona, and Jaen International Piano Competitions in Spain, the Concurs Internacional Maria Canals de Barcelona, Frinna Awerbuch International Piano in New York, the Rina Sala Gallo International Piano Competition in Milan, and the International Competition for Piano and Orchestra in Sicily. He has also won first prize in the Bergen Symphony Soloists Competition, the New York State Music Teachers Association, and the Five Towns, Great Neck, and Port Washington Piano Competitions. He also received The Harold Bauer Award, the most coveted recognition given to a pianist with the highest honors at the Manhattan School of Music, 1989; The Outstanding Young Men (TOYM), 1996; The Filipino World Class Achiever, 1999; and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan, 2008. Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by James C. Diaz

CRUZ, WILLY (Wilfredo Buencamino Cruz)b. San Miguel, Manila 30 Jan 1947. d. Quezon City 16 Apr 2017. Composer, musical director, pianist. He was born to Daniel Cruz, a lawyer, and Narcisa Buencamino, a cashier at LVN Pictures. His musical talent comes from the Buencamino side: his maternal great grandfather, Fortunato, was a sarsuwela composer and choirmaster of San Miguel, Bulacan, and his grandmother, Marcelina, was a sarsuwela singer. His great grand uncle was composer Francisco Buencamino. His cousins are pianist Cecile Licad, composers Lorrie Ilustre and Nonong Buencamino, and actor Nonie Buencamino. It was under Licad’s mother, Rosario Buencamino, that he began his training in piano techniques and the discipline of classical music. When he was seven, he composed a piece for the piano. He also trained under Marcelino Carluen, who widened his musical horizons to include jazz and pop.

At the Ateneo de Manila University where he finished his elementary and high school education as well as his bachelor’s degree in 1968, Cruz was conductor and president of the Ateneo Glee Club. It was during these years that he discovered he was not cut out to be a classical concert artist and found himself increasingly involved in popular music. Cruz became one of the founders and served as musical director of the Ambivalent Crowd, a group which first performed at weddings, then moved on to the concert stage.

In the early 1970s, Cruz composed and arranged jingles for commercials, scored for films, and was musical director for the sarsuwela, Ang Kiri (The Flirt). Then, in 1975, he composed “Araw-Araw, Gabi-Gabi” (Day by Day, Night by Night) which won first prize at the World Popular Song Festival and sold close to 100,000 records. It also won in the best theme song category of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1975. He began writing lyrics in 1976, translating and adapting foreign songs, which were released by Jem Records, where he was president and general manager, 1976-79.

Cruz scored and arranged for more than 100 films. He briefly returned to his classical roots by composing his first symphonic work, Freedom in One Movement, for the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). In 1992, he had his own concert at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) with the PPO and Sharon Cuneta.

In 1981, Cruz scored his biggest hit with “Never Ever Say Goodbye,” which also launched Nonoy Zuñiga as a top recording and performing artist. The subsequent album, which featured six other songs composed by Cruz, won three Cecil Awards in 1982: Album of the Year, Record of the Year, and Best Arrangement.

Some of his songs for the movies have won the following awards: Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) Award for “Kung Mahawi man ang Ulap” (When the Clouds are Gone), 1984; FAMAS and FAP, 1985, and Star Awards, 1986, for “Bituing Walang Ningning” (Star Without Luster); FAMAS and FAP Awards for “Sana’y Wala nang Wakas” (Wishing it Would Never End), 1986; FAP Award for “Maging Akin Lamang” (Just to Have You), 1987; FAMAS Award for “Pahiram ng Isang Umaga” (Lend Me One Morning), 1988; FAP Awards for “Oras-oras, Araw-araw” (Every Hour, Every Day), 1989, and “Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Kita?” (Is it a Sin to Worship You?), 1990; and Star Award for “Himala ng Pag-ibig” (Miracle of Love), 1992.

As a film musical scorer, he has won the following awards: FAMAS Award for Bukas Luluhod ang mga Tala (Tomorrow the Stars Will Fall on Their Knees), 1984, and Bituing Walang Ningning, 1985; FAP Awards for Baby Tsina (China Babe), 1984, and Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas, 1986; FAMAS Award for Balweg the Rebel Priest, 1987; FAP Award for Pinulot Ka Lang sa Lupa (You Were Only Picked Up From the Earth); FAMAS, 1988, and Star Awards, 1989, for Nagbabagang Luha (Blazing Tears); FAMAS, 1989, and Star Awards, 1990, for Pahiram ng Isang Umaga; and FAP Award for Oras-oras, Araw-araw, 1989. He also won three Awit Awards for musical scoring, Best Television Special award from the Pambansang Akademyang Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining (PATAS), and a niche in the FAMAS Hall of Fame for garnering five awards for musical scoring.

In 2002, Cruz recorded a new solo instrumental album titled, Got To Believe in Magic, which is a collection of romantic songs locally and internationally known. The Willy Cruz Piano Silver Series was released in 2006 by Viva Records, with Cruz performing on piano the hit songs, “Walang Kapalit” (Equal to None), “Forevermore,” “Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw” (You Are What I Need), “Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang?” (Why Have You Come Only Now?), “Pangako” (Promise), “Sana’y Maghintay Ang Walang Hanggan” (May Eternity Wait), “Kung Mawawala Ka” (If You Will Be Gone), “Dadalhin” (Let Me Bring You), “Kahit Na” (Even If), “Can We Just Stop and Talk A While,” “Pangako Sa’Yo” (I Promise You), and “Kailangan Kita” (I Need You). In 2015, his songs that became famous in the 1980s were used to create a musical titled, Bituing Walang Ningning, presented by Resorts World Manila, VIVA Communications, and Full House Theater Company and Ultimate Productions. Written byMilagros Carunungan,updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab
Cubero, Alejandro (See THEATER volume.)

Ernani Cuenco (Ernani Joson Cuenco Sr) was a music composer, teacher, and a National Artist for music. He was born in Malolos, Bulacan on 10 May 1936. He died in Mandaluyong, Metro Manila on 11 Jun 1988. The son of Felix Cuenco and Maria Joson, he was married to Magdalena Marcial, also a musician, with whom he had two children. His son, Ernani Jr aka Jong, is also a musician and a film and television actor. Cuenco started taking piano and violin lessons at six. While in high school at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), he took up piano with Julio Esteban Anguita, and violin with Ramon Mendoza at the UST Conservatory of Music. He completed a music degree in piano and cello from the UST and a master’s degree in music education from Santa Isabel College.

A seasoned performer, Cuenco played with the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra and the Manila Symphony Orchestra from 1960 to 1968, and the Manila Chamber Soloists from 1966 to 1970 organized by Oscar C. Yatco and Basilio C. Manalo. In 1983 and 1987, he toured the United States with other Filipino performers and artists including the Kayumangging Kaligatan, a choral group he founded in 1982.

Cuenco was at one time or another on the faculty of the music departments of several major schools and colleges in Manila including the UST Conservatory of Music, where he taught for decades. He also helped initiate the annual Sampung Daliri (Ten Fingers) concert of the UST Conservatory of Music, featuring their piano faculty, alumni, and students.

He wrote award-winning musical scores for Filipino films. His first commission came in the early 1960s, for movie producer Joseph Estrada. For the next two decades, he continued scoring for numerous films and writing some of the most memorable songs, often in collaboration with lyricist Levi Celerio. His works include Diligin Mo ng Hamog ang Uhaw na Lupa (Sprinkle Dew on the Parched Land), 1975, and Bakya Mo, Neneng (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), 1977, both awardees of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for Best Musical Score; "Bato sa Buhangin" (Stone in the Sand), 1976, FAMAS Awardee for Best Theme Song, 1976; Ang Babaing Pinagtaksilan ng Panahon (A Woman Betrayed by Time), Gawad Urian for Best Music, 1980; and Pedrong Taruc,1982, and Isang Bala Ka Lang (You’re Only Worth a Bullet), 1983, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP) awardees for Best Musical Score. His greatest hit, “Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal” (How Much Do I Love You), 1979, shows how Cuenco enriched the Filipino love ballad by infusing it with elements of the classic kundiman. His song “Kahit na Magtiis” (As I Endure) with words by Joseph Ejercito Estrada became a hit when the latter assumed the Philippine presidency in 1998. Its revival by the Philippine Madrigal Singers with an arrangement by Christopher Borela lent prestige to the composition, and was included in the choir’s live concert recording of their international tour of 2000, titled Around the World in 2001. Another recent recording of his music is Renato Lucas and Raul Sunico’s rendition of his love song, “Nahan” (Where?) in the album Romanza, released by Tawid Publications in 2004.

Cuenco was posthumously conferred the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts, and the National Artist award in 1999.  Written by Julie Ann Hallazgo, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) is the leading institution in the country that plans and implements programs for the development and promotion of the arts—music, dance, theater, visual, literary, cinematic, and broadcast arts. Since 1969 when it was created by Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos, it has sponsored programs and activities such as festivals, exhibitions, competitions, and publications to preserve, promote, and enhance the artistic and cultural heritage of the Filipino people, and to develop audiences that will appreciate and support artistic and cultural work. It is home to nine resident companies that present regular seasons of productions, workshops, and outreach performances: Ballet Philippines, Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, Philippine Ballet Theatre, Philippine Madrigal Singers, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Tanghalang Pilipino, and UST Symphony Orchestra.

Sitting on a 60-hectare complex on Roxas Boulevard in Pasay City, the CCP is part of a vast international network of arts and culture organizations that provide exchange opportunities between Filipino artists and artists from all over the world. This network also brings in performances and exhibitions that allow local audiences to experience arts and cultures from elsewhere.
