These organizations include the Association of Asia Pacific Performing Arts Center, the Conseil International des Organisations de Festivals de Folklore et d’Arts Traditionnels, the World Dance Alliance, the International Theater Institute, the Asian Theater Alliance, the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, and the ASEAN–Korea Traditional Music Orchestra.

The CCP is composed of several departments that promote arts education, direct outreach and exchange programs all over the country, mount productions and exhibitions, manage cultural holdings, and develop its assets. In its first two decades the CCP focused on what were later perceived as elitist performing arts—theater, ballet, opera, and similar shows—a bias that was shaped by its first board of trustees chair, then First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos. Following the successful EDSA revolt against Marcos and his martial rule and the subsequent change in the country’s leadership, the CCP expanded its scope to include literature, film, and broadcast arts, among others. It also reoriented its direction to emphasize original Filipino artistic and cultural expressions rooted in the Philippines and the participation of the regions in the definition of a national culture.

Music. The CCP is home to the country’s premier symphonic orchestra, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). Established in 1973, the PPO (then known as the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra) initially accompanied local and foreign performing artists at the CCP. It later evolved as one of the best music ensembles in the Asia-Pacific region, premiering works by Filipino and foreign composers, and promoting music appreciation throughout the country. Past conductors and musical directors of the PPO include Luis Valencia, Oscar Yatco, Ruggero Barbieri, Olivier Ochanine, and Yoshikazu Fukumura.Among the internationally renowned conductors who have performed with the PPO are Mendi Rodan, Piero Gamba, Enrique Batis, Sebastian Bereau, and Nicholas Koch. Some of the world’s best Filipino and foreign artists have also performed with the PPO, including Van Cliburn, Renata Tebaldi, Judith Engel, Anthony Camden, David Benoit, Cecile Licad, Raul Sunico, and Lea Salonga. The PPO is now on its 34th concert season. It has toured in Europe, Asia, and more recently, the United States, when it performed for the first time at the Carnegie Hall. Aside from its regular concert seasons at the CCP, the PPO also participates in the CCP Outreach Program by performing in public spaces and conducting workshops in the provinces.

Another resident company of the CCP is the Philippine Madrigal Singers. Organized in 1963 by Andrea O. Veneracion, later National Artist for music, the choir is composed of students, teachers, and alumni from the various colleges of the University of the Philippines. Performing a wide repertoire of various styles and forms, the ensemble has consistently won all the top prizes in most of the world’s prestigious choral competitions. The choir also maintains an active outreach and concert schedule every year and is regarded as one of the country’s most active ambassadors of goodwill and one of the world’s most traveled choirs.

The UST Symphony Orchestra is also a resident performing group of the CCP. It holds regular concerts at the CCP and participates in the CCP Outreach and Exchange Program. It also serves as a pool for additional players as the needs of the PPO dictate.

In 1987, the CCP launched the Filipino Artists Series (FAS), a monthly program featuring solo performances of acclaimed and emerging Filipino musical artists. Among those featured in the FAS were bass baritone Jonathan Zaens; flutist Antonio Maigue; cellist Wilfredo Pasamba; pianists Corazon Kabayao, Mariel Illusorio, Peter Porticos, and Rene Dalandan; violinists Gilopez Kabayao, Gina Medina, and Denise Huang; and sopranos Clarissa Ocampo and Maria Cristina Viguilla-Navarro. FAS was discontinued in 2009 but was later revived in 2012 as the Special Concert Series. Some of the performing artists in this series are pianist Charisse Baldoria, soprano Katrina Saporsantos, cellist Antoni Josef Inacay, trumpet player Raymond de Leon, percussionist Aimee Mina dela Cruz, and flutist Sarah Mae Gabuyo.

The CCP also embarked on the production of Filipino operas as well as Western operas that were adapted to a Philippine setting. In 1970, it partnered with the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines in producing El Filibusterismo (Subversion), the operatic adaptation of Jose Rizal’s novel, with music by Felipe Padilla de Leon and libretto by Guillermo Tolentino. De Leon and Tolentino’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), first staged at the FEU Auditorium in 1957, was also restaged at the CCP in 1974, with Don David as Ibarra, Ruby Salazar as Maria Clara, Jimmy Melendres as Padre Damaso, and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa. In 1984, the CCP and Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines commissioned Francisco Feliciano to create the three-act opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), with libretto by Cuyugan-Asensio. In 1987, the CCP partnered with Music Theater Foundation in another restaging of Noli… this time with Nolyn Cabahug as Ibarra, Andion Fernandez as Maria Clara, and Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa (alternating with Luz Morete). Rolando Tinio’s Philippine adaptation of La Traviata and La Boheme were also produced by and staged at the CCP in 1991 and 1992, respectively. Two major opera productions of the CCP in the 21st century were Spoliarium , 2003, and Madame Butterfly, 2012. Spoliarium was inspired by Juan Luna ’s life and masterpiece, with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, and co-produced by the CCP with the Opera Guild of the Philippines and Music Theater Foundation of the Philippines. Madame Butterfly was a co-production of the CCP and MusicArtes, Inc, with director Anton Juan giving local flavor to Puccini’s famous opera.

The CCP is also the organizer and main proponent of major music festivals including the biennial Andrea Veneracion International Choral Festival and the CCP International Jazz Festival which was merged with the Orchestra and Symphonic Band Festival, and the annual Flute/Woodwind Festival. It has also been actively supporting the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) since its inception in 1973. The CCP Arts Education Department also organizes masterclasses of renowned musical artists as well as yearly workshops in rondalla music, choral music, and band music.

Dance. The CCP has four resident dance companies: Ballet Philippines (BP), which is based at the CCP Main Building, and Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFC) which are all based outside the CCP.

Since its founding in 1969, BP has performed over 400 works at the CCP, ranging from full-length classical ballets to modern dance and neo-ethnic pieces, under its founding artistic director Alice Reyes, later National Artist for Dance, and after her, Denisa Reyes, Cecile Sicangco, Noordin Jumalon, Alden Lugnasin, Augustus Damian III, Alan Hineline, Max Luna III, and Paul Morales. The company has also collaborated with prominent foreign and local choreographers, dancers, librettists, actors, and set, costume, and lighting designers. Notable productions of BP include Amada, Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), Rama, Hari, Tales of the Manuvu, Te Deum, For the Gods, Encantada (Enchantress), and La Revolucion Filipina (The Filipino Revolution). It has also produced some of the country’s top ballet dancers who have undergone training at BP’s official school, the CCP Dance School. BP also stages the yearly Neo-Filipino, a dance showcase featuring the latest works of the best and leading choreographers in the country.

Founded in 1987 by artistic directors of different ballet companies, PBT has become one of the country’s leading dance companies specializing in classical ballet. PBT’s regular performance season at the CCP consists of such classics as Romeo and Juliet , Carmen, The Nutcracker, Cinderella, Carmina Burana, and Swan Lake. PBT has been managed by a series of artistic directors, all belonging to the PBT Council, namely, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Julie Borromeo, Eddie Elejar, Gener Caringal, and Ronilo Jaynario.

The Bayanihan, under choreographer Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, later National Artist for Dance, and later, under executive director Susie Benitez and dance director-choreographer Ferdinand Jose, and the ROFG under artistic director Ramon Obusan, later National Artist for dance, and later, under Dulce Obusan, have been acclaimed nationally and worldwide for their continuing efforts to research, perform, preserve, and perpetuate Philippine folk music and dance traditions. Both companies participate in CCP’s outreach programs by conducting folk dance workshops around the country.

Dance-related festivals organized or initiated by the CCP include the Pang-alay, which featured different Philippine folk dance groups; the Fiesta Folkloriada, an annual festival of folk dance groups all over the world where the Bayanihan is an active participant; the biennial CCP Ballet Festival where various ballet schools in the country gather and perform classical, modern, and neo-ethnic works; and Dance.MNL: The Philippine Dance Festival which was held for the first time in 2016. Dance.MNL is also intended to be a biennial festival which aims to unite and celebrate the Filipino dance community.

The CCP has also given grants or financial assistance to local dance groups which represented the Philippines in international competitions or festivals. Among the grantees were the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, the Dureza Ballet School, Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance, and St Anne’s Dance and Music Studio in 1988; Dance Theater Philippines, Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, Ben-Lor Ballet Academy, St Anne Dance Theater Company (Taguig), La Salle Dance Troupe, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe, Odon Sabarre and the People’s Center School of Dance, and Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center in 1989; Dance Concert Company and Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance in 1990; and Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement, Chameleon Dance Company, Araullo University Dance Troupe, and Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe in 1991.

In 2014, the CCP launched its first ever Ballet Competition held at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino. The biennial competition has a Junior and Senior category and requires contestants to perform both classical and contemporary pieces.

Theater. The CCP, in partnership with the NCCA, has organized the National Theater Festival (NTF), a quinquennial event that gathers theater artists, practitioners, scholars, and enthusiasts from all over the country in a 10-day celebration of the latest achievements in Philippine theater. The NTF, which started in 1992 and was last held in 2012, usually includes performances from various theater groups, a conference, exhibits, and film screenings.

During the first NTF, production and festival grants, as well as six workshop and one research grant, were given to the nine participating regional theater groups. These are Adela Community Organization of Silay City, Negros Occidental; the Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc.-UHAY of Malolos, Bulacan; Cebu Central Colleges Theater Workshop Company and University of San Carlos Theater Guild of Cebu City; Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo City; Komedya ng San Dionisio of Paranaque; Kulturang Atin Foundation Inc., and Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao City; and the Salidummay Music Theater Company and Tadec Group of Baguio City. Production grants were also given to seven Metro Manila-based groups, namely Bulwagang Gantimpala, Dulaang UP, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, and Tanghalang Pilipino. Many other groups have availed of these grants in subsequent CCP National Theater Festivals.

The CCP has also supported theater groups outside Metro Manila through its Outreach and Exchange Unit. It provided financial assistance to deserving applicants for the touring of produced local productions to different sites within the region. Theater companies that received touring grants are: in 1988, the Dula Agus Ensemble of Butuan City, Salidummay of the Cordillera, and Teatro Amakan of Iloilo; in 1989, the Sining Pananadem in Marawi City, Dance Theater of Tacloban City, and Susi ng Tayabas in Quezon; in 1991, Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna and the Adela Community Organization from Silay City, Negros Occidental; in 1992, Sining Kambayoka Ensemble of the Mindanao State University and the Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao; in 2014, the community-based theater guild in Sorsogon, Teatro Ambahanon and Kabpapagariya Ensemble of General Santos City, the Youth Advocates thru Theater Arts in Dumaguete City, the Integrated Performing Arts Guild in Iligan City, and the Sining Kambayoka Ensemble in Marawi City; and in 2015, Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc. of Malolos City, Artista Sillimania of Dumaguete City, Kuntaw Mindanao of Davao del Norte, and Kaliwat Performing Arts Collective of Davao City. Meanwhile, production venue and full grants were given to Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, UP Playwrights Theater, Telon, Sining Silangan, Philippine Drama Company, UP Repertory Company, Teatro Santa Ana, and Teatro Umalohokan.

In 1994, the CCP Coordinating Center for Dramatic Arts awarded playwriting fellowships to four writers, giving them cash grants to develop their full-length plays. The fellows chosen were JB Capino for his play Los Indios Bravos (The Brave Natives), Dennis Marasigan for Aves de Rapina (Birds of Prey), V. E. Carmelo Nadera for Hermano Puli, and Bebot Rodil for Datu Matu.

Prior to its reorganization after the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the CCP was the home of two local theater companies: Teatro Pilipino, under artistic director Rolando Tinio, and Bulwagang Gantimpala Theater, under artistic director Tony Espejo. Teatro Pilipino, the first resident theater company of the CCP from 1976-86, staged Filipino translations of plays by William Shakespeare, Anton Chekhov, George Bernard Shaw, August Strindberg, and Tennessee Williams, as well as a few Filipino works like Francisco Baltazar’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), Bienvenido M. Noriega’s Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), and Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason).

Bulwagang Gantimpala started out as the production arm of the winning works from the CCP Literary and Playwriting Contest. It staged original Filipino works like Jomar Fleras’s adaptation of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, titled Kanser (Cancer), Bonifacio Ilagan’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), Rene O. Villanueva’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), and Noriega’s Bongbong at Kris (Bongbong and Kris). In 1987, it became an independent theater company and has since moved its office elsewhere.

Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) is now the resident drama company of the CCP. Established in 1987, TP has staged more than 150 productions and is now on its 30th season. Its founding artistic director was Nonon Padilla who directed the company for 17 years until he was replaced by Herbie Go, Dennis Marasigan, and Nanding Josef. Its repertoire consists of original works by Filipino playwrights, restagings of Filipino sarsuwela, and translations and adaptations of foreign plays. TP maintains a stable of professional actors known as the Tanghalang Pilipino Actors’ Company. The company regularly conducts acting workshops and has also toured some of its productions in various provinces.

TP has also partnered with the CCP, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and the Writer’s Bloc, Inc. in producing the highly successful Virgin Labfest, a laboratory festival of new, unproduced, and untested one-act plays by amateur and veteran playwrights. This yearly project which started in 2005 has now become one of the most anticipated theater events in the country and has also produced a canon of acclaimed works.

In 2011, the CCP and the NCCA organized the first Monodrama Festival, a four-day event featuring monologues and one-actor performances. In 2013, the CCP produced Triple Threats, a series of concerts featuring the stalwarts of Philippine musical theater. Among the artists who have performed for this series are Nonie Buencamino, Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo, Audie Gemora, and Bituin Escalante. The series has also featured composers Rony Fortich and Vincent de Jesus in 2015 and ensemble players in 2016.

Visual Arts. The CCP through its Visual Arts and Museum Division (VAMD) implements and manages the year-round contemporary art, design, and festival-related exhibitions at the various venues at the CCP. These exhibitions provide a showcase for current directions, trends, and movements in Philippine contemporary art, including the fields of architecture, sculpture, photography, digital art, and the allied arts. Aside from managing exhibit venues, providing curatorial assistance, and organizing forums, lectures, and talkback sessions with artists and designers, the VAMD also coordinates with the visual arts community on the activities and concerns of the visual artists all over the country.

The VAMD has organized and presented exhibits featuring artworks of notable Filipino artists among them: Fernando Amorsolo, Victorio Edades, Carlos V. Francisco, Cesar Legaspi, H. R. Ocampo, Vicente Manansala, Fernando Zobel, Lee Aguinaldo, Constancio Bernardo, Jose Joya, Napoleon Abueva, Roberto Chabet, Arturo Luz, Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Ang Kiukok, Justiniano Nuyda, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Romulo Olazo, Ray Albano, Nonon Padilla, Prudencio Lamarroza, Impy Pilapil, Ileana Lee, Danilo Dalena, Onib Olmedo, Jaime de Guzman, Julie Lluch, Solomon Saprid, Ben Maramag, Bencab, Tony Velasquez, Mars Ravelo, Francisco Coching, Roberto Feleo, Kidlat Tahimik, Mark Justiniani, Karen Flores, Claude Tayag, and Agnes Arellano. The VAMD has also presented exhibits of artists’ groups such as the Social Realists, Kasibulan Women Artists, Paete artists, Black Artists of Asia, Abstract Expressionists, Figurative Expressionists, Mabini Art Movement, Salingpusa, Baguio Arts Guild, VIVA Excon, and artists from various schools like the University of the Philippines, University of Santo Tomas, and the Philippine High School for the Arts.

The VAMD also gives recognition to Filipino artists through the 13 Artists Awards. Started by former CCP museum director Roberto Chabet in 1970, the 13 Artists Awards later became a biennial award under the management of Ray Albano, and a triennial award in 2009. The award is given to artists who take “the chance and risk to restructure, restrengthen, and renew art making and art thinking.” Since 2009, the recognition has been given to more than 170 artists in the fields of painting, sculpture, mixed and multi-media, and installation art. The most recent awarding was held in 2018 and the recipients were Zeus Bascon, Bea Camacho, Cian Dayrit, Janos Dela Cruz, Carlo Gabuco, Dina Gadia, Guerrero Habulan, Eisa Jocson, Doktor Karayom, Raffy Napay, Archie Oclos, Lynyrd Paras, and Shireen Seno. The awarding usually coincides with a month-long exhibition of the awardees’ works.

Literature. The Literary Arts division of the CCP, now known as the Intertextual Division (ID), undertakes activities that deal with literary text, performance text, and hypertext. Among its accomplishments is the publication of ANI (Harvest), a literary journal which is now on its 39th edition. The journal features short stories, essays, and poems in Filipino, English, and other Philippine languages. It also took care of other CCP special publications like Himala y Balagtas and Himalay Rizal.

In previous years, the CCP sponsored literary contests and awarded writing grants to writers in Filipino, English, and the major regional languages. It began sponsoring a playwriting contest in 1969 in both English and Filipino. The first winners of the CCP Playwriting Contest were: In Frailty’s Grace by Elsa V. Martinez, first prize; And the Day But One by Jose Ma. Hernandez, second; and The Onyx Wolf by Virginia Moreno, third; Tabak at Tanikala (Bolo and Chain) by Dionisio S. Salazar; Status Quo by Angel R. Makiling, and Halik sa Kampilan (Kiss the Sword) by Cipriano V. Ilagan, honorable mention.

A verse writing category was added in 1973. The first winners in the English division were Artemio Tadena for “The Bloodied Envelope,” first prize; Gemino Abad for “In Another Light,” second prize; and Federico Licsi Espino for “Scope of Movement,” third prize. The poets given honorable mention in the English division were Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for “Twelve,” Jolico Cuadra for “The Possibilitation Poems,” and Simeon Dumdum Jr for “Rainy Day.” In the Filipino division, the first winners were Teo Antonio for “Pilipino sa Isang Lawa ng Chicago” (A Filipino by the Lakeside in Chicago), first prize; Vict. V. de la Cruz for “Isang Pag-aalay sa Sining, sa Bayan, sa Bathala” (An Offering to Art, to Country, and to God), second prize; and Victor S. Fernandez for “Mga Bulaklak sa Parnaso” (Flowers on Parnasus), third prize. Given honorable mention were Gonzalo K. Flores for “Bahay sa Looban” (A House in the Interior), Eduardo P. Garrovillas for “Ang Bagong Pilipino” (The New Filipino), and Virgilio S. Almario for "Doktrinang Anakpawis" (Doctrine of the Laborer).

The following categories were added in 1974: epic narrative, won by Luwalhati C. Marquez for “Balante”; short story, won by Reynaldo Duque for “Bagani Ubbong at Iba Pang Kuwento” (Bagani Ubbong and Other Stories); novel, won by Benjamin P. Pascual for “Utos ng Hari” (King’s Command); essay, won by Pablo R. Glorioso for “Pamana ng Panitik at Iba Pang Sanaysay” (Legacy of Letters and Other Essays) and Virgilio S. Almario for “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makina” (The Poet in the Machine Age). A biography category was added in 1979. Honorable mention was given to Lydia Ingle for “Edades: Kites and Visions,” 1980 in the English division and to Lamberto Ma. Gabriel for “Padre Gregorio L. Crisostomo, Ulirang Pilipino” (Father Gregorio L. Crisostomo, a Model Filipino), Filipino division. Hernando J. Abaya won the grand prize when the award for the category was resumed in 1984 for “The Making of a Subversive.”

The novel category was also instituted in 1979. The first co-winners in the English division were F. Sionil Jose for Tree and Edith Tiempo for His Native Coast. In the Filipino division, the prize went to Dominador B. Mirasol for Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold is the Brown Earth).

A new category—criticism—was added in 1984. In the English division, an Appreciation Award was shared among Nick Nicolas Jr for “Theater, Films and Others: A Compendium of Critical Reviews,” Wilhelmina Q. Ramas for “Sugbuanon Theater: From Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar,” and Soledad S. Reyes for “Criticism and Ideology.” In the Filipino division, the grand prize in criticism was given to Virgilio S. Almario for “Taludtod at Talinghaga: Mga Sangkap ng Katutubong Pagtula” (Verses and Metaphor: The Elements of Folk Poetry).

In 1987, the annual literary contest was transformed into the Gawad CCP Para sa Panatikan under the supervision of the CCP’s Coordinating Center for Literature. The contest dropped the English category in favor of an all-Filipino rule. The categories were poetry, short story, one-act play, three-act play, dance libretto (one-act dance drama), and the full-length musical drama.

The winners in the poetry category that year were Fidel D. Rillo for “Musa Insurekta” (Insurgent Muse), first prize; Teo Antonio for “Cespora Personata at Iba Pang Pagbubulay-bulay” (Cespora Personata and Other Ruminations), second prize; and Danton Remoto for “Kuwaderno” (Notebook), third prize. In the short story category, the winners were Reynaldo Duque for “Ang Gamugamo sa Lampara ni Julio Madarang” (The Firefly About Julio Madarang’s Lamp), first prize; Chit Balmaceda-Gutierrez for “Kulas,” second prize; and Tomas F. Agulto for “Ang Walang Lubay na Istasyon ng Pag-asa at Paghahanap” (The Eternal Station of Hope and Searching), third prize. The critical essay category on the different arts was instituted a year later.

The winning poems and stories in the Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan have also been published in ANI, while the critical works have appeared in Kultura, the CCP magazine for critical essays. The Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan was discontinued in 1990.

The CCP has also given grants to writers who applied for writing grants for drama in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in the performing arts. Grantees in drama are Reynaldo Duque, 1988, and Jose A. Bragado, 1989, for Ilocano; Ruperto Alaura, 1988, RobertoVillanueva, 1989, and Leonilo Estimo, 1993, for Cebuano; Carlos Ojeda Aureus, 1992, for Bicolano; Julian Jagudilla, 1989 and 1990, and Jose Galiza and Eugenio de Pablo, 1991, for Hiligaynon/Karay-a; and Rene O. Villanueva, 1988, and Ariel N. Valerio, 1993, for Filipino.

In 2015, the ID spearheaded the biennial event called Performatura 2015, Performing Literatures, a three-day intertextual festival held in various venues at the CCP. The event included conversations with National Artists; Chromatext Rebooted, an exhibit merging text and visual arts; performance poetry featuring young poets; and workshops on the poetic joust balagtasan, speech choir, and ventriloquism.

Film. The Media Arts Division is the main implementor of the CCP’s year-round film, broadcast, and emerging media events, which include screenings, productions, festivals, awards, workshops, and fora. It also coordinates with all sectors of the film community—both local and international, independent and mainstream, contemporary and classic.

In 1987, the CCP started to give recognition to Filipino alternative films and video. Known as the Gawad CCP Para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Bidyo or Gawad Alternatibo, this is considered the longest-running independent film competition of its kind in the Asian region. Gawad Alternatibo annually cites the best efforts of Pinoy filmmakers in four categories: Animation, Experimental, Documentary, and Short Feature. Each winner receives a cash prize and a certificate. Special citations are also awarded to the best work from the regions, as well as works on/for/by children. Many of today’s outstanding filmmakers and media practitioners are awardees of Gawad Alternatibo.

The Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival is one of the CCP’s most important cinema-related undertakings every year. Established in 2004, the festival has given birth to some of Philippine cinema’s contemporary masterpieces and is regarded as one of the most prestigious independent film competitions in the country, and a much awaited cultural event as well. Some of today’s acclaimed filmmakers have launched their careers via the annual festival and competition, including Kanakan Balintagos aka Aureaus Solito, Lawrence Fajardo, Chris Martinez, Jun Robles Lana, Alvin B. Yapan, Francis Pasion, and Eduardo Roy Jr. Simultaneous film-related events are also held during the festival, including the Cinemalaya Film Congress, a two-day conference that looks at all aspects of independent filmmaking and distribution; the Cinemalaya Sine Taktakan, a forum with the year’s batch of new Cinemalaya filmmakers; exhibitions that include Tributes to Past Indie Mavericks of Pinoy Cinema; a Cinemalaya Kids’ Treats; World Premieres of New Digital Works (the Cinemalaya/NETPAC Prize); and a host of other activities.

The CCP also holds annual film lectures and retrospectives on Filipino filmmakers and actors, like Gerardo de Leon, Manuel Conde, Luciano B. Carlos, Mona Lisa, Jaclyn Jose, and Fernando Poe Jr, as well as foreign film artists like Akira Kurosawa, Isabelle Huppert, and Olivier Assayas.

Broadcast Arts. In recognition of the broad reach and powerful influence of radio and television, the CCP established in 1987 a Coordinating Center for Broadcast Arts which was one of the units of the then Visual, Literary, and Media Arts Department. While all these units have been replaced by the Media Arts Division, the CCP—then and now—has continued efforts to equip ordinary citizens with the skills to produce radio programs and videos that reflect their realities and that allow them to promote their sectoral interests through broadcasting. It conducts hands-on training-workshops on radio and television production and scriptwriting, accepts apprenticeships, and awards production grants. While bringing its training program to as far north as Batanes and as far south as Tawi-tawi, the CCP encourages the use of Filipino languages in the programs and videos produced by its trainees. Among those who complete the training programs and are given grants to produce their own radio programs are farmers, fisherfolk, social development and cultural workers, students, and local leaders who produce and host talk shows, historical documentaries, instructional programs, public service announcements, music shows, and dramatizations of Filipino myths and legends. Their productions are aired in cooperation with local radio stations.

The CCP produces television programs as well as videos. In 1990 it produced Pinoy Eh, a magazine show aired on ABC Channel 5. Directed by Marilou-Diaz-Abaya and hosted by Ces Quesada, it had 13 episodes on such topics as the Filipino language, music, cinema, architecture, literature, dance, rituals, ethnic groups, and places. Another television production is the 1992 13-episode drama series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) based on Jose Rizal’s novel, written and directed by National Artist for cinema Eddie Romero, starring Joel Torre and Chin-chin Gutierrez. The series is also available in DVD. The Red Carpet was a monthly program aired on Net 25 in 2009-12, featuring the shows at CCP and the cultural and artistic scene in the country. On Set, also on Net 25, 2009-12, highlighted the country’s top caliber artists such as Lea Salonga, Ryan Cayabyab, and Bienvenido Lumbera.

CCP is also on radio. Following the 1986 EDSA revolt, it produced the weekly radio magazine Kultura ng Bayan (Culture of the People), aired on DZRV in 1986-92, then on DZRM until 1996. It featured Filipino music and theater, talked about arts and culture in the Philippines, and held the balagtasan on current socio-political issues. Among CCP’s current radio programs is the weekly Culture Carousel, which has been airing on DZFE since 1990. It features CCP music artists as well as visiting music artists and airs their performances. Another production is DiskArte (Artistic Strategy) which discusses social issues using the arts. It airs on DZRH in partnership with the Manila Broadcasting Corporation (MBC). The program was formerly titled Sugpuin ang Korupsyon (Fight Corruption) which aired on DZRH in 2004-08 until it was reformatted. It was awarded The Freedom Project 2013 Jury Prize and the People’s Choice Award by The Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom of Germany. Another CCP radio production was the children’s show Wan Dey Isang Araw (One Day), aired on DZAS in 2005-13, which tried to revive the tradition of storytelling in the Philippines. It featured stories by Luis P. Gatmaitan, Eugene Evasco, Augie Rivera, and Grace Chong.

In 1987-98, the CCP gave out the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon (CCP Awards for Television), annually to outstanding television programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and other content producers. Among the awardees were the musicals Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You) and Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music With Ryan), the drama series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and Lovingly Yours, Helen, the children’s show Batibot (Small but Strong), the talk show Pep Talk, the public affairs programs Probe Team, Public Forum, and Viewpoint, and the gag show Sic O’Clock News. In 1990-1998, the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo (CCP Awards for Radio) was given at the same time as the television awards, to outstanding radio programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and music and sound designers. The radio awards were henceforth given every two years. Among the awardees in 1990 were the documentary Parangal (Tribute), on DZRM; the drama series Drama Filipina on DZEC, the arts and culture show Filipiniana on DZLC in Lucena, the music magazine shows Yukbo sa Musika on DYMR and Salam in sa Kaliwat on DXWG, both in Cebu, and radio pioneer Francisco “Koko” Trinidad for his contribution to Philippine radio.

Other Programs. The CCP organizes various year-round arts-affiliated events, such as Pasinaya, the biggest multi-arts festival in the country. Started in 2010, Pasinaya is an annual one-day open-house festival which serves as a gathering of CCP resident companies, patrons, and the general public. Simultaneous events are held in all of CCP’s venues, with designated zones for dance, theater, music, literature, film, visual arts, children and family, variety, and the artists market. There are also crash workshops, film screenings, visual arts exhibitions, food booths, and activities for children. Some of the resident companies also perform excerpts from their upcoming shows or past productions.

Outreach and exchange programs include: KUTITAP: Isang Piging ng Kabataang Makasining, an annual three-day event for children and young people that started in 2009 and is aimed at raising their awareness of and appreciation for indigenous arts, culture, and traditions; Ugnayan sa Sining, an annual series of cultural exchanges and community tours featuring some of the country’s prominent regional cultural groups; Lakbay Sining, a national touring program which features performances from CCP resident companies or art exhibitions previously mounted at the CCP; Kaisa sa Sining, a program which links CCP to regional cultural groups in order to facilitate regional cultural development, exchanges, artistic programs, and collaborations; Lakbay Sine, a project of CCP Media Arts Division; and Lakbay Harana , a joint project of the CCP and Tribung Pilipino Foundation which aims to promote and reawaken the public’s, and especially the young generation’s, interest and appreciation for Philippine traditional music like the kundiman, balitaw, danza, and immortal Filipino love songs. The CCP through its Cultural Exchange Department also provides local tour grants for regional performing groups. It is also active in giving art therapy workshops—called Kalinga ng Sining—in provincial areas devastated by natural calamities or armed conflicts.

The CCP has occasionally engaged in film production. It produced two movies: Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987, directed by Eddie Romero, and Emir, 2010, directed by Chito Roño.

A heritage project of the CCP is the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art. First published in 1994, the CCP Encyclopedia remains to be the most authoritative and most comprehensive sourcebook on Philippine art, with volumes on the peoples of the Philippines, architecture, visual arts, dance, music, theater, film, literature, and broadcast arts. Prior to the encyclopedia, the CCP also published beginning in 1989, 28 videos and monographs on the seven arts, known collectively as Tuklas Sining. The first essays on the seven arts were compiled and published in a coffee table book with the same title in 1991. To encourage the staging of more sarsuwela, the CCP came out with the sarsuwela series which made available to scholars and performing groups the scripts and music of the classic Tagalog sarsuwela Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), and Walang Sugat (No Wounds) as performed and staged by Tanghalang Pilipino. The initial publication in 1991 included the cassette tapes and books for Paglipas ng Dilim and Dalagang Bukid, and in 1994, for Walang Sugat. The videotaped performances of Dalagang Bukid and Walang Sugat were released in DVD format in 2007.

The Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is the highest recognition awarded by the CCP to artists or groups of artists who have produced a body of outstanding works and excelled in their chosen artform. The award is also given to cultural workers who have helped in enriching Philippine art through their works in research, curatorship, and administration. The Tanging Parangal is given to individuals or organizations to honor their outstanding contributions to the development of the arts in the country.The first Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, then called by another name, was given in 1977 to Hubertus Kuhne (for cultural administration). The award was given annually from 1989 up to 1994, and thereafter every three years. The most recent conferment was in 2015 and the awardees were: Denisa Reyes for Dance; Fides Cuyugan-Asensio for Music; Antonio Mabesa for Theater; Roberto Chabet for Visual Arts; Ricardo Lee for Literature; Nora Aunor for Film and Broadcast Arts; Paulo Alcazaren for Architecture; and Ben Farrales for Design. Leoncio Deriada, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Talaandig School of Living Traditions, and The Missionary Society of St. Columban received the Tanging Parangal.

The Order of the National Artists, the highest state honor given every three years to individuals who have made significant contributions in Philippine arts, was administered by the CCP from 1972 to 1992, and after that, by the CCP and NCCA. The award is conferred by the President of the Republic of the Philippines upon the recommendation of the CCP and NCCA.Fernando Amorsolo was posthumously conferred the first National Artist Award in 1977. The award was most recently conferred in 2018to Larry Alcala (visual arts, posthumous), Resil B. Mojares and Ramon Muzones (literature), Francisco Mañosa (architecture), Ryan Cayabyab (music), and Kidlat Tahimik (film).  Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Lily Grace Tabanera, and Elmer L. Gatchalian
Cuneta, Sharon (See FILM volume.)

CUSTODIO, BERNARDINO (Bernardino Feliciano Custodio) b. Manila 20 May 1911. d. Manila 23 Nov 2001. Conductor, composer, teacher. He was the son of Antonio Custodio and Eulalia Feliciano. He was married to Lourdes Victoria with whom he had four children. He obtained a degree in piano forte from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1930 and a master’s degree from the University of Santo Tomas (UST).

He studied piano with Pedro Eloriaga, composition and conducting with Alexander Lippay, Jeno von Takacs, and Herbert Zipper, and was a Fulbright grantee in 1947. He taught at the UP after his graduation, but left the university shortly before the 1950s to join the newly established UST Conservatory of Music, where he served as dean from 1957 to 1961. He also served as the dean of the Yupangco-Yamaha School of Music from the early 1970s to 1992.

From 1940 to the 1960s, he served as associate conductor of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. He was also the conductor for the inauguration of the Philippine Republic’s first president, Manuel A. Roxas, in 1946.

Custodio’s compositions include piano solos “Pauli-uli” (Repetition), 1947, “Sarimanok,” 1976, “Prelude,” 1977, “Ritual Dance,” 1978, “Vision,” 1981, and “The Juggler,” 1982, “Prelude and Fugue,” 1988; Malayan Suite, 1932, for orchestra; and Serenade for violin, cello, and piano, 1932. He orchestrated for films such as Beast of the East, 1948, and He Promised to Return, 1950, the original music of both were composed by Julio Esteban Anguita.Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

CUYUGAN-ASENSIO, FIDES (Fides Belza Cuyugan-Asensio) b. Lucena, Quezon 1 Aug 1931. Singer, actor, director, librettist, translator, teacher. She is the daughter of Gervacio Santos Cuyugan and Jacinta Belza. She is married to Manuel Asensio with whom she has two children. She finished two courses at the Philippine Women’s University: bachelor of arts in English, with special studies in drama, 1950, and bachelor of music, major in voice and minor in piano, 1951. She obtained her artist’s diploma, major in voice with special studies in stage movement and eurhythmics, from the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia in 1955.

As an opera singer for three decades, Asensio has sung lead and title roles in virtually all locally produced operas and sarsuwela. She made her operatic debut in Johann Strauss’s Die Fledermaus in 1954, presented by the Manila Symphony Society. She sang the part of the demented Sisa in the premiere performance of Felipe Padilla de Leon’s three-act Filipino opera, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), staged by the Music Theater Foundation of the Philippines (MTFP) in 1957. She reprised the same role in a 1987 restaging of the opera at the Main Theater (now Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). A compact version of the same opera was toured by the MTFP in key cities of the United States in 1988. She has also sang the lead roles in Ibert’s Angelique, 1961; Ferrari’s Secret of Suzanne, 1963; Mozart’s The Abduction from the Seraglio, 1964, and The Marriage of Figaro, 1983; Donizetti’s Il Companello, 1965; Verdi’s La Traviata, 1970; Britten’s Turn of the Screw, 1988; and Debussy’s L’Enfant Prodigue, 1989 and 1991. She appeared in the sarsuwela Ana Maria, 1968, by Antonio J. Molina; Minda Mora, 1974, and Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1979, by Severino Reyes; Mapulang Bituin (Red Star) by Rosendo Santos; and Sumpang Mahal (Beloved Promise) by Rey T. Paguio.

She wrote the libretto of and sang a leading role in Larawan ng Kababaihan: Maskara at Mukha (Portrait of Women: Mask and Face), 1981, with music by Lucrecia R. Kasilag, and staged at the CCP Main Theater. In 1984, she performed the lead role in and was also the librettist of La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), a three-act Filipino opera with music by Francisco F. Feliciano, and premiered by the Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines at the CCP Main Theater. In 1992, she began working on the libretto of Mayo… Bisperas ng Liwanag (May… Eve of Light), a Filipino opera based on the short story “May Day Eve” by National Artist Nick Joaquin, which premiered at the Camp Aguinaldo Theater in Nov 1997. The music was by Reynaldo Paguio. Asensio later translated the libretto into English for the opera’s staging in Aberdeen, Scotland, in Apr 2000. Inspired by Santiago Albano Pilar’s book Juan Luna, the Filipino as Painter, she wrote the libretto for the opera Spoliarium, with music by Ryan Cayabyab. The title was taken from the 1884 award-winning painting of Juan Luna at the Exposición Nacional de Bellas Artes in Madrid. The opera was premiered at the CCP Main Theater in Feb 2003.

Asensio directed many operas as a faculty member and chairperson of the Voice, Music Theater and Opera Department of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. Among them: Menotti’s The Medium and The Saint of Bleeker Street, which she translated into Filipino as Ang Santa sa Daang Pitong Gatang; Puccini’s Suor Angelica; Poulenc’s Dialogue of the Carmelites; Mozart’s The Impresario; Delibes’ Lakme; Gounod’s Romeo et Juliette; Offenbach’s Tales of Hoffman; and The Joke is Me (based on Puccini’s Rigoletto). For the MTFP, she directed Joseph’s Rebecca, Britten’s Turn of the Screw (where she also sang a lead female role), Humperdinck’s Hansel and Gretel, Menotti’s The Telephone, and Debussy’s L’Enfant Prodigue.

As voice mentor, Asensio has guided several pupils towards international recognition, among them: sopranos Andion Fernandez, Johanna Cabili, and Margarita Yulo Gomez; tenors Sal My’Neo Malaki, Lemuel Cuento, and Jonathan Badon; and dramatic mezzo-soprano Kim Ok Soo.

From 1969 to 1974, she performed, directed opera excerpts, and wrote scripts for Sunday Sweet Sunday, a weekly musical TV show on ABS-CBN which she also co-hosted with tenor Jimmy Melendrez. She also hosted, with violinist John Lesaca, her second weekly late-night musical TV show on GMA 7, A Little Night of Music, 1989-98. Asensio is also an accomplished film actress, with critically acclaimed performances in movies like Oro Plata Mata, 1982, directed by Peque Gallaga, and Niño, 2011, directed by Loy Arcenas.

At present, Asensio is a professor emeritus in voice at the UP College of Music where she has taught since 1969. She was the chairman of the Voice and Music Theater Department from 1988 up to her retirement in 1997. She is the artistic director of Opera Guild of the Philippines and has been the president and artistic director of the MTFP since 1987.

Asensio was listed in the 1999 National Centennial Commission book Outstanding Women of the Philippines by Victoria Paz. She was also bestowed the PAMA-AS Gintong Bai Award for the Musical Arts by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2005. In 2015, she received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining Award for her outstanding achievements and contributions to Philippine arts and culture.Written byElmer L. Gatchalian,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

DADAP, JERRY (Jerry Amper Dadap) b. Hinunangan, Leyte 5 Nov 1935. Composer, arranger, teacher, choirmaster. He was born to Vedasto Dadap and Dionisia Amper, a church singer who comes from a musical family. He first heard Verdi arias from his mother. Most of his 13 siblings are also musically inclined. His brother, Michael, is a guitar artist. He married Celeste Icban with whom he has four children, one of whom is Jemay, a violinist. While studying to be a church minister at Silliman University in 1954, he continued his musical training under Priscilla V. Magdamo. He earned his bachelor’s degree in music at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music in 1964, and his postgraduate diploma in composition from the Mannes School of Music, New York City in 1971.

In 1972 he inaugurated the Lahi (Race) concert series, which sought to encourage and popularize Filipino compositions. In 1979 he organized the Andres Bonifacio Music Foundation, which has three performing groups: the Andres Bonifacio (AB) Musicale, the AB Concert Choir, and the AB Rondalla. His works have been performed at the Composers’ Symposia at the New England Conservatoire de Musique in Canada, 1971. He is the first Filipino to conduct his own works in Carnegie Recital Hall, 1971. Dadap taught music at Santa Isabel College and University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music

Dadap is among the first Filipino composers to explore the symphonic potential of the Philippine rondalla. He has written over 50 major works, including The Passionate and the Wild, 1960; Violin Concerto in Three Movements, 1965; Philippine Symphonic Rondalla, 1967; The Redemption, 1974; Five Little Fingers, 1975; Mangamuyo (Beg) I for flute, clarinet, trombone, violin, viola, cello, and ethnic instruments, 1976, and Mangamuyo II for ethnic instruments and two old woman singers, 1977; Choral Cycle No. 1, 1964, No. 2, 1966, and No. 3 (a capella), 1985; Song Cycle No. 1 for baritone and orchestra, 1975, No. 2 for soprano and orchestra, 1976, and No. 3 for soprano and orchestra and No. 4 for baritone and orchestra, 1981; Tomaneg at Aniway (Tomaneg and Aniway), 1975, and Life Force, 1981, music for ballet, the latter commissioned by the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines(CCP); La Lampara (The Lamp), one-act ballet, 1980; and The Other Maria Clara, a sarsuwela, 1978. Another major work is the contemporary musical, AndresBonifacio,AngDakilangAnak-Pawis (Andres Bonifacio, The Great Plebeian), staged in 1979 at the CCP Main Theater (now Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo).

In 1960, he was hailed by the UP Committee on Annual Awards as an outstanding musician. He was also awarded the first prize in the National Rondalla Composition Contest which was sponsored by the Manila Times Publishing Company in 1967. His composition the “Demolay Hymn” earned him the Distinguished Service Award Medal by the International Order of Demolay in 1968. In the same year, he was given a meritorious achievement award in the field of music by Southern Leyte province. In 1974, he also received an award from the Southern Leyte Press Club. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo and Antonio C. Hila,updated by Crisancti L. Macazo
Damaso, Jimeno (See THEATER volume.)

DAVID, DON (Don Alfonso David) b. 23 Dec 1917. d. Antipolo, Rizal 21 Mar 1986. Singer. His love for music was nurtured by his father, Pedro David Sr, who used to buy records of Enrico Caruso, Nelson Eddy, and Janet MacDonald, and his mother, Dionisia Alfonso, who played the bandurria. In grade school, he already showed a talent for singing, and in high school at Manila North (now Arellano) he was a member of the glee club. Joining singing contests, he won first prize in the Listerine Amateur Hour. In 1949, he got a scholarship at the Manila Academy of Music where he studied voice under Isabel de Padua. He attended an opera training workshop at Centro Escolar University. He trained under Mario del Rio and Pedro Roxas.

David was already a well-known nightclub singer and recording artist when he first appeared in Verdi’s La Traviata at the Far Eastern University Auditorium. From then on until the 1970s, he played major roles in almost all the operas and sarsuwela produced in Manila. A lyric tenor, he sang in La Traviata three times and in Puccini’s La Boheme four times. He partnered such leading sopranos as ConchingRosal, ArmidaSiguion-Reyna, FidesCuyugan-Asensio, ConchitaGaston, RubySalazar, SalvacionOppus-Yñiguez, Letty Liboon, Elsie Cacnio, Luz Morales, Lulu Corrales-Razon, Araceli Calero, IrmaPotenciano, and EvelynMandac. Written byRamon Jocson

THE DAWN This Filipino rock band was founded in 1986 amid the exultation of the EDSA People Power Revolt. It became the Philippines’ foremost band in that period and the prototype of a commercially successful Filipino rock band, the first to fill the Araneta Coliseum, Folk Arts Theater, and ULTRA Stadium for solo concerts while also reaping corporate endorsements. It remains one of the most influential and longest-running rock institutions in the country today.

Originally a three-piece group composed of Teddy Diaz on vocals and guitars, JB Leonor on drums, and Clay Luna on bass, The Dawn eventually recruited Jett Pangan in 1986 as lead vocal. Carlos Balcells soon replaced Clay Luna, and upon the death of Diaz in Aug 1988, a succession of lead guitarists took his place, including Noel Mendez, Sushi, Francis Reyes, and Kenneth Ilagan. The Dawn’s current line-up is Jett Pangan on vocals, Sancho, Buddy Zabala, and JB Leonor on drums. Jett Pangan has developed his own solo career as a musical theater actor in Beauty and the Beast, 2005; Dreamgirls, 2006; Tick, Tick, Boom, 2009; Jekyll and Hyde, 2012; Nine, 2012, and Rock of Ages, 2012. He has also appeared in countless TV guestings. JB Leonor is on the board of directors of his family’s companies. Sancho worked as an artist and repertoire manager for BMG Records, producer of Neo Records, and session guitarist for Cynthia Alexander and Ely Buendia. Buddy Zabala, founding member of the Eraserheads, is also an active record producer.

The Dawn shot to fame with a series of hit singles including “Enveloped Ideas,” “Salamat” (Thanks), “Iisang Bangka” (Same Boat), and “Tulad ng Dati” (Just Like Before), and hit albums released in quick succession which cemented their reputation as the country’s preeminent new wave band. The group has eight albums with Octo Arts: The Dawn, 1986; I Stand With You, 1988; Beyond the Bend and The Dawn Live, 1989; Heart’s Thunder, 1990; Iisang Bangka, 1991; Abot Kamay (Within Arms’ Reach), 1992; and Puno’t Dulo (Beginning and End), 1994. With Sony Music, they produced Prodigal Sun, 2000, and with Warner Music, Harapin (Face It), 2004. The later albums Tulad ng Dati, 2006, Later Half of Day, 2008, and Sound the Alarm, 2009, were all with MCA Music. Of the band’s 14 albums, three are compilations under PolyEast Records Philippines: Iisang Bangka Tayo (We’re in the Same Boat), 1991, The Dawn: OPM Timeless Collection Gold Series, 1997, and The Story of The Dawn: The Ultimate OPM Collection, 2001.

As a nod to its influence on the Philippine musical landscape, The Dawn is the first Filipino band to be featured in a semi-biographical movie, titled Tulad ng Dati (Just Like Before) directed by Mike Sandejas, which was named Best Picture at the 2006 Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival and Competition. The Dawn has also provided the music for the play EJ: Ang Pinagdaanang Buhay Nila Evelio Javier at Edgar Jopson (EJ: The Life Traversed by Evelio Javier and Edgar Jopson), with libretto by Ed Maranan, 2008. Most recently, the band performed for the Nonito Donaire’s Fists of Fury victory party at the Venetian Macau, 2014, and the finale for the landmark First Philippine Music Festival, 2015.Written by Lisa Nakpil

Constancio de Guzman (Constancio Canseco de Guzman) was a music composer and film scorer. He was born in Guiguinto, Bulacan on 11 Nov 1903. He died in Manila on 16 Aug 1982. He was the son of Higino de Guzman, a writer in Spanish, and Margarita Canseco. He married Leonor Buensuceso with whom he had six children. He was the grandson of fictionist Severino Reyes, nephew of Tagalog fictionist and poet Lope K. Santos, and brother of film director and screenwriter Susana de Guzman. During his boyhood, he studied piano and composition under Nicanor S. Abelardo, but his father sent him to law school. Later he switched to commerce and finished business administration in 1931. After passing the Certified Public Accountancy board examinations, he started working in the movies, together with his sister Susana. He wrote numerous pieces of music for films beginning 1931, becoming one of the earliest, if the not the first, Filipino musical director for the movies. He composed music for the films of Sampaguita, LVN, Royal, Lea, National, X'Otic, Excelsior, and Tagalog Ilang-Ilang.

One of de Guzman’s compositions, “Panaginip” (Dream), became a big hit by accident. His father heard Constancio play the song and had it published, thinking it was the composition of a friend. It sold by the thousands, and the father was surprised to learn it was his own son’s work. Since then de Guzman has recorded hundreds of songs, principally under Vicor Records and Columbia Records. De Guzman was at one time director of Villar Records. He was also musical director in many music companies in the Philippines and served as a director of Filipino Society of Composers, Arrangers, and Publishers (FILSCAP).

Some of de Guzman’s notable compositions are: "Bayan Ko" (My Country), "Babalik Ka Rin" (You Will Come Back), "Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig" (My Only Love), “Birheng Walang Dambana” (Virgin Without a Shrine), "Pamaypay ng Maynila" (Manila Fan), “Lambingan” (Tender Caressing), “Ang Pag-ibig Ko’y Ikaw” (You are My Love), and "Maalaala Mo Kaya?" (Will You Remember?). He also composed music for the following movies: Arimunding-munding, Señorita (Miss), Sarung Banggi (One Night), Probinsyana (Provincial Lass), Darna, Roberta, and Ikaw ang Aking Buhay (You Are My Life) where he won the Best Musical Scorer award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) in 1959. He was also named the Best Composer and Lyricist in the 1969 Awit Awards.

In the EDSA Revolution of 1986, de Guzman’s song, “Bayan Ko” became the symbolic anthem of the Filipino people that represented their sentiments and eagerness to be freed from the Marcos's dictatorship. This resonated with the earlier purpose for which the song was written, as a hopeful expression of independence from the Americans. The song was incorporated into the restaging of Severino Reyes’s sarsuwela, Walang Sugat (No Wounds) in 1970. The Tagalog lyrics were written by Jose Corazon de Jesus. “Bayan Ko” won for de Guzman the gold medal at the Paris International Fair of 1948, together with his other song, “Kung Kita’y Kapiling” (When I’m With You). “Bayan Ko” has also been used in the Lino Brocka film Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge), 1985; in the TV documentary EDSA 25: Sulyap ng Kasaysayan (EDSA 25: A Glimpse of History), 2011; and in the movies Don’t Give Up on Us, 2006, Pisay, 2007, and Noy, 2010.

His other famous song, “Maalala Mo Kaya?”, was used by ABS-CBN for their TV series of the same title, which started in 1991 and is hosted by Charo Santos. Maalaala Mo Kaya is considered the longest running drama anthology in the Philippines to date.

De Guzman also acted for the movies, appearing in Huling Dalangin (Last Prayer), 1948, and Hiyas ng Pamilihan (Gem of the Marketplace), 1949.  Written by Flerida G. Nolasco, updated by Arwin Q. Tan
De Jesus, Vincent (See FILM volume.)

article_title: De la Cruz, Katy (See THEATER volume.)
text: De la Cruz, Katy (See THEATER volume.)

DE LA PEÑA, ERNIE (Ernesto Javines de la Peña) b. Manila 26 Oct 1932. Lyricist, composer. He was born to Luciano de la Peña and Ceverina Javines. He is married to Edelmira Maglonzo with whom he has three children. He completed his elementary and secondary education at the La Concordia College and Santa Ana High School. He took up commerce at the Far Eastern University but did not finish the course.

De la Peña began his musical career by winning the grand prize in Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) in 1957. Later, together with Alfonso Manila and Bing Angeles, he formed the ABE trio. He worked with Alpha Records for two years, then with Vicor Records until today.

He has written the lyrics of songs recorded by Rico J. Puno, Sharon Cuneta, and Didith Reyes. Among them are Charo Unite’s “Lupa” (Earth), “Mahal Kita, Mahal Mo Siya, Mahal Niya ay Iba” (I Love You, You Love Her, She Loves Someone Else), and “Tawag ng Pag-ibig” (Call of Love), all in 1979, and “May Bukas Pa” (There’s Still Tomorrow), 1981; Chito Ilacad’s “Kapalaran” (Fate); and Willy Cruz’s “Araw-araw, Gabi-gabi” (Day by Day, Night by Night), both 1975. He also composed the music of “Ang Tao’y Marupok” (Humans are Weak), 1956, with lyrics by Max Surban, and has written his own composition, “Buhay” (Life), 1987. In 1986, he wrote the lyrics of Tito Sotto’s “Magkaisa” (Unite), sung by Virna Lisa, which became popular after the victory of the people’s uprising in Feb 1986. His song “Lupa” has been used in the action movie, Andres Manambit: Angkan ng Matatapang (Andres Manambit: Clan of the Brave). He is also the writer behind “Magsayawan” (Let’s Dance) used in the 2003 film Ngayong Nandito Ka (Now That You Are Here). Another one of his hits became a theme for the TV show May Bukas Pa (There Is Still Tomorrow), in 2009. To date, he has composed the music for 80 songs, and has penned the lyrics for almost 70 songs. His more popular songs, remade by later artists, include, “Ang Pag-ibig Kong Ito” (This Love of Mine), “Habang May Buhay” (While There Is Life), and “Jeprox” (Brat).

De la Peña won the Cecil Award for Best Recording in the Vernacular Language in 1985 as producer of Max Surban’s “Baleleng.” As a lyricist, he won in the Best Song category of Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), 1975, for the song “Araw-araw, Gabi-gabi,” and third prize in the 1979 Metro Manila Popular Music Festival for the song “Lupa.” The same song won the grand prize in the 1979 Tokyo Music Festival. He also won the Catholic Radio Award in 1981 for his lyrics of “May Bukas Pa.” Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

DE LA PEÑA, VERNE (LaVerne David Carmen de la Peña) b. Manila 9 Sep 1959. Composer, ethnomusicologist. He is the son of Benjamin M. de la Peña and Purita Carmen, both from Indang Cavite. As a son of a presbyterian pastor, de la Peña grew up in a family where music was always present because it was an important part of his father’s ministry as a leader of the United Church of Christ of the Philippines (UCCP). His father and uncle were both amateur violin players and sang baritone. As the family moved every three years to different places following his father’s pastoral assignments, de la Peña was exposed to the local cultures of different communities, which always had choral singing. This exposure to music in his early childhood musical experience was immersive. At Union High School of Manila (that is part of Philippine Christian University) where he got his secondary education, he listened to folk pop music, formed a band, and composed some songs.

He entered the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman as a veterinary medicine major in the mid-1970s. Two years after, he shifted to music, major in composition. His first composition teacher was Fr Manuel Maramba, OSB. He later studied with Ramon Santos and Francisco Feliciano, both of whom instilled in him the appreciation for things Asian, particularly Asian philosophy. This inclination to write compositions that ran counter to Western compositional method was thus deeply entrenched in him, and de la Peña, like Jonas Baes, followed the path of this tradition in art music composition. This was further deepened with his apprenticeship as a music copyist for Jose Maceda. De la Peña graduated in 1983 with a bachelor of music degree in composition. For this degree, he wrote the piece Nyuma for 36 singers and Asian instruments, which portrays the idea of forces yin and yang. Nyuma is a three-layered textural music in which representations of yin and yang weave around a static drone. It was during this time when de la Peña was invited to become a member of the erstwhile League of Filipino Composers. For around eight years or more, de la Peña was active as a music director for Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Asian children’s theater Teatro Mulat, for which his Si Suan, Si Suan (Suan, Suan) was composed. This work for four artists—singer, puppeteer, actress, and drummer—is minimalist and utilizes subtle forms of expression using Asian materials.

After earning his bachelor’s degree, de la Peña immediately taught as lecturer in music theory at the UP College of Music. Later he continued his composition studies with Ramon Santos and earned his master’s degree in composition in 1992 with a piece called Seven Songs of the Book of Revelation. This was rendered by the UP Madrigal Singers and the UP Concert Chorus. In 1993, deciding to work on research techniques in addition to composition, de la Peña entered the PhD program in ethnomusicology at the University of Hawaii at Manoa. He finished this in 2000 with a dissertation on the music performed during funerary rites among the Kankanaey in Benguet. However, de la Peña did not forget composition and continued composing for choirs such as hymns and anthems, especially those for UCC which appeared in Pilgrim Press, USA.

After his doctoral studies, de la Peña resumed teaching in the UP College of Music and held the position of chair of the Department of Musicology starting 2004. He has also served as officer-in-charge and member of the Advisory Board of the UP Center for Ethnomusicology. In addition to his research on Cordilleran music in Luzon Island, de la Peña has also done research work on the Tagalog song genres awit, pasyon, and urban hip hop. In 2001, he became the secretary general of the National Music Competitions for Young Artists. Beginning 2010, he has been hosting the weekly DZUP radio program, Tunog at Tinig (Sound and Voice), which got a citation by the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 2012. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

article_title: De la Rama, Atang (See THEATER volume.)
text: De la Rama, Atang (See THEATER volume.)

DE LEON, BAYANI (Bayani Mendoza de Leon) b. Manila 24 Nov 1942. d. 13 Sep 2013. Composer, conductor, arranger, writer, teacher. He was the son of National Artist for music Felipe Padilla de Leon and pianist Iluminada Mendoza. He is married to Cynthia Guerrero, a Centro Escolar University (CEU) mathematics and piano graduate. He had two children with Cynthia Guerrero de Leon, film and photography artist Lakasnubay and cellist Sarighani; and two children with Rhodora Peñaranda, Okir and Amihan.

De Leon’s mother taught him the piano before he was seven. He learned to play the trumpet and the bugle by watching the band which his father conducted. He also learned to play the violin without any formal training. Later he took piano lessons with his aunt and enrolled at the Laperal Music Academy as a scholar. He obtained the following degrees: bachelor of arts in philosophy at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), 1963; bachelor of music, major in composition, at the CEU, 1972; and master of arts in music at the University of the California, Los Angeles, USA, 1982. He also received a scholarship grant in music composition from the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP), 1969-72, as well as a Fulbright-Hays Scholarship grant in music, 1979-81.

He began composing in high school. His first works were the 1960 sarsuwela Hibik sa Karimlan (Cries in the Dark) and Handog sa Diyos (Offering to God), for which he was also the librettist and musical director. This earned him the Musician of the Year award from Mapa High School in 1958; a year later, he was cited as Student Composer-Director of the Year.

He took pride in his Philippine Asian heritage and interwove Philippine folk and ethnic motifs into the musical elements of all his compositions. His large works include Okir (Legendary Bird) for flute, harp and contrabass; Eliksiya (Helix) for voice and movements; Batong-Buhay (Living Stone) for rondalla and orchestra; Bahay-Bata (Mother’s Womb) for rondalla, indigenous instruments, harp, and clarinet; Silay-Parnaso (A Glimpse of Parnassus) for violin and orchestra; Batang Laro (Child’s Play), a suite of seven pieces in various instrumental settings; and Bahay-Bata, chamber music. He wrote music for full-length ballets Legend of the Sarimanok, Atlantis, and Anting-Anting (Amulet), which were choreographed and performed with a full orchestra at the Cultural Center of the Philippines; sarsuwela or musical theater May Puso ang Lupa (The Land Has a Heart), 1963, and Ako! (Me!), 1971, Pag-asa (Hope) with libretto by Severino Montano, Sidewalk Vendor with his own libretto, Villa Mariquita with libretto by Frank Gomez premiered at the Los Angeles Wilshire Ebell Theater, and Mga Sugatang Perlas (Wounded Pearls) with libretto by Ambassador Sedfrey Ordonez premiered at the Town Hall in New York City; and a dance-theater work called A Tale of Two Women: Sisa and Maria Clara.

His first serious guitar composition, Kapilas na Giting (A Piece of Valor), was premiered at the Cultural Center of the Philippines by guitarist Agnes Narciso. This piece is included in several CDs by German guitarist Hucky Eichelmann. A number of de Leon’s guitar works, which were commissioned by guitarists Angelito Agcaoili and Theresa Calpotura, are featured in their respective CDs La Guitarra Filipina (Filipino Guitar) and Kanta Filipina (Filipino Song). He composed Ritwal (Ritual) for guitar quartet, commissioned by the UST Guitar Alumni Society, and Amihan (Northeast Monsoon) for guitar orchestra for the 2010 UST International Guitar Festival.

As a teacher, he gave lecture-concerts on Filipino identity in music under the auspices of the World Kulintang Institute, National Endowment for Folk Arts, The Center for Traditional Music and Dance in New York, and the Pilipino Cultural Resource of San Diego.

He also shared his expertise in developing several rondalla ensembles (Philippine native string band) and kulintang ensembles (Philippine gong ensemble). In the West Coast, he was music director of PASACAT Performing Arts Company and the SAMAHAN Philippine Dance Company, for whom he composed original dance music based on Philippine epics and legends. In the East Coast, he became music director of the Paaralang Pilipino Foundation Rondalla, the Foundation for Filipino Artists Rondalla, the Alay Philippine Performing Arts Rondalla, the University of the Philippines Alumni & Friends Rondalla, and the Philippine Chamber Rondalla of New Jersey. Through concert performances and recordings of many of his almost 500 compositions and arrangements for rondalla, he elevated the rondalla to a concert instrument.

He was a Kriya Yoga initiate; practiced and taught Tai Chi; founded the first Gurdjieff Society in the Philippines; delved into herbology and the healing arts; and was a mentor to many artists and musicians.

Bayani was a prolific writer. While at UST, he won prizes in the UST Rector’s Annual Literary Contests. In 1965, his short story, “Mga Luha ni Leia” (Leia’s Tears), placed third in the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature. He was editor of Pag-asa, a government magazine publication. He authored several books: Baybayin, Ancient Script of the Philippines, Beginner Etudes for the Rondalla Instrumentalist, Elegy to Myself and Other Poems, and This Joining Can Blossom Thankfully from the Mouth of the Beast, a collection of his poems in English and Tagalog. He was managing editor of Simon & Shuster/Prentice Hall for 25 years through his retirement.

He was a member of the League of Filipino Composers. Among his award-winning compositions were: The Golden Earth, a dance drama, first prize, University of the East Song and Dance Competition, 1966; Los Penitentes (The Penitents), a choral drama, first prize, National Songfest, 1967; Sisa, a choral portrait, first prize, National Songfest, 1968; and Alamat ng Lupa (Legend of the Earth), a choral legend, second prize, National Songfest, 1968. He was a recipient of the 2008 PAMANA Award from the Philippine government; was the 2008 Most Outstanding Filipino-Amerian Achiever in America award, and was given the 2014 Gawad Rondalla Posthumous Award by NCCA. Written byAntonio C. Hila,updated by Cynthia de Leon

DE LEON, FELIPE PADILLA b. Peñaranda, Nueva Ecija 1 May 1912 d. Manila 5 Dec 1992. National Artist for music. Composer, teacher. He was the son of Juan de Leon and Natalia Padilla. He married pianist Iluminada Mendoza with whom he had six children. One of them, Bayani, was also a well-known composer, and another, Felipe Jr, is a writer. De Leon’s father died when he was only three years old. His mother supported the family by selling betel nut leaves. He entered elementary school only when he was eight years old. When he was studying at the Nueva Ecija High School, he went on trips with his hometown band and wrote short pieces for them. In 1927 he took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP), but had to stop schooling in order to make a living. He played the trombone in dance orchestras which performed in cabarets, circuses, and bodabil. Then, he worked as assistant conductor of the Nueva Ecija High School Orchestra, where he started doing musical arrangements, and later on, writing music for the sarsuwela. He decided to study music formally and enrolled at the UP Conservatory of Music, where he studied under Col Antonino Buenaventura and Antonio Molina. He contributed articles to the school paper and vernacular magazines, and later wrote music columns for the Manila Times (then known as Manila Tribune) and Taliba.

In 1939, he graduated with a music teacher’s diploma, major in conducting. Much later, he took advanced studies in composition under Vittorio Giannini of the Juilliard School of Music in New York. Before World War II, de Leon taught at the UP Conservatory of Music and served as director of the Department of Music of La Union College of Manila and, during the war years, at St Scholastica’s College. He later taught at the Centro Escolar University Conservatory of Music, Cosmopolitan Colleges, and Laperal Music Academy; and became dean of the Institute of Music of Araneta University, a regent of the Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila, and technical assistant on cultural affairs in the Office of the President of the Philippines. He was a founding member of the League of Filipino Composers, and president of the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers or FILSCAP and Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda ng Pilipinas or PASAMBAP. Known as a nationalist composer, de Leon sought to express the Philippines’ cultural identity through his compositions. He wrote piano compositions, hymns and marches, art songs, chamber music, symphonic poems and overtures, band music, school songs, orchestral works, operas, kundiman, and sarsuwela.

Considered as his masterpieces are the two operas, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1957, and El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1970, which have been staged both here and abroad. Among his other works are “Tindig, Aking Inang Bayan” (Rise, My Motherland), a march he wrote during the Japanese regime; “Bagong Pagsilang” (New Birth), a march written during Martial Law; and the popular Christmas carols “Payapang Daigdig” (Peaceful World), 1946, and “Noche Buena” (Christmas Eve Celebration) and “Pasko na Naman” (It’s Christmastime Again), 1965. De Leon received many awards, among them, Composer of the Year, 1949, Manila Music Lovers Society; Musician of the Year, 1958, UP Conservatory of Music; Presidential Medal of Merit, 1961; Rizal Pro-Patria Award, 1961; Republic Cultural Heritage Award, 1971; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award from the City of Manila, 1971; and First Cultural Achievement Award, 1975, Cultural Center of the Philippines and Philippine Government Cultural Association. He was conferred an honorary degree, doctor of philosophy in the humanities, by the UP in 1991. He was proclaimed posthumously National Artist for music in 1997. The National Commission for Culture and the Arts celebrated his birth centenary in 2012 with a musical concert titled Sa Daigdig ng Musika ni Felipe Padilla de Leon: Celebrating the Centenary of a Cultural Visionary (In the World of Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Music: Celebrating the Centenary of a Cultural Visionary) at the Philamlife Theater, Manila. Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Connie Ladrido

DE LEON, RAYMOND b. 12 Mar 1981. Trumpet player. His father, Abelardo, is a retired trumpeter of the Philippine Army Band and was his first mentor. His sister Maria Teresa plays clarinet while his other sister Joyce plays flute. At age six, Raymond learned his first music pieces and began performing as soloist in a local symphonic band at age nine. Thereafter, he started receiving numerous invitations to perform as soloist in various symphonic bands of the country. His brother Edwin has a bachelor’s degree in trumpet performance in Germany and is a trumpet soloist and First Sergeant of the US Army Band. De Leon is married to Abigail Anne Cano and they live in Malabon City.

He competed in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) and bagged three first prize awards (1992, 1995, and 2004). In 2003, he was a semifinalist in the first Calvia International Trumpet Competition held in Mallorca, Spain in 2003. He also competed in the International Trumpet Guild Solo Competition held at Rowan University, New Jersey, USA in 2006. He gained international stature in 2011 when he won the first prize in the Seattle Philharmonic Don Bushell Concerto Competition. In the following year, he had his debut as trumpet soloist with the Seattle Philharmonic. From then on, he has had various concert tours in Asia, USA, and Europe.

De Leon took his bachelor’s degree in Trumpet Performance at the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music. He was the recipient of Miguel Benavidez Award for International Excellence in Music. He studied under Roger Llado, who is the former principal trumpet player of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. He has collaborated with international trumpet soloist Hakan Hardenberger as well as Edmund Cord, the former principal trumpet player of the Israel Philharmonic.

He was a featured soloist in the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra oncert in 14 Dec 2012, performing Alexander Arutiunian’s Trumpet Concerto. Among the numerous symphonic orchestras and symphonic bands that featured him as soloist are UST Symphony Orchestra, UST Symphonic Band, Banda Malabon Cuatro, 56th Army Band, Pacific Lutheran University Symphony Orchestra, Seattle Philharmonic Orchestra, and Clarion Music Ensemble. Written byCrisancti L. Macazo

DE LEON-REGALA, CARMINDA (Carminda Mata De Leon-Regala) b. Cotabato 31 Aug 1939. Pianist. She is the daughter of David de Leon, a doctor, and Tomasita Mata. She is married to Teodoro Regala, a lawyer, with whom she has four children. A music graduate of the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music under Russian teacher Olga Ifland de Wit, she took her postgraduate studies in piano in Vienna, Austria under Richard Hauser and in Manila under Stella Brimo and ReynaldoReyes. She taught choir, music theory, and history at the International School. She served as president of the UP College of Music Alumni Association and UP Musical Arts Research Foundation.

Regala has performed in numerous concerts at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP), Rizal Park, and Paco Park, as well as in several provinces. She has been a soloist for the PhilippinePhilharmonicOrchestra and the ManilaChamberOrchestra, and has worked with conductors OscarC.Yatco, RegaladoJose, HerbertZipper,

FranciscoF.Feliciano, BasilioC.Manalo, SergioEsmillaJr, Henry Lewis, and RedentorRomero. She has held joint concerts with other Filipino pianists and has been featured in a solo recital in the CCP’s Filipino Artists Series. She has accompanied violinist GilopezKabayao, Russian violinist Valery Kilmov, American violinists Jacob Krachmalnik, and Stanley Plummer, and singers FidesCuyugan-Asensio, NoelVelasco, and ElmoMakil. She has also performed in chamber music concerts such as 8 Hands Piano Concert with Roberta Bray-Armacost, Amelita Dayrit-Guevara, and Nena Del Rosario-Villanueva in 2001. In 2009 she performed in a concert titled ALA Philippines Concert at Greenbelt Park with music director Justice Magdangal de Leon. She has been a soloist and accompanist in performances in Hong Kong, the United States, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, China, Tokyo, Japan, and France. Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

DEL ROSARIO-VILLANUEVA, NENA (Natividad Hautea del Rosario-Villanueva) b. Manila 22 Sep 1935. Pianist. She is the daughter of businessman Mariano del Rosario and Gertrudes Hautea. She is married to Generoso Villanueva, a lawyer-businessman from Bacolod, with whom she has five children. Del Rosario-Villanueva was a child prodigy. Influenced by her mother, a music teacher who was once considered the best piano teacher in Iloilo, she tinkered with the piano at two and a half years old and performed in public at five. During World War II, she occupied herself by studying entire volumes of musical works by Mozart and Beethoven. In 1945, she appeared as soloist of the Manila Symphony Orchestra under Herbert Zipper when she was 10, in the first piano recital held at the old Assumption Convent after the war. On her first trip abroad—to America—aboard the passenger vessel Gen Gordon, when she was 11 years of age, she played her pieces on the ship’s piano. A fellow traveller turned out to be the illustrious pianist Jose Maceda, later National Artist for music, who sat down with her and taught her Albeniz’s Triana totally by ear.

Typical of her extraordinary achievements at a young age, del Rosario-Villanueva made her Carnegie Hall debut with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra after winning a musical competition sponsored by The New York Times. Shortly after this, she entered the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia where she trained under the Russian teacher Isabelle Vengerova.
