She was the first Filipino to obtain an artist’s diploma from the Institute in 1956. In Manila, she studied piano with Victorina Lobregat and Jose Maceda. She also took lessons with the celebrated Vladimir Horowitz, Ilona Kabos, and Abram Chasins. She was once an associate professor at the University of Philippines College of Music.

Del Rosario-Villanueva has appeared with the Manila Symphony Orchestra and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. Overseas she has performed with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, New York Little Symphony Orchestra, CBS Symphony Orchestra, Japan Philharmonic Orchestra, NHK Orchestra (under the baton of Seiji Ozawa), and Orchestra Villa de Madrid, as well as with Russian cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and violinist Rony Rogoff. She performed solo piano recitals in Ecuador, New York City, and Japan in 2001, and in the following year at the Musee de’l Armee at Invalides Paris and Santory Hall in Tokyo.

She collaborated with pianists Carminda de Leon-Regala, Amelita Dayrit Guevara, and Bonny Bray Armacost in a benefit concert for the Santuario de San Antonio Parish, for Forbes Park’s street children, Philippine General Hospital (PGH) Adopt-a-Child, PGH Brain Patients, and JPIC scholarships in 2001. She also performed in a benefit duo concert with Reynaldo Reyes at St Cecilia’s Hall in 2002 and in a rare solo recital of Beethoven’s Sonata in E Major, Chopin’s Impromptu, Liszt’ Etude, and Ravel’s Ondine in Mar 2003 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). In December of that year, she collaborated with Carminda Regala and the German Ambassador Herbert D. Jess playing Mozart’s Sonata for four hands, Rachmaninoff’s Etude Tableau, among others. The CCP special concert series presented Villanueva with Japanese violinist Reiko Otani in 2005. In 2008, she interpreted A. Doronila’s version of Philippine Rhapsody at Casa Blanca at the Plaza San Luis Complex in Manila’s Walled City, in a tribute concert to the Katipunan.

In 1997, she received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in the field of music.Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo,updated by Josephine Baradas

DEL VALLE, LETTY (Leticia Guevara Del Valle) b. Solano, Nueva Vizcaya 4 Mar 1939. Music educator, pianist. She was born to Gonzalo Guevara of Bulacan and Clara Lontook of Nueva Ecija. She is married to Gregorio A. del Valle Jr with whom she had four children.

Her training in music started with piano lessons taught by CICM nuns at the Little Flower Novitiate, a convent in her hometown. This was followed by piano and violin studies at the music department of the St Joseph’s College of Quezon City from grade five to high school. She played organ accompaniment to choir singing in masses and benedictions in church as well as in school functions. Del Valle entered the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music in the mid-1950s and completed the teachers’ diploma and bachelor of music in piano, 1959 and 1961 respectively, as well as a master of music in music education degree in 1970. While a faculty member of the College of Music from 1969 to 2005, she studied performance in Japanese Koto, Maguindanao kulintang, Kalinga nose flute, lip valley flute, and Indonesian gamelan. She has done field work and research on the musics of the Bontok, Yakan, Tausug, and Mansaka, the folk music of Bohol as well as the indigenous musics of seven tribes of Yunnan Province, China.

As a musician she has performed works of Filipino composers, including contemporary piano pieces of composer Ramon Santos and other ASEAN composers, mostly during festivals and conferences. She has also joined other musicians and students in performing several works of the composer and ethnomusicologist Jose Maceda. She has also written articles on music and music education in several local and foreign publications.

As a music educator and leader, she was chair of the UP Music Education Department for five terms and program director of the College Extension programs for 15 years. She has worked for many years in various capacities with the Department of Education, National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), Commission for Higher Education (CHED) National Competition for Young Artists Foundation (NAMCYA), Musical Arts and Research Management Foundation (MUSARFOUND) and the Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines (PTGP). As president of the Philippine Society for Music Education (PSME) since 2000, she has expanded the programs of the organization, initiated new projects in the study and performance of Philippine music, included nongovernment organizations and community cultural workers in advancing music education, and organized music educators to train teachers teaching music in various parts of the country.

She was a recipient of a UP Diamond Jubilee Award from the University as well as an Outstanding Award for Meritorious Performance and Service in Education and the Arts from her alma matter, St Joseph’s College of Quezon City

DELARMENTE, RODOLFO (Rodolfo Francisco Delarmente) aka Boy Delarmente. b. Pasay City 18 Nov 1947. Choral conductor, educator. He is the son of George Delarmente, an amateur pianist, and Dolores Francisco, a coloratura soprano who sang in church in Moncayo Davao. Rodolfo is married to Leticia Olayao. They have three children.

He received a bachelor’s degree in music education from the University of the East in 1969. He has conducted several choral groups in Metro Manila such as the St Mary’s Academy Glee Club of Pasay City, Pasay Kabataang Barangay Community Choir, The Canticle Choir, The RVM Sisters’ Chorus, and the Sofitel Choir. At present, he is the conductor of the DLSU Chorale.

From 1980 until 1989, he led the St Mary’s Academy Glee Club to win in the regional and national championships in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) Youth Choir Competitions and, from 1992 to 1994, in the Rotary Youth Choir Competitions. He conducted the Pasay Kabataang Barangay Community Choir which won the championships in the National Himig ng Kabataan Choral Competition from 1982 to 1984. He also directed the The Dusit Hotel Choir which garnered grand prizes in the Inter-Hotel Choral Competition from 1981 to 1983. His Canticle Choir captured the grand prize in the NAMCYA Adult Choir Competition in 1998. The Canticle Choir was awarded the Most Outstanding Cultural Group in 1982 at the Malacañan Palace, with Delarmente as the Most Outstanding Choral Conductor of the Year. He also bagged the Catholic Mass Media Award in 1986.

Delarmente led the DLSU Chorale in its 1995 European Tour and swept the grand prizes in all the competitions in Italy, France, Finland, Sweden, The Netherlands, Austria, and Spain. In 2010, DLSU Chorale won the second prize in the chamber choir competition in Llangollen Choir of the World Choral Contest.

As a specialist in choral directing, Delarmente has served as consultant in different community and government choirs and has been invited as lecturer in different choral workshops in the Philippines and abroad. He has also been an adjudicator in different choral competitions in the country. In 1999, he was invited to the World Music Symposium in Rotterdam and attended a choral workshop where he presented a lecture-demonstration about his setting of Philippine ethnic music into a choral composition. Among his works for choir are: “Dumbele,” 1980, lyrics by Ramon Obusan; “Ilay Gandangan,” 1982, based on Maguindanao folk song; “Ama Namin” (Our Father), 2000, based on an Ifugao folk song; “Mag-aman” (In Tandem), based on a harvest song from Bacolod; and “Padayon” (Moving Forward), 2010, composed by Bob Aves, based on a welcome song from Mindanao. In 2002, he was invited as guest conductor in the Asian Youth Choir in Niigata Prefecture, Japan. Written byAntonio C. Hila

DEMETILLO, LESTER (Lester Delariarte Demetillo) b. Dumaguete City 8 Sep 1953. Classical guitarist, guitar pedagogue. His parents are Ricaredo Demetillo, a poet and English professor, and Angelita Delariarte, a church organist. His sister Becky Demetillo is a singer, while his brother-in-law, Edru Abraham, heads the Kontra-GaPi. Growing up at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman campus where his father taught, Demetillo spent his childhood filled with poetry readings at home and Sundays picnics by the UP lagoon listening to the university orchestra. He learned to play the guitar from a family friend as a teenager and was soon obsessed with the instrument, playing the popular songs of his generation. He became proficient enough in the instrument to play professionally in folk houses. His very first break came when his sister Becky, then a regular singer at the famous Butterfly House outside UP campus, needed a substitute guitarist. With his skilful guitar playing and fine singing, Demetillo soon became one of the top folk singers in Manila, becoming the main feature in places such as the Kola House in Ermita and the Appaloosa Bar in Quezon City. He would later form a band with his high school friends called the Silver Grass, which played in campus events such as the Folkways concerts sponsored by the Beta Sigma Fraternity. The band would become his “laboratory” for learning musical arranging and song writing.

Shifting from a previous college course in UP Manila, Demetillo decided to audition at the UP College of Music and got accepted as a composition major. However, in one session with his composition professor Eliseo M. Pajaro, where he was presenting a piece he wrote for guitar, the old man profusely complimented his guitar playing and urged him to shift his major to guitar. At that time, the only guitar professor in UP was Jose Ma. Pellicer whom Demetillo remembers as a kindhearted and jolly teacher. Later, after securing a special permission from the college, he transferred to another teacher, well-known violinist and conductor Sergio Esmilla. Although Esmilla was not a guitarist, his mentorship allowed Demetillo to sharpen his musicality and sight reading skills. In 1980, Demetillo joined the faculty of the UP College of Music Department of Strings and developed its guitar program, which is still implemented today and which has produced some of the country’s top classical guitarists.

Outside UP, Demetillo has given master classes in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia and serves as an examiner for the Associated Board of Royal Schools in Indonesia. He has performed at the American Colleges in Chicago, Sejong Hall in Korea, Melbourne Concert Hall, and the Chuo Center Hall in Osaka. He also founded the UP Guitar Orchestra, the first of its kind in the country, for which he continues to produce arrangements and transcriptions. He remains active in the local concert scene, performing up to 50 shows annually. Recently, Lester also began concertizing on the mandolin and the banjo. Written byVerne de la Peña

DIOQUINO, CORAZON C. (Paz Corazon Gloria Canave-Dioquino) aka Cora Dioquino. b. 3 Jun 1933. Historical musicologist, music history teacher, pianist. She is the daughter of Juan Castro Canave and Paz Panopio Gloria. She was married to Manuel Dioquino, an air force pilot who died in a plane crash. They had five children. She was the valedictorian of the Assumption Convent High School class of 1949. In 1952, she finished her bachelor of music, magna cum laude, at the Catholic University of America, Washington, DC and in the following year, her masters of music, major in piano and minor in musicology. At the same university, she finished her doctor of philosophy in 1955, major in historical musicology with a minor in history of education and a second minor in music education. Her doctoral dissertation was on Carl Philipp Emmanuel Bach’s keyboard sonatas. She is the only Filipino with a doctorate decree in historical musicology.

Her teaching career at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music started in 1957. She assisted Jose Maceda in managing and classifying the collection of field-recorded traditional Philippine music and related field notes and photographs, now housed in the UP Center for Ethnmusicology. She also co-edited the Musika Jornal from 1977 to 1979. As a music educator, she played a crucial role in formulating the existing degree programs such as the Diploma in Creative Performing Musical Arts (DCPMA), Bachelor of Music (BM), and Master of Music (MM), as well as the dance program of the UP College of Music. For decades, she contributed to the field of musicology at the UP College of Music by teaching Western art music history and forms and analysis subjects, which were required for music majors. Among her students were Francisco F. Feliciano and Ramon P. Santos, both of whom later became National Artists for Music. Her mentorship can be also seen in the masteral theses submitted by her advisees to the UP College of Music, many of whom became leaders in the field of music, such as Leticia L. Guevara, Imelda C. Ongsiako, Asuncion Laureola, Mauricia Borromeo, Helen F. Samson, Emmanuel Laureola, Sr Lilia Therese L. Tolentino, Melissa Mantaring, Flerida C. Garde-Nolasco, and Racquel Georsua.

Some of Dioquino’s more important research outputs are in the field of bibliography and organology. Dioquino contributed articles to the Filipino Heritage, 1978, and to the Cultural Center of the Philippines Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994, whose music volume she co-edited with Ramon P. Santos. She also wrote articles for the National Research Council of the Philippines, for The Garland Encyclopedia of World Music (Vol 4, Southeast Asia), and for Humanities Diliman. Her article “Musicology in the Philippines,” which appeared in Acta Musicologica, 1982, continues to be a useful guide to students of Philippine music. She also contributed an essay in Kasaysayan: The Story of the Filipino People, Vol 2, 1998; and a music analytical paper in The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay, 2009. Written byJosephine Baradas

DLSU CHORALE Founded in 1987, the De La Salle University Chorale is the official choral group of De La Salle University Manila. Composed of students from its different colleges, the choir has served the university. In its early years, with Noel Bugarin as conductor, the group gave formal concerts and participated in local choral concerts where it garnered top prizes. The choir received invitations to perform in Tokyo, Japan in 1989 and in the International Choral Festival in Ancona, Italy in 1990.

In 1992, conductor Rodolfo Delarmente took over and the choir participated in its first international choral competition in the 46th Llangollen International Musical Eisteddfod in Wales, England. The group garnered awards for the folkloric and chamber choir categories in that competition. In 1995, the group bagged the top prizes in international choral competitions all over Europe. The tour brought home a total of six first prizes and two grand prix awards from Arnhem, The Netherlands and Tampere, Finland. In Finland, the group bested 53 other choirs from all over the world with three first prizes—the highest recognition given in that festival. In the every-four-year Arnhem International Choir Festival, the DLSU Chorale had taken home the grand prix, public’s choice award, folkloric, light music a capella, and mixed choir awards. In Cantonigros, Spain, the group won first prize in the folkloric category and second prize in the mixed choir category. In Sweden, the group won first prize in the mixed and folkloric choir categories. The choir repeated the same feat in 1999 when the choir won first prize in the mixed choir category in St Petersburg, Russia and first prize in folkloric category in Polheim, Germany. In 2004, the group won first prize in folkloric category in Debrecen, Hungary. In 2010, the group embarked on a North American-European tour. They competed again in the 2010 Llangollen International Musical Eisteddfod where they placed second in the chamber choir category.

In 2013, the chorale has garnered a long list of top prizes in some competitions in Europe. The group won the grand prix in the 3rd International Choral Competition-Kaunas Cantat in Kauna, Lithuania, where they also bagged the gold prizes for the adult chamber choir category, polyphonic category, and the folkloric category. In the 41st Festival of Songs in Oloumuc, Czech Republic, the choir took the gold in the adult chamber choir category, gold for spiritual, gospel, pop categories, and gold in the folkloric category. At the 11th International Choir Competition-Antonio Vivaldi in Karpenissi, Greece, the choir garnered the first prize in the adult chamber choir category. It also bagged the first prize at the 31st International Choral Competition of Sacred Music in Perveza, Greece.

Apart from competing, the DLSU Chorale reaches out to Filipino and foreign audiences with concerts all over the world. In 2002, the group embarked on its first North American Tour, visiting several cities in the United States and Canada. The tour was so successful that the chorale was invited again in 2004 with more performance engagements. The choir’s growing reputation has paved the way for more organizers inviting the choir to perform for their communities. This has led to three invitations in 2001, 2005, and 2007 to South Korea. The group continues to have a growing audience and enjoy cordial relationship with local Koreans.

Despite its busy schedule abroad, the DLSU Chorale also shares its music locally. Apart from its regular concert season and outreach concert to various local communities and churches, the DLSU Chorale performs for charitable causes that promote choral, classical, and Filipino music. Written byAntonio C. Hila

ERASERHEADS aka Eheads. This rock band was founded in late 1989 by combining two college bands—Curfew and Sunday School—at the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman. The trio of Raimund Marasigan (drums), Buddy Zabala (bass), and Marcus Adoro (guitar) of Curfew was a group based at the UP Narra Residence Hall. They joined Ely Buendia (guitar, vocals) from Sunday School, which was a group from the UP Molave Residence Hall. The new quartet called themselves The Eraserheads, lifting the name from a movie Eraserhead by the director David Lynch. Robin Rivera, a humanities teacher from the university, worked with the group as recording engineer, and they recorded the privately circulated cassette album Pop-U! in 1991, which eventually led to a three-year recording contract with BMG Records Pilipinas two years later in 1993.

The Eraserheads’ first album Ultraelectromagneticpop! was shipped by BMG in Oct 1993 with 5,000 initial units. These escalated to an excess of 200,000 copies, thus leading to its certification by the Philippine Association of the Recording Industry as a “7X Platinum Record.” The album’s quirky production style, with novelty singles like “Pare Ko” (My Dude), “Tindahan ni Aling Nena” (Mrs. Nena’s Variety Store), “Ligaya” (Happiness), and “Toyang” caused a commercial avalanche in the Original Pilipino Music (OPM) industry and the country’s independent music scene.

On the heels of their astounding debut in 1993, the Eraserheads lost no time in creating chart-topping albums in yearly succession, bringing their mentor Robin Rivera to the fold as their album producer of choice. Circus, 1994, which sold 214,000 copies, a “7X Platinum Record,” and Cutterpillow, 1995, which sold 400,000 copies, a “14X Platimum or Diamond Record,” surpassed expectations. In 1996, the elaborate Christmas album and EP titled Fruitcake, sold 122,000 copies, a “3X Platinum Record,” complemented by a matching Fruitcake book from Anvil Publishing. This album marked a turning point in the Eraserheads output, moving their direction into more serious compositional works. In mid-1997, they once again released an EP titled Bananatype, featuring the song “Tikman” (Taste) that became a Burger Machine commercial. The same year, they went to California for the first of many similar engagements in the United States and the rest of the world, to perform at The Palace in Hollywood and the Calvin Simmons Auditorium in Oakland. Soon after, BMG Pilipinas released the fifth Eraserheads album, Sticker Happy, 1997, which sold 55,000 copies, becoming a platinum record.

By then, Ely Buendia’s iconic composition from the Cutterpillow album of 1995, “Ang Huling El Bimbo” (The Last El Bimbo) had won much critical praise for its imagery, while its music video won the International Viewer’s Choice Awards for Asia at the 1997 MTV Video Music Awards. Their later albums elicited mixed reactions: Aloha Milkyway, 1998, a compilation album for the ASEAN market; Natin 99 (Ours 99), 1999; and their unforeseen swansong Carbon Stereoxide, 2000. In Mar 2002, management problems brought Ely Buendia to effectively leave the group. Kris Gorra, the singer-guitarist from the all-female band, Fatal Posporos, was recruited to join the Marasigan, Zabala, and Adoro trio, now renamed the Eheads, to fulfill the band’s remaining contractual obligations, with a self-produced independent EP, titled “Please Transpose” issued in 2003.

In Oct 2003, Marcus Adoro had similarly quit and the Eheads changed their name once again, becoming the reformulated band, Cambio, with Marasigan, Zabala, and Gorra, joined by Ebe Dancel from Sugarfree and Diego Mapa from Monsterbot. They released two albums for the MCA Music label, namely Derby Light, 2004, and Matic, 2007. In 2004, BMG released the two-volume compilation Eraserheads Anthology, with resurgent sales of 209,000 units, creating a demand for lucrative, enormously budgeted reunion engagements and recordings such as the concert and album Eraserheads: The Reunion Concert, 2008, and the bonus CD single, which was distributed in the Sep 2014 issue of Esquire Magazine Philippines.

Eraserheads is the recipient of the following awards from NU Rock Awards: Album of the Year for Ultraelectromagneticpop!, Listener’s Choice Award, and Band of the Year, 1995; Album of the Year for Circus, 1995, and Cutterpillow, 1996; Best Music Video and Song of the Year for “Ang Huling El Bimbo,” 1996; Artist of the Year, Listener’s Choice Award, and Best Video for “Fruitcake,” 1997; and Hall of Fame, 2003. They were recognized as the Most Favorite Band in 1995 and Most Popular Group in 1997 by the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Awards. In the Awit Awards, they won Best Performance by a Group for “Ligaya,” 1994; Album of the Year for Cutterpillow, 1996, and Eraserheads: The Reunion Concert, 2009; and Best Alternative Recording for “Fruitcake,” 1997, and “Julie Tearjerky,” 1999. They received the Awit Awards’ Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino in 2012. From Katha Music Awards, they won the following: Album of the Year and Best Rock Album for Cutterpillow, Best Rock Song for “Ang Huling El Bimbo,” and Best Rock Group, all in 1996; and Best Rock Vocal Performance for “Fruitcake,” 1997. Eraserheads also won the MTV Pilipinas Lifetime Achievement Award in 2004 and the MYX Magna Award in 2009. Written byJuan Bautista H. Alegre

ESMILLA, JOSEPH (Joseph Porciuncula Esmilla) b. Quezon City 6 Oct 1963. Violinist. Born to Sergio Esmilla Jr and Araceli Porciuncula, he attended the University of Santo Tomas (UST), the Notre Dame of Greater Manila, and the Susan Wagner High School in the United States. At the age of five, he started violin lessons with his father and, at eight, studied under Oscar Yatco. He then entered the Juilliard School of Music as a scholar. He finished his bachelor’s and master’s degrees in violin at the Juilliard School, under Dorothy De Lay, Jens Ellerman, and Masao Kawasaki. He later did postgraduate work at the Mannes College of Music with Felix Galimir. While at Mannes, he won the concerto competition in 1985, which earned him the honor to perform Max Bruch’s ViolinConcertoNo. 1G minor with the Mannes Orchestra under the baton of Yakov Kreizberg. In 1985, he was also one of 12 pupils in the seminar course in violin with Sandor Vegh in Salzburg, Austria, which is held in conjunction with the annual Salzburg Music Festival; and a scholar at the International Music Camp at Interlochen, Michigan for two months. He also participated in the music festivals of Aspen, Colorado; Salzburg, Austria; and Dartington, United Kingdom. He took advanced professional studies in violin and chamber music with Arnold Steinhardt and John Dalley of the Guarneri Quartet.

Esmilla was first violinist of the Philippine Youth Orchestra since its founding in 1975 and was its assistant concertmaster before he left for the United States. He was among those chosen to participate in the First International Chamber Music Festival organized by the Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1976; a member of the Philippine Youth Orchestra which formed the core of the First Asian Regional Music Camp Orchestra, 1977; and Philippine representative to the World Congress of the Jeunesses Musicales International in Seoul, Korea, 1977. Upon the invitation of Dean Liebermann of the International Summer Academy, he performed as soloist at the Concert of the Best Students during the Salzburg Festival. He served as the concertmaster of the Manila Chamber Orchestra, the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO), and the Detmold Chamber Orchestra, and he was associate conductor of the Manila Chamber Orchestra. He also played for the Harrisburg Symphony Orchestra.

Esmilla has been featured as a soloist with the MSO, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, Manila Chamber Orchestra, Cleveland State University Orchestra, and Shippensburg Festival Chamber Orchestra. He has extensively concertized as a chamber musician and soloist in the United States, Germany, Austria, Malaysia, South Korea and the Philippines. He was also featured in the Harrisburg Opera production of Lehar’s Paganini, in which he performed the violin solos. Esmilla became the first Filipino violinist to be a member of the World Youth Symphony Orchestra. In recent years, Esmilla has worked with the MSO as guest conductor in the concert titled Forces of Nature in 2010, and as soloist in the Philippine premier of Erich Wolfgang Korngold’s Violin Concerto in D Major, Op. 35 in a concert titled A New World in 2010.

He has recorded Sentimyento (Sentiment), a collection of encore pieces, with pianist Albert Tiu, under Bookmark Audio in 2000; Concierto para Trio (Concert for Three), a collection of pieces by Spanish and South American classical composers, with Triode, a piano trio composed of Albert Tiu (piano), Joseph Esmilla (violin), and Sean Katsuyama (cello), under Northbrach Records in 2003; and Eaken Trio + 1, with the Eaken Piano Trio of Philadelphia, under Con Brio in 2010.

Esmilla has been on the faculty of the UST Conservatory of Music, University of the Philippines College of Music, Towson University in Baltimore, Maryland, Elizabethtown College, and Shippensburg University in Pennsylvania. He was the music director and conductor of Shippensburg’s University/Community Orchestra for its 2007-08 concert season.Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

ESMILLA, SERGIO (Sergio Zalamea Esmilla Jr) b. Manila 22 Feb 1927. d. Quezon City 23 May 2017. Violinist, conductor. He is the second of eight children of Leonila Zalamea, a piano teacher before her marriage, and Sergio Esmilla, a municipal judge in Laguna and a music lover. Esmilla is married to Araceli Porciuncula and they have four children, of whom two are also musicians: Joseph, a violinist, and Rosario, a pianist.

His musical education began early, with piano lessons given by his mother when he was five, and solfeggio lessons with Valentin Borlaza and violin lessons with a cousin of his mother and retired University of the Philippines (UP) teacher Cayetano Jacobe when he was seven. At age 10, he began private lessons under Ramon Tapales, and later became the pupil of Ernesto Vallejo. After World War II and before entering college, he took solfeggio lessons under Hilarion Rubio. He would have wanted to become a doctor, if not for his father’s objections—and so he studied instead at the UP Conservatory of Music, obtaining a teacher’s diploma in violin in 1948. In 1953-54, he pursued a music degree at University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music, then in 1956 went to the United States for masteral courses in violin and chamber music at the Julliard School of Music. He also took postgraduate studies in chamber music and conducting at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore. He considers Edward Dethier and Raphael Hillver as the two persons who exerted the most influence on the development of his music. Two years later, he returned to the Philippines, unable to continue his studies due to lack of funds.

Esmilla’s first job, at 18, was with the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO). Afterwards, he performed as a soloist for the Manila Municipal Symphony Orchestra (MMSO) in their concerts in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Hawaii. From 1949 to 1954 he was assistant concertmaster of the Manila Little Symphony under Federico Elizalde. He rejoined this orchestra upon returning from abroad in 1958. In 1960, he performed Barber’s Violin Concerto in its Philippine premiere at St Scholastica’s College. Upon the special request of Dame Margot Fonteyn, he played the violin solos for her 1961 performances in Manila and Hong Kong. He has taught violin at the La Concordia College, the UST where he was director of the conservatory in 1964, and the UP where he taught from 1969 until his retirement in 1993. For a time, he headed the UP College of Music’s strings and chamber music department. He was also invited to teach violin at the Philippine High School for the Arts after its establishment in 1978.

He was a member of the Manila String Quartet from 1956 to 1962 and the UP String Quartet from 1969 to 1979. He was the music director of the Philippine Youth Orchestra from its organization in 1974 until its temporary discontinuation in 1987 by the new administration of the UP College of Music. He was able to lead the PYO on a successful concert tour of Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taiwan in 1979. In 1987, upon the establishment of the Manila Chamber Orchestra Foundation by Tony Ozaeta and Armando Baltazar, Esmilla was chosen to be its music director, and since then, he led the orchestra until its dissolution in 1993. Thereafter, Esmilla retired from his professional teaching positions at the UST Conservatory of Music and the Philippine High School for the Arts, but he remained active until his death. He developed young musicians by giving private lessons and holding string orchestra workshops, the most recent of which was the Berkeley Square String Orchestra Workshop in Aug 2015, for the newly opened Suonare Music Center in Quezon City, where Esmilla was a consultant and a special instructor for violin. Written byEdna Marcil M. Martinez,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

ESPEJO, CELSO (Celso Ona Espejo) b. Barangay Abra, San Jose, Batangas 6 Apr 1936. Conductor, rondalla teacher. His parents were Luis B. Espejo and Gliceria C. Ona. Celso married Nena Villamor Garcia, with whom he has five children. He received his elementary education from P. Ulan Elementary School, San Jose, Batangas and finished high school at San Jose College, San Jose, Batangas. He holds an elementary teacher’s certificate and a bachelor of science in education degree from the Lyceum of the Philippines in Manila.

At age eight, Espejo trained in his family’s comparsa in San Jose, Batangas. Founded by his grandfather, Marcos Espejo, the Espejo Comparsa was composed of 12 members, namely Celso, his father, uncle, and tenants of his grandfather. The group played boleros, waltzes, tangos, and kundiman during weddings, baptisms, and anniversaries. Espejo initially played the guitar which he learned from his brother and then eventually played the other instruments of the ensemble such as the bandurria, banjo, banjo-laud, and bajo de unas.

As a teacher, Espejo first taught a rondalla which was comprised of teachers in the Pedro Paterno Elementary School in Calaca, Batangas. He then transferred to Manila after one year. In Manila, he taught several rondalla groups in Pasay (Timoteo Paez, Zamora), Cainta, Las Piñas, Quezon City (Novaliches, Philippine Union College, Marcelo Elementary School), and Parañaque. For a period of almost 20 years, he produced several prizewinning rondalla groups in Pio Del Pilar High School in Parañaque. Aside from the school rondallas, he also mentored a senior citizens’ rondalla in Malibay, Pasay. With almost 40 years of teaching rondalla to children and adults alike, Espejo garnered first prizes in at least six national rondalla contests including the Hamon sa Kampeon (Champ’s Challenge) in the 1960s as well as first prizes in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) rondalla competitions for both elementary and high school levels.

In the 1980s, Espejo and three other rondalla masters formed the Pambansang Samahan ng Rondalla (PASARON) to promote the rondalla through workshops, competitions, and festivals. Espejo became the first president of PASARON. Espejo conducted rondalla seminars nationwide for PASARON and NAMCYA as well as during the three International Rondalla Festivals held in Naga, Dumaguete, and Tagum. In 2002, he founded the Celso Espejo Rondalla (CER) which has been praised by rondalla enthusiasts for its bandurria virtuosity and “symphonic” sound. Aside from directing the CER in concerts and recordings, Espejo served as the chairman of the board of judges for the NAMCYA rondalla competitions and has also written the Celso Espejo Rondalla Method Book. During the 4th International Rondalla Festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines on 16 Feb 2014, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts awarded the Gawad Rondalla to Celso Espejo in recognition of his contributions to the development and appreciation of rondalla music in the Philippines. Written byJocelyn Timbol Guadalupe

Sources:

Aning 2007; Celso Espejo Rondalla Facebook page; Espejo 2013; National Commission for Culture and the Arts 2014; Timbol-Guadalupe 2012.

ESTANISLAO, AURELIO (Aurelio Santos Estanislao) b. Bocaue, Bulacan 13 Aug 1923. d. 14 Nov 1978. Singer, teacher, actor. His parents are Ysmaela Santos and Aurelio Estanislao Sr, a pianist; his grandfather was a clarinet player who founded two bands in Bocaue. Estanislao studied at University of the Philippines (UP) where he received a degree in history, magna cum laude, in 1953. From 1947-50, he took up voice lessons with JovitaFuentes under a Barredo scholarship at the UP College of Music. He was awarded the Premier Prix du chant from the Conservatoire National de Musique de Paris where he studied in 1952 under Gabriel Paulet, Germaine Martinelli, and Pierre Bernac. He also took up graduate studies in voice at the Mozarteum in Salzburg, Austria (under Stoja Millinkovic, Ernst Reichart, and Bernhard Paumgartner), and at the Music Academy of the West in Santa Barbara, California (under Lotte Lehmann).

While a student, he received a Rockefeller Foundation grant-in-aid as a research assistant at the UP. He first started out as a history instructor and later traveled to France on a French government scholarship to the Université de Paris in Sorbonne where he received his master’s degree in history (or Diplôme d’études universitaires en historie modern et contemporaine) in 1953. In 1957, he won a teaching assistantship in history at the University of California, Los Angeles. Shortly after, he gave up his interest in history and devoted himself entirely to music.

Estanislao, the country’s only exponent of lieder singing in his time, has prizes in major musical competitions in Europe and performed under world-famous conductors like Ernest Ansermet and Thor Johnson, and with major orchestras like the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande. He also recorded for London Decca and Columbia Masterworks.

Estanislao also performed onstage. He played the role of the comic servant Lukas in SeverinoReyes’ WalangSugat (No Wounds); appeared in ServandodelosAngeles’ AngKiri (The Flirt); and was Charlemagne in the komedya Principe Baldovino (Prince Baldovino), and the king in the highly successful staging of Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I. He also played Crispin in SinoBaKayo? (Who Are You?).

Estanislao won major prizes at the 1954 International Music Competition in Geneva, Switzerland; the 1954 International Music Competition in Munich, Germany; and the International Music Competition in Bosch, Holland. He was a recipient of the Manila Times award as outstanding young man in music, 1955; Filipino Musician Award, UP Conservatory of Music, 1956; Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) award for music, 1959; and the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, 1978. Written byMa. Lourdes Maniquis, Antonio C. Hila, and Ma. Patricia Brillantes

ESTELLA, JOSE (Jose Atanacio Barredo Estella) aka Jose Estrella. b. Escolta, Manila 1870. d. 6 Apr 1943. Composer, conductor, pianist. He is the father of film director Ramon Estella. He studied at the Conservatory of Music in Madrid, Spain and was the director of the all-Filipino Orquesta Rizal in 1898. He was also the piano teacher of Francisco Roxas (1896 martyred revolutionary supporter) and Nicanor Abelardo. He married Matilde Tronqued, then aged 16, a daughter of an actor in Compania de Yeyeng Fernandez, in 1903 (Tronqued de Estella Diary).

Estella was active as a composer of musical theater from the 1890s to around 1912. He composed the music of the Spanish zarzuela El Diablo Mundo (Devil’s World), which inaugurated the opening of Teatro Zorrilla in 1893. Estella’s works for the stage include: the one-act opera Veni, Vidi, Vici (I Came, I Saw, I Conquered), 1904; and the sarsuwela Ang Opera Italiana (The Italian Opera), La Venta de Filipinas al Japon (The Sale of the Philippines to Japan), and Sangla ni Rita (Rita’s Pawn). He also composed a three-act opera in Tagalog called Lakambini (Muse) with libretto by Patricio Mariano, for the opening of Manila Metropolitan Theater in 1931.

Most of his piano compositions were valse, which earned him the title the “Waltz King” of the Philippines. He had a dance orchestra which performed the valses. He is said to have written more than 100 waltzes, most popular of which was “Ang Maya” (The Sparrow), composed earlier for the sarsuwela Filipinas para los Filipinos (Philippines for the Filipinos), 1905, by Severino Reyes. This piece was later recorded by soprano Maria Carpena, and is one of the earliest examples of a Filipino popular music hit.

In the realm of art music, he completed Filipinas (Philippines) in 1928, which is the first extant symphony in the Philippines. This work is based on traditional Filipino tunes and rhythms of the balitaw, kundiman, and other folk songs. He also wrote a large work Ultimo Adios (Last Farewell), a symphonic tone poem for orchestra based on Rizal’s poem.

As light classical music composer, Estella was famous for his “costumbrista” suites that depicted local characters and scenes. He generically titled these Cancionero Filipino (Filipino Songbook). They were written between 1887 to 1929. His first cancionero, titled “Naci en Binondo” (I Was Born in Binondo), 1887, appeared alone in a manuscript that is now archived in the University of the Philippines College of Music Library. Subsequent canciones appeared as song collections and were written for various performance media. The first Cancionero Filipino was for an orchestra, only the first movement (De Jarana) of which is extant. The second Cancionero Filipino, also for orchestra and dated 1928-29, is in the style of impressionism. It consists of “El Amanecer en el Campo” (Dawn in the Fields), “El Medio Dia” (Midday), and “La Noche” (Night). The third Cancionero Filipino, also for orchestra, seems to be a reworking of his first and contained scenes of romantic love and courtship: “De Jarana” (Like a Serenade), “La Emprentada” (The Printer), “Declaracion de Amor” (Declaration of Love), and “La Retirada” (The Recluse).

Other cancioneros are extant. Cancionero Filipino a 2 Voces y Quinteto Cuerdas (Songs for Two Voices and String Quintet) was dedicated to Natividad Ocampo de Arellano, then president of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, and was premiered on 6 Dec 1922 at the Manila Grand Opera House. Another cancionero consists of “Tristezas” (Dolours), “En El Batis” (By the Stream), and “Sa Iyo” (To You). Another cancion Filipino, with heteroglossic linguistic titles, has “Buhay Ko” (My Life), a kundiman; “En Hamaca” (In a Hammock), a danza; and “Alaut” (Disgrace), a balitaw. He also composed a cancionero based on Cebuano music and which contains Cebuano Songs: “La Bibinquera” (Female Rice Cake Vendor), “Kamingaw” (Loneliness) based on an old Visayan Song, and “Sa Imong Saad” (According to Your Promise) for baritone and piano. Estella self-published the pieces in his last two cancioneros as separate sheet music for voice and piano. In these works, Estella contributed to the elevation of folkloric Philippine music and to the creation of a patriotic awareness for the uniqueness of Philippine music.Written byAntonio C. Hila,updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

FELICIANO, FRANCISCO (Francisco Francisco Feliciano) b. Morong, Rizal 19 Feb 1941. d. Quezon City 19 Sep 2014. Composer, educator, and conductor. National Artist for music. One of the nine children of Maximiano Feliciano and Julia Francisco, he is married to Rebecca Herrera with whom he has two children. Feliciano first learned music from his father, who owned and led a brass band. He took formal training in music at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, where he earned a teacher’s diploma in composition and conducting in 1964, and a bachelor’s degree in music in 1967. He also obtained a diploma in music composition from the Hochschulefür Musik in Berlin, Germany in 1977. He was an outstanding graduate student at the Yale University School of Music in 1979 where he also obtained the degree doctor of musical arts in composition in 1984. While at Yale, he also conducted the Yale Contemporary Ensemble, considered as one of the leading performing groups in America for contemporary and avant-garde music.

He received scholarship grants from the JDR III Fund for music composition, 1977-80; Lee Foundation Scholarship in Singapore; and Diakonishes Werk Scholarship and Berliner Kirchenmusikschule Scholarship in Germany. He was also a scholar to the 1976 International Summer Courses for Modern Music in Darmstadt, West Germany. Feliciano was resident conductor of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, 1981-86, and he was a member of the League of Filipino Composers.In 1980, he founded the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music and served as its Director until his demise in 2014. From 1998 to 2001, he was the dean of the PWU College of Music.

Feliciano’s orchestral works include Prelude and Toccata, 1973; Fragments and Die Verklarung Christi, 1976; Variation uberein Gestalt, 1977; Transfiguration, for orchestra, chorus and narrator, 1983; Pagdakila sa Kordilyera (Ode to Cordillera), 1987; and Missa Mysterium: Misang Sambayanang Pilipino (The Mystery Mass: Mass of the Filipino People), for soloists, chorus and orchestra, 1995. Among his music for theater are: the three-act opera, La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), 1984, with libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio; the music drama Sikhay sa Kabila ng Paalam (Zeal Despite Goodbye), 1993, with libretto by Sedfrey Ordoñez and Beth Nacion-Puyot; the opera Ashen Wings, 1995, with libretto by Anton Juan Jr and Beth Nacion-Puyot; and the Philippine Women’s University commissioned opera on the occasion of its 80th anniversary, Dangal ng Lahi (Honor of the Race), 2000, an opera on the life and death of Jose Abad Santos, with libretto translated by Anton Juan Jr; as well as the music for the ballet, Yerma, 1982, with choreography by Anton Juan Jr.

Among the chamber music pieces he has composed are: Stuck fur Neun Instrumenten, 1975; String Quartet No. 1, 1977; Piece for Six Percusssions and Eight Character Pieces for solo timpani, five timpani, trombone, bassoon, and contrabass, 1980; Isostasie III for strings and woodwinds, 1981; “Siya-Kuno” (Chaconne/As If) for woodwind quintet, 1990; Voices and Images for strings and percussions, commissioned by the Singapore Arts Council, 1992; Perpetuum Immobile (Forever Motionless), premiered in New York City at the ISCM Festival in 1996; “Kochi,” for flute, clarinet, violoncello and piano, 2002; “Batawa,” for bamboo instruments, 2003; and “Five Songs by Rainer Maria Rilke,” for baritone, clarinet, and string orchestra, 2004. Some of his choral works are: Te Deum, 1978; Bagbagto (for male voices), Si Yahweh ang Aking Pastol (Yahweh Is My Shepherd), and “Pokpok Alimpako,” 1981; Panalangin sa Takipsilim (Prayer at Dusk), 1988; “Pamulinawen,” 1992 “Pamugun,” 1995, “Restless,” 1997, and “Enduken,” 2002. Among his solo pieces are: “Isostasie II” for solo violin and “Ulog” for solo flute, 1979, and “Ading” for shakuhachi, 1980.

He was also the author of Four Asian Composers, published in 1983. Feliciano composed for, edited, and published Sound the Bamboo, 1990, and The AILM Collection: Hymns, Psalms, and Songs for Worship, 2005. His recordings include: Missa Mysterium, 1997; AFP Five Star Band, 1998; and Still I Search for My God, 2010.

His award-winning works are Salimbayan (Hanging Out Together) for woodwind quartet, second prize winner at the 1976 International Composition Contest in Hitzacker, Germany; and “Pokpok Alimpako,” adjudged Best Composition in Contemporary Music at the 1981 International Choral Festival in Arezzo, Italy.

Feliciano is a recipient of the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila in 1983 and was listed in Who’s Who in the World, 8th edition, 1987-88. Feliciano’s conferment of the National Artist Award was signed by the Office of the President Benigno Aquino III in Jun 2014.Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

FELIPE, JULIAN (Julian Reyes Felipe) b. Cavite (now Cavite City), Cavite 28 Jan 1861 d. Sampaloc, Manila 2 Oct 1944. Composer. He was one of the 12 children of Justo Felipe, a tinsmith, and Victoria Reyes. He married Irene Tapia with whom he had five children. He took his elementary schooling at the Recollect Convent and in a public school in his hometown and his secondary education in Binondo, Manila. When he was 10 years old, he began his music lessons under Leandro Cosca. When Cosca died, he studied with Pedro Catalan, a Recollect priest who taught him piano. The aftermath of the 1872 Cavite Mutiny, however, interrupted his studies. Years later, he became official organist of the San Pedro Church of Cavite. He also taught music at the La Sagrada Familia, a local girls’ school.

In 1895, his compositions “Aurorita, Danza” (Early Dawn Danza), “Cintas y Flores” (Ribbons and Flowers), and “Motete al Santisimo” (Motet to the Most Holy), were played at the Regional Exposition in Manila, and earned for him membership in the exclusive Santa Cecilia Musical Society.

During the 1896 Revolution, he was imprisoned at Fort San Felipe, then at FortSantiago, together with the 13 martyrs of Cavite. His 13 companions were sentenced to death, but he was found innocent and released on 2 Jun 1897.

When Emilio Aguinaldo came to power, he commissioned Felipe to put into music the country’s longing for liberty. The result was the “HimnoNacionalFilipino” (Philippine National Hymn), originally titled “Marcha Magdalo” (Magdalo March). It was first played during the proclamation of Philippine independence in Kawit, Cavite on 12 Jun 1898. In Aug 1899, JosePalma wrote the poem “Filipinas” (Philippines) whose words became the lyrics of the national anthem.

After the Philippine-American War, Felipe was elected councilor of Cavite. He was also appointed director of the Banda Nacional of the first Philippine Republic in 1899. In May 1904 he served as bandmaster in the US Navy. Written byFilemon D. Nolasco

FERNANDEZ, ANDION (Andion Hernandez Fernandez) b. Manila 2 Jan 1969. Singer. She is the daughter of Jose Javier Fernandez and Celia Hernandez. She is married to composer Jeffrey Ching, with whom she has two children, Jeffrey Jr and Clara. She studied at the College of the Holy Spirit and the Poveda Learning Center for her elementary and high school education. She took up music at the University of the Philippines but did not complete her course. Since 1990, she has been a scholar of the German Academic Exchange Service, and in 1991, began masteral studies in voice under Karan Armstrong and Ira Hartmann, and contemporary music with Aribert Reimann at the Hochschule der Künste in Berlin, Germany, where she eventually graduated with honors in 2001. While studying in Berlin, Fernandez also won the Zarzuela Prize at Placido Domingo’s Operalia competition in Hamburg in 1998. She also participated at the prestigious BBC Cardiff Singer of the World Competition in 2001, and was adjudged winner of one of the five concerts, the Concert 3 on 12 Jun 2001.

During the Second International Voice Competition of Julian Gayarre in Spain in the early 1980s, Fernandez won a scholarship and a chance to sing with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra of New York. She also received a US Embassy grant which enabled her to visit major music schools in the United States. After winning in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) in 1986 where she sang Brahm’s “Standchen,” she became a resident artist of the Music Theatre Foundation of the Philippines, and a featured soloist of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. At 18, she was chosen by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) to sing the title role of Maria Clara in Felipe Padilla de Leon’s opera, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1987. She was also one of the soloists in the highly acclaimed Messiah Spectacular, also a CCP production.

Fernandez has performed extensively abroad. She performed for the Philippine National Day Concert in the 1992 Universal Exposition in Seville. She also sang at a command performance for the King and Queen of Malaysia and at the wedding of Prince Oscar of Prussia in Hannover, Germany. She performed at the Beethoven Halle in May 1992 and the World Bank auditorium in Washington DC in Feb 1993. She also performed at the Festwochen Herrenhausen in Hannover, the Schloss Sanssouci in Potsdam, the Festspielhaus in Baden Baden, the Gran Teatre del Liceu in Barcelona, the Gulbenkian Auditorium in Lisbon, and at the Kallang Theatre and Victoria Theatre in Singapore. From 2001-10, Fernandez was a soloist of the Deutsche Oper Berlin, and she has also sung for the Deustsche Oper am Rhein, the Deutsche Staatsoper Berlin, and the Nürnberg Oper. She has sung under the baton of distinguished conductors: Leopold Hager, Christopher Hogwood, Mikhail Jurowski, Kent Nagano, Christian Thielemann, Marcello Viotti, and Alberto Zedda.

Among the opera roles she has played were Yum Yum in Gilbert and Sullivan’s The Mikado, Michaela in Bizet’s Carmen, Pamina in Mozart’s The Magic Flute, Susanna in Mozart’s Le Nozze di Figaro, Hänsel in Humperdinck’s Hänsel und Gretel, Emily in Gian Carlo Menotti’s Help! Help! The Globolinks, Niklausse in Offenbach’s Les contes d’Hoffmann, and Rosina in Rossini’s The Barber of Seville. She has also sung the role of Agnes in the premiere recording of Emil von Reznicek’s Ritter Blaubart under the baton of Mikhail Jurowski in 2002. At the world premiere of Symphony No. 5, “Kunstkammer” composed by her husband Jeffrey Ching, in 2006, Fernandez sang the soprano solo part, also with Mikhail Jurowski conducting. Aside from Symphony No. 5, she has premiered the solo parts of many of Ching’s compositions, among them the award-winning opera Das Weisendkind (The Orphan) in Erfurt, Germany in 2009, and Before Brabant in Hong Kong in 2014. She has also sung for the recordings of Ching’s Concerto da Camera, 2009; Bombyx Mori, 2010; Broken Madrigals, 2011; Horologia Sinica, 2012; Diese So-Geliebte, 2013; Raven Mantra, 2013; Qi-cento, 2013; and Wesendonck Sonata, 2013.Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

FERNANDEZ, NARCISA (Narcisa Velos Fernandez) aka Nars Fernandez. b. Davao City 29 Oct 1935. She is the daughter of Miguel Fernandez, a farmer who had his own rondalla and played a number of musical instrumentsand Matilde Velos who sang during social gatherings, including political rallies. She studied at the Fernandez Piano School, a private school in Davao City. In 1969, she graduated with a bachelor of music, major in piano and minor in voice. She took a master’s degree at St Joseph College in Rensellaer, Indiana, and, in 1979, graduated in Church Music and Liturgy, with emphasis on composition.

Inspired by the call of the Catholic Church’s Second Vatican Council towards “inculturation,”she began to compose her own songs in the vernacular for liturgical use. These were simple in composition, easy to learn, and lively and attractive to the young and old.When she joined the Davao City-based John XXIII Catechetical Center, she went around the Archdiocese of Davao and adjacent Dioceses to run liturgical music seminars as well as teach the songs she composed. She was a staff member of this Center from 1972 to 1976.

Her first collection of songs was published by the Daughters of Mary of the Assumption in 1976 under the title Huni sa Kinabuhi I (Tunes of Life), which contained a total of 67 original compositions. Her second collection of original compositions, Huni sa Kinabuhi II, was published by the Archdiocesan Liturgical Center of Davao in 1981 with 36 songs included. In 1986, a third collection, Huni sa Kinabuhi III, was published by the same center with 79 original compositions. Later, after she joined the Communication Foundation of Asia (CFA), her last collection of songs, Ang Bag-ong Huni sa Kinabuhi (The New Tunes of Life), was published bythe CFA in 1996 with 12 original compositions.Her songs have also been recorded on cassette tape by Fr Edgar Labagala of the Bishop Thibault Communication Center of the Archdiocese of Davao.

Some of her songs have become classics and are still popular in Visayas and Mindanao. Her collections include Mass Ordinary, i.e., “Ginoo Kaloy-i Kami” (Lord Have Mercy) and the Lord’s Prayer, “Amahan Namo” (Our Father). Some of her songs that have withstood the test of time are “Ayaw Wad-a ang Paglaum” (Don’t Lose Hope), “Ang Kinabuhi sa Tawo” (The Life of a Person), “Ang Kalinaw Ibilin Ko Kaniyo” (Peace I Will Leave With You), “Daygon Ta ang Ginoo” (Let us Praise the Lord),“Kasaulogan sa Kinabuhi” (Celebration of Life), “Maglipay Kita” (Let Us Be Joyful), “Maria Babaye sa Pagtoo” (Mary Woman of Faith), and “Sa Atong Pagtan-aw sa Panahon” (In Discerning the Signs of the Times). She also wrote songs which critiqued the Marcos dictatorship, namely, “Nganong Naingon Niini Ang Atong Nasud?” (Why Has Our Country Become Like This?), “Gugma sa Katawhan” (Love for the People), and “Ginoo Ikaw Ray Nasayod” (Only You Lord Know What is Happening).

Her awards include the Pioneers of Philippine Liturgical Music Award given by the Jesuit Music Ministry, Manila, in 2005; Certificate of Recognition and Appreciation given by the Diocese of Tagum in 2009; the Assumption Tribute and Special Recognition, given by The Assumption College of Davao, Davao City; and a plaque of appreciation as composer, arranger and singer, given by the Archdiocesan Liturgical Center, Archdiocese of Davao, in 2013.Written byKarl M. Gaspar

FERNANDEZ, POPS (Maria Cielito Lukban Fernandez-Nievera) b. Quezon City 12 Dec 1966. Singer. She is the daughter of former actors Eddie Fernandez and Dulce Lukban. She finished her elementary and high school education at the International School. She was married to singer Martin Nievera with whom she has two sons Robin and Ram Nievera.

Fernandez, hailed as the “Concert Queen,” scored her first hit via the songs “Dito” (Here) and “Just Say You Love Me,” both released in 1982. Her first major concert, Folks Meet Pops, 1983, held at the Folk Arts Theater, launched her as one of the country’s top concert performers. She has staged a number of successful solo concerts, like Sweat it Out and Heading for the Stars,1984; Always, Pops, 1985; Pops Movin’ On, 1987; Awesome, 1988; Out of Control, 1989; Hot Escapade and Twelve-Twelve, 1990; and Just Believe, 1992. With her former husband, she has performed in hit concerts like Twogether, 1985; One Heart, 1987; High on Love and The Awesome Escape, 1988; Out of Control Madness, 1989; King and Queen of Hearts, 1992; and Foursome and Foursome… The Repeat, both in 2013. She has concertized in major concert venues in Manila and has performed in campuses and provinces as well as in the United States, Canada, and Australia. In 12 Dec 2014, she performed once again with Martin Nievera and a host of other guests in their concert The Penthouse Live Reunion Concert, Philippine International Convention Center (PICC) Plenary Hall.

She has produced a number of albums: Pops, 1982; Pops Fernandez in Love, 1983; Heading for the Top, 1984; The Best of Pops Fernandez, 1986; Pops Fernandez Awesome, 1988; Change, 1991; The Way I Feel Inside, 2002, and Moments, 2002; Awesome, 2009; and The Story of Pops Fernandez, 2014. Her hit songs which have received gold record awards are “Dito” and “Just Say You Love Me,” 1982; “Don’t Say Goodbye,” 1989; and “We Can Work it Out,” 1990.

She also starred in movies, some of which are Pag-ibig Pa (More Love), 1982; Always and Forever (The Movie), 1986; Si Mister at si Misis (Husband and Wife), 1987; Sa Puso Ko Hahalik ang Mundo (The Earth Will Kiss My Heart), 1988; Kung Maibabalik Ko Lang (If Only I Can Bring it Back), 1989; Too Young, 1990; Linlang (Deception), 1999; Gusto Ko Nang Lumigaya (I Want to be Happy), 2000; Video King, 2002; and ZsaZsa Zaturnnah Ze Moveeh, 2006. She has also appeared in TV commercials and shows. Some of her notable TV shows include Penthouse Live, 1982-87; P.O.P.S. (Pops On Primetime Saturday), 1992; A.S.A.P. (All-Star Sunday Afternoon Party), 1995-2003; and S.O.P. (Sobrang Okey, Pare!), 2003-04. She has been active lately with fund-raising concerts such as Kami Naman ang Taya (It’s Our Turn), 2013, a benefit concert of pop singers/ artists for the benefit of Yolanda typhoon survivors, held at the Newport Performing Arts Theater, Resorts World Manila. In 21 Sep 2015, she was one of the hosts in the 63rd FAMAS Awards, at the Newport Performing Arts Theater, Resorts World Manila.

Her Awesome album reached gold and platinum marks in 1989 and 1990 respectively. She was also adjudged as Best Concert Performer by the Aliw Awards in 1985, Entertainer of the Year by the Parangal Awards in 1991, Top Female Celebrity Endorser by the Creative Guild in 1991, Most Famous Celebrity Mother by the Gintong Ina Foundation in 1991 and 1992, and Best Musical Variety Show Female Host by the Star Awards in 1992. In 2010, she was given the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation Box-Office Entertainment Awards for Female Concert Performer of the Year. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian,updated by James C. Diaz
Fernandez, Praxedes (See THEATER volume.)

FERRER, ALEGRIA (Alegria Ocampo Ferrer) aka Gay Ferrer. b. Manila 4 Jan 1965. Soprano, stage actress, voice teacher. She is the daughter of Alfredo San Jose Ferrer and Cristina O. Ocampo, both lovers of classical music. Alfredo is the son of Enrica San Jose, who was well known in Pasay, Las Piñas, and Cavite area as a pabasa chanter of the devotional text pasyon (verse narrative on the life and death of Christ) during Lent. Alegria played ukelele in her elementary school years in St Joseph’s Academy in Las Pinas. In third year high school and upon the encouragement of her mother Cristina, she studied voice with Pacita Torralba at Philippine Women’s University. In her fourth year, Alegria had a masterclass with Lilia Reyes who selected her to sing three songs in a student recital held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1980. Lilia Reyes recommended her for further studies in the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, which she began in 1981 under Fides Cuyugan-Asensio.

Alegria joined the UP Concert Chorus in their 1983 European tour as a soloist. In that trip, she auditioned in the Mozarteum Hochschule fur Musik in Salzburg, Austria and passed. She studied in that country for two years in 1984-86, gaining further technique with the eminent German soprano Liselotte Egger. In those two years, Alegria had performances and had masterclasses with Elizabeth Schwarzkopf, Anton Schilawksy, and Herbert von Karajan. She resumed her studies at UP in 1987 and graduated bachelor of music in voice in 1992. She did further work with Fides Cuyugan-Asensio for her master’s degree, which she earned in 1997. For this she refined her dramaturgical stance in opera, a distinguishing characteristic of Asensio’s art. From 1997, Alegria also studied privately with opera aficionado, Antonio Hila, who trained with Mercedes Matias, an Italian educated coloratura who had mastered the art of bel canto.

Alegria began teaching at UP College of Music in 1997. In 1998, she was commissioned by the government and a Japanese Foundation to record a CD compilation of Philippine art songs, titled Alay ng Pag-ibig (Love’s Offering) as part of the centennial celebration commemorating the 1898 Philippine independence from Spain. From 1990s and in the next decade, Alegria performed in notable venues in Manila like the Cultural Center of the Philippines, Concert at the Park, PCI Bank Theater, Meralco Theater, PhilAm Life Auditorium, Puerta Real in Intramuros, and Abelardo Hall Auditorium. As an opera singer, she took on lead roles like Mimi in La Boheme in 1989; Violeta in La Traviata, 2008; Lakme in Lakme in 1993, Euridici in Orpheus and Euridici, 2005; Anastacia in Mayo, Bisperas ng Liwanag (May, On the Eve of Enlightenment) in 1997, and Woman in La Voix Humaine in 1995. As a stage actress, she essayed the roles of Lady Macbeth in Macbeth in 1993, and the title character in Phaedra in 1996. She also had numerous outreach concerts, some of which were accompanied by pianists Regadalo Jose, Nita Quinto, and Mauricia Borromeo, in Angono, Cebu, Davao, Iloilo, Isabela, and Bacolod cities, and in Japan. As a stage director, she did Poulenc’s Dialogues of the Carmelites, 2009; Mozart’s Magic Flute, 2010; The Abduction from the Seraglio, 2014; and Dvorak’s Rusalka. 2014. She also collaborated with Lucio San Pedro, most of whose works for soprano Alegria had interpreted on the concert stage.

For her achievements as a female classical singer, she was awarded the Aliw Awards in 2004, 2006, and 2007. In 2008, she was elevated to the Hall of Fame in the same category in Aliw. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

FILSCAP (The Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers Inc) FILSCAP was organized in 1965 to facilitate the monitoring of performances, mechanical reproduction, and synchronization rights granted by law to creators and owners of original music. It is also a collecting agency in the Philippines, overseeing collective rights management for public performances and use of original music in the television, radio, and movie industry.

FILSCAP is a member of the Paris-based CISAC (Confederation of International Societies of Authors and Composers) and is acknowledged as the only official music copyright society in the Philippines. It adheres to the strict regulations of CISAC. Representing the rights of both local and foreign composers, lyricists, and music publishers, FILSCAP’s role is to monitor and manage for its members the extensive repertoire of copyrighted local and overseas musical works. Application for permission or license is undertaken by an individual or organization with the intent to perform, authorize the performance of, mechanically reproduce and/or synchronize copyrighted music in any form content and method for purposes of profit.

FILSCAP is a membership body consisting of over a thousand gifted individuals that include the most famous names in the local songwriting industry such as national artists for music Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucrecia Kasilag, Levi Celerio, Lucio San Pedro, and Ernani Cuenco, and pop music icons George Canseco, Ryan Cayabyab, Willy Cruz, Jose Mari Chan, and Jim Paredes. FILSCAP remains effective in protecting the legal rights of its members both in the Philippines and overseas.Written byRichie Quirino

FLORANTE (Florante de Leon) aka Boy de Leon. b. 22 Aug 1950. Folk-rock singer, songwriter, acoustic guitarist. He is the son of Isaias de Leon from Pasig, Rizal and Adella Miguel. Isaias died when Florante was 17 years of age. Florante was the youngest in the brood of 15. He is married to Ruth Pestaño and has four children.

At seven, Florante played the ukelele. In 1967, on his second year in high school, he formed a band called The Ludwigs, which was named after the instruments the members used. After less than two weeks of rehearsals, the band was able to play the Beatles, Dave Clark 5, and Zombies in a basketball court. Being the lead guitarist of the band, he was sought after by other bands, some of which he eventually joined. After playing with as many as 14 combos, he performed in Okinawa, Japan for a year.

Early in the 1970s, he performed cover songs by James Taylor and Cat Stevens in folk houses. He later ventured into rock music with a group, playing the songs of Grand Funk and Santana. He started to compose the song titled “Jack of All Trades” but was unable to finish it. This led him to quit singing in English and start composing in Tagalog. The folk ballad “Ako’y Pinoy” (I Am a Filipino) was his first major hit. His first public television appearance was on Channel 13 in Alice Zerrudo in Concert (Evening Post), 1979.

In 1971, he decided to go on solo performance because he was tired of organizing bands that had to be continually disbanded. He composed, arranged, sang, and collaborated with other Filipino music artists as seen in his prolific output of 51 recorded singles and albums. His songs were included in the collection of printed Original Pilipino Music (OPM) titled All Pinoy Music Special, which contains 320 local songs with chords, Vol. 1, 1996. He collected 12 of his compositions in his first LP album titled Mga Tula at Awitin ni Florante (Poems and Songs of Florante). These songs were so popular that they were taught in elementary schools. Because he wrote songs associated with everyday street culture, Florante was addressed as “Tatang, Kaka, or Pinoy” by his colleagues. By the time his songs got printed, Florante was already considered a leading exponent of Pinoy rock music. In his second album, he included “Handog” (Offering), which was a song of gratitude to all people who helped him, as well as a farewell song. This song became the theme song of the Film Academy of the Philippines. Another song of his, “Abakada,” was composed for the International Year of the Child in 1979.

At the time when the song “Anak” (Child) by Freddie Aguilar was playing in all radio stations, Florante’s music posed a challenge to it. Florante’s song “Pinay” (Filipina), which he first sang at Don Bosco College, was used by Asia Brewery in a beer commercial, and “Ako’y Pinoy” (I Am a Filipino) by San Miguel Beer and Selecta companies in their own commercials (Velarde 1978).

Florante was an Aliw awardee as Best Folk Singer of the year in 1976. In a survey conducted by Jingle Magazine, Florante was declared the Best Performer in 1975 and Poet of the Year in 1976-77. In the 1980s, his career ended. Florante and his family migrated to the United States after the 1986 EDSA Revolt. Written by Josephine Baradas

FRANCISCO, LUCIA (Lucia Almeda Francisco) b. Trozo (now Binondo), Manila 18 Dec 1888. d. Quezon City 1 Oct 1972. Pianist. The youngest of eight children of Higino Francisco and Eduviges Almeda, she began her musical training at the Academia Musical Galvez, graduating in Mar 1913. She enrolled at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music and in 1917, while still a student, was appointed to the piano teaching staff by then director Wallace George. In 1920, she and five other students became the first graduates of the UP Conservatory of Music. She finished a postgraduate course in piano in 1923. She then studied in the United States as a government scholar, graduating from the Peabody Institute in Baltimore, Maryland in 1926. She proceeded to Europe and earned a piano teachers’ diploma at the Fountainbleau Conservatory of Music in Paris, France in 1927. Upon her return to the Philippines, she taught at UP until her retirement in 1953, after which she was appointed emeritus associate professor in piano.

Not long after her death, Francisco’s pupils, led by Eva Ponce-Panajon, organized the LuciaFrancisco Music Circle. Her adopted son and grandnephew Higino Francisco, established the Lucia Francisco Scholarship Program at the UP College of Music.Written byElmer L. Gatchalian

FRANCISCO, MANOLING (Fr Manoling V. Francisco, SJ) b. 26 Feb 1965. Liturgical composer. He is the fourth child of Victor and Concepcion Francisco. His siblings are Eduardo, Victor Jr, Leonardo, and Vicente. When he was six years old, he took summer lessons on electone piano, music theory, composition, and solfege in Yamaha and Greenhills Music Studio. At age 13, while preparing for his first piano concerto under Asuncion Laureola of University of the Philippines College of Music, he was enlightened with a calling for priesthood. He then became active in catechism, community immersion, and theater.

As a young musician with a vocation for priesthood, he commenced composing as an outlet for personal expression. In a school-wide music composition competition, Manoling’s melody was chosen for Onofre Pagsanghan’s lyrics of “Hindi Kita Malilimutan” (I Won’t Forget You), winning first place in the said contest. He then continued to compose music together with classmates Jandi Arboleda and Norman Agatep. Among their early compositions were “Mariang Ina Ko” (My Mother Mary) and “Gumising” (Wake Up). Fr Manoling’s first solo composition was created during his college sophomore year in Ateneo de Manila University and was titled “One More Gift.” During the same year level, he collaborated with the aforementioned classmates in composing a setting of a Mass in the idiom of gospel, “I Will Sing Forever.” He later composed more songs such as “Anima Christi” and “Pasko Na” (It’s Christmas). In 1984, during his junior year, his song “Gabing Kulimlim” (Dusk), followed by “Tanging Yaman” (Only Wealth) in 1985 were very popular in churches. In his senior class, he attempted to compose in classical style, which led to “Luwalhati sa Diyos” (Glory to God). This, however, did not prosper. He ventured back into composing with simple melodies and chord progressions and thus easy to sing and remember, without sacrificing depth of messages.

He described his church works as in-between secular and liturgical styles, infusing the complex meanings of his spiritual songs with a touch of romantic ballad and traces of kundiman, but with a contemporary feel. With these qualities, local artists like Dulce and Basil Valdez were moved and had included Francisco’s songs in their albums. The impact of his compositions to the laity has given him a realization that he fulfills the needs of the church. His most recent work is an album for the Holy Week, released in 2014.

Francisco graduated class valedictorian at the Ateneo de Manila Grade School and High School for the years 1979 and 1983, respectively. In 1990, he was conferred with a bachelor’s degree in pre-divinity by the Ateneo de Manila University, cum laude, and was graduating class valedictorian. In 1997, he was summa cum laude and also class valedictorian upon conferment of his master of arts in theology by the Loyola School of Theology. He got his licentiate in 2002 and doctorate in systematic theology in 2005 from Weston Jesuit School of Theology, Cambridge, Massachusetts.

Fr Francisco entered the Society of Jesus in May 30, 1985 and was ordained priest in 1997. He had served as parish priest and school director of St Joseph’s Catholic Mission in Kiangan, Ifugao. His distinctions include: Ten Outstanding Students of the Philippines (TOSP), 1990; The Outstanding Young Men of the Philippines (TOYM), 1999; Ten Outstanding Students of Weston Jesuit School of Theology, 2001; and Who’s Who of Students in American Colleges and Universities; and Alpha Sigma Nu Honor Society of North America, 2002.

He is a co-founder of Bukas Palad Ministry; music director of the opening liturgy in World Youth Day 1995; and musical director in Bayan Umawit: Vatican II Commemorative Concert. Currently he is a theology professor at the Loyola School of Theology; counselor, spiritual director, retreat master, and executive director of Tanging Yaman Foundation Inc.Written byCrisancti L. Macazo

FUENTES, JOVITA (Jovita Fuentes) b. Capiz 15 Feb 1895 d. Manila 7 Aug 1978. National Artist for Music. Singer, teacher. One of 13 children of Canuto and Dolores Fuentes, wealthy landowners, she learned to sing the habaneras and the danzas at the age of five. She began piano lessons under the town organist, then went to the Colegio de Santa Isabel in Manila. During school vacations she organized sarsuwela and operettas with friends and neighbors. After college, Fuentes took formal voice lessons from Salvina Fornari, an Italian singer residing in Manila. She was an instructor of voice culture at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, 1919-24. In 1924, she left for Milan, Italy to further hone her skills in opera singing and acting under voice teachers Arturo Cadore, Luigi Lucenti, and Maestro Villani.

Fuentes first earned international recognition in Apr 1925 when she appeared as Cio Cio San in Puccini’s Madame Butterfly at the Teatro Municipale di Piacenza in Italy. Upon her return to Manila on 23 Aug 1930, the day was declared a public holiday. After a few performances in Manila, she proceeded to San Francisco, USA in 1931, then Europe. As her fame spread in Europe, she was given roles in other operas: as Mimi in La Boheme, Liu Yu in Turandot, Princess Yang Gui Fe in Li Tai Pe, and the title role in Iris.

In 1932, Richard Strauss chose Fuentes to star in his opera Salome, after hearing her sing in Wiesbaden, Germany. In 1938, she again performed Madame Butterfly, this time in New York. She gave her final recital in Manila in 1945 and, the following year, appeared in the movie Prima Donna. She retired from the concert stage in 1955 and spent her remaining years teaching voice. Aside from singing and teaching, Fuentes actively promoted music and the arts. She founded the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, the Bach Society of the Philippines, and the Artists’ Guild of the Philippines. She opened a scholarship at the UP Conservatory of Music in 1952, sang for free in many benefit concerts, and pushed for the creation of the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP), which staged European as well as original Filipino operas.

After retirement, she chaired the MPFP board of trustees, became president of the Artists’ Guild, and headed the voice deparment at the UP Conservatory of Music and the College of the Holy Spirit. Awards and citations garnered by Fuentes include Voice Teacher of the Year Award from the Manila Music Lovers’ Society, 1952 and 1953; Leadership in Music Award from UP, 1957; Presidential Medal of Merit in Music, 1958; Jose Rizal National Centennial Commission Certificate of Appreciation, 1961; Ten Outstanding Filipino Women Award from the Federacion Internacional de Abogadas, 1967; Diwa ng Lahi, Araw ng Maynila award, 1975; and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award, 1975.

She was proclaimed National Artist for music in 1976. On her birth centenary in 1995, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and the Jovita Fuentes Music Cultural Society prepared a series of activities: major music schools held concerts; a commemorative stamp was issued; a historical marker was erected at the UP College of Music; and her biography Jovita Fuentes: A Lifetime of Music, 1979, written by Lilia H. Chung, was translated into Filipino, Jovita Fuentes: Dakilang Tinig ng Dakilang Awit by Virgilio Almario, 1995. A play, The Passion of Jovita Fuentes, 2009, by Peter Nery Solis, and a children’s book The First International Diva, 2012, by Lin Acacio-Flores, were also written based on her life. The Roxas City Council in 2012 declared every Feb 15 as Jovita Fuentes Day.Written byRaj Mansukhani,updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

FULE, ERLINDA (Erlinda Cordero Fule) b. Alaminos, Laguna 9 Apr 1933. d. Quezon City 12 Dec 2012. Piano pedagogue, pianist. She is the youngest of four children of Francisco Fule and Socorro Cordero who were both school teachers.

Erlinda finished her primary education in her hometown in Alaminos and San Pablo City in Laguna. After World War II, she moved to Manila and enrolled in the Assumption Convent and later transferred to Holy Ghost College (now College of Holy Spirit) where she completed her secondary education. It was also in Holy Ghost College that she pursued her music degree under Amanda Cabrera and eventually obtained her bachelor of music in piano, 1952, and bachelor of arts, 1953. She then took further studies in music at the Peabody Conservatory of Music in Baltimore, Maryland and obtained a master in music degree in performance under the tutelage of eminent pedagogue for piano Erno Balogh, who was a pupil of Hungarian composer Bela Bartok. She also studied theory under Louis Cheslock.

Upon her return to the Philippines in 1955, she took further piano studies with Stella Goldenberg-Brimo and became featured soloist under conductors Luis Valencia, Antonino Buenaventura, and Sr Rosalinda Abejo, RVM. She taught at Holy Ghost and St Joseph College before eventually becoming a faculty member of the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1960. At the UST Conservatory of Music, she taught piano and theory subjects. Her interest in history and the affairs of the country made her enroll at the UST Graduate School to pursue a master’s degree in political science. Hence, she also taught Philippine history, Philippine Constitution, and Rizal course among the students of the conservatory. It is here at the UST Conservatory of Music that she would spend the next 50 years of her academic and professional life.

During the time of conservatory director Sergio Esmilla Jr, she helped establish the degree program in Music Education, and under dean Stella Goldenberg-Brimo, she assisted in putting up the UST Brass Quintet and the UST Woodwind Quintet. One of her important legacies was reestablishing the UST Symphony Orchestra and organizing as well the UST Symphonic Band along with Fr Manuel P. Maramba, OSB. Fule was also a frontliner in the conservatory projects, such as the UST Summer Music Camp which she herself conceptualized and the Sampung mga Daliri Atbp (Ten Fingers and Others) concerts that was a brainchild of Ernani Cuenco.

Fule succeeded Alejandra Atabug as dean of the conservatory in 1990 and held the position until 2001. She was appointed to the Board of Trustees of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) after the EDSA revolution and it was during her term as board member of CCP that the UST Symphony Orchestra achieved a resident company status at the CCP. She was also an active member of the Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines for more than two decades.
