Among her piano students were Cris Montenegro, Misael Manalaysay, Apolonia Bataclan-Guilang, Cynthia Polilio-Yumul, Fe Marsha Nicholas, Heliodoro Fiel, Darren Matias, Larry Orque, and Kitty Cendana.Written byMaria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua

GARCIA, ANTONIO (Antonio del Rosario Garcia) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 13 Jun 1865. d. 4 Apr 1919. Pianist, cellist. His father, Calixto Garcia, was an organist and cantor in the SanAgustin, Intramuros and Santa Cruz churches, and his mother, Eusebia del Rosario, was an entrepreneur. He married Paulina Vasquez with whom he had six children. He first learned music from his father, who besides singing and playing the organ, was adept with the flute, violin, and guitar. Starting at nine years old, Garcia studied under different teachers at the Colegio de Niños Tiples of the ManilaCathedral for the next four years: singing and vocalization under Luis Calpe, piano under Luis Vicente Arche, and violin and cello under Ramon Valdes. Later, he continued schooling at the Ateneo Municipal.

Garcia made his public debut in 1878 when he was only 13. The following year, playing the cello, he was awarded second accesit (honorable mention) in a musical contest conducted by the Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario. At 16, he became the organist of the Parroquia del Sagrario of the Manila Cathedral. He appeared in nearly every program given at the University of Santo Tomas, MalacañanPalace, and Casino Español, and in various concerts initiated by musical patrons or given by the Liceo Cientifico Artistico-Literario and Sociedad Musical Filipina de Santa Cecilia. The visiting Hungarian concertmaster Remenyi was so impressed by his versatility on the piano, violin, and cello that he strongly urged Garcia to take further studies abroad.

During this time, Garcia taught solfeggio and, later, piano at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran together with Blas Echegoyen and Jose Muezo, and at the Ateneo Municipal with the same artists and Jose Felix. He became director of the instrumental section of the Sociedad Filipina de Santa Cecilia in 1891. He continued to play in churches and theaters, public venues, and private homes, and directed Gruet’s orchestra in Manuel Garrido’s farewell concert at the Filipino Theater. He served as director of Euterpe Orchestra when it was organized by nonprofessional musicians in 1899.

During the American regime, he also taught at the Centro Escolar University, Santa Catalina College, and Colegio de Consolacion. In 1916, Ignacio Villamor, the first Filipino president of the University of the Philippines (UP), asked Garcia to serve as director of the newly opened UP Conservatory of Music, an offer which he modestly declined. Among Garcia’s pupils were Conchita Cruz Herrera, Rosario Valdez, Barbara Cuaycong, JovitaFuentes, Mariano Aguilar, and Jose Paez. He was the friend and favorite pianist of jurist Cayetano Arellano. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang

GARCIA, RAFAEL (Rafael Vasquez Garcia) b. 23 Oct 1889. d. 31 Jul 1931. Composer. He is the eldest son of AntonioGarcia, pianist and cellist, and Paulina Vasquez. He had his early schooling at the Ateneo Municipal. In 1903, he went to Hong Kong to study at St Joseph’s School, but the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War forced him to leave the colony in 1904. He studied piano, theory, and harmony under Buenaventura Galvez de Reyes. He became a teacher at age 15 in the Hospicio de San Jose and later in the Philippine Lyric Academy.

In 1924, he made piano transcriptions of Debussy’s The Afternoon of a Faun, Rossini’s William Tell, a minuet from Bizet’s L’Arlessienne No. 1, Liszt’s Danse Macabre, Op. 43, Mozart’s Turkish March and the allegro and minueto from the Jupiter Symphony No. 41, and Bach’s aria from Orchestral Suite in D.

He has written about 50 piano transcriptions of the works of Weber, Grieg, Schubert, Chopin, Beethoven, Moskowsky, Mendelssohn, and others.

His original compositions include “Lento e Languido” (Slow and Languid), begun in 1916 and finished in 1930; “Nocturne en Do Menore (Nocturne in D minor),” 1920; “Danse des Lutins (Dance of the Lutins),” Heroide-Elegiaque (Sad Heroine),” “Serenade,” and “Alaala” (Memory), all in 1921; and “Legende (Legend),” “Variations Upon a Philippine Folk Song,” and “Romanza”(Romance), all written for piano in 1929. None of his music can be located at present.Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel
Gardoce, Elena (See LITERATURE volume.)

GASTON, CONCHITA (Conchita Corteza Gaston-Helm) b. Silay, Negros Occidental 14 Dec 1921. d. The Hague, Holland 11 Jun 1984. Singer. She was the daughter of former Negros Occidental governor Emilio Gaston and Amparo Corteza, and the sister of dancer-choreographer IndayGaston-Mañosa. She was married to Max Helm. Her early schooling began at the Assumption College in Iloilo. She later transferred to St Theresa’s College in Manila. She took her voice lessons with MercedesMatias-Santiago, and later, with Madame Olga Esner in New York.

Gaston started her career as a mezzo-soprano in New York. Under contract with Columbia Artists, she traveled cross-country to sing in recitals. She sang in the first televised English version of Madame Butterfly for NBC. She also appeared as Susuki in Madame Butterfly at the Salt Lake City Festival in Utah with conductor Maurice Abravanel. She sang with Beverly Sills in Strauss’ Der Rosenkavalier.

The American conductor Leonard Bernstein chose Gaston to play the role of Jocasta in Oedipus Rex by Stravinsky. She sang Bizet’s Carmen in the original French in the New York City Center, and in Flemish at the Royal Flemish Opera House in Belgium. She also appeared as Vonchakovsna in Prince Igor by Stravinsky. She performed with an Italian cast from the Rome Opera Company in Nabucco, I Puritani, and Madame Butterfly. She was the first Filipino opera singer to perform in Bulgaria at the State Opera House of Sofia.

Her long-standing battle with cancer propelled her to organize the Conchita Gaston Cancer Foundation in 1980. To date, the Foundation has helped a thousand cancer victims in Bacolod by shouldering their chemotheraphy, operation, and medication expenses.

Gaston was a recipient of the 1984 Gawad CCP Para sa Sining from the Cultural Center of the Philippines.Written byCollie de los Reyes

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS BAND aka AFP General Headquarters Band, GHQ Band. Camp Gen Aguinaldo, Quezon City. The group was founded by Col Laureano G. Cariño in 1937. He was later succeeded by Col Perigrino T. Aledia, who was a graduate of University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music and conductor of the UP ROTC Band. The band is both a marching band and a concert band. It also maintains a combo or dance band, which plays during social gatherings and program entertainment numbers for the military. The General Headquarters in Camp Aguinaldo and its four major commands composed of the Philippine Army, the then Philippine Constabulary, the Philippine Air Force, and the Philippine Navy are within the scope of responsibility of the GHQ Band in terms of service support.

The band also has figures in the Civil Relations Projects of the Armed Forces. It gives community concerts and provides music for civic parades and for programs of public entertainment. Civic organizations like the Community Chest and the Rotary Club have used the band in their numerous programs and given it recognition and awards on many occasions. The complexity in the range of musical tasks makes this outfit a unique part of the military organization.

Being a multicommand organization, the band occupies a vital role in the accomplishment of the mission of the Armed Forces of the Philippines to achieve peace and prosperity. Its current director and conductor Lt Theodore Lumagui, a former student of Col Aledia in the UP College of Music, is reorganizing and revitalizing the GHQ Band in order to make it more responsive to the increasing responsibilities given to it by the Armed Forces of the Philippines.Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

GERODIAS, MARIA RACHELLE (Maria Rachelle Rivera Gerodias) b. Novaliches, Quezon City 27 Sep 1971. She is the daughter of Rolando Gerodias and Perla Rivera. She graduated cum laude from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music. She obtained a master’s degree in vocal performance at Eastman School of Music in New York, and professional diploma in operatic studies in the Hong Kong Academy for the Performing Arts.

A sought-after singer in the country, Rachelle has been performing to large audiences, both locally and abroad, earning critical reviews. She is also one of the most award-winning sopranos, having won first prize in the Civic Morning Musicals Vocal Competition in Syracuse, New York and having been in the Aliw Awards Hall of Fame for best female classical performer. She received the Ten Outstanding Young Men award in 2010 and the Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service Award in 2013.

Gerodias has essayed lead operatic roles and sung standard classical songs, oratorios, musicals, and the Filipino art song kundiman. She has collaborated with some of today’s most celebrated musicians in the Philippines and abroad, including conductors Georg Tintner, Piero Gamba, Oscar Yatco, Ryan Cayabyab, Yaacov Bergman, Christoph Eschenbach (Pacific Music Festival in Japan as Despina in Mozart’s Cosi Fan Tutte), and Maestro Castriota (L’Orchestra Citta di Firenze). She had chamber concerts with Peter Schmidle of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra and received high acclaim in her Apr 2008 European Debut at the Volksoper Wien in Vienna, Austria, where she sang Liu in Puccini’s Turandot. Her collaboration with Mirella Freni makes her the only Filipina to have ever worked with the legendary opera diva. She had also performed in the Sarajevo Philharmonic Orchestra’s 2009 New Year Concert at the National Theater of Sarajevo, under Uros Lajovic.

In Asia, Singaporeans were captivated by her rendition of Kathy in The Student Prince, Micaëla in Carmen, Susanna in Le Nozze di Figaro, and Liu in Turandot. In 2009, she represented the Philippines as soloist of the China National Symphony Orchestra in Beijing for the Asia-Europe Culture and Arts Festival. She also performed with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra for the World Expo in Shanghai. In Oct 2010, Gerodias joined an international cast of singers performing the lead role in a production of Il Barbiere di Siviglia in Daegu International Opera Festival 2010, South Korea. Her most recent operatic triumphs were the roles of Violetta in Verdi’s La Traviata at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2012. She also essayed the role Zerlina in Mozart’s Don Giovanni at the Daegu International Opera Festival in Korea in 2012.

Gerodias teaches at the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music. Her voice has been recorded on compact disc albums such as the Philippine Christmas Festival along with the Warsaw Philharmonic Orchestra, and Philippine Classical Gems, along with the London Philharmonic Orchestra and the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra.

She is a member of The Zonta Club of the Philippines and the UN Women. She recently established the Rachelle Gerodias Music Foundation Inc, a scholarship foundation that supports the education of underprivileged musicians who would be serving in the Unida Evangelical Church Music Ministry. Written byAntonio C. Hila

GERONIMO, SARAH (Sarah Asher Tuazon Geronimo) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 25 Jul 1988. Singer, actress, television host. Sarah is the third of four children born to parents Delfin Geronimo and Divina Tuazon. She acquired her first music lessons from her father, a retired employee who would make her practice every day.

Sarah’s first stage appearance was at two years of age at a mall show where she sang “Pasko Na Naman” (It’s Christmas Once Again) together with Pinky Marquez and Richard Reynoso. As early as four years of age, she was auditioning for various television programs and was selected for the following shows: from four to six years old, Pen Pen de Sarapen; seven to eight years old, Ang TV (The Television); eight to nine years old, Next. She performed in shopping malls and hotel lounges and was one of the performers in the 1995 visit of Pope John Paul II to Manila. For four consecutive years, starting at six years of age, she won the top prize in Tuklas Talino sponsored by the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company. After joining numerous singing contests, her biggest break came when she won as the first grand champion of Star For A Night on 1 Mar 2003 singing “To Love You More” at age 14. This show, produced by Viva Entertainment, aired on IBC 13, and hosted by her idol Regine Velasquez, won for her one million pesos and a 10-year contract with Viva Artists Agency. Since then, she has had 13 major concerts both here and abroad. Dubbed as the “Pop Princess,” she was one of the youngest artists to have ever filled up the Smart Araneta Coliseum for a solo major concert.

She appeared in 11 films, with A Very Special Love, 2008, You Changed My Life, 2009, and It Takes a Man and a Woman, 2013, considered as her landmark movies. Despite an active movie and concert career, she manages to maintain a regular television profile with appearances in dramas, and as featured artist in the ABS-CBN Sunday variety show ASAP since 2004. She also hosted her own musical variety show, Sarah G. Live!, 2012-13. She has been noted as one of the youngest worldwide to be a judge/mentor in the TV singing competition The Voice of the Philippines. Her unceasing popularity has made her one of the most sought-after celebrities to endorse a wide range of products from shampoo, to car brands, laundry detergents, real estate, cellphones, fastfood chain, pawnshop, deodorant, and fashion line.

Her hit songs include “How Could You Say You Love Me”, 2004; “Forever’s Not Enough,” 2005; “Dahil Minahal Mo Ako” (Because You Love Me), 2008; “Sino Nga Ba Siya?” (Who is She, Really?); “Ikot-Ikot” (Going in Circles), 2013; and Kilometro” (Kilometer), 2014. Of the 22 albums she has recorded, four have won platinum awards. Star For A Night, 2003, Taking Flight, 2007, and Just Me, 2008, won double platinum; Sweet Sixteen, 2004, won triple platinum; and Popstar: A Dream Come True, 2003, won seven time platinum. Her sold-out concerts at the Araneta Coliseum include The Other Side, 2005, In Motion, 2007, The Next One and Record Breaker, 2009, 24/SG, 2012, and From the Top, 2015.

She received the following recognition from Awit Awards: Best Performance by a New Female Recording Artist for “Forever’s Not Enough,” 2004; Best Dance Recording “Sa Iyo” (For You), 2007; Best Selling Album of the Year for One Heart, 2012; Best Rhythm and Blues Music for “Ikot-Ikot,” 2014; and Album of the Year for Perfectly Imperfect, 2015. Other notable awards she has received are: Best Asian Artist in the Mnet Asian Music Awards (MAMA), 2012; Best Female Concert Performer, Recording Artist, and Box Office Queen in the 45th Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Awards, 2014; and Bestselling Philippine Artist in World Music Awards, 2014.Written byKatherine V. Molina

GLOC-9 (Aristotle Condenuevo Pollisco) b. Binangonan, Rizal 18 Oct 1977. Rap artist, songwriter. He is the son of Orlando Pollisco and Blesilda Condenuevo. He is married to Thea Gomez with whom he has three children. Pollisco graduated from STI Regalado Fairview with a nursing degree in 2006, but his body of work about nation and community was heavily influenced by a life and education cradled by Binangonan and Morong, Rizal.

It was in high school from 1991 to 1994 in Morong Rizal, when Pollisco, an avid fan of Original Pilipino Music (OPM) decided that he wanted to be a rapper like Francis Magalona aka Francis M. His first rap name was Venom, until in 1997 he became a member of the rap group Death Threat, during which he claimed the name Gloc-9. When he was unceremoniously dropped from the group in 1999, Pollisco became a contractual crew member and dishwasher at restaurants and fast food chains. On the upside, it was during his stint with Death Threat that he met Francis M during a TV guesting in Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!). This was a friendship that would become a constant in Pollisco’s life.

While working to contribute to the household expenses of his family, he continued recording demos and dropping these off at different recording companies. In the year 2000, Enrico Santos of ABS-CBN’s Star Records picked up one of his demo tapes, and sent someone to look for him in Binangonan. Pollisco was then hired as a music researcher with Star Records, with the opportunity to pitch projects and write songs. In 2002, his song “Bakit” (Why) was chosen for the Himig Handog Love Songs contest, the first time that Pollisco was introduced as solo artist Gloc-9 in the mainstream. This would lead to his first two albums Gloc-9, 2003, and Ako Si… (I Am…), 2005, both with Star Records.

Wanting to have the freedom to write the songs he aspired to do, Pollisco resigned from his job as music researcher and sought to find his way in the music industry. Unsurprisingly, he was met with the same roadblocks any musician with no connections and backers faces. Given the uncertainty of his future as recording artist, and with a growing family to fend for, Pollisco decided to enroll in a nursing degree, thinking he would just work overseas if his dream of a recording contract did not pan out.

Going back to school would provide Pollisco with more material to write about. In 2006, he released a low-budget independent CD entitled Limang Kanta Lang (Five Songs Only). In 2007, Sony Records would sign him up for a mainstream album Diploma, which had as carrier single “Lando,” with a hook sung by Francis M. This officially started his solo mainstream career as Gloc-9, writing the songs that he wants, evolving in his rap skills and musicianship, from one album to the next.

From Matrikula (Matriculation), 2009, and Talumpati (Declamation), 2011, both with Sony Records, and Mga Kwento ng Makata (Poet’s Stories), 2012, and Liham at Lihim (Letter and Secret), 2013, with Universal Records, Pollisco would build a reputation not just as rapper, but as songwriter who keeps an eye out for stories that are untold, taking on voices of the underrepresented, encouraging his audience to reassess collective truths and critique institutions.

“Upuan” (Seat), 2009, is a conversation the powerless might have with those in positions of power, demanding that they be held accountable for the disparity between the lives of those in government and the governed. In “Walang Natira” (No One’s Left), 2011, Pollisco assesses the state of a nation that is dependent on having its own people leave as Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs). “Sirena” (Mermaid) portrays the narrative of growing up homosexual in this country, and how sexuality does not capture the value of an individual. In “Magda,” 2013, what Pollisco discusses is the archetypal narrative of the woman brought to prostitution, this time from the voice of the long-lost love who fails to understand.

Across these major hits, what Pollisco does is speak of lives that would otherwise go unnoticed, encouraging collective reflection about those we silence and choose to be blind to. In the process, he is able to speak to an audience that is used to escapist music, shedding light on issues bound to the state of the nation, unlike any other rapper and songwriter of his generation. What Pollisco has proven is that songs in the mainstream can be both popular and relevant, which in turn is what makes his work important.

Pollisco is a four-time Rap Artist of the Year Awardee of the Philippine Hip-Hop Awards from 2005 to 2009. His song “Upuan” was the first rap song to win Song of the Year from the Awit Awards in 2010, and his singles “Sirena” and “Magda” won numerous awards at the Awit Awards, PMPC Star Awards for Music, and MYX Music Awards. Pollisco is also a two-time winner of Best Theme Song from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), first for “Hari ng Tondo” (King of Tondo) which was the theme song for Manila Kingpin, The Asiong Salonga Story, 2012, and the second for “Hindi Pa Tapos” which was the theme song for Bonifacio, Ang Unang Pangulo (Bonifacio, The First President), 2014.

In 2015, he was featured by MTV Asia’s Music Evolution, which hailed him as the Philippines’ Rap Icon. His song “Dapat Tama” (Do What is Right) commissioned by GMA News and Public Affairs for its 2013 voter awareness campaign, won the Bronze Medal in the New York TV Festival Awards of 2014. Written by Katrina Stuart Santiago

GONZAGA, OTONIEL (Otoniel Aurelio Gonzaga) b. Iloilo 31 Jul 1941. d. Vienna, Austria 13 Jan 2018. Singer. He was the son of Eduardo Gonzaga, an eye specialist, and Anita Aurelio, a mezzo-soprano.Gonzaga, a tenor, received his musical training at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia, USA, under Richard Lewis, Margaret Harshaw, and John Lester. For some years he was based at Frankfurt, Germany with his wife Christina Ackerman, a Swede, and their three children.

He had a series of opera engagements in Trier and Augsburg before joining the Frankfurt Opera in 1977. He has appeared as guest soloist in almost 40 European theaters—Munich, Hamburg, Stuttgart, Dusseldorf, Hanover, Zurich, Basel, Vienna, Graz, Glasgow, Barcelona, Madrid, Brussels, Ghent, and Copenhagen—performing at least 50 major roles. He has also appeared in the theaters of the United States such as in Boston, Cincinnati, Cleveland, Columbus, Philadelphia, and Miami, and his debut at the New York City Opera debut was the role of Fernando in Verdi’s Atilla. In Prague, Czechoslovakia, he played the role of Alfredo in La Traviata, and Otello in Verdi’s Otello. In the United States, he has performed with the Philadelphia Opera as Ottavio in Don Giovanni and with the Boston Opera as the Young Count in the US premiere of Bernard Alois Zimmermann’s Die Soldaten, a role which he sang in Brussels with the Frankfurt Opera. His Frankfurt performances include Tamino and Don Ottavio, the Duke in Rigoletto, Ricardo in Un Balloin Maschera, Alfredo in La Traviata, and Cavaradossi in Tosca. With the Volksoper in Vienna, he played Tamino in Die Zauberflote and Sou Chong in Lehar’s Das Land Des Lachelns, a role he has sung in some 30 different productions over 500 times, making it his most performed role. He was Manrico in Il Trovatore with the Saarbrucken Opera, Calaf in Puccini’s Turandot in Anchorage, and Florestan in Beethoven’s Fidelio. In 2005, he was invited to cover for Placido Domingo in the 50th anniversary of Washington DC’s National Opera where he performed the second act of Giordano’s Fedora and the fourth act of Verdi’s Otello.

Among his command performances were those for His Royal Highness Prince Edward of England during his visit to Marbella, Spain in 1995, the 50th anniversary celebration of the United Nations, and the 20th anniversary of the diplomatic ties between China and the Philippines, all in 1995.

Under the direction of Eugene Ormandy, he has appeared as concert soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra as well as the Marlboro Festival Orchestra under the direction of Pablo Casals. He has also performed with the Radio and TV Orchestras of Bavaria, Frankfurt, Belgium, and Austria, and with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). His concert repertoire includes Verdi’s Requiem, Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, Mahler’s Das Lied von der Erde, Berlioz’s Requiem, Haydn’s The Creation, Puccini’s Te Deum, Bruckner’s Mass in E Minor, and Handel’s The Messiah. He has also worked with the following famous conductors: Pablo Casals, Herbert von Karajan, Eugene Ormandy, Max Rudolf, Giuseppe Patane, Alberto Erede, Sir John Pritchard, and Michael Gielen.

Gonzaga's recordings include Otoniel Gonzaga Live Performances and The Artistry of Otoniel Gonzaga, Live Performances II. His last concert in the Philippines was in 2006 when he performed as a soloist with the PPO and guest artist Lea Salonga, and with the Manila Philharmonic Orchestra and guest artists Dulce and soprano Camille Lopez Molina.

He was conferred an honorary doctor of music degree by the Central Philippine University in 2001and the Presidential Order of Merit for Outstanding Achievement in the Field of Music in 2007. Written byRamon Jocson and Rolando B. Tolentino,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

GRANADA, GARY (Gary Gamutan Granada) b. Davao del Norte 4 Apr 1960. Composer, singer, writer, educator. He is the eldest of the two children of Ireneo Granada, a fisher, and Cristina Gamutan, a dressmaker. He is married to Susan Fernandez with whom he has three children. He completed his elementary and secondary education in Maco, Davao City. He took up metallurgical engineering at the University of the Philippines (UP) under a government grant.

His father taught Granada to play the ukelele and the guitar at the age of three, and to sing Visayan love songs. As a young boy, he regularly sang with the local parish choir. By the time he reached high school, Granada had improved his guitar playing and at the age of 14, went on to win amateur contests.

Granada has written more than 300 songs, including issue-oriented songs, inspirational songs, Christian songs, and love ballads. He has recorded most of his songs in more than 20 albums, most of them under his own recording label, Sigya, an old Tagalog word for inspiration. Among his albums are: Pagsamba at Pakikibaka (Worship and Struggle), Malay at Pananampalataya (Consciousness and Faith), Kasama (Comrade), Parang (Fields), Daluyong (Storm), Ugat (Root), Sa Kalagitnaan (In the Middle), Pamantasan ng Puso (University of the Heart), Harana (Serenade), Gary Granada Live, Sino Ka Ba, Jose Rizal (Who Are You, Jose Rizal), Samu’t Saring (Varieties), Legends Series: Gary Granada, Cebuano Classics, The Essential Gary Granada Collection, Gary Granada Songmaking Clinic, and Sa Pagitan ng Ngayon at Kailanman (In the Middle of Now and Forever). His works spanning 20 years (1974-94) numbering 150 songs were compiled in a series of compact discs from Backdoor Records under the “Classic Alternative” label of Ivory Records.

Many of his songs have won awards, including: “Kahit Konti” (Even Just a Bit), 1981, second prize, Fourth Metro Manila Popular Music Festival or Metropop; “Kung Sama-sama, Kayang-kaya” (Together We Can), 1983, grand prize, Ministry of Human Settlements jingle-writing contest; “Love is a Healthy Heart,” 1983, grand prize, Philippine Heart Center jingle-writing contest; “Salamat, Musika” (Thank You, Music), 1984, grand prize, Seventh Metropop; “Bahay” (House), 1988, grand prize, Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP) Musicfest; “Earthkeeper,” 1989, grand prize, United Nations Environmental Program songwriting contest; and “Mabuti Pa Sila” (They are Better Off), 1998, grand prize, Metropop Song Festival. His recent award-winning songs include “Balitaan Mo Ako” (Give Me Some News), 1999, Best Folk Pop Recording, Awit Awards; and “Huling Hiling” (Last Request), 1999, Best Christmas Recording, Awit Awards. He has also written songs which have been featured in movies such as Emir and Bunso (Youngest Child).

Granada has also written numerous commercial jingles which include “Kapag Nananalo/Natalo Ang Ginebra” (When Ginebra Wins/Loses), “Dugong Ginebra” (Ginebra Blood), “Iba Na Ang Pinoy” (The Filipino is Different), “Alay Mo, Buhay Ko” (Your Gift, My Life), “Bangon Na” (Rise Up), “Mag-impok sa Bangko” (Save Up in the Bank), “Lakbayin ang Pilipinas” (Travel the Philippines), and “Tagumpay Nating Lahat” (Our Triumph). He has written two award-winning commercial jingles: “Alay Mo, Buhay Ko,” 1986, for UNICEF, cited Ad of the Year, and “Tagumpay Nating Lahat” (Our Triumph), 1991, for the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company, an Anvil awardee.

In 1996, he wrote the libretto and music of Lean, A Filipino Musical, a musical based on the struggles of slain UP student activist, Lean Alejandro, against the Marcos dictatorship. It was first staged at the UP Theater in 1997.

Granada was one of the featured artists in the Filipino Artists Series of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1992. Aside from cohosting a radio program aired over ZNN Radio Veritas, he is also the general manager of Infomatrix Media Planners based at the UP. Granada is also involved with the Institute for Asian Church and Culture, the Pambansang Koalisyon ng Musikong Pilipino, and Musicians for Peace. He received the Awit Award for Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino in 2012. Written byEdna Marcil M. Martinez and Elmer L. Gatchalian,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

GREGORIO, EMMANUEL (Emmanuel Blancaflor Gregorio) b. Manila 30 May 1936 d. Pasay City 30 Jan 2008. Singer, voice teacher, vocal therapist, choir conductor. He was the second of five children born to Ruperto Gregorio and Rebecca Blancaflor. He was married to pianist-harpist Lourdes de Leon with whom he had three children.

He obtained the degree of bachelor of music in 1968 and master of music in 1971 at the Centro Escolar University under a scholarship grant from the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines and under the tutelage of Jovita Fuentes. Among his teachers were composers Antonio J. Molina, Alfredo S. Buenaventura, and Lucino T. Sacramento.

He has performed in more than 40 operas. He appeared as Raimondo in Lucia di Lammermoor, Lothario in Mignon, Falstaff in The Merry Wives of Windsor, Ramfis in Aida, Landgraf in Tannhäuser, Alvise in La Gioconda, Timur in Turandot, Coppelius, Dappertutto, and Miracle in The Tales of Hoffmann, Sarastro in The Magic Flute, Figaro in The Marriage of Figaro, Nilakantha in Lakme, Ferrando in Il Trovatore, Alfio in Cavalleria Rusticana, Papageno in The Magic Flute, Germont in La Traviata, Sparafucile in Verdi’s Rigoletto, and Mak in William Russo’s opera The Shepherd’s Christmas. He was chosen to be bass soloist in Bruckner’s Te Deum and Faure’s Requiem with the San Francisco State University Concert Chorus and Symphony Orchestra. He was invited to do the role of Skula in Prince Igor by the Russian Opera Company of San Francisco, and the role of Farlaf by the In Chalis Opera Group in Glinka’s Ruslan and Ludmila. These two operas marked the first time that a Filipino sang full productions of Russian operas in the original languange. His participation in an international production of Tannhäuser in Taipei also marked the first time a Filipino sang in a Wagnerian opera.

Gregorio has also appeared in the premiere performances of original Filipino operas, among them: Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s Mariang Makiling, 1963, Diego Silang, 1964, Alamat ng Pinya (Legend of the Pineapple), 1968, and Prinsesa Urduja (Princess Urduja), 1970; Lucino T. Sacramento’s Pagmamahalan (Loving), 1968; Felipe Padilla de Leon’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1970; and Bayani M. de Leon’s Ako! (I Am!). He was also in Fulgencio Tolentino and Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1971, and Rolando S. Tinio’s production of Leon Ignacio’s Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1974.

Several concert tours took him to key cities of the Philippines, one of which was for the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Outreach Program in Jan 1989. As bass-baritone of the Vocal Ensemble Philippines, he went on two international concert tours that covered Southeast Asia, Australia, the United States, Canada, Eastern and Western Europe, and Japan. A concert tour in 1986 with his wife took him to 10 cities in the United States. After that tour he decided to stay on to accept more invitations to Honolulu, Los Angeles, and Chicago where he conducted vocal workshops. He was appointed voice trainor at the Ingleside Presbyterian Church working in the Youth Program to combat drug abuse.

In 1992 he guested in several concerts such as the Las Piñas Bamboo Organ Festival, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) Home Concert series in the French Ambassador’s residence, and at the Paco Park Presents. He also performed as bass soloist for Du Bois’ Seven Last Words, and as baritone soloist in Rossini’s Stabat Mater and in Walton’s Belshazzar’s Feast, both with the PPO conducted by Piero Gamba and Nicholas Kok, respectively. Moreover, he was the chorus master in CCP’s production of Puccini’s La Boheme and founded the Metro Manila Concert Chorus.

From 1992, Gregorio taught at the University of the Philippines College of Music, where the trio The Three Baritones was formed with Elmo Makil and Gamaliel Viray. Gregorio had affinity with Makil and Viray for they were products of Silliman schools, were evangelical, and, at various points in life, were choral conductors. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo,updated by Yvette Andaya

GUEVARA, AMELITA (Amelita Katigbak Dayrit-Guevara) b. Manila 15 Oct 1936. Pianist. She is the daughter of Aurelio Dayrit and Imelda Katigbak. She is married to Ricardo Guevara, a lawyer, with whom she has four children. She took piano studies under the late Eugenia Agoncillo, Stella Brimo, Reynaldo Reyes, and Olwen Jones. She graduated magna cum laude with a bachelor’s degree in music from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1957. After earning her master’s degree in piano and musicology from the Ohio State University in 1960, she returned to the Philippines and joined the faculty of the UST Conservatory of Music. She became the pianist of the UST Resident Piano Trio which had Rizalina Buenaventura as violinist and Herminia Atienza as cellist. Guevara had her premiere recital in 1949 and her junior recital in 1952 at the Santa Isabel College.

As commissioned by the Ohio State University, she has given solo recitals in 10 different towns and cities in the United States and conducted a 600-piece combined children’s choirs. She has performed as soloist with the Manila Symphony Orchestra, Metro Manila Symphony Orchestra, and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO), and with conductors like Antonino Buenaventura, Bernardino F. Custodio, Sergio Esmilla Jr, and Oscar C. Yatco. She has held duo concerts with Nena del Rosario-Villanueva at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, Iligan City, and Paco Park Presents, and Carminda de Leon-Regala at Union Church Music Festival. She appeared with the members of the “Ivory Mafia” which include del Rosario-Villanueva, de Leon-Regala, Erlinda Velasco, and Bonny Armacost in numerous concerts in Metro Manila, Cebu, Iligan, Tarlac, the United States, and Tokyo. During the Philippine Centennial celebration in Jun 1998, her group performed internationally in Spain, Prague, the United States, Greece, Japan, Korea, and Monaco. In addition, they regularly performed for a cause at the Manila Polo Club and Dasmariñas Village Club House, Makati City.

In 1959, Guevara was awarded with the following scholarships: Fulbright Scholarship Grant, Delta Kappa Gamma of Ohio Overseas Scholarship, and Altrusa grant-in-aid and Ohio out-of-state tuition scholarship.

She has taught at St Mary’s College, St Scholastica’s College, and Immaculate Conception Academy. She also served as president of the Manila Symphony Women’s Board for many years. She has been conducting the Coro de San Antonio in Forbes Park since 1962 and has presented the group in numerous fund-raising concerts, staging of various cantatas and oratorios on special occasions.

She served at the Cultural Center of the Philippines as executive director of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra from 1987 to 1994. During her term, she was able to procure musical instruments through donation from Japan. Written byRosalinda Galang and Elmer L. Gatchalian,updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

HAGIBIS An all-male Filipino song-and-dance group formed in 1979, the original members of Hagibis were Bernie Fineza, Mike Respall, Sonny Parsons, Joji Garcia, and Mon Picazzo, with Mike Hanopol being credited as their main producer and songwriter. They were famous for performing in the vein of American disco group The Village People, complete with costumes and synchronized choreography. “Hagibis” in Filipino means “rush.”

The group’s music is considered a prime example of the Manila Sound genre, which is known for being “catchy and melodic, smooth, lightly orchestrated, [and an] accessible folk/soft rock.” Hagibis was a large influence in Pinoy rock music’s evolution and the boom of Original Pilipino Music (OPM) during the 1980s.

The group was packaged to exude a macho image, as illustrated by the lyrics and subject matter of their songs that deal mainly with female beauty and the female form. Their self-titled debut album Hagibis, 1979, was one such record and it produced the hit songs “Legs,” “Nanggigigil” (Antsy), and “Katawan” (Body). The latter track was used as the opening and closing theme of the popular TV sitcom Palibhasa Lalake (Because They’re Men), which was aired in ABS-CBN from 1987 to 1998. Their subsequent albums include HumaHagibis (In a Rush), 1980, under Blackgold Records and Walang Katapat (Incomparable), 1997, which was distributed by Star Records.

In 1981, Hagibis starred in a film directed by Tony Ferrer, titled Legs, Katawan, Babae (Legs, Body, Woman). The group has also served as commercial endorsers for Honda motorcycles and Ginebra San Miguel. When Hagibis disbanded in the 1980s, former member Sonny Parsons went on to become an action star and, later, councilor of Marikina City.

Hagibis is currently back with a new lineup, which includes original members Parsons and Respall, alongside new members, Carlos Nabiula, and Pete Gatela. As of 2014, they are still active as a group and have already made various TV appearances, with live concerts on the way. Written byFrancesca Casauay

article_title: Hail Mary the Queen Children's Choir
text:
HAIL MARY THE QUEEN CHILDREN’S CHOIR The Hail Mary the Queen Children’s Choir (HMTQCC) was founded in 1999 in the Immaculate Conception Parish in Cubao, Quezon City. In 2001, the group also started serving in the music ministry of the Mary the Queen Parish in San Juan City and, in 2004, in Christ the King Parish in Green Meadows, Quezon City.

Under the husband-and-wife team of Maria Theresa and Jude Roldan, both alumni of the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music Alumni, the Hail Mary the Queen Children’s Choir won the top prize in the Music of the Religions category in the third World Choir Olympics held in Brehmen, Germany in 2004. The group also joined in the First Asian Choir Games in Jakarta, Indonesia in 2007, winning the gold medal in the gospel and spiritual categories and silver medals in both Musica Sacra and Musica Contemporanea categories. The choir won the title “Children’s Choir of the World” in the 67th Llangollen International Musical Eisteddfod North Wales, United Kingdom.

The HMTQCC also won gold in the children’s choir category of the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ National Choral Competition in 2009. In that same year, the group’s outstanding achievement was recognized by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts with an Ani ng Dangal award.

The group has performed in Cebu and Bohol in 2004 and held a series of concerts in the Greater Los Angeles area in the United States in 2005, 2008, and 2011. Written byRaul Navarro

HANOPOL, MIKE b. Maasin, Leyte 1946. Musician, singer, songwriter. He was the former lead bass guitarist of the iconic Filipino band Juan de la Cruz in the 1970s, sharing the limelight with rock pioneers Pepe Smith and Wally Gonzalez. His grandmother, Nanay Inday, was his earliest influence, lulling him to sleep with her guitar playing. At the age of 14, Hanopol started earning a living from playing the instrument. His exploits include being the leader of the band in the seminary and, in 1967, he joined yet another band that flew to Vietnam one month shy of his college commencement rites.

His musical career spanned three and a half decades of several hits and 20 albums, which earned him multiple recognition from Aliw Awards and gold prizes, notably for his song “Laki sa Layaw” (Spoiled Brat). His third album, Lagablab (Burning), displays verses from the Psalms and the Ten Commandments. He also mentored the hugely popular band, Hagibis, writing several of their early songs.

In April 2001, Hanopol collaborated with popular Filipino music icons Fredie Aguilar, Rey Valera, and Vehnee Saturno in their album, Saga, which aimed to “inspire Filipinos… in the music industry… as well as to support Pilipino music.”

Hanopol relocated to the United States in 1982, living in Florida and New York, and continues to perform with bands in concerts across that country, before returning to the Philippines in 1993. He founded the band Tribu Kemistri. Hanopol and the Juan de la Cruz band held a reunion concert in Pasay City on 11 Jun 2005. Written byLara T. Mendoza

HERNANDEZ, JUAN (Juan de Sahagun Concepcion Hernandez) b. Sampaloc, Manila 12 Jun 1882 d. Manila 10 Feb 1945. Composer, conductor, teacher. He is the only child of Isidoro Hernandez and Josefa Concepcion. He showed a natural talent for music when he learned to play the piano without the benefit of instruction in his early years. He took formal lessons in solfege under Cayetano Jacobe when he was 12 years old and advanced lessons in solfege under a certain Capt Jose Fernandez and later with Rosalio Silos, one of the first musicians in the Spanish Regiment No 72 in 1894. He took his first lessons in piano under Jose Estella in 1895 and continued with Antonio Garcia from 1896 to 1897. From 1898 to 1901, he took up lessons not only in piano but also in composition and principles of instrumentation with an Italian musician, Santino Coppa. In 1896, he entered the Colegio de San Juan de Letran where he earned his bachiller en artes (bachelor of arts) in 1898. He continued his higher studies at the School of Law at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he earned his law certificate in 1902.

Upon the invitation of a French diplomat, a patron who frequented the Bohemian Club where Hernandez worked, he went to Saigon from 1902 to 1904, and held the position “Chef d’ Orchestre au Cafe de la Musique.” Upon returning to the Philippines in 1905, he served as a clerk in the law division of the Executive Bureau. In 1906 he became a second clerk in the Quartermaster of the Constabulary Bureau in Fort McKinley. It is believed that Alexander Lippay, then director of the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music who got impressed with Hernandez’s chamber piece Poemas del Hogar (Poems about Home), appointed him as instructor in science and composition in 1926 at UP, where he taught harmony, harmonic analysis, keyboard analysis, dictation, sight-reading, and transposition. Beginning in the 1930s, Hernandez also worked as music director for Parlatone Pictures and taught at St Theresa’s College in San Marcelino.

Hernandez got his bachelor of music in composition degree from UP in 1933. For his recital, he played his Piano Concerto in D minor (Fantasie, First Movement), which he wrote under the mentorship of Jeno von Tackacs. This first movement concerto was dedicated to his daughter Carmela, who played it complete with the other two movements—romance (second movement) and rondo (third movement)—in her piano graduation recital on 23 Jan 1939. The concert drew the attention of the press because Juan Hernandez, the father, conducted the orchestra for her daughter who was also his student at UP. Carmela was Hernandez’s daughter with second wife Ascension Manio Garcia. The piano concerto was later performed by Carmela’s daughter Titas Gonzales Gayoso in her piano graduation recital at UST in 17 Mar 1962.

Hernandez’s works previous to his concerto were waltzes like “Rosarito,” 1900, dedicated to Rosario Lozada who was his first wife; “Primavera” (Spring), 1908; and “Crepuscul” (Twilight), “Gratitud” (Gratitude), and “Flirteo” (Flirt), all in 1912; as well as the two-step “Internal Revenue” and the gavotte “Pintakasy,” both 1905; the patriotic song “Maria Clara,” 1907, based on the poem of Jose Rizal; the choral work “Alcazano Flotante,” 1912; and the Spanish serenade “Nuits de Lune,” 1914.

Hernandez is also most remembered for his music for theater, notably the music for the sarsuwela Minda Mora, 1904, which contained the famous song “Mora, Bella Flor” that his daughter Carmela popularized in Sunshine Hour at radio station KZRM and the Tagalog melodrama Lukso ng Dugo (Leap of Blood) in 1906. Hernandez’s other works are: Ang Puso ng Isang Pilipina (The Heart of a Filipina) and Ang Krus na Pula (The Red Cross), 1919, Ang Guardia Nacional (The National Guard), 1921, Ang Mutya ng Silangan (The Muse of the East), 1922, and La Gloria (The Glory), 1931. He also wrote the music for the ballet Scheherazade, 1915.

His “Himno a los Martires del Siglo Primero” (Hymn to the Martyrs of the First Century), 1911, won second prize in the Scholastic Hymn Contest in connection with the Rizal Day Celebration; “National Heroes Hymn,” 1928, second prize in the UP Conservatory composition contest; and “Nostalgias,” 1931, an Oriental waltz, which received the second prize in the composition contest conducted by the Philippine Carnival. Written byAntonio C. Hila,updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

HILA, ANTONIO C. (Antonio Caleja Hila) aka Tony Hila. b. Casiguran, Sorsogon 14 Oct 1947. Historian, professor, choral conductor, voice coach, and music critic. He was born to Mateo H. Hila Sr and Carolina Caleja. His father played the trombone, bandurria, and bajo de unas. His father also had a rondalla composed of family members, which was mentored by violin teacher Francisco de Vega. He studied violin and bandurria under de Vega and, as a member of the family ensemble, played primarily for ocassional family gatherings and, from time to time, in the town’s community programs. He is married to Maria Corazon Alejo, art history professor at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts, with whom he has four children, including pianist Hiyas Hila.

Hila obtained his bachelor’s degree in history from UP Diliman in 1967, and his master’s degree in 1990, and his doctorate degree in 1998, in the same discipline from the University of Santo Tomas, meritissimus and summa cum laude, respectively. After getting his bachelor’s degree in history, he took courses from 1970 to 1972 which led to his bachelor of music degree in choral conducting at the UP College Music. He also took voice lessons under Mercedes Santiago from 1970 to 1974, and studied harmony and theory with Lucio D. San Pedro from 1974 to 1976. Since the late 1970s to the present, he has been conducting the Coro Pasigueño Choir of Pasig City.

As a historian, Hila has written three books: The Historicism of Teodoro Agoncillo, 2001, Music in History and History in Music, 2004, and The Musical Arts in the New Society, 2007. He has also written monographs on Philippine culture, articles on music in scholarly journals, the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ Tuklas Sining series on Philippine arts, National Commission for Culture and the Art’s Kuwadro series on the National Artists, and the CCP Encyclopedia for the Philippine Arts, music volume, first edition. As resident music critic, he writes for the Philippine Daily Inquirer.

Hila has taught history at Lyceum of the Philippines, 1968-70; Letran College, 1975-76; and at the De La Salle University (DLSU), 1978 to 2007, where he was chair of the History Department from 1990 to 1998. He is currently a professorial lecturer in history at both De La Salle University and the UST Graduate School.

In the public sector, Hila was the chair of the National Committee on Historical Research of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts from 1998 to 2004, and a member of the Board of Trustees of the Philippine National Historical Society, the Sorsogon Heritage Society, the Board of National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) Foundation, and Commission on Higher Education’s Technical Panel for history. He also serves in the editorial board of the Philippine National Historical Society and the Manila Studies Association. In addition, he sat as an adjudicator in several choral competitions, the Awit Awards, and kundiman contests.

Hila has read papers in national and international conferences and has given lectures in local as well as international fora. He became a research fellow of the Yuchengco Center for Asia in 1997, and in the same year, was sent to Waseda University in Tokyo, Japan as an exchange research fellow. He was an Outstanding Teacher awardee of the DLSU Student Search for Outstanding Teacher in 2001 and was cited one of the Ten Influential Teachers in DLSU in 2006. He also held the Remedios Bosch Jimenez Professorial Chair in Music Studies in DLSU from 1999 to 2007. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

HIMIG SINGERS A multi-awarded choir from Davao, the Himig Singers was formed in 1998. Under Max Aviola, the group won the top prize in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) in the college choir category in 1990 and in 1993.

From the middle to late 1990s, the group embarked on its international tours. In 1994, they won first prize in the polyphonic category of the XV International Music Festival in Cantonigros, Spain. In Vienna, Austria, the Himig Singers also competed and won first prize in the mixed choir category, as well as the grand prize in the 26th International Youth Music Festival. The group won the Audience Award at the 2004 Vivace International Choral Festival in Veszprém, Hungary.

In 2005, the Himig Singers was renamed Himig Gospel Singers while on tour in Canada. At the First Asian Choir Games in 2007 in Jakarta, Indonesia, the Himig Gospel Singers was declared champion in the mixed vocal ensemble category.

Through the years, the Himig Singers has recorded and produced a number of albums such as The Himig Singers, 1999; Mga Awiting Pilipino (Filipino Songs), Faith & Inspiration, and Paskong- pasko (Christmas All the Way), 2000; and Church Arise! and Christmas with The Himig Singers, 2005. Written byRaul Navarro,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

HONTIVEROS, EDUARDO (Eduardo Pardo Hontiveros, SJ) b. Roxas City 20 Dec 1923 d. Quezon City 15 Jan 2008. Composer, priest. Born to Supreme Court Justice Jose M. Hontiveros and Vicenta Pardo, he comes from an artistically and musically inclined family, his elder sister being stage actor Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana, wife of film director and National Artist for film Lamberto Avellana. Film director and actor Jose Mari Avellana and visual artist Ivi Avellana-Cosio are his nephew and niece respectively. He entered San Jose Seminary in 1945, and later joined the Jesuit order. He obtained his master’s degree in philosophy at the Berchmans College, Cebu in 1949, and his doctorate in sacred theology from the Gregorian University in Rome in 1958. From 1958 to 1989, he taught theology at San Jose Seminary and the Loyola School of Theology, also serving as the latter’s president from 1983 to 1989. In 1989, he became dean of the St John Vianney Seminary in Cagayan de Oro City.

Soon after Hontiveros began his priestly duties, he was assigned as choirmaster of San Jose Seminary. Though he lacked formal training in composition, he arranged music for the choir and composed original music with English, Latin, and later Tagalog texts. In 1971, Hontiveros arranged the songs for a liturgical concert sung by a choir of the urban poor. This was the beginning of an annual tradition that spanned the years 1971 to 1978. His first liturgical composition in Tagalog was “Misang Bayan sa Awit” (The People’s Mass in Song). Some of his songs are: “Awit ng Mangingisda” (Song of the Fisherfolk), “Pagtitipan” (Tryst), “Pananagutan” (Responsibility), “Dakilang Pag-ibig” (Great Love), and “Dapit-hapon” (Dusk). Lyrics were sometimes written by Hontiveros himself or by his friends and colleagues.

In 1986, Hontiveros helped organize the Jesuit Music Ministry, which is responsible for publishing and taping many of his compositions, along with those he has inspired. In 1972, he cut his first long-playing record Luwalhati sa Diyos (Glory to God). In 1975, he collaborated with Rolando S. Tinio in a musical dramatization for television of Gaspar Aquino de Belen’s Pasyon (Passion).

His works are found in cassette tapes like Panunuluyan (In Search of an Inn), Aking Pastol (My Shepherd), Papuri’t Pasasalamat (Praise and Thanks), Himig Heswita (Jesuit Hymns); publications like Awiting Pansamba (Songs of Praise), 1976, Tugunan, Taon A (Responsorial Psalm, Year A), 1989; and anthologies like Magsiawit sa Panginoon (Let’s Sing to the Lord), 1989, and Pagsamba Praise Book, 1991.

He received the Ateneo de Manila’s Gawad Tanglaw ng Lahi in 1976 and an award from the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa. In 1992, Hontiveros was bestowed the Asian Catholic Publishers’ Outstanding Catholic Author Award. He also received the Papal award Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice in 2000. Written byRene B. Javellana,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

HOTDOG A Pinoy rock ‘n’ roll band that gained phenomenal popularity in 1974, Hotdog was led by brothers Rene and Dennis Garcia and had Ella del Rosario, Gina Montes, Lorrie llustre, and Mazo Diez among its members. Among their many hit songs were “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You’re the Miss Universe of My Life), “Pers Lab” (First Love), “Annie Batungbakal,” “Beh Buti Nga” (Suits You), and “Bongga Ka ’Day” (You’re Fabulous, Pal).

The release of “Miss Universe” rode on the lavish promotions for the Miss Universe pageant held in Manila in 1974 while “Pers Lab” established Hotdog as a major recording band. Their music touched on the theme of love, rendering it casually, but without the typical mushiness common to many Filipino songs. The band initiated what has been called the Manila Sound, a very light kind of pop music that uses colloquial or Taglish (Tagalog and English) language, and is expressive of juvenile sentiments. Some of their hit songs were adapted into movies with the band’s participation such as Bongga Ka ’Day, 1974; Hotdog: Unang Kagat (Hotdog: First Bite), 1975; and Annie Batungbakal with Nora Aunor, 1979. The band was instrumental in launching the solo careers of musicians like songwriter Lorrie Ilustre, and singers like Zsa Zsa Padilla and Ella del Rosario. The group officially disbanded in 1984, closing a successful band career with another hit tune titled “Manila.” In 1988, they had a reunion concert at Rizal Theater, Makati City. Other reunion concerts followed in 2011 and 2012 titled Hotdog… Isa Pa Nga! (Hotdog… One More Time!) held at Dusit Thani Hotel, Makati City. The band has produced an eight-album collection of 250 songs, 25 of which became gold records. In 2009, the band received the Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino from Awit Awards. Written byGalileo Zafraupdated by Connie Ladrido

IGNACIO, LEON (Leon Matias Ignacio) b. Quiapo, Manila 20 Feb 1882. d. 1967. Composer. The only child of Felix Ignacio, a viola player for the ManilaCathedral, he lost both parents early in life, and was raised by his grandparents. Ignacio married sarsuwela singer Pastora Matias, who trained AtangdelaRama as a sarsuwela artist. At age four, he learned to play the violin. Before the age of 10, he was earning 20 centavos a day as a violinist, and at 14, became a regular violinist in the orchestra of JuanMolina at the TeatroZorrilla and the ManilaGrandOperaHouse. He also learned to play the piano.

In 1900, Ignacio was musical director of SeverinoReyes’s GranCompañiadelaZarzuelaTagala. In 1902, after some training in harmony and composition, he composed his first musical score for a three-act sarsuwela, Infierno, by PantaleonLopez. He also joined HermogenesIlagan’s troupe. He composed the music for other famous sarsuwela: DalagangBukid (Country Maiden), 1919; PaglipasngDilim (After the Darkness), 1920; SaBungangangPating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1921; and AngKiri (The Flirt), 1926. Other sarsuwela he did were Ararong Ginto (Golden Plough), Alamat ng Nayon (Legend of the Countryside), Aking Ina, Anak ni Eva (My Mother, Eve’s Daughter), and Ang Bulaklak sa Kabundukan (The Flower in the Mountain). He was musical director for the following sarsuwela: WalangSugat (No Wounds), AngKalupi (The Wallet), and R.I.P., all staged in 1902.

Ignacio’s first song, “Sa Pinto ng Langit” (At Heaven’s Gate), 1915, launched his career in the field of entertainment music. It also established RubenTagalog as the “king of kundiman.” Ignacio worked on lyrics by JoseCorazondeJesus and JulianBalmaseda, and wrote “O Batute” for de Jesus, with music by NicanorS.Abelardo. Many of his songs were recorded. Ignacio also composed for the movies, his best known song being “Lambingan” (Tender Affection), a danza Filipina.

He is believed to have composed some 500 songs for about 50 sarsuwela, among them, “Nabasag ang Banga” (The Jar was Broken), “Lambingan” (Tender Affection), “Tampuhan” (Lovers’ Quarrel), “Paraluman” (Muse), “Pinto ng Langit” (Heaven’s Gate), “Pagsuyo” (Courtship), “Dahil sa Pag-Ibig” (Because of Love), and “Sugat sa Puso” (Heart’s Wound). Ignacio’s music spanned the sarsuwela and movie eras, contributing to the development of the Filipino popular song in the first half of the century. Among his prizewinning songs are: “Ilaya,” first prize in a contest sponsored by the Ilaya Music Store, 1931; “Kundiman ng Bayan” (Kundiman of the Country), first prize in a government-sponsored contest, 1943; and “Lapitan Mo Ako” (Come to Me), third place in the Juan Luna Centennial Awards, 1958. One of his compositions also received a special certificate of merit in the 1931 Paris International Fair. He was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award in 1963. In 1983, during the Second Cecil Awards, Ignacio was given a posthumous Lifetime Achievement Award in recognition of his contribution to Philippine culture. Written byMa. Lourdes Maniquis

ILUSTRE, LORENZO (Lorenzo Saez Ilustre) b. Ibaan, Batangas 8 Aug 1866 d. Batangas, Batangas 3 Jun 1922. Bandmaster, conductor, composer, educator, and businessman. The youngest of five children of Nicolas Ilustre and Narcisa Saez from Batangas, Lorenzo sang with the choir of Ibaan Church and played with the town’s local brass band. Lorenzo married his violin student, Apolonia Guerra y Pastor (also from Ibaan, Batangas) with whom he had six children (Aurea, Julia, Concorida, Fracita, Epitacio and Cipriano). His first musical training was under Padre Braulio Enriquez of Ibaan Church. He was later taught by his uncle, Lino Ilustre, who was a composer, organist of Batangas City church, and conductor of Banda Batangas. The young Lorenzo played the clarinet in this brass band and, at times, was asked to conduct it. On one occasion, he was spotted by bandmasters of the Spanish regimentary band who were scouting for new Filipino music leaders. Upon invitation and passing the competitive examination of the Spanish military, Lorenzo Ilustre became the bandmaster of the 71st Regiment of the Spanish Army, one of the seven regiments stationed in the Philippines during the Spanish colonial era. In his brief assignment from 1888 to 1897, he traveled with his troop to Cebu and Iligan.

Ilustre later gave up his post as band leader to join his brother, Maj Mateo Ilustre, who was in the revolutionary army against the Spaniards in the towns of Rosario, Taysan, and Ibaan, under the command of Gen Miguel Malvar. Upon the change of colonial masters from the Spaniards to the Americans, their guerilla company continued to fight against the American troops. However, the impending defeat of the guerilla movement forced their surrender to Capt D.N. Boughton, 3rd Cavalry, in charge of the civil affairs of the old provincial capitol of Batangas. As a reward for surrendering, Lorenzo was appointed leader of the US Military Band in Batangas, in recognition of his brilliance as a former conductor of the Spanish Military Regimental Band. Under Ilustre’s direction, the US Military Regimental Band of Batangas provided public concerts in Manila and other provinces. This obliged him to travel extensively, which became too strenuous that hisqaA stomach ulcer developed. Thus, he resigned from the American military service.

Upon retirement, Ilustre founded and conducted the Rizal Orchestra, which gave weekly Sunday afternoon concerts in Batangas City plaza. He also established the Banda Ibaan and an all-female rondalla group. In his weekly visits to Ibaan, he trained 40-50 musicians and composed music for their band performances. Aside from these, he also trained students to play musical instruments, particulary the clarinet and the violin. Ilustre also ventured into business by opening Batangas City’s biggest single-floor supermarket called “Ang Kaibigan,” located at the busiest part of the city, Rizal Street.

Upon the founding of the Iglesia Filipina Independiente (aka Aglipay Church), he joined this new nationalist church, composing music for it. His music for Easter is still being sung at the Batangas City Aglipay Church by cantoras who learned the music by oral tradition. Despite his conversion to the Iglesia Filipina Independiente, his remains are interred at the baptistery of the now Basilica of the Immaculate Conception, the main Catholic Church in the city of Batangas, resting beside the select few but very prominent citizens of Batangas City.

Among his compositions are: “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell), “Himno al Recibimiento de los Restos de Apolinario Mabini” (Hymn Welcoming the Remains of Apolinario Mabini), “Ang Pangingibang Bayan sa Sariling Lupa” (Migration in One’s Own Land), “Diwa ng Bagumbayan” (Spirit of Bagumbayan), “Himno Mabini” (Mabini’s Hymn), “Encarnacion Polka,” “Gregorio Himno” (Gregorio’s Hymn), “Ang Samyo ng Sampaguita” (The Scent of Jasmine), “La Triste Noche Feliz” (A Sad Christmas Eve), “A las Ocho de la Noche” (Eight in the Evening), “Recuerdo a Un Amor” (Memento for a Beloved), “Jota Rizal,” “Tagala Batangueña,” “Misa Cantada” (Sung Mass), “Misa Pastorela” (Mass for the Traditional Christmas Play), and “Sa Dakong Sikatan” (Where the Sun Rises). Written byArwin Q. Tan

ILUSTRE, LORRIE (Lorenzo Buencamino Ilustre) b. Manila 29 Aug 1955. Composer, musician. He is the only child of Cipriano Ilustre and Mercedes Buencamino. He is married to Ma. Teresa Lantin with whom he has two sons. His great grandfather Fortunato Buencamino was a sarsuwela composer and choirmaster of San Miguel, Bulacan. He is the cousin of pianist Cecile Licad and composers Willy Cruz and Nonong Buencamino, and actor Nonie Buencamino, and grand nephew of composer Francisco Buencamino. He is the grandson of composer and bandmaster Lorenzo Saez Ilustre. He finished elementary and high school at the De La Salle Greenhills, then took up commerce major in accounting at the De La Salle University. After college, he enrolled at the University of the Philippines College of Music for three semesters, taking up composition and flute. His formal training in music, however, came much earlier in childhood when he underwent formal training in music, piano, and classical guitar. In school, he also joined a rondalla, a brass band, a combo, and other instrumental groups. These rock-band performances in high school led to his professional performances with the original Hotdog band from 1974 to 1976. He was also with the New Minstrels when the group performed in Europe.

As musical arranger, he has recorded music with the Apo Hiking Society, Pilita Corrales, Gary Valenciano, VST & Co., Hagibis, Sharon Cuneta, and Rico Puno, among others. Ilustre is also active in advertising as a composer of jingles and musical scorer for commercials.

His entry into film was influenced by his cousin, film director Mike de Leon, and his grandmother, LVN producer Narcisa Buencamino de Leon. He scored LVN’s Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (Does Your Heart Beat Faster?), 1980; Bancom Audiovision’s Kisapmata (Split-second), 1981; and MVP Pictures’ Batch ’81, 1982, all directed by Mike de Leon. The first two movies won for him the Gawad Urian for Best Music for 1980 and 1981. In 1999, he scored Cinema Artists Philippines’ Bayaning 3rd World (3rd World Hero), also directed by Mike de Leon. It won for him the Best Music Award at the 23rd Gawad Urian in 2000. Aside from these, he also composed the music for Ang TV Movie: The Adarna Adventure, 1996; Pepot Artista (Pepot the Actor), 2005; Kagat ng Dilim (Fangs of Darkness), 2006; and Paglipad ng Anghel (When the Angel Flies), 2011.

Ilustre has been based in Las Vegas for years and he has been the associate conductor, pianist, and arranger of Vegas the Show, which was voted as the Best Entertainment in Las Vegas by the BroadwayWorld.com in 2013. He has accompanied many Filipino artists who performed in Las Vegas, like Martin Nievera, 100">Bert Nievera, Lani Misalucha, Ai Ai de las Alas, and Pops Fernandez.

In 2013, he played as accompanist for Patti Austin in her concerts at the Crowne Plaza Hotel and at the Solaire Resort and Casino. He also recorded Cecile Azarcon’s compositions in a CD compilation in 2013. Written byRosalie S. Matilacupdated by A. Tan

INANG LAYA Singing duo launched in 1981. Becky Demetillo-Abraham (b. Iloilo 4 Oct 1948) is the lead singer, with Karina Constantino-David (b. Manila 19 Mar 1946) as guitarist and singer. Demetillo-Abraham is the daughter of poet Ricaredo Demetillo and Angelita Delariarte. Her brother Lester is a well-known guitarist. Demetillo-Abraham studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) from primary school to college, finishing speech and drama in 1971. She was alto-soprano soloist of the UP Concert Chorus, member of the UP Madrigal Singers, and a folk singer in popular folk houses in the 1960s and 1970s. She is married to artist-performer Edru Abraham, with whom she has two children, Apollo and Astarte, both artists.

Constantino-David is the daughter of historians Renato Constantino and Letizia Roxas, and the grandniece of National Artist for music Jovita Fuentes. Her husband is sociologist, TV host, and columnist Randy David. She studied at the Jose Abad Santos Memorial School and UP Integrated School, and took up sociology at UP which she finished in 1966. She obtained her master’s degree in economics and social studies at the University of Manchester, England in 1974, and taught at the UP Institute of Social Work and Community Development, becoming its director in 1977. In 1986, she was designated by Pres Corazon Aquino as undersecretary of the Department of Social Services and Development. She resigned in Nov 1987. She now sits on the Board of GSIS.

The original Inang Laya also included Teresita Gimenez-Maceda, who researched the music, and Jane Po of the UP College of Music, who contributed her knowledge of avant-garde music and documentation.

The group’s first album was Pagpupuyos (Blazing Fire), which documented nationalist songs beginning with the anti-Japanese resistance movement. Recorded over Po’s four-track recording machine and launched in Dec 1981, it sold 500 copies off the rack and orders poured in for months to come. Inang Laya started performing before large crowds in assemblies, concerts, strikes, demolition areas, and protest actions. In early 1982, UP Tropang Bodabil (later Peryante), headed by Chris Millado, invited Inang Laya to be the musical director and composer for its production of Marina Feleo’s play on the peasant movement and the Hukbalahap, Dahong Palay (Rice Stalks/Rice-field Snake). Their recording of “Butil ng Palay” (Rice Grains), the theme song, was often heard on radio and used for TV ads of the Philippine Information Agency.

Inang Laya became an active part of the street-concert scene during the height of the anti-dictatorship protests from 1983 to 1986. They captured in song the dramatic events of the period, some of which they directly experienced. Demetillo’s husband, Edru Abraham, and brother Lester Demetillo, contributed in evolving the type of music suitable for their lyrics. In early 1985, the duo held a concert in Australia for women’s groups, from which came a recording titled Song of Freedom. In 1986, they joined commercial artists from the music industry in making an album carrying the People Power song, “Handog ng Pilipino sa Mundo” (Filipinos’ Gift to the World). They cut the songs “Mga Babae” (Women) and Amado V. Hernandez’s “Lumuha Ka, Aking Bayan” (Weep, My Country) for a long-playing album. They also did two albums for Dyna Records: Inang Laya, 1987, and Atsay ng Mundo (Domestic Helper of the World), 1989, which was second in sales for that year. In 1996, as their contribution to the Philippine Centennial celebration, Inang Laya recorded and produced a double edition of 26 cuts titled ALAB 1896-1996, Alay Sa Laya Ng Bayan (BLAZE 1896-1996, In Honor of the Country’s Freedom), covering song styles from the late 19th century to the late 20th century.

Inang Laya’s songs have also been heard at Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) presentations. They collaborated with choreographer Alice Reyes in Ballet Philippines’ Portraits of the Filipina, and performed in the CCP’s Filipino Artists’ Series in 1987.

In 1987, Demetillo-Abraham and Constantino-David established Hasik, a nongovernmental organization concerned with women issues and the urban poor. Written byMa. Lourdes Maniquis,updated by Lester Demetillo

INDONG-COLASING (Pedro Alfafara aka Indong and Nicolasa Caniban aka Colasing) Balitaw performers. Alfafara was born in Carcar, Cebu, in 1881. Not much is known about his early life except that an uncle, who was a balitaw practitioner, taught him the dance movements of the balitaw and that Indong quickly excelled in the form because of his natural gift for verse and rhyme and his resonant, melodious voice. Caniban was born in Mambaling, Cebu City in 1900, though other sources cite her birth year as 1906. She learned the art of the balitaw from her parents.

Alfafara was the more experienced artist, performing with other women-partners whom he helped train, before he met Caniban. The two must have teamed up first around 1920. By the 1920s, they had become extremely popular, touring the towns of Cebu as well as places in Bohol, Leyte, Negros Oriental, and Mindanao. They were invited to perform during fiestas, carnivals, and other festivities, private as well as public. The two were in such demand that they had to turn down invitations. They commanded a high price for performing and audiences would shower them with coins as they performed. There are references to other balitaw performers before Indong-Colasing, such as Hermenegildo(Amoros)Solon and his daughter Meding, ca 1916, but Indong-Colasing was the most popular pair of the prewar period.

In an interview published in The Freeman of 19 Nov 1926, Caniban said that she spontaneously composed the verses as she performed but that she and her partner would decide on a subject or theme beforehand, e.g., the unfortunate maiden, the deceitful promise, wealth breeds misery, or the patient wife. In the course of the performance, one of the partners might stray from the theme, thus testing the other’s skill in improvising without missing a beat.

Caniban possessed an amulet which she believed gave her the power to attract attention. She carried this mutya in a bottle of oil tied around her waist and anointed herself with the oil before a performance.

When the balitaw began to decline, the team split up. For a time, Alfafara continued performing with a new partner, Bebing Ybañez of Minglanilla, Cebu.

Eventually, both Alfafara and Caniban migrated to Mindanao. He settled down in Gingoog, Misamis Oriental, living the life of a farmer, while she raised a large family in Digos, Davao, where she sold fish in the market for a living. Written byErlinda Alburo

IÑIGO-CHUA, MARIA ALEXANDRA (Maria Alexandra Gil Iñigo-Chua) b. Manila 29 Jul 1968. Music historian, educator, community musician. She is the only daughter of Pedro Dimayuga Iñigo and Carmencita Amacio Gil. Her maternal grandfather was the former Philippine ambassador to Argentina and a medical doctor, Pedro Gil. She is married to Richard Tan Chua with whom she has four children: Arianna Natasha, Alrick Nicholas, Adrian Nathaniel, and Alessa Nicole. She finished her elementary and secondary education at the Nazareth School in Sampaloc, Manila, where she graduated high school salutatorian in 1985. She started learning the piano at age nine and eventually finished her bachelor of music degree in piano at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music in 1991, magna cum laude. She studied with pianists Stella Goldenberg Brimo and Erlinda Fule. She finished her master of music degree in musicology at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music in 2000, writing a thesis “Kirial de esta Yglesia de Baclayonaño 1826: A study of an Extant Sacred Music Manuscript of the Spanish Colonal Period in the Province of Bohol.” This was eventually published as a book by Ateneo de Manila University Press in 2010. In 2017, Chua finished her doctoral degree in music at the UP College of Music under a scholarship granted by the Commission on Higher Education. She is a faculty member of the UST Conservatory of Music and senior researcher at the UST Research Center for Culture, Education, and Social Issues.

Chua’s research on the sacred music of Bohol is a pioneering study of early 19th century liturgical music repertory in the Philippines. This has advanced historical music scholarship in the country. She has done research on the villancico genre, on the printed music books of Monasterio de Santa Clara, traditional music of Bohol, and music during the Japanese occupation. She has published articles such as “Misa Baclayana” in the book Tubod: The Heart of Bohol, 2003; “A Study of Sacred Music Manuscripts in the province of Bohol” in Pintakasi: A Journal of the Cultural Heritage of the Church in the Philippines and “A Critique of Romanillo’s Augustinian Recollect Legacy to Arts and Culture” in Recoletos History, Legacy and Culture, 2005; “Calenda, Suroy, Altares, Bolibongkingking, et al: The Hispanic Musical Tradition of Loboc, Bohol” in Musika Jornal, 2008; “Philippine Music in the Context of Hispanization and Christianization” in Diagonal: Journal of the Center for Iberian and Latin American Studies, 2009; and a chapter in The Manila Galleon: Traversing the Pacific by Rural Empowerment Assistance and Development foundation Inc, 2012.

Chua has presented papers in various local and international conferences and has received research and scholarship grants from the Sumitomo Research Grant, UP Office of the Vice-Chancellor for Research and Development, UST Center for Intercultural Studies, and the Spanish Program for Cultural Cooperation.

She sat as a member of the executive committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts Committee on Music, 2003-07; was president of the UST Conservatory of Music Alumni Association, 2001-06; and a member of the Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines and of the International Council for Traditional Music. She co-founded the Musicological Society of the Philippines in 2002. Written byArwin Q. Tan

INTARAY, MASINO aka Masinu. b. Brooke’s Point, Palawan, ca 1943. d. 30 Nov 2013. Palawanon storyteller and musician. He was born near the head of the river in Makagwa valley at the foothill of Mantalingayan mountain at Brookes Point, Southern Palawan. He was not only a well-known epic chanter, poet, and story teller, but an outstanding percussionist and kusyapi (two-stringed lute) musician. In addition, he also played the aroding (mouth harp) and babarak (ring flute).

Intaray is best remembered for his narrative songs, notably the tultul (long narrratives) of Mämininbin, which French linguistic-anthropologist Nicole Revel recorded in 1971 when Intaray was just 28 years old. His rendition was consequently transcribed, translated to French and English, and published in Paris in 2000. Like Usuy, who was another eminent traditional Palawanon tultul master, Intaray’s songs illustrate the process of oral transmission in which a traditional artist projects—not an individual art per se—but communally-held cultural knowledge, truths, and values. Using improvisatory, formulaic techniques of remembering words, Intaray was exemplary for his creativity, which enabled him to chant a complex yet coherent structures of voice and meaning all night long, even for successive nights. The narratives of this chant are about mythical heroes and heroines who embody desired Palawan virtues. They teach ideal ways of maintaining good, balanced, and harmonious social relationships, even as these entertain listeners as well. Intaray knew not only the verbal art tultul, but also sudsungit or short narratives, and tuturan or myths of origin and teachings of ancestors. On the kusyapi, he was remembered for his kulilal, which is a lyrical song genre on seven-syllabled verses (karang) about love, a type of music based on a scale with semitones and which is accompanied by the bigger-sized kusyapi, a two-stringed lute played by a man. Kulilal can also be played with the pagang, a bamboo polychordal zither, played by a woman. In addition, Intaray also played the bagit, a strictly instrumental music genre based on a scale with no semitones and played on the smalle-sized kusyapi. In contrast to kulilal, bagit music depicts the movements and sounds of nature and of animals like birds, dogs, and monkeys.

In the realm of ceremonial instrumental music, Intaray was an expert in basal or rhythm ensemble music. Along with rice wine drinking, dancing, and singing that are heard in joyous collective celebrations like tambilaw or thanksgiving after harvests, this music conveys the fundamental value of sharing among the Palawan. Basal music reflects this value for no instrument predominates in the group. Instead, techniques of hocketing (alternation of parts) create a counterpoint of rhythms and colors that symbolizes musical joint effort. A pair of sanang (hanging gongs with narrow rims) produces bright sounds that interlock with the dry beats of the gimbal (drum). These, in turn, are counterposed by one, two or three wide-rimmed agung, which produce low booming sounds. The very essence of musical interlock points to creative cooperation and togetherness that is an attribute of most traditional Southeast Asian musics.

For his artistic gifts and achievements, Intaray was conferred the title Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan in 1993. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

Sources:

de Leon n.d.; Revel 2000, 2001, 2005, n.d.

JACINTO, RAMON (Ramon Pereyra Jacinto) aka RJ Jacinto. b. Makati City 3 Jan 1946. Musician and entrepreneur. Ramon Pereyra Jacinto distinguished himself as an enterprising and creative musician, establishing his own private company, RJ Enterprises. When he was only 15 years old, he produced, sold records, and promote his high school band, his own RJ and The Riots. He would later become the senior vice president in their family steel business as well as founding the legendary rock radio station, DZRJ. He also set up RJ Bistro, which was renowned for resuscitating the live performances of local bands during the years following the 1986 EDSA uprising.

Manned by his volunteer group of classmates, DZRJ was the laboratory for on-air experiments of radio concepts unknown and unheard of before in Philippine entertainment history. Easily, DZRJ developed a cult-like following, doing away with rampant payola (recording company fee to radio stations) and introducing alternative music to Filipino teenagers.
