It was the first station to give exposure to such rock legends as the Ventures, the Shadows, the Beatles, the Beach Boys, Lil Richard, and Elvis. Likewise, RJ directed his station and put an emphasis on playing the music of local talent.

Jacinto would also be responsible for making the local band scene flourish with his insistence on showcasing local talents in his club, the RJ Bistro, as well as enshrining the importance of the guitar as instrument when he established a guitar manufacturing business based on his own penchant for producing specific sounds that he wanted to hear while performing with his band. His RJ Guitar Centers continue to provide various, world-class RJ Guitar models and handles the exclusive distributorship of coveted Taylor, Traben, and Michael Kelly guitars and Belcat products in the Philippines.

Jacinto’s legacy to the music scene owes largely to his ties with Ninoy Aquino and his collaboration with local bands in the 80s, i.e., after his return to the country following his and his family’s exile abroad for more than a decade. He continues to manage his businesses, while also performing weekly at the RJ Bar for Thank God It’s RJ! every Friday. In addition, he hosts the RJ Sunday Jam, which is simulcast through 2nd Avenue RJ and RJ100.3 FM on Sundays from 9 am–12 noon and performs once a month at the Captain’s Bar of the Mandarin Hotel in Makati as part of The Greatest and The Latest Concert Series of RJ100.3FM. Written byLara T. Mendoza

JACOBE, CAYETANO (Cayetano Dimaranan Jacobe) b. Lumbang, Laguna 8 Aug 1876. d. 17 Jun 1940. Violinist. He was the son of Juan Jacobe and Cecilia Dimaranan. He married Ana Protacio with whom he had five children, but no one of them survived. He was a choirboy in the Catholic church of his town. On his own he learned how to play the small violin his father gave him as a gift. At age eight, he studied violin in Manila under his uncle, Ubaldo Jacobe, bandmaster of a Spanish military band. Then he studied under Maestro Velasquez, who introduced him to opera and concert music. In his middle teens, Jacobe joined Pedro Gruet’s orchestra, the best known in the city during the late 1800s, and played in theaters and for foreign opera companies. At this time, he also learned composition and directing from an Italian music professor, Ciro Cavalieri.

Jacobe first performed in public as a violinist in 1900, playing “Fantasia” from Lucia di Lammermoor. Arrested for alleged involvement during the Philippine-American war in the midst of his budding career, he persuaded the authorities to free him by giving a dazzling demonstration of his musical prowess. Resuming his performances, he captivated the metropolitan audience and received glowing reviews from the local press. In 1909, he was part of the Philippine Constabulary Band which gave concerts in many American cities. He became known to American audiences and reaped praise from American critics, who said he deserved to be called the “second Pablo de Sarasate.”

At various periods, Jacobe was a member of the Manila Monday Musicale Symphony Orchestra, ManilaSymphonyOrchestra, and the Philharmonic Orchestra of the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music. The public often gave him standing ovations.

He was also “a graceful, elegant, and aristocratic band and orchestra conductor,” according to AntonioJ.Molina. Among the bands and orchestras he directed were the Orquesta Rizal, Tiwi Orchestra, Banda Pagsanjan, Banda Cuaderno, Banda Kawit, and Banda Tipas.

Besides his public performances, Jacobe taught in various schools. In 1904 he was professor of violin in the Centro Artistico, Manila, and in 1916, became a member of the faculty of the newly opened UP Conservatory of Music. He also taught at the Centro de Bellas Artes, Centro de Artistas de Manila, San Juan de Letran, San Beda, and La Salle.

Among his compositions, none of which can be located at present, were “Zorilla,” “Tres Dalagas” (Three Maidens), “Trining,” “Concha,” “Juanita,” and “Amparo.” He also composed the musical scores of the following sarsuwela: Mabuhay ang Filipinas! (Long Live the Philippines!), Tatlong Maria (Three Marys), and Amor Patria (Love for the Motherland). Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang

JAVIER, DANNY (Daniel Morales Javier) b. Manila 6 Aug 1947. Composer, singer, actor. He is the son of Leonardo Javier and Teofista Morales. He is married to Catherine Ann Francisco and has four children. He received his elementary education at the Colegio de la Immaculada Concepcion in Cebu City, Gacat Elementary School in Southern Leyte, and Calagasan Elementary School in Argao. Starting 1958, he studied in various schools in Metro Manila, finishing his high school at San Beda College and bachelor of arts in general studies, minor in psychology and philosophy, at the Ateneo de Manila University. At various times, he worked as vice-president for programming and merchandising at IBC 13, marketing manager of Jem Recording Company, and board member of Adams Mining Corp. He has been a consultant of the Commission on Elections for its information and education program and currently runs the Pidrophil Trading International Corporation.

Javier is part of the ApoHikingSociety, one of the most popular singing groups in the country since the 1970s and a stalwart of the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit or OPM for nearly four decades. He has sung with the Apo in its performances in almost all major cities in the country and its series of concerts in the United States, Canada, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. He has recorded 18 albums with the Apo, several of which were gold and platinum record awardees, and written over 300 songs, of which several scores have been recorded.

Among Javier’s well-known compositions are “Show me a Smile,” “PumapatakangUlan” (Rain is Falling), “Kaibigan”


(Friend), “Kabilugan ng Buwan” (Full Moon), “DiNaNatuto” (You Never Learn), “Awit ng Barkada” (Song of the Gang), “Paano” (How), “Just a Smile Away” (a jingle for a toothpaste commercial), and “Isang Dangkal” (A Handbreadth). His other compositions include “Doo Bidoo,” “Simbang Gabi” (Dawn Mass), “Suntok sa Buwan” (Taking a Chance), “Agila, Haring Ibon” (Eagle, Bird King), “Ajaw Ajaw,” “Alam Ko” (I Know), “Animal Song,” ”Bakit ang Babae” (Why Oh Woman), “Blue Jeans,” “Care,” “Dream of Me,” “Gabi na Naman” (It’s Night Once Again), “Good, Good Time,” “Kailangang Malaman Mo” (You Need to Know), “Kumot at Unan” (Blanket and Pillow), “Labag sa Batas” (Against the Law), “Lullaby,” ”Lumang Tugtugin” (Old Tune), “Maghihintay Pa Rin” (Will Still Wait), “Mahal Pa Rin Kita” (I Still Love You), “Moral of the Story,” “Pag-Ibig” (Love), “Panahon ng Pag-Ibig” (Season of Love), “Para Lamang sa ’Yo” (Only For You), “Pasko na sa Mundo” (It’s Christmas Time On Earth), “Prinsesa”(Princess), “Prisoner’s Lament,” “Sabado na Pare Ko” (It’s Saturday My Pal), “Show Me a Smile,” “Tamad” (Lazy), “Tell Me Why,” “This is My Song,” “Those Were the Good Ole Days,” “True to My Music,” and “Words.”

Javier has appeared frequently on television as host of various game or musical shows. From 1990 to 1998, he co-hosted with Jim Paredes and Boboy Garrovillo the Apo’s own noontime musical variety show on ABS-CBN. Javier has also been involved in several TV commercials as part of the Apo or as the character he created and has become identified with: Pidro, the probinsiyano (provincial lad) who expresses the down-to-earth values in Filipino life. Written byRosalinda Galang updated by Crisancti L. Macazo
Jocson, Max (See FILM volume.)

JOSE, REGALADO (Regalado San Luis Jose) b. San Juan, Rizal 13 May 1927. d. 30 Nov 2009. Pianist, conductor, pedagogue. He was the third of eight sons of Lino Jose of Baliuag, Bulacan and Emilia San Luis of Marilao, Bulacan. Lino worked in a Manila printery but was a prizewinning poet on the side; he declamed tulang pamutong to local beauties as they were crowned on festive days. Emilia was a seamstress. Regalado married his piano student, Remedios Aranas Trota of Zamboanga City in 1954. Remedios herself studied voice under Jovita Fuentes. The couple have six children, two of whom, Regalado Jr, and Ricardo, are writers. Regalado studied at the Burgos Elementary School and finished his high school at the University of Manila. He began his music lessons with a neighbor, the mother of Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, in whose house there was a piano. While still young, Jose fractured his right middle finger while fixing his bike—improper treatment left that finger permanently bent like an L-hook, but this was never noticed by his future audiences. Lino often took his son to compete in pagalingan sa piano (piano-playing competitions) in fiestas and bring home some extra prize money. In his teens, Jose played the piano accompanying silent movies at the Manila Metropolitan Theater. Here he accompanied Jose Mossessgeld in his production of the opera Rigoletto. During the Japanese occcupation he took piano lessons at Philippine Women’s University. In 1946, he obtained his teacher’s diploma from the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, then located at the Philippine General Hospital compound. This was ahead of his high school diploma in 1947. In 1951, he began studies at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore, Maryland, USA. In 1952, he obtained his master’s degree and, in 1953, his artist’s diploma. He was also a scholar at the Mary Washington College, University of Virginia, and a Walter Huffman Personal Scholar in Composition in 1952. UP granted him an additional year of study, and in 1953 he graduated at the top of his class.

Jose’s first major performance as a concert pianist was at the Independence Day Concert at the Rizal Memorial Coliseum in 1946. His concert on 18 Oct 1947 at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Gymnasium launched his career. The program included the Philippine premier of the then ultra-modern Concerto for Piano and Orchestra by Shostakovich. Despite a blackout, his unwavering delivery of Chopin’s Polonaise in A Flat Major landed him in Society pages. He has played with almost all Filipino conductors as well as with George Hurst, Helen Quach, Herbert Zipper, and other foreign conductors. Jose premiered the piano concertos of Filipino composers Eliseo Pajaro, Lucino Sacramento, and Rodolfo Cornejo. He concertized extensively here and abroad. In the 1960s, he and Remedios, billed as “Two hearts that beat as one,” gave duo piano concerts all over the country. Jose also accompanied most of the top Filipino artists of his time—especially memorable were his renditions of Philippine kundiman and German lieder with baritone Aurelio Estanislao. He was commissioned to assist many visiting performers, such as soprano Montserrat Caballé and cellist Pierre Fournier. He played Liszt’s Sonata in B Minor as Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolph Nureyev did a pas de deux at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. His last major performance was the Concerto for Piano and Orchestra by Nicanor Abelardo in 2007.

He served as resident conductor of the Manila Symphony Orchestra from 1972-78. As the first music director and conductor of the Metro Manila Symphony Orchestra in 1978-83, he brought music to many audiences through the Concert at the Park series at the Rizal Park. Ever protective of the ordinary musician’s lot, he once held up the second act of Rigoletto until the sponsors agreed to come up with the salaries of the orchestra. He conducted for foreign artists like Paul Badura-Skoda, Natalia Makarova, and many others. He also conducted the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra.

Jose began teaching at the newly created UST Conservatory of Music in 1947. Among his co-teachers were Julian Esteban Anguita, Bernardino Custodio, Mercedes Matias-Santiago, Antonio J. Molina, and Salvacion Oppus-Iñiguez. His fellow students then included vocalists Grace Turla Melendres and Remedios Bosch-Jimenez, pianists Benjamin Tupas, Reynaldo Reyes, and Leandro Locsin. He returned to UP to teach in 1948, after concertizing with the Municipal Symphony Orchestra of Manila in a tour to Hongkong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Hawaii and Guam. At UP, he became chair of the piano department in 1966 until his retirement in 1992. He continued teaching until shortly before his death, investing more than 60 years rearing generations of musicians. He also taught at Santa Isabel College, Philippine Women’s University, and College of the Holy Spirit.

Jose received numerous honors and citations. He was Accompanist of the Year, 1949. He won first prize over 130 contestants in a TV piano competition in Baltimore, Maryland in 1952. The following year, he also received the American Student Leaders Award, and upon his return to the Philippines, was named Filipino Musician of the Year by the UP Conservatory of Music. Among his other awards are: Award of Music in the Field of Music and Pedagogy and Musicianship, UP College of Music, 1960; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan, City of Manila, 1973; Outstanding Pianist, Music and Arts Center, Malolos, Bulacan, 1977; and Gintong Ama Award, 1991. He was appointed professor emeritus by the UP College of Music in 1992. Written byMa. Patricia Brillantes,updated by Regalado Jose

JUAN DE LA CRUZ BAND This Filipino rock band was formed in 1968 with members Wally Gonzales on lead guitar and vocals; Sandy Tagarro on bass guitar and vocals; Edmund Fortuno on drums; Bing Labrador on keyboards; and Alex Cruz on saxophones and flute. The band’s first major appearance was at the Antipolo Rock Festival in Dec 1970. This was followed by the Cultural Center of the Philippines production of the rock opera Jesus Christ Superstar by Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber where Tagarro played the role of Judas Iscariot.

The Juan de la Cruz Band easily distinguished itself from the outset by performing only their own original compositions. This was a major break from the prevailing trend in the Filipino music scene where local versions of foreign hits were popular and deemed viable by the recording companies. Despite its effort, it would still take some years before the band would be on firm footing with its own works.

The ensuing years found the group in shaky existence with its constantly changing membership. Fortuno, Labrador, and Cruz left to form their own band, Anak Bayan. Tagarro soon followed suit. Replacements came in the persons of Clifford Ho, Bobot Guerrero, Romy Santos, and Rene Sogueco, who also left for other bands despite the critical acclaim garnered by the Juan de la Cruz Band’s debut album Up In Arms for the Sunshine label of Vicor Music Corporation.

It was in 1974 when Gonzales unveiled the new Juan de la Cruz Band which would rock the local music industry. Forming a powerhouse trio with Wally were Joey Smith, who would later come to be known as Pepe Smith, and Mike Hanopol. The trio were former members of Zero History which performed in Tokyo. Smith, a singer, composer, and drummer, and Hanopol, a singer, composer and bassist, joined the rock trio Speed, Glue & Shinki with Japanese artist Shinki Chen, which recorded for Atlantic Records in Japan. Smith was earlier also a member of The Downbeats.

The Juan de la Cruz Band made its bow with the album Himig Natin (Our Music) in 1974. The title song became the theme of Filipino rockers who had at long last found something to call their own. It also introduced Pinoy rock as a music genre.

The Juan de la Cruz Band went on to record three more albums Maskara (Mask), Super Session, and Kahit Anong Mangyari (No Matter What). They are the ultimate iconic figures of Pinoy rock and their hits, which include “Himig Natin,” “Balong Malalim” (Deep Well), “Laki Sa Layaw” (Spoiled Brat), “No Touch,” “Titser’s Enemi Number One” (Teacher’s Enemy No. 1) laid out the groundwork for the standards by which Pinoy rock is now measured. Written byCarmencita A. Gil

KABAYAO, GILOPEZ (Gilopez Lopez Kabayao) b. Fabrica, Negros Occidental 23 Dec 1929. Violinist. He is the son of Doroteo Kabayao and Marcela Lopez. He is married to pianist Corazon Pineda with whom he has three children. He showed his musical gifts at an early age. At three, he improvised short pieces in the minuet style on the piano. At six, he began to study violin under his father and piano under his mother; at nine, he made his debut playing Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto with a local symphony. While in the elementary school at Silliman, he was enrolled with the university’s music school. Later he attended the Academy of Music owned by his parents. After World War II, Kabayao studied at the Horacemann School of Music in New York, USA, and became the pupil of Theodore and Alice Pashkus in New York and in Vienna, Austria. At age 19, Kabayao made his international debut at the Carnegie Hall to critical acclaim, accompanied on the piano by his sister Marcelita. Together with her, Kabayao returned to the Philippines in 1953. The two went on a concert tour of the southern provinces, interacting with the audience in every performance. Through their efforts, elementary schools received donations of records and phonographs, and schoolchildren were introduced to classical music.

In 1978, he served as music director and conductor of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. He has taught at the Silliman School of Music as visiting professor and has given master classes in Manila, Vancouver, Beijing, and at the University of Minnesota. Kabayao is credited for having brought classical music to some of the remotest parts of the country. Kabayao continues to promote Philippine music through his recordings and violin transcriptions of Philippine folk songs. He continues to mentor and train young violinists. The Kabayaos are active in the Arts Council of Iloilo Foundation Inc and the Gilopez Kabayao Foundation Inc in the development of Ilonggo artists and Iloilo’s cultural productions. They established the Kabayao Family Quintet, consisting of the couple and their three children. They have a Listening Program for Filipino Youth for teaching music appreciation and a VCD series titled Sayaw Diwa (Spirit Dance), choreography based on Philippine music.

Kabayao has performed in Belgium, Hong Kong, Japan, New Zealand, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore. In 1952, he won second prize at the International Violin Competition under the Academia Nazionale di Santa Cecilia in Rome. His other awards include: the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award, 1961; an honorary doctorate in music from the Central Philippines University, Iloilo City; Outstanding Alumnus Award of Silliman University, 1961; Award of Recognition from the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines, 1966; Presidential Award of Merit, 1969; Ramon Magsaysay Award for Public Service, 1972; the Outstanding Filipino Overseas Award, 1976 (with his wife, Corazon); and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila, 1979. In 2008, Gilopez and Corazon Kabayao were awarded the Gawad CCP para sa Sining (Music). Written byRolando B. Tolentino,updated by Connie Ladrido

KALA Established in 2006, this funk-rock and disco style band revived the 1970s Manila Sound with their album Manila High, distributed by Sony BMG Music Entertainment in 2006. The original members of the group were Raymond Daylo (drums, back-up vocals), Mike Grape (lead vocals), Lyle Pasco (bass guitar), JP Tanchanco (lead guitar), and Brian Tanchanco (lead vocals, keytar, and synthesizers). The last two are children of Salsa King Sonny Tanchangco of the 1970s. The group’s first album immediately obtained the Filipino mainstream listeners’ appreciation as they mixed the prevailing sound of the 1970s with the new technology and the acid jazz style of the present.

Their singles “Jeepney,” “Manila High,” “Bakbakan Na” (It’s War), and “Rock Baby Rock” gained recognition from MYX, a music television network, and from Awit Awards, one of the longest-running music awardgiving bodies. They were awarded in 2007 with the titles Favorite New Artist, Best Performance by a New Group Recording Artist, Favorite New Group Artist, People’s Choice Favorite Group for their song “Jeepney,” and People’s Choice Favorite New Group for their album Manila High. The group continued to promote the Manila Sound fusion with new members (Jade Justine on bass guitar and Voopee Elviña on lead guitar) and recently produced the album titled Future Disco, 2013. Written byCristina Maria P. Cayabyab
Kalayo (See Pinikpikan.)

article_title: Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)
text: Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)

KASILAG, LUCRECIA R. (Lucrecia Roces Kasilag) b. San Fernando, La Union 31 Aug 1918. d. Paco, Manila 16 Aug 2008. National Artist for music. Composer, cultural and arts administrator, educator. She was the third of six children of Marcial Kasilag Sr, a government engineer, and Asuncion Roces, a music teacher and her first musical influence. Shortly after Kasilag’s birth, the family moved to Albay, and then to Manila. At an early age, the young Kasilag played the bandurria and the guitar, and during weekends, her mother would assemble the brood to form the “Kasilag Rondalla” and play before their mother. She graduated valedictorian from Paco Elementary School and from the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) High School. After finishing her bachelor of arts degree in English, cum laude, also at the PWU, Kasilag took piano lessons with Concha Cuervo and, later, Pura Lacson-Villanueva and Sr Baptista Battig. In 1939, she obtained her music teacher’s diploma from St Scholastica’s College of Music and was sent on an Asian tour by impresario Alfredo Lozano. She finished her bachelor of music degree at the PWU, and then studied at the Eastman School of Music, University of Rochester in New York, where she obtained her master of music degree, major in theory and minor in composition in 1950. She was conferred the following honorary doctorate degrees; doctor of music by the Centro Escolar University, 1975; doctor of laws by the Philippine Women’s University, 1980; and doctor of fine arts by the St John University, New York, 1981.

Kasilag taught at St Scholastica’s College and Assumption College, 1939-41; PWU, 1939-44; and the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music, 1946-47. While at PWU, she did pioneering research into indigenous culture and gained worldwide recognition as the music director of the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company. From 1953 to 1977 she was dean of the PWU College of Music and Fine Arts.

She served as artistic director and, later, concurrently as president of the Cultural Center of the Philippines from 1969 until her retirement in 1986, and as a special consultant from 1986 to 1989. She held key positions in national and international music organizations, among which were: chair, League of Filipino Composers, 1956-98; president, National Music Council of the Philippines, 1973-83; executive secretary, Regional Music Commission of Southeast Asia, 1953-56; president, Philippine Society for Music Education, 1972-75; chair, Committee on Culture, UNESCO National Commission of the Philippines, 1972-86; chairman emeritus, Asian Composers League, 1990-92; and president, National Music Competitions for Young Artists Foundation, 1990-ca 1998.

Kasilag began composing during World War II. She has written over 350 compositions: folk song arrangements, art songs, solo instrumental pieces, and choral, chamber, and orchestral works. She has done significant pioneering work in combining the resources of accidental and oriental instruments in East and West compositions.

Some of her works which were recorded by Kubing Records in 1979 are: Toccata for Percussions and Winds, 1958; Divertissement for Piano and Orchestra, 1960; Legend of the Sarimanok, 1963; Filiasiana, choral dance kaleidoscope, 1964; Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: The Golden Salakot), for indigenous instruments and mixed chorus, 1969; Ekologie I: On a Day Off, for tape recorder and indigenous instruments, 1972; the operatorios Her Son, Jose, 1977, and The Spiritual Canticle, 1991; and music for the ballet, Sisa, 1976.

Her fusion of eastern and western musical influences are evidenced in works such as Improvisations No. 2, for Muslim gamelan and tipangklong, 1970; Improvisations Nos. 3 & 4, 1974; Ang Apoy ng mga Hayop (The Fire of Animals), a musical tale for indigenous instruments, 1986; Trojan Women, 1994; Visions: Dialogue for Western Flute and Pinoy Flutes, 1996; Bayanihan Ethniking, 1996; and Prelude Etnika and Toccata, for guitar, 1996. Her keyboard compositions include “Variations on Walay Angay,” 1950; “Sonate Orientale,” 1961; “Scherzino,” 1980; “Rondeau,” 1981; “Elegy on Mt. Pinatubo,” 1992; and “Serendipity,” 1994.

Kasilag’s orchestral works include Ang Pamana (The Heritage), 1966; Violin Concerto, 1983; In the Beginning, 1988; Benedictus Cantata, 1990; Violin Concerto No. 2, 1994; Ode to the President, 1995; and the Centennial Tribute to Filipino Womanhood, a symphonic cycle for orchestra, indigenous instruments and mixed media, 1998. Her last work was Why Flowers Bloom In May, a Filipino opera with Fides Cuyugan-Asensio as librettist. It was staged at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in Mar 2008.

She has written several articles and essays on various aspects of humanities and research in Asian music. Her autobiography titled Lucrecia Roces Kasilag: My Story has been published by the Philippine Women’s University in 2000. Another biography titled Lucrecia R. Kasilag: An Artist for the World was authored by Visitacion dela Torre, and was published by Vera-Reyes, Inc. in 1985.

Kasilag has been recipient of grants from the East-West Center, Fulbright Scholar Commission, Asia Foundation, and the JDR III Foundation. In 1971, she was designated as a Colombo music expert to advise the University of Singapore on the setting up of its music department. She has represented the Philippines as delegate at international conferences of the International Society for Music Education, and has led Philippine cultural delegations to other conferences. She is listed in Who’s Who in the World, International Scholars Biographical Dictionary, The New Groves Dictionary of Music and Musicians, The World Who’s Who of Musicians, The World Who’s Who of Women, Reference Asia: Who’s Who of Men and Women of Achievement and Distinction (Vol II), and Musika Jornal (Vol X), the principal refereed journal of the UP Center for Ethnomusicology published annually.

Among the many honors she has received were the Presidential Award of Merit as Woman Composer in 1956; Presidential Award of Merit and Gold Medal for Leadership and Outstanding Contribution to Music and the Arts in 1960; Republic Cultural Heritage Award in music for her Toccata for Percussions and Winds, 1960, and for her Misang Pilipino (Filipino Mass), 1966; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award in music in 1954 and 1973; the Outstanding Filipino Award for the Arts by the Philippine Jaycee Senate International, 1991; as well as a host of special awards from schools and organizations. Kasilag was also a recipient of several honors from foreign governments—West Germany, Spain, France, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Bulgaria, Japan, Taiwan, and China. In 1989, she was named National Artist for music. Written byAntonio C. Hila,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

KATINDIG, EDDIE (Eduardo Pangan Katindig) aka Eddie K. b. Tondo, Manila 23 Apr 1937. d. Quezon City 24 Dec 2017. Saxophonist. He was the sixth of 10 children of Mariano Katindig and Simeona Pangan. His first marriage with Remedios Hernandez bore six children, three of whom—Tateng, Henry, and Eugene—are musically inclined. After Hernandez’s death, he married Marianne Velasco with whom he had three daughters. He took up aircraft maintenance at the FEATI University. He also studied at the Banda Aguila School of Music in Santa Cruz, Manila in 1956.

Starting as a percussionist, he joined his four brothers in a band called The High Chord (later named Philippine Playmate) which performed in Las Vegas and Los Angeles in the early 1970s. It was during this time that he learned how to play the saxophone from a private tutor. When the group broke up after more than 10 years, he decided to embark on a solo career as a saxophonist. When he returned to the Philippines in 1977, he entertained regularly at the Vineyard Jazz Club and, later on, at Birds of the Same Feather (later Birdland), where he gained a solid following among young audiences. He left again for the United States in 1984 after several stints in local clubs. He returned to the country in 1987. In 1989, he began to record jazz albums for OctoArts Records. To date he has produced six: Eddie K, Eddie K Master Sax, Eddie K Plays OPM, Eddie K Plays the Hits of George Canseco, Christmas with Eddie K, and Christmas on Sax. His first album, Eddie K, 1989, was the first instrumental album to become a gold record. He had a successful solo concert at the Philippine International Convention Center in 1990. His most recent concert was in 1993 at the Diamond Hotel. After that and for a number of years beginning in 1995, he reinvented himself by playing on the vibraphone in a serious jazz standards setting performing in Harris Grill in Alabang. Then from 2005 to 2012, he played with Richard Merk in an all-star band in Merks Bar & Bistro in Greenbelt 3 in Makati.

In 1992, Katindig received a Catholic Mass Media Award as Best Instrumentalist for “Maalaala Mo Kaya?” (Will You Remember?). He was awarded with Lifetime Achievement Awards by pinoyjazz.org headed by Sandra Lim Viray, and by Jazzphil USA headed by Charmaine Clamor. Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Richie Quirino

KILAYKO, LEONOR (Leonor Monserrat Sian Kilayko) b. 27 Apr 1944. Pianist. Her parents are Ramiro Kilayko and Carmen Sian. She grew up in Talisay, Bacolod, Negros Occidental. She studied piano under the tutelage of Sr Cecille Donato, at the St Scholastica’s College Manila, where she earned her bachelor’s degree in music. She then studied at the Mannes School of Music in New York, USA, and under Heinz Schroeter and Gunter Ludwig of the Cologne State Academy of Music. She also attended the master classes of Claudio Arrau in Bonn, Germany, Bela Nagy in Tanglewood, Massachusetts, USA, and Nikita Magaloff in Geneva, Switzerland, and a course in interpretation of Spanish music under Rosa Sabater in Santiago de Compostela, Spain.

In 1990, Kilayko taught at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. In time, some of her students in UP became concert pianists, won in competitions, and later joined the ranks of esteemed piano professors in UP. In the early 2000s she had to return to Talisay to take care of her ailing father Ramiro Kilayko.

Kilayko has performed numerous times in the country and in Germany, France, Austria, Spain, Switzerland, Mexico, and the United States. She has also played over the radio for Deutche Welle, Deutche Rundfunk, and Radio Hilversum. In the early 1990s, she did an all-Schumann concert at the UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium. In 1994, she performed Rossini’s Messe Solenelle with the UP Concert Chorus in Belgium. In 1998, during the celebration of the Philippine-German month, she did a concert at the Paco Park where she performed pieces by Scarlatti, Mendelssohn, Brahms, and Schumann. The concert was part of a regular program titled Paco Park Presents, aired in PTV 4. In 1999, she performed in a benefit concert at the Philamlife Auditorium, the proceeds of which went to the Sian-Kilayko Foundation for the Arts and Sports. In 2001, she did a repeat performance of Messe Solenelle with selected artists from UP and University of Santo Tomas (UST), in Bacolod. In 2012, she did three solo concerts: at the Paco Park where she performed German classics; in Talisay at the third death anniversay of her father; and again in Talisay in a concert titled A Night of the Masters and Leonor Kilayko.

Kilayko was a recipient of the Sister Baptista Battig Centennial Award given at the St Scholastica’s College Manila in 2007. She also received a plaque of recognition from the Society for Arts and Culture in 2012. Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by James C. Diaz

KONTRA-GaPi (Kontemporaryong Gamelan Pilipino) This is an indigenous music and dance ensemble in residence at the College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman. Founded in 1989 by art studies professor Pedro “Edru” Abraham Jr, the group’s goal is to promote and experiment with Filipino musical practices through the use of indigenous instruments from different ethnolinguistic groups across the Philippine archipelago (Abraham, 2015). Kontra-GaPi’s repertoire is a fusion of newly created music drawn from various traditions like the Maguindanao and Maranao kulintangan from Mindanao, and the gangsa (flat gong) and bamboo music of the northern Mountain Province and Kalinga. The group also incorporates local dances into stylized choreographies like the traditional pangalay and igal of the Samal-Sama Dilaut (Badjao) peoples in the south, and the ati-atihan in the Visayas. Every year Kontra-GaPi trains 15 to 20 new recruits. Since its inception, the ensemble has had around 600 student members perform with the group locally and in tours abroad. They had visited the United States in 2000, Australia in 2003, Thailand in 2009, and China for the World Exposition in 2010. Kontra-GaPi also represented the country in six folkloric festivals in 2013, where they earned distinctions. In 2014, music percussion student Jaimar Palispis officially became the group’s associate director.

Kontra-GaPi also maintains an active sociopolitical voice, conscious in its advocacy for the welfare of indigenous communities, human rights, and the environment. These advocacies remain in line with the group’s stand against anything that “stifles freedom, individuality, and inventiveness,” hence the additional layer of meaning in the group’s name as kontra (against) -gapi (shackle). With its rhythmically driven soundscape, Kontra-GaPi highlights the more participatory and communal aspect of music making, maintaining the philosophy that creativity can also be derived from within the community and that artistic excellence is not the sole property of “experts” nor of “leaders in the power centers of music.”

Kontra-GaPi received the UP Diliman Chancellor’s Recognition for Outstanding Achievement in the Performing Arts in 1996. Written byIsidora Miranda

Sources:

Abraham 2015; Caruncho 1996; Kontragapi Wordpress 2015.

article_title: La Torre, Sylvia (See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)
text: La Torre, Sylvia (See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)

LAICO-VILLANUEVA, VIRGINIA (Virginia Los Baños Laico-Villanueva) b. Manila 7 May 1952. Pianist. She is the daughter of Jaime Laico and Luz Los Baños. She is married to Edwin Villanueva with whom she has three children. She earned her bachelor’s degree in music at the Chicago Conservatory College in Illinois, USA in 1972 and her master of musical arts at the Peabody Conservatory of Music in Baltimore, Maryland, USA in 1974. She has taught at the Peabody Conservatory of Music and St Scholastica’s College where she teaches music history and literature.

Laico-Villanueva started to play professionally in 1972. She performed as soloist for the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra (now Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra) in 1976, 1977, and 1980, and the Daegu Symphony Orchestra in Korea in 1982. She has worked with conductors Luis Valencia, Shalom Ronli-Riklis, Ilarion Ionescu Galati, and Regalado Jose. Laico-Villanueva has performed in several cities in the United States, in Philippine venues such as the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), PCIBank’s Francisco Santiago Hall, and St Cecilia’s Hall of St Scholastica’s College, and on radio in Singapore, Hong Kong, and South Korea. She was featured by the CCP in its Filipino Artists Series in 1989 and 1991. She was one of the guest performers at the Piano Festival of the French Piano Institute in 1999 and is one of the few Filipino pianists to perform a solo concert in Budapest, Hungary. Aside from performing, she has composed a few works which include “Woodwind Trio,” 1983, “In a Maranaw Village for Solo Piano,” 1995, and “Philippine Postcards Two Piano Suite,” 1998.

She received the Young Artist Award from the Manila Symphony Society and Chopin award and Battig Music Guild Scholarship from St Scholastica’s College, and Artist Award from the National Federation of Music Clubs of the United States, and first prize for her work Tatlong Awit Tungkol sa mga Bata (Three Songs About Children), an entry to the CCP Song Cycle Composition Contest. She was commencement concert winner at the Chicago Conservatory College. She has been accorded the Outstanding Scholastican Award, the Sister Baptista Battig Centennial Award for Music Education, and the Sister Baptista Battig Centennial Award for Performance as Concert Artist in 2006 during the centennial celebration of St Scholastica’s College. Written byRosalinda Galang and Elmer L. Gatchalian,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

LAS PIÑAS BOYS CHOIR (LPBC) The Las Piñas Boys Choir was founded in 1969 by Fr Leo Reiner, a Belgian priest in the Las Piñas Parish Church, which is famous for its bamboo organ. The choir was initially intended to enhance the midnight Mass of Christmas of 1969 through music and songs. The first groups were composed of 24 boys, aged 9 to 14 years old who were all students of St Joseph’s Academy, the parochial school adjacent to the church. After passing auditions, the boys undergo systematic training in music before being chosen to be members of the choir. The choir is supported by the Las Piñas parish and performs regularly for the Las Piñas Church.

The choir became known after winning third prize in the first National Children’s Choir Competition organized by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1972 and first prize in the third edition of the same competition, now under the National Music Competitions for Young Artists, in 1974. Invitations to join musical productions at the CCP followed: Carmina Burana, 1974; Bernstein’s Mass, 1976; Brahm’s Requiem, 1978; Puccini’s La Tosca, 1979; Mozart’s The Magic Flute, 1983; Bizet’s Carmen, 1985; and Britten’s War Requiem, 1992. In 1989, three of its members joined the “World’s Little Singers” held during the bicentennial celebration of the French Revolution in Paris. Moreover, the group has performed at Malacañan Presidential Palace, and in all major cities and towns all over the country. The choir has sung with the Taipei Children’s Choir, at the International Festival for Children’s Choirs in Tokyo, and at the Choir Festival of Brisbane, Australia.

A more regular schedule of concerts was offered to the boys with the yearly International Bamboo Organ Festival, which took off after the restoration of the Bamboo Organ in 1975. Few children’s choirs in the country have the opportunity to perform a major choral work year after year, to meet different conductors and orchestras, and to be exposed to the music of the masters, such as St John’s Passion, Magnificat, Mass in B minor and many cantatas of Bach, the Coronation Mass, Great Mass in C of Mozart, Coronation Anthems of Handel and Salve Regina and Great Organ Mass of Haydn, Misa ng Sambayanan Pilipino (Mass of the Filipino People) by Francisco Feliciano, and “Gloria” and “Magnificat” by Vivaldi. The shorter masses performed during the Festival were heard again on Sundays during the High Mass, accompanied by the Bamboo Organ. The choir’s repertoire has also expanded to include Filipino kundiman and light classics.

Two long-playing albums were produced in 1975: one presenting the newly restored Bamboo Organ, and a second one with Filipino Christmas carols. All their festival performances have been documented on the yearly Highlights (cassette and CD) since 1982.

Early exposure to music has made several alumni decide in favor of a career in music. One of them is organ builder Cealwyn Tagle, who, together with his company—the Diego Cera Organ Builders—is responsible for the restoration of some of the historical organs in the country. A second alumnus is Armando Salarza, who now teaches organ at the University of the Philippines College of Music and St Scholastica College’s School of Music. His formation in Graz and Vienna as organist and church musician for 10 years also benefited the choir, which he headed as conductor and musical director since 2003. Under his direction the choir was nominated for best choral group in the 2005 and 2006 Aliw Awards, and was declared champion of the children’s choirs category during the fifth World Choir Games held in Graz, Austria in 2008. The choirmasters who helped build a 45-year-old tradition of choral singing in Las Piñas are Fr Leo Renier, 1969-74; Engracio Tempongko with Zenas Lozada as accompanist, 1974-79; Fr Leo Renier and Donna Ofrasio as accompanist and trainer of the preparatory choir, 1979-95; Renato Cortes, 1995-2000; Ricardo Mazo, 2000-01; Gerardo Fajardo, 2001-03; and Armando Salarza, 2003-present. Music has been their medium to train characters and personalities. They have proven that it is still possible to find young boys who feel rewarded not by money or stardom but by the mere satisfaction of a good performance, and who never stop striving for perfection. Written byMilagros Carunungan, Elmer L. Gatchalian, Leo Renier, and Armando Salarza,updated by Ma. Josephine Baradas
Lasaten, Jessie (See FILM volume.)
Latonio, Jun (See FILM volume.)

LEAGUE OF FILIPINO COMPOSERS (LFC) Founded in Oct 1955 under the auspices of the Regional Music Commission of Southeast Asia, the LFC aimed to cultivate, promote, and propagate contemporary music composed by its members. It had 11 charter members, with conductor-composer Eliseo M. Pajaro as founding chairman. From 1956 until 1998, Lucrecia R. Kasilag served as its chairperson. From the original 11 charter members, the League has accepted only 27 members until 1990, many of whom have later been conferred the National Artist award.

Until 1968, the LFC organized annual festivals of Philippine music featuring the new major works of its members, through subsidies from the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines. The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) continued the holding of the annual Philippine Music Festival from 1969 to 1990. Starting 1976, the LFC, together with the CCP, conducted annual nationwide competitions for young composers, which have generated more than 40 new works in varied forms, ranging from art songs to chamber music, piano compositions, and symphonic music. It also held workshops and seminars to promote contemporary works among Filipino composers. It received substantial assistance from the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines and the CCP in the form of commissions and financial subsidies. The League also commissioned new works for orchestra and other instrumental ensemble.

Members of the League continued to write major compositions using western idioms with conventional traditions using folk themes and legends. Western genres such as the concerto, symphony, symphonic poem, overture, suite, opera, choral, chamber, art song, ballet and incidental music were written, combined with 20th century musical practices such as atonality, minimalism, polyrhythm, polytonality, percussive dissonance, electronic music, and Eastern modal systems. These produced works of distinct cultural personality that helped elevate the Filipino composers who were evaluated by global standards.

In 1973, the LFC became a member of the Asian Composers League (ACL), and hosted the Third Conference Festival of the ACL in 1975, the first large-scale event in the history of the organization. On this occasion, Lucrecia R. Kasilag was elected chair of ACL, a position she held until 1990. The ACL began with four-member countries and later expanded to 12. International conferences organized by the ACL provided a space for exchanges and dealt with topics which included, among many, the attainment of international levels of acceptance and recognition of Asian composers. In 2005, a local chapter of the ACL, the Asian Composers League, Philippines Inc., was founded and it has taken the role of supporting and fostering the development of contemporary musical compositions of Filipino composers.

The commissioned symphonic works by the LFC have been recorded in the four-disc Pagdiriwang (Celebration) which was released in 1979. This was followed in 1983 by the recording of two violin concertos by Lucrecia R. Kasilag and Alfredo S. Buenaventura featuring violinist Carmencita Lozada and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra.

The living members of the LFC include: Ryan Cayabyab, Jerry A. Dadap, Verne dela Peña, Bayani M. de Leon, Ruben R. Federizon, Manuel P. Maramba, OSB, Eduardo Parungao, Ramon P. Santos, and Chino Toledo. Deceased members are Rosalina Abejo, Alfredo S. Buenaventura, Antonino Buenaventura, Rodolfo S. Cornejo, Bernardino F. Custodio, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Francisco F. Feliciano, Lucrecia R. Kasilag, Antonio J. Molina, Eliseo M. Pajaro, Angel M. Peña, Hilarion F. Rubio, Lucino T. Sacramento, Lucio D. San Pedro, Rosendo Santos, Amada Santos Ocampo-de Francesco, Ramon Tapales, and Restie Umali. Written byEdgardo B. Maranan,updated by Arwin Q. Tan

LEDESMA, KUH (Maria Socorro Hashim Ledesma) b. Bacolod City 16 Mar 1955. Singer, actor. Born to Luis Ledesma and Carmen Hashim, she finished her elementary and high school at the Malate Catholic School. She obtained her nursing degree at the Colegio de San Agustin in Bacolod. She married Luis Manuel Gonzales with whom she has a daughter, Isabella, who is also a singer. Ledesma was the lead vocalist of Music and Magic before she decided to become a solo singer. In 1980, her first single, “Dito Ba?” (Is It Here?), became a hit. The same year, she appeared as Sita in the dance musicale Rama, Hari (King Rama) at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and held her first concert at the Araneta Coliseum. In 1981, she was Kapinangan, wife of Datu Sumakwel, in the dance musicale Kapinangan, directed by Behn Cervantes at the Manila Metropolitan Theater. These events established her as a singer with not only class and intelligence but also broad mass appeal. In 1982, she had an all-Filipino concert Ako ay Pilipino (I Am a Filipino) at the CCP that featured a variety of indigenous sounds, kundiman, and pop songs. It was followed by another production at the CCP titled Inspired Madness in 1983 where she collaborated with film director Peque Gallaga and composer Ryan Cayabyab.

From 1984 to 1986, she joined the Apo Hiking Society in a series of concerts, Ang Pinoy Nga Naman! (That’s How Filipinos Are) at the Folk Arts Theater. In the 1990s, she had a series of concerts with foreign artists such as Noel Pointer, Jack Jones, Kenny Rankin, The Platters, and Michel Legrand. She also performed with local artists such as Regine Velasquez, Pops Fernandez, and Jaya in her Power of Two Concert series. Since then, Ledesma has performed countless times to a wide range of audiences: in big commercial venues such as the Araneta Coliseum and the ULTRA as well as in the CCP’s Folk Arts Theater, the Philippine International Convention Center, nightclubs and hotels, school gymnasiums and provincial auditoriums, and on tours to the Middle East, United States, and Canada.

Though she became famous as a chanteuse of the heart, she has lately introduced ideas and causes into her performances, as in Bayan Ko (My Country), her concert series at the Music Museum in 1990, and her recent appearances in behalf of ecological concerns. Ledesma has recorded 12 albums on cassette and five on compact disc, many of which became gold records. These include her first album, Kuh, 1980; Kuh’s Magic, 1981; Just You, Just Me and Ako ay Filipino (I Am a Filipino), 1982; Unforgettable and Too Marvelous, 1985; Feeling and Lihim (Secret), 1987; Ba’t Mahihiyang Sabihin (Why Not Say It?), 1990; and Night and Day, 1992.

She appeared in her own TV show, Kuh by Special Arrangement, which ran from Oct 1986 to May 1987, and in various TV specials. She also acted in a few movies: Tinimbang ang Langit (Heaven is Weighed), 1982, where she played the lead role; Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1983; and The Year of Living Dangerously, 1984. Her most recent acting stint was in GMA Network’s My Husband’s Lover, 2013, where she played the mother of lead actor Tom Rodriguez.

Ledesma received the following recognition from Aliw Awards: Best Female Concert and Roadshow Performer, 1980; Best Female Performer in Hotels, Nightclubs, and Restaurants, 1981; and Entertainer of the Year, 1982. She also received the Cecil Award for Best Female Vocal Performance, 1981, and Best Pop Female Vocal Performance and Best Album for Just You, Just Me, 1982. She was chosen as Singer of the Year by the Philippine Movie Press Club, 1981-82, and was recognized by the National Press Club as one of the Ten Most Outstanding Singers in the Philippines in 1990. In 1988, Kuh by Special Arrangement won as Best Musical Television Program at the Catholic Mass Media Awards and was also awarded by the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon as one of the best television programs for that year.

In 1990, she was the country’s first representative to and recipient of the Salem Music Awards in London. She received gold and platinum record awards for the single “Dito Ba?,” 1980, and gold record awards for the albums Kuh, Kuh’s Magic, and I Think I’m In Love. In 2012, her first solo exhibition titled Unexpected was held at the Whitespace Gallery, with 40 artworks. Her awards include best female performer, Awit Awards, for the movie theme song “Pinulot ka lang Sa Lupa” (You Were Picked From the Earth), 1989; Natatanging Gawad Sentenaryo, Most Outstanding Filipino, National Centennial Commission, 1999; Ten Most Outstanding Singers in the Philippines, Tinig Awards, National Press Club, 2003; best cultural and arts program for Paano Kita Mapapasalamatan: A Tribute to George Canseco (How Can I Thank You: A Tribute to George Canseco), 15th Annual KBP Golden Dove Awards, 2006; Lifetime Achievement Award, Reflections 18 Awards, North Hollywood, California, USA, 2006; Best in Collaboration, Aliw Awards, Major Concert, Divas4Divas, 2009; Best Asian Performer, 19th Asia Pacific Excellence Awards, 2011; and Dangal ng Musika ng Pilipino, Awit Awards, 2012.Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Connie Ladrido

LEGASPI, CELESTE (Celeste Kalugdan Legaspi Gallardo) b. Manila 18 Mar 1950.Singer, stage, television, and movie actor, stage and movie producer. Born to painter CesarLegaspi and Vitaliana Kalugdan, she studied at St Paul College in Manila, then at Maryknoll College where she finished mass communications. She is married to arranger-composer Dominador “Nonoy” Gallardo with whom she has three children.

While studying at St Paul, she essayed the lead roles in two college productions: One Legendary Evening and Showboat. She also appeared in several plays of the PhilippineEducationalTheaterAssociation, notably in LinoBrocka’s adaptation of AlbertoFlorentino’s Cavort with Angels, 1967. She worked with director RolandoTinio in TeatroPilipino plays mounted at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), including Orosman at Zafira, 1977. She sang the part of the First Woman in CCP Dance Company’s TalesoftheManuvu, 1977. In 1987 and 1988, she performed the role of Olivia in the Rizal Theater and CCP productions of the hit musical Katy! For CCP’s TanghalangPilipino she portrayed the role of Babae (Woman) in Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road), 1988, Caridad in the sarsuwela PaglipasngDilim (After the Darkness), 1991, and Candida in Ang Larawan (The Portrait), Rolando Tinio’s musical adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1997-98.

Legaspi has made numerous singles and long-playing albums which have reached the gold or platinum mark. Ako at si Celeste (Celeste and Me) garnered a gold record award and featured three gold singles:“SaranggolaniPepe” (Pepe’s Kite), “Tuliro” (Bewildered), and “Gaano Kita Kamahal” (How Much Do I Love You); Celeste, Celeste, produced the gold single “MamangSorbetero” (Ice Cream Man); and Bagong Plaka, Lumang Kanta (New Record, Old Songs), Vols 1 and 2, reached the double platinum mark.

Her most raved about concert performances include Celeste Piano, Saksopon, Perkasyon, at Plawta (Celeste Piano, Saxophone, Percussion, and Flute), 1982 and 1983; Celeste in Black and White with Strings Attached, 1983; Celeste Komiks Konsyerto (Celeste Comics Concerto), 1985; Celeste Sine! Sine! (Celeste Movies! Movies!), 1986; and Celeste Tunog PPO (Celeste and PPO Sounds), 1987.

Legaspi also acted in movies, like Lino Brocka’s Stardoom, 1971, and Sa Kabila ng Lahat (In Spite of Everything), 1991; and in MarioO’Hara’s Tatlong Ina, Isang Anak (Three Mothers, One Child), 1987. On television, she was cast in the TV5 drama series, Glamorosa (Glamourous Woman), 2012, and in GMA Network’s Ang Dalawang Mrs. Real (The Two Mrs. Real), 2014.

In 1986, Legaspi spearheaded with friends the foundation of OrganisasyonngPilipinongMang-aawit or OPM which aimed to promote and propagate original Filipino music. At present, she is a board member of OPM as well as chair of its Artists Rights Committee. She is concurrently the president and project director of Musical Theater Phils Inc, board member of TOWNS, and member of the Green Earth Movement. Celeste is the founding president of PHILSTAGE, an association of professional theater companies that currently puts up the annual Gawad Buhay Awards.

Celeste is the chair of the Culturtain Musicat Theater Productions. At present, she is a board member and vice president of Performing Rights Society of the Philippines, Inc (PRSP), which is an association of performers concerned with intellectual property issues involving singers, dancers, and actors.

Together with Girlie Rodis, she has commissioned and produced original Filipino musicals from 1987 to 2015: Katy! The Musical, 1988 and 2013; Kenkoy Loves Rosing, 1992; Alikabok (Dust), 1995; Sino Ka Ba, Jose Rizal (Who are You, Jose Rizal), 1996; Ang Larawan, 1997; Fire Water Woman, 1999; and Saranggola ni Pepe, 2008.

Among the many awards she received are: Sinag Awards from the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining or PATAS in 1975 for her performance in the TV special At Long Last Celeste, and in 1976 for the TV weekly musical Iba’t Ibang Celeste (The Multifaceted Celeste); Outstanding Performance Award from the World Popular Song Festival in Tokyo, Japan, where she rendered “Puso Mong Nagmamahal” (Your Heart That Loves), 1976; Tinig Awards for live entertainment in 1977, 1979, and 1990 (Hall of Fame); Aliw Awards for Entertainer of the Year in 1978; and The Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service (TOWNS) award in 1989. In 2010, she shared the Gawad Buhay Lifetime Achievement Award with Zenaida Amador. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian,updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

LIBORNIO, JOSE b. Santa Ana, Manila 5 Dec 1858. d. 9 Dec 1915. Band musician and director, composer. His parents are Catalina Ibarra and Francisco Libornio, a piano teacher who died at a young age. He married Gregoria del Rosario with whom he had two children. At the hospicio that took charge of him after his father’s death, Libornio learned how to play the flute. Later, he became a member of the Colegio de Niños Tiples of the ManilaCathedral. He had already reached the fourth year of the segunda enseñanza (secondary school) at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran when he was taken back by his mother who had remarried. With his stepfather’s encouragement, he studied piano and, later, the violin, under native teachers. Though underaged, he joined the Spanish Infantry Band No 7 on its assignments in Jolo, Zamboanga, and Cotabato.

Libornio directed bands in various parts of the country, which took him as far as Vigan, Ilocos Sur. He then joined the Charini Circus in 1882 as a musician, going with it on its engagements in Hong Kong and Shanghai. However, the troupe disbanded in Shanghai after a disagreement, leaving the Filipino members on their own. Libornio made his way to Honolulu, where he taught music and bands for several years, then proceeded to San Francisco, USA, where he became a tramp musician, traveling from state to state. In 1895, he reached Lima, Peru, enlisted in the Peruvian Army, and the following year, was appointed Director General de las Bandas de Musicos del Ejercito of the entire nation. In 1905, he founded a school of music in Lima called the Conservatorio Libornio. He never returned to the Philippines and married a Peruvian, Maria Estrada, with whom he had several children.

It was in Peru where Libornio produced all of his creative works. A list of his musical compositions at the Ministry of War of Peru includes 21 waltzes, 37 marches, six funeral marches, two quadrilles, 13 polkas, a piece for a grand ball, two mazurkas, three danzas, and one gavotte. His works totalled 106 pieces, not including arrangements and compositions for more than 500 pieces of classic and contemporary composers. A significant work was “National Army March,” which used to be played by army bands of Peru.

Libornio was awarded a gold medal for his creative works by the Municipality of Callao during its 81st annual independence celebration and a silver medal by Provincial Council of Lima for directing bands of the Peruvian army. He reached such stature in Peru that when he died, 32 years after he left Manila, his body was borne on the “shoulders of gendarmes with a full regiment attending.” Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang

LICAD, CECILE (Cecile Buencamino Licad) b. Manila 11 May 1961. Pianist. Born to Jesus Licad and Rosario Buencamino, she belongs to a clan of musicians. Her great grandfather Tiburcio Licad was a clarinetist from Arayat, Pampanga, while Fortunato, another ancestor, was a sarsuwela composer and choirmaster of San Miguel, Bulacan. She is the grand niece of composer Francisco Buencamino and the cousin of composers Willy Cruz, Nonong Buencamino, and Lorrie Ilustre, and actor Nonie Buencamino. She was married to Brazilian cellist Antonio Meneses with whom she has a son. She attended school at the Institucion Teresiana (now St Pedro Poveda College). She started her formal music training at age five as a personal scholar of Rosario Picazo at the University of the East School of Music and Arts. Her debut as soloist in the Philippines began at the tender age of seven with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) conducted by Col Antonino Buenaventura. In 1973, at the age of 12, she entered the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, USA, where she trained under Mieczyslaw Horzowski and Seymour Lipkin for three years and with Rudolf Serkin for five years. She continued her training under Serkin at the Institute for Young Performing Musicians in Brattelboro, Vermont from 1979 to 1981. Later, she attended summer sessions in the Ravel Academy in France and Marlboro School and Music Festival as a scholar specializing in chamber music.

Her international career as a soloist was launched when she performed with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra under the baton of Zubin Mehta at Lincoln Center, USA. Licad performed with noted international conductors such as Sir Georg Solti, Claudio Abbado, Seiji Ozawa, Andre Previn, Zubin Mehta, Kurt Masur, Mtislav Rostropovich, Eugene Ormandy, Neville Marriner, Leonard Slatkin, Charles Dutoit, Andrew Davis, Michael Gielen, Michael Tielson Thomas, Pinchas Zukerman, and Alexander Schneider. During her concerts in Europe in 1985-86, she performed with the Berlin Philharmonic and the orchestras of Bamberg, Cologne, Zurich, Mannheim, Baden-Baden, and Saarbrucken. She also had engagements in the Far East and in Tokyo, and a 10-week recital tour of the United States, Canada, Germany, and Italy, capped by a recital at Lincoln Center.

Since 1981, besides her concerts within the United States, Licad toured Europe, Great Britain, and Canada. She also performed in Japan, Australia, Puerto Rico and Brazil, Israel, Morroco, Iceland, Hong Kong, and Columbia. She comes home to the Philippines every year to perform. In 1992, she performed for the Manuel Roxas birth centennial. She has also collaborated with other musicians in chamber music performances such as Peter Serkin, Murray Perahia, Nadja Salerno Sonnenberg, Mstislav Rostropovich, and Alban Gerhardt. She has also collaborated with the Wynton Marsalis Septet. In 2007, she had a performance with cellist son Ottavio L. Meneses at the Cultural Center of the Philippines with the PPO under the baton of Eugene Castillo. Her most recent performance in Manila was Francisfest 2015 with the ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Gerard Salonga.

Licad’s recordings for CBS Masterworks include Sergei Rachmaninoff’s Piano Concerto No 2 in C Minor and Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini Op. 43 with Claudio Abbado and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra by CBS Masterworks Records, 1984, and Frederic Chopin’s Piano Concerto No. 2 and Camille Saint-Saens Piano Concerto No. 2 with Andre Previn and the London Philharmonic, with the latter receiving the Grand Prix du Disque from Warsaw, Poland in 1985. Her recording of Robert Schumann’s Carnaval, Papillons, and Toccata in C Minor released by Sony Classical was cited as record of the month by the Time Magazine Critics’ Choice for July 1990. For EMI, she recorded the sonatas of Johannes Brahms and Cesar Frank with violinist Nadja Salerno Sonnenberg, as well as Tchaikovsky Piano Trio in A Minor, Op. 50 and Brahms Trio for Horn (or viola or cello), Violin, and Piano in E flat major, Op. 40, all in 1994. Other recordings include Cecile Licad Performs Chopin for Music Masters, 1995; Complete Beethoven Edition, Vol. 14: Misc. Chamber Works, Deutsche Grammophon, 1997; Ravel: Piano Works by Music Masters and Summeriest La Jolla by La Jolla Chamber Music Society, 1998; Marlboro Music Festival 50th Anniversary Album, Bridge Records, 2001; Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival: Haydn Guitar Quartet in D Major and Korngold Piano Quintet, Koch Classics, 2002; Louis Moreau Gottschalk: Piano Music, Naxos, 2003; and Casals Encores, Hyperion Records, where she accompanied cellist Alban Gerhardt, 2011.

She appeared on NBC Network television in 1981 with the National Symphony and with cellist Mtislav Rostropovich during the Kennedy Center Honors Program. In 1982, she played Peter Ilych Tchaikovsky’s Piano Concerto No. 1 with Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony. In 1981, Licad received the Leventritt Gold Medal award. It was last given in 1971, and she was the youngest pianist to receive the award as well as the only Asian to receive the said award at that time. Her other awards include: The Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service (TOWNS) award in 1986, Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) award in 1987, Presidential Award of Merit in 1991, and the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, 1994.Written byRosalinda Galang,updated by Ma. Edelquinn Sy-Beltran and Crisancti L. Macazo

LIPPAY, ALEXANDER (Alexander Hopfgarten von Lippay) b. Venice, Italy 2 Jun 1892. d. Baguio City 3 May 1939. Austro–Hungarian composer and conductor. He was the director of the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music from 1925 to 1930, and founder of the Manila Symphony Orchestra in 1931. His father, Bartholomäus Dominik Berthold Palatingraf von Lippay (1864-1919), was a court painter to Pope Pius X, while his mother, a pianist, was Guiditta Hopfgarten. His younger brother, Franz Lippay (1897-1965), was a nationally recognized scientist of Austria.

He studied law and philosophy at the University of Vienna in Austria for five years, and musical science at the Vienna State Academy of Music. He conducted opera orchestras in Frankfurt, Cologne, and Mannheim. He was contracted by UP president Guy Potter Benton (1921-24) to head the UP Conservatory of Music. He received his official appointment as director of the UP Conservatory in Dec 1924 and arrived in Manila on Mar 1925. His term ended in 1930. In 1931, he founded the Academy of Music in Manila. In the same year, the Manila Symphony Orchestra was formally organized under the auspices of the Manila Symphony Society, an offshoot of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, the organization that supported him throughout his 14-year career in Manila. It also marked the inauguration of the Manila Metropolitan Theater in 1931. He conducted the orchestra until his death in 1939.

Manuscripts of four of his symphonic works are found in the Manila Symphony Orchestra Library in St Scholastica’s College, Manila. These are the Variations and Fugue on an Original Theme for Full Orchestra, 1917; Thirteen Variations on the Philippine National Hymn, 1928; Kaleidoscope, Miniatures on Philippine Folksongs for the Orchestra, 1929; and Seventeen Variations and Fugue based on an Ifugao Melody, 1935. Another work, Palad sa Kabus (Palm of the Poor), 1927, which is an arrangement for voice, viola, and wind instruments of a song by Manuel Velez, exists in the Legarda Family Archive. Written byMalou Maniquisupdated by Ma. Edelquinn Sy-Beltran

LLOYD, CECIL aka Mystery Singer. b. ca 1910. d. Metro Manila 6 Apr 1988. Singer. He started singing in 1930 on radio. In 1934, he was featured on KZRM as the Mystery Singer, a term coined by announcer Jimmy Morgan. He finished law at the University of the Philippines in 1936 and made his first recording of Tagalog compositions, MikeVelarde’s “Ikaw” (You) and “Buhat” (Ever Since) in 1939. During the Japanese Occupation, he performed at the Avenue Theater, where audiences cheered every time he sang “Bakit Di Ka Pa Dumarating?” (Why Haven’t You Arrived?), hinting at the American promise to return and liberate the country. He was popularly known for his rendition of the song “Marta.” After World War II, he formed his own band, Rhumbamigos, specializing in Latin American music.

In 1948, Lloyd established Philippine Recording System, the first Filipino-owned record company. Due to financial constraints, it relied mainly on his own recordings of folksongs such as “Lulay,” “MagtanimayDiBiro” (Planting Rice is Never Fun), and other compositions mostly by ConstanciodeGuzman, and adaptations of American hits such as “Are You Lonesome Tonight?” and “Tennessee Waltz.” Later, he was able to attract such talents as SylviaLaTorre, Bimbo Danao, RubenTagalog, TonyMaiquez, PanchoMagalona, and Leopoldo Silos. He left the recording business in 1955 and served as motion picture director, then radio director, for the National Media Production Center until his retirement in 1976. He hosted his own Sunday noontime show on DZRM while performing regularly at the Rizal Park every Saturday.

Lloyd agreed to lend his name to the short-lived Cecil Awards of the Philippine music industry. Before his death, he was legal consultant to the Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines. He is considered the “Father of the Philippine RecordingIndustry”. Written byRolando B. Tolentino

LOBOC CHILDREN’S CHOIR (LCC) The Loboc Children’s Choir is made up of 9 to 16-year old students from Loboc Central Elementary School. Alma Fernando Taldo, an English school teacher from the same town, founded it in 1980 in order to enliven school and community events. Since then, it had garnered national and international awards.

The LCC is a three-time first prize winner of the National Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA), children’s choir category, in 1993, 1995, and 2001. In 2003, the choir earned two major awards at the 6th International Folksong Choir Festival held in Barcelona Spain, winning first prize in the children’s choir category and bagging the Europe and its Songs 2003 Cup for achieving the overall highest mark in all categories. In 2011, the choir won third place in the Tolosa Choral Competition in Spain, children’s choir category.

Considered a cultural treasure of the province of Bohol, the group has performed for visiting dignitaries, including Her Majesty Queen Sofia of Spain in 2012. The choir has concertized in key cities in the United States, Canada, Spain, Italy, Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, France, Singapore, China, Korea, and Vietnam. They sang with the World Youth Orchestra in concerts in Bohol and Cebu in 1999, and also participated in the International Children’s Culture and Arts Festival in Tianjin, China in 2000.

The LCC has played an important role in the promotion of the musical heritage of Bohol. They did a historical performance of the piece Misa Baclayana from circa 18th century in a concert at the Inmaculada Concepcion Parish in Baclayon, Bohol in 1999. They later recorded the music as accompanying audio material for Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua’s book Kirial de Baclayon año 1826: Hispanic Sacred Music in the 19th Century Bohol, Philippines (Ateneo de Manila University Press, 2010). In 2013, they recorded live at the Chiesa Di Santa Maria della Pieve in Arezzo, Italy, which was released into a Christmas CD album titled When Angels Sing. Included in the CD is the group’s performance during the finals night of the 59th Concorso Polifonico Internazionale Guido d’ Arezzo. Another album that they did is titled And a Child’s Heart Sings.

Aside from excellent performances, the choir established the Loboc Socio-Cultural Multipurpose Cooperative (LSCMPC) that provides college scholarships for deserving LCC graduates especially those who intend to pursue a career in music. Moreover, they have been actively involved in raising funds for the rehabilitation and restoration of the churches of Bohol that were devastated by the powerful earthquake that struck the province in Oct 2013.

Alma Fernando Taldo, founder and conductor of the LCC, grew up in a musical environment and learnt music from her paternal grandfather. She is assisted by Noel Kerr Caneda, former LCC member and recipient of the LSCMPC scholarship, who graduated with a degree on bachelor of music choral conducting from the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music. Written byMaria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua

LOPEZ, MINGGOY (Domingo Abagon Lopez) b. Pasil, San Nicolas, Cebu City 12 Aug 1912. d. 20 Jan 1981. Actor, composer, singer. His parents were Juan Lopez and Basilia Abagon. Domingo Lopez married Maria Caridad Falcon, from Sogod, Leyte in 1933. Raised in the crowded barangay of Pasil, Lopez demonstrated an early love for music. At eight years old, he sang and acted in the pastores (Shepherds Play) of Nita Alburo. He later joined a group of artists known as the Zarzuela Cebuana. He dropped out of high school to further develop his talents in acting, singing, and playing musical instruments.

The most memorable year was 1930. That year Lopez was discovered by Badong Yburan, a veteran actor who often played the role of a comedian. He was 18 when Yburan invited him to join the stage actors’ group called Tirana’s Troupe, headed by Emy Gabuya. That same year he played a major role in a play and was hailed as a consummate actor. Finally in 1930, he wrote his first song, “Pagkatam-is” (How Sweet), which was sung by Diosdado Alferez, another Cebuano musician, for a singing contest at San Nicolas. This song won first prize. Later, Lopez composed “Karon Pa Lamang” (Only Now), his second song, which was also very popular, and another memorable balitaw titled “Kagahapon ug Karon” (Yesterday and Today).

Because the actor’s blood ran strong in his veins, acting soon became his profession. From the group of Emy Gabuya, Lopez moved on to Piux Kabahar’s group. It was there that Domingo Lopez penned the lines of the song “Rosas Pandan,” which was made into a film, with script by Piux Kabahar and directed by Toting Villarino. In this same movie, Lopez’s balitaw titled “Bukidnon” was performed. After learning what he could from Kabahar’s group, Lopez joined the actors’ group of Toting Villarino who were mainstays at the famous Teatro Oriente. From there, he later joined the Antingan Troupe led by Leox and Tancred Juezan.

Though Lopez had no formal training in reading music, he learned the skill from Pidong Villaflor. The young Lopez always stayed by the side of Pidong at barrio Kalubihan, especially when the latter was composing a song. Another famous Cebuano composer, Ben Zubiri, hung out with Lopez. Many of Lopez’s songs were recorded by D’ Sound Recording under the management of Jhul Antopina, a writer who also made records. Among these were “Sala sa Panahon” (Time’s Fault) and “Hagki Ako” sang by Yelly Albino.

Lopez also wrote carols, such as “Pasko sa Buta” (A Blindman’s Christmas) and “Maayong Pasko, Tagbalay” (Merry Christmas, Householder). The latter was sung by Sergs de la Peña and became very popular throughout the Visayas and Mindanao. Another song Lopez composed was “Ayaw Gayod Palipat” (Don’t Be Fooled) which was sung by the Zabala sisters and brought a lot of sales for D’ Sound Recording. His song “Salimuang” (Delirious) was considered a masterpiece.

Lopez also acted in radio and television. He was a member of Cedric Tumulak’s group with ABS in Cebu. He was the main actor in the play Maria Flor de Luna which was famous on air in the Visayas and Mindanao. Written by Hope Sabanpan-Yu

LOPEZ-VITO, MA. LUISA (Ma. LuisaLopez-Vito Koch) b. Iloilo City 10 Aug 1939. Pianist. Born to Jose Maria Lopez-Vito and Remedios Jalandoni, she married Hans Georg Koch. She studied at the University of Santo Tomas under BenjaminTupas and, beginning in 1957, in the Mannes School of Music in New York with Olga Stroumillo, who was known for the Leschetizky piano method. She gained national recognition in her first public performance as soloist for the Manila Little Symphony Orchestra and as first-prize winner of the Mozart Bicentennial Competition in Manila. In the United States, she took part in Tanglewood Summer Festival in 1957 and in the Marlboro School in Vermont in 1962 where Rudolf Serkin coached her.

Lopez-Vito’s repertoire covers a wide range of the piano literature, particularly music by 19th century German and French romantic composers. Beginning the mid-1980s, she dedicated herself to New Music, as soloist and member of the Ensemble Musica Negativa, strong followers of the Second Vienna School of Schoenberg, Berg, and Webern. She recorded the works of Theodor W. Adorno, Hubert Stuppner, and Victor Fenigstein.

Since 1961, she won major prizes in the various international competitions, among them, fourth prize in the Van Cliburn Competition in 1966; first prize in the International Piano Competition, Orense, 1967; the De Falla Prize in Madrid, 1968; Selection Prize in the Busoni International Piano Competition 1970; first prize in the Concours International de Piano, Epinal, 1973; and second prize in the Concours Cziffra, Versailles, 1974. After her debut concerts in New York, she also performed in several European countries, particularly in Spain. Her last concerts in the Philippines were with the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra and SergioEsmillaJr, 1982; with the PhilippinePhilharmonicOrchestra and OscarC.Yatco, 1984; and at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines, 1989. Since 1969, Lopez-Vito has resided in Germany, where she recorded for Radio Berlin, Stuttgart, and Frankfurt. She stopped appearing in public after an illness in 2002. Written byRolando B. Tolentino updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

LOVING, WALTER (Walter Howard Loving) b. Livingstone, Virginia, USA 17 Dec 1872 d. Manila 1945. Band conductor. He was married to Edith McCary, with whom he had a son, Walter Jr, who rose through the ranks of the US Military, served in Korea as an infantry officer, and retired as a colonel in 1969. Walter Sr was a graduate of the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston and took up a postgraduate course at the Leipzig Conservatory in Germany. In 1899, he arrived in the Philippines with the US Army, and in 1902 organized the Philippine Constabulary (PC) Band. The band started with 30 members and grew to 80. At the St Louis Exposition in 1904, it garnered the grand prize and a gold medal, and in 1909 played during the inauguration of Pres William Taft at the White House.

He retired from the PC in 1916 to join the US Military in its war effort in the World War I but was not enlisted to take part in combat. He served as a civilian in the Military Intelligence Division. He returned to the Philippines in 1920 to lead the PC Band once more, only to retire again three years later. When Manuel Quezon became president in 1935, Loving was invited to reorganize the PC Band into the Philippine Army Orchestra. He was promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel by Quezon. In 1937, he was asked to prepare the PC Band for the Golden Gate International Exposition in 1939 where it was well received. Their final concert was on 15 Dec 1940, at the Central Student Church in Manila. Loving was killed during the Battle of Manila in 1945, believed to have been beheaded by the Japanese officer, Gen Yamashita, at the entrance of the Manila Hotel.

Loving composed “Marcha de los Colectivistas” (Collectivista March) in 1922 to honor the newly founded Partido Collectivista Liberal of Manuel L. Quezon.

In 2013, the National Historical Commission of the Philippines published a book written by Robert Yoder, titled In Performance: Walter Loving and the Philippine Constabulary Band. Other published articles on Loving include Antonio Hila’s “Walter Loving and the Philippine Constabulary Band,” 2004, and Mary Talusan’s article in the Philippine Studies Quarterly Journal titled, “Music, Race, and Imperialism: The Philippine Constabulary Band at the 1904 St Louis World’s Fair,” 2004. Written byAntonio C. Hilaupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

LOZADA, CARMENCITA (Carmencita Santos Lozada) b. Pasig 11 May 1937. d. Quezon City 15 Aug 2006. Violinist. Born to Lucio Lozada and Felisa Santos, she obtained her bachelor of music degree from the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) College of Music and Fine Arts in 1955 under the tutelage of Luis Valencia. She earned her master of arts degree at the Vienna State Academy in Austria and pursued further studies at the Mozarteum Summer Academy and the Nice International Academy. Lozada gave an impressive performance as a soloist at the closing concert at the Salzburg Mozarteum. She was based in Siegen, Germany, but returned to the Philippines regularly to perform and to give music classes in violin at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, National Arts Center of the Philippines, PWU, and UP. Lozada has concertized widely abroad, playing with major orchestras in Europe, the United States, Canada, and Asia. She has also made radio recordings and television appearances in Germany, Holland, Austria, and Poland. Her disk recordings are with Eurodisc in Berlin. She also played in chamber ensemble and gave concerts with the harpsichord and the organ.

In 2004, her 15-CD compilation was published by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) as heritage recordings. They feature Lozada’s performances with various international orchestras covering 50 years of concertizing around the world, playing the violin concerti of European and Filipino composers.

She earned a diploma of merit in Nice, France. She won twice at the Paganini International Violin competition in Genoa, Italy, in 1956 and 1961.
