In the Philippines, she won in the National Violin Contest in Manila in 1954, and received a presidential award in 1956, the University of the Philippines (UP) Award in 1967, and the Outstanding Overseas Filipino in Music Award in 1977. In 2005, Lozada was conferred the PAMA-AS Gintong Bai Award for her contribution in the advancement of Philippine culture and the art by Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo. Written byAntonio C. Hilaupdated by Arwin Q. Tan
Lucas, Jesse (See FILM volume.)

LUCIA FRANCISCO MUSIC CIRCLE (LFMC). Organized on 12 Dec 1954 by friends and students of Lucia Francisco of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, it aimed to encourage gifted but poor music students to pursue their studies in piano. It also envisioned training piano students to reach their full potential, either as concert artists or pedagogues who will, in turn, mentor future piano scholars. LFMC offered piano scholarships to qualified students between the ages of five and 12 on an annual basis. The students were trained by members of the Circle, comprised mostly of UP graduates with a degree in piano performance. They had been presented in piano recitals at the UP College of Music Abelardo Hall Auditorium.

A four-year scholarship at the university level was established, with a maximum of eight scholarships open every year. Among the Circle’s university scholars were Raul Sunico, Jose Contreras, Corazon Pineda-Kabayao, Adolovni Acosta, and Lino Rivera. Some of the younger pianists are now noted professors at the UP College of Music such as Luci Magalit and Geraldine Marie Gonzales who not only graduated with honors but were also proclaimed in The Ultimate Pianist competition, 2006, grand prize winner and first laureate, respectively.

The first president and co-founder of the LFMC was Eva Ponce-Panajon, who was succeeded by Jose Balingit, and Consorcia Valmonte. The incumbent president is a former child scholar, Guillermo Lauzon, who was installed in office in the early 1990s. Since 2000, the Circle has not been active. Written byFelizidad Z. Reyesupdated by James C. Diaz

LUMUNTOD, AMAL b. Dulawan-Tangwapo, Cotabato circa 1930. Kulintang player. He is a master kulintang player recognized not only in Cotabato but also in Manila. Although he had no formal schooling, he is a respected master of the kulintang in Datu Piang, Maguindanao.

Lumuntod’s musical trademark is the solo performance on the kulintang with no other instrumental accompaniment. He has become the recognized exponent of the binalig Dulawan style of performance. His new style of playing duyug was one of the features of Maguindanaon kulintang, examined by Kristina Benitez in her dissertation titled “The Maguindanaon Kulintang: Musical innovation, transformation and the concept of binalig,” submitted to the University of Michigan in 2005.

He first performed in Manila during the UNESCO International Conference in 1966, before musicians like Iannis Xenakis, Mantle Hood, Tran Van Khe, and Shiegeo Kishibe who all admired him. He visited Iran in 1972 and Hong Kong in 1979. He won international acclaim as kulintang soloist when he toured four countries in Europe in 1988 together with other Filipino musicians. He has also performed in Datu Piang where his style is admired and copied by the younger generation. Among his students are recognized kulintang players Danongan Kalanduyan, Genot Kamensa, Madendog Kamangsa, and Usop Tanggo.

His kulintang solos are featured in the record disc Kulintang and Kudyapiq published by the University of the Philippines Department of Music Research in 1988. He received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in 1991. Written byElmer L. Gatchalianupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

LUNA, MANUEL ANDRES (Manuel Andres Luna) b. Badoc, Ilocos Norte 30 Nov 1856. d. 15 Jul 1883. Violinist. He is the son of Joaquin Luna and Laureana Novicio, and the brother of Antonio and JuanLuna. He studied at the Ateneo Municipal, then at the Escuela Nautica, where he graduated with a certificate of piloto de ambos mares y capitan de cabotaje. He learned to play the violin during his leisure time. Encouraged by his teacher to go abroad, he pursued advanced studies in the Real Conservatorio de Madrid in Spain. He studied and came under the influence of Jesus Monasterio. After receiving his diploma as professor of violin, he gave concerts in Spain, France, and Italy.

Upon his return to Manila in 1879, Luna gave a series of performances sponsored by the Liceo Cientifico Artistico Literario. Foreign musical talents such as Garrido, Coppa, and Arche were his patrons. He made his first public appearance during a benefit concert held at the Teatro de Variedades in 1879, where he played De Beriot’s Scena di Balleto, with Arche on the piano. He also did some conducting during this period. In 1881, during the inauguration of the Recoletos Church, he conducted the grand chorus of about 80 voices, with members of the orchestra of the Manila Cathedral, Artillery Band, and Gruet participating. Apart from this, he gave violin lessons to children of prominent Manila families. Luna died at the young age of 26 years, unmarried, and left no musical compositions. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang

MABUHAY SINGERS. Formed in 1958 by Manuel P. Villar, president and chief executive officer of the Mabuhay Records Corporation (MARECO) more popularly known as Villar Records, the group was a combination of two leading trios at that time—the Tres Rosas and the Lovers Trio. The two groups got together by chance at the MARECO studios in Escolta one afternoon and Villar instantaneously thought of making them sing together. He immediately asked Leopoldo Silos, renowned composer and in-house musical director of the outfit, to conduct the group in singing Manuel P. Velez’s balitaw, “Lawiswis Kawayan” (Hissing Sound of the Bamboo Tops). Villar loved the way the group sounded and instantly he gave it the name Mabuhay Singers, thereby making it the official singing group of his record company. With its name, which literally means “long live,” Villar intended the group to keep alive the Philippine music legacy in the forms of balitaw, danza, kundiman, polka, and others that developed in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and reflect the culture, tradition, and most importantly, the ideals of a nation struggling to be free from foreign oppression and trying to cultivate self-respect and moral virtues among its people.

The members of the Tres Rosas namely, Carmen Camacho, Nora Hermosa, and Raye Lucero, and of the Lovers Trio, namely, Ador Torres, Floro San Juan, and Bert Legaspi were the original members of the group whose voices were immortalized in the first long-playing album of the group produced and released by Villar Records, Halina’t Umawit (Come and Sing). The album consisted of popular Philippine folk songs like “Leron Leron Sinta” (Leron Leron Beloved), “Cariñosa” (Charming Lady), “Aking Bituin” (My Star), “Paruparong Bukid” (Butterfly Song), “Chitchiritchit” as well as folksy songs with known composers such as “Lawiswis Kawayan” by Manuel P. Velez, “Kataka-taka” (How Strange) by Santiago Suarez, “Sarung Banggi” (One Night) by Potenciano Gregorio, and “Tugtuging Bukid” (Rural Music) by Constancio de Guzman.

After the success of this first album, the group came up with the albums Philippine Folk Songs, Maligayang Araw (Happy Day), Mabuhay Singers Sing Pandangguhan, Dahil sa Iyo and Other Philippine Hits (Because of You and Other Hits), Manila, I Love Manila, and Bakasyon (Vacation). In Philippine Folk Songs the group sang folk tunes from the different regions of the Philippines like “Zamboanga” (From the Chavacanos in Mindanao), “My Nipa Hut-Butterfly Song” (from the Tagalog “Bahay Kubo” and “Paruparong Bukid”), “Dandansoy” (from Western Visayas) and “Where is My Ring” (from the Kapampangan’s “Atin Cu Pung Singsing”) with English lyrics that became popular during the American colonial occupation. In Manila, I Love Manila, on the other hand, the group sang standard Filipino love songs like Constancio de Guzman’s “Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig” (My Only Love) and “Maalaala Mo Kaya” (Will You Remember), Juan Silos Jr’s “Ikaw ang Buhay” (You Are My Life), and Miguel Velarde Jr’s “Ikaw” (You) with English lyrics penned by Luis Ma. Trinidad. Obviously, these albums were Villar’s attempt at promoting Philippine songs internationally. It is also worth noting that in the first several albums of the Mabuhay Singers, producer Villar and musical arranger Silos deliberately wanted the group to sing in unison or without complicated vocal arrangements so as not to intimidate but rather invite the listeners to enjoy singing along with the group. However, the later albums produced and released in the late 1960s and early 1970s such as Sariling Awit (Our Own Song), Kundiman, Awit ng Pagmamahal (Songs of Love), Pamulinawen, Perlas ng Silangan (Pearl of the Orient), and Anihan (Harvest), featured more sophisticated vocal and orchestral arrangements by Silos to highlight the ingenuity and artistry of Filipino music. The traditional and classic Christmas songs that are famous today such as “Sa Paskong Darating” (This Coming Christmas), “Pasko Kasi” (Because It is Christmas), “Sino si Santa Klaws” (Who’s Santa Claus), “Himig Pasko” (Christmas Melody), “Damdaming Pasko” (Christmas Feeling), “Dalangin sa Pasko” (Christmas Prayer), and others were originally recorded by the Mabuhay Singers for their Christmas albums, Pasko sa Pilipinas (Christmas in the Philippines), 1961, and Kami Po’y Paskuhan (Give Us Gifts), 1973.

In the early 1960s, Bert Legaspi had to quit the group for some reason and he was immediately replaced by Chi Licerio. That was also the time when Villar started inviting popular soloists of the day to sing as members of the group like Ruben Tagalog, Cely Bautista, Rita Rivera, Noel Samonte, Flor Ocampo, Ric Manrique Jr, Robert Malaga, Don David, Everlita Rivera, Betty Rivera, and Robert Natividad. Other members who came much later in the 1980s, 1990s, and at the beginning of the 21st century were Rene Evangelista, Naning Alba, Leila Atienza, Nolito Gregorio, Peping de Leon, Eddie Suarez, Marlon Marifosque, Jimmy Salonga, Emma Lucero, and Juliet Barangan. With Leopoldo Silos as musical director for more than two decades, the group was able to make around 50 long-playing albums that featured folk, classic, and standard Filipino songs in Tagalog and in the major languages of the Philippines, namely, Cebuano, Waray, Hiligaynon, Kapampangan, Ilocano, Pangasinan, and Bicolano. In some albums, the group also sang songs in Chavacano and Tausug. They also did several albums that featured foreign hit songs in English and Spanish. For their topselling records, the Philippine Records Association honored the group with a citation in 1973. That same year, the Department of Tourism brought the group on tour to parts of the United States and Canada under its grand Balikbayan Project to serenade and convince Filipinos abroad to come home and witness the developments that were taking place in the Philippines under the New Society.

The popularity of their records played on radio programs and all sorts of cultural activities such as fiestas and school-based Filipiniana celebrations all over the country has inevitably made the Mabuhay Singers one of the most in demand performers in the Philippine music industry during the 1960s and the 1970s. In the late 1980s, when Villar Records had become inactive in the recording business, the Mabuhay Singers became the leading musical performers in the Regency of Manila and at the Intramuros Bar of the Hotel Nikko Manila Garden. In the late 1990s up to 2005, the group sang regularly in Tiya Dely Magpayo’s Serenatang Kumbidahan (Invitation to Serenade) aired on Saturday evenings over DZRH 666 kHz of the Manila Broadcasting Company. In Feb 2006, with Michael M. Coroza as producer-host through the support of Sonia Roco, Noel Lacsamana, Jeanette Job-Coroza, and Dennis Regis, the group launched its own program called Harana ng Puso Kasama ang Mabuhay Singers (Serenade of the Heart with the Mabuhay Singers) over DWBR 104.3 FM of the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS), which is aired every Sunday from 8:00 to 10:00 in the evening. The group celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2008 with a two-night grand concert at the Philamlife Auditorium in Manila. This concert was produced and hosted by Sonia Roco with a script written by Michael M. Coroza, production design by National Artist Salvador Bernal, and directed by Jerry Respeto. In 2010, Poly-East Records produced and released the latest CD album of the Mabuhay Singers, Mabuhay Singers: Patuloy sa Pag-awit (Mabuhay Singers: The Singing Continues) where the group sang contemporary hits like Joey Ayala’s “Karaniwang Tao” (Common Person), Aiza Seguerra’s “Pagdating ng Panahon” (When Time Comes), and Florante de Leon’s “Handog” (Offering). The present members of the group are Raye Lucero, Cely Bautista, Emma Lucero, Juliet Barangan, Peping de Leon, Eddie Suarez, and Jimmy Salonga.

In 2004, the Aliw Foundation of the Philippines bestowed upon the group a Lifetime Achievement Award in the field of music. Likewise, in 2006, the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino honored the group with a National Award of Recognition for promoting Philippine languages through songs. In 2008, the School of Humanities of the Ateneo de Manila through its Department of Filipino paid tribute to the Mabuhay Singers with an award of merit for tirelessly promoting Filipino culture through the decades. An exhibit of their memorabilia was installed at the lobby of the M.V. Pangilinan Building to be viewed by Ateneans and guests of the university. Other academic institutions such as De La Salle University and University of Santo Tomas have also paid tribute to the contributions that the group has made in preserving Filipino cultural heritage in music. Written byMichael M. Coroza

MACEDA, JOSE (Jose Montserrat Maceda) b. Manila 31 Jan 1917 d. Quezon City 5 May 2004. National Artist for music. Ethnomusicologist, composer, pianist, educator. He was the son of Casto Noroña Maceda and Concepcion Montserrat. He was married to French pianist Madelyn Clifford with whom he had four daughters.

Maceda graduated with a music diploma at the Academy of Music of Manila in 1935 before he was sent to Paris in 1937, where he studied piano with Alfred Cortot. In 1941, he returned to the Philippines, bringing with him a French style of piano playing in many concerts and recitals. In 1946, he took further studies in San Francisco with E. Robert Schmitz, another French pianist known for his pedagogy and interpretation of French works. He also studied musicology at Queens College and Columbia University in New York, 1950-52, and anthropology and ethnomusicology at the University of Chicago, Northwestern and Indiana Universities, 1957-58. Eventually, he ended up at the University of California in Los Angeles where he got his doctor of philosophy degree in 1964. He also took up musique concrete in Paris at the Radio Television Francaise in 1958, where he worked with Pierre Schaeffer.

In Manila, he turned his concentration from piano playing to composing New Music. He conducted concerts in 1964 to 1968 of avant-garde and Asian Music, including works of Varese, Boulez, Xenakis, and Ravel which were programmed together with Chinese music, kulintang, and kudyapi, and his first avant-garde works. These concerts introduced to Philippine audiences the latest languages of music composition. Among his avant-garde works were: Ugma-Ugma, for native instruments and chorus using blocks of sound alternating with tense-high voices, 1963; Agungan, for gongs featuring decays, densities, colors, sounds struck with sticks, hands, sliding palms, 1965; Kubing, for bamboo instruments and men’s voices, 1966; and Pagsamba (Worship), a ritual music for a circular auditorium, for 116 instrumentalists, 100 voices, and a chorus of 25 men, 1968. Since then, his works have expanded to other realms, involving elements like drone, distribution of labor, a separation of musical functions, relative values of pitch and levels of timbres. These techniques were used in the following: Cassettes 100, for 100 participants with cassette recorders playing together, 1971; Ugnayan (Coordination), music for 20 radio stations, 1974; Udlot-Udlot (Fluctuation), a ritual for open air played by hundreds of performers, 1975; Ading, for 200 performers based on drones and melodic cells, 1978; Aroding, for 40 mouth harps, men’s voices, flutes, 1983; Siasid, for percussion, bamboo tubes and five violins, 1983; Suling-Suling, for 10 flutes, 10 flat gongs, and 10 kudlong, 1985; and Strata, for 10 percussion bars, 5 tumtum, 5 celli, 5 flutes, and 5 guitars, 1988. His compositions in the 1990s include Dissemination, 1990; Distemperament, 1992; Music for Five Pianos, 1993; Two Pianos and Four Winds, 1996; Music for a Chamber Orchestra, 1997; Music for Gongs and Bamboo, 1997; Udlot-udlot for Six Performers, 1997; and Sujeichon, 2002; many of which have been premiered outside of the Philippines, particularly in Japan. His latter works show Maceda’s return to the use of western instruments subjected to his continued musical innovation that featured sounds with constantly transforming rhythm, different densities, texture, sonority, mass, and short melodic fragments.

His monumental composition Pagsamba has been recorded, together with Suling-Suling and Colors Without Rhythms, in a CD titled Gongs and Bamboos, released by Tzadik Records in 2001. A sequel to this album featuring Strata, considered as his most ambitious large scale work, has been recorded together with Sujeichon and Music for Two Pianos and Four Percussions, in an album titled Drone and Melody, also released by Tzadik Records in 2007.

In music research, Maceda has, since 1972, had continuous field experience in many places in the Philippines, Sarawak, Thailand, Kalimantan, and other parts of Southeast Asia, Africa, and Brazil. He has deposited all his research collection in the University of the Philippines (UP) Ethnomusicology Archives. This consists of about 2,500 hours of music in tapes of 51 Philippine ethnolinguistic groups and other groups in Asia, besides field notes, music instruments, song texts, transcriptions and translations, photos, personal files, books in English, European and Asian languages, and his music compositions. A summation of his many decades-long, extensive research on indigenous instruments of the many ethnolinguistic groups in the country is documented in Gongs and Bamboos: A Panorama of Philippine Musical Instruments, published by the UP Press, in cooperation with the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, in 1998.

He was always invited to attend international conferences and deliver lectures in universities and institutions in England, France, Yugoslavia, Hungary, Poland, United States, Brazil, Mexico, Japan, China, Indonesia, India, Iran, Nepal, Malaysia, Vietnam, Thailand, Korea, and Taiwan.

His scholarly works won for him prestigious national and international awards, which include: three grants from Rockefeller Foundation in Southeast Asia, 1956, the United States, 1961-63, and Brazil, 1968; the Ordre des Palmes Academiques from France, 1978; UP Composer’s Award, 1985; UP Outstanding Researcher Award, 1985; the JDR III Award by the Asian Cultural Council in New York, 1986; Philippine National Science Award for Outstanding Researcher in the Humanities, 1987; Gawad Tanglaw ng Lahi from the Ateneo de Manila University, 1987; UP University Professor Award, 1988; the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, 1989; and the National Artist Award in music, 1997.

Maceda dedicated his life towards the promotion of a national cultural identity, initiating and inspiring scholarly study of the musics and culture of the Filipino minority tribes. As a composer, he has incorporated in his works a blending of avant-garde techniques steeped in an Asian philosophical approach to time and music. His experiments blazed the trail of a new trend in composition among younger Filipino composers. Written byCorazon C. Dioquinoupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

MAIGUE, ANTONIO (Antonio Ruiz Maigue) aka Tony Maigue. b. Cavite City 13 Aug 1962. Flutist. He is the son of Benruben Maigue and Caridad Ruiz, a singer. His grandfather, Jose Ruiz, was a composer, pianist, and conductor. He was a member of a jazz band during his high school years at the San Sebastian College in Cavite City. He learned to play the violin and the guitar before his interest shifted to the flute. In 1979, he enrolled at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music for his flute studies. There he became the principal flutist and soloist of the Philippine Youth Orchestra. In 1980, he won first prize in the solo instrument division of the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA). In 1981, he became a scholar at the International Music Camp in Battineau, North Dakota where he was given the Award of Distinction. He also represented the country in the Asian Music Camp held in Tokyo, Japan in the same year. After his graduation recital in 1983 at the UP, he went to Paris as a scholar of the French Embassy, the Young Artists Foundation of the Philippines, the Metro Manila Symphony Foundation, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). He won the single slot for that school year with a degree “Fin d’ etude” after topping the entrance competition at the Conservatoire National de Rueil-Malmaison in Paris. Under the tutelage of French master flutists like Philippe Pierlot, Jean-Pierre Rampal, Alain Marion, Claude Bolling, and Auerel Nicolet, he received his Diploma of Superior Studies the following year garnering the highest honors, Premier Prix, Medaille D’or. He finished his flute studies at the Conservatoire in 1987 with a degree of “Virtuosite.” Upon his return to the Philippines, he has taught at the UP College of Music and at the St Scholastica’s College. At present, he is a full-time professor of flute at the UP College of Music.

A most sought after flutist, he has given concerts in the United States (Chicago, New York, Washington DC, and San Francisco), United Kingdom, Romania, China, Japan, Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong Kong, Singapore, and the Philippines. In 1990, he participated in the Pacific Music Festival in Sapporo and Tokyo, Japan as principal flutist of the London Symphony Orchestra which was conducted by Leonard Bernstein.

Locally, he has been featured as soloist of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, the Manila Chamber Orchestra, and the Manila Chamber Orchestra since 1992. From 1991 to 2001, Maigue appeared numerous times as soloist and as assisting artist for the CCP’s Filipino Artist Series, and its conjunct Bravo Filipino National Circuit Tour Outreach Program which brought him with other artists to Angeles City, Cebu, Capiz, Cagayan de Oro, Bukidnon, Iloilo, and Bulacan in 2001. He has also been featured as a soloist at the 2000 International Bamboo Organ Festival. He was the principal flutist of the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra from 2000 to 2001, and the Manila Philharmonic Orchestra from 2001 to 2006, and again in 2013 for the orchestra’s special performance at the Opera City Concert Hall in Tokyo, Japan.

Maigue has performed with conductors Sergio Esmilla Jr, Pierro Gamba, and Sebastian Bereau, pianists Della Besa and Raul Sunico, guitarist Lester Demetillo, harpist Lourdes de Leon-Gregorio, and singers Luciano Pavarotti, Andrea Bocelli, Lea Salonga, Lani Misalucha, Maria Cristina Viguilla-Navarro, and Josephine Roces.

He has recorded a solo album with Viva Records in the 1990s which was released as part of the company’s Silver Series in 2008. Other recordings include his collaboration with artists such as Armida Siguion-Reyna, Bob Aves, Isay Alvarez, Robert Seña, Gary Valenciano, Inang Laya, and Raul Sunico. He is the musical director of Tutti Flutti, a concert series of solo and ensemble flute performances which he founded in 2009, as well as the Manila Flute Choir from 1998 to 2005.

Maigue was selected as one of the Ten Outstanding Young Men of the Philippines (TOYM) in the field of Music Concert and Contemporary Music in 2002. He received the UP Gawad Chancellor Award Para sa Pinakamahusay na Alagad ng Sining in 2003, the Emilio Aguinaldo National Achievement award in 2003, the Julian Felipe National Achievement Award in 2005, and the Most Outstanding Filipino in the Field of Music from the Global Pinoy Award in 2010. Written byElmer L. Gatchalianupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

MAIGUE, RAYMUNDO (Raymundo Ruiz Maigue) aka Rayben Maigue. b 23 Jan 1957. Trumpeter, big band jazz conductor, music director, teacher. He is the son of Benruben P. Maigue and Caridad Ruiz. Rayben, as he is fondly called, is the grandson of Jose Ruiz, who was a prolific pianist-composer-conductor during the American occupation in the Philippines. His brother Antonio Maigue is a flautist. He is married to Nanette Moscardon, a soprano, whom he met during his studies at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. They have four children, the first three of which have studied in the same university: Franco, a guitarist; Lara, a voice major and composer; and Danya a sport science major and a professional hip-hop dancer. His youngest daughter, Galan, is the artist-painter of the family. He manages a home-based studio, Maigue Music Studio, together with his wife and children.

Maigue enrolled at the UP College of Music in 1974 and graduated four years later with a teacher’s diploma, major in trumpet. He later completed the bachelor’s degree in the same instrument, being the first student to graduate in 1980 under that major. He also pursued a second degree in orchestral conducting and again was the first student to graduate with that major in orchestral conducting in 1987. The UP College of Music became his second “home” when Maigue became a lecturer in that institution beginning 1980. He was appointed chairman of the Department of Winds and Percussion of the UP CMu in 2007.

As a trumpeter, Maigue was the featured soloist of the Philippine Youth Orchestra under the baton of Sergio Esmilla in a South East Asian Tour, which included Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Singapore. Later, he served as that orchestra’s assistant conductor from 1978 to 1986. In 1978, he was adjudged the lone winner for a performance solo in the brass and winds category in the National Competition for Young Artists held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Rayben was also a delegate to the Asian and ASEAN music camps held in Hong Kong, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Brunei, and the Philippines.

In 1980, he took over from pianist Fred Robles as the conductor-musical director of the then semiprofessional UP Jazz Ensemble, which in time developed many big names in the professional music industry, such as Tots Tolentino, Emcy Corteza, Bond Samson, Michael Guevarra, and Mel Villena. Maigue was both the musical director of the UP Wind Ensemble from 1982 to 1989 and the UP Brass Ensemble from 1980 to the present, and was the adviser of the UP College of Music Student Council in 2009.

As a composer he penned “Partners,” a music theme song for GMA Network in 2004; “Win the World for Our King” commissioned by the Brotherhood of Christian Businessmen in Nov 2005; and the Philippine Navy soundtrack for the book A Voyage to Our Destiny in 2013. He was the artistic director of the The Sound of Music held at the Meralco Theater in 1997, South Pacific performed at the UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium and later at the CCP in 1990, and Grease held at the UP Theater, UP Diliman in 1994. He also conducted a jazz version of Handel’s Messiah in the UP Theater in Dec 2014. Outside of UP, Maigue heads the Bungang Himig Choir of the Sacred Heart Parish.

In 1989, he was given the first Quezon City Achievement Award for the Field of Philippine New Age and Jazz Music. In 1999, Petron Corporation acknowledged Maigue for his continuous achievements as one of the prime movers of jazz in the Philippines. In Feb 2010, he was honored with the Arts Productivity Award by UP Diliman. Written byRichie Quirino

MAIQUEZ, TONY (Antonio Maiquez) b. 10 April 1910. d. 1969. Musical director, composer. Maiquez finished premedical studies at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran and music at the University of the Philippines. He was first employed by Ocean Airlines, then became a bandleader for 10 years. Later he worked with Serafin Payawal in Casa Manama owned by Amado Araneta.

It was Araneta who took in Maiquez for his FilippineFilms. In 1942, Maiquez started composing the kundiman which would make him famous, among them, the recording hits “Awit Ko’y Dinggin” (Hear My Song), “Panaligan Mo Sinta” (Believe in Me, Darling), “Itanong sa Bulaklak” (Ask the Flower), “Babaing Uliran” (Model Woman), “Tuwing Magsasayaw Kita” (Every Time We Dance), “Ang Daigdig Ko’y Ikaw” (My World is You), and “Iginuhit sa Buhangin” (Drawn on the Sand).

He was with PremiereProductions for 15 years. The first picture he scored was Sekretang Hongkong (Hong Kong Secret Agent), 1947, which was directed by Mike Caquin. He composed many memorable movie theme songs, such as “Pandora,” 1955, which was his first hit, and “Yaya Maria” (Nanny Maria), 1957.

Maiquez was the first musical director to be elevated to the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Hall of Fame. His FAMAS award-winning scores were for the films Pandora, 1955; 5 Hermanos (5 Brothers), 1956; Yaya Maria (Nanny Maria), 1957; Water Lily, 1958; SapagkatKamiayTaoLamang (For We Are Only Human), 1963; Iginuhit sa Buhangin, 1965; and Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan (When the Heart Has Been Broken), 1967.Written byRosalinda Galang

MAKIL, ELMO (Elmo Quidangen Makil) b. Galimuyod, Ilocos Sur 17 Apr 1937. d. Parañaque City 1 Jan 2003. Singer, conductor, arranger, composer. He was born to Anselmo Makil and Francisca Quidangen. He was married to Lorna Peña-Reyes. They have two daughters, one of whom, Frances, is a stage, television, and movie actor. In his high school days at the Kalinga Academy, he became seriously involved in music, immersing himself in choral singing. His rich baritone caught the attention of William Pfeiffer, former vocal coach of the Westminster Choir College, who took him in as his protege at the Silliman University in Dumaguete City. After obtaining a bachelor’s degree in music from Silliman, Makil went to the University of the Philippines (UP) for a bachelor of music degree in voice where he came under the tutelage of Aurelio Estanislao. He pursued graduate studies in voice at the University of Hawaii, taking active interest in ethnic music. He participated in various ethnic ensembles and was the first Filipino to play the lead role in a Japanese noh drama.

Makil taught at Silliman University before moving over to the UP College of Music where he became an associate professor at the Voice, Music, Theater, and Opera Department. Later, he became the Chair of UP College of Music’s Voice Department. Makil was a member of Performing Arts Inc and the UP Bel Canto Philippines, and was a founding member of the UP (now Philippine) Madrigal Singers, the UP Concert Chorus, the UP Gleemen (with Rey T. Paguio and Estanislao), the Philippine Army Chorale, and the Musica Sacra Filipinas. He was also part of Three Baritones, a group he formed with fellow baritones Gamaliel Viray and Manny Gregorio, said to be inspired by the trio of Luciano Pavarotti, Placido Domingo, and Jose Carreras, known then as Three Tenors.

Makil has starred in operas, Broadway shows, and sarsuwela, aside from giving solo concerts and taking part in choral performances. He played lead roles in the operas Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), and Andres Bonifacio, Ang Dakilang Anakpawis (Andres Bonifacio, The Great Plebeian), the sarsuwela Minda Mora, and the Broadway musicale South Pacific. In Mar 1992, he performed in the Philippine premiere of Benjamin Britten’s War Requiem with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. In 1993, he performed the lead role in Rigoletto in Singapore.

He recorded an album of Filipino songs with Pilita Corrales, Pilita and Elmo Together At Last, produced by Danny Tan and Ben Zubiri for Quantum Records in 1996. One of the songs included in this album is their rendition of the popular Cebuano song, “Matud Nila” (So They Say), which won the Awit Award for Best Traditional Recording in 1997. After recovering from a stroke, he was able to record 60 songs in a recording studio in Bulacan. This recording has never been commercially released but was played during a musical tribute after his death over DZFE 98.7 FM’s Bravo Filipino program. His last musical performance was in Dec 2002 during a fundraising event for Talayan Christian Church in Quezon City, where he performed with members of Musica Sacra Filipinas.Written byFelizidad Z. Reyes and Ma. Patricia Brillantesupdated by Elmer L. Gatchalian

MALABON MUSIKONG BUMBONG aka Samahang Banda Harikos, Banda Filipina, St Anthony Original Bamboo Band, Musikawayan. A musikong bumbong is often called “banda de boca” (literally, “band of the mouth”) because its musical sound is produced by means of one’s oral and vocal control as, for example, “buzzing” a piece of leaf or paper placed between lips. It is not the instruments that produce the sound per se but the mouths and voices of the players. However, some instruments in the band, such as the bamboo flute and bumbong (which looks like a sousaphone in the beginning), are actual sound-producing bamboo instruments.

Malabon Musikong Bumbong was founded by Gregorio Kilala and Felix Ramos at barrio Tonsuya in Malabon (now a city), Rizal (formerly Morong) during the 1890s at the time of the Philippine revolution against the Spain in 1896-98. Felix Ramos was the founder, as well as inventor and maker of bamboo instruments used by the original group. He and the original members were all katipuneros or revolutionaries against Spain. Aside from Kilala and Ramos, the comrades included Juan De Silva, Anaceto Topacio, Tomas Gonzales, and Delfin Borromeo. These men had no formal training in music and played by ear or “oido.” They used their musical talents to entertain their fellow katipunero and to enliven their revolutionary activities by playing patriotic songs. Sometimes, they played music as a front for their revolutionary secret meetings. In 1896, the group was known as Samahang Banda Harikos. To strengthen their will to fight, each musician believed that he was the best and claimed superiority over the other as in “Hari ako” (I am king), hence the term “Banda Harikos.” With around 28 all-male members then, the bamboo band also played for fiestas, funerals, processions, and parades. Aniceto Topacio was the first conductor. Later, Felix Ramos’s son, Magno Ramos, took charge of the second and third generations of the bamboo band.

During the early part of the American occupation, the group was temporarily disbanded and they reorganized in 1921 with the help of Marcelo De Silva. The group’s name was then changed to Banda Filipina because they began to accept female members, under Matias de Silva as conductor. The members were composed of sons, relatives, and brothers of the original members. But due to the prevalence of courtship among members, the group was short-lived. In the late 1960s, Visayan men joined and constructed additional bamboo replicas of band instruments like saxophones, clarinet, trumpet, French horn called trompas that sounded like bumbong. In 1984, the group’s name became St Anthony Original Bamboo Band, with an all-male membership. Bayani de Silva was the conductor until 1992 and Gilbert M. Ramos, a fourth generation descendant of Felix Ramos, was the musical director. In 1990, the name reverted to Banda Filipina as requested by old members, with the inclusion once again of female members. With the death of Bayani de Silva in 1993, Gilbert M. Ramos became the conductor and musical director. Gilbert is a bachelor of music graduate, major in conducting, from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music.

In 2004, the group’s name was changed to Musikawayan and was officially registered as manufacturer and seller of bamboo musical instruments with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) with both Ronnell P. Ramos and John Dave Ramos, fifth generation descendants of Felix Ramos, as in-charge. The group was a marching band until 2005. After this, their instruments were replaced with those suited and made for stationary stage performances, like marimba, gabbang, angklung, tipangklung, guitar, and drum set. The bamboo flute, bamboo clarinet, bamboo saxophone, and bumbong are still in use. In 2006, musicians were trimmed down to five from 10 members for convenience and economic reasons. However, when need arises, the group can still provide a full bamboo marching band. The members of Musikawayan are mostly relatives and a few are members of the community. They receive basic lessons in note reading and harmony under Gilbert Ramos.

The Malabon Musikong Bumbong has received several distinctions such as the certificate of honor during the term of Pres Manuel L. Quezon, the Malabon Gintong Parangal, the Most Distinguished Men of Malabon in 1998, and the Certificate of Appreciation for their invaluable contribution in preserving the cultural heritage of Malabon in 2010. They have been featured at the Concert at the Park, Fort Santiago, Manila Hilton, Manila Hotel, SM malls, and in the different Casino Filipino branches as part of the stable of PAGCOR artists. They have performed before local and foreign dignitaries and in other countries as well. The “Veteranos de la Revolucion” (Veterans of the Revolution) is the group’s theme song. Their repertoire has evolved from mostly patriotic to varied types of music that cater to a wider audience of music aficionados. Written byPacita M. Narzo

MALICSI, JONATHAN (Jonathan Coloma Malicsi) b. Olongapo City 29 Apr 1947. Singer, teacher. Born to Lolita Coloma Malicsi-Carpio and Miguel Gonzales, he attended the Tapinac Elementary School and Olongapo City High School. From the University of the Philippines (UP), he obtained the following degrees: bachelor of arts in English in 1966, master of arts in linguistics in 1980, and doctorate in Philippine studies (anthropology and sociology) in 1981. He pursued postgraduate studies in linguistics at the State University of New York at Buffalo in 1980. He began his musical studies in 1974, even as he took classes in voice and repertoire under Herbert Brauer from the Berlin Conservatory, then with MercedesSantiago and Kathy Sternberg. In the 1980s, he studied under visiting artists from the United States and from the Metropolitan Opera, Curtis Institute, and Salzburg Mozarteum. In 1984, he finished his bachelor of music in voice at the UP College of Music.

Malicsi has taught at the UP Department of English and Comparative Literature, Department of Humanities, and Department of Linguistics where he served as chair from 1976-79 and is currently a professor emeritus. He has headed the UP System’s President’s Committee on Culture and the Arts (UP-PCCA) beginning 1982. He was a member of the Council of Advisers of the UP’s Sentro ng Wikang Pilipino and General Education Council.

Malicsi has been on the musical scene since 1965, performing as resident soloist of the UPMadrigalSingers and UPConcertChorus and as tenor soloist in numerous productions like Dubois’ Seven Last Words, 1993-96 and 2007-08; Handel’s Messiah 1994; Rossini’s Messe Solenelle, 1994 in Belgium and 1995 in UP; Stravinsky’s Les Noces, 2000; Mozart’s Coronation Mass, Britten’s War Requiem, and Stainer’s The Crucifixion, 2002.

From 1996-2010, he has sung with the UP Bel Canto Philippines in its concert performances in various churches and school auditoriums in different parts of the country, including a concert tour of China. He has played major operatic roles, such as in EliseoM.Pajaro’s Balagtas at Selya (Balagtas and Selya), Jerry A. Dadap’s AndresBonifacio, Ang Dakilang Anakpawis (Andres Bonifacio, The Great Plebeian), the Filipino musical adaptation of The Little Prince by Rolando S. de la Cruz and LucreciaR.Kasilag, Mozart’s The Magic Flute and The Marriage of Figaro, and as Goro in Puccini’s Madama Butterfly, 1994 in Singapore, and in the same opera as Pinkerton, 1996, and Ferrando in Mozart’s Cosi Fan Tutte, 1999.

He has performed as orchestral conductor for FEU Glimpses into Its Cultural Past, 1994; The Magic Flute, 1996; Gianni Schicchi, 1997; Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seeds of Freedom), 1998; La Verbena de la Paloma, 1999; and Golden Beginnings, 2000. He has also conducted in stage productions of Repertory Philippines and Alley Productions. He has served as musical and stage director for a series of concerts of the UP Chamber Orchestra, 1994-97; Luther, 1997; A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1997; Cosi Fan Tutte, 1999 and 2000; and La Voix Humaine, 2000. He has also written lyrics for Tagalog version of some English hymns in 2010.

He has earned many honors and awards for his work in the academe and in culture, including the Ulo ng Apo Award for Cultural Development from the Olongapo City government and professorial chairs in teaching social sciences and linguistics at UP. Written byRosalinda Galangupdated by James C. Diaz

MANALO, BASILIO (Basilio Cajucom Manalo) aka Billy Manalo. b. Baguio City 2 Apr 1927. d. 28 Mar 2008. Conductor, violinist, teacher. He was the son of Antonio Manalo and Maria Cajucom. He was married to Cecile Mapa and they had five children, one of whom, Ino Manalo, is a writer and cultural administrator. Manalo received his early music education at the St Scholastica’s College Conservatory of Music in 1943. Six years later, he obtained an undergraduate diploma and a postgraduate diploma in violin at the Juilliard School of Music in New York, USA, under the noted teacher Ivan Galamiani.

As a young violinist, Manalo played in the postwar concert of the Manila Symphony Orchestra in 1945. From 1951 to 1976, he served as the concertmaster of the Manila Symphony Orchestra, after which he became the assistant concertmaster of the Hong Kong Philharmonic from 1978 to 1980. When he returned to the Philippines, he became the resident conductor of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra until 1987. During these years, Manalo served as director of strings for the National Youth Music Camp in Mt Makiling, Laguna. In 1985, he founded and directed the Philippine Research for Developing Instrumental Soloists (PREDIS) with Sr Mary Placid Abejo, OSB, which was based in St Scholastica’s College. In 1986, he was appointed chair of the strings department of St Scholastica’s College.

He was conferred the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for music by the city of Manila in 1992. Written byAntonio C. Hilaupdated by Ma. Edelquinn Sy-Beltran

MANALO-CONCORDIA, NELIA (Nelia Siolo Manalo-Concordia) b. Pateros, Rizal 9 Jun 1913. Singer. Born to Nicasio Manalo, a writer of musical plays, and Salome Siolo, a church singer, she learned the basics of music from her mother. She studied piano and voice at the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music under the tutelage of VictorinoCarrion. She also took voice lessons under Felicing Tirona of Philippine Women’s University (PWU) and JovitaFuentes. She married former representative Manuel Concordia of San Pablo City.

In the 1930s, her appearance on stage as Amneris in Aida caught the attention of the Filipino audience and media. Her performance of the leading roles in La Traviata, Lucia di Lammermoor, and Faust further established her name in Manila. She appeared in concerts held for the benefit of charitable and religious institutions.

In 1950, she went to the United States and took up further voice training and courses in acting and concert singing. She became a scholar at the Juilliard School of Music and was chosen as its representative to a Verdi program at Queen’s College where she sung arias from La Traviata. She also played parts in La Boheme and Faust at the Juilliard Opera Theater. From 1952 to 1954, Concordia gave several performances in the Philippines, at the Far Eastern University and with the National Opera Company. She also taught at the PWU, St Paul College, and Centro Escolar University. Written byRamon Jocson

MANDAC, EVELYN (Evelyn Lorenzana Mandac) b. Malaybalay, Bukidnon 16 Aug 1940. Singer. She is the daughter of Manuel Mandac, now a retired army general, who was a church choir member and participant in local sarsuwela, and Noemi Lorenzana, an amateur singer. She is married to Sanjay Bhattacharya, a securities analyst, and resides in New York. Her first voice teacher was Lourdes Razon; later she studied under AurelioEstanislao of the University of the Philippines (UP), Hans Heinza, and mezzo-soprano Jennie Tourel of the Juilliard School of Music. She earned a teacher’s diploma in voice in 1961 and a bachelor of music degree, major in voice, in 1963 at UP. In 1964, she was admitted to Oberlin College in Ohio, USA, on a Fulbright grant. Then, through a Rockefeller grant, a UP fellowship, and an Alice Breen Award, she entered the Juilliard School of Music, obtaining her master of music degree in 1966.

A lyric soprano, Mandac made her professional debut in 1968 as a soprano soloist in Orff’s Carmina Burana with the Mobile Symphony Orchestra in Alabama, USA. In 1975, she performed for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, where she sang Mimi in Puccini’s La Boheme, 1969; Lauretta in Puccini’s Gianni Schicchi, 1975; Despina in Mozart’s Cosi Fan Tutte, 1974-75; and Susanna in Le Nozze di Figaro (The Marriage of Figaro), 1974-75, also by Mozart.

Mandac also appeared in the world premieres in 1976 of Inez de Castro and The Black Widow, 1972, by Italian composer Thomas Pasatieri who created the roles especially for her. She also starred in Luciano Berio’s Passaggio, 1972, during its American premiere and its performance by the RAI Orchestra of Turin, Italy. She also performed in a TV opera, the first of its kind in 1977, as Lisa in The Queen of Spades by Tchaikovsky. In the mid 70s, for a while she was with the Columbia Artists Management Inc. (CAMI), which seasonally scheduled concert stage performances for distinguished opera singers, pianists, and composer-conductors.

Her other lead roles include Liu in Puccini’s Turandot, Manon in Massenet’s Manon, Melisande in Debussy’s Pelleas et Melisande, Micaela in Bizet’s Carmen, Leila in Les Pecheurs de Perles (The Pearl Fishers) also by Bizet, Gilda in Verdi’s Rigoletto, Zerlina in Mozart’s Don Giovanni, Pamina in Die Zauberflote (The Magic Flute) also by Mozart, and Anne Trulove in Stravinsky’s The Rake’s Progress. Other American premieres also include The Basserides by Hans Werner Henze, The Mines of Sulphur by Richard Rodney Bennett, and Rinaldo by George Frideric Handel.

As a concert singer, Mandac has performed in various international music festivals in Glyndebourne, England; Salzburg, Austria; Ravinia, Italy; and Saratoga Springs and Ann Arbor in the United States. She has also performed as soloist for almost all the major symphony orchestras in America, under the baton of renowned conductors Claudio Abbado, Herbert von Karajan, James Levine, Zubin Mehta, Eugene Ormandy, and Seiji Ozawa. Her recordings include those with the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Boston Symphony Orchestra (RCA), Alexander’s “Songs for Eve” (Seraphim) and her latest, Meyerbeer’s L’Africaine, 1972, with the San Francisco Opera, together with Placido Domingo and Shirley Verett. She has also performed with opera singers such as Marilyn Horne, Sherill Milnes, Brigit Nilsson, Frederica von Stade, Jennie Tourel, Kiri Te Kanawa, and Richard Tucker.

Since 1987, Mandac has devoted her time in teaching vocal technique incorporated with yoga, to enable her students to perform with ease and at the same time with creative energy, in her studio in New York. From the 1990s until the present, she has helped put up fundraising concerts. She has also continued to conduct master classes in the United States, Canada, and in the Philippines where she would also do vocal consultation for students who sought her mentoring in which she would always impart with them the secret to success: focus, passion, and discipline.

During her student days, Mandac distinguised herself by winning first prize in the Jeunesses Musicales, Manila, 1962; first prize, Hour of Music Competition, New York, 1965; second place, Metropolitan Opera Auditions, New York, and the third prize, International Music Competitions, Brussels, Belgium, both in 1966. In 1962 she was also selected as one of the Ten Outstanding Young Men or TOYM awardees for music in Manila. Written byFelizidad Z. Reyesupdated by James C. Diaz

MANGUIAT, ED (Ed Marasigan Manguiat) b. Lipa City 6 Mar 1959. His parents are Benjamin de Torres-Manguiat Sr and Juana Marasigan Lumbera. He obtained a bachelor of science in hotel and restaurant admistration from the University of the Philippines. He founded the University of the Philippines Singing Ambassadors (UPSA) in 1980. He now heads the Conducting Department of the New Era University (NEU) College of Music.

As choir conductor, he was awarded the Dirigentenpreis (Conductor’s Award) at the second Johannes Brahms International Choir Competition, 2001, in Germany and the Special Prize for Excellent Conducting Performance at the 25th Bela Bartok International Choirs Festival, 2012, in Debrecen, Hungary.

He steered the UPSA to be the first Asian choir to win the grand prize in the Arezzo Competitions in Italy in 2001. This qualified the UPSA to join the European Grand Prix (EGP) for choral singing the following year. UPSA is one of the only four Filipino choirs that had made it to the finals of EGP. He also led the choir to get top prizes in other international choral competitions in Gorizia, Italy; Debrecen, Hungary; Tours, France; Varna, Bulgaria; Llangolen, Wales, United Kingdom; Neuchatel, Switzerland; Torrevieja and Cantonigros, Spain; Sopot, Poland; Trencianske Teplice, Slovakia; Maasmechelen, Belgium; Wernigerode, Germany; Arnehem, The Netherlands; and Prague and Padubice, Czech Republic. Under his mentorship, UPSA was elevated to the ALIW Awards Foundation’s Hall of Fame after winning Best Choral Group three times.

Manguiat attended the 1st and 4th World Symposium on Choral Music in Vienna, Austria in 1987 and in Sydney, Australia in 1996, respectively. He attended workshops with well-known choir directors like Eric Ericson, Narcel Corneloup, Erwin List, Jurgen Jurgens, Miles Morgan, and Catherine Fender and also collaborated with Oscar Yatco.

He is also a choral clinician and a member of both the International Federation of Choral Music (IFCM) and the Philippine Choral Directors Association (PCDA). Through the latter, he has shared his specialization in regional and national conventions of choirs and conductors in Cebu, Cagayan de Oro, and Davao.

As composer and lyricist, Ed has collaborated with National Artists Lucio San Pedro (“Mga Alipin sa Silangang Malayo” [Slaves From Faraway East]), Virgilio Almario (“Matitiis Mo Ba?” [Can You Endure It?]), and Bienvenido Lumbera (“Pangarap na Langit” [Dream of Heaven]). His compositions include church hymns, inspirational songs, and company themes like “Purihin Natin ang Lumikha” (Let Us Praise the Creator), “Salamat at Ako’y Ligtas” (Grateful Because I Am Saved), “Magtapat at Magpakatatag” (Confess and Be Resolute), “Ipagdiwang Kaniyang Kaningningan” (Celebrate His Resplendence, Iglesia Ni Cristo [INC] 75th Anniversary Theme), and “Sing For Me” (DSWD hymn). His composition “Anghel na Bituin” (Star Angel) was one of the themes used in the internationally acclaimed film Magnifico, directed by Maryo J. delos Reyes, 2003. Recently, his composition “Salamat po, Ama, Purihin at Awitan Ka!” (Thank You, Father, We Praise and Sing to You) was chosen as the theme song for the INC Centennial Celebration in 2014.

The Lhuillier Foundation, the Rotary Club of Manila, local government units of Bohol and Lipa City, and Phi Kappa International Honor Society, have recognized and cited his musical achievements and civic contributions. Accenture Philippines acknowledged him as one of their Four Global Pinoy Achievers and most recently SM City Lipa cited him as one of their Global Achievers. Written byAntonio C. Hila

MANILA CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY Founded in 1921 by BonifacioAbdon, Francisco Avellana, JoseCarrion, and Felipe Marin, it started as a chambermusic group playing in private Manila homes and clubs in Manila for members of the foreign community and the Filipino elite. It also performed during high masses and religious services in Manila churches. The group later included pianists Jesus Litonjua and Jose Cortez. Its leading members were Bonifacio Abdon, dean and director of the Escuela de Violin, and VictorinoCarrion, founder of the Schola Cantorum, both of whom produced notable artists and musicians.

From chamber music evenings, the Society expanded its activities to concerts of sacred music with the Schola Cantorum, performing such works as Verdi’s Requiem, Mozart’s Requiem Mass, and Gounod’s St. Cecilia’s Mass. Later, its scope of work included symphonicmusic, choralmusic, and operas like Aida, La Traviata, Lucia de Lammermoor, all in 1933; Il Trovatore and Cavalleria Rusticana, both in 1934, featuring vocal artists like Angela de Gonzaga, NeliaManalo, Octavio Cruz, Vicente Vera, and Jose Barredo. During its two-decade existence, it also offered musicales featuring old Filipino music of the romantic age, made recordings of Filipino folksongs, and revived the tradition of harana or serenatas (serenades) in the Antipolo festival. It featured performances of world-acclaimed personalities such as violinist Jascha Heifetz and coloratura Toti del Monte as well as recitals of Filipino artists such as sopranos Raymunda Guidote and Purificacion Borromeo. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian

MANILA CHAMBER ORCHESTRA (MCO) aka Manila Symphony Chamber Orchestra. The ManilaChamberOrchestra was founded in 1985 when conductor and violinist SergioEsmillaJr brought up the idea of forming a chamber group to banker Antonio Ozaeta. Its aim was to provide a professional venue for the country’s young talents in music. The group consisted of two foreign senior wind players and 24 Filipino musicians who had earlier trained with the PhilippineYouthOrchestra. On 8 May 1985 the MCO gave its inaugural concert at the PCIBank’s FranciscoSantiago Hall in Makati. The program included “Spring” and “Winter” from Vivaldi’s Four Seasons, Grieg’s Holberg Suite, Op. 40, Mozart’s Divertimento in D, KV136, and Haydn’s Quintet for flute, oboe, clarinet, horn, and bassoon. It has since been giving annual concert seasons and special performances that have featured renowned Filipino musical artists like pianists LeonorKilayko, NenadelRosario-Villanueva, and RaulSunico, composers RyanCayabyab and JoseMariChan, soprano AndionFernandez, cellist RamonBolipata, violinist JosephEsmilla, as well as foreign international artists like British guitarist Michael Conn, German violinist Christopher Poppen, and British cellist Richard Markson. It has also come out with live recordings of selected repertoire from its previous concerts, featuring prominent Filipino as well as foreign visiting artists.

The MCO was initially subsidized by PCIBank through the MCO Foundation Inc. When the foundation decided to go public in 1992, it had the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT), Metro Manila Electric Company (MERALCO), Philips, and IBM among its contributing members. The MCO was also patronized by foreign cultural agencies like the Goethe House, the Australian Embassy, and the British Council. Written byEdna Marcil M. Martinez

MANILA SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (MSO) It was instituted as a formal orchestra in 1931 with the Manila Symphony Society at its helm headed by Filomena Legarda. Alexander Lippay, an Austro-Hungarian composer and conductor, and director of the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music in 1925-30, is the founder and conductor of the orchestra. It began as an informal symphony concert orchestra in 1926 that played Lippay’s symphonic concerts under the patronage of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, a music society made up of the colonial elites of Manila. Its musicians were initially contracted from the UP Conservatory of Music and the Philippine Constabulary Band. In 1931, the orchestra was formally organized and managed by the Manila Symphony Society, an offshoot of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas. When Alexander Lippay died, the baton was formally handed over to Austrian conductor Herbert Zipper in Aug 1939, during a memorial concert for Lippay. Zipper conducted the orchestra from 1939 to 1969. Under Zipper’s guidance, the MSO premiered such works as Mozart’s Requiem, Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, Bach’s Magnificat, and major works of Mahler and Brahms. The orchestra also played for Manila Ballet Moderne, led by Trudl Dubsky, who became Zipper’s wife. At the end of World War II, in May 1945, the orchestra held the first postwar concert among the ruins of Santa Cruz Church in Binondo, Manila. It became one of the most attended concerts in MSO history.

The orchestra also played for the US Armed Forces every night for approximately 150 days in Manila’s Rex Theater. In the 1950s and 1960s, the MSO was the most important orchestra playing European classical works at various venues like the Manila Grand Opera House, Far Eastern University Auditorium, the Philamlife Auditorium, as well as in schools and in parks. It featured soloists like Oscar Yatco, Nena del Rosario-Villanueva, Gilopez Kabayao, and Benjamin Tupas. The MSO went through troubled times starting in the 1960s. It lost some of it members to Redentor Romero’s newly formed National Philharmonic Orchestra. The emergence of other symphony orchestras in later years, such as the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra in 1973, and the Manila Chamber Orchestra in 1985, further stripped its ranks. In 1978, the MSO became the resident orchestra of the newly renovated Manila Metropolitan Theater. However, the theater’s unstable financial conditions after 1986 affected the orchestra. In 1989, Herbert Zipper returned to the country to help revitalize the MSO which had been inactive for more than a year. The MSO re-established itself with concerts featuring Japan’s Yoshinao Osawa in its 1989-90 season, and Helen Quach in 1991. The orchestra did not last long and was disbanded. Today’s MSO traces its name and origin from Lippay’s original MSO through Basilio Manalo who was once the concertmaster of the MSO.

Other local and international guest conductors that stood on MSO’s podium include Oscar Yatco, Gilopez Kabayao, Bernardino Custodio, Lucio San Pedro, Walter Hendl, Eaktay Ahn, Christoph Poppen, Lorenzo Martinez Palomo, Yaakov Bergman, Jeffrey Rink, and Sebastian Bereau.

Through the years, numerous musicians had joined and participated in some of MSO’s performances. Currently, the MSO’s music director and principal conductor is Arturo Molina, while the executive director and associate conductor post is held by Jeffrey Solares. Principal posts in the orchestra, on the other hand, are held by the the following musicians: Regina Medina-Perez, violin 1 concertmaster; Kim Carl Mirandilla-Ng, violin 2; Jaydee de Ocampo, viola, acting principal; Antoni Josef Inacay, violoncello; Emmanuel Ongleo, contrabass, acting principal; Francisco Candelaria, flute; Arvin Jan Medrano, oboe; Randolph Lopez, clarinet; Celso de Leon Jr, french horn; Sylvester Glorioso Aviñante, trumpet; Edgardo Villanueva, trombone; Cloyd Agtarap, tuba; and Roby Calderon, percussion.

The MSO had also collaborated with local and international artists like Cecile Licad, Mercedes Matias Santiago, Stella Goldenberg Brimo, Ernesto Vallejo, Reynaldo Reyes, Julio Esteban Anguita, Basilio Manalo, Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, Arturo Molina, Victor Michael Coo, Camille Lopez Molina, Margarita Gomez Gianelli, Lourdes de leon Gregorio, Aida Gonzales, Regina Medina Perez; Sara Maria Gonzales, Christian Tan, Rudolf Golez, Regina Buenaventura, Diomedes Saraza Jr, Yehudi Menuhin, Nellie Miricioiu, Jose Mossessgeld Santiago Font, Montserrat Caballe, and Lydia Artymiw.

Albums of the group also include collaborations with local band Sugarfree titled Sugarfree Live! With the Manila Symphony Orchestra, released by EMI Philippines in 2007, and Romantic Piano Concertos CD Series, with Ingrid Sala Santamaria as soloist, conducted by Arturo Molina, and released in 2014. At present, the library of the Manila Symphony Orchestra is stored at St Scholastica’s College (SSC). It was rescued from flood waters by Basilio Manalo and Sr Mary Placid, dean of SSC Music Department, in the late 1990s. Written byMa. Edelquinn Sy-Beltran and Crisancti L. Macazo

MANILA SYMPHONY SOCIETY (MSS) Manila Symphony Society is the patron of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. It was founded by Alexander Lippay out of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, which was its parent organization. From 1927 to 1931, the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas supported the symphonic concerts led by Lippay. Out of those symphonic concerts, a formal orchestra was established and permanent membership became necessary. For many years, the MSO was the only symphony orchestra in the country whose performers were paid regular salaries. This was made possible by the Manila Symphony Society, which together with the MSO were professional music organizations.

At the onset of the organization, the 1932-33 Board of Directors of the society was led by Filomena Roces Legarda as president; Rosalind W. Duckworth, vice-president; Rosario Abreu Roensch, treasurer; Arthur Hoyer, secretary; and members Mrs. H.B. McCoy, A.V.H. Hartendorp, and Alexander Lippay. Major patrons were: Maria Elison Earnshaw, wife of Tomas Earnshaw, mayor of Manila (1927-33); Concepcion Fernandez-Crame, wife of Gen Rafael Crame, the first director of the defunct Philippine Constabulary; Nina Isabelle Gilmore, wife of Eugene Allen Gilmore, vice governor-general of the Philippines (1922-29); and Aurora Aragon-Quezon, wife of Pres Manuel L. Quezon and First Lady of the Philippines (1935-44). Other names included John Brimo, Carmelo Cristi, Ernest Korneld, and Hans Inhelder, together with Andres Soriano, Benito Legarda III and Benito Legarda IV, Basilio Valdes, and Rita Legarda-Valdes.

During the 25th anniversary of the Manila Symphony Society in 1956, the Board of Directors was composed of Trinidad F. Legarda, president; Rosario de Valdes, first vice-president; Pilar Vergel de Dios, second vice-president; Ernest Korneld, third vice-president; Carmita L. de Carrion, executive secretary; Maria Orense Casas, social secretary; John G. Brimo, Treasurer. The directors were Purita L. Ponce Enrile, Edgar Krohn, Hans Inhelder, Rachel Kaufman, Mona Lisa Steiner, Naty Aguinaldo, Candida Bautista, Kathy Sternberg, Angelo O. Fiteni, and Rafael Gomez. It also included composers Lucrecia Kasilag and Antonino Buenaventura and pianist Julio Esteban-Anguita as technical advisers.

Since its establishment, the MSS has sought to help foster a hospitable climate for music appreciation in the country. Over the years, it has conducted, launched, and funded projects to develop cultural interests and activities, particularly in Manila. It has provided free instruction on orchestral instruments to music students, music teachers, and professional musicians through a special educational grant by the JDR III Fund, and has also invited American and West German professors to further hone the MSO members’ artistry. The MSS was instrumental in recruiting Herbert Zipper to take over the directorship of the orchestra when Alexander Lippay passed away. The MSS and the MSO regularly offered free concerts of excerpts from operas and ballets, as well as other musical fare in public parks and in schools. The repertoire ranged from classical music to contemporary works by Filipino artists.

In the later years, the MSS did not only encourage Filipino composers to create new works but also featured Filipino soloists and conductors, among them Oscar C. Yatco, Gilopez Kabayao, Nena del Rosario-Villanueva, Reynaldo Reyes, Benjamin Tupas, Raul Sunico. Written byEdgardo Marananupdated by Ma. Edelquinn Sy-Beltran

MANRIQUE, RIC (Eric Manrique Jr) b. Manila 23 May 1941. d. Buena Park, California, USA 22 Sep 2017. Singer. He was active in the glee club during his high school days at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran. He took up commerce at the Far Eastern University, but did not graduate. In 1960, he joined Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), a national amateur singing contest on television, and became champion for several weeks with his rendition of standard English ballads. Teddy Valdemor, the program’s director who was a songwriter as well, handpicked Manrique to sing one of his compositions, “Till I Die.” This turned out to be Manrique’s first big hit. In 1963, he had a big break when he sang “Sapagkat Kami’y Tao Lamang” (For We are Only Human), the theme from the movie of the same title which won for its composer Tony Maiquez the FAMAS Awards for Best Musical Score and Best Theme Song.

For the next two decades, he became one of the most sought after interpreters of movie themes penned by leading musical directors for films, such as Tony Maiquez, Leopoldo Silos, Restie Umali, Pablo Vergara, and George Canseco. His first long-playing album, Sa Lamlam ng Buwan (Under the Pale Moonlight), released under Villar Records in 1967, featured “Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak” (Because of a Flower) by Leopoldo Silos and S.Y. Ramos, the theme of the film of the same title from Nepomuceno Productions topbilled by Charito Solis and Ric Rodrigo. His “Magbalik Ka, Hirang” (Please Come Back, My Love), a cut in his 1971 album of the same title also under Villar Records, was used as the theme of Uhaw (Yearning), the first ever bomba (bold) film in the Philippines that featured Merle Fernandez in 1970. “Luha at Halakhak” (Tears and Laughter), by George Canseco, was a cut from his 1976 album under Vicor-RCA Records Kapantay ay Langit (High As the Sky) and was the theme for the movie Eva Fonda 16 with Alma Moreno on the lead role. His bestselling LP, Diyos Lamang Nakakaalam (Only God Knows), came out in 1973, the title song of which was a masterpiece by Leopoldo Silos with lyrics penned by Manuel P. Villar Sr, president and CEO of the Mabuhay Records Corporation (MARECO aka Villar Records). One of the cuts in the said album was “Sabihin Lang” (Just Say It), which is an adaptation in Tagalog of the song “Speak Softly Love” from the movie The Godfather.

Singing themes for Tagalog films proved to be so advantageous for Manrique that upon the early retirement of Ruben Tagalog from the music industry in the early 1970s, he became one of the contenders for the title “Hari ng Kundiman” (King of Kundiman). A long-playing album that he did for Oregon Records in 1971, which featured movie themes composed by Pablo Vergara, was aptly titled Hari ng Kundiman. In 1979, as to somewhat declare his ascent as the new kundiman king, he did the album titled Kundiman (Love Song) under A&W Records International where he rendered classic compositions like Francisco Santiago’s “Madaling Araw” (Dawn), “Pakiusap” (Plea), and “Anak Dalita” (Child of Woe), and Nicanor Abelardo’s “Bituing Marikit” (Beautiful Star), “Nasaan Ka, Irog” (Where are You, My Love?), “Kung Hindi Man” (If Not So), and “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig), not in the usual bel canto style of singing but in a manner that is characteriscally his—sweet, relaxed, and natural. His other hits, mostly themes from films, include “Ikaw ang Ligaya Ko” (You are My Happiness), “Hindi Nahahati ang Langit” (Heaven Can’t Be Divided), “Iginuhit sa Buhangin” (Drawn on Sand), “Nasaan ang Pangako” (Where is Your Promise), “Kapag Puso’y Sinugatan” (When the Heart is Wounded), “Paano Kita Lilimutin” (How Can I Forget You), “Ang Daigdig Ko’y Ikaw” (You are My World), and “Saan Ka Man Naroroon” (Wherever You Are).

He appeared in musical films such as Christmas Holiday, 1965; Mula Nang Kita’y Ibigin (Since I’ve Loved You), 1966; and Top Ten, 1967. He sang as a member of the Mabuhay Singers in the late 1960s and early 1970s. He hosted his own radio show, Panambitan (Serenade), which aired every Sunday evening over DZBB 594 of GMA 7 for almost two decades since the late 70s. From the late 90s up to 2002, he regularly sang in Serenatang Kumbidahan (Invitation to Serenade), a Saturday night Filipiniana musical program produced and hosted by Dely Magpayo. In 2003, he migrated to California where he sang occasionally in concerts, cultural programs, and benefit shows for the Filipino community. Written byMichael M. Coroza

MARAMBA, MANUEL (Manuel Perez Maramba, OSB) b. Manila 4 Jul 1936. Composer, pianist, teacher. Maramba is a Benedictine monk.His parents are banker Tomas Maramba Sr and Pacifica Perez, a pianist who was Maramba’s first music teacher. He earned a bachelor of arts degreein piano from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music at age 17, and went on to the PeabodyConservatory of Music in Baltimore for a master’s degree in piano, which he received in 1956, as well as a bachelor’sdegree incompositionand an artist’sdiploma inpianowhich were obtainedin 1958. In addition, he earned a master’s degree in musical arts from Yale University School of Music and studied sacred music at the Kirchenmusikschule in Regensburg, Germany and the Vienna Hochschule für Musik. Maramba has a bachelor’s degree inphilosophy and a licentiate in sacred theology and canon law.

At Peabody, Maramba was the recipient of the Lilian Gutman Award in piano and the Marie K. Thatcher Award in composition. At Yale, he received the Martha Curtis Miles Scholarship in theory and composition and Lucy G.Moses Fellowship in performance. He won in the Artist GuildAuditions held in New York. As a prize, he was presented in a recital at Carnegie Hall in 1956. He also won theSprague Hall Concerto Composition at Yale University, for which he performed with the Yale Symphony Orchestra. He was musician-in-residence at St John’s College in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA from 1974 to 1976. In between his performances abroad, Maramba appeared as soloist with the major orchestras in the Philippines.

As a composer of sacred music, he is best known for “Hymn to San Lorenzo Ruiz,” dedicated to the first Filipino saint. He also wroteMusic for Orchestra, 1958; Quintet, for soprano, three flutes, and dancers, 1979;Jubilate 1,for two brass choirs, tuba, and timpani, 1980;Awakening, music for ballet, 1981;Concerto for piano,two kulintangs, and orchestra,Suite for Organ and String Orchestra,and Chamber Work for Sixteen Instruments, all in 1982;Transfiguration I, 1983, and Transfiguration II, 1987,chambermusic;Aba! Santo Niño(Hail Holy Child), a one-act opera, 1985; andThe Seven Mansions, music for ballet, 1991.

Maramba was actively involved with the Benedictine Abbey of Our Lady of Montserrat and San Beda Glee Club as organist and choir conductor in 1960. He was president of the Philippine Society of Organists and was vice-president of the National Music Council of the Philippines. He was also a board member and later two-term president of the PianoTeacher’sGuild of the Philippines and is a member of theLeagueofFilipinoComposers. He has taught music courses at the UST Conservatory of Music, UP College of Music, and St Scholastica’s College of Music. In 1991, he was appointed as assistant director of the Pope Paul VI Institute of Liturgy in Malaybalay, Bukidnon where he shared his expertise in liturgical music, liturgical legislation, and liturgy of the hours.

Maramba received Outstanding AlumnusAwardsfrom the UST and De La Salle University. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo and Filemon D. Nolascoupdated by Mauricia Borromeo

MARCELO, JUNGEE (Proceso Gideon Herrera Marcelo) b. 9 May 1964. Gospel songwriter, singer-dancer, television host. He is the youngest of four children of Proceso Santos Marcelo, former bodabil actor-turned pastor/broadcaster at Far Eastern Broadcasting Corporation FEBC and Celia Herrera, gospel songwriter, Evangelical Christian writer, music teacher, and linguist. Jungee finished his elementary in Valenzuela Community School, high school in University of the East Caloocan and college in Philippine School of Business Administration (R. Papa campus) with a degree in marketing in 1983. Initially, he wanted to be a commercial jingle writer.

His gospel songwriting career for the PAPURI Music Ministry began at age 15, and was interrupted when his mother died in 1983. To recover from his grief, his father brought him to the United States. While in the United States, Jungee immersed in the pop music culture and hip-hop, and enrolled in pop vocal music with Terri Danne and pop guitar at the Los Angeles Pierce College. He danced in the underground circuit as a back-up dancer and was spotted by the owner of the Metro Dance and Arts Academy in Los Angeles to teach “locking” in exchange for lessons in ballet, jazz, and tap. He returned to the Philippines for good in Nov 1990 and was invited to teach hip-hop in the Halili Cruz Dance Studio. He formalized hip-hop instruction for teachers at the University of the Philippines College of Human Kinetics.

In 1991, he was signed up by Vicor and his big break came when Gary Valenciano caught his performance on television one day and asked him to come up with lyrics for a song originally titled “Turn It Up.” Jungee changed it to Hataw Na (Pull It Up), which eventually became the title of the album, the movie, and the world tour of Gary V. For the same album he wrote “Muli” (Again) and “Sa Yahweh ang Sayaw” (To Dance for the Lord). Jungee has written 200 pop songs to date. Most noteable are “Di Ka ba Marunong Umayaw?” (Can’t You Say No?), a song against drugs, and “Palilipasin Mo na Lamang Ba” (Will You Just Let It Pass?), both in 1991; “Bukas na Lang Sana ang Kahapon” (Wishing Tomorrow Were Yesterday), 1999, “Ako na Lang” (Let It Be Me), “Pangsamantagal”(Temporary for Too Long), “Nasa Iyo na ang Lahat” (You’ve Got Everything), sung by popular actor Daniel Padilla, and “Salbabida” (Lifesaver), sung by Kyla. The last two songs were dedicated to his wife Anna Marie Perez Marcelo.

He currently hosts a television show he conceived titled This Is My Story, This Is My Song, produced by Zoe Broadcasting and aired in GMA TV 11 and Light TV 33, featuring the lives of different songwriters and the stories behind their songs.

His songs and albums have won in the Awit Awards: Best Dance Recording for “Di Ka ba Marunong Umayaw,” 1993, and “Sa Yahweh ang Sayaw,” 1994; Best Inspirational/Religious Recording for “Sa Yahweh ang Sayaw,” 1994, “Ako’y Binago Niya” (He Changed Me), 1998, and “Yahweh Elohim,” 2002; Best Folk-Pop Recording for “Ito ay Naganap” (This Happened); Best Jazz Recording (With Vocals) for “Never Find Another,” 2003; Best Rap Recording for “Ngayon ang Taon” (This is the Year), 2007; Best World Recording for “Panatang Makabayani” (A Hero’s Oath), 2011, and “Pansamantagal,” 2014; Album of the Year for Juris, Now Playing, 2011; Song of the Year for “Ako na Lang” (Let it Be Me), 2012; Best Movie/TV/Stage Theme Song Recording for “Bakit Di Ka Crush ng Crush Mo” (Why Are You Not the Crush of Your Crush), 2014; Best Vocal Arrangement for “Kunwa-kunwari Lang” (Just Pretending), 2014, and Best Rock/Alternative Recording for “Salbabida,” 2015. “Nasa Iyo na ang Lahat” swept the special awards in the 2012 Himig Handog P-Pop Love Songs where it bagged Star Records Buyers’ Choice, Tambayan 101.9 Listeners’ Choice, and MOR Listeners’ Choice. “Salbabida” also won the grand prize in the 2014 Philpop. Written byKatherine V. Molina

MARFIL, JOY (Marie Jocelyn Unahan Marfil) b. Nasipit, Agusan del Sur 23 Jul 1970. New music composer, theater and film music scorer, educator. Her parents are Diosdado Bonus Marfil and Emiliana Sumatar Unahan. Her father taught her ukelele beginning eight years old. She later joined the rondalla from grade five to high school. She was exposed to Mansaka indigenous music and dance at a tender age because her family lived in their community since birth. She entered the University of the Philippines College of Music and finished a bachelor of music in composition, cum laude, in 1993 and a master of music in the same field in 2001. Under a Fulbright scholarship, she finished her master’s degree in music theory at the State University of New York in 2005. Another scholarship grant from the University of the Philippines system enabled her to finish a doctorate in composition from the University of Hawaii Manoa in December 2015.

Marfil’s compositions had many influences, but Stravinsky’s rhythms and Jose Maceda’s approach to sound texture were more prominent. These influences are evident in her Lantaw (Contemplation), 1997; Awit (Song) for chorus and large ensemble, 1998; and Faces of a Woman for multimedia and chamber orchestra, 1999. Although she composed for Western performance media like Amani, for piano and cello, 2016; Anastasis, for solo flute, 2016; Strained Freedom, for String Quartet, 2016; Chasing Time for violin, cello, piano, 2013; Pangandoy II (Desire II) for violin and cello, 2010; Kabataan (Youth) for a capella choir, 2009; Marfil was also drawn to non-Western music instruments which were used in her Moon Under Ruined Castle for guzheng, 2013; Muted Cry for violin, cello, three guitars, 13-sting koto, and 17-string koto, 2012; Anguish of Isolation for kulintang, agung, angklung, tsuri-daiko, khlui, sogo, Nepali bell, 2011; Outback for solo piri (Korean reed instrument), 2011; and Pangandoy I for choir, five gandingan, and vibraphone, 2010. She wrote Agos ng Panahon (Time’s Flow), for solo bandurria, from 2015 to 2016; Dung-aw (Wake Song) for flute, clarinet, timpani, bell, timpani, 2011; and Mga Sibat sa Puso ng Cordillera (Arrows from the Heart of Cordillera), 2011. Her most recent large work Padayag (Expression), 2015, synthesized traditional Mansaka music materials with Western orchestral instruments. Marfil also composed the music for Basilia ng Malolos (Basilia of Malolos), a contemporary sarsuwela of UP Playwrights’ Theater in 2007.

Marfil’s art music works have received awards and other recognitions. To name a few, these were third prize for “Ang ’Yong Kapaligiran” (Your Environment) given by the League of Filipino Young Composers, 1990, and first prize for her arrangement of a music for Brass Quintet, National Music Competitions for Young Artists, 1995. She was also featured as one of the Filipina Young Composers of the 31st Anniversary of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, where her song cycle Paghihintay (Waiting) and Minsan at Ngayon (Only Once and Now) were performed, 2000. Her Anastasis was selected for the concert series of the Fondazione Adkins Chiti: Donne In Musica, Italy, and her Strained Freedom, for String Quartet, was heard in the Asian Composers’ League Conference and Festival in Vietnam, 2016.

In the field of film music score, she received the Best Musical Score and Best Theme Song awards for Mulanay from the Manila Film Festival (MFF), 1996, as well as the Gawad Urian Best Musical Score, 1997, from the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino.
