Her theme song for the movie Saranggola (The Kite) was chosen Best Theme Song in MFF, 1999, while her work for Mga Munting Tinig (Small Voices) won the Star Award Best Musical Score from the Philippine Movie Press Club, 2003. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

MARIFOSQUI, VICENTE (Vicente Tuason Marifosqui) b. Pasig, Rizal 14 Jan 1866. d. 20 Feb 1936. Band director, composer. His father, Felipe Marifosqui, was prominent in the community having served as manager of the town band, and later capitan municipal; his mother was Victoria Tuason. His wife was Julia Arcinas. They had six children. One of his daughters, Vicenta Eloriaga, was a piano teacher and head of the Escuela de Piano which later joined the Schola Cantorum of VictorinoCarrion and the Escuela de Violin of BonifacioAbdon to form the Escuelas Confederadas de Musica. Another daughter, Julia Gonzalez, taught voice culture. Vicente was enrolled at the Ateneo Municipal but never finished his studies. After his father’s death he became director of the Pasig Band. During the 1896 Revolution, he fought first on the side of the Spanish, then on the Filipino side. He was captured and imprisoned in the same cell as Ariston Bautista and JuanLuna.

After he was freed, he conducted the Orquesta Rizal for a time. When the Banda Arevalo was dissolved in 1911, he formed the Banda Dimasalang also in Pasig, which he directed until his death. Occasionally he directed the bands of Salinas, Cavite, and of Cabanatuan, Nueva Ecija. He was asked to direct the National Guard Band during World War I. Later, he taught piano in Laguna and in Pasig, became the musical director of Cine Lux for a time, and played bass in Cine Savoy. He composed several marches which his bands played, and made arrangements and instrumentation for band and orchestra. Written by Espiridion Arsenio Manuel

MATA, MANUEL ANTONIO b. Quiapo, Manila 13 Jun 1861 d. 1 Apr 1901. Composer, organist. The son of Maria Nakpil and NatalioMata, director of the Quiapo Church choir, he studied in a private school and received his musical education from his father. Composer JulioNakpil, his cousin, took piano lessons with him. He showed such ability on the piano and organ that upon reaching the age of 14, he was allowed to play the organ in the Quiapo Church in the absence of his father. Besides the piano and organ, he also played the guitar, bandurria, and harmonium. He taught piano to the children of well-known families of the city such as the Marcaidas, Chuidians, Sunicos, Carrions, Lontoks, and Guidotes. He married Rosario Vergara, with whom he had 10 children.

Mata composed secular and religious music. Among his pieces for the piano were “Siempre Alegre” (Always Happy), “Concha,” “Adela y Pacita” (Adela and Pacita) “Pilar y Vicenta” (Pilar and Vicenta), “Fandango Filipino” (Filipino Fandango), “Paulita,” “Amanda,” and “Clarita,” which enjoyed some popularity as dance pieces. At the time of the inauguration of the Carriedo Water System in 1882, he composed “Aguas del Carriedo” (Waters of Carriedo). His religious compositions include “Plegaria a Santa Teresa” (Prayer to Saint Theresa); “A los Dolores de la Virgen Santisima” (To the Sorrows of the Most Holy Virgin), a joint work with his father; Misa Pastorela, based on native materials, which was sung on Christmas eve and Feast of the Three Kings; and other pieces in honor of the Virgin or sung during novenarios.

Mata’s piano compositions received a medal of honor in the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas in 1895. His “Plegaria a Santa Teresa” was awarded a diploma in the celebration held in honor of that saint in 1882. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang

MATA, NATALIO (Natalio Javier Mata) b. Quiapo, Manila 3 Jul 1833 d. 15 May 1896. Organist, choirmaster. He was born to musician Pedro Mata and Eduarda Javier. He acquired his musical education from the Colegio de Niños Tiples of the Manila Cathedral where he later taught vocal and instrumental music. He became the organist of the Quiapo Church and the director of its choral group. His son, Manuel, later took on his post as the church organist while he occasionally sang with the choir or directed the Gruet and San Juan orchestras as well as the choir’s invitational performances.

He arranged the masses of Calahorra, Rossi, Caballero, and other Spanish composers. He also composed liturgical music like “Rosario a La Virgen de Monserrat” (Rosary to the Virgin of Monserrat), “Rosario para Nuestro Nazareno Jesus” (Rosary for Our Jesus the Nazarene), “Gozo” (Praise), Misa a Nuestro Padre Jesus Nazareno (Mass for Our Father Jesus the Nazarene), Misa a San Jose (Mass for Saint Joseph), and “A los Dolores de la Virgen Santisima” (To the Sorrows of the Most Holy Virgin), a collaborative work with his son Manuel. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel

MATIAS-SANTIAGO, MERCEDES(Mercedes Regalado Matias-Santiago) b. Cavite City 4 Mar 1910 d. Manila 20 Jun 2003. Singer, teacher. She was born to Juan Matias of Ligao Albay and Rosario Regalado of Cavite City. She married Geronimo Santiago Jr. She began her voice lessons with Galia Arellano in 1925 and later with Victorino Carrion. In 1928, she went to Italy for further vocal training with renowned vocal pedagogues such as Ernesto Caronna, the mentor of Luisa “Isang” Tapales and Hugo Benvenutti whom Jovita Fuentes recommended to her, and the famous Rosina Storchio.

She had her operatic debut in Verdi’s Rigoletto in 1931 at the Teatro Lyrico in Milan. She also sang the lead roles in Rossini’s The Barber of Seville and Verdi’s La Traviata. But it was for Donizetti’s Lucia di Lammermoor, which she performed 29 times between 1935 and 1959 that she became known as the foremost “Lucia” of the country.

Upon her return to the Philippines in 1934, Matias-Santiago held a series of concerts at the Manila Grand Opera House and the Metropolitan Theater and gave recitals to the provinces with Regalado Jose as her collaborative pianist. She premiered Rodolfo Cornejo’s The Seasons, a song cycle for soprano and string orchestra in Manila on 15 Sep 1935. Isang Tapales, Jovita Fuentes, and Matias-Santiago were referred to as the country’s “triumvirate” of operatic stars. She recorded songs for Parlophone company, among them “Sampaguita,” “Dalagang Bukid “(Country Maiden), “Huling Awit” (Last Song), and “Takipsilim” (Dusk).

Upon the invitation of then University of the Philippines (UP) Pres Rafael Palma who heard her perform at the Metropolitan Theatre, she became chair of the UP Music Conservatory’s Voice Department. After World War II, she went to the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music, upon the invitation of Julio Esteban Anguita and became chair of the Conservatory’s Voice Department. She also taught at Santa Isabel College, St Scholastica’s College, St Paul College, and Centro Escolar University.

Among the students she taught who became known in the international operatic stage were Maria Nina Zandueta, Enya Gonzales, Conchita Gaston, Dalisay Aldaba, and Eleanor Calbes. Another student, tenor Aristeo Velasco, made a name in the local operatic scene.

She put up a private studio on 1081 Maceda Street in Sampaloc in the 1960s where she stayed until she died. It became the mecca of several voice students who studied privately under her. Among the pianists who collaborated with students in her studio were Nelly Arriola, Cleofe Batallones, Purificacion Cavan, Ruben Federizon, Lourdes Gregorio, George Hernandez, Ruben Hilario, and Antonio Ubaldo. Since the 1970s she mounted annual voice recitals featuring her students at the Philamlife Auditorium that sang mainly operatic arias and duets. Pianist Regalado Jose, her long-time collaborative artist since before the war, was the featured pianist who assisted her students.

She received numerous awards and citations, among them, the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila in 1982 and the Medal of Distinction from the Concert Society of Manila in 1990. Written byAntonio C. Hila

MATURAN,DIOMEDES(Diomedes Padilla Maturan) b. Manila 16 Aug 1940.d. 7 Apr 2002.Singer.Son of ProcesoMaturanand Felisa Padilla,hemarried Sylvia Policarpio withwhom he had four children.He went to Santa AnaElementary School and Manuel Roxas High School.He was a sophomore in pre-dentistry at the University of theEast when he became national champion of TawagngTanghalan (Call of the Stage) in 1958 with hisrendition of “Rose Tattoo.” That same year, LVNPicturesintroduced him in the movie Rose Tattoo ng Buhay Ko(Rose Tattoo of My Life) withlead stars CharitoSolis and Eddie Rodriguez.He was able to make 25 films that include Ginintuang Tinig (Golden Voice), also with Solis and Rodriguez in 1959, Private Maturan with Pugo, Patsy, and Bentot in 1959;Maturan at Lagman (Maturan and Lagman) with Cenon Lagman, the 1959 national champion of Tawag ng Tanghalan, with Marita Zobel, and Mila Ocampo in 1959; Lovingly Yours with Mila Ocampo in 1959; PrinsipeDiomedesat ang Mahiwagang Gitara(Prince Diomedesand the MagicGuitar) with Marita Zobel in 1961; and Top Tunes with Eddie Mesa and Jose Mari in 1964.

He was dubbed as “Perry Como of the Philippines” and indeed he recorded cover versions of well-loved foreign classic, standard, and pop songs such as “Hello, Young Lovers,” “The Alphabet Song,” “Tulips and Heather,”and “I Wanna Give” aside from “Rose Tattoo” that catapulted him to fame. However, he never failed to include original Filipino songs in his repertoire.He did a back to back long-playing album with Ruben Tagalog under Villar Records, Dahil sa Iyo (Because of You), which featured 12 classic compositions of Miguel Velarde Jr with the composer himself conducting the orchestra. The six Velarde classics that he recorded for the said album were the title song, “DahilsaIyo” (Because of You), “Buhat” (Ever Since), “Ikaw ay Akin” (You are Mine), “Lahat ng Araw” (All Days), “Gabi at Araw” (Night and Day), and “Magmula Ngayon” (From Now On).His solo album, Dinggin(Listen), released in 1961 also under Villar Records featured 12 Filipino love songs written by Juan Silos Jr, Leopoldo Silos, Tex Salcedo, and Levi Celerio. The title song, “Dinggin” (Hear) by Ruben Escare and Levi Celerio, has since then become a favorite Filipino love song in the tradition of harana (serenade).He also popularized original Filipino songs in English, such as Jesse Saclo’s “My Wishes” and “Why, Oh Why” and Pablo Vergara’s “I’ll Never Let You Go.”

Since 1958 until his death in 2002, Maturansang in almost all musical shows on radio, television, and stage. He regularly performed at the Grand Opera House in the 1960s, had frequent singingengagements in the US military bases and in Filipino communities in the United States, Europe, and Canadaduring the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s. In 1997, Universal Records released his CD album Memorable Love Songs where he sang his most favorite Filipino songs such as Salvador Asuncion’s “In Despair,” Pablo Vergara’s “God Knows,” Francisco Buencamino’s “Prinsesa ng Kumintang” (Princess of Kumintang), and Francisco Santiago’s “Pakiusap” (Plea) and “Madaling Araw” (Dawn). He was singing regularly at Tiya Dely Magpayo’s Serenatang Kumbidahan (Invitational Serenade) over DZRH of the Manila Broadcasting Company until his death.

In 1984, he received the Cecil Award in the category of Outstanding Light Classical Vocal Recording for his rendition of “Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal” (How Much I Love You), a classic Ernani Cuenco and Levi Celerio composition. He was the first male singer to receive a Hall of Fame award from the National Press Club in 1980. Written byMichael M. Coroza

MAZO, DICK (Ricardo Mazo Jr) b. Cainta, Rizal 9 Nov 1938. Choral conductor, pianist, organist. Mazo learned piano at age six and became an accomplished accompanist during his grade school and high school years. After completing his secondary education, he accepted a post in FGU Insurance Group as choir conductor, also at St John Methodist Church as a choir conductor. In 1973, he resigned from his posts to accept a scholarship grant at the University of the East School of Music then under the directorship of Col Antonino Buenaventura, later National Artist for music. Apparently, before earning his degree from the said university, he was yet again granted a scholarship, but this time by the Switzerland-based World Council of Churches.

He obtained his mastery in piano and conducting as well as an artist diploma in organ from the Robert Schumann Institute in Dusseldorf. After obtaining his degree, he did a series of concerts throughout Germany, including one at the famous Gothic Cathedral of Cologne, before coming back to his home country in 1983. After he came back for good, he cooperated with the National Council of Churches in the Philippines in producing a Filipino Hymnal, which is considered his greatest contribution in the field of music.

He served as faculty member of Asian Institute of Liturgy and Music, and of the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music teaching organ performance and choral conducting. Being a choir conductor and director, he was revered for elevating the standard of choral performances manifested in the groups he conducted, namely, the Monastery Boys Choir which is based in Malaybalay, Bukidnon; the Ellinwood Malate Church Choir in Malate; and Coro Tomasino at the University of Santo Tomas. Written by Crisancti L. Macazo

MELENDREZ, JIMMY (Joaquin G. Melendrez) b. Intramuros, Manila 17 Apr 1935. Singer. He married Grace Turla with whom he has five children. He studied at Colegio de San Juan de Letran and FEATI University. JoseMossesgeldSantiago-Font had drafted him into the ranks of the choruses for operatic productions of the late 1940s. Melendrez was often heard over DZPI’s Sing for Fun, a pop-oriented program. Taking lessons from pianist-singer Grace Turla, a piano graduate of University of Santo Tomas and a University of the Philippines graduating voice student, Melendrez became a concert and opera soloist. He gave his first full-length recital at the Philamlife Auditorium in 1965.

He then embarked on a singing career that peaked via television from the late 1960s to the mid-1970s. Melendrez and soprano FidesCuyugan-Asensio together hosted Sunday Sweet Sunday which was probably the first attempt in the Philippines to teach classical-music appreciation informally through television.

Melendrez played lead roles in operas like Mozart’s Abduction from the Seraglio, Puccini’s Gianni Schicchi, and Bizet’s Carmen when it was first staged in Filipino in 1956. The following year, he appeared as Padre Damaso in Felipe de Leon’s opera Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) in its world premiere at FEU Auditorium. In the 1960s, he joined Conchita Sunico’s Karilagan Revue as tenor soloist and performed at the Lincoln Center in New York, and began singing on stage and television. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo

METRO MANILA CONCERT ORCHESTRA (MMCO) The MMCO, previously known as Metro Manila Community Orchestra, was organized in 2000 by Alfonso Coke Bolipata, Teresita Serrano, and Patricia B. Licuanan. Bolipata was then a faculty member of the Music Center of Miriam College, which was headed by Teresita Serrano. Licuanan, then president of Miriam College, approved its organization. It was registered under the umbrella of the Institute for Orchestra Development in the Philippines (IODP). The organizers held auditions for its membership in Jan 2000 and presented an inaugural concert at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) on 23 Jun 2000, with conductor and music director Josefino “Chino” Toledo. In its many years of existence, the group has been guided by a vision to sustain the formation, growth, and development of talented musical artists, thus uplifting the culture of Philippine communities, especially the marginalized.

In 2010, on its 10th year, the orchestra was renamed Metro Manila Concert Orchestra, after having performed 40 concertos. Since then, it has featured outstanding Filipino pianists Raul Sunico, Albert Tiu, Cristine Coyiuto, Aima Labra Makk; violinist Alfonso Bolipata; soprano Camille Lopez; the Novo Concertante Choir; and young soloists Michael Yu, Luci Magalit, and Caitlin Coyiuto. Thus year 2010 saw the orchestra moving beyond being a local community training orchestra, which has a limited association, onto a “people’s orchestra” that has performed, not only in concert halls such CCP and Francisco Santiago Hall, but in school auditoriums, churches, makeshift stages in the provinces as well. This flexibility has allowed the orchestra to transcend the divide between high art and popular culture, making symphonic music broadly available to the public.

A distinguishing character of this orchestra is that it has played a wide variety of musical genres. New compositions from young Filipino composers who wrote in contemporary idiom have been launched in special programming titled “Music Under Konstruction Orchestral Reading Project.” In addition, the orchestra has annual concerts designed for children, in cooperation with the CCP. This series has enhanced the musical learning experience of the children particularly in marginalized communities. Another program at present is the School Outreach Series, which is aligned to the K-12 curriculum, which highlights the values “maka-Diyos (pro-God), makatao (pro-people), makabayan (pro-country), and makakalikasan (pro-environment).”

On 3 Jul 2012, the Metro Manila Concert Orchestra Foundation Incorporated (MMCOFI) was organized and registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to manage the MMCO and replaced the IODP. Since 2013, it has moved its office and rehearsal hall from the Miriam College Campus to Erehwon Center for the Arts in Villa Beatriz Subdivision, Old Balara, Quezon City. The MMCOFI Board of Trustees is composed of Milagros B. Arnaldo, chair and president; Corazon Alma G. de Leon, vice president; Mary Ann M. Streeter, treasurer; and Rafael R. Benitez, Bro Ricardo P. Laguda, FSC, Clarita T. Ordoñez, Renato T. Boysie Villavicencio, Michael T. Toledo, and Mercedes Palanca Pleno, members. At present, the MMCO has become one of the leading symphony orchestras in the country. It has answered the demand for a debonair symphonic sound that is the product of the synergy between its conductor and the musicians. Written by Antonio C. Hila

article_title: Mirano, Elena Rivera (See Rivera Mirano, Elena.)
text: Mirano, Elena Rivera (See Rivera Mirano, Elena.)

MOLINA, ANTONIO (Antonio Jesus Naguit Molina) b. Quiapo, Manila 26 Dec 1894. d. 29 Jan 1980. National Artist for music. Composer, cellist, educator. He was the son of Juan Molina, a customs inspector during the final years of the Spanish regime, and Simeona Naguit. He was married to Pilar Siauingco, who died in 1957, with whom he had six children including Rosita, a pianist; Exequiel (Lito), jazz artist and journalist; and Antonio Maria Jr, conductor and composer based in the United States. His second wife was Carmen Serrano. In 1896, his father founded the 22-piece Orquesta Molina whose members lived and rehearsed in the family residence. At 12, he could play the violin, and later, the bandurria, mandolin, guitar, laud, bajo de uñas, octavina, and the cello. His favorite instrument was the violoncello. He played it so well that he became an orchestra soloist at the Manila Grand Opera House.

He went to the Escuela Catolica de Nuestro Padre Jesus Nazareno in 1902 in Quiapo and then to Colegio de San Juan de Letran where he received his bachelor’s degree in 1909. He also studied architectural design, landscape sketching, and decorative and freehand drawing. To please his father, he enrolled for a law degree at the University of Santo Tomas and then at the Manila Law School but shifted to music upon his father’s death. He stopped his law studies in 1913 and did odd jobs to help his family. During this time, he formed a string band, Rondalla Ideal and learned to compose by ear and later, by writing the notes. From 1916 to 1924, he was orchestra director of the Cine Empire on Carlos Palanca St, Manila during the era of the silent movies. He took formal lessons with Nicanor Abelardo in 1918. In 1919, he enrolled at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music for a teacher’s diploma in violoncello which he obtained in 1923.

In school, he composed the following: Era La Penumbra, Kung sa Iyong Gunita (Upon Your Remembrance), Cantilena Romantica, Ave Maria, Scherzo in D major, Epifania de las Rosas, and No Adayuca. His teachers included Nicanor Abelardo and Conservatory director Robert Schofield. From 1922 to 1924, he concertized extensively in Hanoi and other parts of Indochina. Molina also taught at the UP Conservatory of Music and then at Centro Escolar University (CEU). Molina wrote his first composition, “Matinal,” 1912. This was followed in 1913 by a set of waltzes, Lamentos de Mi Patria (Laments of My Fatherland), and in 1915 by his most popular violin piece, “Hatinggabi” (Midnight). While in school, he composed works which included a sarsuwela, Ana Maria, and his most important orchestral works, like Misa Antoniana Grand Festival Mass, 1964, and Ang Batingaw (The Bell), 1972, and chamber music compositions, like Prelude and Romanz for cello and piano, 1928, and Bontok Rhapsody.

In his works Molina used whole tone and pentatonic scales, many ninth and eleventh chords, and linear counterpoint. He included the use of ethnic instruments like the kulintang and the gabbang in symphonic music. He wrote hundreds of scores for chamber music, chorus, orchestra, instrumental and vocal solo music, and sarsuwela. About 200 of his works utilize folk tunes. He was one of the early 20th century Filipino composers who, with Nicanor Abelardo and Francisco Santiago, continued the nationalistic movement in Philippine music. Molina was also actively involved in the development of choral and rondalla music in the Philippines. He functioned as both organizer and conductor of such groups. He conducted the premiere of Bach’s Christmas Oratorio on 14 Dec 1947, the first performance of Mozart’s opera Don Giovanni, and the first television choral concert to be presented in the Philippines. In 1949 he received the Choral Conductor of the Year award from the Music Lovers’ Society. He was the only Filipino musician cited in the 1952 edition of Who’s Who in American Education. He was listed in the Philippine Commonwealth Directory and Encyclopedia of the Philippines. The CEU conferred on him an honorary doctorate in law in 1953, and named him dean emeritus upon his retirement from the university in 1970. He received the Civic Assembly of Women of the Philippines Citation of Merit in 1962, Patnubay ng Kalinangan Award for music, City of Manila, 1969; the UP Conservatory Alumni Award and the Phi Kappa Beta Award in 1972, and the Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1972. On 12 Jun 1973 he was the first musician to be conferred the National Artist award.Written byEdna Marcil M. Martinezupdated by Connie Ladrido

MOLINA, ARTURO (Jose Arturo Tria Molina) b. Malate, Manila 24 Jan 1958. Violinist, violist, strings pedagogue, and orchestral conductor. He is the son of Salvacion Tria and Benjamin Molina. His father was the nephew of the Antonio Molina and was the composer’s secretary and occasional copyist. Arturo’s paternal grandfather Mariano Molina was a pianist who traveled internationally, while his great grandfather Juan Molina was the founder of the Molina Orchestra active in the early 20th century. Arturo’s siblings are also notable musicians. His older brother Augusto is a violinist and his sister Regina is a cellist who played for the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO).

Molina’s formal violin lessons began at age six with Adriano Garcia, a violist of the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO). He received his early orchestral training at the University of the East Students Orchestra under Col Antonino Buenaventura and not long after received a scholarship to study under the MSO’s director Oscar Yatco. When Yatco went to Germany, Molina went on to train with Basilio Manalo, then concertmaster of the MSO. In the early 1980s, Molina joined his mentors Manalo and Yatco at the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) as its principal violist, at the time when the orchestra underwent some major reorganization. By 1984, he was recognized as a promising young musician and was given a scholarship to study in Russia through the Orchestra Development Program of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

At the Kiev Conservatory, Molina came under the tutelage of Alexander Yegorov and went on to win the conservatory’s annual competition after three years of study. Upon his return to the Philippines, an invitation came from conductor and violinist Sergio Esmilla to lead the Manila Chamber Orchestra, the resident performing group at the PCI Bank’s Francisco Santiago Hall in Makati. Molina would later also serve as concertmaster of the PPO as part of his service for the scholarship he received. In 1999, he formed the Battig Trio with cellist Wilfredo Pasamba and pianist J. Greg Zuniega, performing concerts locally and on tours in Italy, France, and Germany.

Alongside a prolific career as a professional violinist, Molina began to teach younger musicians through the auspices of the Philippine Research for Developing Instrumental Soloists (PREDIS), which his former mentor Manalo and Sr Mary Placid Abejo founded in 1985. “Sir Toti,” as he is known to his students, have made significant contributions to strings pedagogy in the country, mentoring violinists that have gone through the strings program of the PREDIS, and the collegiate programs at the St Scholastica’s College in Manila and at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. Many of his own students have won the National Music Competitions for Young Artists and have represented the Philippines in international music festivals and competitions. They have also gone to pursue careers as leading soloists, orchestral musicians, and music educators in the Philippines and abroad. From 1994 to 2003, Molina was chair of the Strings Department of the UP College of Music.

Molina’s transition to an orchestral conductor came about with the formation of the Manila Youth Symphony Orchestra (MYSO) as a further training ground for the PREDIS and musicians from other universities in Manila. In 2000, he became a fellow at the Conductor’s Institute at the University of South Carolina. Not long after, the MYSO organization transitioned into a more professional orchestra, paving the way for the revival of the MSO. Molina was at the helm of the relaunch concert in 2001, leading a new generation of musicians through varied programming set to revitalize local interest in orchestral music. Written by Isidora Miranda

MOLINA, LITO (Exequiel Siauingco Molina) b. Quiapo, Manila 20 May 1929. d. 5 Mar 2003. Jazz musician, music critic. Molina was the fourth child of composer and National Artist Antonio J. Molina and Pilar Siauingco. He was a grandson of conductor and orchestra manager Juan Molina. He was married to Josefa Tuason with whom he had three children. He studied at the San Miguel Elementary School in Manila, the Mapa High School, and the University of Santo Tomas where he received his degree in journalism in 1952.

He was exposed to music in the Molina household and studied piano under Iluminada de Leon. After discovering his interest in jazz music, he played with the Martiniano Esguerra Orchestra in 1943. In 1945 he played professionally with various bands, and in 1951 was invited to join the Pete Aristorenas Orchestra, then considered the finishing school of jazz in the Philippines.

In 1955, Molina and Tony Velarde formed Jazz Friends. The original band members included Piding Alava (piano) and Angel Peña (bass). The iconic Jazz Friends blazed the Philippine jazz scene and immediately established the artistic standard for other jazz bands and artists. During the late 1950s, the UPSILON fraternity of the University of the Philippines started a series of concerts that brought jazz music to the university campus. This event has since then become an institution. He was also a member of the Executive Jazz Band from 1967 to 1982.

Molina was also a music critic. He got his first job as a journalist in 1954, but it was only in 1960, after a brief stint as a salesperson for a Manila appliance firm that he landed a job as deskman for the Evening News. He eventually became its editorial writer, then features editor, and incidental music reviewer. He moved on to other newspapers until he was invited to set up Business Day (now Business World) in 1967. He was its managing editor and music reviewer until his retirement in 1987. He was also a member of the Samahan ng mga Manunulat at Manunuri sa Musika sa Pilipinas or SAMMPI since 1985 up to his death.

He was considered by many as the “Father of Philippine Jazz,” promoting this musical idiom to as many audiences as he could reach. Throughout his musical career he had inspired several Filipino jazz artists to continue the Philippine jazz tradition. Molina remained active in the concert scene in spite of a stroke he suffered in 1982. He led the Philippine Jazz Ensemble at the Monterey Jazz Festival in California in 1981, and participated in the Asian Arts Festival in Hong Kong in 1982. His passion for jazz music is best reflected in his statement: “A crusade for sane music in this country is often a labor of love.” Written byEdna Marcil M. Martinezupdated by Katherine Molina
Molina, Titay (See THEATER volume.)

MORALES, BIBIANO b. Manila 2 Dec 1872. d. Manila 30 Jun 1931. Violinist, conductor, composer. Morales was the grandson of BibianoMorales, known in his time as “el primer maestro de capilla y organista de la Iglesia Catedral de Manila” (the premier choir master and organist of the ManilaCathedral), and the son of violinist and conductor Ignacio Morales. He was married to Magdalena Cobarrubias. He received his first music lessons from his father and was later tutored by AntonioGarcia. Later he appeared in concerts either as soloist or orchestra member. He occasionally conducted for resident or visiting troupes.

In 1903, he traveled as far as Java, Indonesia, as concertmaster for an Italian opera company. Upon his return, he became conductor of the Orquesta Molina. He was also concertmaster for the Manila Monday Musicale Symphony Orchestra, then led by Vincenzo Gambardella. He composed the music for the one-act sarsuwela written by Corcuera, Ang Pagpapalayaw ng Magulang sa Anak (When Parents Spoil their Children), Ang Pag-ibig ng Babae (The Love of a Woman), and Ang Paglililo ng Asawa (Marital Infidelity), all of which were produced at the Teatro Libertad on 20 Jul 1902. He also taught violin at the Ateneo de Manila and the Colegio de Niños Tiples of the Manila Cathedral.Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo

MOSCARDON-MAIGUE, NANETTE (Nanette Yanson Moscardon-Maigue) b. Bacolod City, Negros Occidental 17 Feb 1957. Soprano leggiero. She is the third child of four children of Generoso Moscardon and Gloria Yanson. Maigue grew up in a musically inclined family. Her mother had three sisters whose voices were together often heard in the church. She took piano lessons at the La Consolacion College Bacolod in 1967 and with other private piano teachers. In 1984, she got married to Raymundo Ruiz Maigue with whom she has four children: Franco, a guitarist; Lara, a voice major and composer; Danya, a sport science major and a professional hip-hop dancer; and Galan, the artist-painter of the family. Moscardon-Maigue majored in piano beginning 1973 at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music but later shifted to voice. She was mentored by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio and earned her teacher’s diploma in voice in 1987.

Maigue became a member of the UP Concert Chorus in 1974 where her musical theater stints started. She bagged the major roles in musicals such as The Best of Broadway, 1974 and 1975, and Kismet of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1975 and 1980; in Sumpang Mahal (Beloved Promise), 1976; in the “Tagalized” mime The Prodigal Son, 1975; and in West Side Story in Pilipino by the UP College of Music, 1977. Her college years were intertwined with performances as a freelance singer in the country and abroad. She was invited as a soloist of the Karilagan Arts International representing the Department of Tourism in the ASTA Convention in Acapulco Mexico, of the UP Filipiniana Dance Company, and with Manila Symphony Orchestra in key cities of Europe, Southeast Asia, Hongkong, and the United States. From the 1970s to the 1990s, she did remarkable performances in the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) productions of Aloyan, 1978, Noli Me Tangere, 1987, and La Boheme, 1992. She also did a concert in Taiwan’s International Festival in 1982. She starred in Minda Mora, 1981, of the Zarzuela Foundation which toured in Southeast Asian cities. She was a soloist in Poulenc’s music with the UP Concert Chorus and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 1984. At the Metropolitan Theater, she sang roles in musicals like Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1978 and 1979, Dahil Sa ’Yo (Because of You), 1980, and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1979. At the Concert at the Park and at the Paco Park Presents, she did many concerts. In Fort Santiago’s Dulaang Raha Sulayman, she performed in Philippine Educational Theater Association’s Pilipinas Circa 1907, 1982, and at the Philamlife Auditorium, she sang in Menotti’s The Medium.

Together with guitarist Lester Demetillo and brother-in-law Antonio Ruiz Maigue, Nanette founded an ensemble called Trio in 1987. They first performed at the Concert at the Park during the Linggo ng Wika celebration titled Mga Piling-Piling Awitin at Musika (Selected Songs and Music). As part of the CCP’s Outreach Program, the Trio staged well-received concerts in Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. In 1996, they also mounted a mini-concert series, visiting major newspaper company offices.

In the Manila Chamber Orchestra Opera concert season in 1987, Nanette joined other opera artists like contralto Aida Gamboa, tenor Nolyn Cabahug, and baritone Elmo Makil at the Francisco Santiago Hall, PCIBank Tower, Makati Ave. She also had solo performances in the same hall for various years interpreting a number of Jeffrey Ching’s works, which were accompanied by the Manila Chamber Orchestra with Sergio Esmilla as conductor.

Maigue taught voice in a number of music schools: for nine years at the UP College of Music from 1991 to 2000, De La Salle College of St Benilde in 2002, and in the UP College of Music Extension Program from 2006 up to the present. Since 2011 to present, she also teaches at their family-owned school, the Maigue Music Studio in Quezon City.Written byMa. Josephine Baradas

MOSSESGELD SANTIAGO-FONT, JOSE aka Jose Santiago-Font. b. San Miguel de Mayumo, Bulacan 14 Apr 1893 d. Manila 5 Mar 1958. Singer. His parents were Simon Mossesgeld and Rosa Font. He was married to Dolores Andrada with whom he had a son. He obtained his bachelor’s degree at the Ateneo de Manila in 1911 and studied law for two years at the University of Santo Tomas. He received his first musical training from Donato Cajili and Simplicio Solis. He studied violin under BibianoMorales, then voice under Ferdinando Avedano and, sometime after 1926, under Romano Romani in the United States. For three years he was a member of the Roxy Theater Ensemble in New York City. In 1930 he was awarded a study grant by the Caruso Scholarship American Foundation.

Santiago-Font’s operatic debut was held on 27 Jun 1931 at the Teatro Comunale of Trieste, Italy, where he sang in Wagner’s Gotterdammerung. From 1931 to 1936 he performed in some of the most prestigious opera houses in Italy, including the Teatro Alla Scala of Milan, San Carlo of Naples, and Teatro Reggio Turin, as well as the Teatro Colon of Buenos Aires and the Liceo of Barcelona. He also toured the Netherlands in the early 1930s and performed in all the major theaters there.

In Manila, he played, the roles of Mephistopheles in Faust, the high priest in Aida, the baritone role in Rigoletto, Escamillo in Carmen, among other roles. Santiago-Font did at least 28 recordings for Columbia records and sang kundiman for the radio. Written byRaj Mansukhani

article_title: Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines
text:
MUSIC PROMOTION FOUNDATION OF THE PHILIPPINES (MPFP) Founded in May 1956, it was the brainchild of singer and National Artist for music JovitaFuentes, who envisioned an institution which would promote and cultivate music appreciation among Filipinos from all sectors of society. Created by Congress on 18 Jun 1955, it was formally organized in May 1956 with the following board of trustees: Jovita Fuentes, chair; Isabel Roces, vice-chair; LucreciaR.Kasilag, secretary; Evelina Kalaw, treasurer; RamonTapales, liaison officer; and Liwanag P. Cruz, LeonorOrosa-Goquingco, and FelipePadilladeLeon, members. The Foundation has launched a number of major projects, starting with the first Philippine Music Festival in Feb 1957. This featured Felipe Padilla de Leon’s NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not) which was a major full-length opera in Tagalog of its time, a ballet and dance concert, and a symphony band concert. It has sponsored grand band concerts, national band competitions, ballets, concerts, sarsuwela, operas, and recitals by its scholars. From 1952 to 1972, it commissioned 20 works, including operas, sarsuwela, symphonies, concertos, symphonicpoems, works for chorus and orchestra, overtures, and chambermusic.

The Foundation is credited with having opened the door of opportunity to many gifted Filipino musical artists through scholarships, travel grants, and various national competitions. Many personalities in Philippine music—conductors, pianists, singers, composers, choreographers, bandleaders, musicologists—owe much of their development and training to the Foundation. Its list of scholars include CecileLicad, AndreaVeneracion, BenjaminTupas, GamalielViray, and AliceReyes. The Foundation operated until 1989, when it was turned over to the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines. Written byEdgardo B. Maranan

MUYCO, MARIA CHRISTINE (Maria Christine Muyco-Levi) b. Victorias, Negros Occidental 26 Jul 1965. Composer, ethnomusicologist, educator. Her parents are Salvador Muyco and Cecilia Macainan. She is married to Titus Levi, media economist and musician. She has a bachelor’s degree in humanities from the University of the Philippines (UP) Visayas, 1986; a bachelor of music in composition from the UP Diliman, 1996; a master of music in music composition from the University of British Columbia, 1998; and a doctorate in Philippine Studies from the UP Diliman, 2008, with a dissertation titled “Sibod in Binanog: Understanding of the Binanog Music-Dance Tradition of the Panay Bukidnon (Philippines).” She also completed a year in ethnomusicology and dance Studies at the University of California in Los Angeles, from 2006 to 2007. Muyco served as chair of the Composition and Theory Department of the University of the Philippines College of Music and of the Asian Composer’s League, Philippine Chapter from 2010-16.

Muyco writes music in a wide range of idioms covering conventional western idioms and forms, traditional Asian and Philippine concepts and instrumentation, and electronic and computer-based technologies, conceptualizing works that reflect her familiarity with contemporary theories and experience in fieldwork in traditional Philippine communities. Her aim is to “infuse life into instruments and technologies for the benefit of people and groups.” Her musical works reflect social advocacies, particularly in the areas of gender and women’s interest such as Ritwal Para sa Mga Kababaihan (Ritual for Women) for percussion, chorus, and community participants, which was held during Women’s Week in 2001, and InBukasyon (Invocation) for chant and Philippine indigenous musical instruments, 2013. Her work also advocates children’s rights, such as Ako at ang Kalikasan (I and the Environment), 1995, and Kapilas ng Buhay (Part of One’s Life), University of the Philippines Abelardo Hall, by the UP Cherubim Children’s Choir, 2002; and Mumunting Tinig (Tiny Voices), a collection of new choral pieces for children, funded by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, published in 2015. She also did work for marginalized communities in the context of nation formation and globalization, like Tinagong Dagat (Hidden Sea), a musical dance-drama for the Dagyaw Theatre Group, 1994. She is also actively engaged in community work through creative workshops and livelihood-generating projects that reconstruct, transmit, and enrich living traditions in Central Philippines among the Bukidnon communities of Panay and the Ati communities of Boracay. Her research in these communities inspired her works Baradbad for Chinese orchestra and Ti(nag)hoy (Outcry) for choir, 2012, and Pagbilog (Rounding) for Chinese orchestra and Bu(u)kot (Veiled) for large orchestra, erhu, and dance, 2014.

She has collaborated in numerous multimedia arts projects, notably, the multi-awarded feature film Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa (Dance of Two Left Feet) with poet and director Alvin Yapan and musician and composer Jema Pamintuan. The production won the Gawad Urian, including Best Film, 2011. She also shared the Cinemalaya award for Best Musical Score for the same work with co-composer Jema Pamintuan 2011. Another collaborative work for Ateneo’s ENTABLADO was Si Pilandok at ang Bayan ng Bulawan (Pilandok and the Town of Bulawan), a musical dance-drama that ran for a total of 20 performances at a number of venues from Aug to Sep 2010. Her interest in environmental sound led to IkoToki, 2014, a work for Jeepney Orchestra, which utilized invented instruments fabricated from old jeepney parts.

As a scholar, she has publications in scholarly journals, among them, “Mangalimog Ako: Finding One’s Voice in Sugidanon (Epic Chanting)” in Songs of Memory in Islands of Southeast Asia, 2013. Her doctoral dissertation was published by the Ateneo de Manila University Press as Sibod: Ideology and Expressivity in Binanog Dance, Music, and Folkways of the Panay Bukidnon, 2016. Written byElena Rivera Mirano

NAKPIL, JULIO (Julio Garcia Nakpil) b. Quiapo, Manila 22 May 1867 d. Quiapo, Manila 2 Nov 1960. Composer, pianist. He was the fourth of 12 children of Juan Luna Nakpil, a musician and jeweler, and Juana Putco Garcia. His eldest sister Petrona married Dr Ariston Bautista, a philanthropist and good friend of Jose Rizal and Juan Luna. In 1898, he married Gregoria de Jesus, widow of Andres Bonifacio with whom he had eight children. Juan Nakpil, the eldest and only son became a National Artist for architecture. Julio and Gregoria with their children lived in the house built by Dr Ariston Bautista and wife Petrona Nakpil as the couple was childless. The Nakpil-Bautista heritage house is now a museum located at Barbosa St in Quiapo.

Growing up, Julio was barely educated as he received only two years of formal schooling beginning at the age of eight when he was a student at the Escuela de Instruccion Primaria in Quiapo. The strict education at this school did not appeal to the precocious and highly creative child. He was well read and even learned to read and write well in Spanish. He was also largely self-taught in music. After taking a few lessons in violin from Ramon Valdes and piano with his cousin Manuel Mata, he honed his musical talent on his own.

He became a well-known pianist in Manila’s affluent society performing in social gatherings and at the Malacañan Palace during the time of Gov Eulogio Despojol. He started composing short pieces for the piano and his first known work was “Cefiro” (Zephyr) in 1888. Other early compositions were “Ylang-Ylang,” a mazurka de salon; “La Brisa Nocturna” (The Night Breeze), a habanera; “Noche Tempestuosa” (Stormy Night), a polka de salon, and the danzas “Eco de Iloco” (Echoes from Iloco) and Ecos de Visayas (Echoes From Visayas), all in 1890. In 1891, he composed “Recuerdos de Capiz” (Memories of Capiz), a habanera, which became his most famous work. It reached six printings with the first edition published by Louis Schumpff, an editor in Paris. This piece together with the “Luz Poetica Amor” (Dawn of Enlightenment), 1892, and the “Exposicion Regional de Filipina,” 1895, were awarded a Diploma of Honor in the Exposicion Regional held in the Philippines in 1895. He also received acclaim in succeeding expositions receiving diplomas and medals in Hanoi in 1902 and St Louis in 1904. His other compositions for piano before the onset of the revolution were “Teatro Luisa,” 1891, “Clotilde,” “Dance Campestre,” a habanera para concierto, also for violin and piano, “Kundiman,” and “Lulay,” 1892.

Nakpil was deeply stirred by the events leading to the revolution. He composed “Amor Patrio” (Love of Country) in 1893, a romanza with words from Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), inspired by the national hero’s deportation to Mindanao. He joined the Katipunan in 1896 and was assigned in the procurement of arms for the revolutionaries. He fought his first battle alongside Emilio Jacinto in San Mateo under Andres Bonifacio. He was commissioned by Bonifacio to compose and write the lyrics for the national anthem of the Philippines, titled “Marangal na Dalit ng Katagalugan” (Noble Hymn of the Tagalog Region), 1896. His other popular works during the time of the revolution were “Balintawak” and “Armamento” (Armament), 1896; “Pamitinan” (Hiding Place), a polka, and “Pag-ibig” (Love), “Pahimakas” (Farewell), a funeral march commemorating Rizal’s execution and “Pasig-Pantayanin,” 1897; “Biak-na-Bato,” 1898; “Sueño Eterno” (Eternal Sleep), 1899, a tribute to the bravery of Antonio Luna; “Salve Patria, 1903; and “Kabanatuan,” a marcha funebre, 1904. His other works include “Pinching,” “Mediodia,” “Johnny and Little Julia,” “Produciones Musicales,” “Deus Omnipotens et Miserecors,” a marcha funebre, and “Victory March,” 1944.

Nakpil wrote his memoirs on the revolution, which was translated by Encarnacion Alzona and published as Julio Nakpil and the Philippine Revolution in 1964 by Carmelo and Bauermann Inc. For his role as a revolutionary and musician at the time of the revolution he received a medal and citation from the Civic Assembly of Women in 1954. In 1963, he was given a posthumous award by the Bonifacio Centennial Commission in recognition of his patriotism. Written byFlerida D. Nolascoupdated by Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua

article_title: National Commission for Culture and the Arts (See ARCHITECTURE volume.)
text: National Commission for Culture and the Arts (See ARCHITECTURE volume.)

article_title: National Music Competitions for Young Artists Foundation, Inc
text:
NATIONAL MUSIC COMPETITIONS FOR YOUNG ARTISTS FOUNDATION, INC (NAMCYA) Founded formally in 1973, it was created by virtue of Presidential Proclamation 1173, dated 7 Aug 1973, which declares the period between 26 Nov and 2 Dec every year as National Week for Young Artists. The NAMCYA seeks to encourage young artists to excel in performance, and to preserve, develop, and promote Philippine music as art and as a handmaid of cultural development.

Since 1973, the main sponsoring institution of the annual event has been the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) whose president sits as chairperson of the national committee which conducts the competitions. The CCP has also hosted the competitions and festivals in its venues. In 2001, Presidential Proclamation No 80 was signed affirming NAMCYA’s continuing mission for the development of the nation’s young artists. This proclamation also further designated the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) as the principal supporting agency of NAMCYA. Aside from the competitions, a new outreach component has been introduced since 2010 providing musical training and workshops to young musicians.

Competitions are held from the divisional up to the regional levels; the first prize winners then come to Manila to vie for national honors in the main categories of Choral Performance, Solo Voice and Instruments, Family Ensemble, and Chamber Music, in both Western art music and Philippine indigenous and folk music traditions.

Since its initial competitions in 1973, the NAMCYA has accorded national recognition to more than 250 children’s, youth, and college choirs, 200 pianists, 300 solo/orchestral instrumentalists, 180 traditional music artists, 74 family ensembles, 15 chamber music ensembles, 50 rondalla groups, and over a hundred solo voice performers, as major-prize winners. An important contribution of the NAMCYA to Philippine musical literature is the commissioning of new contest pieces annually which provides a continuous source of works with high artistic quality from prominent Filipino composers such as Ramon Santos, Lucio San Pedro, Francisco Feliciano, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucrecia Kasilag, Ruben Federizon, Ryan Cayabyab, Josefino Toledo, and Eudenice Palaruan. In 2008, it organized a competition for new choral arrangements of folk songs, together with the NCCA, and the winning 15 entries were published in a compilation titled Mga Awiting Bayan Para sa Korong Pilipino (Folk Songs for the Filipino Chorus).

Many NAMCYA winners have brought international prestige to the country by winning further prizes in foreign competitions and pursuing advanced training and concertizing abroad, among them: the Bolipata Brothers, Jaime and Alfonso; pianists Rowena Arrieta, Jovianney Emmanuel Cruz, Aries Caces, Rene Dalandan, Zinorl Bronola, Hiyas Hila, Karen Francisco, and Michelle Nicolasura; vocalists Andion Fernandez, Luz Morete, Josephine Roces, Johanna Cabili, Rachelle Gerodias, Jonathan Velasco, Katherina Olver, Joseph Legaspi, Joan Cano, and Maria Katrina Saporsantos; violinists Joseph Esmilla, Dionisia Fernandez, Jeffrey Solares, Joseph Brian Cimafrancia, Sara Maria Gonzales, Ralph Taylan, Joanna Ruth Livioco, and Jonathan David Livioco; cellists Gian Carlo Gonzales and Gerry Graham Gonzales; flutists Antonio Maigue and John Raymond Sarreal; bassoonist Adolfo Mendoza; guitarist Benchito Cariño; composers Conrado del Rosario, Arlene Chongson, Virginia Laico-Villanueva, and Christine Muyco; and choral groups like the Ateneo de Manila College Glee Club, the UP Singing Ambassadors, Himig Singers, University of the East Chorale, the UP Cherubim and Seraphim, the Loboc Children’s Choir, the Ivatan Children’s Choir, Boscorale, Baao District Children’s Choir, Ilocos Norte Children’s Choir, the Coro Tomasino of the University of Santo Tomas, and the De La Salle Zobel High School Chorale.

Through the Rondalla and Traditional Ensemble Categories, the NAMCYA has positively encouraged the appreciation and development of these unique Filipino musical traditions. At present, the number of rondalla groups in the Philippines has grown, and has indirectly caused a booming plucked string industry, and has initiated more research into the production of instruments used in the ensemble.

In 1992, the NAMCYA celebrated its 20th anniversary with an International Children’s Choir Festival which featured the Han-Sheng Children’s Choir from Taiwan and the Szczecinski Choir Chkopiecy from Poland. Written byAntonio C. Hila and Ramon P. Santosupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

NATIVIDAD, ROBERTO (Roberto Reyes Natividad) b. Obando, Bulacan 14 Mar 1941. d. 2 Jan 2007. Singer, teacher, musical director. A tenor-baritone, he was the son of Eliseo Natividad and Lucia Reyes. He married Cecilia Alava, a voice and piano teacher, church choir director, and former member of the Opera Chorus of the Philippines. He studied at Bonifacio Elementary School, then at Arellano High School where he graduated in 1957. He took up commerce at the Philippine College of Commerce (now Polytechnic University of the Philippines) in 1958, but later went to the University of the Philippines where he took initial studies in music. He obtained his bachelor of music major in voice in 1966 under Jovita Fuentes from the Centro Escolar University (CEU) Conservatory of Music. He taught music in Manila public schools in 1968 and in San Beda High School in 1969. He became choir director of various chorales in government and private offices.

As opera singer, he played lead roles in the Tales of Hoffman, Princesa Urduja (Princess Urduja), Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), and Ang Binhing Filipina (The Filipina Breed), staged at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines; in CEU productions like MariangMakiling, Madame Butterfly, Mignon, and Ang Sundalong Kapitan (The Soldier Captain); in the Southeast Asia production tour of Minda Mora by the Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines, 1981-82; in the MetropolitanTheater productions of HindiKitaMalimot (I Cannot Forget You), DahilsaIyo (Because of You), and Star Cavalcade; and in the Himig ng Lahi (Music of the Race) tour to the United States, Canada, and Europe, 1988.

Vice president and musical director of Cultura Filipina Musica Incorporada and an active church soloist, he organized a male ensemble called Guryang, which toured the provinces in 1983. Best known for his rendition of Tagalog kundiman, he was a mainstay of the TV musical program, Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You), where he also became musical director.

Natividad was the recipient of the Outstanding Performer in a Musical Series Award, given by the Philippine Academy for Television Arts and Sciences (PATAS) in 1976. He was also hailed as the Kundiman Singer of the Year by the National Press Club of the Philippines in 1990. Written byMa. Lourdes Maniquisupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

NAVARRO, JOEL (Joel Pizana Navarro) b. Manila 24 Jan 1955. Conductor, singer, music educator, church musician, composer, arranger. Navarro is the son of Jose Silverio and Angeles Pizana and is married to Ma. Divina Amor Pascual with whom he has three children. He graduated from University of the Philippines (UP) Elementary School and the Philippine Science High School (PSHS). In 1976, he received his degree in mathematics from La Salle Bacolod. He taught at the Ateneo de Manila University while enrolled for graduate studies. From 1980 to 1985, he was a scholar of the Bishop J.U. Teodoro Memorial Foundation while he worked on his bachelor of music degree at the UP College of Music. He finished his master of music degree in 1993, also in choral conducting in UP. In 2005, he obtained his doctor of music arts from the Michigan State University with a grade point average of 4.0. He was a recipient of the Multicultural Fellowship (for Doctoral Studies) for Minority Faculty at the Calvin College from 2001 to 2003.

Navarro has handled the Ateneo Glee Club and other choirs, and, occasionally, has guest conducted orchestras and choruses such as the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) and the Festival Choir of the International Association of Southeast Asian Schools in Jakarta, Indonesia. He was the conductor of the Ateneo Glee Club when it won first prize in the collegiate choir category of the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) in 1980, and top prize in the folkloric division and third prize in the mixed choir division at the Festival de Cantonigros in Spain in 1983. In 1989 the club’s performances were televised nationwide in Italy. It also won the Grand Prix de la Ville Tours in the 2000 Florilege Vocal de Tours, which earned them the right to represent Tours in the 2001 European Grand Prix of Choral Singing in Debrecen, Hungary. The Collegium Vocalis, another choral group which Navarro led for five years, won first prize in 1983 and 1985 in the Concurso de Coral Polifonico at the Spanish Cultural Center in Manila.

He conducted the PPO’s performances of Rutter’s Magnificat, Tschaikovsky’s Nutcracker Suite and Handel’s Messiah in 1989, as well as the musicals West Side Story, 1998, and The King and I, 2000. He also served as guest conductor of the Bamboo Organ International Festival, 2011, and the Jakarta Festival Chorus and Aula Simfonia Jakarta, 2014. While teaching at the Calvin College (CC) in Michigan, he was the conductor of its many choral groups such as CC Capella, 2002-14; CC Meistersingers, 2002-03; CC Lyric Singers, 2003-08; and the CC Oratorio Society since 2003. At present, he conducts the Singapore Bible College Chorale.

Navarro taught at the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music, UP College of Music where he chaired the Department of Conducting and Choral Ensembles, International School of Manila, and the Calvin College in Grand Rapids, Michigan. He is currently a professor and lecturer at the Singapore Bible College. He is also a regular consultant of the NAMCYA and the Kodaly Society of the Philippines, aside from having conducted numerous workshops and lectures about music and its connection to religious worship in various international conferences from the 1990s to the present.

In 1985, Navarro was awarded a British Council grant to observe prominent British choral groups. In 1991, he was cited as the Most Outstanding Alumnus for the Arts by the PSHS Batch 1971-B. He has also sung solo in campus and public concerts. He composed the pop songs “Suwerte-suwerte Lang” (Simply Luck) and “Manalig Ka” (Have Faith), finalists in the Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in l977 and 1980, respectively. He was also awarded the Best Choral Arrangement of a Traditional Song by the KATHA Awards in 1997 for his arrangement of “Lagi Kitang Naaalala” (I Always Remember You). Among his other compositions are “Hanggang Langit” (Up to the Heavens), 1980; “Isang Salmo” (One Psalm), 1987; “Sing to the Lord a New Song,” 1993, revised 2009; “Lord Is My Shepherd,” 1995; “Non Nobis Domine,” 2001; “God, You Spin the Whirling Planets,” 2003; “We Are His People” and “Psalm 131: My Heart is not Proud, O Lord,” 2005; “In That Language of Languages,” 2008; and “Palm,” 2009.

Navarro has also written articles and reviews on Philippine choral music, church music, and conducting. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgoupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

NAVARRO, PEDRO (Pedro B. Navarro) aka Pedro N. Bravo. b. Tagudin, Ilocus Sur 17 Sep 1879 d. Malabon, Rizal 9 Mar 1951. Conductor, composer. He came from humble beginnings as the only child of Pedro Bravo, a fisherman, and his wife, Bartola Navarro. In 1904, he married Timotea Garcia. His daughters Irene, Severena, and Leonor were also musicians. He is the grandfather of Mary Talusan, a Filipino-American ethnomusicologist who teaches at Loyola Marymount University in California.

During his lifetime, Pedro Navarro was a respected band director and composer. After losing his father to the sea before Pedro reached the age of nine, Pedro was brought to the local convent where he studied violin and flute. Fr Mariano Ortiz, a Spanish priest, recognized his musical talent and sent him to the San Agustin Convent in Manila. From age 11 until he was a young man, he sang in the choir, played piccolo and violin, and studied solfeggio and harmony with the famous composer and teacher Marcelo Adonay, then maestro di capella (choirmaster) of San Agustin Church in Intramuros.

At the end of the Spanish-American war in 1898, Pedro left the convent and joined several American military bands in Manila, including the 6th US Artillery Band. Loving heard Navarro and convinced him to join the newly founded Philippine Constabulary Band in 1902. Around this time, he changed his last name from Bravo to Navarro, his mother’s maiden name. In 1904, Navarro traveled with the PC Band to the United States to participate in the Philippine Exhibit of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in St Louis, Missouri, known as the St Louis World’s Fair. It was during this world’s fair that the PC Band became known to international music lovers, was recognized by John Philip Sousa, and acknowledged as among the best bands in the world. A legend still told today is that during the PC Band’s performance of the William Tell Overture the lights suddenly went out, but the amazing musicians kept playing in the dark.

In 1909, Navarro served as Chief Musician when the PC Band returned to the United States at the invitation of President-elect Taft to march in his inaugural parade. They were celebrated by American music lovers in Washington DC, New York, Boston, Atlantic City, New Jersey, Chicago, Cincinnati, Madison, Wisconsin, and Denver. They participated in the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific International Exposition and was praised by Pres William Howard Taft wherever they went. In 1915, Navarro proved himself an effective leader when Loving became ill and actually took charge of the PC Band at the Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco for 10 months, during which they were presented with a bronze medal. Shortly after returning to Manila, Loving retired as major, and during his farewell concert in Feb 1916 handed the baton to Navarro in the middle of the piece “Auld Lang Syne.” Navarro was active as the conductor for a period of 18 months from 1916 to 1918, performing each week at the Luneta and other venues. In addition to the standard Euro-American concert band repertoire, Navarro often included his own compositions during PC Band concerts. He left his position as conductor suddenly for active duty in Baguio where he served from 1918 to 1924. He retired from Philippine Constabulary after his tour was finished.

After retiring from the PC, Navarro continued his musical activities. In 1925, he established the all-girls Banda Ligaya in Malabon that included his daughters Irene, Severina, and Leonor. In 1926, Navarro became director of National University (NU) Band and often combined both boys and girls band together for performances. He was criticized for including girls in his bands because bands up until then had been exclusively male. In 1928, the all-girls Banda Ligaya won at the Manila Carnival. In 1932, it won the “All-star” Band Championship, while the National University all-boys won the Band Music Contest. Navarro continued to conduct the NU Band until 1940, while directing other bands in Malabon.

Navarro died at age 72, surrounded by band musicians who were rehearsing then, still holding their instruments. A Requiem Mass was held for him at the San Bartolome Parochial Church in Malabon on Tuesday, 13 Mar. He was buried at the Philippine Army plot in the Cementerio del Norte in Manila. Few of Navarro’s compositions survived after he died, but recent research uncovered dozens of band pieces including numerous marches and pieces featuring instrumental solos. The titles of the compositions—such as “Los Brutos y Borregos” (Brutes and Sheeps), paso doble; “Bonnet,” march; “Acedera,” solo for trombone; “Miss Rubio,” for solo saxophone; and “Id Est,” for solo cornet—reveal the historical eras that Navarro belonged to in his lifetime, including the Japanese regime. On 18 Jul 2014, the UP Symphonic Band featured several of Navarro’s works, which have not been heard for half a century. He was honored by his hometown of Tagudin, Ilocos Sur in Dec 2014. Written byMary Talusan

NAVARRO, RAUL (Raul Casantusan Navarro) b. Muntinlupa 10 Sep 1969. Author, choral conductor, countertenor, pianist, educator. He is the son of Rolando Navarro and Paz Casantusan of Muntinlupa City. He finished his elementary and secondary education at the Muntinlupa Elementary School and Muntinlupa National High School. He earned his first bachelor’s degree in music education under a full scholarship from Santa Isabel College in 1990, graduating cum laude. In 1991, he began his second bachelor of music degree, major in choral conducting, at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, as a full scholar of the Francisco Buencamino Music Foundation Scholarship from 1991 to 1995. He graduated magna cum laude in 1996. He then pursued his master of music degree, major in choral conducting, in UP College of Music, graduating in 1999. In 2004, he finished his doctor of philosophy in Philippine Studies, major in sociology and minor in history, from the College of Arts and Letters of UP.

Navarro has published two books with the Ateneo de Manila University Press. His first book, Kolonyal na Patakaran at ang Nagbabagong Kamalayang Filipino: Musika sa Publikong Paaralan sa Pilipinas, 1898-1935 (Colonial Policy and the New Filipino Consciousness: Music in the Public School in the Philippines, 1898-1935), won the National Book Award (History Category) from the National Book Development Board and the Manila Critics Circle in 2008, the UP Gawad sa Natatanging Saliksik sa Filipino (Original Research Category) in 2008, and a UP Diliman Centennial Professorial Chair in June 2008-09. His second book, Musika at Bagong Lipunan: Pagbuo ng Lipunang Filipino, 1972-1986 (Music and New Society: Constructing Philippine Society, 1972-1986), was published in 2014. Navarro has presented papers in various local and international conferences like the First Philippine Art Studies Conference at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2002; Sangandaan 2003, An International Conference on Arts and Media in Philippine-American Relations, 1899-2002 at UP Diliman in 2003; New Directions in Art Studies at the National Museum in 2010; the 9th International Conference on Philippine Studies at the Michigan State University in 2012; and Philippine Studies in a Changing National and Global Landscape: A Roundtable Discussion at the UP Asian Center in 2013.

Aside from his scholarly works, Navarro has performed extensively as a choral conductor, singer, and pianist. He has won gold and bronze awards at the 2008 Busan Choral Festival in South Korea with the UP Vocal Ensemble–Santa Isabel College Singers. His Vox Angeli Children’s Choir was awarded the Champion of the Children’s Choir Category at the 2008 Hong Kong International Youth and Children’s Choir Festival. In the 1994 World Tour of the UP Concert Chorus, he was appointed assistant conductor and pianist by Reynaldo T. Paguio. He has also sang countertenor as the solo alto part of Vivaldi’s Gloria, 1994, and Handel’s Messiah, 1995, with the UP Orchestra under Reynaldo Paguio.

Navarro chaired the Conducting and Choral Ensemble Department of the UP College of Music, 2005-11. He is currently the graduate coordinator for both Master of Music and Doctor of Philosophy in Music programs of the UP College of Music. Written byArwin Q. Tan

NIEVERA, BERT (Robert Jose de la Cruz Nievera) b. Baguio City 17 Oct 1936. d. Las Vegas, Nevada, USA 27 Mar 2018. Singer. He was the son of Jose Nievera and Lunas de la Cruz. His first wife was Conchita Razon with whom he hada son, Martin, a popular singer and TV host, and two daughters. From his second wife Carolina Hernandez, he hada son and two adopted children. He studied at the University of the Philippines Diliman where he took foreign service from 1953 to 1955. He transferred to St Louis College in Baguio where he took business courses from 1955 to 1957.

Nievera had his first singing job in 1958 when he sang at the Airmen’s Club of Camp John Hay in Baguio. In the same year, he joined Student Canteen’s “Search for Johnny Mathis of the Philippines,” and won the title. In the 1960s, he made rounds as featured performer in various clubs in the Philippines. He left the country in 1966 and joined the group Society of Seven as lead singer. The group performed in Las Vegas, Reno, Lake Tahoe, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Hawaii in the United States until 1976.

In 1989, Nievera returned to the Philippines and did major concerts, lounge acts, small concerts, and TV shows and guestings. He performed in the Las Piñas Bamboo Organ International Festival held at the Las Piñas Church in 1991. In the same year, he sang at the Manila Peninsula lobby with the ManilaChamber Orchestra. In 1992, he co-hosted the short-lived TV musical program Chairman of the Board with Eddie Mercado and Bobby Ledesma. As featured performer in the 1990 ASEAN Year, he gave four shows in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia and five shows in Singapore. In 1990 he performed in the highly successful Timeless concert with the PhilippinePhilharmonicOrchestra(PPO) at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines(CCP) Tanghalang NicanorS.Abelardo. The show had a repeat in 1991 (Timeless II) and 1992 (Timeless III) held in the same venue, and in Mar and Oct 1993 (Best of the Timeless) at the Philippine International Convention Center Reception Hall, all of which were staged to full-capacity audiences. Then in 1999, he performed with pianist Raul Sunico in a concert titled Jazz Swings in Manila.

He recorded three albums: Nievera released in Hollywood by Silver Sword Production in 1976; Sumasainyo, 100">Bert Nievera (Yours, Bert Nievera), an all-Tagalog album released by Vicor Records under the Blackgold label in 1978; and Nievera Remembers released by Wea (now Universal) Records in 1985. Nievera’s album Salamat sa Pag-Ibig (Thank You for the Love) was released by Quantum Music Corporation and was produced by Danny Tan for The Balladeer Inc in 1996.

Among his hit songs are “Langit sa Lupa” (Heaven on Earth), “Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko” (My Neighbor, My Love), “Bakit Ako Mahihiya?” (Why Should I be Ashamed?), “Awit” (Song), “Paalam” (Farewell), “Kapalaran” (Fate), “O Pag-Ibig” (Oh Love), “A Christmas Lullaby,” “Kung Mayroong Pangarap” (If There is a Dream), “Timeless,” “Gabi Na… Magandang Umaga” (It’s Already Dark, Good Morning), “Hindi Sapat ang Lahat” (All is Not Enough), “Minsan Lamang” (Just Once), “Kasiping Ka” (In Your Arms), “Ang Tangi Kong Mahal” (My Only Love), “If You Are But a Dream,” and “Ikaw Lagi ang Tapat” (You are Always Faithful). Written byElmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

NIEVERA, MARTIN (Martin Ramon Razon Nievera) b. Manila 5 Feb 1962. Singer. He is the son of singer 100">Bert Nievera and Conchita Razon. He has two sons from his former wife Pops Fernandez and another from Katrina Ojeda. He obtained an associate in arts degree from the Diablo Valley College in California, USA.

Nievera started his pop singing career in 1982 when he was featured in a series of launching shows at the Tavern on the Square. In the same year, he recorded his first album Martin… Take One for Vicor Records. The album turned gold and platinum in five months. At that time he was also part of the musical variety show Penthouse Live! which he co-hosted with Pops Fernandez and Nanette Inventor until 1987.

In 1983, he participated in the sixth Metro Manila Popular Music Festival as interpreter of Alvina Sy’s “Pain.” The song, which won first place in the competition, became one of Nievera’s popular hits. He held his first major concert Wanted: Martin Live! in the same year at the Folk Arts Theater with Fernandez and Inventor as guests. The said concert was one of Nievera’s most successful as it enjoyed repeat performances not only in Manila but also in Cebu and Baguio. He has since then given countless hit concerts and shows in hotels, music lounges, school gymnasia, and other major public venues like the ULTRA, Folk Arts Theater, Araneta Coliseum, and Music Museum. Most of his concerts have been toured in different Philippine provinces from Ilocos to Zamboanga. He has performed in the United States mainland, Canada, Guam, Hawaii, and the Middle East. Among his biggest concerts are Martin’s Rage and Martin On the Right Track, 1984; Twogether and Martin… Forever, 1985; Apat Dapat, Dapat Apat (Four and No Less), with Zsa Zsa Padilla, Nanette Inventor, and Gary Valenciano, 1986; Airborne I, II, and III, 1987; Martin Nievera’s Escape and The Awesome Escape, 1988; Martin Madness at the Music Museum and Out of Control Madness, 1989; Dream, with the members of the Manila Chamber Orchestra and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, 1990; Voices, with Regine Velasquez, 1991; King and Queen of Hearts, 1992 and 1993; Martin Nievera Live With The Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, 2000; Martin Nievera XXV, 2007; Hawaii’s Society of Seven, with Lani Misalucha, 2008; Missing You, with Pops Fernandez, 2009; As 1, with Gary Valenciano, 2009, which led to a series of concerts touring the Middle East, United States, and Canada, 2009-11; and Once In A Lifetime with Sharon Cuneta, 2012. He has also done movies like Always and Forever (The Movie), 1986; Maria Went to Town and Shoot that Ball, 1987; Stupid Cupid, 1988; and Magic to Love, 1989.

Nievera’s albums that have received gold and/or platinum awards include: Martin… Take One, 1982; The Best Gift, 1984; Martin, 1985; Miracle, 1987; A Martin Nievera Christmas, 1988; Dream,1989; A New Start, 1991; Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin, Be My Lady, and Roads, 1994; You Are My Song, 1996; Journeys, 1997; Forever, 1998; Forever Forever and Return to Forever, 1999; My Souvenirs, 2001; More Souvenirs, 2001; Chasing Time, 2002; Chasing Time Vol 2, 2003; Unforgettable, 2004; Best Wishes: A Wedding Love Song Collection, 2004; When Love Is Gone, 2005; Awit ng Puso (Song of the Heart), 2006; Milestones, 2007; Martin Nievera’s Greatest Hits, 2010; and 3D: Tatlong Dekada, 2013.

Some of his hit songs are “Be My Lady,” “Paradise,” “You’re on the Right Track,” “You are to Me,” “Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin” (You are Everything to Me), “Please Don’t Throw My Love Away,” “Each Day with You,” “How Can I,” “Miracle,” “No Way to Treat a Heart,” “Giliw” (Beloved), “Till the End,” “Say that You Love Me” (revival), “Come With Me,” “Hanggang Kailan (Till When),” “Promise of Love,” “Ikaw Lamang (You Alone),” “Pain,” “Ikaw” (You), “Because of You,” “We are the Reason,” “Now and Forever,” “Maybe This Time,” “Forever” (duet with Regine Velasquez), “You are My Song,” and “Kahit Isang Saglit (Even for Just a Moment).”

Nievera has been cited by the Aliw Awards Foundation as Most Promising Entertainer of the Year, 1982, and Entertainer of the Year, 1983. As host of the hit TV celebrity talk show M.A.D. (Martin After Dark) from 1988-98, he was cited by the Star Awards for Television as Best Male TV Host in 1988, 1989, and 1991. The show has also been cited by the Star Awards as Best Celebrity Talk Show in 1989 and 1991. He was also given the same award for Best Celebrity Talk Show Host from 1989 to 1991 and again in the years 1993, 1994, and 1996. He was also heralded by the Aliw Awards Foundation Hall of Fame as Entertainer of the Year and Lifetime Achievement Award recipient in 2006. He was recognized by the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Awards as the Male Concert Performer of the Year from 2008 to 2010. He also received the following recognition from Awit Awards: Best Performance by a Male Recording Artist for the songs “Never Say Goodbye,” 1995, “You Are My Song,” 1997, “Kahit Isang Saglit,” 2000, and “True Love,” 2003; Best Performance by a Duet, “Forever,” 1995, with Regine Velasquez; Best Ballad Recording and Best Movie Theme Song, “You Are My Song,” from the movie Wanted: Perfect Mother; Best Produced Record of the Year, “What’s On the Other Side,” 1998; Best Christmas Recording, “Can’t Stop Christmas,” 2002; People’s Choice Favorite Male Artist, 2006 and 2008; Best TV Theme Song, “Ikaw ang Pangarap,” 2009, from the ABS-CBN drama series Lobo (Wolf); Eggs AllHits.ph Most Downloaded Song, “Don’t Say Goodbye”; and Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino, 2006. Written byElmer L. Gatchalianupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

NONO, GRACE (Grace Sacote Nono) b. Butuan City 6 May 1965. Singer, author, cultural worker. She is the daughter of Igmedio Aromin Nono of Nueva Ecija and Ramona Ranoda Sacote of Camiguin. Grace Nono was raised in Agusan del Sur. She attended the Philippine High School for the Arts where she majored in theater arts. She received her bachelor of arts in humanities and master of arts in Philippine Studies from the University of the Philippines Diliman in 1986 and 2004, respectively. Nono also received training from the Asia-Pacific Cultural Center for UNESCO in Kyoto in 2009 and the Asian Institute of Management in Manila in 2003. She finished a doctoral degree in ethnomusicology at New York University’s Department of Music in 2014.

As an artist, Grace has specialized, since the late 1990s, in the contemporary performance of Philippine sung oral traditions taught to her by local elders, many of them babaylan (shamans). As a singer, she has been featured in local concerts in Butuan, Bunawan, Davao, Iloilo, Palawan, Mindoro, Bicol, Baguio, and Sagada, and at national and international events and venues like the Cultural Center of the Philippines, the House of World Cultures in Berlin, the Circulo de Bellas Artes in Madrid, in the Lincoln Center’s La Casita Festival in New York, the Asian American Arts Alliance’s Locating the Sacred Festival in New York, the Asia Society in New York and in Hong Kong, the National Museum of Singapore and the Singapore Arts Festival in Singapore, the Music Village Festival in London, the Gathering of Drummers in Prague, concerts in Paris and Monte Carlo, the World of Music, Arts and Dance (WOMAD) Festival in Yokohama, the World Exposition on Nature’s Wisdom in Nagoya, the Asian Fantasy Orchestra tours of New Delhi, Bombay, Tokyo, Nagoya, Osaka, Miyazaki, Bangkok, Vientiane, Yangon, Jakarta, Hanoi, and Ho Chi Minh, various performances in Huairou, Nanning, Shanghai, Penang, Kaohsiung, Seoul, Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Diego, and Chicago.

As a recording artist, Nono has so far released six award-winning solo albums: Tao Music, 1992 and 1993, Opo (Yes), 1995, Isang Buhay (One Life), 1997, Hulagpos (Breaking Free), 1998, Diwa (Spirit), 2002, and Dalit (Sacred Song), 2008. She has also contributed tracks to around 15 compilations. She also co-produced, together with Bob Aves, five recordings of Philippine oral/aural musical traditions: Maguindanao Kulintang, featuring Aga Mayo Butocan,1995; Pakaradia-an: Maranao Epic Chants and Instrumental Music, featuring Sindao Banisil, 1996; Marino: Hanunuo Mangyan Chanted Poetry and Instrumental Music, featuring Ulyaw Bat-ang, et al, 1998; Tudbulul Lunay Mogul: T’boli Hero of Lunay, the Place of Gongs and Music, featuring Mendung Sabal, 2002; Kahimunan: Cultural Music of the Manobo, Higaonon, Banwaon of Agusan del Sur, featuring Salvador Placido, et al, 2002.

As author, Nono has published two books, with accompanying recordings: The Shared Voice: Chanted and Spoken Narratives from the Philippines, 2008, and Song of the Babaylan: Living Voices, Medicines, Spiritualities of Philippine Ritualist-Oralist-Healers, 2013. She also contributed an essay, “Audible Travels: Oral/Aural Traditional Performances and the Global Dispersal of a Philippine Indigenous Religion” to the book Back from the Crocodile’s Belly: Philippine Babaylan Studies and the Struggle for Indigenous Memory, 2013.

As cultural worker, Nono founded in 1995 the Tao Foundation for Culture and Arts, a Philippine nongovernment organization engaged in grassroots cultural regeneration initiatives, for which she has received support from the Toyota Foundation, UNESCO, the Australia-Philippines Community Cooperation Program, the Advocates of Philippine Fair Trade, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, the Cultural Center of the Philippines, and local communities.
