Nono won over 40 awards, including the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) award, 1994; The Outstanding Women Award in the Nation’s Service (TOWNS) award, 2001; a National Book Award, 2009; the University of the Philippines Distinguished Alumni award, 2011; album of the year awards for Opo (Catholic Mass Media and Katha, 1996) and Diwa (Catholic Mass Media, 2002); best world music album awards for Opo (Katha, 1996), Anugan (Katha, 1998), and Isang Buhay (Katha, 1998); and the National Press Club Award, 2003. She also received a fellowship from the Asian Cultural Council in New York in 2008 and the Asia-Pacific Performance Exchange program in University of California Los Angeles in 2006. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

NOVO CONCERTANTE MANILA Novo Concertante Manila was founded by Arwin Q. Tan in 1998 as his recital choir in the bachelor of music choral conducting degree where he was awarded magna cum laude from the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. Years later, Novo Concertante was ranked 8th in the world ranking of choirs in the Interkultur Germany top 1000 choirs. From a humble beginning, the group is now a veteran of several international choral festivals and competitions.

The Novo Concertante was the Grand Prix Award winner in the 2003 A Voyage of Songs held in Genting Highlands, Malaysia. In 2009, Novo Concertante joined the 46th Internationaler Chorwettbewerb in Spittal, Austria where they were awarded the 1st Preis (Kunstlied category) and 2nd Preis (Volkslied category). In the same year, they won first prize in the polyphonic music category of the 55th Certamen International de Habaneras y Poliponia in Torrevieja, Spain. Again in Asia, in 2012, the group successfully bagged the grand prize in the 1st Xinghai Prize International Choral Festival, and the grand prize in the 1st Asia Cantate International Choral Festivalin Phuket, Thailand.

In recognition of its achievements in international competitions, the group was awarded thrice the Ani ng Dangal by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) in 2010, 2011, and 2013.

As the group’s conductor, Tan, who also teaches music history and is an artist at UP, and was given the Most Outstanding Conductor Award in the 2012 Asia Cantate International Choral Competition. Written byRaul Navarro

OBANDO MUSIKONG BUMBONG aka Banda Sta Clara Musikong Bumbong. Bamboo band ensemble from Obando, Bulacan. Instruments of the ensembles are bamboo replicas of European band instruments such as oboe, clarinet, horn (trompa), trumpet, trombone, saxophone, and sousaphone. Due to the material of the instruments, the sound of each instrument is very different from its original model. In fact, the instruments rely on the voice of the performers to produce the sounds. An instrument is open at both ends and has a hole on the side covered with a membrane that produces a buzzing sound when the player “hums,” rather than blows, into the mouthpiece of the instrument. The air pressure of the “hum” makes the membrane vibrate, varying the pitch and loudness. The shape of the instrument amplifies and projects the sound. The group also employs other instruments like the harmonica, cymbals, and snare and bass drums.

The origin of the Obando Musikong Bumbong can be traced back to the time of the Philippine Revolution against Spain (1896-98). Obando is in Bulacan, which was one of the first eight provinces in Luzon to revolt against Spanish rule. It was founded by Bonifacio Anastacio. In the 1950s, Obando Musikong Bumbong also came to be called the Santa Clara Musikong Bumbong after the name of one of the patron saints of the town, Santa Clara. The two other patron saints are San Pascual Baylon and the Virgin of Salambao. Santa Clara is believed to miraculously grant prayers, especially the wish of a childless couple for a long and much awaited offspring, following the fulfillment of the annual “fertility dance” held in the Obando town fiesta from 17-19 May. This is done in the churchyard where devotees and pilgrims from all walks of life converge.

The Santa Clara Musikong Bumbong performs the song “Santa Klarang Pinung-Pino” (Exquisite Saint Claire) during the procession that commences from and ends in the Obando Church. Devotees dance, swaying their hips and moving their hands and waist in unison. For variety, the ensemble also plays other types of music, as do the other regular marching bands, which also participate in the celebration.

Aside from their local religious devotional ritual function, the group has been invited to perform in town fiestas in other provinces like Pampanga, Nueva Ecija, and Rizal. The group was selected to participate in the 5th Philippine Folk Festival held at the Folk Arts Theater on from 4 to 11 July 1982 and in the Marian Congress and the Holy Trinity Special Project held at the Quirino Grandstand on 29 Jan 2000. In 1998, the Santa Clara Musikong Bumbong was chosen to represent the Philippines in the 32nd Smithsonian Folklife Festival, an international exposition of living cultural heritage that features community-based cultural groups held in Washington, DC.

Membership in Santa Clara Musikong Bumbong consists of around 25 males, mostly family members, relatives, and their neighbors. Most of the members are young, with the following age distribution: a few between 7 to 12 years old, seven to nine members who are adults, and three to four senior citizens. Organizationally, the ensemble has a president who takes charge and gives counsel to the group and a trainer who takes charge of the rehearsals and conducts and gives cues during performances. Maximo C. Santiago or “Ka Emong,” 82 years old in 2014, became the sixth president of the ensemble during the 1950s. He still plays the harmonica and saxophone. Rodrigo C. Anastacio is the bass drum player, trainer, instrument maker, and a third genaration descendant of the founder, Bonifacio Anastacio. Antonio A. Anastacio, son of Bonifacio, was the former trainer and conductor of the group. The following are the other former leaders of the group: Genaro Ramos, Bianong Cabigao, Jose S. Roxas Sr, Mariano Remigio, and Roman Sta Ana. Written byPacita Narzo

OCAMPO, LOUIE (Jose Luis Jocson Ocampo) b. Manila 21 Jun 1960. Composer, arranger, keyboard player, musical director, producer. His parents are Benigno Ocampo and Pacita Jocson. He is married to Maria Josephine Marquez with whom he has three children. As a child, he listened to his father’s Henry Mancini albums. He also became a fan of the piano duet Ferrante and Teicher and jazz fusion artists like Chick Correa. At the age of 13, he studied the piano and electric organ under Carmencita Arambulo. While in high school at De La Salle, he played the keyboard and composed music for jazz fusion bands and pop groups. In 1977, he gained recognition as keyboard soloist by winning first prize in the International Electone Festival in Japan. From 1977 to 1979, he studied music at the University of the Philippines and St Paul College, then went to the United States for further studies in composition. In 1983, he completed studies in film scoring at the Berklee College of Music in Boston, where he studied under John Williams, Gary Burton, and Jerry Goldsmith. In the Philippines, he pioneered the use of computers and synthesizers for composing, arranging, and recording.

Ocampo has produced long-playing albums for local and international artists. He has worked as musical director for many pop stars in the country. Since 1984, he has toured extensively with Filipino singers throughout Japan, Southeast Asia, Australia, and the United States. In 1991, he directed the successful Carnegie Hall concert of Regine Velasquez.

He has published and recorded over 50 compositions, including such hits as “Closer You and I,” “You Are My Song” (co-written with Martin Nievera), “Yakapin Mo Ako” (Embrace Me), “Points of View,” “Don’t Say Goodbye,” “Ewan” (I Don’t Know), “Say That You Love Me,” “Tell Me,” and “Babalik Ka Rin”(You Will Return) with lyrics by Chot Ulep and sung by Gary Valenciano. He has composed music for four Filipino films, including the adaptation of his hit song “Si Aida, Si Lorna, o Si Fe” (Aida, Lorna or Fe) in the movie of the same title, 1989; Lagarista, 2000; Felix Manalo for the song “Ang Sugo ng Diyos sa Mga Huling Araw” (The Chosen One for The End of Days), 2015; and two European films. He composed and arranged more than 100 jingles for TV and radio commercials. He also wrote the GMA “Kapuso Jingle,” 2002, and the 25th anniversary jingle of Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!), 2004. He also composed the theme song of the pioneering local children’s show Batibot (Small But Strong), 1984, with lyrics by Rene O. Villanueva, as well as the music for a number of songs used in the program.

In 1999, he produced his debut album titled Louie O in which his compositions were recorded via synthesizer. The instrumental repertoire in the album include “Foster In Mind,” “Coming Home,” “Through the Years,” “Farewell to a Princess,” “My Funny Girl,” “Coming Into the Light,” “Dalagang Filipina” (Filipino Maiden), “Josephine,” “Recuerdos” (Memories), “Patricia’s Lullaby,” and “The Other Side of the Road.”

In 1977, Ocampo bagged the Best Electronic Organist title in the Southeast Asia Electone Concourse held at Jakarta, Indonesia playing his own composition titled “Moods of Tina.” He received second prize in the 1979 Metro Manila PopularMusic Festival for the song “Ewan” in collaboration with Rowena Arrieta; the 1983 Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Award for Best Theme Song for his composition “Hindi Laro ang Ibigin Ka” (It’s Not a Game to Love You); the Aliw Award for Best Musical Director in 1985 and 1987; the Song of the Year Award for “Ikaw Lang ang Mamahalin” (I Will Love Only You) in the 1988 CatholicMassMediaAwards; the Song of the Year nomination for “Say that You Love Me” in the Hoku Awards in Hawaii; and Award of Excellence for Best TV Jingle, 12th Advertising Congress in 1991. Awit Awards also gave him the following: Best Produced Record of the Year for the song “Closer You and I,” 1992; Best Ballad Recording for the song “So Many Questions,” 1994; Best Christmas Recording for “Christmas Past,” 1995; Best Instrumental Performance for “Forever” in 1995 and again in 2001 for “Patricia’s Lullaby”; Best Ballad Recording and Best Movie Theme Song for “You Are My Song,” 1997; Best Produced Record of the Year for “What’s On the Other Side,” 1998; Album of the Year for Interactive, 1999; Best Traditional Recording for the song “Dalagang Filipina,” 2000; Best Musical Arrangement and Best Vocal Arrangement for the song “Tell Me,” 2004; Best Ballad Recording for “It’s Over Now,” 2008; and Digital Award for the song “Don’t Say Goodbye,” 2014. Written byRaj Mansukhaniupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

OPERA GUILD OF THE PHILIPPINES The OperaGuildofthePhilippines was formally organized on 22 Dec 1969. Among the founding members were DalisayAldaba who conceived the idea, Chito Madrigal Vasquez, Eloisa F. Revilla, Letty Montelibano, Lee Dilworth Dibble, and Josephine Nicholoff. The guild was set up as a private nonstock corporation to promote and stimulate interest and broaden the base of support for opera training of the highest professional standards; to make scholarships available to young Filipino artists in need of financial assistance; to undertake a continuing program of opera presentations; and to strive for professionalism in all aspects of opera, so that Filipino opera artists may meet international standards necessary to project a Philippine cultural image abroad. At present, the Guild is chaired by Imelda Cojuangco.

Previous chairpersons include Chito Madrigal Vasquez, Eugenia Puyat, and Glecy Tantoco. In 1969 the Guild initially began to stage its performances in the open-air theater of the Dulaang Raha Sulayman in FortSantiago in a program billed as Opera Under the Stars with excerpts from Mozart’s The Impressario, Purcell’s Dido and Aeneas, Puccini’s La Boheme, Strauss’s Faust, among others. The Guild later transferred to the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines where it staged the full-scale performances of Leoncavallo’s I Pagliacci and Pergolesi’s La Serva Pedrona in 1970, and later, Mozart’s The Impressario, Mascagni’s Cavalleria Rusticana, Smetana’s The Bartered Bride, Puccini’s Madame Butterfly and Tosca, and Mozart’s The Marriage of Figaro.

The guild’s last three operas were successfully produced in cooperation with the CCP. Madame Butterfly featured Wilma Vernocchi of La Scala de Milan and Italian tenor Franco Corici. Tosca had a Filipino choir singing with the complete cast of the San Francisco Opera Company led by world-class tenor Placido Domingo and Eva Marton. It became the biggest production and largest opera season of the Guild. Mozart’s comic opera featured an all-Filipino cast. In 1992 the Guild produced yet another successful staging of Rigoletto which also featured an international cast. Written byLucresia R. Kasilag and Edgardo B. Maranan

OPPUS-YÑIGUEZ, SALVACION (Salvacion Aguilar Oppus-Yniguez) b. Maasin, Southern Leyte 1 May 1918 d. 24 Sep 2004. Singer, teacher. From childhood, Oppus-Yñiguez was steeped in both politics and music. The daughter of Tomas Oppus, a congressman, and Felicidad Aguilar, she married Leyte politician Nicanor Yñiguez. Oppus-Yñiguez was the governor of southern Leyte from 1967 to 1986. Well before her own foray into politics, however, she trained to teach and perform music. After graduating from La Consolacion, she studied voice at the Academy of Musical Arts, then earned a teacher’s diploma in piano from the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music in 1938 and graduated from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music with a bachelor’s degree in voice and piano in 1940.

Oppus-Yñiguez, a soprano, taught at the UP Conservatory of Music, 1936-47; UST Conservatory of Music, 1947-67; Santa Isabel College, 1954-67; and St Scholastica’s College, 1955-65. After retiring from politics, she taught at Santa Isabel since 1989 and at UST since 1990 until shortly before her demise in 2004.

She starred in operas and other dramatic works, such as Leoncavallo’s I Pagliacci with the La Scala tenor Giuseppe Savio, Strauss’s Die Fliedermaus, Bach’s Passion According to St Matthew, Handel’s Acis and Galatea, and Debussy’s L’Enfant Prodi. She was the first artist to hold a formal recital in Cagayan de Oro City as part of an outreach tour in 1953. She joined the First Philippine Cultural Mission to Southeast Asia in 1957.

Oppus-Yñiguez was named Filipino Musician of the Year by the UP in 1956 and Distinguished UP Alumna in 1958. She received a plaque of distinction from the Battig Music Circle in 1960. A song cycle for high voice and piano titled Baybayon (Seashore) was composed by Noni Espina and dedicated to Yñiguez in 1967. It was eventually published by Capella Music Inc in 1969. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgoupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo
Ortiz, Andres (See THEATE R volume.)
Padilla, Zsa Zsa (See FILM volume.)

PAGUIO, REY T. (Reynaldo Tolentino Paguio) b. Balanga, Bataan 29 Nov 1935 d. 14 Oct 1999. Conductor, composer, educator. His parents are Carlos Paguio and Lourdes Tolentino. He composed his first piano piece at the age of seven. When he was 11, he enrolled in the University of the Philippines (UP) Integrated School and was also a full-time student at the UP Conservatory of Music, having won a two-year scholarship in piano from De la Rama Lines. He also got a full scholarship at UP by winning the Ernestina Crisologo-Jose piano competition. He studied further in the United States, finishing a master’s degree in music, major in choral conducting, at the Southern Methodist University in Dallas, Texas in 1965, and another master’s degree, major in music education, in 1966.

He was in the Dean Honor’s List and was awarded the Most Outstanding Graduate Student of the Year, the Nita and Jake Aiken Music Award, and the Delta Lambda Sigma Award, as well as a member of the Phi Kappa Alpha Music Honor Society. He has served as an artist-in-residence in UP and was a full professor in conducting, music education, and piano. He was also the college secretary as well as the chair of two departments in the UP College of Music: Music Education and Conducting and Choral Ensembles. In 1997, he became the dean of the UP College of Music.

In 1962, Paguio organized the UP Concert Chorus, composed of students from different UP colleges. He brought the group up to international standards through frequent participation in international chorus festivals and competitions where they won top prizes. He was the longest-running conductor of the UP Concert Chorus, 1969-99, and as conductor, he premiered choral works in the Philippines, like Bernstein’s Mass, 1972. He also produced and composed the music of two modern sarsuwela, Sumpang Mahal (Beloved Promise), 1977, and Ms. Philippines, 1980. Another major work is Mayo, Bisperas ng Liwanag (May, Eve of Light), an opera based on Nick Joaquin’s short story May Day Eve. He had served as consultant for choir groups all over the country and appeared on stage and television as solo piano artist, accompanist, conductor, and musical commentator. In 1989, he was the TV host in its initial year of A Little Night of Music based on his concept and aired on GMA 7. He was a board member of the Music Council of the Philippines and the Conductors League of the Philippines.

In 1982, Paguio received the UP Professorial Award as the Most Outstanding Music Alumnus of the Year. In 1991, he was the recipient of the Llames Professorial Chair in Music. Written byJeanna B. Malabuyoc and Felizidad Z. Reyesupdated by Connie Ladrido

PAJARO, ELISEO M. (Eliseo Morales Pajaro) b. Badoc, Ilocos Norte 21 Mar 1915. d. Houston, Texas 6 Oct 1984. Composer, conductor, teacher. Born to high school principal Marcelo Pajaro, a sarsuwela performer, and Cecilia Morales, an amateur singer, he was exposed to music through his father. He was married to Joaquina Tobias. While in third grade, he started music lessons with a retired member of the Philippine Constabulary Band. He played with the jazz band of Marcial Wasan when he was nine and with the Modernista Band when he was a student at the Northern Luzon Normal School in Laoag. In 1947, Pajaro obtained his music diploma from the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, where FranciscoSantiago encouraged him to go into composition. Through scholarships, he was able to enroll at Westminster Choir College in Princeton, New Jersey and the Eastman School of Music at the University of Rochester, New York. He received his master’s degree in music in 1951 and his doctoral degree in composition in 1953.

When he returned to the Philippines, Pajaro taught at the UP, becoming full professor in 1969. He also lectured at Santa Isabel College, National Teachers’ College, and Philippine Women’s University. He was acting director of the UP Conservatory of Music, 1967-68, and acting dean, 1968-69, when it became the UP College of Music. He founded the Philippine Music Educators Group in 1955 (later known as the PhilippineSocietyforMusicEducation) and the League ofFilipinoComposers in 1955.

Between 1951 and 1974, he composed such musical works as Mir-i-nisa, a full-length ballet, 1969; the orchestral works The Cry of Balintawak, 1947, LifeofLam-ang, 1951, and Ode to Academic Freedom, 1958; and a series of Song Cycles, 1957-58. His works combine Filipino folk themes with 20th-century compositional techniques. As music educator, he initiated training programs to raise the competence of music teachers. He authored two volumes, Himig Pilipino (Filipino Airs) and Himig Pilipino ng Bagong Lipunan (Filipino Airs of the New Society) for use in public schools. He introduced modern music techniques to Filipino students and pioneered in the teaching of modern music techniques.

Pajaro received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award for music in 1964 and 1970. In 1966, he received the Presidential Award of Merit for BinhingKalayaan (Seeds of Freedom), the first Filipino modern opera. He also received the UP Alumni Award in 1971 and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1974. He is listed in the Who’s Who in Music, 1974; Who’s Who of Intellectuals, 1976; and Who’s Who in the World, 1977. Written byFelizidad Z. Reyes and Maria Patricia Brillantes

PANGKAT KAWAYAN aka Singing Bamboos. The group was founded on 6 Sep 1966 at the Aurora A. Quezon Elementary School in Quezon City by Victor Toledo. It is a youth orchestra playing music on bamboo instruments. The original group, the first Pangkat Kawayan Company composed of 50 elementary school children, lasted for 13 years. In 1973, the second Pangkat Kawayan Company was organized, followed by the third in 1978, and the fourth in 1983. Each formation was retired as soon as 50 percent of the members reached the age of 24. At present, the group is composed of students in elementary, secondary, and college levels from Quezon City and Manila.

The first musical pieces of Pangkat Kawayan consisted of Filipino folk melodies. It has developed a repertoire of traditional music, light classics, modern pieces, and popular music both Filipino and foreign. The group’s more than 100 instruments consist of various types of bamboo: the bumbong, a musical bamboo tube; talungating or bamboo marimba; tipangklung, a set of angklung (bamboo shakers) arranged as a horizontal keyboard, also known as “bamboo piano”; bamboo flute tulali; a bamboo clapper bungkaka; a bamboo knocker kalatok; xylophones gabbang; rattles alugtug; pipe diwdiwas; and Philippine angklung. Completing the orchestra are supplementary instruments such as drums, cymbals, gongs, triangles, and tambourines. Toledo designed the instruments, and he continues to manufacture new ones from bamboo and other materials.

Pangkat Kawayan has performed in many musical programs and entertained at national and international conferences. Its first performance abroad was at the World Expo ‘70 in Osaka, Japan. This was followed by performances in other world expositions and in international festivals. It played for “Balikbayan” performance tours in Hawaii and the West Coast in 1973, and in the United States mainland and Canada in 1974. In 1975, it was sent on official missions to Australia and Spain, and in 1978 to the People’s Republic of China. It also performed in the United States in 1982 and 1983.

The ensemble is led by Laura Gorospe, executive director; Elena Carlos, managing director; and Victor Toledo, musical director and conductor. It received the 2014 Manuel L. Quezon Gawad Parangal for the group’s vigorous promotion of bamboo music. Written byMilagros Carununganupdated by Josephine Baradas

PAREDES, JIM (Jaime Ramon Misa Paredes) b. Manila 31 Aug 1951. Composer, singer, photographer, columnist. Born to Jesus Paredes Jr and Ester Misa, he studied at the Ateneo de Manila from grade school to college. He graduated with a bachelor’s degree in communication arts. He is married to Lydia Mabanta, with whom he has three children. Writer Paulynn Paredes-Sicam is a sister.

Since 1973, Paredes has been a part of the ApoHikingSociety, one of the foremost exponents of OPM or Original Pilipino Music which exerted influence in the Philippine music scene in the 1970s and 1980s and whose popularity continues to this day. From 1975 to 1979, he was artist and repertoire director for Jem Recording Company. He was involved in two award-winning television shows—as scriptwriter of Ryan Ryan Musikahan (Music with Ryan) and as co-host of Tatak Pilipino (Filipino Brand). He co-hosted a popular noontime musical variety show on ABS-CBN 2 with DannyJavier and Boboy Garrovillo titled Sa Linggo nApo Sila (Apo on Sundays), 1990-95, which later became ‘Sang Linggo nApo Sila (Apo for an Entire Week), 1995-98, when their show was aired everyday of the week. He also became the headmaster of Pinoy Dream Academy, 2006, a reality-TV singing competition on ABS-CBN.

Paredes writes for his weekly column “Humming in My Universe” in The Philippines Star, since 2007, and also in “Writing on Air” in his website. He has also published books titled Humming in My Universe–Random Takes on Everything, 1999; Between Blinks; Writing on Water; and As Is Where Is, 2007.

Among Paredes’s noted compositions are “Batang-bata Ka Pa” (You’re Still Much Too Young), “HandogngPilipinosaMundo” (Filipinos’ Gift to the World), “Mahirap Magmahal ng Syota ng Iba” (It’s Difficult to Love Another Man’s Sweetheart), “Sasaya ang Pilipinas” (The Philippines Will be Happy), “Nakapagtataka” (Surprising), “When I Met You,” “Tuyo Na’ng Damdamin” (The Feeling is Gone), and “Panalangin” (Prayer). He has also composed commercial jingles and produced records for artists like HajjiAlejandro, RyanCayabyab, Eddie Munji III, Janet Basco, and CelesteLegaspi.

Paredes has received CatholicMassMediaAwards for his compositions “American Junk,” “Di Ka Nag-iisa” (You’re Not Alone), “Handog ng Pilipino sa Mundo,” and “Tuloy ang Ikot ng Mundo” (And the World Keeps On Turning). He takes an active part in the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit or OPM, of which he was president in 1989 and board member in 1986-90, and in the Green Earth Movement of which he is founder and president. The songs of Apo inspired the movie I Do Bidoo Bidoo, 2012, a musical romantic comedy topbilled by Ogie Alcasid, Eugene Domingo, Zsa Zsa Padilla, Sam Concepcion, Tippy Dos Santos, and Gary Valenciano, written and directed by Chris Martinez. Written byRosalinda Galangupdated by James C. Diaz

PAROKYA NI EDGAR (PNE) Formed in 1993, this Pinoy rock group is known for originally penned novelty rock songs and satirical covers of popular foreign hits. Beginning as a garage band named Comic Relief, it was composed of the following founding members: vocalists Chito Miranda, Vinci Montaner, and Jeric Estaco, with guitarists Gab Chee Kee and Mikko Yap, then high school students of the Ateneo de Manila University. At an earlier period, they opened for a concert by the Eraserheads at the Ateneo school fair. Later, they recruited Buwi Meneses (bass) and Dindi Moreno (drums), and renamed themselves Parokya ni Edgar. Yap, who is credited for coining the band’s name, left after high school and was replaced by Darius Semaña (lead guitar).

In one of their appearances at the underground rock venue Club Dredd, they impressed Universal Records’ managing director, Bella Dy Tan, who signed them immediately to the label. Their first album Khangkhungkherrnitz, 1996, sold 120,000 copies and was conferred triple platinum record status by the Philippine Association of the Recording Industry. Their succeeding albums were Buruguduystunstugudunstuy, 1997, which also achieved triple platinum record sales; Jingle Balls Silent Night Holy Cow, 1998, which attained gold record status; and Gulong Itlog Gulong (Roll, Egg, Roll), 1999, once again achieving triple platinum record status, featured a deviation from their expected novelty mold with the rock ballad, “Halaga” (Value).

PNE’s tongue-twisting album titles have created legendary consternation among fans and record store sales personnel. The band’s prodigious output in the succeeding years, Edgar Edgar Musikahan (Edgar, Edgar Music Making), 2002; Bigotilyo (Mr. Moustache), 2003; Inuman Sessions (Drinking Sessions) Vol.1, 2004; Halina sa Parokya (Come to the Parokya), 2005; Solid, 2007, and Middle Aged Juvenile Novelty Pop Rockers, 2010, and Inuman Sessions Vol. 2, 2012 brought Parokya ni Edgar an envied commercial longevity. In Oct 2012, founding member Vinci Montaner left the band after a lucrative 20-year stint to devote his time to a school for special children. The band itself had taken time out for advocacy, such as the “Free Mali” (the solitary elephant in the Manila Zoo) animal rights campaign initiated by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) in 2013. Montaner briefly reunited with the band in 2013 for a one-off appearance by Parokya to launch their greatest hits and 20th anniversary album Bente (Twenty). PNE was awarded with the MYX Magna Award in 2014. The band’s most recent concert tour was in 2015 when they performed in key cities in the United States. Written byJuan Bautista H. Alegre

PASAKNUNGAN PHILIPPINES A nonstock, nonprofit association, Pasaknungan Philippines was organized in 1964 by violinist Vicente Sales to encourage and promote Filipino cultural traditions and to create a pool of artistic talents and leaders in the country especially in violin. One of the training groups of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines(CCP), it teaches children from 6 to 19 years old who come from low-income families, and who can sing but have no prior knowledge of violin. Its weekly sessions at Nayong Pilipino’s Batangas House follow a three-level curriculum that includes rudiments, solfeggio, violin ensemble, and string orchestra performance. The group was originally composed of 25 children of Government Social Insurance System (GSIS) employees whom Sales taught for free on weekends. Its membership at one time grew to about 300-450 children but is now limited to 150. Its past members make up 35 percent of professional string players in Philippine symphonic orchestras.

The group performed at the CCP twice a year, as well as in two television programs namely, Paco Park Presents and Concert at the Park. Initially funded by parents of its students through minimal monthly contributions, Pasaknungan since 1981 has been jointly supported by the Philippine National Oil Corporation and the CCP. Due to the vast number of young aspiring musicians, the association had to seek the assistance of its very own musicians who were more advanced to guide the younger ones in their music learning. Some of these were Rebecca Alejaga and Jorge Joy Sababan who eventually became members of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. Also, violinist Dionesia “Donnie” Fernandez was discovered in the group, sent as a scholar to Juilliard School of Music in New York until she finished her postgraduate education. Fernandez eventually occupied the assistant concertmaster position of the White House Orchestra in Washington, DC. Written byEdna Marcil M. Martinezupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

PATATAG Founded in 1984, it was named after pateteg, a northern Luzon bamboo percussion instrument played singly or in a group, and was originally made up of six singers. It was born of the protest movement against the Marcos dictatorship, aiming to compose and popularize protest music. Its membership has ranged from 12 to 20, drawn from different fields of endeavor. Through its music workshops in various regions of the country, Patatag has helped in the formation of protest chorales like Balitaw in Cebu, Salidumay in the Cordilleras, and Kalantog in Laguna.

Patatag gave its debut performance on 6 Mar 1984 to welcome the Lakbayan protest marchers who converged at the University of the Philippines (UP) Sunken Garden on the eve of a massive rally at Liwasang Bonifacio. It rendered songs like “Awit ng Tagumpay” (Song of Victory) and “Dapat Bawiin” (We Must Recover), Filipino adaptations from the works of Chilean composer-poet Victor Jara. Patatag held its first concert, Alay sa Magbubukid (Homage to the Farmer), in Oct 1984 at the National Press Club in support of various farmers’ issues. This was followed by two concerts in 1985: Nagbabagang Lupa (Earth on Fire), which dramatized the national outrage over the massacre of farmers in Escalante, Negros Occidental, and Buhay Proletaryo (Proletarian Life), a tribute to the workers’ movement.

In 1985, the group went on a tour of the Visayas, performing and holding workshops for amateur musicians in Bohol, Samar, Leyte, Bacolod, and Cebu. It recorded its songs in cassette, titled Nagbabagang Lupa. In 1987, Patatag raised the issue of human rights in its concert OPLAN Patatag at the Folk Arts Theater. In 1988, it recorded Batang Clark (A Kid From Clark), in support of the campaign against the US military bases, and in 1990, a collection of religious protest songs called Masdan, O Yahweh (Look, O Yahweh). Over the years, Patatag has played indigenous-based music like “Bebsat san Kaigorotan” (Igorot Community), folk ballads like “Tano” (depicting the condition of poor peasants), pop songs like “Batang Clark,” traditional music like “Baleleng,” kundiman like “Manggagawa” (Worker), church music, rock, and art songs. Some of its members include theater artists like Rody Vera, Upeng Galang-Fernandez, Louie Pascasio, Lia Moran, Bessie Lee, Dodgie Fernandez, Ella Ola, Noel Kintanar, Chris Millado, Susan Fernandez, Fidel Nemenzo, Clotilde Lucero, Lorenzo Gealogo, Al Santos, Telly Nacpil, Norman Mendoza, and Mark Encarnacion. Many of them have gone on to establish successful careers in different fields.

Patatag received nominations for Best Music Group, 1987, and Best Live Concert, 1988, in the Aliw Awards. The songs of Patatag are considered as the ones that lent a strong voice to the struggling people of the 1980s and the 1990s, elevating protest music into recognized high revolutionary art and culture. They make up the prolific musical tradition of the leftist mass movement that continues to be relevant amongst the oppressed classes in Philippine societies.

A tribute to the music of Patatag was held at the UP College of Music in Aug 2015 which featured the religious protest songs of Masdan, O Yahweh, interpreted by the UP College of Music faculty and students, with a pre-concert forum by Jonas Baes and Rody Vera, under a Metro Manila Commission Professorial Chair Lecture. The concert served as a reunion for the Patatag members. Written byMilagros Carununganupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

PEÑA, ANGEL M. (Angel Matias Peña) b. Laoag, Ilocos Norte 22 Apr 1921. d. Bulacan 22 Dec 2014. Composer, bass player. He was the eldest son of Gregorio Cid Peña, a telephone operator, and Rosario Velarde Matias, a school teacher. Angel was married to Josefina Oliver Lovinaria, with whom he had a daughter, Irma. He obtained his formal training in music during his three-year stint in Hong Kong where he earned a Licentiate with the Royal School of Music of London in the mid-1960s. He received a certificate of merit in double bass playing with Gary Hickling as his mentor, under a grant from the JDR III Fund and a license from London’s Royal School of Music.

From 1956 to 1963, Peña was staff arranger and bass player of the Manila Broadcasting Corporation Orchestra and Little Symphony Orchestra. During the same period, he arranged various jazz concerts for the Upsilon Sigma Phi at the University of the Philippines. He worked as the dance bandleader at the Hong Kong Hilton for a time. He conducted lecture-demonstrations at, among others, the Thomas Jefferson Library in Manila in 1968, and at the University of Hawaii in 1975. He was accepted as bassist of the Honolulu Symphony Orchestra in 1969, and has since lived in Hawaii until his return to the Philippines in the late 1990s. He also played the double bass for the Hawaii-Pacific String Quintet. Upon his return to the Philippines, he became actively involved in the circle of Filipino jazz musicians: Bob Aves, Lito Molina, Richie Quirino, Mario “Tots” Tolentino, Ignacio Moran, Joey Valenciano, Bobby Enriquez, the UST Jazz Band, and the UP Jazz Ensemble.

Peña was affiliated with the Performing Rights Society Ltd. of London, the UK Songwriter’s Guild of Great Britain, the American String Teachers Association, the Musicians Association of Hawaii, and the Audition Committee of the Honolulu Symphony Orchestra.

Among his original compositions for orchestra are Igorot Rhapsody, 1959; Concerto No 1 for double bass and orchestra, 1969; Concerto for jazz quartet and orchestra, 1981; Symphonic Variations on Two Manobo Themes, 1983; Concerto No 2 for Double Bass,” 1991; Philippine Festival Overture, 1993; and Trinity, a symphonic cycle for ballet, 1994. He has also composed chamber music, among which are Prelude and Fugue for Brass Quartet, 1959; Petit Recueil for Three Double Basses, 1965; Three Pieces for String Quartet, 1971; Variations on “Bahay Kubo” for Violin and Viola, 1973; Philippine Serenade and Prelude and Fugue for Ukelele and String Quartet, 1974; Four Sketches for Chamber Orchestra, 1982; Divertissement for Brass Quintet and EDSA String Quartet, 1987; Adagio for Strings, 1989; Bamboo Dance, 1991; and Divertimento for String Orchestra, 1997.

His songs include “Hymn to Pharmacy,” 1953, first prize winner of the National Composition Contest sponsored by the Philippine National Pharmaceutical Association; “Iyo Kailan Pa Man” (Yours Forever), 1953; “Filipina,” 1968, which was featured in the film Where is Chris?, starring Cristina Ponce Enrile; “Sa Batis ng Ligaya” (In the Brook of Happiness), 1971; “Ulila ng Pangarap” (Orphaned Dream), 1977; and “The Lord’s Prayer,” 1990. From 2001 onwards, his jazz and popular music compositions dominated his output which include “Balikbayan,” 2001; “Swing in F,” 2002; “Roto,” 2003; “Trombonology” and “Piece Beyond,” in memory of Filipino jazz icon, Lito Molina, 2004; “Bass-ic-ally Yours,” 2005; and “Igorot Jazz Fantasy,” 2006.

He won two first prizes and one third prize in the Philippine National Composition Contests, and received a plaque from the Order of the Knights of Rizal for his composition “Homage to Rizal.” In 1998, he was honored by the House of Representatives of Hawaii, passing a resolution recognizing Peña’s contributions to the field of music as a jazz musician and arranger living in the state of Hawaii. He has three long-playing records of original compositions released in Manila, the United States, and West Germany. In 2006, an all-Angel Peña album titled Ugnayan (Collaboration) was produced and conducted by Gerard Salonga, performed by the Global Studio Orchestra. His autobiography titled, A Man and His Music, was published by the Ateneo de Manila University Press in 2007. Written byRaj Mansukhaniupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

PHILIPPINE AIR FORCE BAND aka PAF Band. Nichols Air Base, Pasay City, Metro Manila. Although organized in its present form during the early part of 1949, this miniature air force band was already in existence much earlier as a section of the 534th Air Base Squadron in Pasay City. In 1952, the PAF Band was activated pursuant to Section 1, General Order Number 212 of General Headquarters, Armed Forces of the Philippines. Its organizer, Lt Lauro L. Abano, was subsequently designated as its first commanding officer. Succeeding him at the helm later were Maj Mariano S. Bareng, Maj Valentin Y. Mechilina, and Col Emiliano T. Pineda. In 1961, 1st Lt Augusto C. Bataclan took over the Command as the fifth Commanding Officer and held it for 16 years.

The PAF Band is composed of one officer and more than 60 bandsmen, with a unit component of an eight-piece combo and an 18-man dance orchestra. The band’s primary mission is to furnish music for military and social functions of the Command. It is also tasked to provide miscellaneous support for other services such as radio broadcasts, stage shows, concerts, and other musical activities as the Commander may direct. Since its activation, the band has not only rendered concerts at the Rizal Park and Nayong Pilipino but also in principal cities, provincial capitals, and different towns all over the country. In 1953, upon the invitation of General Wang Shu-Min, known as “Tiger Wang” of the Nationalist Chinese Air Force, the band performed for two weeks at different military bases in Taipei, Taiwan. It has also played at international conventions, ASEAN conferences, National Day celebrations, programs of government and civilian agencies, gatherings of different foreign embassies, and athletic competitions. This unit also provides musical requirements for arrival and departure of different heads of state, celebrities, tourists, balikbayan, and other foreign dignitaries at the Manila International Airport, now known as the Ninoy Aquino International Airport.

The Philippine Air Force Band is known not only as a unit of fine musicians but also as a group of outstanding and dependable military men. The band, regarded as the best marching unit of the PAF, has won several awards and trophies at different competitions like the 520th Air Base Wing Monthly Flight Drill Competition, the PAF Inter-Wing Mass Calesthenics Competition, and the Nichols Air Base Platoon Drill Competition. The band has also been a consistent recipient of plaques, resolutions, certificates, letters of appreciations and awards of merit from various government and civilian institutions. With the passing of years, the PAF Band has become an indispensable outfit of the Command in pursuance of the Armed Forces of the Philippines’ commitment to the entire Filipino people, particularly towards the enrichment of the country’s arts and culture. Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

PHILIPPINE ARMY BAND Fort Bonifacio, Taguig City. The Philippine Army Band began as the Philippine Constabulary Band or PC Band. Organized on 15 Oct 1902 by Col Walter H. Loving, the then Philippine Constabulary (PC) Band catapulted the cause of band music, brought fame to the country, and established itself as a highly accomplished musical organization. In addition to its performances at home, the band crossed oceans on several tours in early decades of the 20th century to represent this island nation in Southeast Asia. The PC Band played at the St Louis Exposition in 1904, the inauguration of President Howard Taft in Washington, DC in 1909, and the Pan Pacific Exposition and Golden Gate Exposition in San Francisco, California in 1938. In 1904, this powerhouse band of some 87 players attracted visitors from all over the world to the St Louis Exposition’s Philippine Pavilion, where the smartly uniformed band performed everyday.

Sharing the limelight with Col Loving were two Filipinos who alternated in conducting the said band: Capt Pedro Navarro and Capt Alfonso Fresnido. During the Japanese Occupation of the Philippines, some members of the band were mobilized into the Metropolitan Constabulary Band. After the death of Col Loving and Capt Fresnido during World War II, then Defense Secretary Maj Gen Basilio J. Valdez designated 2nd Lt Antonino Buenaventura to re-organize the band in 1945. Under the young officer’s direction, the organization was renamed the Philippine Army Band. Col Buenaventura was able to regroup practically all members and, shortly after, the band once more bounced back to life.

The period after World War II saw the welcome return of overseas performances as musical ambassadors. When Dr Goldman came to Manila in 1946, he personally selected the band in his conducting under the USO. His report considered the band as the principal military band in the entire Pacific area. In Aug 1955, Pres Ramon Magsaysay sent the band to Jakarta, Indonesia to officially represent the Philippines in the First Floating Exposition in Southeast Asia. A high point for the band came toward the end of its first 90 years when in 1992 under then Commanding General, Philippine Army Lt Gen Arturo Enrile, the band participated in the Singapore National Day Parade as part of the ASEAN Festival in Singapore. The Singapore Armed Forces senior director of music Col Toni Wei Shi Ren was full of admiration and praise for the performance of the Philippine Army Band. Col Buenaventura led the prestigious band for 16 years when it was in the musical limelight. When he retired in 1961, he handed down the baton to Lt Col Jesus del Carmen. In 1964, Lt Leonardo Sabale took over and recruited many young talents. When Capt Sabale was assigned to General Headquarters, Lt Elias Roan took over. He was later succeeded by Lt Sg Eliseo Javier who continued running the outfit in its proud tradition of excellence in music. In 1973, Lt Col Javier passed the baton and command to a younger conductor, Maj Jose FG Dunca Jr, from the 1st (Tabak) Division, Fort Magsaysay, Palayan City.

The Philippine Army Band contributed immensely to the appreciation and propagation of band music through the holding of annual concerts on legitimate stages. Likewise, it lent its artistry to grace military as well as socio-civic affairs. For over a century, the Philippine Army Band has established a remarkable tradition that has succeeded and prevailed over the upheavals of two world wars and the changes of political administrations. Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

PHILIPPINE CHORAL SOCIETY (PCS) Founded 11 Aug 1951 by Liwanag Cruz, it was the first professional choral group to introduce the art of choral singing. It paved the way for the organization and development of other local choral groups in the country. At one time or another, the PCS had practically all the well-known vocal artists of the local concert stage as either as members or soloists.

After a decade of dormancy in 1960 and 1971, the PCS was revived on 21 Mar 1971 when Cruz became its musical director once more. With new members and a new repertoire, it presented a revival concert at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines(CCP), featuring Orff’s Carmina Burana, Beethoven’s Choral Fantasie, FelipePadilladeLeon’s NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not), LucioD.SanPedro’s Valedictory Poems (of Jose Rizal), and BenjaminTupas’s “AveMaria.”

In 1973, the PCS held auditions for singers wishing to join the organization. To mark its 25th anniversary in 1976, it presented a concert at the CCP, with an impressive list of celebrities in Philippine music: ConchingRosal, AurelioEstanislao, PilarMariño, Kathy Sternberg, and ReynaldoReyes. Written byRolando B. Tolentino

PHILIPPINE CONSTABULARY BAND The Philippine Constabulary Band was formed upon the behest of then Col Henry T. Allen, chief of the Philippine Constabulary, who felt the need for a band to assist in military ceremonies as well as in civic and official functions. Its formation got encouragement from then Civil Gov Howard H. Taft and Vice Gov Luke Wright. Then 2nd Lt Walter H. Loving, who was designated the commanding officer, organized the band.

Loving was an African-American who was born in Lovingstone, Virginia on 17 Dec 1872 and had his musical education from the New England Conservatory. He imposed strict discipline among the musicians and set a high standard for band playing. He took only the best among Filipino musicians after passing a rigorous audition.

The band was sent to the 1904 St Louis Exposition where it became a sensation after playing completely in the dark in a competition when the light snapped out while it was playing Giacomo Rossini’s William Tell Overture. Loving tied a white handkerchief at the tip of his baton to cue accurately the musicians who memorized their parts. The band continued playing during the entire power outage that lasted for an hour, without missing any notes under accurate cueing. At once, Loving and the musicians became “world celebrities.” The band bagged the second prize, with the first prize going to the veteran Le Garde Republicaine band of France. It played alongside with seasoned bands from America and Europe such as the US Marine Corps Band, the John Philip Sousa Band, the Mexican National Band, the band of the British Grenadier Guards, and the Royal Italian Band.

Loving trained the band to double as an orchestra when they arrived home having been inspired by the Victor Herbert Orchestra and the German Symphony Orchestra at the exposition. It is this sole distinction to play as an orchestra that added prestige to the band’s fame.

The band made its second visit to the United States on the occasion of Pres William Howard Taft’s inauguration as president of the United States in 1909 where it earned many “firsts.” It was the first non-American band that accompanied Pres Taft in the inaugural parade from the White House to the Capitol where he would take his oath of office, an honor traditionally given to the famed US Marine Band. It was also the first non-American band that played during Pres Taft’s reception and the first non-American band to perform at a new riverside bandstand in Washington, D.C.

From Washington, the band proceeded to fulfill engagements in New York, Chicago, San Francisco, Philadelphia, Atlantic City in New Jersey, and Seattle.

In 1913, the band went back to the United States to play at the Panama-Pacific Exposition at San Francisco, California, giving side performances in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobe, and Honolulu. Sousa conducted the band at the Exposition and ranked it the “best and organized” among the bands that played.

In 1916, Sgt Pedro Navarro took over as the band’s conductor when Loving got sick of tuberculosis. When Navarro retired the following year, Lt Jose Silos succeeded him. Alfonso Fresnido took over as the band’s conductor when Silos retired after a year.

In 1938, Pres Manuel Quezon recalled Loving to prepare the band to play in the Golden Gate Exposition in California that was scheduled the following year.

In between these overseas engagements, the band gave concerts first at the Binondo Square in front of the Binondo Church known as Plaza Calderon de la Barca before it went to the 1904 St Louis Exposition. Later on, Luneta (now Rizal Park) became its venue for its regular serenata or band concert.

The band was disorganized when the Pacific war broke out. Loving and his wife Edith were incarcerated at the University of Santo Tomas for three years and three months. Prominent citizens of Manila pleaded to release the couple. They were allowed to go back to their apartment in Ermita. During the liberation, a Japanese who had gone berserk in Feb 1945 beheaded Loving at Luneta, ironically the site of his greatness, where he and the band gave the best performances that made them famous among the Filipino audience.

In 1945, Maj Gen Basilio Valdez, then secretary of National Defense ordered the reorganization of the band assigning Lt Antonino Buenaventura the task. He was able to gather some 98 original members. However, because the PC had not been reactivated yet, the band was placed under the Philippine Army. It bounced back to life with Buenaventura handling it for 16 years. Written byAntonio C. Hila

PHILIPPINE MADRIGAL SINGERS (PMS) aka MADZ. Formerly the UP Madrigal Singers. Choral Ensemble. Organized in 1963 by Andrea O. Veneracion of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, it was modeled after the University of Indiana Madrigal Choir where Veneracion earned a master’s degree in voice. The group’s first public performance of a choral program was at the UP Abelardo Hall on 1 Oct 1963. In Feb 1964, it held its first public performance outside of the university at the Philamlife Auditorium, attended by Pres Diosdado Macapagal and the First Lady. The choir participated at the 2nd International Choral Festival in 1969 that marked its first international exposure.

In 1980, the choir changed its name to the Philippine Madrigal Singers when it became a resident company of the Cultural Center of the Philippines that entitled them to an annual subsidy. The current choirmaster since 2001 is Mark Anthony Carpio. Originally composed of 12 singers, they now have 18 to 24 members who are teachers, students, and alumni of UP. Their unique style of concertizing—sitting in a semicircle—is drawn from the style of singing the madrigal, a Renaissance piece sung a capella by entertainers or guests gathered around banquet tables. The group’s repertoire includes Renaissance music, European classics, Filipino and international folk songs, contemporary music, sacred music, Negro spirituals, avant-garde, opera, and even popular music. It aims to set standards of excellence in choral competitions, develop appreciation for choral music, establish the Philippines as an active and respected member of the international choral community, and widen the Philippine perspective on choral works and techniques. They have also performed in the premieres of choral works by major Filipino composers like Lucrecia Kasilag, Francisco Feliciano, Ruben Federizon, and Jeffrey Ching, as well as in operas and sarsuwela. The choir is one of the Asia’s most awarded, having won the top prizes in the world’s most prestigious choral competitions: Arezzo and Gorizia, Italy; Marktoberdorf, Germany; Spittal, Austria; Neuchatel, Switzerland; Tour, France; Varna, Bulgaria; Debrecen, Hungary; and Cantonigros and Torrevieja, Spain. They hold the distinction of being the first choir in the world to win the European Grand Prix for choral singing twice, in 1997 and 2007. Some of the group’s members have moved on to become choirmasters, musical directors, solo performers, and teachers, notably Elmo Makil, Evelyn Mandac, Enrico Saboren, Francisco Aseniero, and Noel Velasco.

In 1992, the Philippine Madrigal Singers went on its sixth international concert tour covering Italy, Germany, Belgium, Spain, and Brunei Darussalam. They also participated in the l0th Anniversary celebration of the International Federation for Choral Music. They were the featured choir in the American Choral Directors Association National Convention in San Antonio, Texas, USA, and the Joy of Singing International Choral Festival in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, both in 1993. The choir has cut more than 35 volumes of records and discs, not only in the Philippines but also in Spain, Italy, Belgium, Germany, France, Slovenia, Korea, and the United States. The Madz’s musical recordings include: Bayan Ko, Aawitan Kita (My Country, I Will Sing For You), 1998; Madz Around the World and Mad in Love, 2000; Madz in Love, 2002; The Madrigal Collection (Ruby Anniversary Recording), 2003; Iyo Kailan Pa Man (All-Filipino Recording), 2005; Acclamation, 2006; Major Caritas Op. 5, 2008; and Madz in Love Continues, 2009, and Madz Goes Jesuit, 2015.

Some of their publications include: Philippine Madrigal Singers, Series I, II, III, a collection of choral arrangements of Filipino songs, including folk songs and choir arrangements, 1984-1985; Mga Awiting Bayan (Folk Songs), 1993, a collection of choral arrangements of Philippine folksongs; and ASEAN Folksongs, 1996, a folio of five choral arrangements of ASEAN folksongs. Their awards include the following: the Golden Scroll Award, Parangal ng Bayan, Manila, 1994; Gran Premio XVII Kutxa-Maximo Puntacion, 1996, awarded at the Certamen de Masa Corales de Tolosa, Tolosa, Spain; and the grand prize with the highest number of points and the right to represent Tolosa in the Grand Prix Européen du Chant Choral, 1997. They also won the following: first prize, Folklore Category, Voces Mixtas; second place, Polyphonic Category, Voces Mixtas; second place, Musica Sacra Category, Grupo Vocale; third place, Musica Profana Category, Grupo Vocale; Premio Gobierno Vasco, Best Interpretation of a Basque composition with a score of 99 percent, the highest in the history of Tolosa competitions; and Premio del Publico DB, the best choir as chosen by the press Diario Vasco and the public. In 1997, at Grand Prix Européen Chant du Choral, Tours France, the Philippine Madrigals was the grand champion at this choral competition which featured the grand prize winners of six prestigious competitions in Europe: Gorizia and Arezzo, Italy; Debrecen, Hungary; Varna, Bulgaria, Tolosa, Spain; and Tours France.

In the 2004 Certamenes Internacional Habaneras y Polifonia in Torrevieja, Spain, the Madrigals won the following: first place, Polyphonic Category, and first place, Habanera Category. In 2006, at the 35th Florilege Vocal de Tours, Tours, France, they won first place: Vocal Ensemble Category, Free Programming Category, Special Renaissance Category, and Gran Prix de la Ville de Tours. That same year, they received the Lifetime Achievement Award at the Aliw Awards, Manila. In 2007, at the 39th Grand Prix Europeen de Chant Choral, Arezzo, Italy, they won the Grand Prix, the first choir to win the European Grand Prix twice. In 2009, the group was honored as UNESCO Artist for Peace in Paris, France. In 2010, they received the Guidoneum Award in Arezzo, Italy from the Concorso Polifonico Guido d’Arezzo Foundation for “the artistic and choral promotion activity” that have continued carrying out since winning the European Grand Prix for choral singing in 2007. In Aug 2013, the group celebrated its 50th anniversary with the Andrea Veneracion International Choral Festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in honor of its founder. Choral groups from the Philippines and all over the world competed in folk music, vocal ensemble, and chamber choir. Written byFelizidad Z. Reyes and Ma. Patricia Brillantesupdated by Connie Ladrido

PHILIPPINE NAVY BAND aka Headquarters Philippine Navy Band. Bonifacio Naval Station, Taguig City. The Philippine Navy Band was born on 1 Mar 1949 when Lt Anastacio Sosa was designated officer-in-charge and conductor of a small unit of military musicians, then known as the Philippine Naval Patrol Band. It was later renamed Headquarters Philippine Navy Band on 15 Feb 1952, in conjunction with the reorganization of Philippine Naval Patrol into the Philippine Navy which recruited more personnel. In 1966, Lt Commander Geronimo P. Torres assumed the position as the commanding officer and conductor of the band, which was based at the Philippine Naval Station at Roxas Boulevard, Manila. Now in its present station in Fort Bonifacio and led by Capt Rodolfo Morres, a graduate of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music and former member and assistant conductor of the UP ROTC Band, the Philippine Navy Band is not only engaged in furnishing music within the command but also in various public concerts, radio broadcasts, and civic affairs. Under Morris’s leadership, the Philippine Navy Band was proclaimed champion several times in Philippine Military Bands Concert Competitions in the 1990s. Due to the expansion of the Philippine Navy and the greater support given by the band to civilian sector in the field of music, the Philippine Navy Band expanded from 50 to 100 bandsmen. Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

PHILIPPINE NORMALUNIVERSITY HIMIG KAWAYAN aka PNU Himig Kawayan. The Philippine Normal University (PNU) Himig Kawayan was organized in the 1990s by music education professor Pacita Narzo. The group was originally a rondalla class that is a requirement for majors in the bachelor of secondary education in music program at PNU. In 2001, the PNU Rondalla was formally recognized as an independent performing group in the said university. Shortly thereafter, it ventured into angklung ensemble playing. For a time, the same performers play for both the rondalla and angklung ensembles in PNU. Thus, the group was called the PNU Rondalla, Angklung and Ethnic Ensemble. A grant from the Japanese Cultural Center through Grant Assistance for Cultural Grassroots Project in 2007 made possible the separate organization of the PNU Angklung Ensemble. Consequently, the PNU Angklung Ensemble was renamed PNU Himig Kawayan in 2008.

An earlier grant from the UNESCO National Cultural Committee in 2003 and from Local Government Units bank rolled the group in organizing, training and monitoring of bamboo instrument ensembles in different localities in the Archipelago. The Philippine Society for Music Education (PSME) was also involved in the promotion of music by PNU Himig Kawayan to both local and foreign audiences.

Many opportunities paved the way for the transformations of the group. The grant from the Japan Foundation, the close ties with the PSME, and funding from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts defined the directions the group had taken. Funding gave the Himig Kawayan the capacity to build its collection of instruments. Institutional connections with the PSME and the NCCA gave it fora to perform in public and private spaces, and to give lectures on Philippine music.

Notable performances of the rondalla group included participation in the First (2004), Second (2007), and Third (2011) International Rondalla Festivals held in the Bicol region, and in the cities of Dumaguete and Tagum, respectively.

Aside from the many engagements to perform in various education-related activities, government functions and corporate events, the group regularly prepares for annual concerts. Previous concerts were titled Himig ng Lahi (Song of the Race), 2002; Kayamanan ng Lahi (Gems of the Race), 2003; Kabataan, Musika at Kinabukasan (Youth, Music, and the Future), 2006; Musika ng Lahing Pilipino (Music of the Filipino Race), 2009; Cuerdas sa Pagkakaisa (Strings of Unity), 2011; Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika (How Beautiful is Our Music), 2012; and Ngayon at Kailanman (Now and Forever), 2014. Written byRaul Navarro

PHILIPPINE PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA (PPO) Formerly the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra. Founded in 1973 by the late conductor Luis Valencia, it is the resident orchestra of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Partly supported by the Philippine Philharmonic Society Inc, it became a national orchestra in 1982 under the directorship of Oscar C. Yatco.

The PPO performs regularly at the CCP and in popular venues such as churches, schools, town plazas, and parks. It has also performed abroad, at the Hong Kong Cultural Center, and in Kuala Lumpur, Brunei, Singapore, and even in Europe.

Aiming to provide music that showcases Filipino artistry and craftsmanship, the PPO has worked with soloists such as Cecile Licad, Raul Sunico, Aurelio Estanislao, Albert Tiu, Raymond De Leon, Joseph Esmilla, the Bolipata Brothers, Rowena Arrieta, Evelyn Mandac, Reynaldo Reyes, Nena del Rosario-Villanueva, Carminda Regala, and Joseph Esmilla; conductors such as Sergio Esmilla Jr, Regalado Jose, Chino Toledo, and Julian Quirit; singers like Lea Salonga, Arthur Espiritu, Rachelle Gerodias, Celeste Legaspi, 100">Bert Nievera, and Regine Velasquez; and choral ensembles like the Philippine Madrigal Singers and the UP Concert Chorus.

The principal conductors and music directors who led PPO were Luis Valencia, Oscar Yatco, Ruggero Barbieri, Eugene Castillo, and Olivier Ochanine. Currently, Yoshikazu Fukumura is its music director. Among the known musicians who had served as its resident conductor were Basilio C. Manalo, Francisco F. Feliciano, Cecinio Ronquillo, and Agripino Diestro. The present associate conductor is Herminigildo Ranera. Its concertmasters have included Julian Quirit, Proceso Yusi, Basilio C. Manalo, Gonzalo Estrada, and Nemecio Ibero. Those who have served as principals are: Nemesio Ibero Jr, first violin; Ramon Ibero, Jorge Joy Sababan, second violin; Sancho Samala, Joy Allan de la Cruz, viola; Renato Lucas, Gerry Graham Gonzales, cello; Manuel Piñon, Ariston Payte III, contrabass; Enrique Barcelo, Hercules Santiago, flute; Rizalino Garcia, oboe; Dalmacio Cruz, Ariel Sta. Ana, clarinet; Severino Ramirez, Adolfo Mendoza, bassoon; Rodel Colmenar, Vicente Galang, horn; Roger Llado, Fredeline Parin, trumpet; Romeo San Jose, Cornelio Ramos, trombone; Benedicto dela Peret Jr, tuba; Leodivino Roque, timpani and percussion; and Lourdes de Leon-Gregorio, harp.

The PPO has played under the baton of Mstislav Rostropovich, Henry Lewis, Mendi Rodan, Michael Tippet, Piero Gamba, Sebastian Bereau, Yaacov Bergman, Jeffrey Meyer, Yoshikazu Fukumura, Nicholas Koch, James Judd, Jae Joon Lee, and Apo Hsu. The foreign artists who have graced its concerts include Sequeira Costa, William Wolfram, Anthony Camden, Caryl Thomas, David Benoit, Van Cliburn, Rony Rogoff, Albert Lysy, Daniel Adni, Judith Engel, Peter Schmalfuss, Werner Taube, Wilma Vernocchi, Renata Tebaldi, Peter Roesel, Sofiya Golyak, Ray Wang, Roger Wilke, Hyunah Yu, and Kurt Muroki.

The PPO has performed not only in the country but in the international concert halls as well. Among the international concert tours held were: Europe tour in 2001; Asia Orchestra Week at the Tokyo Opera Hall in 2002; Bangkok’s National Theater per invitation by Her Royal highness Princess Galyani Vadhana of Thailand in 2004; Shanghai Expo in the People’s Republic of China in 2010; and the National Centre for the Performing Arts in Beijing, China in 2011.

Aside from playing the classics of European music, the PPO has commissioned and/or performed orchestral works by Filipino composers, like Nicanor S. Abelardo, Francisco Santiago, Antonino Buenaventura, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucio D. San Pedro, Lucrecia R. Kasilag, Jose Maceda, Ramon P. Santos, Ryan Cayabyab, and Chino Toledo. The PPO has also played classical ballets like Swan Lake and Giselle, operas like La Traviata, La Boheme, Madame Butterfly, and Aida, and sarsuwela like Walang Sugat (No Wounds), Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), and Pilipinas Circa 1907 (Philippine Circa 1907).

Recent albums of the PPO include Martin Nievera Live With The Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, under the directorship of Ruggero Barbieri, 2000; Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Ruggero Barbieri, 2001; PPO Plays Triple B: Brahms, Buenaventura, Bizet, Olivier Ochanine conductor, 2013; and Serenata: Well-loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies under the baton of Ryan Cayabyab, 2015. The PPO’s recording of “Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of Pasig) which appeared in its album with Martin Nievera won the Awit Awards for Best Traditional Recording in 2001.

Aside from its performances, the PPO holds training programs and outreach activities to raise the level of musicianship in the country as well as bring quality music to as wide an audience as possible. Written byRosalinda Galang

PHILIPPINE SOCIETY FOR MUSIC EDUCATION (PSME) Founded in 23 Nov 1971, it is a registered national organization dedicated to the advancement of music education. With a membership of music teachers, musicians, schoolmusic administators and students, it seeks to provide directions towards creative and effective music instruction in the preschool, elementary, and secondary levels. The first set of officers was comprised of: Luz Villanueva, Juan Ramos, Corazon Maceda, Lucrecia R. Kasilag, Ma. Luisa Navarro, Candida Bautista, Vicente Sales, Vilma Santiago-Felipe, and Crispina Garcia. Former First Lady Imelda Marcos was honorary chair.

The PSME released publications like Curriculum Guide for Elementary Music, Curriculum Guide for Secondary School Music, and Rondalla Selections, and a cassette tape on Philippine songs, Isang Bansa, Isang Diwa (One Nation, One Ideal). In 1993, it completed a three-summer scholarship program for music teachers with the cooperation with the Philippine Normal University and the Presidential National Commission for Culture (now National Commission for Culture and the Arts). The program was participated in by music teachers from all the Philippine regions.

A national affiliate of the International Society of Music Education (ISME) from 2000 to 2006, the PSME continues to foster the role of music as imperative in the aesthetic development of the Filipino through regular music education workshops and seminars, development of instructional materials in music, and the performance of Philippine music on native musical instruments. Its current main advocacy called “Himig Kawayan” promotes the training of classroom music teachers in the performance and teaching of the Philippine bamboo percussion instruments, inspired by the Pangkat Kawayan founded by the late Victor Toledo. The PSME, with grants from cultural agencies and cooperation of educational institutions, is enabled to hold music education seminars-workshops in key regions of the country. Past presidents are Corazon S. Maceda, Alejandra C. Atabug, Loreta C. Garcia, and Violeta E. Hornilla. The current president is Leticia G. Del Valle. Written byEdgardo B. Maranan and Elmer L. Gatchalianupdated by Mauricia Borromeo

PHILIPPINE YOUTH ORCHESTRA (PYO) The PhilippineYouthOrchestra was founded by the University of the Philippines (UP) Board of Regents in 1974. It was envisioned by Ruby K. Mangahas, then dean of the UP College of Music, in cooperation with several heads of other music schools, as a laboratory program intended to provide quality instruction and playing opportunities for future professional orchestral musicians, conductors, and chamber music artists as well as a forum for the performance of works by young composers.

The training program, under the direct supervision of the UP College of Music, was opened to interested youngsters with basic performance ability on an orchestral instrument. PYO members are a highly heterogeneous group with ages ranging from 12 to 25 years, with academic backgrounds from grade school to college in various fields, and with musical training levels from elementary to advanced.

Since its inception in 1974, the PYO has trained over 92 violinists, 23 violists, 28 cellists, 18 bassists, 16 flutists, 10 oboists, 18 clarinetists, 12 bassoonists, 18 French hornists, 28 trumpetists, 23 trombonists, 22 percussionists, and 5 tuba players. Some noted artists who were former members of the PYO are violinists AlfonsoBolipata, JosephEsmilla, Dionisia Fernandez, Rodelio Flores, John Lesaca, Cecil Coo Cruz, and Arturo Molina; cellists RamonBolipata, RenatoLucas, Wilfredo Pasamba, and Amador Tamayo; flutists Francisco Candelaria, AntonioMaigue, and Robert Schroeder; and bassists John David Ortez and Antonio Rodriguez. Some of its former members held or currently hold posts in the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra.

Under its conductor and mentor SergioEsmillaJr, the orchestra performed all over the Philippines and in parts of Southeast Asia. In 1979, the orchestra toured Singapore, Taipei, and Hong Kong. In the Metro Manila area, the orchestra has performed at the UP, the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines, and the PCIBank Francisco Santiago Hall, among others. It has featured soloists like CecileLicad, RowenaArrieta, JovianneyEmmanuelCruz, NoelArce, and Allier Manahan.

The PYO was discontinued in 1988 by the new UP College of Music administration. An attempt was made to revive the orchestra in 1993, with the initial concert held at the Abelardo Hall of the UP College of Music in Diliman conducted by Basilio Manalo. After this, PYO had another concert featuring American coloratura soprano, Barbara Kilduff and conducted by American conductor, Ward Holmquist held at Philamlife Theater, Manila. Written byCorazon C. Dioquinoupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

article_title: Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines Foundation, Inc
text:
PIANO TEACHERS GUILD OF THE PHILIPPINES FOUNDATION, INC (PTGPFI) aka Piano Teachers Guild of the Philippines. Founded in 1973 as a corollary to the Philippine Society for Music Education, it seeks to encourage and advance professional growth among the country’s piano teachers, both in private and conservatory practice; foster goodwill and harmonious interpersonal relationships among them; establish a board of accreditation to raise professional standards; form chapter-guilds all over the country; and promote new Filipino compositions for the piano. The guild became a foundation in 18 Nov 2013.

At its first general meeting at the Little Theater (now Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) on 11 Mar 1973, Benjamin Tupas gave a lecture-demonstration on “Impressionism—Its History and Relevance to Music and the Humanities.” Pianist-pedagogue Reynaldo Reyes spoke on piano technique and piano repertoire at the guild’s first general assembly in 1974. In subsequent assemblies, discussions focused on issues, trends, and problems in piano teaching and music education.

In 1975, the guild passed a code of ethics for its members, which also set standards for professional fees, proper conduct in dealings between teacher and student and between fellow teachers, compliance with professional obligations and responsibilities, and other aspects of piano teaching.

PTGPFI conducts refresher seminars, workshops in piano performance and pedagogy, repertoire building, competitions, and master classes by local and foreign-based artists-pedagogues. The annual festival remains as its centerpiece, serving a wide circle of teachers and students as an avenue for a public affirmation of achievements in piano study. To celebrate its 40th year, two concerts were held on 18 Nov 2012 at the CCP Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, featuring over 300 piano artist-teachers and students, ages 8 to 80, performing a varied repertoire either solo or ensemble on 40 pianos. To date, chapters have been organized in the cities of Bacolod, Cebu, Cagayan deOro, Iloilo, and in Metro Manila.

The guild’s first president was Milagros Ocampo, who served until 1985. She was succeeded by Sr Mary Placid Abejo, OSB, Mauricia Borromeo, Fr Manuel Maramba, OSB, and Anthony Say. The current president is Mary Anne Espina. National Artist for music Lucrecia R. Kasilag was honorary president until 2008. Written byEdgardo B. Marananupdated by Mauricia Borromeo

PINIKPIKAN Pinikpikan, later known as Kalayo, is an informal drum circle/jamming group of artist-musicians that traces its beginnings to the first Baguio Arts Festival in 1989. In the first decade of its existence, the group found itself with a constantly revolving roster of performers that included Pepito Bosch, Roberto Villanueva, BenCab (who was known to have come up with the name after the popular Cordillera dish “pinikpikan”), Boyu, Diokno Pasilan, Billy Bonnevie, Shant Verdun, Nonoy Alcalde, Samuel Asuncion, Louie Talan, Boy Garovillo, Budeths Casinto, and Carol Bello. Through guitarist Asuncion’s influence and musical direction, Pinikpikan slowly evolved into a musical force that broke into the local and international “world music” scene.

Pinikpikan’s vision is to “present hybrid Filipino music” to both local and international audiences, bringing in a “texture of ethnicity” in their mix of a wide-array of indigenous instruments with the more familiar and amplified sounds of a standard rock band (Asuncion 2015). Pinikpikan’s albums include Metronomad, 1996, Atas (Mission), 1999, Obra Encantada (Enchanted Work), 2000, and Kaamulan, 2003. Atas garnered five awards including Best Album from KATHA Music Awards in 2000, and is distributed in Europe by Tropical Music, Record and Publishing Company. The sounds of gongs (gangsa from the Cordilleras and kulintang from Mindanao), bamboo instruments, and percussions of other music traditions create a distinctive texture to the album’s original music. The fifth track “Una Kaya” (Naturally the First), for example, features the bamboo xylophone gabbang alongside Carol Bello’s powerful vocal chanting. The percussive-driven music of Pinikpikan adds to the group’s popularity in performances and music festivals that enjoin listeners to participate in the music making and impromptu dancing.

In 2001, Pinikpikan collaborated with Ballet Philippines in staging Tambol at Padyak (Drum and March) with award-winning choreography by Tony Fabella at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Pinikpikan was also active in the touring circuit, performing around the Philippines in provincial festivals and cultural shows, community concerts, and school events. Abroad, one of the group’s major appearances was in the ASEAN Cultural Summit in Sep 2002, performing at the historic site of Angkor Wat in Cambodia. Around 2008, Asuncion, along with Bello, Talan, Garovillo, and Casinto, made the transition to form the Kalayo band. Other seasoned musicians joined the group: drummer Reli de Vera (also of Sino Sikat?), multipercussionists Deej Rodriguez, and Gerry Baguio. After its transition to Kalayo, the band has released the album Malaya (Free), 2013, and has performed in numerous concerts and music festivals like the 2008 Rainforest World Music Festival in Sarawak and the Penang World Music Festival, and in a special concert in Paris organized by the Alliance Française Foundation in 2013. Written byIsidora Miranda

PLACID, MARY (Sr Mary Placid Abejo, OSB) b. Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental 31 Oct 1934. Music educator, pianist. She is the eldest daughter of Josepha Casino and Crisogono Abejo. Baptized Lorna, she credits her childhood music exposure to her educator-parents who played the piano. Her mother, a home economics major at Centro Escolar University, studied piano with the Filipino composer Francisco Buencamino Sr, while her father’s sister is the nun-composer Sr Rosalina Abejo, RVM. She finished her elementary and secondary education at Tagoloan Central School, 1947, and St Mary’s High School, Misamis Oriental, 1951, respectively.

Abejo availed of piano lessons at Lourdes College of Cagayan de Oro, with P Capistrano, a music graduate of St Scholastica’s College (SSC) Manila. She then enrolled in SSC where she graduated in 1956 with a Bachelor of Music degree, major in piano and composition. On 24 Apr 1963, Abejo professed her vows in the Order of St Benedict (OSB). Advanced studies led her to the University of Michigan Ann Arbor, where, as a recipient of a Levi Barbour Scholarship for Oriental Women in 1971-75, she finished her master’s, 1972, and a doctorate, 1975, in music education.

Upon her return to the Philippines, she created some important works. First among these was the twice-published Liturgy of Hours, 1979, a compilation of her original modal-based melodic settings of the approved English translations of antiphons and psalms. This is still used by Benedictine nuns locally and abroad. Her other accomplishments clearly reflect the main focus of her masteral thesis and doctoral dissertation, namely, the upgrading of music education at all levels in private and public schools by way of seminars/workshops/programs addressing the training needs of classroom music teachers. Going beyond the classroom and believing in the broad development of the innate musicality of young Filipinos, she co-founded the Philippine Research for the Development of Instrumental Soloists (PREDIS) in 1985, and served as three-term president of the Piano Teachers’ Guild of the Philippines (PTGP) from 1984. Through the years, she actively participated in local and national projects of several private and government-related cultural agencies.

In her mission of instilling the pursuit of excellence among the youth, Sr Mary Placid, dean of SSC School of Music since 1976, has reaped rewards through the prizes won by SSC students in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists; the rebirth of the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) through PREDIS; student participation in international camps and festivals; and the successful careers of her school’s music graduates as performers or teachers here or abroad. She continues to share her expertise in the field of music education and liturgy through her linkages in the country and abroad. The renovation of St Cecilia’s Hall in 2000 and the new five-floor building of the SSC School of Music is the result of her commitment to provide the best environment for nurturing musical talent.

Among her numerous awards are the PAX 1998, the highest award given to SSC Alumnae; the Outstanding Music Centennial Award 2007, the highest centennial award of SSC; and the TOFIL (Ten Outstanding Filipinos) in 2008. Written byMauricia D. Borromeo

article_title: Popular Music Foundation of the Philippines
text:
POPULAR MUSIC FOUNDATION OF THE PHILIPPINES Founded on 8 Mar 1977 by a group of individuals from the musicindustry and the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas, it sought to promote and develop popular Filipino music. It was incorporated on 21 Jul 1977, with officials of the broadcast and print media, the recording companies, and stage and theatrical associations as members.
