The Foundation aims to achieve its general objective by promoting and developing Filipino composers, arrangers, writers, performers, and artists; developing foreign markets for Filipino pop music; and encouraging studies and research on popular music through grants, scholarships, and financial or other forms of assistance to students, researchers, and scholars. Its major project was the holding of the Metro Manila PopularMusic Festival or Metropop, which sought to give recognition and provide incentives to local composers and develop among the public an awareness of and appreciation for popular Filipino music.

The Metropop was launched on 15 Aug 1977. Fourteen compositions were chosen from hundreds of entries. The Foundation would have the legal right to manage the songs, with generous terms offered to the composers. At the second festival held in 1978, changes were made in the rules such as limiting each composer to one entry and reducing the number of finalists from 14 to 12; the participation of music students in the screening committee; and the inclusion of foreign judges. In 1982, two distinct divisions—amateur and professional—were created and the musical categories were expanded to five: jazz, rock, folk, upbeat pop, and ballad. Indigenous music was also encouraged. Starting with this festival, the Foundation decided to honor musical artists who have excelled in their fields and made significant contributions to Filipino music. The first honoree was ConstanciodeGuzman.

The Metropop gave birth to songs like RyanCayabyab’s “KayGandangAtingMusika” (How Beautiful is Our Music), HeberBartolome’s “Tayo’yMgaPinoy” (We are Filipinos), FreddieAguilar’s “Anak” (Child), GeorgeCanseco’s “Ako ang Nagwagi, Ako ang Nasawi” (I Won, I Lost), Charo Unite’s “Lupa” (Earth), LouieOcampo and RowenaArrieta’s “Ewan” (I Don’t Know), Gines Tan’s “MagsimulaKa” (Make a Start), VehneeSaturno’s “Isang Dakot” (A Handful), Rene Novelles’s “A Smile in Your Heart,” and GaryGranada’s “Salamat Musika” (Thank You Music).

Since 1982, the Foundation was chaired by Imee Marcos. It was supposed to hold its ninth pop music festival in Mar 1986, but the EDSA uprising in Feb of that year overthrew the Marcos regime which led to the sudden dissolution of the Metropop.

The vacuum arising from such dissolution led to two later developments in the field of Philippine popular music. From 1996-2003, GMA Network organized the Metropop Song Festivals, which were aired in its station, and the creation of Philpop Music Fest Foundation, chaired by Manny V. Pangilinan, which has revived the songwriting contest, now named Philippine Popular Music Festival, beginning 2012. Written byRosalinda Galang

POTENCIANO, IRMA (Irma Liwanag Ponce Enrile-Potenciano) b. Manila 21 Oct 1931. Singer, teacher. She is the daughter of Alfonso Ponce Enrile, a corporate lawyer, and Purita Liwanag, a music graduate of the University of the Philippines. She was married to Victor R. Potenciano. They have three children. She is the sister of singer, actor, and film producer ArmidaPonceEnrileSiguion-Reyna. She started her voice studies with SalvacionOppus-Yñiguez. At the age of 16, she made her debut as soloist for the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra under LuisValencia. In 1949 she went to New York and trained under Olga Eisner, while finishing high school. She earned a bachelor’s and a master’s degree in voice from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music in 1961 and 1964, respectively; the latter degrees he finished with the highest of honors. Later she acquired certificates of proficiency in the Ward method at St Paul College and in Gregorian chant at La Concordia College. She also had special training in opera with Boris Goldovsky, Fred Poppen of New York and Boston, Hans Bruck and Felix Wolfes of New England Conservatory, Boston, and master classes with Herbert Zipper, Sarah Caldwell, Desire Ligetti, Edna Garabadian, Lucresia Shaw, John Lester, Maestro Chigikov, and Mr Brauer, in the United States, and Arrigo Pola in Italy. Her local mentors include JovitaFuentes for opera, AurelioEstanislao for lieder, ReynaldoReyes in vocal coaching, as well as Asuncion Loangco Lopez, and Jose Mossesgeld Santiago-Font. As would be expected, she has imparted her knowledge and expertise to younger generations. Since 1961, she has been teaching voice at the UST Conservatory of Music. Among her outstanding students are Clarissa Ocampo, Randy Gidongo, Jun Francis Jaranilla, Abdulraman Candao, Mariflor Tuazon, and Ronan Ferrer.

Potenciano played lead or major roles in operas like Bizet’s Carmen, 1949; Gounod’s Faust, 1952; Johann Strauss II’s Die Fledermaus, 1954; Poulenc’s Dialogue with the Carmelites,1962; Leoncavallo’s I Pagliacci, 1966 and 1976; and Puccini’s La Boheme, 1969 and 1975, Tosca, 1970; Lehar’s The Merry Widow, 1977; Turandot, 1979; and Mozart’s The Marriage of Figaro, 1984. She also appeared in Bizet’s Carmen, in Filipino, 1956 and 1958; and in FelipePadilladeLeon’s opera, ElFilibusterismo (Subversion), in its 1970 premiere. She starred in the sarsuwela Minda Mora, 1975; PilipinasCirca1907, 1982; WalangSugat (No Wounds), 1991; and Sa Bunganga ng Pating (At the Mercy of Sharks), 1995. She was the Mother Abbess in The Sound of Music, 1980. As an actress, she appeared in a movie titled Soltero (Single Man), directed by Pio de Castro III, in 1984.

She has also sung in operettas, lieder recitals, concert tours abroad, and movie and stage roles. Some of these include her performance with the Philippine Music Ensemble as Ambassador of Goodwill in Indonesia, and in the solo concert tour in Okinawa, Japan, both in 1969; as soloist in the 1970 Manila Symphony Orchestra Season, conducted by Helen Quach; in solo song recitals at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1971, 1976, and 1980; as soloist in Elijah with the Hong Kong Oratorio Society; in her participation in Her Son, Jose operatorio by Lucrecia Kasilag at the CCP, 1977; with the Vocal Ensemble Philippines, which she founded, in concert tour covering Far East, Canada, United States, and Europe in 1978; in Isang Gabi ng mga Awiting Bayan (An Evening of Patriotic Songs), CCP; as soloist of National Philharmonic Orchestra, with Redentor Romero conducting, 1979; in the Romanian concert tour with six different Romanian symphony orchestras, 1980; in An Evening of Fine Music with Gilopez Kabayao and Vocal Ensemble Philippines, Manila Hotel, 1980; in a duo concert with Conchita Gaston and Metro Manila Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Ramon Tapales, 1981; in An Evening of Operatic Arias, Concert at the Park, 1981, and on the same year with Vocal Ensemble Philippines in another concert tour in the United States and Canada. She also toured with Kayumangging Kaligatan and Ernani Cuenco in 1987 and did solo concerts at Philamlife Auditorium in 1995, 1999, 2001, 2004, and 2005. She also joined in a concert with Raul Sunico in Holiday Inn at New Jersey, USA, 2001.

Potenciano has recorded two albums: Iniibig Kita (I Love You) with The London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Redentor Romero, 1982, and Irma with guitarist Flor Javier.

Among the awards bestowed upon her are the Golden Award for Most Outstanding and Distinguished Alumna of the Conservatory of Music, UST, 1971; Honor Roll of Talaang Pangdangal, UST Alumni Association Incorporated, 1982; Most Outstanding Thomasian, 1984; Gintong Ina Award for Arts and Culture, 1996; Total Award for being the Most Outstanding Thomasian Alumna in Arts and Humanities, 1999; Amazing Alumna Achiever, Miriam/Maryknoll College, 2002; Certificate of Recognition for Dedication and Exemplary Artistry as Faculty of UST Conservatory of Music, 2005; Huwarang Anak ng Bulacan, Club Bulaqueño, 2011; and Outstanding Award as Alumna of the UST Graduate School, 2014. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgoupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

PRESIDENTIAL SECURITY COMMAND BANDaka PSC Band. Malacañan, Manila. Only few would know of the Presidential Security Command Band because the band only graces the exclusive social halls of Malacañan Palace on important occasions. Founded during the incumbency of Pres Manuel Roxas, the PSC Band was organized to provide music during guard mounting, reviews, and parades in connection with decoration ceremonies, escorts of honor for foreign dignitaries, important social occasions, and other state functions. The task of organizing the Presidential Security Command Band fell on the hands of Col Jose Tando who then asked the help of Col Antonino Buenaventura, the commanding officer of the First Armed Forces Band (PC Band). The nucleus of the band came from musicians of Samar and Leyte but because of numerous requests from the military as well as the civilian sectors, musicians from neighboring towns of Rizal, Cavite, and Laguna were enlisted. In 1954, 2nd Lt Ambrosio S. Ordona took over as the second officer-in-charge of the band which then had a total strength of 28 musicians. It was during the incumbency of Pres Carlos P. Garcia that the first combo unit was organized. Named “Linda,” after the only daughter of the President, the combo proved the versatility of the band as it could easily convert itself into an orchestra.

When Maj Ordona retired in 1963, then 1st Lt Luis Palad took over. He worked for the increase of membership from 32 to at least 50. A musician of discriminating taste, Lt Col Luis Palad believed that the first requirement of the band was a good volume. With the support of the then commanding general, Maj Gen Fabian Ver, the band acquired new musical instruments and sets of gala uniforms. Being a musical enthusiast himself, Gen Ver enlarged this band and elevated it to the level of Major Command bands like the GHQ, PA, PAF, and PN, which has 100 members each. Today, despite the scarcity of players, it is still able to maintain itself as it diligently searches for qualified young players to replace retirees. Written byRodney D. S. Ambat

PUNO, RICO J.(Enrico de Jesus Puno) aka Rico J. b. Manila 14 Feb 1953. d. Taguig City 30 Oct 2018.Singer, actor.Born to Felipe Puno and Corazon de Jesus, he studied at the Burgos Elementary School and Mapa School, and graduated with a commerce degree at the Philippine School of Business Administration. He married Doris Tayag with whom he hadfour children.Puno was elected as a councilor of Makati City in 2016. Previously, he was also the councilor of Makati City's first district in 1998 until 2007.

Puno started out as a singer in folk houses and in nightclubs. He was noticed by Vicor executives in 1975 when the Temptations, impressed by his singing at the Pallazi, joined him in an impromptu number. A few months after, his first single under the Sunshine Label, “Love Won’t Let Me Wait,” was released. In this recording, he introduced something new in Philippine music—substituting Tagalog lyrics for parts of the foreign hits. It caught on and became his trademark. His topselling first three albums, The Way We Were, RicoJ.Puno, and Spirit of Christmas, a series of singles which included “Kapalaran” (Fate), and his first solo performance at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines, Rico in Concert, with the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra, established him as the leading pop singer in the Philippines. His performances in the Philippines in such venues as the Araneta Coliseum and his first American tour in 1978 drew the largest audiences ever assembled by a Filipino artist during that period. He also appeared as Judas in the dinner-theater presentation of Jesus Christ Superstar in Filipino in 1971. Among his biggest hit records are the singles “Namamasyal pa sa Luneta na Walang Pera” (Strolling in the Luneta Without Any Money), sung to the strains of “The Way We Were,” 1976; “Kapalaran,” 1976; “Magkasuyo Buong Gabi” (All-night Tryst), 1979; “May Bukas Pa” (There’s Still Tomorrow), 1979; and “Together, Forever,” 1983; and the albums Rico J.Puno, 1976; Rico J. Puno, The Total Entertainer, 1977; and Together, Forever, 1983.

The highest paid entertainer in the country during the peak of his career, Puno is known as a total performer who appeals to all kinds of audiences. He has mixed something of Elvis Presley, Sammy Davis, Frank Sinatra, and Tom Jones in his style, but the end product is uniquely his own. He is acknowledged as having contributed a “new sound” to Philippine popmusic, which has been imitated everywhere and spawned a pop cult.

His film credits include Dr. Potpot Travels to the Moon, 1991, Tom & Jerry: Hindi Kami Hayop (Tom and Jerry: We Are Not Animals, 1993, Alyas Boy Tigas: Ang Probinsyanong Wais (Alyas Boy Tigas: The Smart Countryboy, 1998, Pakners (Partners), 2003, Who’s That Girl, 2011, and Instant Mommy, 2013. With his contemporaries Rey Valera and Hajji Alejandro, he began touring the country in 2002 and has released the live video production The Greatest Hits Live. As a host on television, he was part of Lunchdate, 1986-87, Chibugan Na (It’s Eating Time), 1994-95, and Pilipinas Win na Win (Philippines For the Win) and later Happy Yipee Yehey, 2010. He also played John Lloyd Cruz's fatherin ABS-CBN’s sitcom Home Sweetie Home, 2014, had a guest appearance in ABS-CBN's primetime drama FPJ's Ang Probinsyano (FPJ's The Countryboy ), 2017, and also served as one of the judges in Tawag ng Tanghalan sa It's Showtime (Call of the Stage in It's Showtime), 2018.

Only one year after he broke into the music scene, Puno was named Most Promising Entertainer of the Year in the Aliw Awards. In 1977, he was chosen Entertainer of the Year by the same award-giving body. In 1979, he was awarded as “The King of Tagalog Songs” by Veramil Promotions, and “Jukebox King” by BAMCI Promotions. In the same year, he interpreted the winning song “Lupa” (Earth) composed by Ernie dela Peña at the Tokyo Music Festival. Written byRosalinda Galang

QUIRINO, RICHIE (Richie Commans Quirino) b. Manila on 10 Dec 1955. Jazz artist, composer, author. The youngest child of National Artist for historical literature Carlos Lozada Quirino and novelist Liesel Commans Quirino, he studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music from 1975 to 1978, but transferred and then graduated cum laude in 1980 with a double major in professional music and audio recording from the Berklee College of Music in Boston, Massachusetts, USA.

Quirino has authored three books on jazz in the Philippines: Pinoy Jazz Traditions, 2004, which won the National Book Award (Music Category) in 2005; Mabuhay Jazz-Jazz in Postwar Philippines, 2008, which chronicled the development and evolution of jazz in the country; and Contemporary Jazz in the Philippines, 2011. Together with Collis Davis and Gus Lagman, he produced an 85-minute video documentary Pinoy Jazz: The Story of Jazz in the Philippines in 2006. In addition, he wrote the liner notes for Adobo Jazz Vol 1, a compilation CD, 2002, and Angel Peña’s big band album, Ugnayan (Collaboration), which was produced and conducted by Gerard Salonga in 2006.

As a composer, he is known for “To You My Heart’s Desire,” “Pistahan, When You’re Feeling Blue,” “Basilan” (which he co-composed with Angel Peña), “He Has Risen Again,” “The Truth Shall Set Us Free,” and “Krisdom.” The UP Jazz Ensemble under the baton of Rayben Maigue performed his compositions in 2002.

As a jazz music advocate, he has relentlessly encouraged listeners to appreciate Philippine jazz locally and internationally. Together with Angel Peña and Rayben Maigue, he spearheaded, from 2001 to 2004, the inclusion of over 40 original Filipino big band jazz compositions and arrangements in the repertoire of the UP Jazz Ensemble and that of UST Jazz Band, headed by Roger Llado. To bring together jazz aficionados and further hone and inspire Filipino talent, Quirino co-produced Adobo Jazz Vol 2 and Adobo Jazz Vol 3 Double CD, 2004, together with Rhany Torres. He co-founded the Jazz Society of the Philippines or Jazzphil with fellow enthusiasts.

As a percussionist, he participated in the launching of Guarana Bands CD Album, Musika Brasileira in 2007, and the Spirit of Samba in 2009. In 2013, he performed as drummer for the 6th Filipino-American Jazz Festival held in San Francisco, California. He was also a drummer, co-founder, and co-leader of noted jazz bands such as Destiny, Sunlight, Ambivalent Crowd, Oasis of Love, Executive Ensemble, Ciao, Blue in Green, Kind of Blue, Jr Cobb Jazz Chamber, Lampano Lounge Committee, Jazzphil Ensemble, Astral Jazz, and Guarana, a Brazilian jazz group.

Quirino is a member of the Audio Engineering Society (New York), Jazz Journalists Association, Philippine Musicians Guild, and the Musicological Society of the Philippines. Internationally, he has played Philippine jazz music and lectured about it at various festivals in Germany, The Netherlands, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, Taiwan, Singapore, China and the United States. Written byRaymundo Maigue

QUIRIT, JULIAN (Julian Israel Guloy Quirit) b. Tondo, Manila 9 Jul 1949. Violinist, conductor. His parents are Buenaventura Quirit and Eliza Guloy. He is married to Minerva Chavarria with whom he has four children. His youngest child, Johanna Eliza, was a child prodigy in violin. Quirit was a scholar of the MusicPromotionFoundationofthePhilippines, studying violin at the Philippine Women’s University Conservatory of Music under LuisValencia. At 13, he made his first public appearance playing Mendelssohn violin concerto with the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra, with Valencia as conductor. He received a Young Artists’ Foundation scholarship to study at the Juilliard School of Music in New York under Dorothy DeLay for violin and conducting under Sixten Ehrling.

In 1973, he won first prize in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) and performed in that year with the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra (MSO) conducted by Herbert Zipper. He also won in the Southeast Asian Violin Competition held in Singapore in 1973. From then on, he became soloist for various orchestras in the country, namely, the National Philharmonic Orchestra, UP Symphony Orchestra, and the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra. He represented the Philippines at the international music camp held in Melbourne, Australia in 1972, and was later awarded the chair of concertmaster for the Australian Youth Orchestra. In recognition of his talents, he was presented with a 1721 Guadagnini violin replica by the Australian government, the highest recognition given to a student in Australia. In 1975, he became one of the youngest members of the West Australian Symphony Orchestra and was appointed its deputy concertmaster. During the 150th anniversary of West Australia, he was heralded as one of the outstanding migrants who actively promoted and contributed to the arts, that is, music. He is currently resident conductor of the Australian Pops Orchestra and the Heidelberg Orchestra in Melbourne, as well as concertmaster, lead soloist, and conductor of Melbourne Musicians, a chamber orchestra. He founded and served as principal conductor of the Julian Quirit Orchestra, recognised by the Melbourne Music Council as the best youth orchestra in Australia in 1998. He also teaches in various schools in Australia such as Victoria College of Arts, University of Melbourne, Monash University, and the Presbyterian Ladies College.

His versatility as a conductor is also shown in his work for the Universal Pictures and MGM in Hollywood, USA. One of the movies he collaborated on was the film called Weeds in 1987, produced by De Laurentiis Entertainment Group (DEG). He also conducted the Australian Pops Orchestra for Kingsgate Films directed by John D. Hancock.

Quirit was the principal conductor of the now disbanded San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra in 2001-07. In 2005, he was invited to conduct for the Villach Festival in Vienna. About 17,000 people attended this open-air concert performance.

He currently resides in Australia, but comes home to conduct the PhilippinePhilharmonicOrchestra once in a while. Among the many international artists he had collaborated with are Luciano Pavarotti, Jose Careras, Dionisia “Donnie” Fernandez, Rachelle Gerodias, and Andion Fernandez. Written byRamon Jocsonupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

RANERA, HERMINIGILDO (Herminigildo Galang Ranera) b. Bangkal, Makati 2 May 1961. Conductor, composer, arranger, soloist, chamber musician, educator. Herminigildo belongs to a family of musicians. His father Pacifico Ranera, a retired navy, plays horn and his brothers, Edgar and Ramil, play trumpet and flute, respectively. His mother is Catalina Galang. His grandparents are owners of San Juan Nepomuceno Band in Malibay, Pasay City. His music career began early at age seven when his father taught him to play baritone. His musical talent manifested during high school years when he arranged and conducted music their band. He is married to Suzette Larena with whom he has two children.

Ranera obtained his bachelor of music degrees in trombone in 1983 and in theory in 1984 at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music. In 1987, he earned his master of music in conducting at the University of Colorado, USA, where he was a consistent dean’s lister. He obtained his doctorate degree in educational management from the Cagayan State University, Tuguegarao in 2009.

As a trombonist, tubist, and euphonium player, Ranera has been a featured soloist and chamber musician. He garnered prizes in the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) in the years 1982 and 1983. In 1998, he performed in the First Taiwan International Music Camp held at Taiwan Regional Development Institute. He was also awarded Outstanding Faculty in the Performing Arts Category by the Dangal ng UST in 2003 and Outstanding Artist in the Field of Music by the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan of the City of Manila in 2006.

As a composer and arranger, his song entry “Parangal ni Maria” (Homage to Mary) won first prize in the Marian Song Writing Competition in 1989. In 1990, his “Munting Kaibigan, Munting Kapayapaan” (Little Friend, Little Peace) won in the Children’s Composition Contest, NARRA, which was held at Philamlife Theater. In 1993, his art song titled “Tinig, Dilim at Pangitain” (Voice, Darkness, and Vision) won a prize in the Young Composers Composition Contest organized by the League of Filipino Composers. His compositions “Mabunying Reyna ng Palanyag” (Illustrious Queen of Palanyag), “Nagpayong Hymn,” and “AJ Dela Cruz Jingle” were published in 2010. He did an arrangement for the symphonic band, titled “Symphonic Winds,” of selected compositions by composers Nicanor Abelardo, Francisco Santiago, and Manuel Maramba, OSB. His orchestrations include “Filipino Kundimans,” which was recorded by the Moscow Philharmonic in 2002 and “Christmas Album: Filipino Christmas Songs,” which was recorded by the Warsaw Philharmonic Orchestra in 2003.

At present, he is the associate conductor of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. He is also the musical director and conductor of the following groups: PHILBANDA Wind Orchestra, UST Symphony Orchestra, UST Wind Orchestra, San Juan Nepomuceno Band in Pasay City, Knights of Columbus Council 6115 Choir, and the Philippine Coastguard Symphonic Band. In 1997, he conducted the California State University-Long Beach Symphony Orchestra and, in 2000, the Transylvania State Philharmonic Orchestra of Clij, Romania. He has also conducted the sarsuwela Something To Crow About by Alejandro Jose, which was staged in New York in 2004. In 2006, he conducted the UST Symphony Orchestra in a classical concert at the People’s Republic of China.

Ranera is an associate professor and department head for music education at the UST Conservatory of Music. In addition, he served as a visiting professor in National Taiwan Normal University, Taipei, Taiwan in 1989 and in California State University Long Beach in 1996. Written byCrisancti L. Macazo

REGINO, april boy (Dennis Regino) b. Manila 9 Apr 1969. Singer, songwriter, movie actor, television host. He is the eldest among three brothers. His father was a tricycle driver while his mother, a housewife. They lived as informal settlers along the train tracks of Manila. Before his singing career, he helped his parents earn a living by selling street snack food. He attended Grace Park Elementary School. In his childhood, he learned to play the guitar from his uncle. At 12 years of age, he joined amateur singing contests in nearby provinces such as Bulacan, Tarlac, and Pampanga. At 18 years old, he participated in mini-stage shows and applied for a singing job in Japan, eventually working there for eight years. In 1995, he married Madel Regino. They have a son, JC, his firstborn, who is also a singer, and a daughter, Charm.

In 1993, he decided to form the pop-rock group April Boys, along with his two brothers Vinggo and Jimmy, their mother serving as their producer. Radio commentator, Mike Enriquez, recognized the group’s talent and showed support by promoting their music on the radio.

By 1995, he went solo and launched his first album titled Umiiyak ang Puso Ko (My Heart is Crying), which immediately made it to number one on the radio request list in only a month’s time. 1996 saw him starring in a movie with Joey De Leon titled Ang Misis Kong Hoodlum (My Wife is a Hoodlum) and Takot Ako sa Darling Ko (I’m Scared of My Darling). 1997 was the year his next album Idol was released, which achieved triple platinum. For that popularity, he was given the monicker “Jukebox King” of the 90s. His succeeding album Jukebox Idol contains one of his more famous songs “Di Ko Kayang Tanggapin” (I Can’t Accept It). This received a diamond record award, selling more than a million copies.

He continued to produce more albums such as Salamat Sa Iyo (Thanks to You) and Super Idol, turning out a total of 13 albums. He also staged a major concert in the famed Araneta Coliseum and went into TV hosting with a noontime show. By 2005, he migrated to the United States and continued to work there as an entertainer to the Filipino-American community.

He came back to the Philippines in 2010 after a five-year hiatus and announced, after he signed a contract with Viva Records, that he will be working again in the Philippines.

April Boy’s prostrate cancer was made known to the public in 2011. He had it since 2009. He concealed the information for some time for fear that it might affect his singing career. In Dec 2013, he finally announced his retirement from his 20-year singing career because of his illness. He tearfully admitted that though he would have loved to continue on in his singing, he was physically tired and had to stop. April Boy continues to battle cancer at this time. His most recent show was a free concert to inspire and encourage the victims of typhoon Yolanda in Tacloban City.

Some of the most April Boy’s famous songs include “Di Ko Malilimutan” (I Won’t Forget), “Esperanza,” “Habang Buhay” (Lifetime), “Kailan Kaya” (When Will It Be?), “Kung Kailan Mahal” (When There Is Love), “Lihim na Pag-ibig” (Secret Love), “Madelyn Nag-iisang Ginto” (Madelyn, My Only Treasure), “Nagmamahal ng Tapat Sa ’Yo” (Loving You Faithfully), “Nanghihinayang Ako” (I Have Regrets), “Paano ang Puso Ko” (What About My Heart, Tagalog version of “What Am I Living For?”), “Pagmamahal at Pag-ibig” (Love), “Sa ’Yo Lamang” (All Yours), “Sayang Na Pagmamahal” (Wasted Love), “Umiibig Na Nga” (In Love Indeed), “Umiiyak ang Puso Ko,” “Ye Ye Vonnel,” and “Di Ko Kayang Tanggapin.” Written byJose Valenciano

REYES, LOUIE (Maria Luisa Pasco Reyes-de la Fuente) b. Manila 15 Mar 1951. Singer. She is the eldest child of Alejandro Reyes and Maria Leonila Pasco. She is married to former New Minstrels singer Cesar de la Fuente with whom she has two sons. She studied at the College of Holy Spirit from grade school through college. She received her degree in music education, with voice as minor, in 1972. She studied voice under Dolly Buencamino-Francia, Sr Giovianna, and later, JovitaFuentes.

Reyes began her singing career when she became part of a trio called Babsie, Chit, and Louie and recorded an album titled Chick under Vicor Records in 1968. In 1972, she joined the New Minstrels, releasing six albums with them. She was the group’s lead singer and arranger until 1977. In 1978, she went solo. Since then, she had numerous classical and jazz performances and concerts with singers such as international jazz artist Noel Pointer, Diana Reeves, and David Benoit. Her first album, It’s Time, was produced by Ivory Records in Manila. Reyes has also played lead roles on stage and theater productions such as Gomburza, 1982; Great White Way, 1983; Ewagan, 1984; and EDSA, 1986. She also appeared as Lady Thiang in the Australian production of The King and I, 1992. Aside from continuing to perform locally and abroad, she now teaches in the Arts Development School of Music, in Bellflower, California, USA.

For her role in The King and I, she won the Green Room Theater Award for Best Female Artist in a Supporting Role. She was also a prize-winner in numerous competitions such as Asian Australian Song Competition, 1976; Pacific Song Contest with Eugene Villaluz, 1980; Seoul Song Festival, grand prize, 1982; and Golden Kite Festival, 1985. In 1999, she was chosen as one of The Ten Outstanding Women of the Nation. Written byEdna Marcil M. Martinezupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

REYES, REYNALDO (Reynaldo Gutierrez Reyes) b. Alitagtag, Batangas 12 Dec 1933. d. 15 Feb 2016. Pianist. One of seven children of Telesforo Reyes, former mayor of Alitagtag, and Brigida Gutierrez, he is married to Cristina Giorgili with whom he has a son. He started playing the piano at the age of five and took formal lessons three years later. At 12, when he was a high school student at the University of Santo Tomas, he made his debut during a music festival at the school. In 1950, he graduated with a bachelor of music, major in piano, then studied at the Paris Conservatoire in 1953 as a French government scholar.

In 1954, he won first prize in a chamber music competition sponsored by Radio Stuttgart. Later, the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines gave him a scholarship to the Peabody Conservatory of Music, where he earned a master of music degree and an artist’s diploma in piano in 1960.

Reyes pioneered in programming repertoires according to a particular composer, form, or genre, like his All-Beethoven, All-Copland, All-Greek piano music, Albeniz’s complete Iberia Suite, and the All-Variations (Faure and Tchaikovsky) recitals. He premiered Buenaventura’s First Piano Concerto, 1976, and Pajaro’s Piano Sonata, 1977.

He resided in Baltimore, Maryland. He has taught at the Peabody Conservatory of Music, Towson State University, and the Garrison Forest School and goes on concert tours. Yearly he returned to the Philippines to give master lessons and solo recitals. Reyes and his former student, Ingrid Sala Santamaria had performed biennially to varied audiences in unconventional concert venues in the Philippines and Southeast Asia, such as public parks, basketball courts, ancestral homes, as part of their Romantic Piano Concerto Journey (RPCJ) which was launched in 2001. It was his advocacy to educate diverse audiences on the influence of classical music to transform lives, and he established the Reynaldo Reyes Scholarship Fund in 2004 to help achieve this purpose.

In 1957, he won the Premier Prix in piano, the only Filipino to win this prize. Reyes won several international piano competitions, including second prize at the Busoni International Piano Competition in Italy, and fourth prize at the Marguerite Lang-Jacques Thibaud International Piano Competition in Paris, 1965. Reyes was chosen University of the Philippines Musician of the Year in 1957, 1961, and 1965, and Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) awardee for music in 1977.

Beginning 1990, he served as the official accompanist for the Metropolitan Opera Company’s regional auditions in Washington, DC. He was honored by the Aliw Awards in 2008 for his outstanding service to the Philippines. In 2010, Reyes was conferred the President’s Award for Distinguished Service to the University by the Towson University in Maryland where he served as a full professor since 1978, rising from the ranks of being an adjunct faculty member of the university’s Music Department in 1962. Written byFelizidad Z. Reyes and Julie Ann Hallazgoupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

REYES-AMOROSO, LILIA b. Santa Maria, Bulacan 4 Nov 1936. d. 3 Apr 2001. Singer. Born to Jose and Pilar Reyes, she earned her associate in arts degree in music, major in voice, at the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music. After majoring in voice and piano at the Philippine Women’s University in 1955, she took further studies in Italy and Austria. In 1958 she obtained her master’s diploma in music at the Conservatorio Nazionale Di Santa Cecilia in Rome. Reyes held 75 concerts in France and performed in the international festivals of Spoleto, Salzburg, Autunno Napoletano, Maggio Musicale Fiorentino, Settimana Senese, and Sagra Umbra. She was a regular concert artist for Radio Televizione Italiana, ORTF in Paris, and was featured on radio in ORF in Salzburg and Vienna, BBC in London, Belgian Radio in Bruxelles, CBS in New York, Radio Mexicana, and Radio Vaticana. She was guest soprano in the revival of Donizetti’s Il Futioso Ai Isola de San Domingo and Chailly’s Markheim, both under the direction of Gian-Carlo Menotti. She was soloist for conductors Carlo Maria Giullini, Zubin Mehta, Nino Sanzogno, Peter Maag, Raymond Leppard, Thomas Schippers, Jozef Krips, Mario Rossi, Massino Pradella, and Franco Ferrara.

In 1969, Reyes took the lead in Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: The Golden Salakot), the inaugural presentation of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. She also performed at the inauguration of the National Arts Center of the Philippines in 1976. She was Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company’s solo singer during its first world tour. In 1975, she became the first soprano to do a recording with the newly restored Las Piñas Bamboo Organ. Written byRamon Jocson

REYES-LOZADA, ZENAS (Zenas Jugo Reyes-Lozada) b. Manila 7 Jan 1939. Pianist. She is the daughter of Victor Reyes and Felicidad Jugo. She is married to Remberto Lozada with whom she has three children. She holds a music degree in piano and another in music sciences from St Scholastica’s College. She took up further studies in popular electronic organ at the Yamaha Music School in 1971 and classical pipe organ with German organist Wolfgang Oehms from 1976-79. She taught piano at St Scholastica’s from 1960 to 1985. Reyes-Lozada has performed all over the country and in educational and concert tours in the United States, Europe, and Asia. She was a soloist of the Manila Symphony Orchestra at the Concert at the Park in 1978 and 1980. She premiered Alfredo Buenaventura’s third piano concerto, Determination, with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1980. She played Lucrecia Kasilag’s Divertissement for Piano and Orchestra both here and abroad, and recorded it in 1979. In 2008, she was featured in a concert Marimba Piano, A Thanksgiving Concert at Ateneo de Zamboanga University. Reyes-Lozada has received grants from the French, British, Austrian, and Spanish governments, as well as several awards, among them, the Outstanding Pianist Award from Zonta International, 1976, 1977, and 1978; the St Scholastica’s Music Alumnae Award of Excellence, 1979; and the Insigne de Chevalier dans l’Ordre des Arts et Lettres from the French government, 1990. From 1980 to 1992, she was the artistic director of Puerta Real Evenings, a project of the Intramuros Administration. At present, she is the cultural director of the Quezon City Circle. She received the Performance as Solo Artist Award, Outstanding Music Centennial Awards, St Scholastica’s College, 2012. Written byAntonio C. Hilaupdated by Connie Ladrido

RIGOR, SNAFFU (Roberto Nicolas Rigor) b. Makati, Metro Manila 8 Aug 1946 d. Manila 4 Aug 2016. Composer, band vocalist, record producer. He was the son of Conrado Rigor and Erlinda Nicolas. He was married to Ana Marie Earnshaw with whom he had three children. He studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) from elementary school to college. He took up architecture at the UP in 1964 and finished the course at Adamson University in 1968. In the 1970s, he sang with Ramrods, Cinderella, Backdoor and Blackbuster, and The 70s Superband with Nonoy Tan, Rey Magtoto, Monet Gaskell, Mon Espia, and Mallilin brother. Starting out as a member of the Vicor-Pioneer Records Houseband for Recording, he became recording supervisor for Vicor Music Corp, 1970; executive producer for its Sunshine Label, 1971-78; vice-president for production of Jem Records Corp, 1978-79; vice-president for A & R, Blackgold Records, 1979-80; and Auditions and Research Director, P & D Music Corp, Dyna Records, 1980-82. He became a freelance record producer in 1982.

Rigor produced a number of outstanding records for such performers as the Apo HikingSociety, Tito, Vic and Joey, PilitaCorrales, Sampaguita, SharonCuneta, Sheryl Cruz, Vina Morales, Andrew E., and Donna Cruz. As songwriter, his first success was “T.L. Ako Sa ’Yo” (I’m Truly in Love With You), 1975, sung by Cinderella. He wrote the lyrics of ErnaniCuenco’s “BatosaBuhangin” (Stone in the Sand), 1976, and has also composed popularsongs, such as “Macho Gwapito” (Handsome Macho); “Boy, I Love You,” 1974; “Bulag, Pipi at Bingi” (Blind, Mute, and Deaf), 1979; “Illusions,” 1982; “Heto na Naman” (Here I Go Again), 1988; “Mr. Dreamboy,” 1989; “Larawang Kupas” (Faded Image), 2000; “Paano ang Puso Ko” (What About My Heart), 2001 (an adaptation of Chuck Willis’s “What Am I Living For?), interpreted by singers Rico J. Puno, CherieGil, FreddieAguilar, GaryValenciano, Claire de la Fuente, Sheryl Cruz, and Jerome Abalos, and April Boy Regino, respectively.

“Bulag, Pipi at Bingi” won the grand prize at the Second Metro Manila Popular Music Festival or Metropop and was first runner-up as Best Composition at the Seoul Song Festival in 1979. His composition, “Illusions,” garnered second prize at the Second ASEAN Popular Song Festival in 1982. In 1989, his album Sheryl received the Platinum Record Award from WEA Records, while the song “Himig ng Kalikasan” (Nature’s Song) which he composed and produced won the Awit Awards Best Folk Pop Recording in 1998. Written byRosalinda Galangupdated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

RIVERA, FLORA (Flora Zarco Rivera) b. 2 Nov 1918. d. 5 Sep 1998. Pianist, choral conductor, educator. She was born to schoolteachers and church workers Pablo Zarco and Marciana Morales and had Presbyterian organist and choral conductor, Viola Rich Smith, as music teacher at a young age. She was married to Manuel Traico Rivera, an orthopedic surgeon, and they had three children, including Elena Rivera Mirano, singer and choral director, and Robin Daniel Rivera, composer and teacher.

At the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, she completed her diploma in piano, cum laude, 1939, and bachelor’s degree in piano, 1940. She was a student of Rodolfo Cornejo, Francisco Santiago, and Dolores Heras in piano and of Antonio Molina, Rosita Concepcion Sandejas, and Antonino Buenaventura in theory. Immediately after World War II, she became the first foreign scholar of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, an award created for her and later enjoyed by many students from all over the world. She finished a master’s degree in music, 1947, at the Westminster Choir College in Princeton, New Jersey and trained under Carl Friedberg and Ernesto Berumen in piano, Mary Krimmel in pipe organ, William Pffeifer and Virginia Switten in voice and her mentor, the English conductor, John Finley Williamson, in choral conducting. She served as director of the School of Music of Silliman University, 1940 to 1941, chairman of the Department of Sacred Music of Philippine Christian College, 1947 to 1949, and the Department of Music of the Philippine Women’s University from 1942 to 1945. At the same time she served as director of the Central Church Choir, 1943, and the Ellinwood Church Choir, 1947 to 1949. She was responsible for the professionalization of the ministry of music in the Protestant Church, organizing choirs and leading workshops, setting standards and instituting salaries and honoraria for professional musicians working in the church.

Returning to the Philippines, she was at the forefront of the modernist movement in Philippine music. She was the soloist for the Philippine premieres of the piano concertos by Aram Katchaturian and Arthur Bliss in 1948 and 1955, respectively, both conducted by Antonino Buenaventura with the Manila Municipal Symphony.

In 1951, she joined the faculty of the UP Conservatory of Music. She and her colleagues Eliseo Pajaro, Jose Maceda, and Ruby Mangahas, succeeded in upgrading the Conservatory into a College with a full range of university level curricular offerings. She and other colleagues—notably, Aurelio Estanislao and Andrea Veneracion—organized the Diliman Choral Guild, with her as director. The group, which embodied the spirit of ecumenism, featured a joint choir of students and faculty from the Protestant Church of the Risen Lord and the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice. Together with their church leaders, Fr Patricio Lim and Rev James Palm, the choir performed large works such as the Passion According to Saint Matthew, The Passion According to Saint John, and the Magnificat by Johann Sebastian Bach. Featured performers included the rabbi of the Jewish Synagogue in Manila, Estanislao, Veneracion, as well as then students, Elmo Makil, Noel Velasco, Mauricia Borromeo, and in the children’s choir were Ryan Cayabyab and Joel Navarro.

She directed the Philippine Male Chorale, 1958-61; the UP Male Glee Club, 1961-63; the Chorus Classes of the UP College of Music, 1951-83; the Church of the Risen Lord Choir, 1952-60; the UP Mixed Choir (later UP Concert Chorus) with her student and friend Reynaldo Paguio, 1967-69, and finally, the UP Cherubim and Seraphim, 1971-98, the official children’s choir of the University of the Philippines. As conductor, she encouraged many Philippine composers including Lucio San Pedro, Ramon Santos, and Antonio Regalario to write for the medium of the children’s’ choir.

In the area of music education, she was dedicated to the upgrading of the skills and capacities of musicians all over the Philippines. She and a group of friends active in the choral movement, notably Veneracion, Paguio, and David Yap came together to organize National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) in 1972. She was the director of the Annual Summer Workshop of the organization from 1974 to 1993, travelling to all the parts of the Philippines, adjudicating choral competitions, organizing and directing both regional and national workshops until 1996. Written byElena Rivera Mirano

RIVERA MIRANO, ELENA (Elena Zarco Rivera Mirano) aka Lenette Mirano. b. New Jersey, USA 22 Jul 1951. Her parents are Manuel Traico Rivera, a medical doctor, and Flora Zarco, music professor at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. She is married to the late Rolando Caringal Mirano. She is a retired professor of art studies at the UP College of Arts and Letters in Diliman, where she was the dean from 2009-15.

She has a bachelor of arts degree in English, cum laude, a master of arts degree in comparative literature, and a doctorate degree in Philippine Studies from UP, as well as a master of arts in humanities from Stanford University. As a researcher on traditional culture of Southern Tagalog region, she has authored 100">Subli: One Dance in Four Voices/Subli: Isang Sayaw sa Apat na Tinig which won the National Book Award, Art Book category in 1989; Ang Mga Tradisyonal na Musikang Pantinig sa Lumang Bauan, Batangas (Traditional Vocal Music in the Old Bauan, Batangas) which won Gawad Chancellor in UP Diliman, Best Book in Humanities category in 1998; and The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay which won Alfonso Ongpin Award and National Book Award, Art Book category in 2009.

She served as research director for the Philippine Program at the 1998 Smithsonian Folklife Festival in Washington, DC and the Batangas City Museum, 2006.

As vocalist, she was the featured soprano of the recording album, Kumintang: Awitin ng mga Tagalog na Taga-Batangas (Kumintang: Songs of the Tagalog From Batangas), which she produced for the Diamond Jubilee of UP. A one-woman show developed for the launch of this album was subsequently toured by the Cultural Center of the Philippines as part of its Outreach Program in November 1986.

She is the current musical director of the UP Cherubim and Seraphim, the official children’s choir of UP. Under her directorship, she commissioned the theater piece, Awit ni Pulau (Song of Pulau), 1996, with music by Ramon P. Santos and libretto by Edgardo Maranan, who served as its producer. As children’s choirmaster, she conceptualizes and directs the group’s annual summer program of workshops and concert tours.

She is a member of the Phi Kappa Phi Honor Society, 1971, and the Mu Phi Epsilon Honor Fraternity, 1979.

In 2001, she was designated laureate of the prestigious Prince Claus Fund for Culture and Development of the Netherlands in recognition of her achievements. In 2007, the National Research Council of the Philippines conferred on her the Achievement Award in humanities.

She has read papers in national as well as international conferences and has participated in workshops, festivals and conventions. She was the recipient of various Professorial Chairs such as the Onofre D. Corpuz Diamond Jubilee Professorial Chair, 1992-93; Sigma Delta Phi Professorial Chair, 2000-01 and 2005-06; and the UP Centennial Chair, 2010. Written byAntonio C. Hila

RIVERMAYA Rivermaya is a rock band formed in 1994 with the original roster of members consisting of Jessie Gonzales, vocals; Kenneth Ilagan, guitar; Nathan Azarcon, bass; Rome Velayo, drums; and Rico Blanco, keyboards. In 1994, Bamboo Mañalac joined the group and eventually replaced Gonzales as vocalist following a series of grueling practice sessions. With Mañalac, the band started to produce original songs such as “Ulan” (Rain), “214,” and “Awit ng Kabataan” (Song of Youth) for demo recordings. Over the last 20 years following the departure of the band’s influential members such as Blanco who composed many of the band’s hit singles and the group’s lead vocalist Mañalac, the group underwent five changes in its membership. Both Blanco and Mañalac have since launched their own careers and continue to be active in the rock music scene.

The group produced several huge singles such as “Ulan,” “214,” “Himala” (Miracle), “Kisapmata” (Blink of an Eye), “Elesi” (Rotor Blades), “Hinahanap-Hanap Kita” (Constantly Seeking You), “Umaaraw, Umuulan” (Sunny and Rainy), “Alab ng Puso” (Flaming Heart), “You’ll Be Safe Here,” “Balisong,” “Isang Bandila” (One Flag), “Sumigaw” (Shout), and “Sugal ng Kapalaran” (Gamble of Destiny). The band released several best-selling albums in the 1990s such as Rivermaya, 1994; Trip, 1996; Atomic Bomb, 1997; It’s Not Easy Being Green, 1999; Free, 2000; Tuloy ang Ligaya (The Fun Goes On), 2001; Between the Stars and the Waves, 2003; Isang Ugat, Isang Dugo (One Root, One Blood), 2006; Buhay (Life), 2008; Closest Thing To Heaven, 2009; and their most recent release, Panatang Makabanda (A Vow to the Band), 2013, which also includes the single which appeals to the Filipino sense of nationalism, “Kailan Ka Magigising, Pilipinas?”(When Will You Wake Up, Philippines?) Feted both locally and abroad, Rivermaya performed in the Asian Awards with the single “You’ll Be Safe Here” (originally created for ABS-CBN’s TV series Spirits) to the accompaniment of the Thailand Royal Symphony Orchestra for the live performance.

Rivermaya’s “Umaaraw, Umuulan” (Sun’s Up, Rain Falls) won Best Alternative Recording in the 2002 Awit Awards. “You’ll Be Safe Here,” the theme song of the ABS-CBN primetime series Spirits, received the 2006 Awit Awards Best TV Theme Song Recording and Music Video of the Year.

Rivermaya remains one of the most influential and popular rock bands in the local music scene. Its current members are Ryan Peralta, drums; Mike Elgar, guitar, vocals, and keyboard; Norby David, vocals and bass; and Mark Escueta, vocals, guitar, and percussion. Written byLara T. Mendoza

ROCES, JOSEPHINE (Josephine Roces Chavez) b. Manila 19 May 1962. Singer, stage actor. Her parents are Marcos Roces and Marietta Adriano. She began to sing professionally at age 19 after she won first place in the 1981 National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA). A business graduate of the Maryknoll College in 1983, she went to the American Conservatory of Music in Chicago, Illinois as a scholar in voice training under Neva Bailey and Eric Weisner, concertmaster of the Chicago Lyric Opera Company. After graduating from the Conservatory and winning its commencement competition in 1987, she returned to the Philippines and was soon recognized as one of the country’s finest mezzo-sopranos.

As a soloist, she performed in the CCP Filipino Artists Series in 1988 and in various outreach and campus tours sponsored by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). From 1988 to 1992, she hosted Paco Park Presents, and within that span of time was also a frequent performer in Malacañan during the presidencies of Cory Aquino and Fidel Ramos. She held two concerts in 1992: Touching Fire at the CCP Little Theater Lobby and An Affair to Remember at PCIBank’s Francisco Santiago Hall. She was featured on several occasions in DZFE-FM’s Culture Carousel, Ryan Ryan Musikahan, Concert at the Park, and Paco Park Presents. She held several concerts in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and has also performed in the International Bamboo Organ Festival and the Metropolitan Theater. In 1996, she created a show titled Cartas de Amor (Love letters) for the Filipino Artist Series, to commemorate the 100th death anniversary of Jose Rizal. She also produced a CD titled El Alma Filipina (The Filipino Soul), which features a selection of kundiman, in 1998.

She appeared in the following musicals: as the Baker’s Wife in Into the Woods, Maria Clara in Ryan Cayabyab’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), Mabel in Pirates of Penzance, and the young wife of Sweeney Todd in Sweeney Todd. She also sang the lead role in Peter Brooks’ The Story of Carmen, Yum Yum in The Mikado, and Estrella in Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness). She also played the role of Leonor Rivera, and since then have had 30 performances to date, including two in the United States and three in Canada.

For Repertory Philippines, she portrayed the role of Nora in A Doll’s House, Mrs Kate Keller in The Miracle Worker, Celia Coplestone in The Cocktail Party, and Solange Lemercier in The Maids.

In 2004 Josephine moved to Canada, and has since been based in Mississauga, a suburb of Toronto. Her last performance was at the Kalayaan Cultural Community Centre in Mississauga on 30 Nov 2014. She is also a member of the Ispira Singers and a cantor at the St Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian and Rosalinda Galangupdated by James C. Diaz

RODRIGUEZ, CELESTINO (Celestino Lasala Rodriguez) aka Nyor Tinoy b. Bogo, Cebu 11 May 1872. Composer, essayist. He is the son of landowners Jose Rodriguez and Vicenta Lasala, and uncle of playwright Buenaventura Rodriguez. He obtained his bachelor of arts degree at the Ateneo de Manila in 1892, then studied at the Universidad de Barcelona and the Universidad Central de Madrid, where he finished law in 1900. During the 1896 Revolution, Rodriguez was appointed secretary of a Philippine revolutionary committee formed in Madrid. He later moved to Hong Kong and joined groups involved in support and liaison work for the Philippine revolution. He returned to the Philippines in 1902, passed the bar, and established his practice in Cebu City. In 1904 he was elected municipal president of Cebu; later, he became a member of the Philippine Assembly, 1907-09; senator, 1916-22 and 1922-28; and representative of Cebu’s first district, 1935-38.

Rodriguez was also a composer. He wrote songs for the plays of Vicente Sotto, Buenaventura Rodriguez, and Florentino Borromeo. Two of his most popular songs are “Salilang” and “Dalagang Pilipinhon” (Filipino Maiden), done for the plays Salilang and Mini, respectively, by Buenaventura Rodriguez. He also composed a balitaw entitled “Junto al Pasig” (Beside the Pasig).

Rodriguez wrote two books: Enlazando Con Fines (Joining Boundaries), an undated compilation of his essays on his travels in Europe and America, with notes on the theatrical performances he saw and Episodios Nacionales: Horas Tragicas de Mi Pueblo (National Episodes: Tragic Hours of My Country), 1947, an account of the Japanese Occupation, which puts emphasis on the controversy over guerrilla atrocities. Written byResil B. Mojares

ROMERO, REDENTOR L. (Redentor Ligot Romero) b. Manila 23 Aug 1929. d. Manila 28 Mar 2001. Conductor, violinist, composer. He was born to lawyer Ramon Romero and Maria Ligot. He was married to Dolores Garcia with whom he had two children. His father played the violin, exposed his five children to music early, and dreamed of a concert career for them. Redentor and three siblings studied the violin under noted teachers such as Juan Asprec, BonifacioAbdon, and violin virtuoso ErnestoVallejo. A sister chose to study piano. Redentor was six when he started playing the violin and at 14 he played with a jazz band. In 1951, he obtained his teacher’s diploma from the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music, and in 1955, from the San Francisco Conservatory of Music. He took up special and postgraduate studies at the San Francisco State Conservatory in California, Mills College in Oakland, and the Music Academy of the West in Santa Barbara. He was the student of Naoum Blinder in San Francisco, and attended master classes conducted by Jascha Heifetz. At 18, he was concertmaster of the Honolulu Symphony Orchestra. He also served as concertmaster or assistant concertmaster of other American orchestras, like the Berkeley Symphony Orchestra. At 20, he became a conductor.

As an international conductor, Romero had conducting stints in five continents, from Carnegie Hall to the Bolshoi. He made 15 tours of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and repeat tours of Europe, the United States, Canada, New Zealand, Australia, Mexico, South America, and Asia. He conducted practically all major Russian orchestras and some of the world’s leading orchestras like the Royal Philharmonic, London Philharmonic Orchestra, Warsaw Philharmonic Orchestra, Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra, Adelaide Symphony Orchestra, Guangzhou Symphony Orchestra, Kiev Philharmonic, Novosibirsk Symphony Orchestra, Taiwan National Symphony Orchestra, Salonica State Orchestra, Auckland Symphonia, New York Symphony, American Symphony Orchestra, Athens State Orchestra, Mexico State Orchestra, and Sophia Philharmonic. In 1996, he was invited to conduct for the Bucharest Jeunesses Musicales Orchestra in the Jeunesses Musicales International Music Competition held at Bucharest Romania. He brought the Moscow City Ballet to debut in the Philippines and conducted it with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in 1998 and 2000. The diplomatic relations between China and the Philippines was commemorated with respective concerts in 2000, with him conducting the Beijing Philharmonic Orchestra and Xiamen Symphony Orchestra.

As a composer and arranger, his work Philippine Portraits, a 15-minute work that utilizes various Philippine folk tunes both of the mountain provinces and the Muslims of the south, has been recorded by the London Philharmonic Orchestra under his directorship and was released in 1980 under the album title Redentor Romero conducts the Moscow Symphony Orchestra, London Philharmonic Orchestra, Royal Philharmonic Orchestra. A compilation of his musical arrangements was also recorded by the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra with him conducting in the album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Passion), 1996. He recorded Philippine jazz music with the All-Star Philippine Jazz Band, with him playing the violin.

Romero founded the National Philharmonic Orchestra in 1961 and directed it for 40 years. Some prominent soloists that the orchestra accompanied include Yevgeny Malinin, Philippe Entremont, Vladimir Spivakov, Valery Klimov, Malcolm Frager, Vladimir Krainev, Gary Graffman, Leonid Kogan, Janos Starker, Nelly Miricioiu, Raizza Bobriniova, Stephanie Chase, Susan Star, Paul Badura Skoda, and Gidon Kremer. He was also an impresario who has brought to the country more than 300 musical artists some of whom are Ju Jin, Anna Iarovaia, Alexandru Tomescu, and Anastasia Chebotareva.

He authored a book titled Redentor Romero: An American Affair which was published by Orro Publishing, Manila in 1976.

Romero was cited by Asia Magazine as one of the 24 Most Outstanding Young Men in the Philippines in 1963. He was also cited Most Distinguished Alumnus and Most Oustanding Silver Jubilarian by Arellano High School. He received a TAWID Award from the Ilocano Heritage Foundation and a Century Award from Laoag City in 1985. Written byAntonio C. Hilaupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

ROSAL, CONCHING (Conchita Rosal-Pimentel) b. San Jose, Batangas 8 Dec 1926. d. Quezon City 6 Dec 1985. Singer. She was born to Eusebio and Soledad Rosal, and married lawyer-impresario Luis Pimentel. She started singing at the age of six as a church soloist in the San Jose Church in Batangas. She also loved to sing while her mother sold fish at the market, delighting listeners with her Filipino songs, notably “AngMaya” (The Sparrow). Later she studied voice at the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music where she became a favorite student of noted professor Lourdes Corrales de Razon and a classmate of SylviaLaTorre. Rosal further honed her craft on her own by studying and imitating other singers. In the late 1960s, she took advanced studies in the United States under Dean Verchines, coach to leading artists of the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera.

Rosal’s first performance on stage was in DalagangBukid (Country Maiden), 1950, at the Far Eastern University (FEU) Auditorium. She began her rise to prominence when she won the Elizalde Family Hour talent search in 1952. She learned acting skills while playing Sally in Herbert and TrudlDubsky-Zipper’s production of Die Fledermaus. She was singing in the Manila Symphony Society Chorus when the Zippers cast her as Carmen in the Tagalog version of Bizet’s opera. First presented in 1956 at the FEU Auditorium, the Tagalog Carmen, set in 19th-century Binondo, was a huge success and brought Rosal her first taste of fame in the opera world. Later on, her memorable performances in the Philippine production of Madame Butterfly, 1967, and Aida, 1971, established her as one of the country’s top opera singers. She also starred in La Gioconda and sang the lead role in the sarsuwela, AngKiri (The Flirt).

Rosal’s spinto voice enabled her to sing both dramatic and lyric roles and to execute an operatic repertoire ranging from very light sarsuwela to Carmen for mezzo-soprano. She was also famous for her beautiful rendition of kundiman of which she made several recordings. Together with SylviaLaTorre, she popularized the light classics in mini-concerts at the PhilamlifeAuditorium. She was well known over the radio and later on television.

During a musical career spanning more than three decades, Rosal was hailed as one of the Philippines’ great sopranos. Her last operatic performance was in Aida in 1981. She made her last public appearance in the country in a concert with Sylvia La Torre entitled May Rosal at Torre in 1982. Then she went on a concert tour of the United States in 1983 to raise funds for the Dipolog Church. At this time she was already battling cancer, which led to her death in 1985. Just before she died, she was engaged in a project to record various renditions of “Ave Maria” of which she was able to record only five. Her original Villar long-playing album, Immortal Kundiman of the Philippines, was reissued by the same company in 2003. Written by Rosalinda Galang

ROXAS, FRANCISCO (Francisco Arias Roxas) b. 1851. d. Bagumbayan 11 Jan 1897. Violinist, composer. Francisco belonged to one of the richest creole families since the late 18th century Spanish Philippines, the Roxases, who owned a vast network of businesses like the Ayalas and the Zobels. His parents were Juan Roxas and Vicenta Arias. He was the grandson of Antonio, the brother of Domingo Roxas (1782-1843) who played a crucial role in exploiting early 19th century Philippine economy. Francisco was married to Maria Elio with whom he had six children. He was engaged in business as a shipping agent and ship supplies dealer. As member of the Camara de Comercio de Manila, honorary councilor for civil administration, and member of the governing board of Banco Español Filipino, he was an influential figure in the city. In 1896, he was arrested for alleged involvement in the revolution—a move fabricated by Andres Bonifaco after failing to get Francisco’s financial support. All his properties were confiscated by the government, and he was shot together with other martyrs on Bagumbayan field the following year.

Aside from his business, Roxas was involved in the performing arts. Being a business tycoon, he was one of the patrons of San Juan del Monte Orchestra, providing food to the musicians and allowing them to use his house for rehearsals. He was a well-known violinist during his time and studied music with Jose Estella, based on the account of Felix Roxas, a cousin, who witnessed that Francisco was having music lessons with Estella in Francisco’s house on the night of his arrest in Aug 1896. Some of Francisco’s compositions are remembered. Three of his musical compositions which have been identified by Alfredo Roa are “Florencia,” a pas-de-quatre, “Magnificat,” and “Ave Maria.”with additional notes by Jose S. Buenconsejo. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang

RUBIO, HILARION (Hilarion Francisco Rubio) b. Bacoor, Cavite 21 Oct 1902. d. Bacoor, Cavite 28 Dec 1985. Composer, conductor. He was born to Crispino Rubio and Faustina Francisco. Rubio had four children with his first wife, Saturnina Lina. His second marriage to Angela Legaspi bore him a son. His first music lessons were with Amando Buencamino, Aglipayan chaplain and officer of the Philippine Constabulary. At the age of eight, he was a clarinetist for the Bacoor band and composed his first piece. He studied at the Manila North High School and obtained his associate in arts degree from Far Eastern University in 1927. After working briefly, he went back to school and earned a teacher’s diploma in science and composition from the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music in 1933. From 1937 to 1960, Rubio was a conductor for the National Opera Company. He conducted nine operas, was involved with two major ballet productions, and served as choral conductor for several schools and civic organizations. He also played in several city bands and orchestras providing background music for silent films. He also wrote articles for American music publications and local dailies.

Rubio taught at private music schools, was director of the Centro Escolar University Conservatory of Music in 1944-45, and became full professor at the UP Conservatory of Music in 1936-1937. He founded and was the first president of the Philippine Bandmasters Association and was vice-president of the Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas or PASAMBAP. He was a charter member of the LeagueofFilipinoComposers and a member of the band associations of London and Washington DC.

Among his major works are To the Filipino Youth, a cantata, 1951; Symphony for Greatness, 1966; and Panamin, a concerto for cello, 1970. He also composed music for movies like Kundiman, Palaboy ng Diyos (God’s Wanderer), and Kaban ng Tipan (Treasure Chest), 1939. Written byFelizidad Z. Reyes and Julie Ann Hallazgo

SACLAG, ALONZO (Alonzo Saclag) b. Lubuagan, Kalinga 4 Aug 1942. Kalinga musician, dancer, and performance artist. Saclag is also a cultural worker who advocates for the continuity of Kalinga culture in modern contexts. As expected of someone who grew up in a village in which culture was learned face-to-face among kindreds, Alonzo Saclag was exposed to Lubuagan music traditions that are deeply shared collectively and that have indissoluble link to calendrical and life cycle rituals. He learned his particular Kalinga culture by imitation, mastering instrumental music and dance, the latter of which is an essential ingredient in village ceremonies being a profound expression of sociability in a closely-knit community.

As a passionate advocate of his own cultural heritage, Saclag had extolled members of his community to preserve their traditional material culture, archaeological sites, and even re-invented a new form of bodong (peace pact) in which customary retribution or justice is not applied at the tribal group level but is individually addressed. Clearly a modern subject with an individual consciousness, Saclag’s aspiration to move his culture beyond static tradition is manifest is his advocacies. He convinced the provincial government of Kalinga to convert and finance the transformation of an abandoned Capitol Building into a museum of heritage, which is now a branch of the National Museum. Moreover, in 2009, he founded a School of Living Tradition that was partly supported by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

He also tirelessly campaigned in schools to press the issue on maintaining a strong ethnic identity despite the modern origin of the institution of formal schooling, so much so that he introduced the practice of children wearing the Kalinga costume during important events like graduation ceremonies and even during the Catholic rite of first communion. Another innovation that was consistently a part of his effort to bolster indigenous expressions has been mission of intensifying the singing of folk songs in Kalinga classrooms and, remarkably, putting up skits and other artistic performances that mix old and new elements in a number of schools. In addition, he aspired for the broadcast of traditional Kalinga music alongside contemporary music in the local radio station.

To concretize his effort in moving his culture in a sustainable manner in modern contexts, he founded the Kalinga Budong Dance Troupe where he teaches the youth their local music and dance. Since this dance company now tours in cities beyond the village, i.e., it now circulates beyond its traditional place of origin, it is envitable that artistic hybridity has resulted in Saclag’s projects.

For his artistry, cultural advocacy, and influence, Saclag was conferred the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan in 2000. Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

SACLO, JESS (Jesus Canares Saclo) b. Villaba, Leyte 15 Jan 1929. Composer. Born to Nemesio Saclo and Agrifina Canares, he studied at the Tacloban Elementary School, the University of Southern Philippines High School, and Leyte Colleges, where he dropped out after three months.

In 1965, Saclo composed two songs, “My, Oh, Why” and “I’ve Come to My Senses,” which he produced with the help of a friend after they had been rejected by the recording companies. The records sold well, and led to a job offer from Dyna Records. He left his job as account executive at the The Philippines Herald and became production manager at Dyna from 1966 to 1971. He composed a total of 378 songs for the company, among them such hit songs as “Mama” (sung by Chedeng Cardinez), “Had I Known It” (PilitaCorrales), “I Know” (Eddie Peregrina), “Ting-A-Ling” (Pauline Sevilla), “Hear My Prayer” (Carmen Soriano), “My Wishes” (DiomedesMaturan), “Leave Me Alone” (Stevenson Morris), and “Sway to the Left, Sway to the Right” (Merci Molina). In 1982, he transferred to WEA (now Universal) Records and worked there as technical assistant. Written byRosalinda Galang

SACRAMENTO, LUCINO (Lucino Tinio Sacramento) b. Licab, Nueva Ecija 30 Jun 1908. d. Los Angeles, USA 25 Apr 1984. Composer. Born to Jose Sacramento and Donata Tinio, he grew up learning to play various musical instruments of the family-owned band. Sacramento was married to Margarita Esguerra with whom he had five children. When he was at the Ateneo grade school, he started formal lessons in music under Alimpio Carluen and composed the “Ateneo Seventh Grade March.” In 1927, he graduated from the Nueva Ecija Provincial High School, and in 1934, finished his bachelor of music degree, major in composition, at the University of the Philippines. Originally a piano major, he shifted to composition due to the influence of his teacher, composer NicanorS.Abelardo.

Sacramento taught theory and composition at Santa Isabel College, Philippine Women’s University, and Centro Escolar University. In 1965, he headed the Composition Department of the Cosmopolitan Academy of Music, and later became executive secretary and finally, director. He was one of the initial members of the LeagueofFilipinoComposers, the board of the Pambansang Samahan ng mga Banda sa Pilipinas (PASAMBAP), and the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (FILSCAP). In 1975, he observed musical trends and organization in Los Angeles as a Fulbright grantee. Among his major works are the operas Pagmamahalan (Loving), 1968, and Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1970; Violin Concerto in D minor, 1976; Balintataw (Pupil of the Eye) for chamber ensemble, 1970; and two piano concertos commissioned by Malacañang, Ang Maharlika (The Noble), 1974, and Ang Bituin (The Star), 1975. Written byFelizidad Z. Reyes and Julie Ann Hallazgo

SALA-SANTAMARIA, INGRID (Ingrid Blanco Sala-Santamaria) b. Cebu City 25 Feb 1940. Pianist. Born to Salvador Sala and Pilar Blanco, she is married to Jose Ma. Santamaria with whom she has four children. She received her early music training from her mother. In 1958-59, she studied at the Juilliard School of Music under Josef Raieff. When she went back to Manila, she continued training under Benjamin Tupas, Reynaldo Reyes, Jose Ma. Contreras, and Francisco F. Feliciano. She earned her master’s degree in music at Santa Isabel College in 1962. She has been conferred the doctorate in music education, honoris causa, by the De La Salle University in 2006.

Santamaria has been a regular piano soloist in Concert at the Park, a nationally televised cultural program broadcast from Manila’s Rizal Park, since its initial concert in 1978 up to 1986. She performed the Philippine premiere of Yellow River Piano Concerto with the National Philharmonic Orchestra in 1972. She is the first non-Japanese Asian to take part in the Hiroshima International Music Festival in 1982, 1985, and 1987. She has also performed in the United States, Puerto Rico, Hong Kong, Rio de Janeiro, Vienna, Monte Carlo, and Paris.

In 1991, she returned to Cebu and in her capacity as the chair of the Salvador and Pilar Sala Foundation, started a 10-year development program for the young music talents of the city, with the intention of forming a youth orchestra of a national caliber. It resulted in the founding of the Cebu Youth Symphony Orchestra (CYSO) in 1995, which later became the Peace Philharmonic Philippines (PPP) in 2000. She also founded the PPP Junior Ensemble, which performs the string quartet reductions of the orchestral accompaniment to the romantic piano concertos, transcribed on commission by the PPP music director, Jeffrey Solares.

Together with her former teacher, Reynaldo Reyes, they have launched the biennial Romantic Piano Concerto Journey (RPCJ) in 2001, in which they have performed piano concertos from the Romantic period (1800-1910), as well as works by Filipino composers. To date, they have staged more than 400 performances. This concert tour program has brought them to the various regions of the Philippines and the major cities of Southeast Asia, performing in unconventional venues such as basketball courts, churches, ancestral homes, public parks, and hotel lobbies. It was earlier dubbed as “informances” because they explained the music they were playing, followed by a question and answer segment, encouraging young audiences to learn more about classical music, particularly the piano repertoire of the Romantic period.

Sala-Santamaria has received the Hall of Fame award from the Crestwood Performing Arts League; the Republic Day Award in Music and the Arts from the Civic Assembly of Women of the Philippines, 1980; The Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service (TOWNS) Award in arts and music, 1981; 100 Most Notable Cebuanos Award, 2000; Chevalier Ordre des Palmes Academiques by the French Government, 2002; Chevalier dans l’Ordre National du Merite by the French Government by degree of French Republic’s President Jacques Chirac, 2004; and the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Aliw Awards Foundation, 2008. Written byErlinda Alburo and Antonio C. Hilaupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

SALAZAR, RUBY (Ruby Jose Salazar) Active circa 1965-80. Violinist, singer. She is married to Ernesto Salazar, a lawyer. At 12, she was the youngest performer and first Filipino to be featured with the Honolulu Symphony Orchestra as violin soloist, with George Barati as conductor. She won the first prize in the string division of the Honolulu Spring Music Festival for her interpretation of “Zapateado” by Pablo de Sarasate.

She was awarded a full scholarship by Punahou School in Honolulu where she studied violin and piano under Herman Scheurer and Ruth Orcutt Bacon, respectively. As a voice scholar of the MusicPromotionFoundationofthePhilippines, she also trained under JovitaFuentes in the Philippines. She portrayed various roles in opera, including Maria Clara in FelipePadilladeLeon’s NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not), Laura in Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), the title role in Princesa Urduja (Princess Urduja), Muzetta in La Boheme, Laetitia in The Old Maid and the Thief, Antonia in Tales of Hoffman, Elizetta in Il Matrimonio Segretto, Marguerite in Faust, and Cio Cio San in Madame Butterfly. She is best remembered for her role as Julia in the 1970 revival of SeverinoReyes’s WalangSugat (No Wounds). Written byRamon Jocson

SALONGA, GERARD (Gerard Joseph Imutan Salonga) b. Mandaluyong City 11 Oct 1973. Music director, conductor, arranger, and record producer. He is the younger of two children of Feliciano G. Salonga and Ma. Ligaya Imutan. Gerard is the brother of the renowned singer and theater artist, Lea Salonga. He is married to Divina Francisco, a violinist, with whom he has two children, Antonio and Carmen.

Salonga started playing the piano at age five, but later quit at the age of 11 to take up golf. His elementary and high school years were spent at O.B. Montessori, where he graduated in 1986 and 1990, respectively. While taking up a bachelor’s degree in interdisciplinary studies at the Ateneo de Manila University, he composed the musical titled Halimaw (Monster), 1992. He also served as musical director for Ateneo Blue Repertory from 1993 to 1995. A year after graduating in 1994, he sat in through the last two levels of music theory classes handled by Ryan Cayabyab at the University of the Philippines College of Music. By spring of 1996, Salonga began his studies at Berklee College of Music in Boston, Massachusetts to study piano, arranging, and conducting. His mentor for piano was jazz pedagogue, Ray Santisi; while in conducting, he became a student of David Callahan and George Monseur. In 1998, he received his professional diploma from Berklee, summa cum laude. During his final years in the United States, he worked as a music copyist for Warner Brothers, 1998, and a music copyist/orchestrator/proofreader for Sony Music Library, 1998-99.

After his return to the Philippines, he worked as a musical director for the professional stagings of They’re Playing Our Song, 2000; Dreamgirls, 2003; Baby, 2004; West Side Story, 2008; Sweeney Todd, 2009; and Little Women, 2010.

From 2000 to 2004, he became the resident conductor of the Manila Philharmonic Orchestra. From 2004 to 2011, he became the music director of the orchestra FILHarmoniKA. Other major orchestras he has conducted include the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra. He also conducted the Bangkok Symphony Orchestra, Mostly Philharmonic Orchestra in Seoul, Evergreen Symphony Orchestra in Taipei, and the Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra. In Apr 2012, he began working as the music director and conductor of the ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra. His most notable performances include Prokofiev’s Romeo and Juliet with the Philippine Ballet Theater, 2011; The Legends and The Classics – Cecile Licad, Lea Salonga, and Lisa Macuja, 2012 and 2013; and the Asian Tour of Boublil and Schonberg’s Do You Hear The People Sing?, 2013 and 2014.

Salonga is an arranger of light symphonic music and his arrangements have been performed by the Hong Kong Philharmonic, Pittsburgh Symphony, Indianapolis Symphony, and Baltimore Symphony Orchestras. In popular music, he has arranged and produced songs and albums for artists like Regine Velasquez, Gary Valenciano, Martin Nievera, Jose Mari Chan, and his sister Lea Salonga. In 2005, he produced Musika Natin (Our Music), a series of new recordings of Filipino works by the likes of Lucio San Pedro, Angel Peña, and Antonino Buenaventura, all performed with the FILharmoniKA. He has composed music for television and film, including those for RPG Metanoia, 2010, a full-length animated feature; Aksyon TV, 2011, TV5’s news network; The Filipino Channel, 2004 and 2005, for which he created station IDs that won the Promax Silver Awards for both years; and The Kitchen Musical, 2011, a TV series where he received recognition from Aliw Awards as Best Musical Director in 2001, 2002, 2004, and 2008, and later on became part of the Aliw Hall of Fame in 2010. In 2012, he was honored as one of the country’s Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM). Written byCristina Maria P. Cayabyab
SALONGA, LEA (See THEATER volume.)

SAMPAGUITA (Teresita Quitco Alfonso) b. Java, Indonesia 17 Jul 1950. Singer. Her father is Pete Alfonso, owner of the popular restaurant called Café Indonesia located on Roxas Boulevard during the 1950s. Her mother is Ana Ledesma-Quitco from Negros Occidental. She studied in St Theresa’s College in San Marcelino, Manila. She dropped out during her first year in high school and later went to various vocational schools. She was one of the models for the Bagong Anyo group of First Lady Imelda Marcos that promoted Philippine couture in other countries in the early years of martial law.

Although she played the guitar and could carry a tune, Sampaguita had no aspirations of becoming a singer. It was her then husband music promoter Nilo Santos who convinced her to try her luck as a rock artist. This was in the mid-1970s when Pinoy rock was growing in popularity. While there was no shortage of male rock artists, there were no females in the genre and Vicor Music Corporation was in search of one. She was packaged to fill the void.
