She was given the name Sampaguita after the fragrant national flower, dressed in fabulous, psychedelic costumes, and asked to record the song “Bonggahan” (Razzle-Dazzle), composed by Gary Perez.

Released in 1977, the carefree “Bonggahan” invited fun times in the then popular gay lingo that mixed English and Filipino. Though initially reluctant to be a singer, Sampaguita proved to be a natural with the song and scored a big hit with her first single. She came to be known as the Queen of Pinoy Rock and went on to headline concerts, New Moon, musicals, and the Pinoy rock opera Mahal (Beloved) and to record more songs that have since become classics like “Tao” (Man), “Nosi Ba Lasi?” (reverse of Filipino “Sino Ba Sila?” or Who are They?), “Laguna,” “Sa Diyos Lamang” (Only in God), and “Sayawan” (Dancing).

Sampaguita is now acknowledged as a true Filipino music icon. She is now retired but would once in a while take to the stage to perform her famous songs. Written byCarmencita Gil

SAN PEDRO, LUCIO (Lucio Diestro San Pedro) b. Angono, Rizal 11 Feb 1913 d. Quezon City 31 Mar 2002. National Artist for music. Composer, conductor, film scorer, educator. He was the son of Elpidio San Pedro and Soledad Diestro. San Pedro was married to Gertrudez Diaz with whom he had five children. He became seriously involved in music when his father put up a family band, which later on served as his laboratory for conducting and composition. He had already written songs and learned to play well the bandurria and banjo before he enrolled at the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music in 1932. He earned his teacher’s diploma in composition and conducting in 1937, and took further studies at the Juilliard School of Music in 1947. Upon his return, he taught at the St Scholastica’s College, La Concordia College, Philippine Women’s University, Santa Isabel College, St Paul College, St Joseph’s College, Ateneo de Manila University, Centro Escolar University, and the UP College of Music, where he was a full professor until his retirement in 1978, and served at one time as chair of the Theory and Composition Department. He was named Professor Emeritus by UP in 1979.

San Pedro has been a prolific artist in his more than 60 years of artistic creation. Highly evocative of the folk, his works strove to reflect the Filipino soul, in line with his musical philosophy of “creative nationalism.” He has written hymns, masses, choral works, songs for solo voices, chamber music, incidental music, even background music for movies. Among his famous orchestral works are: Violin Concerto in D minor, 1948; the symphonic poems, Ang Buwan sa Kabundukan (Moon Over the Hills), 1952, and Lahing Kayumanggi (Brown Race), 1961, which earned for him the 1962 Republic Cultural Heritage Award; Suite Pastorale, 1956; and Visayan Fantasy and Ilocano Fantasy, 1984. He wrote the oratorio The Redeemer, 1989, with text compiled by Fred Tiburcio, for the Cultural Center of the Philippines; the cantatas, Sa Dalampasigan (By the Seashore), 1976, and Lupang Mahal ng Araw (Land Loved by the Sun), 1980; and the Santo Niño Mass,1979, and other choral works such as “Sa Mahal Kong Bayan” (To My Beloved Country), 1950; “Sa Lupang Sarili” (On One’s Native Soil), 1940; “Simbanggabi” (Night Mass), 1963; “Magsiawit sa Panginoon” (Sing to the Lord), 1975; and “Pinupuri Ikaw Yahweh Nitong Aking Kaluluwa” (My Soul Praises You, Yahweh), 1978. His “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” (As the Hammock Sways), 1943, with lyrics written by Levi Celerio in 1948, has been sung in many recitals and been choreographed by Denisa Reyes in 1991.

San Pedro also composed and arranged for the band. Some of his works for the band are “Overture in B-flat major,” 1935; “Triumphal March,” 1937; “Mabuhay ang Kasarinlan” (Long Live Independence), 1938; “Martsa ng Bagong Pilipinas” (March of the New Philippines), 1942; “Victory in Parade,” 1943; “Philippine Independence,” 1964; “Festival March,” 1969; “Golden Heart March,” 1971; and “Maharlika March,” 1979. He led the family band that his father founded, the Angono Municipal Symphonic Band, which garnered first prizes in national competitions such as those in 1960 and in 1979.

He wrote musical scores for films like Limbas (Birds of Prey), Varna, Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), and Alabok na Ginto (Gold in Dust). He also wrote incidental music for theatrical presentations such as Martir sa Golgota (Martyr at Golgotha), Cyrano de Bergerac, and Kid Labuyo (The Fighting Kid).

Several compilations of his choral arrangements and vocal music include Mga Katutubong Awitin (Native Songs), The Choral Works of Lucio D. San Pedro, and The Art Songs of San Pedro. A few of his songs which have been part of a Filipino singer’s standard repertoire include “Sa Mahal Kong Bayan” (To My Beloved Country), 1950; “Sa Simula Ako’y Labong” (In the Beginning I am a Young Bamboo Shoot), 1951; “Sa Umaga” (In the Morning), 1952; “Hayun ang Bituin” (There’s the Star), 1955; “Diwata ng Pag-ibig” (Love Fairy), 1956; and “The Last Testament,” 1987.

He won many composition contests from his student days up to 1987. Among these are: first prize, National Heroes Day Competition, 1936; first prize, President Laurel March, 1943; special prize, National Composition Contest, 1946; first prize, Second National Eucharistic Congress of the Philippines Hymn Contest; and grand prize, National Eucharistic Songwriting Contest, 1987. Among the awards he has received, aside from the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, are the Gawad Tanglaw ng Lahi from the Ateneo de Manila University, 1981; Signum Merit Medal from De La Salle University, 1982; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the City of Manila, 1984; and the ASEAN Award for Music and a Papal Award, both in 1990. He was named National Artist for music in 1991, and shortly after was conferred a doctoral degree in the humanities, honoris causa, by the UP College of Music.

In 1998, San Pedro was one of five major Filipino composers commissioned by the Philippine government to write orchestral works in celebration of the centennial of Philippine independence from Spain. San Pedro’s contribution was Alamat ng Lahi (Legend of the Race) for baritone, chorus and orchestra. The music was based on “Isang Dipang Langit” (A Piece of Heaven), a poem by National Artist for literature Amado V. Hernandez. Together with the four other commissioned works by Ramon Santos, Lucrecia Kasilag, Jeffrey Ching and Josefino Toledo, Alamat ng Lahi was premiered in the centennial concert, Alay sa Sandaang Taon (Centennial Offering) at the CCP on 13 Jun 1998 Written byMa. Patricia Brillantes and Antonio C. Hilaupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

SANTIAGO, FRANCISCO b. Santa Maria, Bulacan 29 Jan 1889. d. 28 Sep 1947. Composer, pianist, teacher. Born to Felipe and Maria Santiago, he married Concepcion de Leon in 1923, and they had four children. He had his elementary education at Colegio de San Juan de Letran and finished high school at the Liceo de Manila. When he was seven, he took piano lessons from a private tutor. Three years later, Santiago studied pianoforte under Blas Echegoyen, and later, under Faustino Villacorta and Primo Calzada. Coming from a poor family, he had to support himself through school. When the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music was founded in 1916, he was taken in as a piano instructor. He studied advanced harmony and counterpoint under Robert Schofield.

In 1917, Santiago wrote the first artsong-kundiman, “Kundiman, Cancion Filipina” (Kundiman, Filipino Song) or “Kundiman,Anak-Dalita” (Kundiman, Child of Woe). This piece was sung before the Royal Court of Spain upon the request of King Alfonso II.

Santiago obtained his teacher’s certificate in science and composition from the UP in 1922, his master of music degree and his doctorate at the Chicago Music School, both in 1924. He is the first Filipino to have earned a doctorate in music composition. It was there that he presented his Concerto in B-flat minor for pianoforte and orchestra, which is considered his masterpiece. He returned to the Philippines in 1925, resumed teaching at the UP, and became the first Filipino director of the UP Conservatory of Music from 1930 to 1946. He was later appointed professor emeritus at the same institution.

Among his popular kundiman are “Sakali Man” (If It is So) and “Hibik ng Filipinas” (Cry of the Philippines), 1917; “Pakiusap” (Plea), 1921; “Ang Pag-ibig” (Love), 1922; “Suyuan” (Loving), 1934; “Alaala Kita” (I Remember You) and “Ikaw at Ako” (You and I), 1929; and “Madaling Araw” (Dawn) and “AnoKayaangKapalaran?” (What is Fate?), 1938. His undated kundiman include “Hatol Hari Kaya?” (Will It be the King’s Will?), “Sakali’t Mamatay” (If Death Comes), “Dalit ng Pag-ibig” (Hymn of Love), “Aking Bituin” (My Star), and “Pagsikat ng Araw” (When the Sun Rises). Among his works in the classical idiom are Philippine Overture and the Sonata Filipina in D-flat major, 1922. The last work is the “first sonata written in the Philippines introducing Philippine musical themes,” according to composer AntonioJ.Molina. He also wrote String Quartette in G major and Concerto in B-flat minor, 1924; and Taga-ilog Symphony in D major, 1938.

Santiago was also a film music director. Among the films whose music he supervised are Kundiman, Leron-leronSinta (Leron-leron Beloved), Madaling-Araw (Dawn), Manileña (The Girl From Manila), and the movie inspired by his own composition, Pakiusap. His “Kundiman, Anak-Dalita” was used as the theme for Lamberto V. Avellana’s awardwinning film, Anak Dalita (Ruins), 1956.

Santiago composed a version of “AveMaria” for high voice with violin obligato, 1919. He did musical transcriptions of “Ay,Kalisud” (Ah, Misery), 1928; “Ang Kumintang” (The Kumintang); “Kura-kura,” a Jolo folksong; and “Hawi-hawi,” an Aeta folk song (the last three are undated). He also composed “Sumilang na ang Manunubos” (The Savior is Born), 1932, a Philippine Christmas carol, which according to AntonioJ.Molina, is “the first Philippine Christmas carol ever written for mixed chorus and symphony orchestra.” He also wrote the music of the sarsuwela, Si Margaritang Mananahi (Margarita, the Seamstress), 1913, with libretto by SeverinoReyes.

Santiago was posthumously given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the City of Manila in 1968. Written byFlerida D. Nolasco and Antonio C. Hila

SANTIAGO, JESS (Jesus Manuel Santiago) b. Obando, Bulacan 16 Jun 1950. Composer, poet, singer. He is the son of Frisco Santiago, a barber and band musician, and Maria Manuel. Santiago is married to poet Lilia Quindoza with whom he has four children. He studied at the Obando Elementary School and the G.G. Sancianco High School, then enrolled at the Philippine School of Business Administration. He supported himself through high school and college by doing odd jobs, until he learned how to make a living by singing in pubs and folkhouses. The political, economic, and cultural developments of the 1970s largely influenced Santiago’s music and poetry. His songs touch on the lives of common folk under a repressive order and serve as the social conscience of the times. Among these are “Halina” (Come), “Meme na, Aking Bunso” (Sleep, My Little One), “Huling Balita” (The Latest News), “Butil ng Palay” (Rice Grains), “Hayaan Mangusap ang Aking Gitara” (Let My Guitar Speak), and “Mga Anak ng Dalita” (Children of Poverty). He also composed the “LABAN March” used by the anti-Marcos opposition groups during the 1978 electoral campaign for the Interim Batasang Pambansa. He set to music such popular poems as Alejandro G. Abadilla’s “Ako ang Daigdig” (I Am the World), Jose Corazon de Jesus’s “Isang Punongkahoy” (A Fruit Tree), Amado V. Hernandez’s “Kung Tuyo na ang Luha Mo, Aking Bayan” (When Your Tears Have Dried Up, My Country), and Teo S. Baylen’s “Takipsilim at Lumang Lambat” (Dusk and Old Fishnets).

As a concert artist, Santiago has performed here and abroad. In Jun 1991, he was featured by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in a solo concert held at the Little Theater. Most often, however, he is heard in outdoor rallies, symposia, and even in marketplaces and plazas. He came out with solo albums Halina, 1991; Obando, 1993 and Puso at Isip (Heart and Mind), 2008. His songs have been included in albums like Karapatang Pantao (Human Rights), 1990. He was music director of Lino Brocka’s Bayan Ko, Kapit sa Patalim (My Country, Gripping at the Knife’s Edge) and documentary films like Kabalikat (Partner), Kasama (Comrade), and Doon Po Sa Amin (In Our Town). He composed songs for stage plays such as Bonifacio Ilagan’s Sigaw ng Bayan (People’s Cry), Marina Feleo’s Dahong Palay (Rice Leaves/Rice-field Snake), and UP Repertory’s production of El Extensionista (The Extensionist). His poetry and compositions have been published in various literary magazines in the country and in international magazines. In 1997, he published his book of poems Gitara: Poems / Mga Tula 1975-1985. He has been invited as a guest performer in the following: 2006 Seoul International Human Rights Festival, Seoul, Korea; ASEAN People’s Integration Open Air Concert, Institute for Global Justice, Jakarta, Indonesia, 2008; ASEAN People’s Forum, Hanoi, Vietnam, 2010 and in Cha-am, Thailand, 2011; End WTO Week of Action, Bali, Indonesia, 2013; and Concert for Food Sovereignty, Youth Food Movement Indonesia, Jakarta, Indonesia, 2013.

He was recognized by the Talaang Ginto of the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa as “Makata ng Taon” (Poet of the Year), 1978-79; won in the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, CCP Literary Contest, and the Palihang Aurelio V. Tolentino Playwriting Contest; and received the National Fellow for Literature award from the University of the Philippines Creative Writing Center, 1985, and the first Gawad Inang Bayan from the Polytechnic University of the Philippines, 1991. Other awards include Most Outstanding Citizen of Bulacan in Music and Literature, Provincial Government of Bulacan, 1998; Gawad Nuno ng Tbak, Gawad Kaliwanagan, Tbak Foundation, 2002; Fellow, Asian Public Intellectuals Fellowship Program, The Nippon Foundation, 2005-06; Fellow, Salzburg Global Seminar on Literary Translation, Salzburg, Austria, 2009; Writer-in-Residence, Palihang Rogelio Sicat, 2009; and Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature for his folio of children’s poems, Kuwentong Matanda, Bersong Bata (Old Tales, New Verses), 2009.

In 2011, he was nominated for Best Music in the Gawad Urian for the film Ang Paglilitis kay Mang Serapio (The Trial of Old Serapio) where he also played the lead role. He was an active member of Galian sa Arte at Tula or GAT and other writers’ organizations. He was the executive director of Musika Philippines, which seeks to promote socially relevant music. He is a member of the Societe des Auteurs, Compositeurs et Editeurs de Musique. Written byMa. Lourdes Maniquisupdated by Connie Ladrido

SANTOS, RAMON P. (Ramon Pagayon Santos) b. Pasig, Rizal 25 Feb 1941. National Artist for music. Composer, conductor, musicologist, educator. He is the youngest of six children of lawyer Jose Santos and pianist-singer Amada Pagayon. He married Lourdes Wong with whom he has two daughters, Monica Fa and Waya. He finished grade school at Pasig Catholic School, high school at the San Jose Seminary, and bachelor of music, major in composition and conducting, at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1965. He also obtained masteral (with distinction) and doctoral degrees in music composition at the Indiana University, 1969, and the State University of New York at Buffalo, 1972, respectively. In 1989, Santos was a visiting scholar in ethnomusicology at the University of Illinois in Champaign-Urbana.

As a student at the UP, Santos was attracted to the music of Gustav Mahler and Claude Debussy. Composer Jose Maceda introduced him to Asian traditional and avant-garde music. While in Indiana, his first works had a neoclassic strain, as in Children’s Suite and Pied Beauty, 1968, and Concertino Variations for orchestra, 1969. After he was introduced to avant-garde techniques, he wrote a cantata on the lamentations in the Lenten liturgy titled Improperia for soloist, chorus, orchestra, and kulintang. In New York, he became acquainted with electronic and computer music procedures, as well as indeterminacy and controlled improvisation. He was further exposed to New Music as a fellow at the summer courses in New Music in Darmstadt, followed by a visit at the Institute of Sonology in Utrecht in 1974.

When Santos returned to the Philippines, the reality of life in an Asian society changed his direction. He immersed himself in indigenous Philippine and Asian music, studying Chinese nanguan and Javanese gamelan music and dance. His works assumed open-ended structures of time and space, while exploring the colors provided by local sound sources. At this time, he composed “Nabasag ang Banga at Iba’t Ibang Pinag-ugpong-ugpong na Pananalita sa Wikang Pilipino para sa Labing-anim na Tinig” (The Broken Jar and Variously Connected Phrases in the Filipino Language for Sixteen Voices), 1972, where he explored the musical value of everyday sounds. In the early 1980s, he continued to focus on elements in Philippine culture while using Western sound media, as in Penomenon (Phenomenon), 1979, Tin-ig (Voices), 1983, and Du’A, 1986, for orchestra; and a series of pieces for solo instruments titled Abot-Tanaw (Horizons), 1981-84. He also produced massive environmental works such as Ritwal ng Pasasalamat (Thanksgiving Ritual), 1976, a modern ritual music for practically all the representative instruments at the UP College of Music; and Likas-An (Nature-ing), 1978, which included noncontrollable instruments that he invented, as well as carpenters and electricians. He also introduced works integrating music, dance, drama, and poetry, such as Ba-dw, 1987, which was inspired by the poetico-musical expression of the Ibaloy of northern Philippines; Awit ni Pulau (Song of Pulau), 1990, a children’s theater ritual; and Daragang Magayon (Beautiful Maiden), 1991, for dancers, singer, narrators, and instrumentalists. His Time-Space, 1990, for large orchestra, and S’Geypo, 1993, for 16 flutes and drums, may well signal a new creative phase. Among Santos’ recent works are Likas-An II, for 4 groups of singers, audience, aerophones and percussion instruments, 1994; L’BAD, for large orchestra, 1995; Pasyon Ritwal, for pasyon chanters, chorus, instruments and dancers, 1998; Katutubong Pananaw, Musikang Pilipino (Indigenous View, Filipino Music), canon for voices, 2002; Oggayam for mixed voices, 2004; K’libet, for children’s rondalla, 2004; Pat’tong, for symphonic band, 2004; DW’GEY, for violin, viola, voice and percussion, 2006; Cuerdas II Visayan Medley, 2006; Salikupan, for 3 Saron groups, three kendang, three rebab, singers, bungkaka, tongatong, patang-ug, and bird whistles, 2007; and Daragang Magayon: An Istorya ni Mayon (Beautiful Lady: The Story of Mayon), a theatrical work involving music, dance, and multimedia, for rondalla, piano, percussion, soloists, chorus, and narrator, 2013.

In 1998, he was commissioned by the Philippine government to write an orchestral work in celebration of the centennial of Philippine independence from Spain, together with four other major Filipino composers who each wrote a large work for orchestra. He wrote Nagnit Igak G’nan Wagnwag Nila (Alingawngaw ng Kagitingan) (Reverberations of Courage), for seven choruses, four orchestral groups, and audience—a symphonic ode to freedom conceived as a modern ritual with an indigenous performance design.

Santos held important positions in different academic and musical organizations, such as president of the National Music Council of the Philippines, 1984-93; dean of the UP College of Music, 1978-88; secretary of the League of Filipino Composers; chairman and Secretary General of the National Music Competitions for Young Artists or NAMCYA, 1989-2002; chairman of the Asian Composers League, 1994-97; artistic director of the Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1999; head of the Executive Council of the National Music Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), 1995-2004; commissioner for the arts, NCCA, 1998-2004; president of the Musicological Society of the Philippines, since 2003; director of the UP Center for Ethnomusicology, 2004-14; and vice president of the International Music Council Executive Committee at UNESCO, since 2001.

He has represented the country in various festivals and conferences in Southeast Asia, Korea, Japan, Taiwan, and New Zealand, and became actively involved in the projects of the ASEAN Committee on Information and Culture as project director, delegate, and writer. He received official visitor’s grants in Belgium, the Netherlands, England (through the British Council), the People’s Republic of China, and the US State Department. In 1991 he was invited to be a member of the highly select International Society of Music Education (ISME) Panel on the World’s Musical Cultures which was tasked to formulate new policies in teaching music multiculturally all over the world.

He spearheaded the International Rondalla Festival which began in 2004, held in Naga City. Succeeding editions of the festival have been staged in Dumaguete, 2007; Tagum, 2011; Manila, 2014; and an invitational outreach edition in Taiwan in 2014. In 2013, Santos organized Tunog-Tugan: First International Gongs and Bamboo Music Festival, which included a conference, workshop, and lecture-demonstration, held in Dipolog City in 2013.

As professor of composition, theory, and musicology, Santos has been exerting strong influence on his students at the UP, as well as other students and colleagues at his lectures in the different schools in Metro Manila and teacher-training workshops in the different parts of the Philippines and abroad. He has been instrumental in espousing a modern Philippine music rooted in ancient practices and concepts of life in Asian society.

Santos has published numerous articles in journals such as the Journal of the Indian Musicological Society, Bulawan 15 Journal of Philippine Arts and Culture, and Zeitschrift fur Neue Musik. He has also contributed articles on Philippines music in the Garland Encyclopedia of World Music, 1998; and Sonic Orders in ASEAN Musics: A Field and Laboratory Study of Musical Cultures and Systems in Southeast Asia, 2003. Together with Corazon Dioquino, he edited the Philippine Music volume of the first edition of the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, 1994. He has also published Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music, 2005; Laon-Laon: Perspectives in Transmission and Pedagogy of Musical Traditions in Post-Colonial Southeast Asia, 2012; and the Dictionary of Filipino Musical Terms, First Edition, 2013.

His awards include: second prize in the Bonifacio Centennial Composition Contest in 1963; Fulbright-Hays Grant, 1967; Award of Recognition for Outstanding Achievement in Music by the Minerva Association, 1963 and 1976; teaching assistantship and fellowship at Indiana University; full fellowship at the Institute for New Music in Darmstadt, 1974; “Ilaw ng Karunungan,” Outstanding Fulbrighter in Music, 1983; Chevalier de l’Ordre des Arts et Lettres by the French Ministry of Culture and UPIP Professorial Chair in Composition, both in 1987; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan, City of Manila, 1991; Achievement Award in the Humanities, National Research Council of the Philippines, 1994; Outstanding Pasigueño (Arts), 421st Araw ng Pasig, Municipal Government of Pasig, 1994; General Education Professorial Chair Award, University of the Philippines System, 2004; UP Alumni Association Professional Award in Music, 2004; and the National Book Award for Music for his book Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music, 2006. In 2012, he was awarded the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining. Santos’s proclamation as National Artist was signed by Pres Benigno Aquino III in Jun 2014. Written byCorazon C. Dioquinoupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

SANTOS, ROSENDO (Rosendo Salazar Santos)b. Cavite City 3 Sep 1922 d. Swoyersville, Pennsylvania 4 Nov 1994. Composer, conductor. His father was Rosendo Ejercito Santos Sr who served thrice as mayor of Cavite. His mother was Castora Salazar, a Caviteña who was an accomplished harpist and loved music. When he was 10, he took his first music lesson under Julian Felipe, the composer of the Philippine National Anthem. At 11, he was teaching music. When he was a freshman at Cavite High School at 12, he was doing the musical arrangements for one of the two top bands of Cavite, the Caridad Band. He was a member of the Municipal Symphony Orchestra and a player of Federico Elizalde’s Little Symphony. He earned a bachelor’s degree in music from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1950 and a master’s degree in theory and composition, from the Catholic University of America in 1963. He finished his doctorate at the West Virginia University. He got married to Harriet L. Clandenin in 1966, a pianist, with whom he had three sons.

Santos taught at the UP from 1950 to 1961. Later he taught in different American universities: Catholic University of America, 1961-64, and West Virginia, 1965-68. He joined the faculty of the Music Department of Wilkes University, Pennyslvania in 1968 where he performed as a timpanist, pianist, and conductor of several orchestral groups.

He was the conductor of the Sangley Point Choir, composed of US servicemen and their families. He was also the head of the Philippine Navy Choir which regularly assisted in Catholic services. He led one prominent band in Cavite, the 96 Band, which celebrated its 80th anniversary in 2010. In Aug 1951, he won first prize in a contest connected with the July 4th celebration. His “Philippine Republic March” was chosen in a board chaired by Herbert Zipper, director of the Manila Symphony Orchestra. “Sampaguita,” 1953, was his winning arrangement of a Filipino folk song that earned him international acclaim and performed internationally by the Harvard Glee Club.

He was an active supporter of the University of the Philippines Student Catholic Action (UPSCA). Associated with UPSCA, his work, Hiyas ng Nayon (Treasures of the Town), an operetta in three acts in Tagalog, premiered on 5 Dec 1955. Another UPSCA-affiliated event was the first mass of the newly built Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice, in the University of the Philippines campus. Fr John P. Delaney, SJ commissioned Rosendo’s composition, Missa Chorale, offered in this chapel for its first mass in 20 Dec 1955.

Santos served as conductor of the Philippine Symphony Orchestra, the Philippine Ballet Company on its European tour, and the Guildhall School of Music Symphony Orchestra in London. He was the official tympanist and percussion principal of the Northeastern Pennsylvania Philharmonic Society, Sinfonia de Camara College Misericordia, Wyoming Oratorio Society, Wyoming Valley Symphony Orchestra, Steigmayer Concert Band, and the Venceil Symphony Orchestra. He was guest conductor at different Bank Musical Festivals statewide and was choir director and organist of Lehman First United Methodist Church.

Some of his works are: Piano Concerto in G No. 1, 1948; Tatlong Hiyas ng Nayon (Three Gems of the Town), 1959; Mapulang Bituin (Red Star), 1960; Mindoro Sketches, 1961; Lapu-Lapu Symphonic Poem, 1962; Fantasy, 1968; Fantasie Laeterum for tympani and orchestra, 1970; and Birth of a Nation, 1976.

In 1956 and 1957 he was named Composer of the Year in Manila. He won 12 prizes in a row in different national composition contests. He is listed in the New Groves Dictionary of Music and Musicians. His works include concertos, sonatas, symphonies, symphonic poems, five operas in Philippine languages, band overtures, and more than 200 marches. He wrote 50 masses in Latin and more than 20 in English. More than a thousand of his musical compositions are held in the University of the Philippines Library. He was an honored member of the Senior Mozart Club in Wyoming Valley, Pennsylvania where he had taught more than 2000 children since 1968.

Santos had also conducted church choirs in Maryland, New Jersey and in Lehman, Huntsville, and Shavertown United Methodist Churches in Pennyslvania. In Wilkes College, he became head of the theory, composition and percussion departments, band director, and resident composer. In 1992, he was conferred Professor Emeritus by the Wilkes University. He continued to compose music for his students and to teach his Music 101 class until his death. His last musical work, Melinda’s Masquerade, his only ballet, was performed in 1995, a year after his death. Written byCollie de los Reyes and Flerida G. Nolascoupdated by Connie Ladrido

SATURNO, VEHNEE (Venancio Alconaba Satumo) b. Cabuyao, Laguna 1 Apr 1954. Composer. He was born to Jose Saturno and Juliana Alconaba. He is married to Cleotilde Marquez with whom he has two children. He completed his elementary and secondary education at the Cabuyao Elementary School and Cabuyao Institute in Laguna, then studied advertising at the Polytechnic University of the Philippines. He took a course on basic pop arrangement at the Ryan Cayabyab Music Studio. In 1981, he left an office job and went fulltime in songwriting.

Saturno has written over 400 songs. Some of his hit songs include: “Be My Lady,” sung by Martin Nievera; “Nag-iisang Ikaw” (One and Only You), by Louie Heredia; “Makapiling Ka Sana” (Wish To Be With You), by Dingdong Avanzado; “Para sa ’Yo” (For You), by Randy Santiago; “Isang Lahi” (One Race), by Regine Velasquez; “Pangarap Ka” (You’re My Dream), by Geneva Cruz; “Sana Kahit Minsan” (Just Once) and “Sa Aking Puso” (In My Heart), by Ariel Rivera; “Forever’s Not Enough,” by Sarah Geronimo; “Bakit Pa Ba?” (Why Did I Do It?), by Jay R; “Till My Heartaches End,” by Ella May Saison; “Only Me and You,” by Donna Cruz; “Mula sa Puso” for Jude Michael; “Wala na Bang Pag-Ibig?” (Is There No Love Left?) and “Dahil Tanging Ikaw” (Because There’s Only You), by Jaya; and “Bakit Pa?” (What For?), by Jessa Zaragoza.

He composed “Salamat Maria” (Thank You, Mary), 2007, as the official theme song of the centennial celebration of Our Lady of Naval in Santo Domingo Church, Quezon City. He has also written popular soundtrack and theme songs for films, including The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995, and Saranggola (Kite) and Bulaklak ng Maynila (Flower of Manila), 1999. In the 2013 reality singing show of TV 5, Kanta Pilipinas (Sing Philippines), he was one of the judges with Ryan Cayabyab and Lani Misalucha. He runs the Vehnee Saturno Music Training Center in Quezon City and owns and manages Saturno Music Production. He also produced the first albums of singers Ariel Rivera, Miguel Vera, Ted Ito, Radel Naval, Roeder, Ella Mae Saison, Monique Wilson, Andrea, Tony Lambino, and Maryana.

He won best composition awards for “Isang Dakot” (A Handful), 1982, sung by Sonia Singson at the Third Metro Manila Popular Song Festival; “Kung Akin Lang” (If It Were Mine), 1983, interpreted by Ivy Violan at the third ASEAN Song Festival in Jakarta, Indonesia; and “Love is All We Need,” 1991, sung by Samantha Chavez at the Seventh Asean Song Festival in Yogyakarta, Indonesia. He won second prize for the song “Ako’y Ako” (I Am Me) at the Sixth Metro Manila Popular Song Festival in 1983 and was first runner-up for “Sino Pa Nga Ba?” (Who Else?) at the First Asia Pacific Song Festival in Singapore in 1985. He won the grand prize (with Samantha Chavez) for the song “One Dream, One Love” in the Midnight Sun Song Festival in Finland in 1993 as well as the first prize in the Instrumental Category (out of almost 30,000 entries) for his song “Sana Kahit Minsan” in the USA Songwriting Contest in 1999. He won the Best Composition Award for “Where There is Love” in the Voice of Asia 2001, held in Almaty, Kazakhstan, with Ladine Roxas interpreting the song. He won the Best Song Award for his composition “From the Start,” in collaboration with lyricist Tito Cayamanda and interpreted by Rachel Ann Go, during the Shanghai Music Festival in 2004. He was awarded the Best Arrangement for Own Country Song and Special Award at the Astana Singers’ Contest in 2007. In 2010, he received the top prize for Best Song for his composition, “Within” (co-written with his daughter Popsie Saturno). The song also received the 2011 Ani ng Dangal for Multi-Disciplinary Arts Award from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. In 2012, he received a special award, Natatanging Alagad ng Musika with other artists at the 4th Star Awards for Music of the Philippine Movie Press Club.

In the Awit Awards, Saturno won the following: Best Ballad Recording, “Only Me and You,” 1996, “Alipin Ako” (I’m a Slave), 2002, and “Bakit Pa Ba?,” 2004; Best Pop Recording for “Wala Na Bang Pag-ibig?,” 1998, and “Dito sa Puso Ko” (In My Heart), 2000; Best Country-Ballad Recording for “Kitang-Kita Kita” (I Saw You), 1995, “Bakit?” (Why?), 1997, and “Paano Kaya?” (How Will It Be?), 1999; Best Christmas Recording for “Kapuso sa Pasko” (One in Heart This Christmas), 2005; Best Movie Theme Song Recording for “Kahit Man Lang sa Pangarap” (Even Just in Dreams), theme song of Darna, 1992, and “Kahit Kaunting Awa” (Small Mercies), theme song of The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1996; Album of the Year for No Limits, 2000; and Bestselling Album of the Year for Willie Revillame: Ikaw Na Nga! (It’s You!), 2010, and One Heart, 2012. He also received the Awit Awards’ Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino recognition in 2001. On 26 May 2006, he celebrated his 25th year in the music business with a concert, Silver Songs of Vehnee Saturno, at the Araneta Coliseum. Martin Nievera opened the show with Saturno’s first certified hit (and Martin Nievera’s) “Be My Lady.” Other performers also sang Saturno’s hits. Written byRosalinda Galang

SIDE A This pop rock band ranks among one of the most successful music acts in the country, gaining wide popularity in the 1990s, during the rise of the band music scene in Manila and in other urban centers outside of the metro capital. It was organized in 1985 by the brothers Rodel, vocals, and Naldy Gonzalez, keyboards, who were joined by Joey Benin, bass guitar, Kelly Badon, lead guitarist, Pido Lalimarmo, guitar, and Mar Dizon, drummer. Starting out in hotel lounges in the late 1980s, the band broke into the local mainstream with the release of their self-titled album in 1989, particularly with their songs “Eva Marie,” written by Benin, and “Di Pa Huli” (Not Yet Late), written by Rodel Gonzalez. In 1990, singer Joey Generoso and drummer Ernie Severino joined the group. The group went on to produce their most successful recordings: the White Album and Blue Album in 1991 and 1992, respectively; Hold On in 1994; the more popular By Your Side album in 1995; and Side A 12 in 1997. Side A’s discography also includes a string of anthologies and live recording albums in the early 2000s. The group’s current members include Gonzalez, Generoso, and Severino, along with Ned Esguerra on bass guitar and Leevon Cailao on lead guitar.

Side A is perhaps best known for their song “Forevermore” written by Benin, which won numerous awards including the Awit Awards’ Song of the Year in 1996. Side A also received the following recognition from Awit Awards: Best Performance by a Group for “So Many Questions,” 1994, “By Your Side,” 1995, and “Forevermore,” 1996; Best Ballad Recording for “So Many Questions,” 1994; Best Jazz Recording (With Vocals) for “True Love Can Always Wait,” 1995; and Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino, 2014.

The group’s overall sound can be characterized as “soft rock,” their romantic ballads often laced with clean vocal harmonizations constantly achieved by having band members that are equally comfortable with their vocal chops as well as with their respective instruments. Alongside record-breaking album sales and considerable radio airplay, Side A is also known for their solid live performances, playing to sold out concerts in local club venues and performing stages, and in Filipino communities abroad. Written byIsidora Miranda

SIGUION-REYNA, ARMIDA (Armida Purificacion Liwanag Ponce Enrile Siguion-Reyna) aka Tita Midz. b. Manila 4 Nov 1930. d. Makati City 11 Feb 2019. Singer, actor, producer. She was the daughter of Alfonso Ponce Enrile, a lawyer, and Purita Liwanag, a singer and music teacher. She was the sister of Irma Ponce-Enrile Potenciano who is also a singer and a voice teacher. She married corporate lawyer Leonardo Siguion-Reyna with whom she had three children. Daughter Monique Villonco is a TV producer, son Carlitos is a film director married to screenwriter and actor Bibeth Orteza, and grandchildren Cris Villonco and Rafa Siguion-Reyna are actors. She was also related to comedian Vicente Liwanag and film director Carmen Concha. In the late 1980s, the family-based Reynafilms was established with Armida as the producer, Bibeth Orteza as the writer, and Carlos Siguion-Reyna as the resident director. She was the head of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB) in 1998-2001.

 

After high school at St Joseph’s Academy in New York, she took up voice at Philippine Women’s University, graduating in 1950. Siguion-Reyna sang lead roles in the operas Lucia di Lammermoor, Rigoletto, La Traviata, I Pagliacci, and The Merry Widow, and in the sarsuwela Ang Mestiza (The Mestiza). She also appeared in Tanghalang Pilipino’s Larawan ng Pilipino Bilang Artista (Portrait of the Filipino as an Artist), 1990, and in the anti-US bases play of Galian sa Arte at Tula (GAT), Balagtasan , directed by Ishmael Bernal. She also hosted a celebrity TV show called Cooking Atbp. She recorded the following albums: Aawitan Kita Vols I and II for Villar Records, Armida for Dyna Records, and Sa Lungkot o Saya ... Aawitan Kita (In Sadness or in Happiness ...I Will Sing for You) for Vicar Records.

 

She is well-known for her musical TV show Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You) which won the following awards: Best Cultural Show from the Citizen’s Award for Television (CAT) in 1970, Best Cultural Program for TV from the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP) in 1976, Best Cultural Show for five years from the Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining (PATAS), Best Musical Special from the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA), and Special Award for Best Cultural Show from the Star Awards for Television in 1988. The show was also cited by the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon as one of the top 10 TV shows in 1987, 1988, and 1989.

 

She produced and starred in the 16mm musicals Dung-aw, Lakambini at Supremo (The Muse and The Supremo), Pagpatak ng Ulan (When the Rain Falls), and Sisa . She also acted in the television series Kung Mawawala Ka (If You’ll Be Gone), aired on GMA 7, and Sa Puso Ko, Iingatan Ka (I’ll Keep You Safe in My Heart), aired on ABS-CBN, both in 2001. Her last movie appearance was in Jun Robles Lana’s Bwakaw, 2012.

 

Her first film outfit, Pera Films, produced two movies: Laruang Apoy (Toy Fire) and Bilanggong Birhen (Caged Virgins), both in 1977. Later, she established Reyna Films which produced the following films: Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait For You in Heaven), 1991; Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal (You Are the Only One I’ve Loved), 1992; Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (Harvest Home), 1995; Abot-Kamay ang Pangarap (Elena’s Rdemption), 1996; Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), 1997; Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Her Life), 1998; Minsan May Dalawang Bata (Yesterday Children), 1999; and Azucena, 2000.

 

Her performance in her first film Sa Pagitan ng Dalawang Langit (Between Two Heavens) merited a Best Supporting Actress award in the 1975 Bacolod Film Festival. She won Best Supporting Actress awards from the Urian and the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for the movie Tahan na Empoy, Tahan (Hush, Empoy, Hush), 1977. Siguion-Reyna also won the FAMAS Award for Best Supporting Actress for Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin. Ikaw Pa Lang ang Minahal received 27 awards from the Urian, Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), FAMAS, and Young Critics Circle Film Desk. Many of Reyna Films’ productions also garnered Best Picture honors and special prizes from various international film festivals, such as those in Norter Palm Springs, Newport Beach, Turin, Toronto, and Berlin.

In 2006 Siguion-Reyna received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Star Awards for Movies of the Philippine Movie Press Club as well as the FAMAS Lifetime Achievement Award. In 2010, she was honored with the Natatanging Gawad Urian. In 2011, she received the FAP Lifetime Achievement Award and the Diwata Award from the University of the Philippines Film Institute. She received the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in 2015. In the same year, ABS-CBN Publishing Inc released the book Armida which includes her unfinished memoirs as well as her biography written by Nelson A. Navarro. Written by Lena S. Pareja, updated by Connie Ladrido and Elmer L. Gatchalian

SILOS, JUAN (Juan Lorenzo Silos Jr) b. Jolo, Sulu 8 Feb 1898. d. Quezon City 9 May 1988. Composer, conductor. The son of Juan Silos Sr and Maria Lorenzo, he married Marcela Rigo, with whom he had seven children. His grandfather Leonardo and his uncle Rosalio were bandmasters and composers during the Spanish era. The pre-World War II singers, the SSS Trio (Remedios, Dolores, and Lourdes), and Betty Silos Climaco were his daughters. Film directors Manuel and Octavio Silos were his cousins. His father taught the young Juan how to play the bandurria as well as solfeggio, harmony, and composition.

He composed music for the rondalla, which he himself conducted. In 1935, Silos Jr began composing for the movies, getting his break in the LVN Pictures hit movie Giliw Ko (My Beloved) under director Carlos Vander Tolosa. He composed more than 300 songs, chamber music pieces, and Philippine rhapsodies. Before World War II, he was musical director of Philippine Airs aired over KZRM-AM. After the war, he became musical director of Sampaguita and LVN Pictures, and the Far Eastern University Dance Troupe.

Some of his songs are: “Tanging Ligaya” (Only Joy), “Ako’y Iyong-Iyo” (I’m All Yours), “Tunay na Tunay” (Truly), “Pandanggo ng Pag-ibig” (Fandango of Love), “Kampana ng Simbahan” (Church Bells), “Waray-waray,” “Galawgaw” (Clumsy), “Alembong” (Flirt), “No Money, No Honey,” “Kung Ako’y Mag-aasawa” (If I Get Married), “Bahala Na” (Come What May), “Easy Ka Lang” (Stay Cool), “Darling Ko” (My Darling), and “Tunay na Ligaya” (Real Happiness). Written byCollie de los Reyesupdated by Leonardo R. Silos

SILOS, LEONARDO b. Sampaloc, Manila 6 Nov 1826 d. 27 Dec 1910. Musician, bandmaster. His father was the owner of several banca and barges used to ferry passengers and cargo across the Pasig River from Nagtahan. Among his eight children with Antonia Enriquez were Juan Silos Sr and Rosalio Silos who became musicians themselves. One of his sons, Jose Enriquez Silos, was the father of Salud Silos who was one of the original SSS Trio. Juan Silos Jr is his grandson. As a boy, he was taught by a friend how to play the guitar. By himself, he mastered books on the guitar and on harmony and studied the intricacies of orchestration.

At 16, he was already acquainted with all sorts of musical instruments. He organized and directed an orchestra in Sampaloc. At about 20, he was appointed director of the band of the Spanish Army’s Regiment No 5, a position he held for about 40 years until his retirement in 1887. His band followed the regiment wherever it was stationed: from Manila, they went to Jolo in 1870, then to Cebu, back to Manila, once more to Jolo, then to Zamboanga, to Cavite, and lastly, to Cotabato. From there he returned to Manila, and after directing the Pasig Band for a while, he gave lessons on the guitar, the bandurria, and then the mandolin and laud.

His musical compositions were not published. A hymn dedicated to Alfonso XII of Spain, composed in honor of his birth, received a golden baton from the Spanish royal family. His “Plegaria” (Prayer) received a diploma during the tercentenary celebration of Santa Teresa de Jesus in 1882. Silos also wrote a minuet, several paso dobles, and funeral marches. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuelupdated by Leonardo R. Silos

SILOS, LEOPOLDO (Leopoldo Rigo Silos) aka Polding Silos. B. Manila 6 Mar 1925. d. 10 Mar 2015. Composer, arranger, pianist, music director. He is the son of Juan Lorenzo Silos Jr and Marcela Acasio Rigo. Without formal training, he learned music by exposure and imitation in his natal family, which nurtured music making intensely. His father Juan Silos Jr was a famous musician and son of Juan Silos Sr, who was, in turn, the son of Leonardo Silos. Both Leonardo and Juan Sr held the position of musico mayor (music director) of Spanish Regimental Bands in the 19th century. Leopoldo’s uncles, Rosalio and Jose, as well as his sisters (the Silos Sisters) Dolores, Remedios, Lourdes, and cousin Betty were all professional musicians. At a young age and on a daily basis, he was exposed to his father’s guitar music and, later on, frequently attended music rehearsals of rondalla and listened to the singing of his sisters at home. According to his mother, Leopoldo woud play his father’s compositions and other popular songs on the piano at age four by ear (oido).

From his recollection, Leopoldo composed a short song at age eight, which his father arranged for rondalla. At age 14, he was already arranging music for local bands. This continued to the time of the Japanese occupation when Leopoldo arranged scores for local orchestras. Later on, he arranged for popular orchestras directed by musicians Serafin Payawal, Tirso Cruz, Cesar Velasco, and Tino Gatchalian, who played in Leopoldo’s wedding in 1944. Leopoldo was active in directing six live radio programs. For Bataan Recording Company, he arranged folksongs such as “Lulay” (Swaying), as well as original instrumental compositions such as “Ay, ay, ay,” “Cascarita,” “Todo Pong,” and Tumba Levanta” (Grave’s Opening).

The maturity of his career came with the musical directorship of Villar Recording Company from 1950 to 1973. His first single with Villar was the original composition “Manila Bay Rhumba,” which outsold all other Philippine records at the time of its release. For Villar Company, he arranged and conducted orchestras, accompanying famous singers such as Ruben Tagalog, Sylvia La Torre, Ric Manrique Jr, Cely Bautista, and the Mabuhay Singers. The first single of Pilita Corrales, titled “A Million Thanks,” which later became the title of her TV show, was Leopoldo’s arrangement that he recorded himself.

Leopoldo’s main contribution to Philippine music was not only in the realm of arranging, but in film music scoring and directing as well. Before his time, it was common for scorers to utilize canned music as accompaniment to visuals. Leopoldo was among the first Filipino arrangers who composed original music for movies. He was also musical director of several movies, the most notable of which was Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak (Because of a Flower). Silos composed and arranged the theme song of this movie. In the 1970s, he was the music director for the TV show Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You), featuring Armida Siguion-Reyna. He also wrote commercial jingles, the most famous being “Zoom Zoom Power” for Super Shell. In 1973, at age 48, he went on tour with the Mabuhay Singers and stayed abroad thereafter, disappearing from the local music scene.

Leopoldo has won many awards, including the American Television and Radio Commercial Festival’s CLIO Awards in New York, 1970, which hailed him as the first Southeast Asian winner of the award. One of his albums also merited the Awit Awards and his show Aawitan Kita won for him the Citizens Award for Television (CAT) in the 1970s. Written byLeonardo R. Silos

SILOS, ROSALIO (Rosalio Enriquez Silos) b. Sampaloc, Manila 4 Sep 1862. d. Bagumbayan 29 Dec 1896. Composer, band conductor. Born to LeonardoSilos, composer and bandmaster, and Antonia Enriquez, he was the brother of Juan Silos Sr and the uncle of JuanSilosJr. He received his first music lessons from his father. He was married to Benita Melgarejo with whom he had several children. At 16, he studied solfeggio and piano under Claro Vergara, and later, learned the principles of harmony and orchestration, as well as how to play the flute and the guitar under his father. From 1885, Silos served as band conductor of the Pasig Band, Regiment No 74, and Regiment No 72 of the Spanish army. His last assignment was at Iligan, where he was implicated in the revolutionary movement for being a mason, and shot on 29 Dec 1896, a day before JoseRizal was executed at Bagumbayan (now Rizal Park).

Among Silos’s musical compositions were “Lamentos” (Laments), romanza; “Orillas de Mandaluyong” (River Banks of Mandaluyong), danza habanera; “Brisa Nacional” (Breeze of the Country), mazurka; “Gugma” (Feelings), polka; and “Amor y Celos” (Love and Jealousy). He also composed a number of paso dobles or marches. Written byEspiridion Arsenio Manuel and Rosalinda Galang

SILOS SISTERS aka Silos Trio, Silos Sisters, Silos Quartet. A popular singing group from the mid-1930s to 1950s. The group was originally made up of Salud Silos (b. Manila 12 Apr 1916), daughter of musician Jose Silos, and twin sisters Dolores and Remedios (b. Manila 29 Mar 1919), daughters of rondalla exponent Juan Silos Jr. The group first known as the Silos Trio was founded by Juan Silos Jr, who trained and introduced them to the public in the KZRM’s radio program Manila Radiolites in 1934-35.

Their debut song was “Carmen, Carmela” and they appeared in the radio program Moonlight Troubadors in the 1930s. Salud, formerly a member of the St John Baptist Choir in Pinaglabanan Church in San Juan, later went solo with stage name “Sally.” Thus, Lourdes, sister of the twins Dolores and Remedios, replaced Salud, and the group was known as the Silos Sisters. In the late 1930s, the Silos Sisters sang the popular Sholom Secunda’s “Bei mir bist du schoen” (To Me You’re Beautiful), which was translated to English by Saul Chaplin and Sam Chan and popularized by the Andrew Sisters.

The Silos Sisters appeared in films such as Giliw Ko (My Love), 1939, produced by LVN and directed by Carlos Vander Tolosa and Pakiusap (Plea), 1941, directed by their uncle Octavio Silos. On Sep 1942, Juan Silos Jr added to the group another daughter of his named Betty, who first sang as a child soloist. Together they formed the Silos Quartet. Betty later married musician Joe Climaco and the two eventually became the grandparents of music director Sammy Climaco who was active during the 1980s. During the Japanese Occupation in the early 1940s, the Silos Quartet performed in Avenue Theater in dramas directed by Lamberto Avellana.

After the liberation of Manila in Feb 1945, the quartet went from camp to camp with the Cesar Velasco Orchestra performing for the American soldiers. The Silos Quartet continued to be popular during the 1950s, appearing in radio commercials. Among their famous songs ae “Paruparong Bukid” (Country Butterfly), “Tulad Ko’y Bulaklak” (A Flower Like Me), “Nevertheless,” “Kung Iibig Ka” (If You Fall in Love), “Tayo Na” (Let’s Go), “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut), “Tempranito,” “100">Subli” (devotional song-dance from Batangas), “Huwag Kang Selosa” (Don’t Be Jealous), “Ay Mama,” “El Tragon,” “Dame Un Beso” (Give Me A Kiss), “All My Love,” and “Boogie Charleston.” Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

SOKKONG, BENICIO (Benicio Damagon Sokkong) aka Benny or Beni Sokkong. b. Lepanto, Benguet 23 Aug 1955. Kalinga dancer, musician, music instrument-maker, researcher. His family originated from Tabuk, Kalinga, Northern Philippines. He had his early schooling in the public schools in Lepanto, then took dentistry at De Ocampo Memorial College. A performer and arranger of Kalinga indigenous music and dance, and maker of Kalinga musical instruments, he has been a lecturer at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music from 1986 to early 2000. Through the UP College of Music, he had the chance to participate and perform in international conferences and festivals. This was the time he realized the importance of his culture, and led him to establish the Cordillera Music Tutorial and Research Center (CMTRC) based in Baguio City in the 1990s. He was the organizer and leader of “Pasiking I & II.” He also served as project coordinator of two documentaries on the Kalinga, both produced by the Philippine Information Agency. He has written a manual on the playing of Kalinga bamboo instruments and Kalinga music.

Sokkong has performed as guest artist in the Black Current Aboriginal Arts Festival in Taiwan, 1986; the Asia-Pacific Music Festival in Germany, France, Switzerland, and Italy, 1988; the Seventh Tokyo Music Joy in Tokyo, Japan, 1991; and the Asia-Pacific Festival in Wellington, New Zealand, 1992. In 1999, he represented the Kalinga at the Philippine Folk Festival at the Smithsonian Institute, Washington, and received grants from the Asian Cultural Center in 1999 for a project with the University of Hawaii at Manoa, and in 2000, for Asia Society.

Benny Sokkong and the Pasiking Ensemble performed in Tawag ng Bantula, a three-day National Bamboo Music Festival sponsored by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) and the Musicological Society of the Philippines (MSP) in 2005. In addition, he performed and conducted several workshops with the CMTRC members in Ani ng Sining, 2006; in Tam-awan International Arts Festival in Baguio City, Gyeongju World Traditional Piri Festival (“Manpasikjeok”) in Korea, at the UST (with Aga Mayo Butocan), and at the 22nd Conference on Western Visayas History and Culture in Oton, Iloilo, all in 2011; in the First International Bamboo Festival at Maasin, Iloilo in 2013; and in the international conference, The Folk Performing Arts in the Asean, held at the Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn Anthropology Centre, Bangkok, Thailand in 2015.

Sokkong collaborated with other singers in workshops and concerts in Secret Sounds, a project in throat-singing and mouth harps with Leo Tadagawa from Japan and Mark van Tongeren from Netherlands in 2011. The project was exhibited at the Adam Art Gallery in Victoria University of Wellington. He also collaborated with the Cordillera Fusion Collective and CMTRC performers, St Louis University Cultural Performance Group, and Sagada High school teachers and students in the music video Echoes, which was created by Toby Finlayson and Joel Westlake, and which was an outcome of a three-week cultural development program with indigenous peoples in Baguio City and Sagada in 2012. Music majors from the UP College of Music also trained with Sokkong in Baguio City in 2015 as part of a Jose Maceda Project Series. Written byRosalinda Galangupdated by Josephine Baradas

SOLIS, BERNABE (Bernabe Roxas Bernabe) b. Manila 8 Oct 1898. d. Mar 1971. Active ca 1910-46. Pianist, composer, conductor. Solis was born to Simplicio Solis, a notable Filipino composer in late 19th century, and Eustaquia Roxas of Bulacan, a sarsuwelista or sarsuwela performer. At three, he showed an aptitude for music, and a year later, upon his father’s death in 1903, was sent to the Colegio de Niños Tiples of the ManilaCathedral. At nine, he left music school and became company director of the Compañia de Zarzuela Infantil. He conducted operettas such as La Mascota (The Mascot), La Viuda Alegre (The Merry Widow), El Conde de Luxemburgo (The Count of Luxembourg), and El Sueño de un Bals (Waltz Dream).

He traveled to Siam (now Thailand) where he played exclusively for the King under the sponsorship of the Siamese Boy Scouts, and to Hong Kong where he became a bandleader at the Hong Kong Hotel. He proceeded to San Francisco, California, USA in 1921 where he played the Grieg Concerto with the Liechtenstein Symphony Orchestra and eventually became musical director of the Vasquez Spanish Operetta Company. In 1929, he recorded and arranged a number of songs for Victory Company. He later lived in New York. In Broadway, he arranged the music for Belmont Varieties and Manhattan Varities, both in 1932.

Solis wrote numerous works including Philippine Sketches, for orchestra; “Hymn to Rizal,” for soprano; The Pearls of Mindanao, an operetta; El abanico de Abril (The Fan of April), sketches of life in Spain; In the Desert, a short Jewish cantata; and Eight Negro Spirituals, for solo voices and chorus. He also worked as a part-time censor for the US Army during World War II and as interpreter for the US Immigration and Naturalization Service and the US Court at Manhattan for Spanish and Tagalog speakers. In 1950, he published a 56-page collection titled Selected Songs of the Philippines. Written byRamon Jocson

SOLIS, SIMPLICIO (Simplicio Solis Geronimo) b. Paombong, Bulacan 2 Mar 1864. d. 8 Oct 1903. Violinist, pianist, composer, conductor, music teacher. He was born to Juan Solis and Maria Gonzales, both of whom came from poor families. He married, upon the encouragement of the Jesuits, Eustaquia Roxas, with whom he had 11 children; only three of whom survived. Simplicio is the father of musician Bernardo Solis who was active in theater in the early 20th century. Simplicio died of cholera in 1903.

Solis learned to make and play a bamboo flute at an early age. Like many children of Paombong from the 1860s to 1870s, he was brought by Manuel Tanghal, himself an alumnus of the Colegio de Niños Tiples of the Manila Cathedral, to the colegio, where Simplicio studied solfeggio under Apolinar Calahorra, harmony and organ under Luis Vicente Arche, violin and cello under Ramon Valdez, and piano under Blas Echogoyen. As a diligent student, he rose to the rank of first violin in the Cathedral’s orchestra and earned the praises of Fr Joaquin Calpe, then the director of singing and vocalization in the Colegio. In 1879, he left the Cathedral and taught solfeggio and piano at Ateneo de Manila.

Raymundo Bañas claimed that Solis was one of the greatest Filipino musicians in late 19th century. Solis’s achievements in the field of instrumental music performance, composition, and conducting were indeed widely known during his time. In 1882, he played one of first violins in a quintet for Liceo Artistico Literario in an event attended by the Marquis de Estella. In 1886, Solis played the violin part of Mozart’s quartet in Teatro Filipino and in Colegio de Santa Isabel for the farewell concerts of the visiting violin vituoso Eduard Remenyi. Then in Nov 1889, he played in the first violin section of the orchestra that rendered Gounod’s Mass in Quiapo church in honor of Santa Cecilia, who was the patron saint of the famous musicians’ guild at that time, Sociedad Musical Filipina de Santa Cecilia. Before the criollo violinist Manuel Garrido left for Spain, Solis played Rossini’s La Caridad with Garrido and pianist Antonio Garcia. His virtuosity on the violin was also showcased in his rendition of Alard’s fantasia Los Puritanos and in Singerlee’s fantasia arrangement of Verdi’s Aida. Aside from the violin, Solis was also a highly skilled pianist for he accompanied Filipino violin virtuoso Andres Dancel interpreting Beriot’s 12th Concerto.

Solis also excelled in conducting as demonstrated by his well remembered performance, again honoring Santa Cecilia, of Pacini’s Mass in Quiapo church on Nov 1900. This was under the auspices of another music academy, El Porvenir. In that performance he led prominent musicians of his time: the solo parts were sung by Fulgencio Tolentino, Atanacio Adonay (the brother of Marcelo), and Jose Estella, and the piano was played by Hipolito Rivera and the organ by Gavino Carluen.

In the field of composition, Solis wrote an orchestra piece Grateful Indio in 1884, a composition that seems likely a self-referential piece about his experience as a native who had climbed the social ladder for he had acquired cultural capital through his musical achievements in Intramuros. He won the 1886 contest organized by the house editor of the music store and publisher of La Lira, Saco del Valle. The winning piece was a triumphant march that earned him a gilded fine baton and writing pen. While in residence in Intramuros and while he was a music teacher at Ateneo Municipal, Solis composed a sinfonia nicknamed “Limahong” after melodies that he heard from his Chinese neighbors. Because there is no extant score of this work, it is not certain if this might be an overture of a theater piece or if it is a purely instrumental work. If it is the latter, then the piece would seem like an early symphonic work done by a Filipino and is even more significant because that would have been a self-consciously hybrid work that appropriated Asian musical element. He also composed a work for piano and orchestra titled Porta-Vaga, an early example of a Filipino concerto.

Nonetheless, most of Solis’s compositions are for the church and these are “Choir of Angels” for piano and orchestra, 1888; a hymn dedicated to Pope Leo XIII, 1903; another hymn titled “Vincimus” (We Conquer) performed at San Juan de Letran in 1892; a prayer song titled “Los Cruzados” (Crusaders); a farewell piano piece for the Virgin Mary, “Plegaria ala Virgen” (Prayer to the Virgin) which was dedicated to his former mentor Fr Calpe; a motet titled “Oh, Virgen” for three voices and organ; “Ave Maria” for two voices and organ; and three motets, “O Salutaris” for solo voice, “Ave Verum” for three voices, and “Tantum Ergo” for three voices.

His secular compositions included a hymn set to the music of Rizal’s Ultimo Adios (Last Farewell), which was performed in Teatro Zorrilla in 1901; an elegy set to a Rizal poem; and a romance titled “A Mi Hermana” (To My Sister) with words by Jose Maria Tatay.

For music theater, Solis composed the music for Proteccion Angelica (Angelic Protection), a one-act melodrama staged in San Juan de Letran on Mar 1893; Los Cruzados (Crusaders), a two-act melodrama with words by Joaquin Pellicena; Renegado y Martir (Renegade and Martyr), a drama; El Martes de Carnaval (Tuesday Carnival), one-act comic play which was performed in Oct 1892; Rizal y los Dioses (Rizal and the Gods), an opera set to the libretto by Aurelio Tolentino; The Mirror of Love, Tagalog drama with words by Ramon Reyes; and Hatinggabi (Midnight), a sarsuwela Tagala. Simplicio also helped his friend Hipolito Rivera write the music for Pantaleon Lopez’s sarsuwela Ang Infierno (Hell).

None of Solis’s music manuscripts have survived time, but his biographer Raymundo Bañas, writing in the early 1920s, claimed that these were kept in Ateneo Municipal library where Solis taught. Solis is remembered to have taught music to Norberto Romualdez who became the chief justice of the Supreme Court in the early 20th century and who wrote an authoritative organology of Philippine music instruments and classification of vocal music. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

SOLON, HERMENIGILDO aka Amoros b. Cebu City 13 Apr 1866. d. 1939. Composer. He married Desideria Salazar with whom he had five children. Solon studied at the Seminario-Colegio de San Carlos, but was not able to finish a degree. He had no formal training in music, but when he was barely 14 years old, he started to compose. Before learning to read musical notes, he had already composed numerous songs on his guitar.

In the first decades of the century, Solon was a well-known performer in balitaw and poetic jousts in Cebu. He composed songs for the sarsuwela of FlorentinoBorromeo and other writers. He is said to have written a thousand songs, including religious hymns and serenades. His best-known work, “Garbosong Bukid” (Proud Mountain), was written in Badian, Cebu in 1907 while Solon and his family were in jail on trumped-up charges by a local bigwig. His other songs include “Dingding” (Wall), “Mga Bulak nga Sugboanon” (Flowers of Cebu), “Manulonda” (Muse), “Hamis nga Aping” (Smooth Cheek), “Mahay sa Tigulang” (Lament of the Aged), and “Pagkamaluibon” (Treachery).

An American teacher brought “Garbosong Bukid” and nine other songs by Solon to the United States, where they became popular in nightclubs and hotels in big cities like Seattle. In 1928 representatives of Odeon Recording Co visited Cebu and got a contract to record many of Solon’s songs. A few years later, a local music publisher also bought the rights to some of his songs.

His other works include the unpublished “Handum sa Kamatayon ni Alejo Minoza” (In Memory of the Death of Alejo Minoza), 1925, a long verse chronicle of the life of a Cebuano revolutionary leader. Written byErlinda Alburo

SON, NOMER (Nomeriano Santos Son) b. Manila 4 Jul 1933. Singer. He is the son of Luis Son and Lydia Santos. He is married to Ma. Lourdes Santos with whom he has two children. He completed his elementary and high school at the Far Eastern University in Manila. He earned his bachelor’s and master’s degrees in architecture at the University of Santo Tomas and North Carolina State University in Raleigh, North Carolina, USA, respectively. Son started taking piano lessons at the age of six and violin at the age of nine. He took private voice lessons with Aurelio Estanislao beginning Aug 1973, then studied voice at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music.

He also participated in the spring training program of the Opera Company of Boston and the voice workshops of Raquel Adonaylo at the Curtis Institute of Philadelphia and Hanna Ludwig of the Salzburg Mozarteum. His first stage appearance was in the sarsuwela Ang Kiri (The Flirt), 1974, where he sang the role of Norris. The following year, he debuted in the opera stage as Colline in Puccini’s La Boheme at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. In 1976, he debuted in straight dramas with Teatro Pilipino’s staging of Shakespeare’s As You Like It, translated into Filipino by Rolando Tinio. He has since been one of the country’s most sought after baritones.

Among the operatic roles he has sang are: the title role in The Marriage of Figaro, Sparafucile in Rigoletto, Dr Bartolo in The Barber of Seville, Dr Blind in Die Fledermaus, the Father in Hansel and Gretel, and Pooh Bah in The Mikado. He alternately sang the roles of Elias and Padre Damaso in Felipe Padilla de Leon’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not). He was also seen in Francisco F. Feliciano’s La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf) as the tax collector Torralba, and in Jeffrey Ching’s Masquerade as Don Niccolo. His latest role was at the UP College of Music’s production of Dvorak’s opera, Rusalka, as Votnick, staged at the Cultural Center of the Philippines and UP Abelardo Hall in 2014.

As an accomplished stage actor, he has performed in Teatro Pilipino productions of The Merchant of Venice as Graciano, The Seagull as Sorin, Uncle Vanya as Telyegin and Serebriakov, Mistress of the Inn as the Marquise, The Miser as Harpagon, Twelfth Night as Malvolio, The Importance of Being Earnest as Canon Chasuble, Tartuffe as Cliante, I Am a Camera as Fritzwendel, The Visit as the Mayor, Abaniko (Fan) as Coronato, Ana Maria as Pedro, and Bayan-bayanan (Little Country) as Pol.

He performed in the sarsuwela Minda Mora alternately as Panchito, Juan, and Julio, Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness) as Don Torcuato, and Walang Sugat (No Wounds) alternately as Tadeo and Lucas. He also sang in the following oratorios: Dvorak’s Te Deum and Stabat Mater, Mozart’s Coronation Mass, Brahms’ German Requiem, Jeffrey Ching’s Rizal, Bach’s Magnificat, and Haydn’s Nelson Mass. He was also seen in several Metropolitan Theater productions: as Wang Chi Yang in The Flower Drum Song and as Karpathy in My Fair Lady, and in musical revues like Hindi Kita Malimot (I Cannot Forget You), Dahil sa Iyo (Because of You), and Sarung Banggi (One Night).

His performances abroad include those at the Lincoln Center, Chicago Civic Opera, San Francisco Opera, and other theaters in North America, as well as in Austria, Germany, Malaysia, Thailand, and Singapore. In 1993, he played in Singapore Lyric Opera’s production of Verdi’s Rigoletto as Sparafucile, and since then, Son has become a regular guest singer of the opera company. Written byRosalinda Galang and Elmer L. Gatchalianupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

SOUTH BORDER This band, founded in the 1990s, has brought the styles of rhythm and blues (R&B) and jazz into the popular music standard in the country. The group is composed of Jay Durias, composer, musical arranger, film scorer, musical director, and record producer; Joseph Marco Concepcion, drummer; Manuel Tabunar, bass guitarist; Kell Gatdula, vocalist; Prince Edward Picache, saxophonist and band conductor; and Janno Queyquep, lead guitarist.

Originally from down south Davao, from which their name is taken, South Border first gained prominence in 1996 with the release of their self-titled album. Included here is their very first hit, “Kahit Kailan” (Whenever), which was recognized as Best Produced Record of the Year by the Awit Awards in 1996. The band, though having gone through changes in lineup especially of vocalists, has produced some of the most popular Original Pilipino Music (OPM) such as “Sa ’Yo” (For You), 1999; “Habang Atin Ang Gabi” (While the Night is Ours), a movie theme song, 2002; “Rainbow,” 2003, which is the most downloaded ringback and ringtone in Philippine history; and “Ikaw Nga” (It’s Absolutely You), for the TV series Mulawin, 2003.

The band’s keyboardist and current lead singer Jay Durias composes and arranges most of the songs under Sony Music. Not long after receiving triple platinum awards for their debut album in 1997, lead vocalist Brix Ferraris was replaced by Luke Mijares. Nevertheless, the band soon produced their second album, Bump!, which bagged 16 recognitions from Katha Awards in 1999. One of its songs, “Sa ’Yo,” received the award for Record of the Year, Best Pop Song, and Best R&B Song. In this same year, they also released The South Border Live Album, recorded during their major concert at the Araneta Coliseum on 30 Jan 1999.

A few years later in 2002, they once again garnered the award for Best Pop Song from Katha Awards for the song “Habang Atin Ang Gabi.” This song became the carrier single of their fourth album titled, The Way We Do, 2001, released under Sony Music. In 2001, they performed their biggest major concert at the 35,000-seater Philippine Sports Commission’s Track and Field Oval. They are the first ever Filipino band to fill up the venue. Another album, Retrospective, was released the following year in 2002. But by the end of this year, Luke Mijares resigned as South Border’s vocalist to go on a solo career. He was then replaced by two singers.

Vince Alaras was a member of La Salle Greenhills’ Kundirana and Duncan Ramos used to perform as a singer and dancer for Gary Valenciano’s shows and tours. The duo performed in the new album, Episode III, 2004, which was the first release of their independent label, Brownhand Records. The topselling album also garnered numerous awards, including Album of the Year, Record of the Year, Song of the Year, Best Performance by a Group. Episode III Platinum Edition was released a year after. In 2006, the band moved to the United States. In 2007, the two front men left the group to pursue solo careers. Durias decided to return to Manila while the rest of the members decided to stay in the United States, where they are all permanent residents. Written byCristina Maria P. Cayabyab

SPONGE COLA The group was officially formed in 2002, four years after schoolmates Ysmael Yuzon and Reynaldo Dilay, both members of the theater group Teatrong Bagong Tao (TBT), formed White Chapel, a hard rock/metal group that was popular among high school students at the time. Originally called Sponge after R.S. Surtee’s Mr. Sponge Sporting Tour, they later modified the name of the group after discovering a Detroit grunge band carrying the same name. After the departure of the band’s original drummer, Chris Cantada, due to poor health in 2008, its current lineup features Ysmael “Yael” Yuzon (vocals, guitar), Erwin “Armo” Armovit (lead guitar), Reynaldo “Gosh” Dilay (bass and vocals), and Ted Cruz (drums).

Their single “Lunes” (Monday), from the 2003 release Sponge Cola, an extended play containing five tracks, brought them into the public eye. They have since produced five other albums: Palabas (The Show), 2004; Transit, 2006; Sponge Cola, 2008; Araw Oras Tagpuan (Day Time Setting), 2011; and Ultrablessed, 2014. Palabas and Transit reached gold status while Araw Oras Tagpuan achieved diamond status. A string of hit singles over the years such as “KLSP,” “Gemini,” “Jeepney,” “Bitiw” (Let Go), “Tuliro” (Dumbfounded), “Di Na Mababawi” (You Can’t Take it Back), “Wala Kang Katulad” (You Are like No Other), “Makapiling Ka” (To Be With You), which earned the band numerous accolades from NU Rock Awards, MYX, MTV Philippines, and other people’s choice bodies, established the band’s popularity and influence, revitalizing the Original Pilipino Music (OPM) and the rock music industry with the heavy radio airtime and huge sales of their music.

Their single “Puso” (Heart) was adopted as the anthem of the University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP) in Season 71, 2008, and used for the next four years, while “Bitiw” was the theme song of ABS-CBN’s series Pedro Penduko, which subsequently asked the band to write another theme song for the same show, “Tuloy Pa Rin” (It Goes On). The band was also the first to release copies of Sponge Cola in MP3 and MP4 formats.

Sponge Cola’s appeal lies not only in its catchy lyrics and melodies but in Yuzon’s vocals that cover the range from mellow to screamo and the constant three-part harmony in most of their vocal arrangements. The group also has the ability to adapt to changing technologies in the marketplace, thus making it widely popular with the youth. Written byLara T. Mendoza

SUAREZ, SANTIAGO (Santiago Flores Suarez) b. Sampaloc, Manila 23 May 1901. d. Manila 21 Jun 1964. Composer. He was the son of Simplicio Suarez and Miguela Flores. At 14, he provided piano music as background for silent pictures at night and worked in an embroidery shop during the day. He attended the Ateneo de Manila in Intramuros and finished his piano course at the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music. He also trained under CayetanoJacobe, Pedro Eloriaga, and NicanorS.Abelardo.

In 1925, Suarez started to compose songs and background music for bodabil shows. Such well-known artists as AtangdelaRama, KatydelaCruz, and LouSalvador sang his compositions. In the 1930s, he began composing for the movies and later became musical director. He set up the SS Suarez Music Publishing Company in 1946 and helped composers like Leopoldo Silos, ConstanciodeGuzman, and others to publish their works. He also formed a band in the early 1920s, together with Tirso Cruz Sr and ManuelSilos.

Among Suarez’s compositions which have become classics are “BakyaMo, Neneng” (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), “Sa Libis ng Nayon” (In the Countryside), “Caprichosa” (Capricious Woman), “Tapis Mo, Inday” (Your Overskirt, Inday), and “Bulaklak at Paruparo” (Flower and Butterfly). Some of his popular serenades are “Dungawin Mo, Hirang” (Look out of the Window, My Love), “Natutulog Ka na ba Sinta?” (Are You Asleep Now, Beloved?), and “Umaga na Pala” (It’s Morning).

In 1968 the Awit Awards gave him a posthumous award for composition. In 1985 he was honored at the Eighth Metro Manila PopularMusic Festival by the PopularMusicFoundation. Written byCollie de los Reyes

SUBIDO, DANNY (Danilo Tañedo Subido) b. Manila 5 Jul 1944. Composer. He is the son of Emerenciano Subido and Florentina Tañedo. He is married to Stella Gonzalez. He finished elementary at the Justo Lucban Elementary School and high school at the Polytechnic College of the Philippines.

In 1963-68, he was bandleader and guitar player of the Moonstrucks Combo. He then worked for several recording companies as arranger/composer and production consultant, rising to executive positions starting 1972. He is currently president of Studio 22, director of Final Tracks Recording Studio and FX Recording Studio, and vice-president of the Songwriters Guild of the Philippines. He also writes and produces commercial jingles.

Subido has composed and produced more than 300 songs and 70 jingles, and worked as musical director in about 50 films, including Wanted: Perfect Mother, 1970; I’ll be Loving You Eternally, Angelica, and The Wonderful World of Music, all in 1971; Aloha, My Love, 1972; and Lunes, Martes, Miyerkules, Huwebes, Biyernes, Sabado, Linggo (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday), 1976. In the 1960s and 1970s, he wrote songs for Eddie Peregrina, Edgar Mortiz, The Flippers, Lirio Vital, and Marco Sison. In the 1990s, his compositions were sung by Richard Reynoso and Marissa.

Among his songs are “Two Lovely Flowers” sung by Eddie Peregrina, “My Pledge of Love” by Edgar Mortiz, “I’ll Face Tomorrow” by Marco Sison, “Tangi Kong Mahal” (My Only Love) by Lirio Vital, and “Kailangan Ko” (I Need It) by Richard Reynoso. His song “Memories of our Dreams” was included in the soundtrack of the Lav Diaz’s film, Ebolusyon ng isang Pamilyang Pilipino (Evolution of a Filipino Family), 2004. Among his other more popular jukebox hits are “Sweet Sixteen,” “Giliw” (Dear), and “Mardy”. Albums that have been released with his songs are More, More, More of Nora Aunor, 1968; The Golden Voice, 1970; and Eddie, 1973. Later remakes were interpreted by artists Jolina Magdangal in 2000, and Simon Wood (son of jukebox king, Victor Wood) in 2009. In the 1990s, he was an actor in the film Laban Ko Ito: Walang Dapat Madamay (This is My Fight, No One Should Get Involved).

Subido has won several awards for his jingles, including 16 from the Advertising Congress of the Philippines and two from CLIO Awards. He has been cited as one of the outstanding leaders in the musicindustry in a listing by the Asia Research System and Press Foundation of Asia, 1980. Written byRosalinda Galangupdated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

SUGARFREE A self-styled alternative rock and indie band established in 28 Aug 1999 and which was disbanded on 1 Mar 2011, Sugarfree produced five original albums: Sa Wakas (In the End), 2003; Dramachine, 2004; Tala-Arawan (Diary), 2006; Sugarfree Live! With the Manila Symphony Orchestra, 2008; and Mornings and Airports (2009), all under PolyEast Records (formerly EMI Philippines). Dramachine sold more than 30,000 copies (platinum status) after its initial release in Jul 2004 and was repackaged in 2006. The band is known for its huge hits such as “Mariposa,” “Hari ng Sablay” (King of Losers), “Burnout,” “’Wag Ka Nang Umiyak” (Don’t Cry), “Hangover,” and “Kwarto” (Room)—all whimsical songs that speak of love lost, love reborn, or poignant reminiscences of childhood. They have also produced radio hits such as “Makita Kang Muli” (To See You Again), the theme song of the TV series, Ang Panday, aired in ABS-CBN in 2005. In 2013, Dancel collaborated with Gloc-9 in the popular single about the painful life of young Filipino homosexuals, “Sirena” (Mermaid).

Sugarfree owes its large following mainly to the voice of its frontman, Dancel. It is no surprise that this creative writing major from the University of the Philippines in Diliman is also the composer of more than 90 percent of the band’s songs in their 12-year stint.
