Inspired and mentored by Pinoy rock icons in the 90s such as Rico Blanco of Rivermaya and Dong Abay of Yano, Sugarfree carved out its own niche with their personalized style of love songs set to raw sound, rock rhythm of unfettered guitar strings, and unbridled drum beats. They have performed in small bars, the large auditoriums, and in open plazas all around the country.

Sugarfree’s last official concert was at Eastwood Mall titled Paalam, Pilipinas (Farewell, Philippines) with members Ebe Dancel (lead vocalist), Jai Taguibal (lead guitar), and Kaka Quisumbing (drums). Kaka replaced Mitch Singson, the band’s original drummer. Dancel released his first solo album Dalawang Mukha ng Pag-Ibig (Two Faces of Love) five months after Sugarfree disbanded under Warner Philippines. Written byLara T. Mendoza

SULAIMAN, SAMAON b. Mamasapano, Maguindanao 3 Mar 1953. d. 21 May 2011. Maguindanaon kutyapi artist. He achieved the highest level of skill in the art of playing the kutyapi, the two-stringed plucked lute. Practiced in Mindoro, Palawan, and Mindanao, kutyapi is a solo instrument among the Iraya, Palawan, Subanon, Maranao, Maguindanao, Tiruray, Blaan, Tboli, Ata, Bagobo, Manobo Cotabato, Mansaka, Mandaya, Mangguangan, Bukidnon, Higaonon, and Mamanwa. It is also often paired with bamboo polychordal zither in another type of music. Kutyapi comes in diverse sizes and shapes, and is known by different names.

Fundamentally, however, kutyapi music share a basic music organization. On one of its two strings is played a steady part that one would call drone, while on the other string, a melody is crafted on the movable frets. Kutyapi melodies, which are pentatonic, can be based on a scale with semitones or on one with none.

The Maguindanaon have excelled in kutyapi music, producing fine finger techniques that are difficult to execute. Traditionally, kutyapi playing is transmitted across generations through imitation and Samaon Sulaiman acquired the ability to play it from his uncle when he was around 13 years old. Sulaiman had since then been engaged with honing his skills and cultivating a wide repertory on the instrument, later becoming one of the most acclaimed kutyapi masters in Libutan and other barangays in the town of Magonoy. Along with kulintang artist Amal Lemuntod, Jose Maceda presented Sulaiman in concerts in Manila and in Europe and his creativity on the instrument had strongly influenced other instrumentalists of the area such as Esmael Ahmad, Bitul Sulaiman, Nguda Latip, Ali Ahmad, and Tukal Nanalon. In 1998, Sulaiman was featured in the 50th Smithsonian Folklife Festival in the United States.

Sulaiman’s music can be heard in a field recording that Jose Maceda made in Oct 1980 and which the University of the Philippines Department of Music Research (now Department of Musicology) published in 1988, Kulintang and Kudyapiq: Gong Ensemble and Two-string Lute among the Magindanaon in Mindanao, Philippines. In that recording, he demonstrates his extensive knowledge of the instrument’s repertoire, playing this in two tunings known as dinaladay and binalig. His music is refined and sensitive. It is rich in melodic and rhythmic invention.

Like other distinguished indigenous artists, Samaon also knew how to play the kulintang (graduated gongs laid horizontally in a row), agong (suspended bossed gong with wide rim), gandingan (bossed gong with narrow rim), palendag (lip-valley flute), and tambul(drum).

As a traditional musician, Sulaiman earned a living from sources other than his music. He was a popular barber in his community and served as an imam in the Libutan mosque. For his artistry, Sulaiman received the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan recognition in 1993. Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

SUNICO, RAUL (Raul Morales Sunico) b. Manila 29 Feb 1948. Pianist. He is the eldest of four children of Faustino Sunico and Julita Morales. He started his piano lessons at the age of five under Marina Diokno. He also studied under Benjamin Tupas as a scholar at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music. After graduating from the Ateneo High School, he took up liberal arts and music simultaneously at the University of the Philippines (UP).

There he obtained his teacher’s diploma in piano, 1969; bachelor of music, major in piano, cum laude, 1970; bachelor of science in math, 1972; and master of science in statistics, 1973. He received a master’s degree in music from the UP in 1992. His piano mentors were Benedicta Macaisa of UP, Sacha Gorodnitski from Juilliard, and Joseph Villa of New York University. He also finished his master of music degree from the Juilliard School in New York and a doctor of philosophy degree, major in piano, from the New York University, with a dissertation titled “Selected Philippine Piano Concerti.” In 2006, he was also conferred a doctor of humanities degree, honoris causa, by the Far Eastern University. Sunico succeeded Erlinda Fule as dean of the UST Conservatory of Music in February 2002. He was appointed president of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in Oct 2010.

After winning the 1966 Young Artists’ Competitions, Sunico debuted as soloist of The Manila Symphony Orchestra, with Herbert Zipper as conductor. He was also the silver medalist at the 1979 Viotti International Piano Competition in Vercelli, Italy, and he became a finalist at the 1979 Busoni International. Since then he has performed extensively in the United States, Canada, Austria, Germany, France, Poland, Spain, the Netherlands, Kosovo, Korea, Japan, Sri Lanka, India, Australia, and the United Arab Emirates. In the Philippines, he has been featured as soloist of major symphony orchestras.

Sunico has recorded more than 40 CDs and albums including 15 volumes of Filipino folk songs and kundiman that he arranged for classical piano. His recordings include Lucino T. Sacramento’s two concertos, Maharlika (Noble),1973, and its sequel Ang Bituin (The Star), 1974, with the CCP (now Philippine) Philharmonic Orchestra; In a Classic Piano Mood, 1987; and Philippine Songs Set to Classical Piano, 1990,

He has published the two-volume choral arrangements titled Mga Awit ng Himagsikan: Songs of the Philippine Revolution 1896-1898, 1997, and the four-volume Himig: A Collection of Filipino Folksongs in 1995-99, all under Tawid Publications. Sunico has also recorded the seven-volume Classic Philippine Sentiments: A Keyboard Treasury of Love Songs and Folk Songs, 1999; Ugnayan sa Tugtugan: A Treasury of Philippine Music, 2003; Romanza, 2004; and Sungdoni Ayat, 2006.

A recipient of the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award for music in 1986, he also won the Henry Cowell Prize at the University of Maryland International Piano Competition, 1980. Other awards received include Outstanding Filipino Individual Overseas from the Philippine President, 1996; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the City of Manila, 1998; KATHA Music Awards recipient, 1997 and 1999; Special Award for Himig Vol IV, from the National Book Development of the Philippines, 2000; Diamond Jubilee Award from the Phi Kappa Phi Honor Society, UP Chapter, 2003; and the Aliw Award for Best Male Classical Instrumentalist, 2004. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgoupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

SURBAN, MAX b. 15 May 1947. Singer, composer.Surban finished high school at the University of Southern Philippines and studied to be a machinist at the Cebu College of Arts and Trade. He worked for six months at the Visayan Electric Company before becoming a professional singer.

In 1965, he began singing at the Insular C66, Stardust, and other nightclubs in Cebu. In 1968, he went to Luzon where he spent a year singing at the US Subic Naval Base in Olongapo and two years later at the Seafront in the US Embassy Family Club. During the Vietnam War, he joined a band as vocalist and entertained soldiers at Saigon and Danang. In 1971, he returned to the Philippines and established the Neophonic Band. He later traveled for singing stints in Taipei and Japan.

Surban’s first recorded song in 1971, “Mitulo Na” (And The Tears Fell), sold over 100,000 copies. The recording of “Lolang Kunot” (Wrinkled Grandma) under Vicor Music Corporation followed and soon other hits included “Kurdapya,” “Aguy Kalami” (Oh, So Delicious), “Balbacoa,” “Angelita,” “Estong,” “Baleleng,” “Diskoral,” “Diwalwal” (Stick Out Your Tongue), “Albularyong Buta” (The Blind Folk Doctor), “Budbod ug Bibingka” (Rice Stick and Rice Cake), and many others. He recorded 33 albums.

He became known not only as a balladeer but also as a comic singer whose songs recalled the comic daily experiences of local folk such as the sidewalk vendors, rural people and older men courting young women. The humorous lyrics gave life to calypso, cha-cha, boogie, tango, waltz, and even folk tunes. He also composed “Ang Tao’y Marupok” (Humans are Weak), a Tagalog song, for Rico J. Puno.

Surban received the monicker “King of Visayan Song,” collecting many distinctions for his songs, albums, and contributions as a whole in the music scene in the Philippines and in other countries where he had been invited to perform. On 15 Mar 2008, he was recognized for his contribution to the promotion of Cebuano music and the arts in the Halad sa Kinaiyang Sugbuanon held at the Cebu International Convention Center where he received the Outstanding Cebuano in the Field of Music award. Written byRamon Jocson and Marlon Wuiupdated by Hope Sabanpan-Yu
Suzara, Venancia (See THEATER volume.)
Tagalog, Ruben (See BROADCAST ARTS volume.)
Tagaroma, Patrocinio (See THEATER volume.)

TAN, ARWIN Q. (Arwin Quiñones Tan) b. Laoag City, Ilocos Norte 13 Oct 1971. Choir conductor, music historian, music educator. He comes from a family of entrepreneurs, headed by his father Domingo Ang Tan and his mother Milagros Cheng Quiñones. Arwin first studied piano with Emy Lou Nicolas of Nicolas Music Studio in his hometown before enrolling, at age 15, in Yamaha School of Music under a succession of teachers, the most important of whom was Eric Dimson, who trained him to win in the National Electone Contest in 1994. This achievement brought Tan to Thailand where he joined the Asia Oceania Electone Festival. After finishing a dual humanities and accounting degree at De La Salle University in Jan 1991, Tan passed the government licensure examination for certified public accountant in September of the same year. In 1994, he enrolled for a second degree at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, as piano major under Augusto Espino. Shortly thereafter, however, he shifted to choral conducting, which required recitals that were mentored by Joel Navarro. While in UP, Tan also became a member of the Philippine Madrigal Singers under Andrea O. Veneracion. It was from this experience with Veneracion that Tan’s skills in choral conducting were further honed and his knowledge of performance practice and literature further expanded and vastly enhanced. Tan graduated magna cum laude in choral conducting and valedictorian of the graduating class in UP College of Music in 1998.

The choir Novo Concertante Manila was formed out of his choral conducting recitals. So successful was the organization of the choir that Tan continued directing to the next decade. Under his direction, Novo Concertante Manila soared to great heights by winning top prizes in international competitions. Aside from directing Novo Concertante, Tan also directed the University of Asia and the Pacific Chorale, 2003-06, which also won coveted awards in Europe, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines Chorale, 2003-10.

From Veneracion, Tan acquired new ways of musical interpretation, choir management, and even organizing choral workshops. All these skills Tan, along with colleagues nearest to Andrea Veneracion such as Mark Carpio and Jonathan Velasco, brought to the founding of the Philippine Choral Directors Association in 2007. For the last decade, Tan has conducted choral clinics and has served as a member of juries in national and international choral competitions.

In addition, Tan is a music historian. He finished a master’s degree in musicology from UP, with a thesis on the life and works of the brass band leader and composer Lorenzo Ilustre from Batangas. This work became the basis for a research dealing with music as a form of cultural capital.

Tan has also taught music history in UP College of Music, and a range of other music courses in St Scholastica’s College, Ateneo de Manila University, University of Asia and the Pacific, and the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music.

For his achievements in choral music, Tan’s choir was awarded the Ani ng Dangal by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2010, 2011, 2013, and 2015. He was also conferred the UP Artist I Award in 2013.Written byJose S. Buenconsejo

TAN, DANNY (Daniel Surian Tan) b. Jolo, Sulu 29 Jul 1959. Composer, musical director, arranger, record producer, and talent manager. Born to Den Ho Tan and Perosa Surian, he attended the Muhammad Tulawi Elementary School in Jolo, Sulu and Brooke’s Point Christian High School in Palawan. A scholar of the Department of Education, he enrolled for a degree in music as piano major but eventually shifted to composition at the, University of the Philippines College of Music in Diliman. On his fifth year in college, he worked to finance his graduation recital but this never materialized. He worked as a pianist and choir conductor of San Juan Gospel Chapel and also taught piano and music theory at FEBIAS Bible College. From 1981 to 1983, he became an accompanist and musical director for RepertoryPhilippines, and composer, arranger, and musical director for Far East Broadcasting Co.

Tan gained notice in the musicindustry in 1984, when his arrangement of the song, “Salamat, Salamat, Musika” (Thank You, Thank You, Music) won for composer GaryGranada and interpreter Nanette Inventor the grand prize at the Seventh Metro Manila PopularMusic Festival. He has worked as musical director/arranger for major concerts of noted singers like PilitaCorrales, CelesteLegaspi, Cynthia Patag, JoeyAlbert, Regine Velasquez, JoseMariChan, BasilValdez, BertNievera, Nonoy Zuñiga, Zsa Zsa Padilla, Kuh Ledesma, Ivy Violan, Donna Cruz, Vina Morales, APO Hiking Society, Martin Nievera, Gary Valenciano, Ariel Rivera, Vernie Varga, Mitch Valdes, La Diva, Jaya, Lani Misalucha, and Dulce; for awards nights and music festivals; and for television shows and specials such as Superstar, The Sharon Cuneta Show, Tanghalan ng Kampeon (Stage of the Champion), Maricel Live, Maria Maria, Loveliness, Your Evening With Pilita, Popstar Kids, Pinoy Idol, and SOP.

Among his recorded compositions are “Iisa Pa Lamang” (Only One), “Hindi Sapat ang Lahat” (Everything is Not Enough), “Kung Mayroong Pangarap” (If There is a Dream), “Alam Mo Na, Di Ba” (You Know It, Don’t You), “Easy to Love You,” “Close To Where You Are,” “Written In The Sand,” “Sometimes You Just Know,” “You Lift Me Up,” “My Only Christmas Is Jesus,” “Kasiping Ka” (Intimate With You), “Ay Amor, Rosalinda” (Oh My Love, Rosalinda), “Aking Mundo” (My World), “S’ya na nga Kaya?” (Is She the One?), and “Mahal Kita” (I Love You).

In 1997, Tan founded the KATHA Music Awards, an organization of Filipino composers, where he served as chairman until 2000. He was also a member of the Board of Directors of Filipino Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (FILSCAP) from 1998 to 2000. Tan sat as a judge in TV reality singing contests, including GMA Network’s Pinoy Pop Superstar, Are You the Next Big Star?, Pinoy Idol, and Celebrity Duets. He was the founder, musical director, and arranger for the children pop group Sugarpop, and musical director, vocal arranger for the female powerhouse trio, La Diva, comprised of Jonalyn Viray, Aicelle Santos, and Maricris Garcia. As a talent scout, he discovered Julie Anne San Jose during the auditions of Popstar Kids and David Ezra, Dulce’s son, who is a classical artist and musical theater performer.

Tan has won awards for his compositions, musical scoring, and song arrangements in both international and local competitions. His compositions and musical arrangements of Philippine song entries have helped Regine Velasquez, Ivy Violan, Jaya, Lani Misalucha, and Dessa win the grand prize in the 1989 Asia-Pacific Song Festival in Hong Kong and the FIDOF Award in the 1992 Asia Song Festival in Russia, respectively. He bagged the grand prize in the First Asian Broadcasters Union (ABU)/Golden Kite World Song Festival, Kuala Lumpur Malaysia for the song “Easy To Love You” with lyrics by Jose Javier Reyes in 1990; and won the Best Arranger of a Finnish song and grand prize winner in the 4th International Midnight Sun Song Song Festival, Lahti, Finland, 1991. His musical score for Ang Totoong Buhay ni Pacita M. (The Real Life of Pacita M.) won in the 1991 Metro Manila Film Festival and the Star Awards. His composition “Iisa Pa Lamang” also won him nominations as Best Arranger and Best Composer at the Awit Awards in 1991 and the Golden Scroll Award in the 1991 Young Achievers’Awards. Another composition, “Alam Mo Na, Di Ba,” was adjudged Best Movie Theme Song of the Year by Star Awards in 1993. In 1996, the First Metropop Music Festival awarded him the grand prize for his composition “Sometimes You Just Know,” with lyrics by Edith Gallardo, and interpreted by Jaya. In the following year, he won another grand prize for his composition “You Lift Me Up,” lyrics by Dodjie Simon in the 2nd Asia Song Festival, Hongkong and garnered the best musical arrangement during the 10th Awit Awards. In 1998, he got another award in the Asia Song Festival, Philippines. In 2010, he received the best vocal arrangement award for “Apologize,” interpreted by La Diva, which was also adjudged best musical group in the 23rd Awit Awards. Written by Rosalinda Galangupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

TAPALES, ISANG (Luisa Canals Tapales) b. Manila 21 Jun 1901. d. Manila 3 Jul 1987. Her parents were Silvestre Tapales, a composer and bandleader, and Isabel Canals. Her brother, RamonTapales, was a violinist and former director of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music. She divorced her first husband, Polish baritone George Ciapliz, and married Filipino tenor Enrique Gonzalez with whom she had three children.

At 15, she received a scholarship from the governor of Mindanao to study in Manila. She enrolled at the Philippine Normal School and took private lessons with JovitaFuentes. To raise money for her studies, she joined the troupe of LouBorromeo in 1918 and gave concerts in the provinces in 1922. In 1923, Tapales left for Italy, together with her brother Ramon, and studied under Ernesto Caronna and Lina Cardea. In 1924, she made her operatic debut in Puccini’s Madame Butterfly in Bergamo, then toured Italy for the entire year. She gained international recognition during her tours of South America and Europe in the 1920s. At the Royal Theater of Brussels, Belgium, where she performed for five years starting in 1927, her portrait hangs side by side with other renowned singers like Enrico Caruso. She also starred in La Boheme and Cavalleria Rusticana.

Tapales returned to the Philippines before the outbreak of World War II and produced operas during the Japanese occupation. Later she taught at the Centro Escolar University Conservatory of Music and the University of the East School of Music and Arts.

She received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award in 1977 and the Tandang Sora Award in 1980. Written byAntonio C. Hila

TAPALES, RAMON (Ramon Canals Tapales) b. Baybay, Leyte 17 Feb 1906. d. United States 22 Feb 1995. Conductor, violinist, composer. He and singer IsangTapales were the children of Silvestre Tapales and Isabel Canals. He studied the violin under the tutorship of his father and later with BonifacioAbdon. In 1923, he studied at the Verdi Conservatory of Music in Milan, Italy, graduating in 1927; then trained in violin in Berlin, Gemany under Carl Flesch of the Hochschule für Musik, and in composition under Max Butting of Klindworth-Scharwenka.

Among Tapales’s works for orchestral music are: MariangMakiling, 1934; PhilippineSuite, 1935; The Last Trail, 1946; and Messa in Stile Antico, 1956. He also composed chamber music, like Sonata Satirica, 1971, and vocal music, like “Luha, Masaklap na Luha” (Tears, Painful Tears), 1927, and “Ave Maria,” 1938. He authored Singing and Growing, 1952, a music textbook for the primary grades, and Collection and Recollection, 1979, a book on humor. He also wrote an unpublished book, “The Anatomy of the Violin Technique” under a JDR III scholarship.

He founded and was the first president of the National Music Council of the Philippines and the Regional Commission of Southeast Asia, both established in 1953. He led Philippine delegations to Brussels, Japan, and Southeast Asian countries. He was guest conductor at the National Opera Theater in Riga, Latvia, and in Italy, Belgium, Hawaii, Taiwan, and Korea. He was also a founding member of the LeagueofFilipinoComposers.

He received numerous distinctions, among them, Presidential Awards from four Philippine presidents; first Asian member, executive board of the International Music Council of UNESCO; one of Nine Distinguished Musicians of the World chosen by the UNESCO International Music Committee; and the 1992 Gawad CCP Para sa Sining. He was director of the Conservatory of Music at Silliman University until 1941, and of the University of the Philippines (UP) from 1946 to his retirement in 1970. He was the first dean when the Conservatory became the UP College of Music in 1968. Written byRolando B. Tolentino

TEMPONGKO, ENGRACIO (Engracio Choco Tempongko) b. Tondo, Manila 3 Nov 1925 d. Manila 23 Aug 1991. Choral conductor. He is the eldest of five children of Deogracias Tempongko and Arcenia Choco. His siblings are Angela, Pedro, Victor, and Ester. He finished his elementary education at the Rizal Elementary School in Tondo Manila and completed his secondary education at Torres High School, also in Tondo. He did not have any formal music training in his childhood and his exposure to the art was limited to the music subjects in his school. But Tempongko was immersed in choral music in church. He became assistant conductor of the Manila Cathedral Choir from 1953 to 1970. This provided him an opportunity to train under Fr John Van de Steen, CICM, founder and conductor of the group, who had extensive music training in Europe before coming to the Philippines.

In 1965, Tempongko was awarded a scholarship grant in boys’ choir training by the Music Foundation of the Philippines. He also had an opportunity to go abroad and observe some of the famous choirs such as the choir of the Sistine Chapel in Rome, The Little Singers of Paris, the Vienna Boys Choir, and the Escolania in Montserrat.

He was a delegate to the World Music Congress Festival in Cologne, Germany. He represented the Philippines in 1976 in the Asia Chorus Seminar in Seoul, Korea. He became the choir trainer and conductor of the Las Piñas Boys’ Choir from 1974 to 1978 and, starting in 1970, served as the choirmaster of the Tiples de Santo Domingo, the oldest boys’ choir in the country. As he dedicated his life to teaching music, he became one of the country’s most prominent experts in voice and choir training for boys. He died of cardiac arrest in 1991. Written byMaria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua

TIPLES DE SANTO DOMINGO In 1587, a group of street boys were taken in and taught by Dominican Fr Pedro Bolanos to sing songs to the Virgin Mary and to play musical instruments. They were housed and educated by the Dominican priests. The tradition has been kept till today.

Tiple, a Spanish word, refers to the “highest and brightest human voice,” usually that of a soprano or little boys. The members of the choir are trained to sing in this style. The choir consists of about 28 members whose ages range from six to 13 years old, most of them coming from poor families, though a few from well-to-do clans have been taken in lately. To enable the boys to maintain the quality and continuous development of their voices, the Santo Domingo parish provides them with a total living system. As scholars of the parish, the boys are enrolled at the Angelicum School and are given free board and lodging at the Tiples House in the parish grounds in Quezon City. They visit their families on Sunday afternoon and return to the Angelicum the next day to attend their classes. The choir members are required to attend daily rehearsals in the afternoons for two hours after their classes. Those interested may take piano and organ lessons.

During concert seasons, schedules of rehearsals become more demanding. Since 2000, the choir has been under Eugene de los Santos, who also happened to be a tiple member himself in 1990-94. The Tiples had Engracio Tempongco as their choirmaster from 1970-83.

The Tiples perform regularly on Sundays at the Santo Domingo Church, at 7 and 10 am and 6 pm on weekdays. But the Santo Domingo Church is not the only venue of their performances. The Tiples have given concerts in many locations such as Malacañan Palace, Clark Field, Manila Hotel, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). One of their important performances was a command concert for the international delegates of the General Chapter of the Dominican Order held at the CCP Main Theater in 1977. Another performance at CCP took place in 1988 to commemorate the quadricentennial anniversary of the Dominican order in the country.

The group usually performs outside the Santo Domingo church during yuletide season, for example, in the Villancicos ng Paskong Pilipino (Carols of Philippine Christmas) in which they performed with other choirs at San Agustin Church, Intramuros, in 2011. In 2014, the choir was invited to perform with other top children’s choirs of the country in the concert titled 6th Halina’t Umawit at the CCP Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo; and at the Bamboo Organ Festival performing works of Filipino composers Joed Balsamo and Joy Nilo. The boys’ choir also had their first television appearance in 1988 when they interpreted Vic Villafuerte’s composition, “Maligayang Bati, Panginoon” (Happy Birthday, God). It was also their first recorded musical performance. They are recognized in music circles as one of the leading church choirs in the country today. Written byMilagros Carununganupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

TOLEDO, CHINO (Josefino Javier Toledo) b. Manila 6 Mar 1959. Composer, conductor, educator. Born to Lolita Javier and Victor Toledo, founder of the internationally acclaimed Pangkat Kawayan, he belongs to a highly musical clan in Nueva Ecija. He is married to Emily Ramos, a music education graduate, with whom he has two children. He received his early musical education during tours with the Pangkat Kawayan. While in high school at the Far Eastern University, he took formal music lessons at the Laperal Music Academy. He graduated with a bachelor of music degree, major in composition, from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1979, and had Eliseo M. Pajaro, Lucio D. San Pedro, and Ramon P. Santos as his mentors. After graduation, Toledo taught at the UP and at the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory of Music. Then in 1983, he took further studies in Paris, at the Conservatoire National Superieur de Musique, as a scholar of the French government and, in 1985-86, finished graduate studies in composition at the Cleveland Institute of Music in Ohio, USA under a grant from the Asian Cultural Council.

Toledo served as resident conductor and music director of the Manila Symphony Orchestra in 1985-87, and music director of the Siena Letran Chorale in 1982-83. He has conducted the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) and done musical arrangements for the PPO and Tanghalang Pilipino’s sarsuwela productions. For a time, he was chairperson of the Composition and Theory Department of the UP College of Music. He is currently a full professor of music composition and theory at the UP College of Music, while serving as the executive director of Miriam College Center for Applied Music, music director of Metro Manila Community Orchestra (MMCO), and GRUPO 20/21, a modular music ensemble.

Aside from his 1979 prizewinning works, Tatluhan (Trio) and Taghoy sa Kalikasan (Lament for Nature), his major works include Tula-li, 1984; Aliw-iw, 1985; Dalawang Ug-og (Two Ug-og), 1986; an orchestral piece, Ug-nay (Link), 1984; Kulambo: Ang Kayumangging Puntod (Mosquito Net: A Brown Grave), 1986; Trenodya Para ke Lean (Threnody for Lean), 1988; Tanikala (Chain), 1990; Sigaw (Shout), 1997; Dasal (Prayer), 1997; Kantus: Tagabawa, 1999; Kwaderno Para sa Kwerdas (Notebook for Strings), 2000; Mga Sulyap sa Simbahan ng Quiapo Mula sa Kalye Echague (Glances at the Quiapo Church from Echague Street), 2004, revised 2012; Hoy!, 2004; Ekontra: Kongruo: Iunktum, 2007; and the two-act opera, San Andres B, 2013.

Toledo has also written choral pieces premiered by various Philippine choirs and performed in international competitions. Among these are: “Ako ang Daigdig” (I Am the World), 1986; “Alitaptap” (Firefly), 1995; “Mga Awit ng Paglingap” (Songs of Compassion), for 16 voices and bamboo percussion, 1999; “Dignum et Iustum Est” (It Is Right and Proper), for chorus and piano or orchestra, 2000; and the complete Misa Sama-Sama (Unity Mass), for chorus and small percussion instruments, comprising of “Santo Sanctus,” 2012; “Gloriya,” 2012; “Kredo,” 2013; “Kor Dei,” 2014; and “Kristo Kyrie,” 2014.

He is the founding director of the MMCO, with which he has performed extensively premiering many of his new orchestral works. Together with the MMCO, Toledo has also initiated an Orchestra Reading program, “Music Under Konstruction,” which provides a venue for young Filipino composers to experience and gain practical knowledge working with an orchestra conductor and musicians. Since its inception in 2006, the program has produced 36 original works by young composers such as Nilo Alcala II, Joel Cruz, Gian Gianan, Nelson Polvoriza, Reginald Tan, Louise Ybañez, Erwin Fajardo, Marie-Louise Calvero, Feliz Macahis, Alexander John Villanueva, Michael Bulaong, Robert Sarreal, and Ireneo Orio III.

Toledo has received awards for his compositions, beginning at the age of 16 when he won first prize in the Ateneo de Davao Hymn Contest. From 1978 to 1980, he was a four-time prize winner in the Young Composers Contest sponsored by the Cultural Center of the Philippines and League of Filipino Composers. He was a finalist of the Kucyna International Composition Prize in Boston, 1985, and a Raymond Hubble awardee in composition from the American Society of Composers and Publishers, 1986-87. He was one of the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) awardees in 1997. In 2012, UP recognized his artistic output by granting him the UP Artist III Award. He received the Natatanging Guro Award from the UP Chancellor in 2014. He has been cited in the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, 20th Century Composers of Asia, Komponisten der Gegenwart, Who’s Who in International Music, and Who’s Who in Australasia and Far East. Written byFelizidad Z. Reyes and Ma. Patricia Brillantesupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

TOLENTINO, FULGENCIO (Fulgencio Tolentino) b. Antipolo, Rizal 16 Jan 1872. d. Malate 1940. Active ca 1890-1930. Composer, conductor, pianist. He studied at the Colegio de Niños Tiples de la Santa Iglesia Catedral in Manila and trained under Maestro Blas Echegoyen in solfeggio and Oscar Camps in piano. At 16, Tolentino became the chorus master of a Spanish zarzuela Company. He taught piano for 14 years at the Ateneo de Manila and for five years at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran. Among his students were Francisco Santiago, Antonio J. Molina, Jose Mossesgeld Santiago-Font, Maria Carpena, Francisca Tirona-Benitez, Pilar Hidalgo-Lim, and Lucia Santiago.

A long-time friend of sarsuwela writer SeverinoReyes, he wrote the music for many of Reyes’s plays, like WalangSugat (No Wounds), Los Martires de la Patria (The Martyrs of the Land), and Filotea o Ang Pag-aasawa ni San Pedro (Filotea or the Marriage of Saint Peter). Of his many works, Walang Sugat, 1902, became most famous. Written byRolando B. Tolentino

TOLENTINO, TOTS (Mario Allid Tolentino) b. Baltimore, Maryland, USA 2 Jul 1959. Jazz musician, saxophonist. He is the son of Arturo David Tolentino and Emma Allid. Tots Tolentino is the grandson of former senator Arturo Tolentino. While in high school, he listened to Jazz Friends with Lito Molina at the Thomas Jefferson Cultural Center and at the Bacchus Pub. He started playing flute at the age of 16 with Eli Clamor at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music in 1975 and later on the saxophone after hearing Charlie Parker in the listening room of the school. Aside from Charlie Parker, his major influences are Hubert Laws, Michael Brecker, Sonny Stitt, and John Coltrane. In 1980, Tolentino enrolled at the Berklee College of Music in Boston where he graduated magna cum laude after three years with a degree in professional music.

In 1977, his first group as a horn man was the Sunlight Band headed by pianist-composer, Ed Crisologo Jose, and drummer-composer, Richie Quirino, performing an all-original repertoire under the jazz fusion genre. The following year, he became the founding member of the UP Jazz Ensemble headed by pianist Fred Robles where he experienced a taste of big band performance. He has performed in numerous overseas jazz festivals such as the North Sea Jazz Festival in the Netherlands, the Singapore Jazz Festival, and the Java Jazz Festival in Indonesia. In 1985, under Blackgold Records, Tolentino recorded four albums for Japanese harpist Tadao Hayashi, namely, Standing Room Only, Best of Tadao Hayashi, Christmas a la Tadao, and Tadao’s Christmas Wish. In 1987, Tolentino recorded a number of solos in the independently produced all-original album, Universe, the Light of Peace, under the East-West Records Label. In 1990, he launched his career as a soloist, recording his first album Tots Tolentino. Years after, he recorded Inah, 1991, and Color Real, 1993, with the carrier single, “Ethnic Daw” (Ethnic They Call It), which raised quite a few eyebrows since it was different from the usual Top 40 grooves. In the year 2000, Star Records of ABS-CBN recorded Tolentino’s solo album Buhay (Life), which garnered favorable reviews. In the same year, he was a featured soloist of guitarist-composer Bob Aves’s album titled Inner Country under BMG Records. Affinity, a jazz quintet headed by guitarist-composer Johnny Alegre, recorded two albums under Candid Records titled Affinity and Eastern Skies, which featured Tolentino on the alto sax. In 2005, he was a featured soloist of the all-original Angel Peña big band album called Ugnayan (Collaboration) produced by pianist-conductor Gerard Salonga.

In Jun 1991, Tolentino, along with other guests, singer Vernie Varga and violinist John Lesaca, performed in the concert of pianist Bobby Enriquez dubbed The Master in Concert at the Metropolitan Theater. In 1996, corporate giant Philip Morris launched the Rhythms on Tour series, which included inter-island provincial sorties to Bacolod, Cebu, Cagayan de Oro, and Davao. It featured Tolentino, singers Jacqui Magno, Vernie Varga, Lynn Sherman, Ivy Violan, Roselle Nava, Joannie Feliciano, 100">Bert Nievera, violinist John Lesaca, and pianist Tateng Katindig.

Tolentino simultaneously heads the big band of the University of Santo Tomas and is the director of its jazz program and is concurrently the first alto sax player of The AMP Big Band headed by arranger-conductor Mel Villena.

Tolentino won the 1992 Awit Awards for Best Jazz Recording (Instrumental) for “Inah” under the Vicor Label. Written byRichie Quirino

TRIBUNG PINOY Tribung Pinoy is a singing group founded by banker and art patron Danny Dolor in 1978 to preserve and promote traditional Philippine musical forms and art songs. Except for basso profundo Constancio Cadelina who resigned earlier, the group’s original membership remained the same until their disbanding in 1995. They were Gloria Dizon-Coronel, coloratura-soprano, and Erlinda Dacanay-Azcuna, mezzo-soprano, who are both opera and sarsuwela artists as well as alumnae and faculty of the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Conservatory of Music; Lourdes Sauco Francisco, lyric soprano, a corporate lawyer; Vladimir Valera, baritone and a state prosecutor; and Renato Almira, tenor, who worked for a private corporation, and for a time, was executive secretary of the office of Sen Wigberto Tañada. Julie Mendoza, an alumna of the UST Conservatory of Music alumna, was the group’s musical director and pianist, Ed Borbon its choreographer, Reynaldo Torres its production coordinator, and Dolor himself its executive director and producer.

The group’s repertoire consisted of kundiman, harana, balitaw, and other classical, folk, and standard songs. Their performances were enlivened by novelty songs which featured the unique Filipino way of lambingan (tenderness) and tuksuhan (teasing), capped with theatrical clowning, bringing happiness to their audiences.

In 1980, the group represented the Philippines in the Cross-cultural Friendship Festival held in Seoul, Korea. They also performed in charity concerts for the National Mental Hospital for rehabilitated patients, Correctional Institute for Women in Mandaluyong, and at the Culion Leper Colony in Palawan.

In 1980 and 1983, Tribung Pinoy was cited as the Best Cultural Group by the Aliw Awards. It was elevated to the Aliw Awards Hall of Fame in 1986. In Aug 1989, it was honored by the Kapisanan ng mga Propesor sa Pilipino (KAPPIL) for propagating nationalistic songs as well as the Filipino language itself. By 1990 it had given more than 500 concerts throughout the Philippines and in cities in the United States, Canada, Europe, Asia, and the Middle East.

Since 1995, however, the group has become inactive with the eventual passing of two of its original members: Renato Almira and Erlinda Dacanay-Azcuna. The group’s producer, Danny Dolor, continued to manage other activities through the Tribung Pinoy Foundation. Charity and benefit concerts continued, albeit, occasionally, as well as shows for special events, particularly tributes to literary and musical luminaries such as Abelardo Suarez, Jose Corazon de Jesus, Atang de la Rama, Florentino Collantes, Conching Rosal, Carmen Rosales, and Sylvia la Torre. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgoupdated by Arwin Q. Tan

TUPAS, BENJAMIN (Benjamin Giron Tupas) b. Manila 14 Jun 1930. d. 24 Feb 1974. Pianist. Born to Alberto Tupas and Anastacia Giron, he studied at the Philippine Conservatory (now the Philippine Women’s University College of Music and Fine Arts), University of the Philippines, and University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he obtained a bachelor of music degree in piano under the tutelage of JulioEstebanAnguita. With grants from the Philippine government and the MusicPromotionFoundationofthePhilippines, he attended the Peabody Conservatory of Baltimore and the Georgetown University in Washington, DC, where he enrolled in the School of Foreign Service and the Institute of Languages and Linguistics. He also earned a music degree from Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut. While a student, he appeared as a soloist of the New Haven Symphony, and was praised for his performances of Tchaikovsky’s B-flat Minor Concerto with the Baltimore Symphony.

Tupas concertized widely in the United States and Canada, and under the sponsorship of the British Arts Council, toured England for six months both as a soloist and accompanist.

Tupas taught piano at Santa Isabel College and UST, and was director of the UST Conservatory of Music from 1966 to 1971. The most notable of his students was Ma. Luisa Lopez-Vito. In 1968, he composed Prelude and Toccata Based on Kulintang Motives. He also participated in organizing activities for the National Music Week in 1973, the first NationalMusicCompetitionsforYoungArtists, Ugnayan, and the first Cultural Center of the Philippines songwriting contest. He was a consultant for music at the Bureau of Standards for Mass Media and Department of Public Information before his death.

He won the Harriet Cohen Prize. He also recorded sonatas by Alban Berg and Paul Hindemith for Lyrichord Records, which were cited for their excellence by Time Magazine and High Fidelity. Written byJulie Ann Hallazgo

UMALI, RESTIE (Restituto Aquino Umali) b. Paco, Manila 10 Jun 1916. d. Quezon City 30 Aug 1997. Composer, arranger, teacher. Umali was the second child of Benedicto Umali, a self-taught musician, and Eulogia Aquino, an amateur singer. His wife, Belen Chico, is also a singer. At an early age, Umali was taught violin by his father, and while a member of the Mapa High School glee club and orchestra, was exposed to music techniques, solfeggio, and score reading. He also joined the band while studying at Jose Rizal College, where he earned his bachelor’s degree in commerce, and also at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he alternately played the E-flat horn, trombone, and tuba. He did band arrangements of various songs and musical pieces to earn extra money. He was part of a rondalla composed of members of his family: his mother and brother Cristino on the bandurria; his father, the laud; his sister Chimang, the bass guitar; and himself, the guitar. During the Japanese Occupation, he took his first formal lessons in harmony under FelipePadilladeLeon. He played with the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra at its first concert after World War II, in the partly ruined Santa Cruz Church. He volunteered to teach double bass at the University of the Philippines, a post he held until 1957. While teaching, he took courses in composition and conducting under AntoninoBuenaventura, RamonTapales, and LucreciaR.Kasilag. Then, he taught choral arrangement at the UST. He also attended masterclasses and seminars with international contemporary composers such as Hans-Georg Koch, Gary Burton, Peter Braun, and Joachim Buhler.

He has written over 150 songs for the movies and has supplied music for more than 250 films, including the Universal International production of No Man is an Island starring Jeffrey Hunter and Barbara Perez. Umali was the musical director of the movie, Cry of Freedom, directed by Lamberto Avellana in 1959. Some of his notable film compositions include, “Romance,”1953; “Ikaw ang Lahat sa Akin” (You Are My Everything), 1969; “Sa Araw ng Kasal” (On Wedding Day), 1970; “Dearest Forever,”1971; “Sa Pagitan ng Dalawang Langit” (Between Two Heavens), 1974; and “Lupang Pangarap” (Dream Land), 1975.

Umali arranged the PhilippineNationalAnthem and “Kataka-taka” (How Strange) for the Boston Pops Orchestra, especially for the Philippine Independence Night Concert held in Boston in Jun 1972. His choral compositions and arrangements include “Iginuhit ng Tadhana” (Drawn by Fate), “Ang Pasko sa Aming Nayon” (Christmas in Our Village), and “AyKalisud” (Ah, Misery). His solo songs include “Inay, Inay” (Mother), 1962; “Sa Araw ng Kasal,” 1970; “Nasaan Ka Inay?” (Where Are You, Mother?), 1972; “Batingaw” (Bell), 1973; “Anihan sa Bukid” (Harvest Time in the Field) and “Di Ka Mag-iisa” (You Will Never Be Alone), 1974; and “Inang Mapagmahal” (Loving Mother), 1975. His music as interpreted by PilitaCorrales is featured in a long-playing album, Themes from Filipino Movies. He also wrote music for theater: Ang Lakambini at ang Supremo (The Muse and the Supreme Leader) and Recuerdos (Memories), a one-act ballet.

Among his classical works are: First String Quartet, 1982; Luzviminda, a symphonic suite, 1983; and Dangal ng Lahi (Pride of the Race), a concert overture, 1990. He was at one time board member of the UP Music Alumni Association and the Filipino Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (FILSCAP), and member of the League of Filipino Composers (LFC).

He has won numerous prizes and awards, such as the first prize in the Philippine Independence Hymn Contest in 1947; the Manila Film Festival Best Music award for Bitter Sweet in 1969; the FilipinoAcademyofMovieArtsandSciences(FAMAS) awards as Best Musical Scorer for Sa Bawat Pintig ng Puso (For Every Heartbeat), 1964, Pinagbuklod ng Langit (United by the Heavens), 1969, which also received the Best Theme Song award, Mga Anghel na Walang Langit (Angels Without a Heaven), 1970, and Ang Alamat (The Legend), 1972; and the Olongapo Film Festival Best Music award for Ang Agila at ang Araw (The Eagle and the Sun) in 1973. In 1984, he was the Hall of Fame awardee of the Popular Music Foundation of the Philippines. Written byAntonio C. Hilaupdated by Crisancti L. Macazo

UP CHERUBIM AND SERAPHIM Children’s choral ensemble. It was established in 1971 by Flora Zarco-Rivera, a professor of music from the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music and chairperson of its Department of Conducting and Choral Ensembles. It is the official children’s choir of the University of the Philippines Diliman. The group was a pioneer in the field of the secular, school-based children’s choir. The choral quality they developed is the result of experiments undertaken over the years to discover a sound ideal for Philippine children.

The members are recruited when they are six to nine years old and train for a year before becoming regular members. They perform until they graduate from high school. The group started with 12 children enrolled in Saturday music extension classes at the College and the group has grown to an average of 25 to 30 members. The present director is Rivera’s daughter, ElenaRivera-Mirano, a retired professor in art studies from the UP College of Arts and Letters.

The choir has developed a unique repertoire consisting of compositions for children by Filipino composers, among them, national artists RamonP.Santos and LucioD.SanPedro; arrangements of folk songs by Antonio Regalario and Fabian Obispo; music by young composers Christine Muyco, Phoebe Roa, and Carlos Pizarro; and popular Filipino songs by Joey Ayala and Ryan Cayabyab. Many of the works were commissioned by the group and constitute its contribution to the national musical effort. It also performs songs from the western classical tradition, including choral music written by Schubert, Mozart, and Bach, as well as contemporary compositions by Astor Piazolla, Morten Lauridsen, and Bruno Coulais. The group shares this repertoire through concerts, workshops and music camps.

The group celebrated its 45th anniversary in 2016 with a restaging of the theater piece for children titled Awit ni Pulau: Dulang-Awit sa Tao’t Kalikasan (Song of Pulau: Sung Theater for Man and Nature) with libretto by Edgardo Maranan and music by Ramon P. Santos. The work had its premiere in 1991 in celebration of the group’s 20th anniversary. Written byMa. Lourdes Maniquis updated by Elena Rivera-Mirano

UP CONCERT CHORUS (UPCC) Founded in 1962 by RamonTapales, it began as a choral ensemble known as the UP Mixed Chorus performing for university functions and was composed of students from different colleges. The first conductor was director Tapales, then Aurelio Estanislao became the vocal coach, with Juan P. Ramos, and later RamonP.Santos, as associate directors. Flora Zarco-Rivera led the chorus for a while before ReyT.Paguio became its conductor in 1967 until his untimely death in Oct 1999. In Nov 1999, Janet Sabas-Aracama, a professor from the UP College of Music Conducting Department, took over as the conductor and artistic director.

The Chorus has performed all over the world, with 22 international tours to its credit. The group is known for its versatility: its repertoire include medieval music drama like Carl Orff’s Catulli Carmina, in the 1970s; masses like Ryan Cayabyab’s Misa (Mass), in the 1980s; operas like The Barber of Seville in concert-style in 1987; Broadway musicals like Bernstein-Sondheim’s West Side Story in Filipino, in the 1970s; and sarsuwela like Rey T. Paguio and Domingo Landicho’s Sumpang Mahal (Sacred Vow), Antonio Molina’s Ana Maria, 1991 and 1995, and Atang de la Rama and Leon Ignacio’s Bulaklak ng Kabundukan (Flower of the Mountains), 1994. It has produced three full-length television musicals, and received a Cecil Award for its recording of RyanCayabyab’s Misa.

The Chorus represented the country at international song and performing arts festivals, such as those in Barcelona, Spain, 1974; Manila, 1979; and Aberdeen, Scotland, 12 times in all. In 1985 it was named the United Nations’ Ambassadors for the International Year of the Youth and Philippine Ambassadors of Goodwill. It performed in North America, Europe, and Southeast Asia. In 1986, the group gave a series of concerts in Australia and took part in the Youth Music Festival in Adelaide as part of the 150th anniversary celebration of South Australia.

In 1974, it was named one of the world’s best choirs at the Lincoln Center Intrnational Choral Festival in New York. From the 1980s to the 1990s, UPCC won the following in international competitions: first place, Polyphonic Youth Category, International Choral Competition, Pohlheim, Germany, 1983; third place, Polyphonic Adult Category, International Choral Competition, Spittal, Austria, 1985; third place, Polyphonic Adult Category, first place, Folksong Adult Category, second place, Polyphonic Youth Category, second place, Folksong Youth Category, Förderkreis Internationale Chortage, Mainhausen, Germany, 1988; first place, Polyphonic Youth Category, third place, Folk Category (youth division), and third place, Masterpiece Category (youth division), Polheim International Choral Competition, Germany, 1990; first place, Folksong Adult Category, Concorso Polifonico


Internazionale della Guido d’ Arezzo, Italy, 1990; third place, Polyphonic Adult Category, Eisteddfodd Choral Music Competition, Wales, 1990; and second place, Folk Category, and third place, Mixed Choir Category, Festival Internacional de Musica de Cantonigros, Barcelona, Spain, 1994.

In the 2000s, the UPCC, this time with Janet Sabas-Aracama, won the following: in 2003, first place, International Folk Song Festival, Arezzo, Italy, and second place, Female Choir Category and third place, Male Choir Category, 8th Förderkreis Internationale Chortage, Mainhausen, Germany; and in 2012, first prize and second prize in the same categories the Chorus won in the same festival in Barcelona, Spain in 1994. They also joined in two other international competitions: at the 9th Cantemus International Festival, 2012, in Nyiregyhaza, Hungary, where they won Gold Diploma and Audience Prize, and at the IV International Harald Andersen Chamber Choir Competition in Helsinki, Finland, where they were chosen as one of the six best choirs, the only Asian choir to have made it that far. In Jun 2015, the UPCC won the Grand Prix at the 6th International Krakow Choir Festival in Poland, in the mixed choir competition, where they were the only Asian choir to have competed from among 24 choirs comprising 10 countries. They also won second prize in the folk-popular-and-Gospel music category in the same festival.

Through the years, UPCC reaped a lot of local awards and distinctions: Best Cultural Group, Aliw Awards, 1977, 1982, and 1985; Cultural Newsmaker of the Year Award, from the TV show Tatak Pilipino, 1992; Best Cultural Performing Group, UP Gawad Chancellor, 2002 and 2004; Best Choral Group, Aliw Awards, 2008 and 2009; Hall of Fame for Best Choral Group, Aliw Awards, 2010; Lifetime Achievement Award, Aliw Awards, 2012; and Ani ng Dangal awardee, National Commission for Culture and the Arts, 2013. Written byJeanna B. Malabuyoc updated by James C. Diaz

UP JAZZ ENSEMBLE Founded in 1977, The UP Jazz Ensemble is a jazz group based in the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music. The band has 30 members comprising of current students and alumni of the college and its musical director is Raymundo “Rayben” Maigue. Its beginnings can be traced to the year 1977 when Joseph Howard, a music professor from the United States under a Fulbright grant, volunteered to teach jazz theory, improvisation, and big and small jazz ensembles classes at UP College of Music. His eight-month stay motivated many students of trumpet, trombone, saxophone, and percussion to pour out their creative energies in the art of improvisation that is different from and which complements the classical music training in the College. After Howard left for the United States, his students continued to hold regular jamming sessions which gave rise to the establishment of the group that is now known as the UP Jazz Ensemble. The College of Music later formalized the jamming sessions into a regular course in the curriculum. Since 1980, it has been handled by one of J. Howard’s students, Rayben Maigue, an accomplished trumpet player, composer, arranger, and currently chair of the UP College of Music Department of Winds and Percussion .

The UP Jazz Ensemble’s repertoire consists of well known works of jazz composers and arrangers like Duke Ellington, Glenn Miller, Sammy Nestico, George Gershwin, and Count Basie. They also perform jazz arrangements of popular music compositions such as the songs of the Beatles, film music of John Williams, new age music of Dave Grusin, and the works of Filipino jazz artists such as Angel Peña, Richie Quirino, and Jon Palacio. The ensemble has served as a training ground for student arrangers, composers, and conductors. It has also produced many of the country’s professional jazz musicians who perform in groups like the Ugoy Ugoy Band, Side A Band, Brass Monkeys, Parliament Syndicate, and the AMP Big Band.

In recognition of their meritorious contributions to the field of jazz music, the group was awarded the First City Jazz Achievement Award by the DWCT FM Station City Lite 88.3 in 1989. In 1999, the UP Jazz Ensemble was recognized by Petron Corporation for being prime movers of jazz in the Philippines with their long years of virtuosity and for dedicatedly leading in the development of Filipino talent in the field of music. The ensemble actively promotes Filipino jazz and live big band jazz performance in order to widen jazz appreciation in the country. Written byArwin Q. Tan

UP ROTC BAND A performance group comprised of wind and brass instrumentalists based in the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, the UP ROTC Band’s main function is to provide music in major university events and act as the musical arm of the Reserve Officers’ Training Corps (ROTC) of the university. It offers scholarship to its members by giving free tuition and accommodation at the Department of Military Science and Tactics Complex in the UP Diliman campus.

Its beginnings can be traced to the late 1960s when Eliseo Clamor, a professor at the UP College of Music, formed a band unit for the university’s ROTC program. In the early 1980s, Clamor was succeeded by Rodolfo de Leon under whose directorship the band came to be known formally as the UP ROTC Band. At about the same time, a young trumpet student at the UP College of Music, Raymundo Maigue, was inspired by the visiting Eastman Wind Ensemble from the United States to form a small wind ensemble, the members of which were mostly from the UP ROTC Band. Due to the shortage of membership, this small wind ensemble merged with the Philippine Youth Symphonic Band, a government-sponsored project under the Marcos administration which was the result of an annual summer training camp at the Philippine High School for the Arts in Mt Makiling, Los Baños, Laguna. The summer camp was discontinued during the Aquino administration and the band was adopted by UP. It was renamed the UP-Philippine Youth Symphonic Band (UP-PYSB), with mostly the same members comprising the UP ROTC Band.

The directorship of the UP ROTC Band was passed on to Ret Col Peregrino Aledia in the early 1990s, who also taught band conducting in the UP College of Music. In 1998, Rodney Ambat was appointed by then dean Reynaldo T. Paguio to conduct the UP-PYSB, which he later renamed as UP Symphonic Band. Both the UP ROTC Band and the UP Symphonic Band were later assigned under the leadership of Leopoldo Lopez in 2003, from which time onward, both became known under the merged UP ROTC Symphonic Band. In 2011, upon the demise of Lopez, the baton was passed on to Rodney Ambat who continues to lead the band with an active concert schedule. Since 2011, the UP ROTC Symphonic Band (aka UP Symphonic Band) has presented three major concerts: Ode to the Common Filipino, A Symphonic Metamorphosis, and Sound Images. They have also participated in the 1st National Symphonic Band Festival organized by the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2012. In its history, the band has produced some of the most distinguished names in the military and continues to be a source of commanding officers and enlisted personnel for band units in the Armed Forces of the Philippines and the Philippine National Police. Written by Arwin Q. Tan

UP SINGING AMBASSADORS (UPSA) The University of the Philippines (UP) Singing Ambassadors was founded in 1980 by Ed Manguiat when he was associated with the UP College of Music. It is one of the finest choirs in the Philippines today with a wide range of repertoire from classical choral music literature, popular music with choreography, to Philippine indigenous and folkloric music with colorful costumes.

UPSA has consistently won in international choir competitions in Europe such as five grand prizes, 23 first prizes, and various prizes and awards in Arezzo and Gorizia, Italy; Debrecen, Hungary; Tours, France; Varna, Bulgaria; Llangollen, Wales, United Kingdom; Neuchatel, Switzerland; Torrevieja and Cantonigros, Spain; Sopot, Poland; Trenscianske Tiplice, Slovakia; Maasmechelen, Belgium; Wernigerode, Germany; Arnhem, The Netherlands; and Prague and Pardubice, Czech Republic.

In 2005, UPSA was the official representative of the Philippines to the UNESCO International Music Festival in Paris. The group was elevated to the Hall of Fame at the 25th Aliw Awards after winning three times as the Best Choral Group in the Philippines in 2011, 2010, and 2002.

In 2011, UPSA sang as the “Centennial Choir” in Nestle’s 100 Years Celebration, in the Centennial Celebration of the Yuchengco Group of Companies, and in the Salvador P. Lopez Centenary Program. In the same year, the group launched the “UP Vanguard Centennial Anthem,” a recording which included the “UP Law Centennial March.”

Other highlights of the choir’s history include its leadership in the grand choir composed of 18 groups from 13 countries in Australia’s World Voices where they sang in the international choral festival held at the Sydney Opera House as part of the 2000 Sydney Olympics, and its performance before then French Pres Jacques Chirac and other world dignitaries at the Ecumenical Service for victims of the 9/11 tragedy held at the American Church in Paris. UPSA also provided back-up vocals for Josh Groban in his two-night concert stint at the Philippine International Convention Center. UPSA also has an outreach program which raises funds for the sick and the needy. The group has visited hospital wards, homes for the aged, and orphanages. Written by Antonio C. Hila

article_title: UP Symphonic Band (See UP ROTC Band.)
text: UP Symphonic Band (See UP ROTC Band.)

UST SINGERS The University of Santo Tomas (UST) Singers is a mixed choir founded by Fidel G. Calalang Jr in 1 Sep 1992. It is composed of students and alumni from different colleges and faculties of UST. Since the choir was founded, it has mounted several concerts that earned critical acclaim. During the rectorship of Rolando V. de la Rosa, OP (1990-98; 2008-12), the choir took on its first international sojourn in 1993. What followed were 21 prolific years of national and international recognition, making them one of the world’s best choirs. UST Singers had won 75 first prizes thus far. Since 1993, the choir made 26 international concert tours in Europe, Latin America, United States, Canada, and Southeast Asia. The group represented the Philippines in 22 international contests in Gorizia and Arezzo, Italy; Tours, France; Tolosa, Cantonigros, and Torrevieja, Spain; Lindenholzhausen and Miltenberg, Germany; Miedzyzdrojie and Sopot, Poland; Spittal, Austria; Olomuoc, Czech Republic; Monster, The Netherlands; Cork, Ireland; Bangor, Northern Ireland; Llangollen, Wales, United Kingdom; San Luis Obispo, California, United States; and Yeosu, South Korea.

In 1998, the UST Singers garnered two first prizes and the Prix du Public at the 27th Florilege Vocal de Tours in Tours, France, and the Gran Premio (Citta di Gorizia) together with four first prizes at the 37th Concorso Internazionale di Canto Corale (C.A. Seghizzi) held in Gorizia, Italy. The choir bested 21 international choirs, which qualified the UST Singers to represent Gorizia in the 11th European Grand Prix for Choral Singing held at Varna, Bulgaria in May 1999.

During its 2010 European Concert Tour, the UST Singers made a milestone in the Llangollen International Musical Eisteddfod in Wales when it won for the second time the highly coveted Choir of the World Grand Prize-Luciano Pavarotti Trophy. The group won this award for the first time in 1995. In addition, the UST Singers bagged three first prizes in mixed choir, madrigal singing, and sacred categories, second prize in Light Entertainment, and a grand prize in open choir category at the 16th Bangor International Choral Competition in Northern Ireland; Lady Dorothy Mayer trophy for the 20th- century piece “Gapas” (Harvest) by Eudenice Palaruan; The Peace Prize (Public Prize) at the 56th Cork International Choral Festival in Ireland; three first prizes in sacred, secular/folk, jazz/gospel/spiritual categories, and the Grand Prix at the 6th Mundus Cantat International Choral Festival in Poland; two first prizes in the folk and mixed choir categories at the 28th Festival Internacional de Musica de Cantonigros in Spain; and first prize in the habanera category, Premio del Publico and Premio Intercontinental at the 56th Certamen Internacional de Habaneras y Polifonia at Torrevieja, also in Spain.

Over the years, the UST Singers has also performed in international choral festivals such as the Festival Coral Internacional de Alava and Jornadas Internacionales de Musica Coral de Caja de Burgos, Maig Coral in Barcelona, Festival Mundial de Coros in Puebla, Mexico, the Taipei Philharmonic Festival in Taiwan, Polyfollia International Festival for Choral Singing in Normandie, International Festival of the Choral Art in Jihlava, Czech Republic, Hannover World Expo, Zaragoza World Expo, and Shanghai World Expo.

In 2011, the group completed three international concert tours, which brought the choir to Latvia and Sweden. Moreover, the UST Singers gave a well-received concert in the esteemed Eric Ericson International Choral Centre, in Stockholm. The group also performed in the closing concerts of the 6th International Harmonie Festival in Lindenholzhausen, Germany, and in the 15th Daejeon International Choir Festival in Daejeon, South Korea.

Year 2011 also saw the UST Singers conferred the International Achievement Award from the Aliw Awards. UST also gave them the 2011 Benavides Outstanding Achievement Award for musical achievement. The group was one of the recipients of the 2011 Ani ng Dangal from the National Commission for Culture and Arts for Excellence in International Competition as well, a second time for the group that won the same award in 2009.

In May 2012, the UST Singers received an invitation from the Philippine Embassy in Madrid to perform for the “Mes Filipino” (Philippine Month) festivities. This tour brought them to Palencia, Madrid, Cadiz, Sevilla, Malaga, Carrion de los Condes, and Jerez de la Frontera, with the highlight being the choir’s performance at the Oratorio de San Felipe Neri, site of the signing of the Cadiz Constitution.

In May 2013, the UST Singers returned to the Mundus Cantat International Choral Festival in Sopot, Poland where they emerged grand prize winner in 2010. In Jun 2013, the choir competed in the first edition of the Yeosu International Choral Festival and Competition in Yeosu, South Korea where they garnered three third prizes in the sacred, folk/spiritual/gospel, and pop and jazz categories, and second prize in the mixed choir category. In July, the UST Singers concertized in Beijing, China under the invitation of the Beijing Wuzi University. In October, the choir was featured at the “Philippine Cultural Days in Vietnam,” a project of the National Commission of the Culture and the Arts (NCCA) and the Vietnam Ministry of Culture, Sports, and the Arts in Hanoi, Vietnam.

The UST Singers had concert collaborations with the University of Utah Singers, the APZ Tone Tomsic of Slovenia, the Suwon Civic Choir of South Korea, the Academic Choir of Adam Mickiewicz University of Poland, the Kantilena of Czech Republic, the Junges Vocal Ensemble Hannover, Cantabile Limburg, and Renner Ensemble of Germany, and the Singapore Youth Choir. The choir also worked with conductors Ruggiero Barbieri, Jae Joon Lee, and Robert Ryker for the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ productions of Jeffrey Ching’s Rendezvous in Venice, 1997; Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9, 2009; Karl Jenkins’ Requiem, 2010; and La Traviata and The Barber of Seville, both in 2012.

The UST Singers had recorded CDs such as Then Sings My Soul, Valencia Spain (2010); American Encore, 2009; The UST Singers in 1998, 1999, 2000, 2002, 2004, produced by Jurgen Bruch; and The UST Singers produced by Peter Krings in Friedrichsorf, Germany. Written by Antonio C. Hila

VALDES, MITCH(Alma Oppus Vaca)aka Maya Valdez. b. Manila 21 Oct 1951. Actor, singer. Born to Manolo Vaca, a singer, andAliceOppus, she lived for several years in Japan where her father worked. She finished second year bachelor of arts at St Scholastica’s College in Manila. She was one of the pillars of the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit (OPM) and now serves as its chair.

Valdes began in the theater, workingfirst as a wardrobe mistress, as a props person, and stage manager before becoming an actor.Fresh from high school in 1968, she had her first productions with Repertory Philippines. Later she also joined the Philippine Educational Theater Association in 1974. While at the theater, she made her first TV appearance on the showSuper Laff-inin 1970. Daily shows came in with ABS-CBN’s Oras ng Ligaya(Happy Hour) in 1970 andTony Santos Presentsfrom 1971 to 1973. Her succeeding shows continued to feature her as a comedienne:Cleofatra, 1974;Champoy,c 1980; andU.F.O. (Urbana,Felisa,and Others),in the mid-1980s.In 1983, she went back to lounge actsthat included the musical stand-up comedy actTit for Tat, which was the first in a string of hit shows with singer-comedienne Nanette Inventor. She has since then starred in numerous musical comedy acts opposite the country’s top performers, like the highly successful lounge actRock da Vote,1992, with Inventor, Tessie Tomas, Fe de los Reyes, and Jon Santos.

Valdes won acclaim for her acting and singing as Magdalene in the rock operaJesus Christ Superstar,1971, directed byFritz Infante. In 1972, she portrayed the role of Rose in theCulturalCenterof thePhilippines(CCP) production ofGypsyunder the direction of LinoBrocka. She was Sally Bowles inManilaHotel’s production of Cabaret,1977, directed byLeoMartinez.

Valdes’s first appearances in the movies were in roles which displayed her flair for comedy, likeKasing-kasing Ko (My Love), 1973, and Pabling (Playboy) and Totoo Ba ang Tsismis? (Is the Gossip True?), 1981. In 1976, she won the Best Supporting Actress Award from Gawad Urian for the Lino Brocka film,Lunes,

Martes,Miyerkules,Huwebes,Biyernes,Sabado,Linggo (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday). She showed she was equally good as a dramatic actor inOroPlataMata(Gold Silver Death), 1982, then inBulaklak sa City Jail(Flower in the City Jail), 1984.She combined her considerable talents as actress and singer in her highly praised performance asKatydelaCruzin the hit musicalKaty! The Musical,1988, staged at the Rizal Theater, and later at the CCP Tanghalang NicanorS.Abelardo, under the direction ofNestorU.Torre. She was also cast in the Filipino production of Menopause The Musical: A Period Piece, 2012. In the new millennium, she has been performing in shows at the Captain’s Bar and at the Music Museum. She also appeared in the following movies: Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw (It’s You That I Need), 2000; David F., 2013; and Diary ng Panget (An Ugly Girl’s Diary), 2014. She does occasional guestings in various TV shows. Written by Galileo Zafra and Elmer L. Gatchalianupdated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

VALDEZ, BASIL (Basil Salvador Valdez) b. Manila 8 Nov 1951. Singer. Born to Perfecto Valdez and Suzana Salvador, he studied at the Ateneo de Manila University from grade school to college, graduating with a bachelor of arts degree in philosophy.

In the early 1970s, Valdez first sang with the Circus Band which was composed of Hajji Alejandro, Walter Calinawan, Pat Castillo, Pabs Dadivas, Paco Gamboa, Ceres Jacinto, Boy Katindig, Rudy Lozano, Jacqui Magno, Tillie Moreno, and Gerry Paraiso. Later Valdez went solo. His first album, Ngayon at Kailanman (Now and Forever), 1977, was a major hit and an award winner. Nine other albums followed, all of them successful, including Corner of the Sky, Basil Valdez, Basil: Hindi Kita Malilimutan (Basil, I Will Not Forget You), and Nag-iisang Pangarap (A Single Dream). These albums contain songs—now more than a hundred—which have become etched in the public memory, such as “Ngayon at Kailanman,” “Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan” (Until the End of Eternity), “Kung Ako’y Iiwan Mo” (If You Leave Me), “Paraisong Parisukat” (Four-cornered Paradise), “Kastilyong Buhangin” (Sand Castles), “Ngayon” (Today), “You,” “Lift Up Your Hands,” “Corner of the Sky,” “Hindi Kita Malilimutan” (I Will Never Forget You), “Sana ay Ikaw na Nga” (I Hope It’s You), “Let the Pain Remain,” and “Say That You Love Me.” Most of hit ballads were written by George Canseco. Another composer who became Valdez’s musical director and main collaborator is Ryan Cayabyab who also wrote hit songs for Valdez, including “Nais Ko” (What I Want), “Tuwing Umuulan at Kapiling Ka” (When It Rains and You’re Beside Me), “Kahit Ika’y Panaginip Lang” (Even If You’re Only a Dream), “Tunay na Ligaya” (True Happiness), and “Iduyan Mo” (Cradle Me in Your Arms).

In the 1980s, Valdez became the favorite interpreter of movie theme songs, such as “Paano Ba ang Mangarap” (How Is It to Dream), “Muling Buksan ang Puso” (Open Your Heart Again), and “Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan” (How Often is Once). In 1985, however, health problems forced Valdez into semi-retirement as he underwent throat and kidney surgery several times. Fortunately, he was able to recover from his illness. All throughout the 1990s, Valdez focused his energies on nonmusical endeavors. He taught philosophy in Ateneo de Manila University and religion in Xavier School. He also dabbled into painting and became a pranic healer.

He later made a successful comeback to the recording industry with three albums: The Filipino Classics, 2006, a production with the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra; The Best of Basil Valdez, 2010; and The First Christmas, 2014. He also went back to the concert stage, performing with Kuh Ledesma and Zsa Zsa Padilla in a series of concerts abroad, and appearing as one of the special guests in My Gift: Piolo Pascual First Time in Concert, 2004, at the Araneta Coliseum.

Valdez has performed in numerous venues in the country and abroad, including Japan, Singapore, Malaysia, Canada, United States, Germany, Morocco, Italy, United Kingdom, and Guam. He was also part of the rock opera ballet Rama, Hari (King Rama), 1980, where he sang the part of Rama.

Valdez won the Aliw Awards as Best Male Local Concert Performer in 1977, Best Male Performer in Hotels, Clubs, and Restaurants in 1978, and Entertainer of the Year in 1979. From 1977 to 1980, he was chosen as one of the 10 Most Outstanding Performers in the Philippines at the Tinig Awards. “You,” 1983, “Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan,” 1984, and “Hindi Kita Malilimutan,” 1985, earned Record of the Year awards, in addition to a string of other awards. “You” received awards for Best Pop Male Vocal Performance, Best Ballad Performance, Song of the Year, Best Instrumental Arrangement Accompanying Vocals, and Best Ballad Composition; “Lift Up Your Hands,” for Best Religious Song; “Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan,” for Best Male Vocal Performance; the album Basil Valdez, for Album of the Year and Best Album Package; and “Hindi Kita Malilimutan,” for Best Male Vocal Performance, Best Male Pop Ballad Performance, Song of the Year, Best Pop Ballad Composition, and Best Religious Song. In 1991, Valdez was conferred the Tanglaw ng Lahi Award by the Ateneo de Manila University. In 2001, Awit Awards honored Valdez with a Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino recognition. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

VALENCIA, LUIS b. Aliaga, Nueva Ecija 1913. d. Mar 1982. Violinist, conductor. He was the son of Maximiano and Felisa Valencia. He graduated from the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music in 1932 and took up postgraduate studies there. In 1936, he studied at the Vienna State Academy of Music. Valencia performed for eight years on the concert stage as a violinist and as a conductor. He also organized the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra. In 1963, he was chosen “Orchestra Conductor of the Year” by the Manila Music Lovers Society. In 1968, he was sponsored by the MusicPromotionFoundation ofthePhilippines to go on a tour of Genoa, Rome, Vienna, New York, Toronto, and other music capitals to observe the latest trends in opera conducting. Earlier in 1953, he had received a Smith-Mundt grant for the same purpose.

In the early 1950s, Valencia was head of the violin department of the Philippine Women’s University College of Music and Fine Arts. He served on the jury of the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Fort Worth, Texas in Sep 1973. When the CCP (later Philippine) Philharmonic Orchestra was founded in Apr 1973, he became its resident conductor until he died in 1982. He was given the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in 1982. Written by Crisancti L. Macazo

VALENCIANO, GARY (Edgardo Jose Martin Santiago Valenciano) b. Santa Mesa, Manila 6 Aug 1964. Singer, composer, movie and television actor. Born to Vicente Valenciano, a Filipino engineer, and Grimilda Santiago Ortiz who hails from Puerto Rico, he is the sixth child in a family of seven children. He finished grade school and high school at De La Salle Greenhills and Memorial Junior High School in Florida. He is married to Ma. Anna “Angeli” Pangilinan with whom he has three children: Paolo, a musician; Jose Angelo Gabriel, singer, keyboardist, and dancer; and Kristiana Maria Mikaela, model and singer. Actor Leo Martinez is his brother-in-law. In 1998, he became the first Filipino ambassador for UNICEF.

During his high school days, Valenciano joined the glee club, Kundirana, which performed on school campuses and was immensely popular. Having officially entered the entertainment industry in 1983, he first appeared on television on the Pilita and Jackie Show, but it was his performance on Germspesyal and Penthouse Live! which gained him the notice of the mass audience. A series of concerts at Tavern on the Square followed. In Apr 1984, in his first concert, Alive!, at the Araneta Coliseum, he made his big leap to the top of the pop music world. He has held several concerts every year since then, among them, his first all-OPM (original Pilipino music) concert in Sep 1985 at the ULTRA; his free anniversary concert in Apr 1989 at the Luneta Grandstand to a mammoth crowd of 800,000; his series of concerts in Sep-Oct 1990, Gary V. Major Impact!; and his four-night Gary V. Shout! concerts at the Araneta Coliseum. He has also performed numerous times in Singapore, the Middle East, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Australia, Guam, Canada, Chicago, Washington, New York, Hawaii, San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Japan.

Valenciano has recorded 26 albums starting with Gary … in 1983. Eight have become gold records: Gary …, 1983; Gary … Next, 1985; Gary Inside Out and From Gary, Merry Christmas, 1986; Moving Thoughts and Di Bale na Lang (Never Mind), extended version, 1987; Heart and Soul, 1989; Faces of Love, 1990; and Shout 4 Joy, 1991. Two have reached the double-platinum mark: Faces of Love and From Gary, Merry Christmas. Shout 4 Joy and Moving Thoughts have reached triple-platinum status. Among his most requested songs on radio are: “Di na Natuto” (You Never Learn), “Huwag Mo na Sanang Isipin” (Don’t Think About It), “Di Bale na Lang,” “Take Me Out of the Dark,” and “Shout for Joy.” He has also appeared in TV commercials for major products and composed commercial jingles.

As a musical arranger, he has arranged most of his recent releases in recording including “Shout for Joy,” “Gaya ng Dati” (Just Like Before), “That’s Why,” and “When I Hear You Call.” He also composed three songs and did the musical scoring for most of the arrangements for the first English Christian musical First Name written by Freddie Santos. He finished musical scoring for the Christian film Hinugot sa Dilim (Saved from the Darkness).

He has done more than 10 movies which include Lino Brocka’s Kung Tapos na ang Kailanman (When Eternity Ends) where he was also cited as New Movie Actor of 1991 by the Star Awards for his performance. Other film credits include: Ibulong Mo sa Diyos (Whisper to God) and Natutulog Pa ang Diyos (God is Still Asleep), 1988; Kaputol ng Isang Awit (Fragment of a Song), 1991; Hataw Na! (Hit It!), 1995; and I Do Bidoo Bidoo, 2012. He was the lead actor in “Goodbye, My Friend,” the episode which won for Lovingly Yours, Helen the Best Television Drama Series award from the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA).

He has composed and/or performed the theme songs for the following movies: “Growing Up” for Bagets (Teens), 1984; “You Don’t Have To Say You Love Me” for Payaso (Clown), 1986; “Natutulog Ba Ang Diyos?” (Is The Lord Sleeping?) for the movie of the same title, 1988; “Narito” (Here) for Kung Tapos Na Ang Kailanman (When Forever Ends), 1990; “Sana Maulit Muli” (I Hope It Happens Again) for the movie of the same title, 1995; “Hataw Na,” for the movie of the same title, 1995; “I Will Be Here” for 9 Mornings, 2002; “Kailangan Kita” (I Need You) for the movie of the same title, 2002; “Ako’t Ikaw” (Me and You) for Mano Po (I Kiss Your Hand), 2002; “Aking Munting Bituin” (My Little Star) for Magnifico, 2003; “How Did You Know” for All My Life, 2004; “Because of You” for Bcuz of U, 2004; “Ikaw Lamang” (Only You) for Dubai, 2005; “In Another Lifetime” for Moments of Love, 2006; “And I Love You So” for movie of the same title, 2009; and “Where Do I Begin” for In The Name of Love, 2011.

In 2003, he produced a video documentary titled Gary XXtreme and in 2005 another documentary titled Symphony of the Heart, which is also the title of his concert at the Araneta Coliseum in 2005. He has performed more than 10 solo concerts since the beginning of the 21st century.

Valenciano has garnered over 150 awards, nominations and citations for his performances, recordings, and compositions.
