Among them are several Aliw Awards as Best Male Entertainer in Hotels, Nightclubs, and Restaurants, 1983; Entertainer of the Year, 1984 and 1987; Best Concert of the Year for Pure Energy, 1987; Best Male Concert Performer, 2003; and Best Male Performer in a Major Concert, Entertainer of the Year, and Hall of Fame Awardee, 2005.

He holds more than 30 Awit Awards, including: Best Vocal Arrangement and Best Musical Arrangement for “Eto na Naman” (It’s Here Again), 1989; Best Engineered Recording for “Babalik Ka rin” (You Will Return), 1994, and “Until Then,” 1998; Best Performance by a Male Recording Artist for “Take Me Out of the Dark,” 1989, “Narito” (Here), 1990, “Gaya Nang Dati,” 1992, “Until Then,” 1998, “Everybody Get Down,” 1999, “Lupa” (Earth), 2001, “Ang Aking Munting Bituin,” 2004, “How Did You Know,” 2005, “Break Me,” 2006, “In Another Lifetime,” 2007, “Sana Maulit Muli,” 2008, and “Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan” (To the End of Eternity), 2013; Best Performance by a Duet for “Muli” (Again), with Regine Velasquez, 1994, “Sana Maulit Muli,” with Kyla, 2004, and “Hard Habit to Break,” with Jed Madela, 2008; Best Collaboration for “Letting Go,” with Powerplay, 2009; Album of the Year for Moving Thoughts, 1989, Shout 4 Joy, 1992, and Interactive, 1999; Song of the Year for “Take Me Out of the Dark,” 1989, and “Babalik Ka Rin,” 1994; Best Produced Record of the Year for “Eto na Naman,” 1989, and “Babalik Ka Rin,” 1994; Best Ballad Recording for “Take Me Out of the Dark,” 1989, “In Another Lifetime,” 2007, “When I Hear You Call,” 2009, “Tayong Dalawa” (The Two of Us), 2010, and “Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan,” 2013; Best Pop Recording for “More and More,” 1999; Best Dance Recording for “Shout 4 Joy,” 1992, “Sa Yahweh ang Sayaw” (To Dance for the Lord), 1994, “Everybody Get Down,” 1999, and “Shake It Off,” 2007; Best Inspirational Recording for “Take Me Out of the Dark,” 1989, “Sa Yahweh ang Sayaw,” 1994, “As You Are,” 1999, and “Ipagpatuloy Mo, Galing ng Pilipino” (Let the Filipino Genius Soar), 2015; Best Christmas Recording for “Hele ni Nanay” (Mother’s Lullaby), 1996, and “Once Again It’s Christmas,” 2000; and Best TV Theme Song Recording for “Ipagpatuloy Mo, Galing ng Pilipino,” 2015. In 2006, Awit Awards gave Valenciano the Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino recognition.

His other awards include Best Male Performer, 1983-84, and King of Philippine Songs, 1986-87, from the Pilipino Artists and Tagalog Singers (PATAS) Awards; Tinig Award, 1984, and Most Outstanding Singer, 1990, from the National Press Club; three Best Theme Song awards from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) for “Ibulong Mo sa Diyos” (Whisper to God), 1988, “Sana Maulit Muli,” 1995, and “Ikaw Lamang” (Only You) for the movie Dubai, 2006; Movie Theme Song of the Year for “Narito” in the 1991 Star Awards for Movies; and Best Theme Song for “Ikaw Lamang” in the 2006 Golden Screen Awards. The Guillermo Mendoza Box-Office Entertaiment Awards accorded him the following recognition: Total Entertainer of the Year, 1996; Best Male Singer, 1998; Male Recording Artist of the Year, 2010; and Male Concert Performer of the Year, 2009 and 2015. In the 2014 Star Awards for Music of the Philippine Movie Press Club, he was recognized as Male Recording Artist of the Year, while his concert, Arise 3.0, was recognized as Concert of the Year. His music video for the song “Can’t We Just Stop and Talk Awhile” won Favorite Male Video in the 2002 MTV Pilipinas Music Award.

Valenciano is currently one of the lead male hosts and performers of the ABS-CBN variety show ASAP. He has also appeared as one of the judges in The X Factor Philippines in 2012, a guest adviser in the singing competition The Voice of the Philippines in 2013, and a jury in Your Face Sounds Familiar, Season 1 and 2, 2015. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab and Elmer L. Gatchalian

VALERA, REY (Reynaldo Valera Guardiano) b. Meycauayan, Bulacan 4 May 1954. Composer, singer, film scorer, music director, television host. He was born to Gregorio Guardiano and Elena Valera, whose three children are all musically inclined. He is married to Bernardita Dulalia with whom he has four children. He learned how to play the guitar from his older sister. While in high school, he and his brother formed a band called The Electric Hair, which played in snack houses and music lounges. Valera quit school during his fourth year in college at the Far Eastern University and accepted work in Japan. When he returned, he joined the parish choir and composed songs for the group.

Valera’s break came when a song he composed for Rico Puno, “Ako Si Superman” (I Am Superman), caught the attention of Chito Ilacad, then a production executive of Vicor Records. He soon signed a contract with Vicor and, later on, was given the job of in-house producer in 1979. “Ako si Superman,” 1977, was his first hit single, followed by “Naaalala Ka” (I Remember You), 1978. He began to write songs for Vicor artists, such as “Ayoko na sa ’Yo” (I Don’t Like You Anymore) for Pol Enriquez and “Sorry Na, Pwede Ba?” (Sorry, Please) for Rico Puno. His “Mr. D.J.” for Sharon Cuneta’s first record started the young singer’s rise to popularity. This was followed by “Kahit Maputi na ang Buhok Ko” (Even If My Hair Grows White). His other singles include “Pangako sa ’Yo” (My Promise To You), “Tayong Dalawa” (The Two Of Us), “Malayo Pa ang Umaga” (Morning is “Kung Kailangan Mo Ako” (If You Need Me), and “Walang Kapalit” (No Replacement). Among his bestselling albums then are Walang Kapalit, Rey Valera’s Greatest Hits, and Hello.

Valera became known as “Mr. Hitmaker” and was appointed executive vice-president for artists and repertoire in Vicor’s sister company, Blackgold Records. Apart from recordings, he also represented the country in international song festivals and performed in shows abroad with other Filipino artists. In 1984, after several gold and platinum records and at the peak of his fame, Valera decided to quit his job and recharge. In 1987, when he returned to music, he chose to go into film scoring. He worked as musical scorer in more than 50 movies, also doing the theme songs for many of them, such as Strangers in Paradise, Hello Young Lovers, Exploitation, Sinasamba Kita (I Adore You), and Annie Sabungera (Annie the Cockfighter) where he also co-starred with Nora Aunor and Ace Vergel. However, the continuing decline of original Pilipino music or OPM goaded him to compose songs once again. Upon Sharon Cuneta’s request, he wrote “Kahit Wala Ka Na” (Though You Are Gone). It was adopted as the title of the movie she was making then and started the trend of using Rey Valera’s hits as movie titles and theme songs.

Two of his songs, “Pangako sa ‘Yo” and “Tayong Dalawa,” became the theme song and title of two popular primetime drama series produced by ABS-CBN in 2000 and 2009, respectively. His comeback album, Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Despite Everything), 1990, turned platinum in two weeks’ time. When Viva Records sought to revive Cuneta’s career as a singer, it was through an album of Valera’s greatest hits called Sharon Sings Valera, 1992. His latest albums are compilations of his hits, one in 1994, a second in 2005, and a third compiling his 18 greatest hits in vinyl in 2009. In 2000, he joined Freddie Aguilar, Mike Hanopol, and Vehnee Saturno in the group called SAGA (Songs and Generations After). The group disbanded shortly after producing one album and a concert tour in Canada. He also managed a children’s band named Saling Ket, with whom he released the album Panghabangbuhay (Forever) in 2005. Beginning 2002, he and his contemporaries Rico J. Puno, Hajji Alejandro, Nonoy Zuñiga, and Marco Sison began performing concerts titled The Greatest Hits. Their group is now known as Greatest Hits 5 or GH5. In 2008, Valera reunited with Eva Eugenio, Rico J. Puno, Claire dela Fuente, and Nonoy Zuñiga in a one-night concert called The Legends of OPM.

Valera has received numerous awards and citations, among them, the 1981 Most Popular Recording Artist, the 1982 Presidential Award as “King of Tagalog Songs,” 1982 and 1983 Entertainer of the Year, and 1983 Most Outstanding Recording Artist and Most Popular Singer/Entertainer. He became the recipient of the Lifetime Achievement for Music at the 8th Tinig Awards for the National Club in 2003, the Awit Awards’ Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino in 2005, and the MYX Magna Award in 2015. In the same year, the ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra also paid tribute to him in the concert The Music of Rey Valera. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

VALLEJO, ERNESTO (Ernesto Arreola Vallejo)b. Obando (now Misericordia), Manila 19 Dec 1909. d. Tanauan, Batangas 10 Feb 1945. Violinist. Born to Jose Vallejo, an orchestra conductor, and Felipa Arreola, he showed great interest in music, and musical ability, as a child. He would watch his father at rehearsals of the Army and Navy Club Orchestra, after which he would play parts of the music he had heard on his toy violin. Noticing his talent, composer MarceloAdonay gave him a real violin as a Christmas gift. His father taught Vallejo the violin and the guitar, and the young boy excelled in both in a short time. He was not yet five years old when he took part in concerts at the TeatroZorrilla and the Columbian Club. At the age of seven, Vallejo was presented by the AsociacionMusicaldeFilipinas in his first violin concert at the Army and Navy Club.

In 1920, BonifacioAbdon, then most notable violin teacher in Manila, became his tutor. In 1921, violin virtuoso Mischa Elman and pianist Godowski, who were on a world tour, were so impressed by Vallejo’s playing that they urged the boy to continue his studies in the United States. With the help of philantrophist Ariston Bautista who gave the initial donation of 2,000 pesos, Vallejo was sent to New York in Oct 1923. There he became a student of Franz Kneisel and Sascha Jacobsen, who had been concertmaster of the Philadelphia Orchestra. The teenager gave concerts to thunderous ovations everywhere including the White House.

Vallejo returned to Manila in 1929 and made his first public appearance at the ManilaGrandOperaHouse. It is said that he so completely captivated the Filipino audience that there was a public clamor for him to perform in other places. His success as a violin virtuoso derived from his energetic personality and style of playing, his intelligent interpretation, and his masterful bowing technique. He taught at the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music and later at the Academy of Music of Manila, and became concertmaster of the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra from 1935 to 1941.

Vallejo, his wife Nona Gebbert, and three children all died during a massacre by the Japanese forces in Tanauan, Batangas on 10 Feb 1945. Written by Antonio C. Hila

VAN DE STEEN, JOHN, CICM b. Berchem, Antwerp, Belgium 29 Aug 1920. d. Manila, Philippines 16 Aug 1987. Choral conductor, educator. He professed his first religious vows on 8 Sep 1939 and was ordained as a priest of the Congregatio Immaculati Cordis Mariae (Congregation of the Immaculate Heart of Mary) on 16 Jul 1944 in Belgium. He studied organ with Flor Peeters and Msgr Jules Van Nuffel at the Interdiocesan Higher Institute for Church Music, also known as the Lemmens Institute, in Mechelen, Belgium in 1945-46; and at the Pontifical Institute of Sacred Music in Rome, Italy under Edgaro Carducci and Msgr Domenico Bartolucci in 1961-62.

Van de Steen arrived in the Philippines in Nov 1946. His first missionary assignment was at Solano, Nueva Vizcaya as assistant parish priest. He was subsequently assigned to the various missions of the CICM in the Philippines: Paco, Manila, 1948-49; Parañaque, 1949-1950; Bontoc, Mountain Province, 1950-1953; and Baguio, 1972. In 1953, when the administration of the San Carlos Seminary was transferred from the Vincentians to the CICM Fathers by the Vatican, Van de Steen served as the seminary’s professor of music and art history. He resided at the seminary in Guadalupe, Makati from 1953 to 1971. When the administration of the seminary was later transferred to the Diocesan priests in 1973 by Cardinal Rufino J. Santos, DD, Van de Steen moved to Baguio, serving as the chaplain of the University of Baguio from 1975 to 1985 and the procurator of the Chapel of the Home Sweet Home in Baguio from 1981 to 1985. His last assignment brought him back to San Carlos in 1985 where he served as the seminary’s musical director from 1985 until his demise in 1987.

It was in 1958, on the occasion of the consecration of the Manila Metropolitan Cathedral, that Van de Steen founded the Manila Cathedral Choir. In 1958, the choir was originally made up of laymen, selected seminarians from the San Carlos Seminary, and the Manila Cathedral Boys Choir. The latter’s membership consisted of school boys from the different Catholic Schools at that time: Makati Catholic School, Paco Catholic School, Malate Catholic School, and the Manila Cathedral School. The choir sang at the regular services of the Manila Cathedral, and at the occasional high masses, ordinations, and important events in the liturgical calendar such as Christmas and Easter. Among the group’s notable performances were the singing of the entire Missa Papae Marcelli of Palestrina under the baton of Van de Steen’s professor from Rome, Msgr Domenico Bartolucci; singing for the opening of the International Music Festival at the newly inaugurated Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in Sep 1969; and singing for the papal masses, together with the Tiples de Santo Domingo who were being trained by Van de Steen’s assistant conductor, Engracio Tempongko, at the Luneta Park, Quezon Memorial Circle, and the Manila Cathedral during the visit of Pope Paul VI to the Philippines in 1970. The Manila Cathedral Boys Choir holds the distinction of being the first boys choir to sing and perform at the CCP with their participation in Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: The Golden Salakot) in 1969. The choir became less active when Van de Steen was assigned to Baguio from 1975 to 1985, but was later revived when he was re-appointed at the San Carlos Seminary in 1985. He conducted the Manila Cathedral Choir for the last time in their concert at the CCP titled Papuri VI (Praise VI) in Jan 1986.

Many of the alumni of the Manila Cathedral Boys Choir continued singing long after they had retired from the group, founding their own adult male choirs whose membership consisted mostly of singers trained by Van de Steen. The most active among them revere their esteemed mentor’s memory by carrying his name, the John Van De Steen Male Choir. Written by Arwin Q. Tan

VELARDE, MIKE (Miguel Guison Velarde Jr) b. Manila 23 Oct 1913. d. Manila 1986. Composer, conductor, musical director. Born to Miguel Velarde Sr, a doctor, and Dolores Guison, he was married to Luisa Guison with whom he had six children. Velarde spent the first 18 years of his life in Zamboanga. When he was six, his mother gave him piano and violin lessons. He studied at the Zamboanga Normal School, where he became a member of the school orchestra. He went to Manila and took up medicine at the University of the Philippines, but later realized that music was his true calling. His father objected. To support his music studies, he worked as a bus conductor. Later he ran a weekly how, Stardust Program, where he sang and played his own jazz arrangements on the piano.

Velarde learned the basics of harmony and composition from AntonioJ.Molina and Ariston Avelino, and deepened his knowledge through self-study. He opened a piano-jazz school and worked as song editor of the PhilippinesFreePress and later of the Literary Song Movie Magazine. When SampaguitaPictures was established, he wrote musical scores for its movie productions and managed its advertising. He also became advertising manager for Excelsior and Champion Pictures. During the Japanese Occupation, he worked as a musical director for Avenue Theater, where his concertized arrangements of folksongs like “Planting Rice” were well-received by the audience. In the 1950s and late 1960s, Velarde was deeply involved in films as musical director, scriptwriter, and/or director. Regarded as his most important works are LuksangTagumpay (Bitter Victory), 1960, which received the Best Picture award from the FilipinoAcademyofMovie ArtsandSciences(FAMAS), and for which he wrote the story and screenplay, and Alaala Kita (I Remember You), 1961. He won FAMAS awards for the story of Luksang Tagumpay and for his musical direction of Alaala Kita.

As a composer, Velarde was first influenced by Irving Berlin and Cole Porter. Later, he created songs with his own distinct style, such as: “Ikaw” (You), for the movie Milagro ng Nazareno (Miracle of the Nazarene), 1935; “Habang Buhay” (As Long as I Live), for Lagot na Kuwintas (Broken Necklace), and “DahilsaIyo” (Because of You), for BituingMarikit (Beautiful Star), 1938; “Silayan” (See Me Through), for Pasang Krus (Bearing the Cross), 1939; and “MinamahalKita” (I Love You), for Niña Bonita (Pretty Girl), and “Ikaw ay Akin” (You are Mine), for Orasang Ginto (Golden Clock), 1940. Among these songs, “Dahil sa Iyo” was a great hit in the country and abroad.

In the 1970s, Velarde’s works included a collection of songs for two revivals: SeverinoReyes’s WalangSugat (No Wounds), 1971, and Minda Mora, 1975.

In 1970, he won the Best Conductor award at the First International Popular Song Contest in Japan, where his composition “As Long as Forever” was the Philippine entry. In 1975 the Philippine Government Cultural Association awarded him the Cultural Achievement Award in PopularMusic. He received the CCP Award in 1986.Written by Menchie R. Tajan

VELASCO, JONATHAN (Jonathan Montemayor Velasco) b. Manila 31 Dec 1962. Choral conductor, educator, international choral clinician and juror, singer. His parents are Tirso de la Cruz Velasco, a former senior state prosecutor at the Department of Justice who hailed from Gulayon City, Zamboanga del Norte, and Corazon Bolinas Montemayor from Santa Barbara, Pangasinan. He is the second among six siblings. He finished his elementary education at San Beda College in 1975 and high school at the University of Santo Tomas High School in 1979. He attended the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music from 1979 to 1989, and studied piano under Nita Abrogar-Quinto and Jose Contreras, and voice under Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. While he was at the University of the Philippines, he sang for and became the assistant conductor of the UP Saringhimig, a choral group which won several prizes in top competitions in Europe in 1979 and 1980. In 1981, Velasco joined the UP (later Philippine) Madrigal Singers and eventually became its assistant choirmaster. While pursuing his studies, he joined the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) and won in the voice category C when he was 25 years old. In 1989, he moved to Berlin to pursue advanced studies in choral conducting, voice, piano, and music theory at the Berliner Kirchenmusikschule as a scholar of the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music and Francisco Feliciano. He also received a scholarship from the Rotary Club of Spandau in Berlin in his first two years in Germany. Under the guidance of Martin Behrmann, he obtained an “A” Level Church Musician accolade from the Berliner Kirchenmusicschule with distinction.

In 1990, Velasco became the first Filipino member of the prestigious World Youth Choir, a yearly gathering of distinguished and select groups of choral singers chosen from different continents, directed by the best choral conductors from around the world. He eventually became the first Filipino and the first Asian to conduct the World Youth Choir, as assistant conductor in its 1993 season, and later, as principal conductor in its 1996 season and its 2001-02 winter session. Aside from the World Youth Choir, he was also invited to be the guest conductor of the Ateneo de Manila College Glee Club (ACGC) in their 2000-01 European concert tours. Under his direction, the ACGC won first prizes in Maribor, Slovenia; Cork, Ireland; and Marktoberdorf, Germany; and a gold diploma in Riva del Garda, Italy. In 2001, upon the establishment of the San Miguel Master Chorale, the first-ever professional choir in the Philippines, Velasco was chosen to be its principal conductor, a position he held until 2003. In 2004, he returned to the Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music (AILM) and conducted the AILM Chorale until 2008, the same choir he had conducted earlier in 1995-99. The Chorale made several concert tours in Asia with him, and a special European concert tour in 2006 to celebrate the institute’s 25th Anniversary. At present, Velasco conducts the Ateneo Chamber Singers (ACS), a choir formed in 2001 by the graduating members of the 2000-01 batch of Ateneo College Glee Club, which specializes in sacred music. Under his direction, the ACS emerged as the winner in the Musica Sacra Category and recipient of a gold medal in the Chamber Choir Category of the 2014 World Choir Games held in Riga, Latvia, as well as the first prize winner in the Habanera Category of the 60th Certamen Internacional de Habaneras y Polifonia in Torrevieja, Spain in 2014.

Since his return to the Philippines in 1993 from his studies in Berlin, Velasco served as voice and conducting teacher at the AILM, and later became its Chairman of Choral Studies and Dean of Studies, until his resignation in 2008. He has also actively been propagating the choral arts through his involvement in numerous local and international choral activities since 1993. These include giving choral workshops and clinics in the Philippines and abroad; adjudicating in prestigious international choral competitions such as those in Marktoberdorf, Tolosa, Maaasmechelen, Budapest, Busan, and Singapore; mentoring young choral conductors; teaching voice; and holding important positions in various choral-related organizations. He has held the position of President of the Philippine Choral Directors Association since its inception in 2004. Velasco is also the lone Philippine representative to the World Choir Council, and a member of the artistic committees of the Polyfollia Festival based in Normandy, France, the 8th World Symposium on Choral Music in Copenhagen in 2008, and the ITB International Choral Competition based in Bandung, Indonesia. He currently serves as advisor to the board of the International Federation for Choral Music. Written by Arwin Q. Tan

VELASCO, NOEL (Noel Espiritu Velasco) b. 25 Dec 1948. Singer, choral conductor, composer-arranger. He is the third of five children of Vicente Velasco Jr and Leonila Espiritu. His parents and all of his siblings were and are church musicians. His first wife was soprano Zonia Elvas with whom he has five children, all of whom are musically inclined, with daughter Jeanne Vicars as the most prominent. At present he resides in New England and has been married to American mezzo-soprano, organist, choral conductor, and flutist Gigi Mitchell-Velasco. He studied at the University of the Philippines (UP), graduating with a bachelor of science in business administration in 1972, an artist’s diploma in voice in 1977, and a bachelor of music in voice in 1979. As a scholar of Imelda Marcos’s Young Artists Foundation of the Philippines, he earned an artist’s diploma in voice and opera at the Curtis Institute of Music in 1981.

A bass then later a tenor, Velasco was a soloist and choral arranger of the UP (now Philippine) Madrigal Singers for 10 years, and a member of the UP Mixed Chorus (now known as the UP Concert Chorus). For several years he led and composed-arranged for award-winning groups as the New Horizon Singers, Ateneo College Glee Club, Maryknoll High School Glee Club, several bank and government choirs, and St John Chancel Choir, the latter being the only church choir to sing at the First International Choral Festival at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. In 1978, he joined the Vocal Ensemble Philippines in its six-month world tour as ambassadors of goodwill and culture. In the Philippines, Velasco’s major performances include Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s Her Son, Jose, Eliseo M. Pajaro’s Balagtas at Selya (Balagtas and Selya), Rodolfo Cornejo’s Christ the Redeemer, Francisco Feliciano’s La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), Puccini’s Tosca, La Boheme, and Madama Butterfly, Leoncavallo’s I Pagliacci, Donizetti’s Lucia di Lammermoor, Ponchielli’s La Gioconda, Bizet’s Carmen, Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, Orff’s Carmina Burana, and Verdi’s Requiem. In 1981-90, Velasco was principal tenor of Sarah Caldwell’s Opera Company of Boston, singing close to a hundred performances in lead roles in La Boheme, La Traviata, Tosca, Turandot, Don Giovanni, Daughter of the Regiment, Barber of Seville, Carmen, Orpheus in the Underworld, Invisible City of Kitezh, Die Soldaten, Dead Souls, Taverner, and The Balcony.

In 1982, he helped organize the Opera Company of the Philippines and sang Tamino in Mozart’s The Magic Flute in its launching in 1983. That same year he made his debut with the Opera Orchestra of New York when they brought Berlioz’s Benvenuto Cellini to the Kennedy Center in Washington, DC. His European debut in 1985 was with Paris’s Opera Comique in Rossini’s Il Barbiere di Siviglia, and returned there and at Theatre de Champs-Elysees for the revival of the original French of Donizetti’s La Favorite which has not been performed for 75 years. He has sung at London’s Royal Opera at Covent Garden in Strauss’s Der Rosenkavalier, and with Welsh National Opera (close to 60 performances) in La Boheme, Lucia di Lammermoor, Carmen, and Rigoletto. In Montpellier, France, he sang with Festival International de Radio France in Donizetti’s Poliuto, Gazzaniga’s Don Giovanni, Bellini’s Il Pirata, and von Suppe’s Requiem; with Orchestra di Radio Svizzera in Gstaad’s Alpengala Konzert in Switzerland, in Rossini’s Guglielmo Tell; with Opera de Montpellier in Bellini’s La Sonnambula; with Opera du Rhin in Strasbourg, Mulhouse, and Colmar, in Koering’s La Marche de Radetzky (world premiere); with Houston Grand Opera, in Turandot; and with Reading Grand Opera, in Il Trovatore. In Rome’s L’Accademia di Santa Cecilia, he has performed Britten’s War Requiem, Mozart’s Requiem, and Rimsky-Korsakov’s Golden Cockerel with Rostropovich, who brought the opera to Kennedy Center and Festival Casals with the National Symphony Orchestra, and Barbican Centre with the London Symphony Orchestra. Through the late 1980s and early 1990s, he joined concert tours of Opera & Concert Worldwide, Ambassadors of Opera, and Artists International in the Middle and Far East. He formed and sang in the Three Tenors of Rhode Island in 1997, an ensemble that performs to this day. After a four-year hiatus from opera, he returned to sing the Duke of Mantua in Rigoletto with Providence’s Ocean State Lyric Opera and Chattanooga Symphony and Opera in 1998. He also returned to the concert stage singing many performances of Orff’s Carmina Burana, Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, Dvorak’s Stabat Mater, and Berlioz’s Requiem in Florida, Texas, California, and Hawaii, through 2010. In 2000, he and wife Gigi sang the lead roles in Carmen with the Prague State Opera. They performed together with the Ural State Philharmonic in Ekaterinburg, Russia, and with Sarah Caldwell in Debussy’s Pelleas et Melisande, Mahler’s Das Lied von der Erde, Verdi’s Requiem, and an Opera Gala, plus many a Duo Recitals all over the United States and the Philippines.

Among the international awards he has won are: the Gruben Family Award of the San Francisco Operain 1980, first prize in the Liederkranz Foundation Wagnerian Competition in New York, second prize in the New York Oratorio Society, and winner of the Luciano Pavarotti International Voice Competition in Philadelphia, all three in 1981. He was a finalist at the 1984 Belvedere International Competition for Opera Singers in Vienna, singing in all its gala concerts with the winners in Austria, Italy, and Hungary. He has received career grants from the Sullivan Foundation and the Cultural Center of the Philippines. At UP’s centennial in 2008, he received a citation for his international singing career from the UP Alumni Association, performing in gala concerts at the UP Theater.

VELASQUEZ, REGINE (Regina Encarnacion Ansong Velasquez-Alcasid) aka Chona Velasquez. b. Tondo, Manila 22 Apr 1970. Singer, television and movie actor, television host. Regine is the eldest of five children of Gerardo Velasquez and Teresita Ansong. Her sister, Cacai, was a recording artist, whose husband, Raul Mitra, used to perform in stage musicals and is now a musical director. On 22 Dec 2010, Velasquez married longtime friend and colleague in the industry, Ogie Alcasid, and they have a son. She finished high school at St Lawrence Academy in 1984 but never got to pursue a college degree.

Regarded as one of the most celebrated and influential singers in the country, Regine attributes her first exposure to music to her father who would sing her lullabies after coming home from his work as a construction worker and her mother who taught her how to sing in tune without lyrics. She grew up listening to Pilita Corrales and Michael Jackson, and jukebox queens like Imelda Papin, Didith Reyes, and Eva Eugenio. Later, she also idolized Sharon Cuneta, Kuh Ledesma, and Pops Fernandez. For eight years, starting at the age of six, she joined over 300 amateur singing contests mostly in the Bulacan area and won the top prize 95 times. She reached the peak in her singing contest career when she won for eight consecutive weeks and became the youngest contestant to win the grand prize in the 1984 Ang Bagong Kampeon (The New Champion) hosted by Bert Marcelo and her idol Pilita Corrales, singing “In Your Eyes.”

In 1989, she joined the Asia Pacific Singing Contest and won the grand prize with her renditions of “And I Am Telling You” and “You’ll Never Walk Alone” and since then was given the title “Asia’s Songbird.” It was while she was a guest on Penthouse Live that Martin Nievera, co-host with Pops Fernandez, aired the suggestion of talent manager Ronnie Henares to change her stage name from Chona to Regine Velasquez. In 1986, Ronnie Henares signed her up under his talent management house, Primeline. In an album titled Nineteen 90, she revived “Narito Ako” (Here I Am), an entry of Nonong Pedero for the First Metro Pop Music Festival in 1978, originally sung by Maricris Bermont. This, along with “Please Be Careful With My Heart,” a duet with songwriter Jose Mari Chan which was released in his album Constant Change, heightened Velasquez’s popularity and led to the success of her first solo concert at the Folk Arts Theater in July that same year. Numerous successful concerts here and abroad followed. She was the first Asian to have a sold-out concert in Carnegie Hall in Oct 1991. Considered a landmark in her concert career was her 10th anniversary concert titled Music and Me, 1996, held at the Sunken Garden of the University of the Philippines Diliman campus, with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, and Ryan Cayabyab as musical director.

She got her first recording contract with OctoArts International with her single “Love Me Again.” In 1987, her first album Regine was released by Viva Records with OPM (original Pilipino music) titles like “Urong Sulong” (Back and Forth), “Kung Maibabalik Ko Lang” (If I Could Turn It Back), and “Isang Lahi” (One Race), which became commercial hits. Her other albums include Tagala Talaga (Real Tagalog Woman), 1991; Reason Enough, 1993; first Asia-wide released album, Listen Without Prejudice, 1994; My Love Emotion, 1995; Retro, 1996; Drawn, 1997; R2K, 1999; Reigne, 2001; Covers: Vol 1, 2004, and Vol 2, 2006; Low Key, 2008; Fantasy, 2010; and Hulog ng Langit (Heaven-sent), 2012.

Her first movie acting stint was in The Untouchable Family, 1988. She appeared in two comedy movies, Pik Pak Boom, 1988, and Elvis and James 2, 1990, and was one of the leads in Do Re Mi, 1996. She acted in Tanghalang Pilipino’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1996, a musical adaptation of Jose Rizal’s novel with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera. She played Maria Clara opposite Audie Gemora who played Crisostomo Ibarra. That same year, she signed up with Viva Films, where she did a string of romantic movies that were all box-office hits, including: Wanted: Perfect Mother with Christopher de Leon, 1996; Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Because There’s Someone Like You), 1999, and Pangako… Ikaw Lang (Promise, It’s Only You), 2001, both with Aga Muhlach; Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw (What I Need is You), 2000, with Robin Padilla; and Ikaw Lamang Hanggang Ngayon (It’s Only You Until Now), 2002, with Richard Gomez. In 2003, she reteamed with Christopher de Leon in Pangarap Ko ang Ibigin Ka (My Dream is to Love You), and in 2006, with Robin Padilla in GMA Films’ Till I Met You. She also starred with Piolo Pascual in Paano Kita Iibigin, 2007, produced by Star Cinema.

Her memorable songs include: “Babalik Kang Muli” (You Will Come Back) and “Sana Maulit Muli” (I Hope It Happens Again), 1993; “You’ve Made Me Stronger,” 1995; “I Can,” 1996, sung with Donna Cruz and Mikee Cojuangco for the movie Do Re Mi; “You Are My Song,” 1996, the theme song of Wanted: Perfect Mother composed by Martin Nievera; and “Dadalhin” (I Will Take You) and “Sa Aking Pag-iisa” (In My Loneliness), 2001. Her movie theme songs were hit singles as well, such as “Pangarap Ko ang Ibigan Ka,” “Hanggang Ngayon,” and “Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw,” which were all composed by her husband, Ogie. Her albums Retro and R2K, which featured her renditions of popular American songs, produced a string of hits, including “I Want to Know What Love Is,” “Looking Through the Eyes of Love,” “I Just Don’t Want to Be Lonely,” “Bluer Than Blue,” “On the Wings of Love,” “In Your Eyes,” “I’ll Never Love This Way Again,” and “I Don’t Want to Miss a Thing.” Her renditions of OPM (original Pilipino music) hits, featured in the album Covers Vol 1, were also popular, including “Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin” (I Will Love You Only Once), her cover of an Ariel Rivera original. Her revival of two Ryan Cayabyab songs, “Tuwing Umuulan at Kapiling Ka” (When It Rains and You’re Beside Me) and “Araw-Gabi” (Day and Night), also became radio favorites.

A longtime contract artist of GMA Network, Velasquez started as one of the hosts of the Sunday lunchtime musical variety show SOP (Sobrang Okay, Pare) [It’s Super Okay, Pal!], 1997. The show ran for 13 years and was later replaced by Party Pilipinas (Party Philippines), 2010, of which Velasquez was also one of the main hosts. She also hosted various music competitions on television: Star For a Night, 2002, aired on IBC 13, and Search for a Star and Pinoy Pop Superstar, 2004, Celebrity Duets (co-hosted with her husband), 2007, and Are You The Next Big Star?, 2009, all on GMA Network. She was also the lead star in four of GMA Network’s primetime drama series: Forever in My Heart, 2004, with Richard Gomez, Dawn Zulueta, and Ariel Rivera; Ako Si Kim Sam Soon (I Am Kim Sam Soon), 2008, a remake of the original Korean series, with Mark Anthony Fernandez and Eugene Domingo; Diva, 2009, also with Mark Anthony Fernandez and Glaiza de Castro; and I Heart You Pare (I Heart You, Pal), 2010, with Dingdong Dantes. She sang the theme song of GMA’s remake of Mars Ravelo’s Darna, 2005, titled “Di na Nag-iisa” (Never Alone), starring Angel Locsin.

In 1997, Velasquez teamed up with Kuh Ledesma in a series of concerts in the United States, titled Power of 2. The success of this concert brought Velasquez to Canada, this time with Pops Fernandez. Some of her most successful and memorable concerts are: One Night With Regine, 2002, held in front of the National Museum of the Philippines; Reigning Still, 2004, held at the Araneta Coliseum; Twenty, 2006, her 20th anniversary concert, most remembered for her soaring rendition of “What Kind of Fool Am I?,” another signature song of hers; Divas 4 Divas, 2008, where she performed with Pops Fernandez, Zsa Zsa Padilla, and Kuh Ledesma; Silver, 2012, her 25th anniversary concert held at the Mall of Asia (MOA) Arena; and Ultimate, 2015, where she performed with Martin Nievera, Gary Valenciano, and Lani Misalucha, also at the MOA Arena. She had numerous successful concerts abroad, mainly in key cities of the United States, as well as in Canada, London, South Korea, Japan, and Singapore. She has also performed and collaborated with international artists like Paul Anka, Jacky Cheung, Alicia Keys, Brian McKnight, Mandy Moore, Jim Brickman, Peabo Bryson, and Michel Legrand.

Among her most notable awards are Star Awards for Television Best Actress for “Lobo” (Balloon), an episode of Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2002; Box Office Queen, 2002, from the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Foundation; MTV Asia Favorite Artist Award, 2002 and 2003; Asian Television Awards Best Musical Special for One Night With Regine, 2003; MYX Magna Award, 2011; Natatanging Alagad ng Musika from Star Awards for Music, 2012; Female Concert Performer of the Year for her Silver concert from Star Awards for Music, 2013; and Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role (Comedy or Musical) for the movie Of All The Things, 2013, from Golden Screen Awards. She has received the following recognition from Awit Awards: Best Performance by Female Recording Artist for “Sana Maulit Muli,” 1994, and “Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw,” 2001; Best Performance By a Duet for “Muli” (Again), 1994, with Gary Valenciano, “Forever,” 1995, with Martin Nievera, and “Habang May Buhay” (Until There’s Life), 2001, with Jaya; Best Ballad Recording and Best Movie Theme Song for “You Are My Song,” 1997, with Martin Nievera, and “Kailangan Ko’y Ikaw,” 2001; Best Movie Theme Song for “Pangarap Ko ang Ibigin Ka,” 2004, and “Paano Kita Iibigin,” 2008; Best Rhythm and Blues Music for “A Single Soul,” 2007, with Reuben Laurente; Best Inspirational Recording for “Lipad ng Pangarap” (A Dream’s Flight), 2013, with Angeline Quinto, and “Nathaniel (Gift of God),” 2014; Best Christmas Recording for “Hele ni Inay” (Mother’s Lullaby), 2014; People’s Choice Best Performance by a Female Recording Artist, 2009; and Dangal ng Musikang Pilipino, 2012. Regine’s illustrious career and undeniable vocal prowess continue to inspire and influence a generation of Filipino singers. Written by Katherine V. Molina and Elmer L. Gatchalian

VELEZ, MANUEL (Manuel Gabor Velez) b. Cagayan de Oro 27 Oct 1894. d. Manila 14 May 1959. Composer, band leader, music teacher. Velez came from a family of musicians and is related to the Roa clan. He was the son of Salvador Ramos Velez and Maria Gabor, who is a descendant of the painter Damian Domingo. Manuel married Concepcion Canania, a sarsuwela star, who was known to be the siloy (nightingale) of Cebu. Manuel Velez was the uncle of pianist Nita Velez Abrogar-Quinto and composer Felipe Velez Abrogar. He studied voice under Vincenzo Gambardella, an Italian, and had piano and organ lessons under Mr Cooke, an American. Velez worked as a pianist-conductor of the Cine Ideal in Manila.

Velez’s first composition was for Junto al Pasig (On the Banks of the Pasig), a one-act sarsuwela by Jose Rizal, performed at the Manila Opera House in 1915. Around this time, he also had other theater and church performances in Manila and Iloilo. He served as music teacher in Silay, Talisay, and Bacolod in Negros Occidental. In the early 1920s, he became the only professor of the Cebu School of Music. Later he led the Hiyas band. Then he organized and directed another band called Mga Anak sa Lungsod.

Before World War II, he established the St Cecilia Music Store, which was the only music store in the Visayas at that time. Meanwhile, he continued composing short violin pieces and liturgical music. In the 1930s, he formed a theater company which toured the Visayas and Mindanao. He also set up the production outfit of Star Pictures which resulted in the first postwar Cebuano film, Sa Kabukiran (On the Farm). This contained his most popular song of the same title. Some of the pieces in Piux Kabahar’s sarsuwela were composed by Velez. His other popular songs include “Lawiswis Kawayan” (Bamboo Frond Tips), “Ako’y Kampupot” (I’m a Jasmine), “Balitaw ni Inday” (Inday’s Song), “Maytime in Manila,” and “Luha sa Kalipay” (Tears of Joy). Written by Hope Sabanpan-Yu, with notes by Jose S. Buenconsejo

VENERACION, ANDREA (Andrea Carriaga Ofilada-Veneracion) b. Manila 11 1928. d. Quezon City 9 Jul 2013. National Artist for music. Singer, teacher, choirmaster. She was the eldest of seven children of Macario Ofilada and Raymunda Carriaga, a voice teacher. She was married to a dentist, Felipe Veneracion, with whom she had five children, two of whom joined the UP (now Philippine) Madrigal Singers. Veneracion had her first lessons in voice and piano from her mother. She finished her high school at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), where she developed a love for swimming and the performing arts. During her college years at the University of the Philippines (UP), she became national swimming champion in the 100-meter and 400-meter freestyle events. She graduated with a bachelor of music degree, major in piano, cum laude, in 1950. Veneracion taught for two years at the Guam Academy of Music then returned to the Philippines to teach at the UP Conservatory of Music. She also finished her second music degree, cum laude, this time majoring in voice, in 1960, under the tutelage of Mercedes Matias-Santiago and Jovita Fuentes. Then, as a scholar of the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines and a Fulbright grantee, she earned a master of music degree, with distinction, major in vocal pedagogy, minor in opera, from Indiana University in 1962. She took courses in opera at the Aspen School of Music.

Organizer and moving spirit of the Philippine Madrigal Singers (MADZ), Veneracion has led the award-winning chorus in performances here and abroad—in operas, radio and television programs, and solo concerts. In 1997, they made history by winning the European Gran Prix of Choral Singing held in Tours, France, considered as the most challenging of all choral competitions worldwide. Aside from concertizing, she initiated the nationwide choral workshops with her team from the MADZ, in cooperation with the Outreach and Exchange Program of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Under her pioneering initiative, the MADZ, under its new choirmaster, Mark Anthony Carpio, continues to propagate choral music through its “Sing Philippines” program, MADZ et al. Festival, and the CCP Hands-on Choral Workshop, among others.

She taught at the UP Conservatory until her retirement in 2002, and also chaired its voice department for 15 years. She held numerous posts, including that of artistic director of Folk Arts Theater and adjudicator in international music competitions. In 1984 she was included in the International Book of Honor of the American Biographical Institute, and nominated to receive the Men of Achievement Award in London. In 1989, she received the Director’s Award for Conductor of the Best Contemporary Piece and Director’s Award for Conductor of the Best Renaissance Piece in Gorizia, Italy. Internationally recognized as an authority on choral music and performance, she was elected vice-president for Asia of the International Federation for Choral Music in 1990. She was conferred the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining in 1990. She was among the 100 artists honored by the CCP in its 1999 Centennial Honors for the Arts. She also received the Distinguished Alumni Service Award from the Indiana University in 2001, and the Gawad Diwa ng Lahi from the City of Manila in 2002.

Chronicling Veneracion’s story with the Philippine Madrigal Singers, poet Marjorie Evasco has written A Life Shaped by Music, published in 2001. A popular version of the MADZ story has been authored by a former MADZ singer, Alfred John de Veyra titled, MADZ: Almost Everything about the Philippine Madrigal Singers, released in 2013. In her honor, the CCP organized a biennial competition among choral enthusiasts all over the world which started in 2013, named Andrea O. Veneracion International Choral Festival. Veneracion was conferred the National Artist award in 1999. Written by Felizidad Z. Reyes and Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

VILLAFLOR, TOMAS b. Cebu City 18 Sep 1900. Composer. He was born of humble parents, and was married to Agapita Cuizon with whom he had seven children. Early on, Villaflor took an interest in music and theater. He composed songs for the plays of pre-World War II Cebuano playwrights like Silberio Alaura, Tereso Cui, Jose Rosales, and S. Alvarez Villarino. He also acted in many of these plays. As a composer, he learned and drew inspiration from other Cebuano composers such as HerminigildoSolon, Rafael Gandiongco, and VicenteRubi.

Villaflor was known as a prolific songwriter composing as many as 10 songs a day, mostly in the danza style. His popular works include “Ako’y Pobreng Alindahaw” (I’m a Poor Dragonfly), “Dapat Magsaya” (We Should Be Happy), “Siloy” (Hummingbird), “Dili Ka Maluoy?” (Will You Not Take Pity?), “Aroy-Aroy” (It’s Painful), “ Harana ” (Serenade), “Gibakwi” (Retraction), “Hikalimti Kutob Karon” (Forget From This Time On), “Unongan Ko Ikaw” (I’ll Go With You), “Pagkalaay” (Weariness), “Damgo” (Dreams), “Gawas sa Kural” (Outside the Fence), “Ako ang Bulaklak” (I Am the Flower), “Pagkamalipayon” (Joyful), “Gilangkat” (Strip Away), “Luhang Tinago” (Hidden Tears), and “Makaliton” (Impetuous). In 1938 he wrote the theme song for an American movie titled The Night Before Last. He also composed the music for the comic film,Bertoldo ug Balodoy (Bertoldo andBalodoy), 1938, the first and onlyCebuano talking picture produced before World War II.

Villaflor performed on both stage and radio. In the 1930s, he toured Visayas and Mindanao with the theater company of Manuel Velez. He formed a rondalla for a Cebu radio station and wrote songs for his daughters, the Villaflor Sisters. Some of his songs were recorded. Written by Erlinda Alburo and Resil Mojares

VILLAME, YOYOY (Roman Tesorio Villame) b. Calate, Bohol 18 Nov 1932. d. Las Piñas 18 May 2007. Singer, composer, lyricist, comedian. He was the youngest of 10 children of Ambrosio Villame, a fisherman, and Potenciana Tesorio, a fish vendor. He was married to Elizabeth Codilla with whom he had seven children. He took up a mechanic-driver vocational course in Tagbilaran City, Bohol. At 20, he was drafted into the army and fought for a year in the government’s anti-insurgency campaign in Central Luzon. Then he became a jeepney driver in Manila until 1965. Although he wanted to be a singer, he failed to win any singing contest. Returning to Bohol, Villame worked as a bus driver and set up a rondalla-combo with his fellow drivers. He played the mandolin and the marimba for the group, but it was his unique rendition of songs in Boholano, Tagalog, and English, which made him popular in Bohol.

Leo Meneses, the owner of the bus company where he worked, saw the prospect of expanding Villame’s audience to the rest of the Visayas and Mindanao and set up a recording studio just for him. Labelled Kinamay Records, its initial output was “Magellan,” 1972, the first of Villame’s numerous, witty interpretations of historical events, sung in Visayan-English. From 1971 to 1974, he came out with four long-playing albums: Kinabuhing Bol’anon (Life of a Boholano), Ay, Loleng, I Shall Return, and When December Comes. With Vicor Records, where he was under contract in 1976-92, he recorded the following albums: Tarzan at Barok (Tarzan and Barok), 1977; MacArthur and Dagohoy, 1979; Harana ni Yoyoy (Yoyoy’s Serenades), 1986; Kudeta ni Bonifacio (Bonifacio’s Coup d’etat), 1987; and Mga Awit ni Yoyoy (Songs of Yoyoy), 1989, among others. He was under contract with Alpha Records where he cut his album, Piyesta ng mga Isda (Feast of the Fishes), 1993.

Among his famous songs are “Mag-exercise Tayo” (Let’s Exercise), “Bukonut Woman,” and “Philippine Geography,” all in 1977, and “Buchikik,” 1980. “Bukonut Woman” and “Buchikik” have been arranged for choir and sung by the Philippine Madrigal Singers as part of their repertoire of novelty songs.

He also played sidekick to comedian Chiquito in movies like Isla Limasawa (Limasawa Island), 1972; Sinbad the Tailor, 1973; and Barok Goes to Hongkong, 1984. His screen appearances include Viva Films’ Humanap Ka ng Panget (Look for an Ugly One), 1988; Wooly Bully, 1989; Kumander Toothpick (Commander Toothpick), Teacher Enemy Number 1, and Bikining Itim (Black Bikini), all in 1990; Once Upon a Time in Manila, 1994; Milyunaryong Mini (Mini Millionaire), 1996; Sis, 2001; and Babae sa Breakwater (Woman at the Breakwater), 2004. Written by Galileo Zafra, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

article_title: Villanueva, Rodolfo (See Madrid, Renato E. in literature volume.)
text: Villanueva, Rodolfo (See Madrid, Renato E. in literature volume.)

VILLAR RECORDS Founded in 1950 by Manuel P. Villar, VillarRecords pioneered in the recording of traditional Filipino music at a time when the local recordingindustry was confined to doing cover versions of foreign pop songs. It initially released foreign record labels like RCA, Capitol, CBS, and MGM. When Pres Elpidio Quirino implemented the import control policy in 1950, Villar saw the opportunity to venture into local recording.

Between the period of the 1950s and the 1960s, Villar Records had produced over 500 long-playing albums and 3,000 singles of kundiman, balitaw, folksongs, danzas, harana (serenades), as well as novelty and popsongs, composed by such Filipino composers as NicanorS.Abelardo, FranciscoSantiago, MikeVelarde, SantiagoSuarez, LeviCelerio, Clod Delfino, JosefinoCenizal, and Manuel Villar himself. With the introduction of cassette tapes in the 1970s, Villar Records and its recording company, Mabuhay Recording Company (MARECO), branched out into cassette tape production. Filipino songs sold in the cassette format became popular among Filipino communities abroad. MARECO also produced a cassette tape and an album of native songs from the Mountain Province titled Kayaw. Among the recording artists who have worked for Villar Records are: soloists like Ruben Tagalog, CelyBautista, Carmen Camacho, DonDavid, LiliaReyes, ConchingRosal, Everlita Rivera, Raye Lucero, DiomedesMaturan, PilitaCorrales, Bobby Gonzales, RicManrique, Merci Molina, and Jun Polistico; singing groups like the Reycard Duet, Kayumanggi Trio, Lovers’ Trio, Tagala Trio, RAR Trio, Tres Rosas, Silos Sisters, Villaruz Sisters, and the MabuhaySingers; and instrumentalists like guitarist Pedro Concepcion, pianist Leopoldo Silos and his Villar “Symphonette,” JuanSilosJr and his rondalla, organist Relly Coloma, and trumpeteer Romy Francisco.

After his retirement, Villar passed on the management of the company to his six children: Alan and Willie now manage A & W Records, Ronnie and Jun have Villar’s MARECO, while Peter and Rosemarie supervise the release of A & W labels abroad. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

VILLENA, MEL (Mel Bragado Villena) b. 10 Sep 1959. Band leader, arranger, music director, and saxophone player. He is the son of Luis Villena and Rosalina Bragado. Both his parents were music aficionados while a maternal aunt delved into classical music and opera-style training during her younger days but none of them turned out to be professional musicians. He was a student of the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music in the late 1970s where he met his future wife, Eleanor “Nori” Perez, a composition major. They have four children who are all musically inclined. His eldest daughter Ria, graduated with a bachelor’s degree in music, major in composition, from UP. His twin sons Mark, a drummer, and Miko, a bass player, and his youngest Joshua, a guitarist, are all developing their skills as professional musicians.

In grade school, he played Beatles’ tunes on an acoustic guitar, while whiling his time away on the street corner near his home. Then he turned to the organ, which introduced him to formal music training, prior to picking up the baritone euphonium which he played in the schools’ marching band for eight years. A host of other instruments followed, like the soprano, tenor, and baritone saxophones, the piano and synthesizer, and the diatonic harmonica, more commonly called the blues harp. Pop groups of the 1960s first grabbed his attention, then rock music of the 1970s, until he reached seventh grade when his interests turned to more progressive genres interspersed with a lot of blues. Jazz in the form of big band music came in high school, inspired by legends Duke Ellington and Count Basie. He joined the La Salle Green Hills performing group Kundirana, leading it for two years, while honing his skills as an arranger.

Taking music more seriously, he enrolled at the UP College of Music from 1977 to 1982. Here he met Eliseo Clamor and decided that the baritone sax and jazz music would be the instruments for his career. He eventually joined the UP Jazz Octet, which later evolved into the UP Jazz Ensemble. This is the stage he considered as the most important in his development as a budding musical director and arranger. His first big break came when RPN 9 hired him as the musical director of the comedy series Champoy in 1982 and later NAKUH! Eto Na Po Sila (Oh No! Here They Come). He was also the musical director of GMA Network’s Pare and Pare (Dude and Dude), ABC 5’s Philippine Idol, and ABS-CBN’s The Zsa Zsa Padilla Show, The Sharon Cuneta Show, Twist and Shout, and The Singing Bee. Continuously exposed to music making in the TV industry, he worked with celebrities, such as the comedy duo, Noel Trinidad and Subas Herrero, Mitch Valdes, Cherie Gil, Tessie Tomas, Apo Hiking Society, Sharon Cuneta, Zsa Zsa Padilla, Kuh Ledesma, Regine Velasquez, Gary Valenciano, Martin Nievera, Michael V., and Ogie Alcasid.

In 1995, as a highly acclaimed arranger-musical director, he was bestowed the Awit Award and the Katha Award, and, more recently in 2012, the Aliw Award for Best Musical Director for a Live Act. Villena was musical director of three ASEAN Song Festivals and was a bandleader for numerous foreign visiting acts. He has also been the conductor, musical arranger, and baritone sax player of the AMP Big Band and the AMP Jazz Nonet. Written by Richie Quirino

VIRAY, GAMALIEL (Gamaliel Reyes Viray) aka Gamy Viray. b. Makato, Aklan 29 Dec 1944. d. 19 Oct 2010. Baritone, theater and film actor, and radio host. He was one of four children of Anatalio Viray and Luz Reyes. He was married to theater and film actor Amable Quiambao with whom he had a son, Ishmael. He became interested in singing after listening to the records of Mario Lanza. When he was in fourth grade, he joined church choirs, where he received vocal training. While taking up agriculture at the Silliman University, he had his first formal lessons in voice. Later, when he transferred to the University of the Philippines (UP) in Los Baños, Viray was awarded a scholarship by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines. He was trained by JovitaFuentes and graduated from the Centro Escolar University Conservatory of Music in 1977. He trained further under Inez Zialcita, AurelioEstanislao, and IsangTapales, and took master lessons under visiting voice professors. In the 1970s, he trained with Sarah Caldwell’s Opera Company of Boston, and had an American debut as Burundai in Rimsky-Korsakov’s The Invisible City of Kitezh, 1983. Viray has also done stage direction, choral conducting, and nonmusical performances for some theater companies. He was at one time the choir director of the National City United Church of Christ Chancel Choir and a voice teacher at Santa Isabel College.

In the mid-1970s, Viray was finalist at the international voice competition in Toulouse, France, and in the Francisco Viñas Song Competition held in Spain. A baritone, he took part in almost all the operas produced in the Philippines since the 1970s. He sang in Madame Butterfly, La Boheme, Aida, La Traviata, Carmen, L’Amico Fritz, La Gioconda, Turandot, I Pagliacci, Tosca, Cavalleria Rusticana, Gianni Schicchi, The Merry Wives of Windsor, and LaLobaNegra (The Black She-wolf). In 2003, he took part in the opera Lord Takayama Ukon by Fr Manuel P. Maramba. He acted as Don Antonio in the opera Spolarium, with libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio and music by Ryan Cayabyab. He also performed in the sarsuwela WalangSugat (No Wounds), 1970, AngKiri (The Flirt), 1974, Filipinas para los Filipinos (Philippines for the Filipinos), 1982, and DalagangBukid (Country Maiden), 1987. Viray was part of the cast of the sarsuwela Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang (My Country, One More Step), with music by Lucio D. San Pedro in 2002. He performed with Teatro Pilipino, Tanghalang Pilipino, and Bulwagang Gantimpala, among others. He had solo recitals in the Cultural Center of the Philippines and was one of the The Three Baritones in the 1990s, along with Elmo Makil and Emmanuel Gregorio.

Viray was also a character actor in various TV series and action, drama, and comedy films: The Secret of the Sacred Forest, 1970; Working Girls and Baby Tsina (China Baby), 1984; Hinugot sa Langit (Wrenched from Heaven), 1985; A Dangerous Life, 1988; Pahiram ng Isang Umaga (Lend Me One Morning), 1989; Hulihin si Nardong Toothpick (Arrest Nardong Toothpick) and Nagsimula sa Puso (It Began from the Heart), 1990; Mabuting Kaibigan, Masamang Kaaway (Good Friend, Bad Enemy), Sa Kabila ng Lahat (Beyond Everything), and Makiusap sa Diyos (Beseech God), 1991; Lucio Margallo and Jesus dela Cruz at ang mga Batang Riles (Jesus dela Cruz and the Railroad Children), 1992; Sala sa Init, Sala sa Lamig (Neither Hot Nor Cold) and Masahol Pa sa Hayop (Worse Than an Animal), 1993; Hindi Pa Tapos ang Laban (The Fight Has Not Ended) and Separada (Separated Woman), 1994; Dahas (Violence) and Eskapo (Escape), 1995; Madrasta (Stepmother), Bakit May Kahapon Pa (Why There is Yesterday), Mula Noon Hanggang Ngayon (From Then Until Now), and Istokwa (Stowaway), 1996; Kahit Kailan (Whenever), 1997; Hinahanap-Hanap Kita (I Keep Looking For You) and Suspek (Suspect), 1999; Kaaway Hanggang Hukay (Enemy to the Grave), 2001; Masamang Ugat (Bad Roots), 2003; and Kaleldo (Summer Heat) and Ang Pamana (The Legacy), 2006. He appeared in the TV series Maalala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 2001-2006. Written by Felizidad Z. Reyes, updated by Josephine Baradas

VIRTUOSO, PABLO (Pablo Cabatino) b. 1921.d. ca 1980. Guitarist, comedian, actor. He grew up in the slums of Pasil, Cebu and had no schooling beyond grade school. In 1936, he went to Manila and earned a living by shining shoes and selling newspapers at Plaza Goiti and Plaza Santa Cruz. A skillful guitarist, he would play on the sidewalk to the delight of American soldiers. After World War II, Virtuoso appeared in stage shows at the Clover and at the ManilaGrandOperaHouse. He also performed on radio and did some recordings. He played a wide range of pieces: opera, classical music, jazz, rhumbas, marches, kundiman, and balitaw. In the 1950s, he appeared in musicalfilms, comedies and dramas, among them, Dandansoy (Unfaithful), with Visayan stars Tony Cruz Jr and Rebecca Torres. In the 1960s, he composed the score for Kasal O Sakal (Wedding or Wrangling), Apat Na Takas (Four Jailbreakers), Apat na Maton (Four Bullies), and had more frequent appearance as an actor in countless films with Fernando Poe Jr and Dencio Padilla. Written by Erlinda Alburo, with additional notes by Jose S. Buenconsejo

VITO, IÑIGO (Iñigo Galing Vito) b. Pakil, Laguna 1 Jun 1921. d. 15 Jun 2010. Musician, community cultural organizer, historian. He is considered the foremost culture bearer of the town of Pakil, Laguna. His parents were Pedro Espina Vito, a sacristan, and Mercedes Martinez Galing, a laundrywoman of a priest. His parents were steeped in the local knowledge of the Southern Tagalog region. His uncle, Ricardo Vito, was a priest, and his sister, Erudita Vito, was a cantora (female singer) in church.

He finished his sixth grade at Pangil Elementary School and seventh grade at Paco Catholic School in Manila with honors. He studied for the priesthood at the Franciscan Seminario-Colegio Serafico from 1935 to 1939. He studied the Solfeo de Eslava up to lesson 17 under a teacher and the succeeding lessons by himself. His seminary training, however, was not completed due to ill health. He studied at Araullo High School in Manila after years of seminary life. However, after two years in high school, he went back to Pakil due to the onset of World War II. After the war, he began teaching in various schools and colleges in Pakil. In 1946, he established the Dorado Barrio School in Banilan, Laguna where he taught until 1951. While teaching, he studied at the Union College in Santa Cruz, Laguna where he obtained a bachelor of science degree in education and a master of arts degree in education (non-thesis track). On 27 Nov 1947, he married Alodia Macabasco Ybardolaza, a native of Pakil, a cantora in church, and classmate in elementary school. They had 10 children.

He rearranged the lyrics of “Awit ng Turumba” (Song of Turumba) from balse (three-four time signature) to a marcha (two-four and four-four time signature), and revised some lines of the lyrics of the song. He started to invite people from the neighboring towns to attend the Turumba procession. He also began directing the reenactment of the finding of the image of Our Lady of Virgin of Sorrows at the Laguna de Bay, where he also served as the narrator. He became a member and officer of the Banda Dos of Pakil in 1945 where he played the bajo (bass). He was the hermano (male leader) of the Flores in 1946. In 1958, he went back to teaching and served as a classroom teacher and district coordinator. He retired from teaching in 1984. He also taught Spanish and music at the Eastern College in Paete from 1967 to 1989. He was well versed in Spanish, Latin, Filipino, and English, and wrote in all four languages.

His lifelong interest in local history and culture led him to champion the preservation of tradition in both church and civic life. He served the town as first councilor in the Municipal Council and, later, Chairman of the Pakil Committee on History, Culture and Research for many decades. He was active in the San Pedro de Alcantara Parish as the chairman of the Liturgy Committee and the Committee on Evangelism. He served as president of Parish Pastoral Council for several years. Scholars and students of local culture in Pakil invariably sought his counsel and advice on matters concerning the history and culture of the town and its tradition of theater, music, dance, ritual, and devotional practice. His work with younger scholars, among them Elena Rivera Mirano and Jerry Respeto, assured the transmission, documentation, and retrieval of old traditions in Laguna. He was instrumental in keeping the memory of Marcelo Adonay alive in Pakil, recovering and keeping the composer’s music manuscripts safe, tracing his family tree, and organizing the yearly Adonay Day celebrations in the town. In recognition of his unflagging efforts, Vito was recognized as the Outstanding Senior Citizen for Volunteer Service by the Department of Social Work and Community Development in 1989. His family was also acknowledged as the Philippine Centennial Model Family for the Province of Laguna in 1998. Written by Elena Rivera Mirano and Jerry Respeto

VST & CO. (VST & Company) This all-male group, which specialized in Pinoy disco and pop rock, was formed by Vicente “Tito” C. Sotto III, Marvic “Vic” Sotto, Valmar “Val” Sotto, and Spanky Rigor in 1978, thus the acronym V (for Vic and Val), S (for Spanky), and T (for Tito). Their dance songs were part of the repertory of Manila Sound in the late 1970s, a repertory of Filipinized pop music characterized by its lightheartedness, with romantic lyrics in colloquial Tagalog-English or Taglish. Formed to counteract the famed musical group, the Boyfriends, the group appeared at the time when the American disco film by John Travolta Saturday Dance Fever was a hit. Their goal was to produce music which the people would recognize immediately as a VST song the way people recognized “A Hard Day’s Night” as a Beatles’ song.

The original members singing in falsetto style were composed of seven males, all moustached except for Vic Sotto. They believed that the number seven would bring them luck and success. The members were the Paco boys, namely, the Sotto brothers Vic (lead vocalist, arranger, and lyricist) and Val (rhythm guitar); the “461 guys” from General Lim Street, San Juan or Little Baguio, namely, the Rigor brothers Spanky (bass guitar and lyricist), Male (keyboard), and Roger (guitar), as well as Celso “Chuck” Llarina (lead guitar, lyricist), Monet Gaskell (acoustic guitar, keyboard, lyricist), and Jun Medina (drums) who was later replaced after he left the group for the United States.

The group reached its height of fame from 1978 to 1981. Their hit song “Awitin Mo at Isasayaw Ko” (Sing It and I Will Dance It) was aired on the radio in the Philippines as well as in New York, City at Studio 54. They also did ballads such as “Ikaw Lang Ang Aking Mahal” (You’re the Only One I Love), “Ipagpatawad Mo” (Please Forgive Me), “Etcetera,” and “Kiss… Kiss.”

All in all, VST & Co. recorded and released several long-playing and compilation albums such as Disco Fever and Ikaw ang Aking Mahal/Awitin Mo (You’re the One I Love/Sing It), 1978; Boogie Woogie Christmas Day, 1979; The Best of VST and Co., 2002; The Complete Greatest Hits Collection, 2005; 18 Greatest Hits, 2009; and The VST and Co. Bossa Nova Collection, 2010. An album titled OPM Back to Back Hits of VST & Company & Hagibis was released in May 2012 by Vicor Music of Viva Entertainment Inc. All VST albums became gold hits, selling more than 10,000 copies, except for the second album. The group was included in the two-album set titled Songs of Life produced by Vicor Group of Companies to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the founding of Philippine National Red Cross in 1980. VST songs were also published in The Best of Filipino Artists Noon at Ngayon, Diamond Edition, 2008.

At the height of their fame, VST collaborated with other musicians, like Homer Flores (arrangement and keyboards), Chito Ilagan (bass guitar), Ben Escasa (percussion), Fred Concepcion (trumpet), Boy Alcaide (drums), and Clod Baria (trombone). At least 16 of the VST song lyrics were written by Joey de Leon, 16 compositions made by Vic Sotto, and three songs composed by Tito. The group starred with Vilma Santos in the movie Swing It, Baby. After VST & Co. disbanded, other OPM artists revived and incorporated their songs in their albums, movies, or live performances like Sharon Cuneta, Janno Gibbs, Noel Cabangon, Jolina Magdangal, Nyoy Volante, and Enrique Gil. Josephine Baradas

WITANGCOY, IGNACIO aka Maestrong Asiong. b. 1 Feb 1868. d. 26 Feb 1919. Composer, arranger, band conductor, musician, teacher. He married Sergia Santos, with whom he had three children. He raised his family and spent most of his professional life in Malolos. He studied with the Jesuits in the Escuela Normal in Manila. He played the violin and the piano, and was familiar with all other instruments of the orchestra. At age 17, he was already teaching music to the orchestras in Malolos and nearby Paombong. He also taught solfeggio, violin, piano, and other musical instruments to students from Malolos and other towns.

In 1886, he composed the first version of the “Regina Coeli, Laetare” (Queen of Heaven, Rejoice), a song in slow triple meter, which is sung during the salubong or meeting of the images of the Virgin Mary and the Risen Christ at dawn of Easter Sunday. To the accompaniment of a brass band, it is sung by a little girl in angel costume after she is lowered from the ceiling of a four-posted structure called the galilea and as she removes the black veil of the Virgin Mary to denote that her mourning is over. Maestrong Asiong made three versions of this work. One of the versions is still sung to this day during the Easter Sunday salubong in Malolos parishes.

In 1906, Witangcoy completed the music for the panunuluyan, which is also in slow triple time. This is used for the Christmas eve procession, reenacting the search for an inn in Bethlehem by the pregnant Virgin Mary and St Joseph, represented by images on a karo (religious float) and/or by a kantora (female singer) and kantor (male singer) who will sing their parts to the accompaniment of the brass band. In front of about four or five previously designated houses, the singers plead with the maybahay (houseowner) to give them room for the night because all inns are full and they are very tired. Each maybahay sings his response and turns the couple away, leaving them no choice but to seek shelter in an animal shed, which is the one prepared inside the church where the midnight mass will be held. With the approval of the parish priest Fr Juan Gatmaitan, Witangcoy’s panunuluyan was first performed in Paombong where the Maestro had already trained a band which he also conducted. Because of its success, it was then performed in Malolos with the permission of the parish priest Fr Osmundo Lim. The Malolos version spread to other towns not only of Bulacan but apparently of the Archdiocese of Manila which at that time included many other provinces of Luzon, including Cavite. Today, the Witangcoy panunuluyan is sung at the maytinis of Kawit, Cavite.

In 1908, Witangcoy composed another important piece for another religious dramatization, this time of Jesus’s entry into Jerusalem on Palm Sunday. The “Hossana, Filio David” (Hossana to the Son of David) had six versions, all in slow triple time. After the blessing of the palms, the priest, representing Christ and carrying a palm of his own, leads the procession of the faithful around the church plaza or on the street, stopping at every decorated kubol, a makeshift balcony of bamboo and wood. At each kubol, little girls dressed in white sing one version of the “Hossana” to the accompaniment of a band, all the while showering the priest with flower petals and confetti from their baskets. After the last “Hossana” is sung at the last kubol, the procession winds up in church where the priest celebrates the mass of Palm Sunday. The different versions of Witangcoy’s “Hossana” continue to be sung on Palm Sundays in Malolos and neighboring towns.

For the church feasts, Witangcoy also composed or arranged misa cantada (sung on high mass) and misa de gallo (novena masses before Christmas).

Among the secular pieces that he composed are music for the poems of Pepe Julian, a piece called “Kumintang” which Epifanio de los Santos, another Malolos resident, allegedly collected for the library-museum in Manila, and several balse (waltz). Most famous of his balse was “Elena” which was retitled “Malolena” (Lady of Malolos) when it was performed in the United States. Maestrong Asiong also composed a sarsuwela commissioned by the Bulacan society called Lakas ng Pagkakaisa. This sarsuwela, whose title is missing, was written by Ramon Cruz and featured Horacio Morelos and Vicenta de Leon as lead actors.

In 1913, Witangcoy left for Manila to play at the Sine Empire of Albert Yearsley, together with musicians like Jose Estella and Nicanor Abelardo. Other musicians that he played with in the orchestra were Pedrito Reyes (son of Severino Reyes), Numeriano Lindayag, among others.

In 1974, the scores of the melodies of two versions of the “Hossana Filio David” or “Osana”, one version of the “Regina Coeli Laetare”, and one version of the panunuluyan, composed by Witangcoy and which were and are still in use in Malolos, were written down by Juliano B. Velasco, bandmaster of the Banda Republika of Malolos, Bulacan which accompanied the singers in the performance of these playlets since the 1950s. These scores were commissioned by Nicanor G. Tiongson for his book Kasaysayan at Estetika ng Sinakulo at Ibang Dulang Panrelilhiyon ng Malolos (History and Aesthetics of the Sinakulo and Other Religious Dramas of Malolos), published by the Ateneo de Manila University Press in 1975. At that time, the original copies of the compositions of Maestro Asiong were in the care of his daughter Irene W. Cruz, who would lend out copies of the Maestro’s masses to Luis Witangcoy Santos, a relative, so that these could be performed with a small orchestra and a group of singers on Christmas eve and other important religious festivities. The daughter also kept the Maestro’s arrangements of musical pieces for the different instruments of the orchestra. Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

WOLFGANG This hard rock, heavy metal, grunge band was founded in Jan 1992. Having been influenced by the early 1990s rock band Razorback, Wolf Gemora (born Leslie Gemora) formed Wolfgang together with guitarist Manuel Legarda. They recruited Basti Artadi (born Sebastian Artadi) as vocalist who was at that time with the band Sin City. Mon Legaspi completed the group as their bassist.

The band released their album Wolfgang under Ivory Music, which reached platinum status in less than a year. Artadi, Gemora, and Legarda were individually nominated at the 1995 NU107 Rock Awards, where the band was also nominated as best new artist and best live act, while Legarda won as Guitarist of the Year. The second album titled Semenelin, 1996, reached almost double platinum status (80,000 albums sold) released under Sony Music Entertainment Philippines. This album was named Album of the Year, and was released as an all-English version in the United States. Wurm, 1997, the third album, reached platinum status. All songs in the album are composed in English and the album was released in Japan early in 1998. The fourth album Serve in Silence received nominations and awards as well, but did not achieve an international release. In 2000, Wolfgang released a live concert album Acoustica, with their previous original songs arranged in the acoustic style. Their final album before going on hiatus was Black Mantra, 2001, which included hits such as “No Falter” and “Bow Unto Thee.” Among their other popular hits are “Darkness Fell,” “Halik ni Hudas” (Judas’s Kiss), and “Natutulog Kong Mundo” (My Sleeping World).

In Jan 2007, members of Wolfgang and Razorback performed at a reunion concert at the Music Museum. Basti Artadi, Mon Legaspi, and Manuel Legarda of the original line-up were present, but Wolf Gemora was unable to join because he had already migrated to the United States and was committed to his new California-based band Lokomotiv. In Dec 2008, Wolfgang, with Francis Aquino playing drums, released their sixth studio album Villains under Semenelin Music. Their seventh album Ang Bagong Dugo sa Lumang Ugat (The New Blood in the Old Vein) is produced in Tagalog and features the single “Sandata” (Weapon). Written by Cristina Maria P. Cayabyab

YATCO, OSCAR (Oscar Clemente Flores Yatco) b. Tanauan, Batangas 23 Nov 1931 d. Hanover, Germany 1 Jul 2014. Conductor, violinist, teacher. His father, Alfredo Yatco of Tanauan was former governor of the Rehabilitation Finance Corporation; his mother, Jacinta Flores of Alaminos, Laguna, graduated in piano from the Colegio de Santa Rosa in Intramuros. He was married to Brigitte Weld, a German, with whom he had three children, Anita, Christine, and Marcela. Yatco was born to a family of musicians and music lovers. He and his siblings comprised an enthusiastic ensemble coached by Ernesto Vallejo during World War II, and later by Bernardino F. Custodio and Ramon Mendoza. Yatco became the youngest member of the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) at 14 when it was reorganized in 1944, and the youngest graduate of the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music at 16. After training at Juilliard School of Music in the United States under Ivan Galamian from 1948 to 1952, he went to Germany to study at the State Academy of Music in Munich under Wilhelm Stross from 1954 to 1960. In 1956, he won first prize in the Music Competition among all-German Music Academies. In 1958, he won second prize in the International Music Competition in Munich. He was a frequent soloist of German orchestras, including the Munich and Berlin Philharmonic Orchestras, and the North German Radio Concert Orchestra. He was concertmaster of the Stross Chamber Orchestra for several seasons and a member of the Stross Quartet with which he performed in over 20 countries from 1961 to 1964.

Upon his return to the Philippines, he became the musical director of the MSO from 1964 to 1974. He established a new standard for symphonic music in the country. He tried to reach out to a wider audience by organizing school concerts and performances in Rizal Park. He also sought to professionalize symphonic music performance by instituting year-round salaries for orchestra members. In 1974, Yatco left once more for Germany with his family. Starting out as principal violist of the National Theater Orchestra in Mannheim, he worked his way up to the concertmaster’s chair. He also became concertmaster for the Wagner Festival Orchestra in Bayreuth. In 1979, he was appointed professor of violin with lifetime tenure at the State College of Music in Hanover, Germany.

In 1980, he became conductor and consultant for the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra. In conjunction with Yatco’s concept of orchestral development, the orchestra was renamed the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) in 1982, and was designated the “national symphony orchestra.” Yatco was named its musical director, and served as such until 1997. He traveled twice a year to Manila from his homebase in Hanover to conduct the PPO, as well as to visualize its future and implement its plans. He continued to conduct the PPO as Conductor Laureate until 2009.

To commemorate his 50th year on the concert stage, he performed as soloist of the Khachaturian Violin Concerto with the PPO in 2003. At the 40th anniversary of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2009, Yatco conducted Gustav Mahler’s Symphony No. 2 (The Resurrection), the same piece that the reorganized PPO played in its first concert in 1982 under his baton.

Yatco was awarded the Presidential Medal of Merit by Pres Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo in 2006. Written by Julie Ann Hallazgo, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

ZABAT BAND Gapan, Nueva Ecija. The band was founded by Fr Eliodoro Chico who produced the first generation of band musicians in Gapan during 1820s. Since then, the band has been an essential component in festive church celebrations during Christmas, Holy Week, elaborate Holy Mass, religious processions, and in civic events such as concerts and parades during fiestas. In the early days of the band’s foundation, the bandmaster or maestro was nicknamed “Damusak” (tough) because he was very strict and exacting. They played mostly Spanish music during that time and musicians joined the band purposively to avoid bataris (forced labor), which constructed roads, bridges, churches, and schools as ordered by the Spanish colonial government.

In 1860, the band was named Zabat Band in honor of its new maestro Lorenzo Chico Zabat Sr. He was very active in leading the second generation of band members.
