The year 1900 saw the sons of Lorenzo Zabat leading the band’s third generation, namely, Victorino, Mariano Sr, and Teodoro Garcia Zabat. With the cooperation of these brothers, the band progressed and gained the reputation of being an institution of learning music itself. Lorenzo Zabat died in 1932 and his grandsons led the fourth generation of musicians. They were the seven brothers: Lorenzo Jr, Mariano Jr, Eustaquio, Angel, Panfilo, Miguel, Marcelino ,and cousin Jaime Z. Parungao Sr, a cornet soloist. With the aid of their uncle Exequiel Zabat-Garcia, a composer and arranger, the Zabat Band and Orchestras became more popular in the country, winning several first prizes in competitions in Manila and the provinces.

In 1938, brothers Lorenzo, Mariano, and Eustaquio, including their cousin Jaime, passed the examinations and were admitted to the original Philippine Constabulary Band in Manila. The Band sailed for the Golden Gate International Exposition in San Francisco California, from January to May 1939, led by the famous Col Walter H. Loving and Capt Alfonso Fresnido.

With the continuation of the fourth, fifth, and sixth generations of musicians, the Zabat Band and Orchestra managed to live with honor and respect. The succeeding band leaders were Homer, Danilo, and Enrique Zabat and their cousin Eduardo G. Parungao, all great grandsons of Lorenzo Zabat. With the noble devotion and selfless interest of the Zabat clan from 1820 up to the present time, the band continues to serve the various musical needs of local communities. Written by Rodney D. S. Ambat

ZIPPER, HERBERT (Herbert Westreich Zipper) b. Vienna, Austria 27 Apr 1904. d. Santa Monica, California, USA 21 Apr 1997. Symphony conductor. He was the son of Emil Zipper and Regine Westreich. His fiancee, Trudl Dubsky, a Viennese ballerina, fled to Manila where the two of them eventually married. Trudl Dubsky was one of the leading ballet teachers and choreographers in Manila. He was educated in Vienna, Austria, where he received an artist’s diploma from the Vienna Academy of Music and Performing Arts and his doctorate degree from the University of Vienna. He was an opera and symphony conductor in Germany and Austria before World War II. He was imprisoned in the concentration camps in Dachau and Buchenwald in 1938. In Buchenwald, he recruited fellow inmates who had been in Munich and Vienna orchestras to give secret concerts to raise the morale of other prisoners. He escaped to France, had a short stint with the Theater Pigalle in Paris, then came to the Philippines in 1939 upon the invitation of the Manila Symphony Society. He became the director of the Manila Symphony Orchestra and with the Japanese invasion in early 1942, he was imprisoned again, this time for refusing to conduct a symphony for the Japanese. Paul Cummins who wrote a 1992 biography of Zipper, Dachau Song, said that he hid the instruments just outside of town. When the Japanese were defeated in 1945, he conducted a celebratory concert of Betthoven’s Eroica and Dvorak’s New World symphonies in the ruins of Manila’s Santa Cruz church.

He succeeded Alexander Lippay as music director of the Manila Symphony Orchestra and became director of the Academy of Music in Manila. From 1939 to 1970, he premiered in Manila such monumental works as Mozart’s Requiem, Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, Bach’s Magnificat, and major works of Mahler and Brahms, among others. Zipper left for the United States in 1946, joined the music faculty at the New York New School for Social Research, 1947-53, and served as conductor of the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, 1949-50. In Chicago, from 1953 to 1967, he was director of the Music Center of the North Shore, and was at various times conductor of the Music Center Orchestra and Chicago Business Men’s Orchestra, and music director of the Fine Arts Quartet Foundation. In 1965, he returned to the Far East, directing several musical and educational projects financed by the JDR III Fund in Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, and the Philippines, and guest conducting with the Taiwan Symphony and Seoul Philharmonic. In 1967 to 1972, he was executive director of the National Guild of Community Music Schools. He moved to Los Angeles in 1972 and became projects director of the School of Performing Arts of the University of Southern California (USC). He was director/conductor of the USC Orchestra for five years. Later, he was the artistic adviser of the Colburn School from 1980 to his death. He also managed the In School Concert Program, bringing orchestra to underprivileged children.

Before the World War II, Zipper did some compositions for Radio Vienna and various theaters in Vienna, and a comic opera, Le Parapluie (The Umbrella), for the Theatre Pigalle in Paris in 1939. In the United States, he published two volumes of Choral Series in New York and wrote articles for professional journals. For the past two decades, he had conducted concerts for children in the Los Angeles public school system and on 23 Apr 1996, he conducted his last concert. He is survived by a nephew, Henry Holt of Virginia and a niece, Lucy Horowitz of Boston. Two weeks before his death, Zipper was featured in a Los Angeles Times article where he said that he realized in Dachau that the arts in general have the power to keep you not just alive, but to make your life meaningful even under the most dreadful circumstances.

Among the awards he had received were the Louis S. Weiss Prize of the New School for Social Research, 1954; Presidential Award Medal from the President of the Philippines, 1959; Award of the Immigrant Service League for Outstanding Achievements in the Field of Music in the Chicago area, 1962; Cross of Honor for Science and Art, First Class, by the President of the Republic of Austria, 1966; and Distinguished Service Award, National Guild of Community School of the Arts, 1975. He was the subject of an Academy Award-nominated documentary film in 1996 titled Never Give Up: The 20th Century Odyssey of Herbert Zipper, written and directed by Terry Sanders. The Herbert Zipper Concert Hall in Colburn School is named after his honor and serves as a performance space for Colburn students, visiting artists, and ensembles. A highly competitive scholarship program, Herbert Zipper Scholars, for students between the ages of 8 to 10, is offered by The Colburn School. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Connie Ladrido

ZUBIRI, BEN (Benjamin Dacayana Zubiri) aka Wenceslao Zubiri. b. San Nicolas, Cebu City 28 Sep 1911. d. 9 Nov 1969. Composer, actor, radio personality. His father, Jesus Zubiri, was a Spaniard. His mother, a Cebuana, was Sergia Dacayana. She taught him to play the guitar at an early age. In Bohol, he met and later married Luz Butalid.

Greg Bacua, a famous Cebuano writer and dramatic actor, discovered Zubiri’s talents and asked him to participate in his plays, in which he eventually played major roles. Zubiri then joined the drama group of Toting Villarino and acted in the first Cebuano talking film by Piux Kabahar titled Bertoldo ug Balodoy produced by Hispano-Filipino productions.

Zubiri was known for the songs “Karon Ulahi Na’ (Now It’s Too Late) and “Ang Palad Nagbuot” (Destiny Decides). The genesis for these songs can be traced back to pre-war Cebu when a beautiful girl who admired Zubiri caught his heart. The closeness was interrupted by Zubiri’s sojourn in Manila to represent Cebu in the “Amateur Hour” national finals and also to record his songs with Victor Recording Studios. When World War II broke out, he went home to Cebu on the Corregidor, a passenger ship bound for the Visayas. The boat sank but Zubiri made it to Cebu together with other famous radio personalities like Antolin Alcudia, Suix Cabase, George Nator, and Maning Villareal. However, by the time he returned, the girl he loved was married, thus the titles of the songs above.

During World War II, Zubiri joined the guerillas under Col Cushing. While with the resistance movement, Zubiri wrote the well-loved Cebuano song, “Matud Nila” (So They Say), “Ngano Bang Mipakita Ka” (Why Did You Come), and “Pukawon Ko Ikaw” (I’ll Wake You Up). Well loved too were his “Ikaduhang Bathala” (Second God), “Katulog na Inday” (Sleep, Inday), “Tuhoi” (Believe), “Pasayawa ko, Day” (Let’s Dance, Day), “Mito-o Ako” (I Believe) and “Gugmang Gibati Ko” (The Love I Feel).

After the war, Zubiri returned to the newly established radio station KZRC where he sang once more. He also became the director of musical programs such as Haranista (Serenader) and Gabii sa Tirana (Night of the Love Song). He also became the director of Camay Theatre of the Air.

From 1950, Zubiri managed the radio dramas of Philippine Manufacturing Corporation (PMC) starting with Ligid sa Kapalaran (Wheel of Life), a daily morning serial drama on radio and Asa ka Inday? (Where are You Inday?) which aired in the evenings. He also had other morning programs like Sinugatan sa Bag-ong Adlaw (Presents of a New Day) and Mugrazu Time. From 1951, Zubiri managed the long-running and record-breaking PMC Amateur Hour in Cebu, a one-hour weekly musical-variety show. Zubiri’s management of the PMC Amateur Hour, under the pseudonym Iyo Karpo, made him an immediate household name. People crowded to hear his programs which were played in the plaza because the studio was too small to hold the audience. Zubiri’s jokes entertained his listeners and his program also helped to find radio talent.

In 1955, he started another radio program Pangutan-a Ako (Ask Me), a program that responded to inquiries from the listeners. It was a successful DYRC program. He also worked on the weekly Darigold program and the television variety program Channel 3 Presents for three years.

Later, Zubiri had his own television program with ABS titled Ang Banay ni Iyo Karpo (Iyo Karpo’s Family). Then he also starred in the 30-minute radio program Dear Iyo Karpo and Dahon nga Natagak (Fallen Leaf), a radio serial under his direction. He was also recruited by Boie Laboratories to star in the DYSS drama Langit ang Paghigugma (Heaven is Love). Written by Hope Sabanpan-Yu

ZUÑIGA, NONOY (Zeno Obong Zuñiga) b. Quezon City 3 Sep 1957. Singer. He is the son of Oro Zuñiga and Catalina Obong. He is married to Grace Maroket with whom he has five children. He is a doctor of medicine who graduated from the University of Santo Tomas in 1988. He served as the executive director of the National Council for the Welfare of Disabled Person. He hosted several TV programs which include Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (My Fellow, My Responsibility), a public service program, aired over GMA 7; Med Talk with Dr. Z, aired over IBC 13; and Pilipinas Win na Win (Philippines Winner All the Way), aired over ABS-CBN. He currently leads EcoWise and NOW, companies committed to preserve and conserve the environment advocating proper waste disposal and the production and marketing of organic products.

He was a folksinger in the early 1970s before he became the lead vocalist of Family Birth Control Band from 1975 to 1980. In 1981, he rose to popularity via his recordings of three songs by Willy Cruz, “Doon Lang” (Only There), “Kumusta Ka?” (How Are You?), and “Never Ever Say Goodbye.” He starred in the movie version of the last song opposite Vilma Santos. He used to record for Jem Records, Telesis Recording, Dyna Recording, Vicor Music, Columbia, ADC Music Publishing, and Viva Records Corporation. He has also given numerous benefit and fund-raising concerts locally and abroad.

Zuñiga is the recipient of the following awards: Most Promising Entertainer of the Year, 1981, Aliw Awards; Entertainer of the Year, 1982, Aliw Awards; Best Pop Male Vocal Artist, Best Pop Male Performer, Best Record of the Year, Best Album of the Year, 1982, Cecil Awards; Best Male Vocal Performer and Mr. Popular Entertainer of the Year, Guillermo Mendoza Foundation, 1982; Best Male Vocal Performer, Awit Award, 1991; Most Outstanding Recording Artist, Katha Award, 1998; Best Performance by a Duet, Best Traditional Recording for the song “Saan Ka Man Naroroon,” Awit Awards, 1999; and Best Pop Vocal Collaboration, Katha Award, 1999. His album Ako ay Ikaw Rin (You and I are One), 1981, garnered a platinum-record award. Gold-record awards were accorded to his albums Much More, 1983; Live For Love, 1984; Nonoy Zuñiga, 1990; and I’ll be There For You, 1991. Other albums include Pure and Golden Love Songs, 1997; Impressions, 2001; The Love Album, 2005; Nonoy Zuñiga Collection Kamusta Ka, 2008; Nonoy Silver Series, 2008; 18 Greatest Hits-Nonoy Zuñiga, 2009; OPM Side by Side Hits of Zsa Zsa Padilla & Nonoy Zuñiga, 2012; and Beginnings, 2015. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Arwin Q. Tan
